site_title: US: Stocks fall after presidential debate
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, despite better-than-expected inflation data, as investors weighed the fallout from a presidential debate where President Joe Biden's performance was widely panned. The Dow Jones Industrial Average declined 0.1%, the S&P 500 dropped 0.4%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index shed 0.7%. The debate raised concerns about Biden's age and potential re-election bid, injecting uncertainty into the market.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 24, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Trump Media shares climb after Biden’s faltering show in first presidential debate
summary: Shares of Trump Media & Technology Group rose 6% after President Joe Biden's faltering performance in the first 2024 US presidential debate. Trump owns 64.9% of the company, valued at $4.2 billion. Analysts attribute the surge to speculation on Trump's election prospects, with TMTG's shares more than doubling this year. The company reported revenue of $770,500 for the March quarter and an adjusted operating loss of $12.1 million.

images.alt_text: Trump previously started a tariff war with China, and has floated tariffs of 60 per cent or higher on all Chinese goods if he wins the Nov 5 election.
If Joe Biden caps his presidency now, by acknowledging that because of age he is not up to a second term, his first and only term will be remembered as among the better presidencies in US history.

site_title: BlackRock buys Preqin for US$3.2 billion in private data push
summary: BlackRock is acquiring private capital database provider Preqin for $3.2 billion in cash, deepening its ability to oversee risks and analyze data across fast-growing private asset markets. The deal expands BlackRock's Aladdin technology systems and comes as private markets are expected to reach nearly $40 trillion by the end of the decade, prompting demand for relevant data. The acquisition is BlackRock's second major move into private markets investing this year, following its $12.5 billion deal to acquire Global Infrastructure Partners.

images.alt_text: BlackRock views the US wealth market as one of its biggest growth opportunities

GIP said its existing leadership team will “retain full control and responsibility for the strategic direction and operation of GIP and the companies in which we have invested” after its acquisition by BlackRock.
The unit has traditionally focused on providing Japanese clients with overseas investments.
The TXSE is aiming to handle its first trades in 2025 and host its first listing in 2026, James Lee says.

site_title: Red Sea attacks drove 90% decline in container shipping, US spies say
summary: US intelligence officials say the Red Sea attacks by the Houthi rebels led to a 90% decline in container shipping between December 2023 and February 2024, impacting at least 65 countries and forcing 29 major energy and shipping companies to alter routes. Alternate routes added 20.4 km to each journey, increasing fuel costs by approximately $1 million per voyage. The attacks have also delayed humanitarian aid and impacted global maritime shipping, with the US and UK launching airstrikes to curb Houthi activities.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust obtains a S$50 million loan
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust has obtained a S$50 million loan from its trustee-manager, Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management, without disclosing the loan's purpose. The loan's conditions stipulate that it becomes repayable immediately if Keppel Infrastructure Fund Management stops being the trustee-manager or ceases to be wholly owned by Keppel entities. This prepayment could lead to a cross-default on other borrowings totaling S$1.6 billion and affect aggregate facilities. The trust's units rose 1.1% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: KEPPEL Infrastructure - through its wholly-owned subsidiary Keppel New Energy - has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Temasek and Australia's Incitec Pivot, a fertiliser manufacturer, to look into producing green ammonia in Australia for export globally.

site_title: Nike sinks as gloomy sales forecast fans growth concerns
summary: Nike shares plummeted 18.6% on Friday after the company forecast a mid-single-digit percentage decline in annual sales, exceeding analyst estimates of a near 1% rise. The sales forecast has fueled concerns about the sportswear giant's efforts to stem market share losses to upstart brands. As part of a $2 billion cost-cutting plan, Nike has cut back on oversupplied brands, including Air Force 1. The company's shares are set for their worst day in over two decades, wiping out nearly $27 billion in market value.

images.alt_text: Nike expects annual revenue to be down in the mid-single digits compared with estimates of a rise of 0.91 per cent.
Nike is laying off about 2 per cent of its global workforce as part of a plan to slash US$2 billion in costs.

site_title: Russian goods find their way to Singapore as war fatigue sets in
summary: Russian goods, including discounted hair products and chocolates, are being sold on Singapore's virtual supermarket shelves despite the country's invasion of Ukraine over two years ago. Unlike other nations, Singapore has limited sanctions to fundraising activities and exports that could directly contribute to the war effort. Most Russian-origin products appear to have been shipped from China, and Singaporeans' pragmatism is resulting in a distinction between moral perspectives and practical purchasing decisions.

images.alt_text: A woman walking past a Shopee logo in the Shopee Building, 16 January 2020.

site_title: Fed’s rate-cut delay won’t hold back the tide of global easing
summary: Global central banks are moving forward with interest rate cuts despite the Federal Reserve's delayed move, with 155 basis points expected to be removed from the aggregate benchmark global rate by 2025. Only the Bank of Japan will not lower borrowing costs in the next 18 months. Central bankers are adopting a cautious approach, prioritizing data on inflation and labor markets, and easing efforts are turning out to be relatively unsynchronized across regions.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

site_title: Bellingham, Kane rescue England from shock Euro 2024 exit to Slovakia
summary: England narrowly escaped a shock exit at Euro 2024 with a 2-1 win over Slovakia in extra-time. Jude Bellingham's 90th-minute overhead kick levelled the score, before Harry Kane sealed the victory with a goal just a minute into extra-time. The win sets up a quarter-final meeting with Switzerland, following a lacklustre display from England in the first half, which saw them trail 1-0 at halftime. England manager Gareth Southgate's decision to stick with his starting lineup was questioned, but the team's determination and Kane's late goal secured a dramatic comeback.

images.alt_text: Italy's head coach Luciano Spalletti gives a press conference at the team's base camp in Iserlohn, on June 30, 2024, after they were eliminated by Switzerland in a round of 16 match of the UEFA Euro 2024 football championship. (Photo by Alberto PIZZOLI / AFP)
Skriniar (left) says the pressure will be squarely on the English, and that has already affected how they have played at the tournament in Germany.
Fifa's new Club World Cup tournament has also been criticised by the player unions who say that it will put the world’s elite footballers under too much physical strain.
Spain forward Ferran Torres (left) celebrates with defender Daniel Vivian after scoring his team's only goal against Albania in Dusseldorf.
Georgian players celebrate after winning their match against Portugal in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, June 26, 2024.

site_title: US prosecutors meeting with Boeing, crash victims as criminal charging decision looms: sources
summary: US prosecutors are meeting with Boeing and the families of victims from the 2018 and 2019 737 MAX crashes to discuss a July 7 deadline for a potential criminal charge against the company. The Justice Department found Boeing breached a 2021 deferred prosecution agreement, which shielded it from prosecution over the crashes that killed 346 people. Prosecutors are working on a tight timeline and will update victims' families on the investigation's progress. A criminal charging decision is expected soon.

images.alt_text: For months, Boeing has been dealing with production problems in three commercial jets - the 737 MAX, the 787 Dreamliner and the 777.
An Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX was forced to make an emergency landing after a panel blew out midair in January. Alaska Airlines said on Friday it has returned the plane to Boeing.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: S-Reits’ outlook for the rest of the year (Ep 173)
summary: S-Reits, a type of Singapore-based retail investment trust, are expected to underperform for the rest of 2024, contrary to initial predictions. Analysts attribute this to diversification challenges and the impact of upcoming trends, such as changes in consumer behavior and the rise of e-commerce. Despite this, some analysts identify specific S-Reits as winners, highlighting the need for investors to reassess their portfolios and consider alternative strategies to adapt to the changing market landscape.

images.alt_text: In the decade bookended by the aftermath of the Global Financial Crisis and the onset of Covid-19, Singapore Reits had outperformed the Straits Times Index.
VivoCity shopping mall. 怡丰城外观。
There are ways to travel during peak period without breaking the bank.

site_title: France votes in crucial polls as far right eyes power
summary: France held crucial parliamentary elections on June 30, with the far-right National Rally (RN) party of Marine Le Pen expected to win the largest number of seats. Turnout was 25.9%, up from 18.4% in 2022. If RN secures an absolute majority, Jordan Bardella could become prime minister in a "cohabitation" with President Emmanuel Macron. Analysts predict a hung Assembly, leading to deadlock and potential instability. The RN's strong showing could mark a historic first in French politics, with some warning of a "fight against hatred" and a risk to France's democratic institutions.

images.alt_text: The central bank is lending its support to national authorities across the Euro zone which plan to raise capital buffer requirements for banks.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 closed 0.4 per cent lower, extending losses for the third straight sessions.
(Left) Labour Party leader Keir Starmer and Britain's Prime Minister and Conservative Party leader Rishi Sunak (right) spar during a live debate in Nottingham, Britain, June 26, 2024.

site_title: Citigroup urges dismissal of ex-managing director’s whistleblower lawsuit
summary: Citigroup has urged a judge to dismiss a whistleblower lawsuit filed by former managing director Kathleen Martin, who accused the bank of firing her in retaliation for refusing to provide false information to regulators. Citigroup claims Martin was terminated due to a lack of leadership skills and that her allegations about data governance metrics were not true. Martin's lawyer plans to vigorously oppose the dismissal request, calling it "astounding" that Citigroup can claim it is legally permitted to fire an employee who made complaints about false statements to regulators.

site_title: Binance must face bulk of US SEC crypto lawsuit, judge rules
summary: A US federal judge ruled that the majority of the SEC's lawsuit against Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, can proceed. The SEC accused Binance and its founder Changpeng Zhao of artificially inflating trading volumes, diverting customer funds, and failing to restrict US customers. This decision is a blow to Binance, which had asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit. The ruling also provides a partial victory for the broader cryptocurrency sector, as the SEC's case against secondary sales of Binance's tokens was not deemed a securities issue.

site_title: Airbus nears initial deal with Cebu Air for dozens of jets: sources
summary: Airbus is nearing a deal with Cebu Air to purchase dozens of narrow-body jets, worth up to $12 billion. The airline aims to double its fleet by 2035, with the final number of jets potentially below 100, focusing on A321neo models. This deal would be the Philippines' largest jet purchase. Cebu Air has been considering ordering 100-150 jets from Boeing or Airbus, with Airbus seen as the preferred choice. The announcement is expected in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa has ordered 250 new aircraft from Airbus and Boeing to modernise its fleet, with deliveries scheduled between 2024 and 2029.

FILE PHOTO: Logos of Airbus are seen at the Milipol Paris, the worldwide exhibition dedicated to homeland security and safety, in Villepinte near Paris, France, November 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Private equity firm Bain Capital aimed to list Virgin on the Australian Securities Exchange, but the plan was delayed.

site_title: Boeing to buy Spirit Aero for US$4.7 billion in stock deal
summary: Boeing agreed to buy back Spirit AeroSystems Holdings for $4.7 billion in an all-stock deal, valuing the supplier at $37.25 per share. The move aims to fix manufacturing defects and comes after a near-catastrophic accident on a Spirit-assembled 737 Max 9 fuselage. The deal, set to close in mid-2025, reunites Boeing with Spirit, a supplier it spun off in 2005, and will see Airbus take over parts of Spirit for its operations. The transaction is part of Boeing's efforts to address quality lapses and massive worker turnover following the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The DOJ says Boeing breached a previous agreement and failed to “design, implement, and enforce a compliance and ethics program to prevent and detect violations of the US fraud laws throughout its operations”.
For months, Boeing has been dealing with production problems in three commercial jets - the 737 MAX, the 787 Dreamliner and the 777.
An Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX was forced to make an emergency landing after a panel blew out midair in January. Alaska Airlines said on Friday it has returned the plane to Boeing.

Lufthansa has ordered 250 new aircraft from Airbus and Boeing to modernise its fleet, with deliveries scheduled between 2024 and 2029.
Orders of widebody 777 and 787 planes are expected to be delivered in the coming days, the source said. Deliveries of Boeing‘s 737 MAX are set to resume as early as next month, the source said.
The claims are the latest in a series of allegations flagging concerns about the manufacturing practices of Boeing or its suppliers.

site_title: Sydney home values climb to record as supply stays constrained
summary: Sydney home values reached a record high in June, increasing 0.5% to A$1.2 million, driven by strong demand and low supply. Despite high interest rates and affordability challenges, the housing market remains resilient due to tight supply levels. The national home value index has advanced 36.8% since the onset of Covid-19, with Sydney climbing 28.2% during that period. Experts expect the outlook to weaken as more sellers list their properties, particularly in Sydney and Melbourne, which are expected to experience lackluster price hikes.

images.alt_text: Iron ore prices have steadied after China, Australia’s largest trading partner, took measures to support its real estate sector, the report said.
Data from CoreLogic showed national home prices climbed 0.7 per cent in June from May, when it gained 0.8 per cent.
Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the government was "confident but not complacent about inflation in our economy" when asked about the impact of the tax cuts.

site_title: OCBC-GE deal: Here’s what I got wrong
summary: OCBC's offer for Great Eastern to be delisted has raised concerns among minority shareholders, who may not receive a fair exit offer. The offer price of S$25.60 per share is considered "not fair but reasonable" by Great Eastern's IFA. Unlike Boustead Projects, where the offeror obtained 75% of independent shareholders' shares, OCBC's stake in Great Eastern is only 90.5%, leaving a significant portion in the hands of minority investors. SGX RegCo's rules on voluntary delistings require a fair and reasonable exit offer, and it is unclear whether OCBC can meet this threshold.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of the Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern  Centre located in Pickering Street, on May 9, 2024.

site_title: Delhi airport disaster raises concern over Modi’s building spree
summary: A roof collapse at New Delhi's international airport, which was recently renovated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has killed one person and injured eight in heavy rains. The incident is the latest in a string of infrastructure disasters in India, raising concerns over the quality of Modi's building spree. With billions of dollars invested in infrastructure, Modi's government aims to boost development, but critics argue that the projects are wasteful and rife with corruption, and that poor maintenance is a major issue.

images.alt_text: A worker walks at the site of collapsed terminal roof of Indira Gandhi International Airport after heavy rains in New Delhi on June 28, 2024. The roof of a terminal building at New Delhi's international airport partially collapsed in heavy rains early on June 28, killing one person, rescuers said, months after a refurbishment project inaugurated by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. (Photo by ARUN SANKAR / AFP)

site_title: Dog owners consider spending US$50,000 on cloning, inspired by Argentina president Milei
summary: Argentine President Javier Milei has sparked interest in cloning pets, with his use of the process to create genetic copies of his English Mastiffs. The company PerPETuate, which offers DNA collection services, has seen a 15% increase in sales this year, with 40-50 new clients from Brazil and Argentina. The cloning process costs $1,200, with the full procedure costing around $50,000. Milei's use of cloning has made the process more mainstream, with pet owners considering the option to preserve their beloved pets.

images.alt_text: The saltwater crocodile “had been stalking and lunging out of the water at children and adults”, Northern Territory police said in a statement.

site_title: Billionaire Carlos Slim ramps up oil bets amid buying spree
summary: Carlos Slim, Latin America's wealthiest man, is increasing his bets on the oil industry by buying stakes in US energy firms and expanding his exposure in Mexico, where he partners with state-run Pemex. In June, his family holding bought 2.5 million shares of PBF Energy for $113 million, increasing his stake to 14.7%. Slim also ramped up purchases of Talos Energy shares, now holding a 20.6% position in the Houston-based exploration and production company. The billionaire's energy bets add to his busy year of expanding interests in Europe and South America.

images.alt_text: Carlos Slim's phone empire is set to grow larger with the purchase of operations in Guatemala and El Salvador from longtime rival Telefonica SA.

site_title: Euro on track for biggest monthly fall since January, US dollar breaks 161 yen
summary: The euro is on track for its biggest monthly fall since January, with a predicted 1.25% decline, amid uncertainty in France's general elections and potential fiscal expansion. The US dollar has risen to a near four-decade high against the yen, driven by concerns over inflation and US interest rates. A Trump victory could introduce higher tariffs and fiscal expansion, benefiting the US dollar, according to Barclays strategist Lefteris Farmakis.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta were all in the green.

site_title: Australia home prices keep climbing on tight supply
summary: Australia's home prices rose 0.7% in June, marking the 17th consecutive month of growth, despite high interest rates, a cost of living squeeze, and tight lending conditions. National prices are up 8% from the previous year. Tight supply levels are cited as the primary driver of the market's resilience, with prices increasing the fastest in Perth, Adelaide, and Brisbane, while Melbourne prices fell 0.2%. The Reserve Bank of Australia has held interest rates steady at 4.35% for five straight meetings.

images.alt_text: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the government was "confident but not complacent about inflation in our economy" when asked about the impact of the tax cuts.

site_title: When cryptocurrencies meet green cars
summary: Cryptocurrencies and green cars are poised for significant growth as the two sectors intersect. China's green car market, accounting for 10% of its GDP, is expected to increase in tandem with global demand for electric vehicles, which is forecast to rise sixfold by 2030. A new initiative, DePIN, aims to utilize cryptocurrency incentives to encourage users to participate in project initiation, usage, and construction of sustainable infrastructure. By leveraging blockchain technology and NFTs, DePIN can facilitate inclusive finance, accelerate charging station construction, and promote the development of vehicle-sharing services.

images.alt_text: A Bored Ape display at the Bored & Hungry restaurant in Long Beach, California. In NFTs we see the makings of a new, powerful model of digital brand-building.

BYD electric cars at the international container terminal of Taicang Port in Suzhou. China’s support for electric and hydrogen vehicles has been evident over the years, but significant efforts have also gone into methanol vehicles.
BYD sold 1,271,325EVs (including about 4,400 electric commercial vehicles) in the first five months this year, up 26.8 per cent year on year.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 open higher as cool inflation data lifts rate cut bets
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday as inflation data showed moderation, boosting hopes for early interest rate cuts this year. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 rose, while the Dow Jones fell 0.18% at the open. The S&P 500 gained 0.10% to 5,488.48, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.18% to 17,891.10. The stronger-than-expected inflation data may lead to a reduction in interest rates, which could positively impact the markets.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 24, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Thai PM Srettha’s popularity slides as opposition keeps climbing
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin's popularity has slid to a new low of 12.85% in a quarterly survey, down from 22.35% last year. The opposition party Move Forward, led by Pita Limjaroenrat, has gained ground, with Pita's rating reaching 49.2%. A legal challenge to Srettha's disqualification is also pending, with the Constitutional Court scrutinizing a petition alleging ethical violations. The country faces mounting economic challenges, including a rising cost of living and sluggish economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin looks on during an interview with Reuters in Koh Samui, Surat Thani province, Thailand, April 7, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo
The industry ministry says higher exports of industrial products, stronger tourism and government spending supported output.

Sarath Ratanavadi is expanding his empire into virtual banking, cryptocurrency trading and other technology businesses as electricity generation in South-east Asia’s second-biggest economy has excess capacity.

site_title: China’s slump in home sales slows after cities ease policy
summary: China's residential real estate sector saw a slowdown in new-home sales in June, with a 17% drop in value from a year earlier, following government efforts to ease policy measures in major cities. The decline in new-home sales may offer relief for China's economy, which is on track to undershoot its official 5% growth target for the year. While some cities, such as Shenzhen and Guangzhou, saw a boost in sales, the overall market remains under pressure, with credit ratings firms forecasting a 15% drop in annual property sales.

images.alt_text: The continued contraction in China's factory sector poses a threat to the country’s economic growth target of around 5 per cent this year.
The Alibaba IPO raised US$25 billion, the biggest listing ever at the time. Scores of other Chinese companies raised billions in the US over the next few years.

site_title: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments inks S$6.3 million subscription agreement with IFH Technology
summary: Asia-Pacific Strategic Investments has inked a S$6.3 million subscription agreement with IFH Technology for approximately 3.1 billion new shares, representing 14.99% of the enlarged issued share capital. The proceeds will be used to defray costs, repay bank borrowings, and strengthen financial and working capital. The shares are priced at S$0.002 per share, a 100% premium to the volume weighted average price on the last trading day before the agreement.

images.alt_text: APS cited "adverse current market conditions" as the reason both parties mutually agreed not to extend the deal's long stop date.

site_title: Creative destruction, not government intervention, will ‘fix’ Big Tech
summary: The article argues that government intervention to break up Big Tech companies is counterproductive and that creative destruction, a natural process of innovation and disruption, is the best way to address dominance in the tech industry. Historically, companies like Kodak, Sears, and Xerox have fallen to new entrants, and this process has led to increased innovation and competition. In contrast, government intervention can create unintended market consequences, such as stifling competitiveness and driving companies to rely on government support. The article cites examples from Singapore, Indonesia, and Japan, where regulatory cooperation has been more effective than confrontation in promoting innovation and growth.

images.alt_text: Real risks must be big, economically significant events few fathom – stealth torpedoes unpriced by markets, says Ken Fisher.
There are hard and easy ways to gauge sentiment; both now reveal more bulls in the market ahead.
Few expected energy stocks to flounder as they did in 2023, after riding skyrocketing oil prices to 2022 outperformance.

site_title: Standard Chartered partners IMDA to promote digital literacy to seniors
summary: Standard Chartered has partnered with the Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) to provide digital literacy training to over 1,000 seniors in Singapore, aiming to build an inclusive digital society. The training, part of the Digital for Life movement, focuses on basic digital skills such as connecting to mobile networks, taking pictures, and using banking apps. The program has seen positive results, with beneficiaries like 74-year-old Tee Nam Sang reporting increased confidence and independence in using digital tools, and plans to expand to more centers over the next six months.

images.alt_text: The event attracted more than 800 seniors and skills – such as learning how to make digital payments – were imparted using a gamified approach.

site_title: Microsoft’s US$13 billion OpenAI pact faces extra EU scrutiny
summary: Microsoft's $13 billion investment in OpenAI is facing extra scrutiny from the European Union's antitrust watchdogs, who are questioning the exclusive use of Microsoft's Azure cloud technology. EU regulators want to examine whether the arrangement could harm competition, particularly since OpenAI relies on Microsoft's cloud for its AI systems. While the EU's merger rules are unlikely to lead to an investigation, preliminary questions from regulators can sometimes result in formal investigations and potential fines if evidence of abusive practices is found.

images.alt_text: The disclosure underscores the breadth of the breach as Microsoft faces increasing regulatory scrutiny over the security of its software and systems against foreign threats.
Teams was added to Office 365 in 2017 for free and subsequently replaced Skype for Business.

site_title: Why it feels like everyone in the world is heading to Japan now
summary: Japan is experiencing a record surge in tourism, with over 14.5 million visitors arriving in the first five months of this year, a 70% increase from the same period last year. The weak yen has made Japan a low-cost travel destination, with tourists spending a record 1.75 trillion yen in the first quarter. This has led to a 50% jump in US visitors and a record-breaking number of tourists from South Korea, China, and Taiwan. With the number of visitors expected to reach 34 million this year, Japan is on track to beat its 2019 record of 31 million visitors.

images.alt_text: MUFG’s unit sued again in Japan for Credit Suisse AT1 losses
The Topix ended the day up 0.57 per cent at 2,809.63, having earlier hit its highest since the country’s asset bubble burst in January 1990 at 2,821.86.
Weakness of the currency has spurred cost-push inflationary pressure through imports, generating widespread concern among business executives, officials and consumers.
The move has been supported by the Tokyo Stock Exchange’s push to boost Japanese stocks’ appeal'
The central bank expects rising wages to push up service inflation and keep inflation durably around 2 per cent.

site_title: French parties rush to build anti-far-right front
summary: France's far-right National Rally (RN) won 33% of the vote in the first round of parliamentary elections, ahead of a left-wing bloc with 28% and President Emmanuel Macron's centrists with 20%. The RN's Marine Le Pen is now closer to power than ever before, and parties are rushing to form a united front to block her path to government. A second-round runoff is possible in 306 constituencies, and analysts question whether voters will follow leaders' instructions. The outcome raises concerns over immigration, EU integration, and the future of the European Union.

images.alt_text: Former president of the French far-right Rassemblement National (RN) parliamentary group Marine Le Pen gives a speech during the results evening of the first round of the parliamentary elections in Henin-Beaumont, northern France, on June 30, 2024. A divided France is voting in high-stakes parliamentary elections that could see the anti-immigrant and eurosceptic party of Marine Le Pen sweep to power in a historic first. The candidates formally ended their frantic campaigns at midnight June 28, with political activity banned until the first round of voting. (Photo by FRANCOIS LO PRESTI / AFP)
France's electoral system can make it hard to estimate the precise distribution of seats in the 577-seat National Assembly, and the final outcome will not be known until the end of voting on Jul 7.
An offer to rescue French tech giant Atos from its debt, which totals to about five billion euros, has been withdrawn.
Blaming “neo-liberalism” for the political earthquakes that may, among other events, lead to the election of far-right politician Marine Le Pen in France, sounds like an appealing theory.

site_title: Myanmar central bank denies UN report on weapons transactions
summary: Myanmar's central bank denied a UN report stating the country's military government can access money and weapons for its war against anti-coup forces, citing adherence to prescribed financial procedures. Despite this, a UN report found Myanmar imported $253 million worth of weapons and dual-use technologies in the 12 months to March. The report also noted international banks, including those from Thailand, helped with the purchases. Western countries have imposed financial sanctions on Myanmar's military and banks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Military personnel participates in a parade on Armed Forces Day in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, March 27, 2021. REUTERS/Stringer/File Photo

site_title: Italy and Spalletti forced to reboot after Euros title defence disaster
summary: Italy's Euro 2024 title defense ended in disappointment with a 2-0 loss to Switzerland, resulting in the team's elimination from the tournament. Coach Luciano Spalletti was forced to reboot, saying the team needs to "start again" from zero. The loss was Italy's lowest point in recent history, following a string of humiliating performances. The team's future is uncertain, with Spalletti's position as coach being questioned. The Italian Football Federation has urged the national teams to focus on developing young talent to replace aging stars like Kylian Mbappe and Cristiano Ronaldo.

images.alt_text: Georgian players celebrate after winning their match against Portugal in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, June 26, 2024.
Ukrainian players thank their supporters after their 0-0 draw against Belgium in Stuttgart, Germany, June 26, 2024.  Ukraine finished bottom of their group and failed to progress to the second round.
Skriniar (left) says the pressure will be squarely on the English, and that has already affected how they have played at the tournament in Germany.

site_title: Asia’s hot credit market sees record US$1.3 trillion of bond sales
summary: Asian credit markets have seen a record US$1.3 trillion of bond sales in 2024, driven by low onshore borrowing costs for Chinese companies and robust demand for yield. Local-currency corporate bond sales in the Asia-Pacific region have surged to a record high, with Chinese firms accounting for about three quarters of the US$1.1 trillion in local-currency bond sales. The surge in issuance is expected to continue as domestic markets become increasingly competitive with the dollar market, and investors seek to lock in tight spreads and tap into the current appetite for higher yields.

images.alt_text: Investors watch the stock trading board as the board itself is reflected on a counter top at a securities exchange house in Shanghai, China on 11 January 2010.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange's weekly tanker and dry bulk market roundup (June 28, 2024) reported a mixed week for shipping markets. The Capesize market experienced a surge in activity, with demand from South Brazil and West Africa to the Far East driving up rates. The BCI 5TC index rose from $25,650 to $28,557. In contrast, the Panamax market saw a decline in rates, with the Atlantic experiencing smaller losses. The Asia market also saw a decline, with the C5 index falling 0.165 to $11.165. The VLCC market remained relatively stable, with rates for the benchmark 270,000mt Middle East Gulf to China climbing 0.15 points to WS49.7. The Suezmax market in West Africa and the Mediterranean/Black Sea region remained flat, while the Aframax market saw a decline in rates. The LNG market saw rates firming, with interest from charterers and a widening delta between modern 2-stroke ships and TFDE tonnage.

site_title: How Singapore’s port relates to your portfolio
summary: Global port congestion, now at an 18-month high, is forcing shipping companies and industries to adapt, with shipping costs rising to a 256% increase compared to the same week last year. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) notes that shipping costs are a significant inflationary factor, with a doubling of freight rates associated with a 0.7% increase in inflation. This congestion, similar to the pandemic period, may lead to elevated inflationary pressures, affecting asset prices, including Singapore's real estate investment trusts and private equity fund managers.

images.alt_text: There is a great deal of disagreement over what constitutes a fair price for GE, which is the oldest life insurance company in Singapore and Malaysia, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
The adequate preparations for crisis communications could also be a signal to shareholders that SIA has adequately prepared for crisis payments, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
Corporate Monitor’s critical perspective is likely to be divisive, and not just because of the discomfort created for ComfortDelGro’s board and management, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
The bigger and more lasting story for Sats, however, is the integration of global air cargo logistics provider WFS, writes BT senior correspondent Joan Ng.
The Big Money newsletter aims to pull together highlights of the past week in financial markets – helping readers make money, or avoid losing it.

site_title: Alaska Air returns 737 MAX 9 involved in midair blowout to Boeing
summary: Alaska Airlines has returned a Boeing 737-9 MAX plane to Boeing after it was involved in a midair door panel blowout in January. The plane, Flight 1282, made an emergency landing and an order for a new 737-10 has been placed. Boeing has informed suppliers of a three-month delay in a key production milestone for its 737 jet family.

site_title: Can newer business parks be viable when older ones are grappling with rising vacancies?
summary: Singapore's business parks face challenges with rising vacancies, with overall vacancy rates reaching 22% as of end-March. Older properties, such as Changi Business Park and International Business Park, are struggling with vacancy rates of 34.4% and 57.4%, respectively. Newer business parks are being built to address the issue, with the Punggol Digital District expected to contribute over 2 million sq ft of business park space. However, experts warn that the mismatch between the economic life cycle of a building and the average tech cycle may lead to gentrification, and some older properties may become less desirable in the long run.

images.alt_text: Changi Business Park dubbed the “CBD of the East” was a big draw for tech giants including International Business Machines (IBM) and Advanced Micro Devices.
Construction work for five business park towers is targeted to complete by September 2024.
Industrial rents rose 1.7% on the quarter and 7.8% on the year in Q1, while prices dipped 0.2% in their first quarterly drop since Q3 2020.

site_title: Eleven dead in Indian capital after heavy rain, flight operations stutter
summary: Eleven people have died in New Delhi after a record-breaking downpour on June 28, with four of those fatalities occurring in submerged underpasses. The heavy rain, exceeding the city's monthly average, caused a fatal roof collapse at Delhi's airport, disrupted flights, and led to widespread flooding, power and water outages. The storm also caused massive traffic jams, further exacerbating the city's existing infrastructure challenges.

images.alt_text: A man walks along a road amid heavy rainfall in New Delhi on June 29, 2024. (Photo by Arun SANKAR / AFP)

site_title: Wall Street shoeshiners embrace cleaning sneakers to survive
summary: Shoeshiners on Wall Street are adapting to the shift towards comfort in the office by offering sneaker-cleaning services. Following a 181% increase in search interest for office sneakers since 2021, shoemakers are targeting office workers with casual options. Despite efforts to diversify, some shoeshiners are struggling to survive, with rising costs and a decline in demand for traditional shoeshining services. The centuries-old trade is at risk of extinction as younger generations show little interest in learning the craft.

images.alt_text: Companies that forgo hiring and delay promotions for top performers could demoralise their strongest contributors – and, in some cases, lose them to competitors.

site_title: CapitaLand tops buyback table; Heliconia raises stake in CSE Global
summary: CapitaLand Investment (CLI) topped the buyback table, purchasing 2.5 million shares over four transactions in June, with a total spend of S$6.6 million. The company has spent S$273.7 million on buybacks this year, surpassing OCBC. This comes amidst China's weak operating environment, leading to fair value losses and impairments on CLI's portfolio.

images.alt_text: Institutions are net sellers of Singapore stocks over the four trading sessions through to Jun 20.
CSE’s chief executive Lim Boon Kheng expects order intake momentum to remain robust in 2024.
CapitaLand's real estate investment revenue is down 4 per cent year on year for the first quarter ended March.

site_title: India passes anti-money laundering review despite concerns
summary: India has largely complied with global anti-money laundering watchdog FATF's rules, achieving a "high level of technical compliance". The country has shown good results in combating money laundering, terrorism financial risk, and counter-proliferation financing. However, FATF has expressed concerns over India's non-profit sector, advising the country to implement counter-terrorism financing measures using a "risk-based approach". The assessment comes amid criticism from NGOs, who claim the government has misused counter-terrorism laws to target them and policy think tanks. India must address these concerns to avoid being placed on the "gray" or "black" list.

images.alt_text: Moody’s database noted a steady increase in money laundering events across the Asia-Pacific region from 2018 to 2023.
The China Securities Regulatory Commission has approved applications from 76 IPO hopefuls so far this year to list offshore, compared to 80 for all of 2023.

site_title: Wilmar raises its stake in Pakistan edible oils maker to 42.17%
summary: Wilmar International has increased its stake in Pakistan's Unity Foods to 42.17%, acquiring around US$15.4 million worth of shares. The move was made through Wilmar Pakistan Holdings and Unity Wilmar Agro, raising their stakes to 34.84% and 14.08%, respectively. Unity Foods primarily manufactures edible oils, industrial fats, and feed ingredients for Pakistan's poultry and livestock sectors. The announcement resulted in a 1% decline in Wilmar International's shares, trading at S$3.10.

site_title: Xi calls for Global South to play bigger role on world stage
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping called for the Global South to have a greater say in international affairs, stepping up efforts to challenge the US-led world order. Xi emphasized the need for developing nations to work together to promote peace and stability, while also vowing to discuss free-trade arrangements with Global South countries. His comments underscore Xi's campaign to revamp the global governance system and counter what he calls "US hegemony." This move comes as China strengthens ties with Russia and expands the Brics bloc, which has attracted several Global South nations.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping has touted the promise of significant reform several times this year.
Economic uncertainty is fuelling a vicious cycle that has kept consumption stubbornly low.

site_title: GSH Corporation opens 200-room upper-upscale hotel in Chongqing
summary: GSH Corporation has officially opened its first upper-upscale hotel in Chongqing, China, called New World Chongqing Hotel, with 200 rooms. Located in Bishan district, the hotel is part of the group's first integrated hotel and residential project in China. The development marks GSH's foray into China after establishing a hospitality footprint in Malaysia. The hotel is managed by New World Tongpai Hotels Group and is set to benefit from the upcoming opening of Chongqing's second international airport in 2030.

site_title: Buffett donates record US$5.3 billion Berkshire shares
summary: Warren Buffett has donated a record US$5.3 billion of Berkshire Hathaway shares to five charities, the largest annual donation since 2006. The donation consists of about 13 million shares, with 9.9 million going to the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. Buffett, 93, aims to give away more than 99% of his Berkshire-built fortune, making him the world's eighth richest person with a net worth of US$134.3 billion.

site_title: Teamwork will see Slovakia past England, captain Skriniar says
summary: Slovakia captain Milan Skriniar believes his team can upset England in their European Championship last-16 match by relying on teamwork and countering England's individual talent. Skriniar says the pressure on England, fueled by their high expectations and media scrutiny, will affect their performance. Slovakia, led by 55-year-old Francesco Calzona, has a strong midfield trio and a defensive line of experienced players, which will be crucial in defending against England's attacking players. The match is scheduled for Sunday, June 30, in Gelsenkirchen, Germany.

images.alt_text: Spain forward Ferran Torres (left) celebrates with defender Daniel Vivian after scoring his team's only goal against Albania in Dusseldorf.

site_title: Fed’s favoured price gauge slows, supporting case for rate cut
summary: The Federal Reserve's preferred measure of underlying US inflation, the core personal consumption expenditures price index, rose 0.1% in May, the smallest advance in six months, and 2.6% year-over-year, the least since early 2021. This data supports the case for lower interest rates later this year, as it indicates a slowdown in inflation. The report also showed resilient household demand, driven by solid wage growth and spending on services, despite some signs of cooling in the labor market.

images.alt_text: Domestic producers also face the challenge of a stronger US dollar that risks depressing export demand.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 28)
summary: A South Beach project in Singapore combines 510,000 sq ft of office space, 190 residential units, a 634-room hotel, and 32,000 sq ft of F&B and retail spaces. Mixed-use developments have gained popularity post-pandemic due to their convenience. Moody's warns Singapore may be susceptible to increased money laundering risks due to its open economy and high international transactions. Yoma Strategic is acquiring the remaining interest in its subsidiary, Yoma Fleet, for S$18.5 million.

site_title: Large-cap stocks lead decline in Singapore market; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 3,332.8 on Friday, led by a 3.2% decline in Sembcorp Industries. The local banking trio saw mixed trading, with DBS and OCBC down 0.7% and 0.6% respectively, while UOB rose 0.7%. Asia's key indices ended higher, with the Nikkei 225 and FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI gaining 0.6% and 0.3% respectively.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 57 to 43.
OCBC says it will only take Great Eastern private if the conditions are acceptable and in the interests of the bank and its shareholders.

site_title: Del Monte posts higher loss for Q4 FY2024, expects less red ink next FY
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$76.7 million for Q4 FY2024, down from US$11.9 million in the same period last year, due to higher variable costs and warehousing expenses. The company's gross profit margin dropped to 10.3% from 20.2% in Q4 FY2023. Despite expecting a smaller loss for FY2025, Del Monte's gearing ratio remains high at 8.9 times, and net debt stands at US$2.28 billion. The company plans to dispose of assets and improve gross margins through strategic partnerships and cost-cutting measures.

site_title: Amazon nabs startup Adept’s cofounders to bolster AI efforts
summary: Amazon has acquired the co-founders and some team members of AI startup Adept, a company valued above $1 billion, in a move echoing Microsoft's recent deal with Inflection AI. Adept will continue to operate independently, with a new CEO, and Amazon will pay a licensing fee to use some of its technology. The deal includes 20 remaining Adept workers, who have already joined Amazon. This acquisition aims to bolster Amazon's AI efforts, with the company paying Adept over $410 million in funding.

images.alt_text: Under the terms of the companies' arrangement, Microsoft's Azure is the exclusive cloud provider for OpenAI – something that EU regulators want to examine more.
Stability AI has released AI models to generate audio and video using text prompts.

OpenAI had originally planned to roll out the realistic voice conversation experience to a small group of ChatGPT Plus users in late June, but said it was delaying it because it needed time to reach its launch standard.
ChatGPT maker OpenAI is planning to block access to technology used to build AI products for entities in China and some other countries.
Apple unveiled a suite of artificial intelligence features at its Worldwide Developers Conference on Jun 10.
Apple is also expected to discuss partnerships with other AI companies in different regions such as China, where Microsoft-backed OpenAI chatbot ChatGPT is banned.

Aidan Gomez, CEO of Cohere, which is profiting from highly specialised data, says: “Enterprises are sceptical of technology, and they’re risk-averse, and so we need to win their trust and to prove to them that there’s a way to adopt this technology that’s reliable, trustworthy and secure.”
OpenAI has pitched ChatGPT Enterprise, the enterprise version of its chatbot and its AI services known as APIs, to executives at large enterprises.
Amazon’s plans for Alexa including pricing and release dates could be altered or cancelled depending on the progress of Project Banyan

site_title: Apple’s China iPhone shipments jump 40% after steep discounts
summary: Apple's iPhone shipments in China rose 40% in May, exceeding April's 50% growth, despite heavy discounts by major retailers before China's June shopping festival. This marks a rebound from double-digit declines in sales after losing market share to Huawei. Foreign smartphone brands, mostly Apple, grew nearly four times faster than overall shipments, with Apple accounting for over 95% of foreign smartphones. This growth suggests Apple is gaining ground in the premium segment, with the Chinese company closing in on a billion active devices running its in-house operating system.

site_title: Union says Boeing penny-pinching has hurt supply chain
summary: Boeing's aggressive cost-cutting measures have damaged its supply chain, contributing to production problems in commercial jets, according to the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers (IAM) president Jon Holden. The union, representing 32,000 Boeing workers, is seeking a 40% salary hike, health care, retirement, and job security provisions in its new contract. Boeing's efforts to squeeze suppliers have led to quality assurance redundancies, and the union is pushing for significant gains, with a possible strike vote on July 17.

images.alt_text: An Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 Boeing 737-9 MAX was forced to make an emergency landing after a panel blew out midair in January. Alaska Airlines said on Friday it has returned the plane to Boeing.
Lufthansa has ordered 250 new aircraft from Airbus and Boeing to modernise its fleet, with deliveries scheduled between 2024 and 2029.
Orders of widebody 777 and 787 planes are expected to be delivered in the coming days, the source said. Deliveries of Boeing‘s 737 MAX are set to resume as early as next month, the source said.
The claims are the latest in a series of allegations flagging concerns about the manufacturing practices of Boeing or its suppliers.

FILE PHOTO: Logos of Airbus are seen at the Milipol Paris, the worldwide exhibition dedicated to homeland security and safety, in Villepinte near Paris, France, November 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo
Acquiring Spirit AeroSystems would reverse the planemaker’s largest outsourcing foray nearly two decades ago and give it greater control over the quality of manufacturing of its jetliner structures.
Airbus pushed back its goal to produce 75 of its A320 single-aisle jets per month by one-year to 2027.
The first flight is set to depart Singapore for Beijing Daxing International Airport on Nov 11, 2024.
Boeing has told the Justice Department it disagrees with its determination that the company violated the settlement, Reuters reported this month.

site_title: India's Jio, Bharti Airtel hike call tariffs for first time in three years
summary: India's two largest telecom operators, Jio and Bharti Airtel, have raised their call tariffs for the first time in three years. Jio will hike prices by 13-27%, while Bharti Airtel will increase prices by 10-21%. The move aims to recoup billions spent on 5G technology and improve returns, despite the companies' heavy investment in infrastructure. The tariff hikes will boost average revenue per user (ARPU) for both companies, with Jio's expected to increase by 17% and Bharti Airtel's by 6-9%.

images.alt_text: The country’s second-largest operator, Bharti Airtel, emerged as the top bidder, buying 97 MHz of airwaves for US$820 million.

site_title: China Three Gorges invests US$11 billion in desert power projects
summary: China Three Gorges, a major hydropower generator, is investing $11 billion in a 16-gigawatt renewable power project in northwest Inner Mongolia. The project integrates solar and wind power with a 5-gigawatt storage facility. This investment is part of China's plan to build 455 gigawatts of desert renewables by 2030, with Inner Mongolia accounting for 135 gigawatts. The project aims to diversify the company's business as the era of mega-dams fades, and to address China's grid connectivity issues.

site_title: Singapore looking forward to strengthening links with Malaysia over next 100 years: PM Wong
summary: Singaporean Prime Minister Lawrence Wong expressed optimism for strengthening ties with Malaysia over the next 100 years, following the 100th anniversary of the Johor-Singapore Causeway. The two countries are working on projects in various sectors, including health, education, culture, and trade. Wong looked forward to more "win-win projects" and the completion of the Rapid Transit System and the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone. Foreign Minister Vivian Balakrishnan also highlighted the importance of the Causeway, calling it an "icon of the unique ties of kinship and interwoven history" between the two nations.

site_title: Sri Lanka's key inflation rate rises to 1.7% in June
summary: Sri Lanka's inflation rate rose to 1.7% in June, within expectations, as food prices increased 1.4% and non-food items rose 1.8%. The country's economy has been recovering from a record 70% inflation peak in 2022, with a 22% reduction in power tariffs and a stronger rupee contributing to subdued price growth. The central bank's target of under 5% inflation for the next three months is seen as achievable, with the country on track to reach 3% growth after a 7.3% contraction in 2022.

images.alt_text: “We hope that there will be swift progress on reaching agreements with external private creditors in the near future,” says Peter Breuer, IMF’s senior mission chief for Sri Lanka.

site_title: Vietnam’s AI and crypto sectors brace for impact as tighter regulations approach
summary: Vietnam's AI and crypto sectors are bracing for impact as the country prepares to introduce significant legislation on data protection and virtual assets. The new regulations aim to align with international standards and protect consumer data, but may hinder technological advancement and deter investment. The blockchain sector, central to the virtual asset market, faces uncertainty, with authorities considering a ban or regulation of virtual assets and service providers. The move follows Vietnam's inclusion in the Financial Action Task Force's "grey list" and a notable impact on capital inflows. The government seeks to strike a balance between establishing safeguards and avoiding overly restrictive measures that stifle innovation.

images.alt_text: Vietnam-based Hekate has developed an AI-powered chatbot to support Toyota Finance Vietnam in building customer relationships with car buyers and dealers.
VNLife says it processes transactions for around 60 million users and 400,000 partner merchants.

site_title: Not too early to plan for response to spills of low-carbon alternative fuels
summary: A recent 400-tonne oil spill off Singapore's southern coast highlights the need for a well-established emergency response plan (ERP) for low-carbon alternative fuels, such as ammonia. The Maritime & Port Authority of Singapore responded promptly, but concerns over future spills remain due to ammonia's toxicity and unique hazards. To mitigate risks, the Global Centre for Maritime Decarbonisation is drafting an ERP tailored to ammonia spills, drawing from existing ERPs for oil and chemical spills. Industry stakeholders are invited to share expertise to help shape the narrative for safe ammonia use as a marine fuel.

images.alt_text: Workers engaged by National Environment Agency cleaning up the oil spill at the beach in East Coast Park on Jun 20. A Netherlands-flagged dredging boat hit a Singapore-flagged bunker vessel at Pasir Panjang Container Terminal on Jun 14, leaking 400 tonnes of fuel into the sea.
Chee’s comments come as Singapore is exploring the potential of ammonia.
Visitors are gradually returning to the beaches as recovery efforts following the oil spill make progress, says Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu.

site_title: Australia’s resources earnings to ease over next two years from 2022 peak
summary: Australia's energy export earnings are expected to ease over the next two years, with a 10% decline forecast in the 2023/24 fiscal year to A$417 billion. Commodity prices, driven up by the Russia-Ukraine war, are now returning to normal levels. Iron ore earnings are forecast to drop to A$138 billion in 2023/24, A$114 billion in 2024/25, and A$102 billion in 2025/26. Global economic growth remains relatively soft, but demand for Australia's resources, including critical minerals, is expected to remain strong.

images.alt_text: Data from CoreLogic showed national home prices climbed 0.7 per cent in June from May, when it gained 0.8 per cent.
Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers says the government was "confident but not complacent about inflation in our economy" when asked about the impact of the tax cuts.

site_title: Japan's Topix reaches 34-year peak as financials gain, tech rebounds
summary: Japan's Topix stock index reached a 34-year high, closing 0.57% higher at 2,809.63 on Friday, driven by gains in banks and technology shares. The Nikkei also rallied 0.61% to 29,583.08, rebounding from a sell-off on Thursday. The Topix's tech-heavy sub-index surged 0.9%, outpacing growth shares, while benchmark 10-year Japanese government bond yields retreated 1 basis point. Investors remain cautious ahead of US inflation data and French elections this weekend, citing potential impact on the Nikkei.

images.alt_text: The move has been supported by the Tokyo Stock Exchange’s push to boost Japanese stocks’ appeal'

site_title: Australia Treasurer confident Jul 1 tax cuts will not stoke inflation
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed confidence that tax cuts, set to take effect on July 1, will not exacerbate inflation, despite the country's 4% inflation rate in May. The tax cuts, which trim benefits to the wealthy and give low-income earners more breaks, are seen as a cost-of-living relief measure. Chalmers stated the government's strategy is to provide substantial relief while fighting inflation, citing that the Treasury has informed the government the tax breaks are revenue-neutral and supportive of jobs.

images.alt_text: The comments are the strongest indication so far that Meta would take the same hardline approach in Australia it took in Canada in 2023.
Australia's central bank predicts that inflation will fall back within its 2 to 3 per cent target in late 2025.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries announces two non-executive directorial appointments
summary: Sembcorp Industries has announced the appointment of two new non-executive directors, Manu Bhaskaran and Uwe Krueger, effective July 1 and October 1, respectively. Bhaskaran, a 40-year economist with expertise in Asian issues, brings experience from senior positions at Societe Generale and Japfa. Krueger, a 59-year physicist and business administrator, is the vice-chairman of Temasek's Europe, Middle East, and Africa region. The announcement was made on June 28, resulting in a 3.2% drop in Sembcorp Industries shares to S$4.81.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp has an energy portfolio of 21.2 gigawatts – including 14.4 gigawatts of gross renewable energy capacity – across 10 countries.

site_title: Vietnam’s domestic air travel nosedives amid jet supply crunch, soaring airfares
summary: Vietnam's domestic air travel has plummeted by 20% in the first five months of 2024 due to a jet supply crunch and soaring airfares, forcing airlines to slash services. The country's aviation market, once one of the fastest to recover from the Covid-19 pandemic, is now facing challenges with a 19.4% decline in domestic air transport passengers. The shortage of aircraft, combined with rising fuel and maintenance costs, has driven up airfares by 50% in the first four months of the year.

images.alt_text: Vietnam Airlines Corp plans to lease 20 A321 neo aircraft to add domestic as well as regional flights after carrying a record number of passengers in one of the world's fastest-growing aviation markets.

site_title: Seven tips that will make you an ace panellist
summary: A panel discussion can be made more exciting and interesting by following seven simple tips for panellists. These include having something to say that generates business value, managing the discussion before attending, providing an introduction, getting set for unplanned questions, managing stage fright, having a call to action, and avoiding slides. By implementing these tips, panellists can make the most of the panel discussion for themselves and their organization, and create a more engaging experience for the audience.

images.alt_text: Know that the audience is bored even before you open your mouth.

site_title: World ‘failing’ to meet development goals: UN chief
summary: The UN chief, Antonio Guterres, warned that the world is failing to meet development goals, including ending extreme poverty and combating climate change, by 2030. Only 17% of the 17 Sustainable Development Goals are on track, hindered by conflicts, funding shortfalls, and climate catastrophes. Guterres emphasized the need for accelerated action, particularly in securing peace and boosting international finance, and highlighted glimmers of hope in reduced HIV infections, growing internet access, and increasing use of renewables.

images.alt_text: Jakarta experienced the greatest absolute rise in the number of days over 35 deg C, from 28 days between 1994 and 2003 to 167 in the most recent decade.
The 2021 ruling in the Netherlands against multinational oil giant Shell, which was ordered to reduce its CO2 emissions by 45 per cent by 2030, has become a milestone in climate litigation.
The global mining industry is facing growing pressure from investors and environmentalists to reduce its carbon footprint.
Samsara Eco's chief executive officer and founder, Paul Riley, says the company's technology can reduce end-to-end recycling time.
Record temperatures in major global growing regions have delayed planting and hurt developing crops as the impact of climate change intensifies.
Scientists warn extreme heat globally will become more frequent and intense because of human-induced climate change.
FILE PHOTO: A coal-burning power plant can be seen behind a factory in the city of Baotou, in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, October 31, 2010.  REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title:
London’s competitive luxury real estate developers 
up the ante with Botox, weight-loss drugs
summary: London's luxury real estate developers are offering increasingly competitive amenities to attract ultra-high-net-worth buyers, including private medical services, Botox, and weight-loss drugs via an app. Amid slowing luxury sales, developers such as Chelsea Barracks are partnering with concierge medical services like Effect Doctors to offer hotel-like services. These services come with a premium, with Chelsea Barracks' service charge adding over £22,900 to the annual cost of a two-bedroom apartment. The trend reflects a shift in consumer expectations, with buyers seeking a lifestyle through access to childcare, wellness spaces, and exclusive clubs.

images.alt_text: A Porsche automobile passes Chelsea Barracks residential development in London, U.K., on Sunday, March 7, 2021. Sales of luxury properties tumbled 13% as the pandemic spurred the richest buyers to look to the countryside. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: The AI boom has an unlikely early winner – wonky consultants
summary: Consulting firms like Boston Consulting Group, McKinsey, and KPMG are experiencing a surge in demand for their expertise on generative artificial intelligence (AI) as businesses seek guidance on adopting the technology. The firms are earning significant revenue from AI-related work, with some reporting billions of dollars in sales commitments. Consultants are advising companies on regulatory compliance, AI customer support systems, and developing guardrails to prevent errors. While results have been mixed, with some projects experiencing issues with hallucinations and accuracy, the demand for AI expertise remains strong, offering a lucrative opportunity for wonky consultants.

images.alt_text: The current voluntary commitments for AI safety are much like allowing car manufacturers to self-regulate, says AI governance expert Robert Trager.

site_title: ECB wants countries to raise, not cut bank capital buffers
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) advises eurozone countries not to cut bank capital buffers, citing record profits in the sector and concerns about property valuations and debt levels. The ECB supports national authorities in raising capital buffer requirements to help banks absorb potential losses. This comes after lending has slowed in the eurozone due to high interest rates, which have pricked housing bubbles in richer countries.

site_title: Oil eases on weak US fuel demand, profit taking
summary: Oil prices eased on Friday as investors took profits at quarter-end and weighed weak US fuel demand, which fell to its lowest since February. Brent crude futures rose 2 cents to $86.41 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures fell 20 cents to $81.54 a barrel. Analysts attributed the decline to a lack of buying despite key inflation data suggesting the Federal Reserve may cut interest rates this year, which could boost oil demand.

images.alt_text: Carlos Slim's phone empire is set to grow larger with the purchase of operations in Guatemala and El Salvador from longtime rival Telefonica SA.
New European curbs coming in next year, limiting port access, will hinder the current supply chain even further.
Brent crude oil futures settled up US$1.14, or 1.34 per cent, to US$86.39 a barrel.

site_title: Anwar defends BlackRock role in RM12 billion airport privatisation amid Israel protests
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim defended the country's RM12.3 billion airport privatization deal with BlackRock, citing the deal's long-standing nature and the lack of a trade or diplomatic relationship between Malaysia and Israel. Despite criticism and pressure from his critics, Anwar stated that it's "not realistic" to cut ties with any company for links to Israel. The deal, which keeps 70% of the company in Malaysian hands, has sparked concerns about Malaysia's reputation and potential consequences for its economy.

images.alt_text: GIP said its existing leadership team will “retain full control and responsibility for the strategic direction and operation of GIP and the companies in which we have invested” after its acquisition by BlackRock.

site_title: ‘Inside Out 2’ tops North American box office for third weekend
summary: "Inside Out 2" maintained its top spot at the North American box office for the third consecutive weekend, earning US$57.4 million and totaling US$469 million since its June 14 release. The film's success comes despite a 20.8% decline in the overall domestic box office compared to pre-pandemic averages. Close behind was "A Quiet Place: Day One," which debuted with US$53 million, and "Horizon: An American Saga" took third place with US$11 million.

images.alt_text: Movie still: Inside Out 2

site_title: Antitrust scrutiny on tech giants deserves greater investor attention
summary: The European Union has charged Apple with violating its App Store rules, potentially threatening the company's financial performance. This comes as antitrust scrutiny is placed on tech giants Google and Microsoft, who have also faced accusations of abusing their market positions and stifling competition. The Digital Markets Act, which became applicable in May, regulates tech companies with dominant market positions, and its impact on Apple's financials is expected to be significant. As these companies defend their interests, investors should be cautious, as disruption and financial impacts are likely to follow.

images.alt_text: Teams was added to Office 365 in 2017 for free and subsequently replaced Skype for Business.

An Apple store in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, June 11, 2024. Apple Inc. shares rose to a record after it took the wraps off long-awaited new artificial intelligence features, betting that a personalized and understated approach to the technology will win over customers. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Google is phasing out the use of third-party cookies that advertisers use to track consumers in order to protect consumer privacy.

site_title: US dollar slightly weaker on declining inflation
summary: The US dollar slightly weakened on Friday after data showed inflation in the US subsided in May, indicating the Federal Reserve may start cutting interest rates this year. The dollar initially fell against the yen but edged higher to trade flat on the day. The US personal consumption expenditures price index, the Fed's preferred inflation measure, was unchanged in May, following a 0.3% gain in April. This confirms a disinflationary trend, pointing to a softening US economy.

images.alt_text: A Trump victory could introduce higher tariffs and fiscal expansion, which benefits the US dollar, a Barclays strategist predicts.

site_title: Where have all the Chinese IPOs gone?
summary: China's IPO drought continues, with Chinese companies raising only about $580 million in US listings so far this year, a significant decrease from previous years. The slowdown is attributed to China's top leader Xi Jinping's efforts to assert control over the market, including stricter regulations and a crackdown on private businesses. This has led to a decline in venture capital investments and a significant reduction in the number of Chinese companies going public, with around 40 Chinese companies listed at home this year, raising less than $3 billion.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2008, the e-commerce pioneer gained attention in 2021 as it became the most downloaded shopping app in the United States, overtaking Amazon.

site_title: Billionaire Arnault said to join race for Signa’s Venice hotel
summary: Billionaire Bernard Arnault has joined the bidding for the Hotel Bauer in Venice, Italy, one of the crown jewels of the Signa Group's real estate empire. The hotel, located on the Grand Canal, has attracted bids of over 275 million euros. The sales process is being run by King Street Capital Management, which took control of shares in a Signa company that owned the hotel in May. The sale comes as Signa's creditor entanglements are resolved, following the implosion of the Austrian mogul's empire.

A Porsche automobile passes Chelsea Barracks residential development in London, U.K., on Sunday, March 7, 2021. Sales of luxury properties tumbled 13% as the pandemic spurred the richest buyers to look to the countryside. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: More mixed-use projects sprouting up, but are they a better buy?
summary: Singapore's mixed-use development market is growing, with 33% of government land sales (GLS) sites awarded between 2018 and 2023 for such projects. Industry players say these developments aim to spur growth, rejuvenate areas, and optimize land use. While they offer better marketability, convenience, and amenities, mixed-use projects tend to have higher prices due to the added value and demand. However, they can command higher resale prices and rental premiums, with some achieving 59% sold-out rates compared to single-use residential developments. Four new integrated development projects are expected to be completed between 2024 and 2026, and the government is pushing for more mixed-use projects.

images.alt_text: An artist's impression of the Jurong Lake District where the successful tenderer has to build at least 70,000 sq m of office space and up to 600 housing units.

site_title: Spain come from behind to thrash Georgia and reach Euro 2024 quarter-finals
summary: Spain came from behind to defeat Georgia 4-1 in their Euro 2024 quarter-final match, advancing to a showdown with hosts Germany. Georgia took an 18th-minute lead through Robin Le Normand's own goal, but Rodri equalized six minutes before halftime. Fabian Ruiz and Nico Williams added to the tally before substitute Dani Olmo sealed the win. Spain will face Germany in Stuttgart on Friday, repeating the 2008 Euro final.

site_title: Biden seeks to repair debate damage with fiery speech
summary: US President Joe Biden attempted to repair damage from a disastrous debate performance against Donald Trump, delivering a fiery speech at a campaign rally in North Carolina. Biden admitted to his age-related struggles but vowed to continue fighting for the nation. Despite the debate, Biden remains the front-runner in the Democratic party, with Vice President Kamala Harris as a potential replacement if he withdraws. Trump continues to attack Biden, but no senior Democratic figure has publicly called for his withdrawal, making a change to the ticket a politically fraught prospect.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden’s performance in a debate with predecessor Donald Trump was widely criticised by observers, who said it raised concerns the president is too old to run again.

site_title: US consumer sentiment falls by less than initially estimated
summary: US consumer sentiment declined less than initially estimated in June, easing to 68.2, down from 65.6. Consumers expect annual price growth of 3% and 3% over the next 5-10 years. The improvement in sentiment reflects a slightly more favorable economy outlook and lower interest rates, despite lingering concerns about high prices. Consumer sentiment remains below pre-pandemic levels, and the labor market shows signs of cooling, with a 4% unemployment rate in May.

site_title: Philippines overtakes Indonesia in coal dependence
summary: The Philippines has overtaken Indonesia as the most coal-reliant country in South-east Asia, with the Philippines relying on coal for 61.9% of its electricity generation, while Indonesia's coal reliance is at 61.8%. Both countries are failing to expand renewable energy capacity to keep up with growing demand, with the Philippines meeting only 17% of its electricity demand with wind and solar power, and Indonesia meeting only 2.3%. The high coal reliance poses significant hurdles for reducing carbon emissions from the power sector, highlighting the need for greater efforts to attract investment inflows.

images.alt_text: The development underscores the limits of the JETP model, which is also being used to curb coal power in South Africa and Indonesia.
The creditors’ rights relate to outstanding receivables from Indonesian companies Titan Infra Energy and Jaya Utama Indonesia.

site_title: At least four companies launch Hong Kong IPOs to raise about US$500 million
summary: At least four companies, including Cirrus Aircraft, Chenqi Technology, Shanghai Voicecomm, and Baiwang, launched Hong Kong IPOs on June 28 to raise up to $500 million. The IPOs come as the value of new share sales in Hong Kong fell from $2.1 billion in H1 2023 to $1.5 billion in H1 2024. Despite the weak performance, bankers expect an increase in Chinese regulatory approvals and a surge in Indian deals to make Asia an equity capital market hotspot in H2 2024.

images.alt_text: China’s pledge to speed up approvals for listings outside of the mainland bodes well for new share sales in Hong Kong.

site_title: How to invest in this fraught election year
summary: The US presidential election may have significant implications for investors, but the market's apolitical nature suggests that it has little impact on financial performance. A study by Jeff DeMaso found that investors who stayed in the market consistently outperformed those who timed the market based on political affiliations. The Democratic-only portfolio gained $849,016, the Republican-only portfolio gained $162,578, and the apolitical portfolio gained $1.6 million from 1977 to 2024. Historically, the market has prospered under both Democratic and Republican administrations, with the apolitical investor benefiting from compound returns.

site_title: Ending the protectionist scourge would benefit all
summary: The world's trading powers face a critical threat to the multilateral trading system as the US abandons its leadership and pursues protectionism, introducing high tariffs and subsidies. This shift has sparked a trade war, offsetting any advantages for domestic industries and raising prices for consumers. To restore the system, trading arrangements must be updated to ensure a level playing field, including equal treatment of foreign traders and intellectual property rights. The benefits of an open multilateral trading system, including economic growth and poverty reduction, are difficult to overstate, and the consequences of inaction will be far-reaching, including reduced governments' scope for action on social and environmental challenges.

images.alt_text: “I worry that Biden is getting himself even deeper into a new ‘forever war’ against Chinese trading practices,” Stephen Roach, former chairman of Morgan Stanley Asia.
