site_title: Nomura executive earns a record US$12 million, tripling CEO’s pay
summary: Nomura executive Christopher Willcox earned a record $12 million in compensation for the year ended March, tripling the pay of CEO Kentaro Okuda. The pay boost came after the company's return to profit growth, driven by soaring fixed-income trading and resurgent markets in Japan. Willcox's compensation is more than triple Okuda's, and the highest ever for an executive officer at Japan's biggest brokerage. The move aims to boost the company's profit, which is expected to almost double by March 2031.

images.alt_text: Rig Karkhanis will be returning to Asia along with the unit’s chief operating officer Aleem Jivraj.
Nomura’s net income rose 79 per cent last year, marking the first increase in annual profit since chief executive officer Kentaro Okuda (pictured) took the helm in 2020.
Nomura has identified India and the Middle East as growth opportunities.
JPMorgan will not engage with Segantii on new block trades and initial public offerings globally.

site_title: Germany, China sign declaration on data sharing
summary: Germany and China have signed a Memorandum of Understanding on data sharing, a step towards allowing carmakers to transfer data to Germany. The agreement follows a cooperation deal on autonomous driving in April and aims to ensure data flows freely while protecting privacy and security interests. The move is seen as a response to EU and US concerns over the security risk of Chinese technology collecting data locally. The joint declaration provides a framework for dialogue between the two countries, enabling a continuous exchange of data policy ideas.

images.alt_text: The levies look to level the playing field by offsetting the Chinese aid with something of equal value

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as tech recovery stalls
summary: US stocks fell on Wednesday, June 26, as tech recovery stalled. The S&P 500 dropped 8.6 points, or 0.16%, to 5,460.71, while the Nasdaq Composite fell 20.4 points, or 0.12%, to 17,697.265. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also fell 49.0 points, or 0.13%, to 39,063.15. Investors are awaiting a crucial inflation report later in the week, which may impact market sentiment.

site_title: Tackling key gaps in logistics
summary: Keyfields, a logistics solutions provider, was founded in 2003 by Kenny Tan to address the shortcomings of conventional logistics software. The company has since developed a full suite of end-to-end solutions for the transport and logistics industry, winning various awards, including the Enterprise 50 Award in 2020 and 2022. Keyfields has secured customers across the Asia-Pacific region and has set up overseas offices in Myanmar, Indonesia, and Thailand. The company prioritizes cybersecurity and offers flexible work arrangements to attract and retain employees, aiming to be attractive to clients and employees alike.

images.alt_text: Altron Shipping chief executive officer Leo Teng Hong.

The Hocklim Engineering team with awards won. (Front row, L-R) Admin staff Yap Jia Yi, quantity surveyor Aye Myint Mar, chief executive officer Chua Yuan Shen, senior engineer Kyaw Wunna.
(Back row, L-R) Quantity surveyor Shaun Kok, contract manager Benny Neo, operation manager Pei Cao, project engineer Mariyappan Gowrisankar.

site_title: More than 40 Indonesian agencies hit by cyberattack on data centres
summary: More than 40 Indonesian government agencies were hit by a cyberattack on data centers, disrupting immigration services and airport operations. Data at five agencies, including immigration services, has been restored, and the government is working to restore data at 39 other agencies. The attack used Lockbit 3.0 ransomware, which demanded a US$8 million ransom, but the government refused. The attack is the worst Indonesia has experienced in recent years, and the government expects to restore data at 18 agencies by the end of the month.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Minister of Communication and Informatics Budi Arie Setiadi said the attacker used a new variant of existing malicious software called Lockbit 3.0, without giving further details.

site_title: Beijing city cuts home buying costs to boost demand
summary: Beijing, China, has cut home buying costs to boost the local property market. The city lowered the minimum down-payment ratio for first-time home buyers to 20% from 30% and for second home buyers to 35% from 40%. Mortgage interest rates were also reduced, with the floor rate for first-home mortgages now set at the loan prime rate minus 45 basis points. Analysts expect the moves to help boost demand from home buyers, following similar policy relaxations in China's other major cities. The measures aim to alleviate the country's ailing property market.

site_title: US new home sales slump to six-month low in May
summary: US new home sales declined 11.3% to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 619,000 units in May, the lowest level since November. This marks the sixth-month low, as a resurgence in mortgages undercut demand for previously owned homes and home building. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate reached a six-month high of 7.22% in early May, before retreating to 7.03% by the end of the month. This indicates a faltering housing market recovery.

site_title: Yen slumps to lowest since 1986, putting traders on red alert
summary: The yen has dropped to its lowest level since 1986 against the US dollar, trading at 160.39 yen, amid a widening interest rate gap between the two countries. The yen's decline is attributed to carry trade strategies, where investors borrow in low-yielding currencies to invest in higher-yielding ones, driven by the US Federal Reserve's high interest rates. Japan's Ministry of Finance and central bank are under pressure to intervene, with some analysts predicting a potential rate hike from the Bank of Japan in late July to support the yen.

images.alt_text: Asian investors struggled for direction in early trade on Wednesday, with many markets fluctuating.

The dollar was last 0.1 per cent lower at 159.43 yen, clinging to a tight range, as traders remained wary of testing a level that prompted a 9.79 trillion yen (S$85 billion) currency intervention from Tokyo in late April and early May.

South Korean Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (L) and Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said they “shared serious concerns about the recent sharp depreciation of the Korean won and the Japanese yen.”

site_title: Airbus tells airlines some of their deliveries in 2025 and 2026 may be delayed
summary: Airbus has warned airlines that some aircraft deliveries in 2025 and 2026 may be delayed due to persistent supply-chain issues, affecting the company's ability to meet contracted deadlines. The European planemaker has struggled with shortages on components, including engines, structural parts, and cabin interiors. CEO Guillaume Faury attributed the issues to geopolitical tensions and specific supply chain challenges, which he expects to persist for 2-3 years. This may lead to lower earnings and cash flow for the company this year.

images.alt_text: Airbus pushed back its goal to produce 75 of its A320 single-aisle jets per month by one-year to 2027.

site_title: Keppel Reit establishes green funding framework
summary: Keppel Reit establishes a green financing framework, governing the use of proceeds, project evaluation, and reporting for its green finance transactions. The framework aligns with the International Capital Market Association's Green Bond Principles and the Green Loan Principles. The Reit issues A$175 million in floating-rate green notes due 2027, with net proceeds used to fund part of its acquisition of 50% interest in 255 George Street in Sydney. This marks the Reit's sustainability-focused funding forming 63% of its total borrowings as of March 31, 2024.

images.alt_text: The green notes will bear interest at a floating rate based on the Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus an agreed spread, payable quarterly.
The 131 billion won revolving credit facility was obtained by Keppel No 4 General Investors’ Private Real Estate Investment Liability Company, a unit of Keppel Reit.
Koh Wee Lih, chief executive officer of Keppel Reit's manager, remains as the Reit Association of Singapore's president.

site_title: South Korea halts battery maker's operations as it probes deadly blaze
summary: South Korean authorities have halted operations of lithium battery manufacturer Aricell following a deadly fire that killed 23 people, with investigations ongoing into suspected safety violations. The factory, which stored 35,000 lithium batteries, was shut down for inspection amid questions about Aricell's hiring of foreign workers and their safety training. The blaze, one of the deadliest industrial accidents in recent years, has raised concerns about workplace safety in South Korea, where dozens of workers lose their lives on the job each year.

images.alt_text: Firefighters retrieve the bodies of workers at the site of a fire at a lithium battery factory in Hwaseong, South Korea.

site_title: South Korea crypto investment firm Hashed expands to Abu Dhabi
summary: South Korea-based crypto investment firm Hashed has expanded to Abu Dhabi through a partnership with Hub71, a global tech ecosystem. Hashed plans to introduce Korean startups to the UAE, including those in financial technology and digital assets, and may open an office in Abu Dhabi. The partnership aims to capitalize on the UAE's favorable regulatory environment, which has attracted operations from Binance, OKX, and Nomura's Laser Digital. Hashed's CEO, Simon Kim, sees the UAE as a key market for Korean startups, citing the country's talent and existing relationship with the UAE.

images.alt_text: Dubai’s reputation as a choice destination for wealthy families fleeing hostile regimes or wars has surged in recent years, exemplified by the Russian money that flooded in following the invasion of Ukraine.
The wealth fund, which ranks as the emirate’s second-largest sovereign investor, reported a five-year rate of return of 10.3 per cent.
The launch of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded-funds in the US helped Bybit double its market share to 16 per cent in March from 8 per cent in October 2023.
FILE PHOTO: Representation of Bitcoin cryptocurrency is seen in this illustration taken January 11, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
A spot Ethereum ETF allows investors to gain exposure to the price of Ethereum without the complications and risks of owning Ethereum directly.

site_title: India raises US$1.3 billion from tepid wireless airwaves auction
summary: India's Narendra Modi administration sold 141 MHz of airwaves worth US$1.3 billion in a recent spectrum auction, a fraction of the US$11 billion earned in 2021 and US$19 billion in 2022. Bharti Airtel, the country's second-largest operator, emerged as the top bidder, purchasing 97 MHz of airwaves for US$820 million. The auction was expected to be low due to operators securing airwaves to replace expiring licenses and the 5G rollout being mostly complete.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man leaves a Bharti Airtel store in New Delhi, India April 20, 2016. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi/File Photo

site_title: EU’s agricultural prices ease towards pre-war levels in Q1, Eurostat says
summary: The European Union's agricultural prices eased towards pre-war levels in the first quarter, according to Eurostat. Twenty EU countries recorded lower output prices, averaging a 6% drop, with cereals experiencing a 28% decline. Input costs also fell, with a 31% drop in fertiliser and soil improvers. The decline is attributed to reduced volatility related to the war in Ukraine, which disrupted agricultural shipments and sent prices to near-record highs in 2022.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The euro sign is photographed in front of the former headquarters of the European Central Bank in Frankfurt, Germany, April 9, 2019. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach
The ECB projects inflation to return to 2 per cent in the final quarter of next year.
Net trade provided the biggest contribution to growth in the three-month period.

site_title: Australian PM says secretive talks led to Assange deal
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese revealed that secretive talks led to a plea deal that freed Julian Assange, the 52-year-old WikiLeaks founder. The US Department of Justice made a "range of decisions" for the deal to proceed, and a "whole range of people" visited the US during negotiations. Albanese exchanged directly with Assange's lawyers and spoke with him upon his arrival in Canberra, where he was sentenced to 5 years and 2 months in prison, effectively completing his sentence. The deal was seen as a resolution to the matter.

images.alt_text: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange leaves the United States District Court following a hearing, in Saipan, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S., June 26, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji

site_title: K-pop stars Seventeen become Unesco ambassadors
summary: Seventeen, a popular K-pop group, has been appointed as UNESCO goodwill ambassadors for youth. The 13-member band will donate £1 million to a UNESCO youth grant scheme for creative projects. As ambassadors, they aim to represent today's young people and promote UNESCO's values of peace and youth empowerment. This partnership is seen as a significant addition to UNESCO's efforts, with the director-general stating it will bring "tremendous momentum" to their work.

images.alt_text: Peru has put forth the “preparation and consumption of ceviche” for which the recipe is “inherited from generation to generation”.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 26)
summary: Singapore's factory output increased 10.1% year-on-year in May, excluding the volatile biomedical sector. In contrast, factory output in Singapore grew 2.9% year-on-year in May, driven by a rebound in the electronics sector. The government plans to strengthen laws on asset recovery to boost its anti-money laundering regime. Meanwhile, the demand for Singapore Savings Bonds slipped, and congestion at Singapore's container port reached its worst since the pandemic, highlighting the global ripple effect of Red Sea attacks.

images.alt_text: In 2023, all industries continued to see wage growth, though the rate of growth across sectors was generally lower than in 2022.

site_title: Hackers grow more sinister and brazen in hunt for bigger ransoms
summary: Cybercrime crews are increasingly using more sinister techniques, such as leaking sensitive records and double-hacks, to extort major companies. Hackers are demanding higher ransom payments, with the average payment reaching $381,980 in the first quarter of this year. The "ransomware-as-a-service" model has made it easier for hackers to target critical supply chain systems. Researchers are also facing harassment, including fake nude photos and false emergencies, as hackers try to intimidate them. The US Department of Justice has created a ransomware task force, but the problem persists due to hackers' ability to operate from countries with limited extradition.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Minister of Communication and Informatics Budi Arie Setiadi said the attacker used a new variant of existing malicious software called Lockbit 3.0, without giving further details.

site_title: McDonald’s says plant-based test in two key US cities failed
summary: McDonald's has announced that its test of the plant-based McPlant burger in San Francisco and Dallas was unsuccessful, citing consumer demand for chicken as the primary reason. US Chief Joe Erlinger stated that consumers are not looking for plant-based proteins from the chain, instead opting for affordable chicken options. As a result, McDonald's is shifting investments towards chicken-based products, which are less expensive to produce. This decision is driven by affordability, with chicken being a more affordable protein option for consumers.

site_title: SGX Cares launches financial literacy training camp for Singapore footballers
summary: SGX Cares has launched a financial literacy training camp for Singapore footballers, equipping them with financial management and investing fundamentals. The program, in partnership with the Football Association of Singapore, aims to help footballers manage their finances during their careers and beyond. The sixth session was attended by 12 footballers from BG Tampines Rovers and is part of a series of workshops that will run until the end of the year. The goal is to promote financial literacy and help footballers prepare for retirement and secure their financial future.

images.alt_text: Ascott Orchard Singapore's pool has a ramp at the side and a grab bar, and some of the exercise equipment at the gymnasium can accommodate wheelchairs.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 26, 2024 (Ep 89)
summary: Asian markets experienced a tech-led bounce on Wednesday, with investors reassessing the Federal Reserve's interest-rate path. The latest Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) saw a decline in applications, with a 10-year average return at 3.3%. Despite a flat opening for Singapore shares, the region's markets fluctuated, with inflation concerns and the US dollar's tumble under scrutiny.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 47 to 44.
Asian investors struggled for direction in early trade on Wednesday, with many markets fluctuating.
The latest tranche offered a first-year interest rate of 3.26 per cent, and a 10-year average return of 3.3 per cent.

site_title: German consumer confidence set to worsen in July
summary: German consumer confidence is expected to worsen in July, dropping 0.8 points to minus 21.8 points, according to a key survey. Inflation concerns and economic uncertainty weigh on consumers, with a focus on "planning security" from the government. The survey reflects a more pessimistic outlook on income prospects and the economy, with fewer consumers willing to make large purchases. The German government's budget discussions have also contributed to the decrease in consumer confidence.

images.alt_text: Skyscrapers in the central business district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The European Central Bank is poised to start lowering interest rates from record highs, confident that inflation is sufficiently contained to ease the burden on the economy. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: Switzerland sticks to bank capital schedule in blow to UBS
summary: Switzerland is sticking to its schedule to implement global bank capital rules, despite US delays, potentially putting its largest lender UBS at a competitive disadvantage. The Basel rules, set to apply from January 2025, will increase UBS's risk-weighted assets by around $15 billion, mainly due to trading rules. The Swiss government is also pushing for a revamp of UBS's capital requirements for foreign holdings, which could add up to $25 billion.

images.alt_text: Countries are introducing the last batch of a global bank capital accord known as Basel III, rolled out after taxpayers were forced to bail out lenders in the global financial crisis of 2007-2009.
FILE PHOTO: The tower of the headquarters of the Bank for International Settlements (BIS) is seen in Basel, Switzerland March 18, 2021. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

The changes to the Basel Committee's “core principles for effective banking supervision” were approved at a meeting of some 220 central bankers and financial regulators on April 24 and 25 in Basel, Switzerland.

site_title: Billionaire Agnellis boost stake in Philips to US$4.19 billion
summary: The Agnelli family's Exor increased its stake in Royal Philips to 17.51%, valuing the Dutch company at $4.19 billion. Exor, the holding company for the Agnelli family, now owns 17.51% of Philips, up from 16.1% in May. The increased investment demonstrates confidence in the company, which settled US claims linked to faulty sleep apnea devices in April. This move follows Exor's acquisition of 19.5 million Philips shares in 2023, marking a 3.3 billion euro investment in the company.

images.alt_text: Philips is joining a growing number of manufacturers that are cutting costs to deal with supply-chain turmoil and inflation.

site_title: Bosch weighs offer for appliance maker Whirlpool
summary: Robert Bosch is weighing a bid for US appliance manufacturer Whirlpool, with a potential deal ranking amongst the biggest disclosed deals for the German industrial group. Whirlpool has been undergoing a major restructuring, including the sale of its European and Middle Eastern businesses, and has a market capitalization of about $4.8 billion. A deal would significantly boost Bosch's home appliance business, amid growing competition from Asian rivals. Bosch CEO Stefan Hartung has stated the company is open to listing divisions on the stock market and exploring financing options for deals.

images.alt_text: Whirlpool has cut back on discounts and promotions while turning to smaller, countertop appliances.
FILE PHOTO: The administrative entrance at the Whirlpool plant in Clyde, Ohio, U.S. October 3, 2017. Picture taken October 3, 2017.  REUTERS/Aaron Josefczyk/File Photo
Supply disruptions have stabilised and that’s also helping the business, Jim Peters says.

site_title: Shopee to adjust services in Indonesia after antitrust violation
summary: Shopee, Indonesia's market leader in the e-commerce sector, has agreed to adjust its services after admitting to violating anti-competition rules by directing customers to certain delivery services. The country's antitrust agency, KPPU, had accused Shopee of breaches last month. Shopee has proposed changes to its user interface to demonstrate compliance and has committed to complying with all applicable regulations. The move comes after a similar investigation into Lazada, another e-commerce platform in Indonesia.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Swire Pacific to raise up to US$500 million via dollar bond: sources
summary: Hong Kong conglomerate Swire Pacific plans to raise US$300 million to US$500 million through a five-year US dollar bond, according to sources. The proposed bond has an initial price guidance of Treasuries plus 120 basis points. Swire Pacific intends to use the funds for lending within the group and general corporate purposes. The company, which owns 45% of Cathay Pacific Airways, will announce the details when appropriate, according to a spokesperson.

site_title: ValueMax associates launch Well Chip IPO
summary: ValueMax associates, Well Chip, has launched its RM172.5 million initial public offering (IPO) on Bursa Malaysia, set to list on Jul 23. The company, which provides pawnbroking services, plans to use 72% of the IPO proceeds for cash capital and 23.2% for expansion. Well Chip expects its cash capital requirements to increase as it grows its network of pawnshops or disburses more pawn loans, with the company aiming to expand into new geographical markets within Malaysia and target Negeri Sembilan within three years.

images.alt_text: Mainboard-listed ValueMax Group intends to cash in on rising demand for more sustainable jewellery, says chief marketing officer and executive director Yeah Lee Ching.
Well Chip applied to the Securities Commission Malaysia (SC) to register its listing prospectus.
ValueMax, as a result, will not conduct its businesses in Malaysia, so long as Well Chip stays as its associated company.

site_title: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange lands in Australia after US guilty plea
summary: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange landed in Australia after pleading guilty to one US espionage charge, ending a 14-year legal battle. He spent over five years in a British high-security jail and seven years in asylum in the Ecuadorean embassy in London. Assange accepted a plea deal, stating he believed the First Amendment shielded his free speech but acknowledged violating the espionage statute. The US government indicated no personal victims, and Assange will be released due to time served. His supporters hailed him as a hero for promoting free speech and exposing war crimes.

images.alt_text: WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange leaves the United States District Court following a hearing, in Saipan, Northern Mariana Islands, U.S., June 26, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji
Anthony Albanese photographer: Rohan Thomson/Bloomberg
Under the plea agreement, Assange will appear in the US District Court for the Northern Mariana Islands.

(FILES) In this file photo taken on May 1, 2019, WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange arrives at court in London to be sentenced for bail violation. - UK Home Secretary Priti Patel has approved the US government's request to extradite the WikiLeaks publisher Julian Assange, her department said Friday, June 17. The Home Office said the interior minister "must sign an extradition order if there are no grounds to prohibit the (extradition) order being made" and the courts had found none. Assange has 14 days to appeal. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

site_title: HDB’s June BTO exercise draws keen interest with application rate over 3 times
summary: The HDB's June BTO exercise drew a record 3.1 times more applicants, with Tampines GreenTopaz having the highest first-timer application rates at 7.8 times for four-room flats and eight times for five-room units. This is the highest application rate since May 2023, with a total of 21,827 applicants vying for 6,938 new flats.

images.alt_text: The Tampines GreenTopaz project will have 561 flats with a waiting time of three years and one month.
Plus flats, a new category of Build-to-Order flats, refer to those found in "choicer locations" within each region across Singapore.
Rents for Housing and Development Board flats fall for the first time since January this year, showing yearly growth despite monthly decline.

site_title: Miner BHP's carbon emissions to rise slightly this year
summary: BHP Group's operational carbon emissions are projected to increase slightly this year due to "organic growth," but the company aims to cut those emissions by at least 30% by 2030. The miner has earmarked $4 billion for operational carbon cuts and plans to increase the use of solar power and decarbonize trucking fleets. Investors are pressing for more detail on its carbon reduction plan, with some predicting the company may need to build a carbon offset portfolio to meet its target.

images.alt_text: The global mining industry is facing growing pressure from investors and environmentalists to reduce its carbon footprint.

site_title: Blackstone snaps up UK hotel operator Village Hotels
summary: Private equity giant Blackstone has agreed to acquire British hotel operator Village Hotels, which runs 33 mid-market hotels across regional cities and suburbs in Britain. The deal was completed without disclosing the value, but Sky News previously reported it was valued around £850 million (S$1.5 billion). This acquisition is part of Blackstone's push into the hospitality sector, which outperforms the broader commercial property market. The deal was advised by Lazard and Santander, while Morgan Stanley advised Village Hotels' previous owner, KSL Capital Partners.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen at the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: F&B jobs portal launched to address industry labour crunch
summary: Singapore has launched FABjobs, a dedicated jobs portal for the food services sector, to address the industry's labor crunch. Co-developed by the Restaurant Association of Singapore and FastCo, the portal caters to the needs of food services companies and job seekers, allowing companies to customize their job postings and job seekers to identify job openings based on location and employer type. The launch aims to attract more Singaporeans into the workforce, particularly stay-at-home mothers, and reduce barriers to re-entry into the job market.

images.alt_text: Bar and restaurant chain Harry’s International has 19 outlets in Singapore.

site_title: Japan chipmaker Kioxia to file preliminary listing application: sources
summary: Japan's chipmaker Kioxia plans to submit a preliminary application to list shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in the coming days, with a full application expected in August and a listing target of the end of October. The company aims to raise capital by issuing new shares, led by Bain Capital, which acquired the memory unit of Toshiba in 2018. Kioxia's operating loss widened to 253 billion yen in the year ended March, but the company reported its first profitable quarter in six quarters due to higher chip prices.

images.alt_text: Under the plan presented to the banks, Kioxia expects to return to profit in the year to March 2025, seeing earnings of around 130 billion yen.

site_title: China’s 10-year yield down to lowest since 2002 on growth worry
summary: China's 10-year government bond yield has fallen to 2.22%, its lowest since 2002, amid concerns over the domestic economy and expectations for further stimulus. The rally is driven by lacklustre economic growth, dovish monetary policy, and ample liquidity in the banking system. Investors are seeking safe-haven flows into government bonds, and the People's Bank of China has hinted at potential measures to slow the advance, including tightening front-end liquidity or selling its own holdings.

images.alt_text: The People's Bank of China has repeatedly hinted at its discomfort over the bond rally in the past few months as long-term yields touched two-decade lows.

site_title: More EVs in Category A could crowd out hybrids, drive up COE prices
summary: Singapore is seeing increased competition in the electric vehicle (EV) market, with more models entering the Category A Certificate of Entitlement (COE) market, potentially driving up COE prices and volatility. BYD and Tesla have launched new Category A models, such as the BYD Seal and Tesla Model 3, which are priced lower than existing Category B models. Industry observers warn that this could crowd out non-EV cars and lead to increased competition, with some predicting rising COE premiums. Despite this, some experts believe that hybrids will still play a significant role in consumer choices.

images.alt_text: COE prices for passenger car categories A and B have increased after significant drops in the preceding round.
China has become an electric vehicle (EV) behemoth as a result of a concerted effort to go all-in on EVs more than a decade ago.
Industry observers attribute the plunge in ultra-luxury car registrations to higher taxes on more expensive cars and reduced rebates that mean higher cost of ownership.
Analysts expect other manufacturers producing in China will pass on part of the extra cost to consumers.
While it runs retail operations for numerous brands in Singapore, Inchcape's global business is focused on automotive distribution.

Cheng Jinkui, president of GWM in the Asean region, notes that the group’s development focus in the next 3-5 years remains on Indonesia, Vietnam and the Philippines for the size of their respective domestic markets.

site_title: French tech giant Atos' top shareholder drops rescue offer
summary: A consortium led by Onepoint, a digital consultancy, has withdrawn its rescue offer for Atos, citing unmet conditions. Atos, struggling with almost $7.2 billion in debt, had initially chosen Onepoint's proposal over a Czech billionaire's offer. The company's chairman, Jean-Pierre Mustier, received a letter from the billionaire, Daniel Kretinsky, expressing interest in restarting negotiations. Atos remains committed to reaching a "definitive financial restructuring agreement" by July, despite the setback.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei rallies to more than two-month high on fresh tech momentum
summary: Japan's Nikkei index rose 1.26% to 39,694.50, its highest closing level since April 9, driven by fresh tech momentum. The Nikkei touched a near-three-month intraday high of 39,788.63. Technology stocks and chip-related heavyweights surged, contributing to the gains. The broader Topix index finished up 0.56% to 2,802.95, securing a 2½-month closing peak.

images.alt_text: A man walks past an electronic board showing the numbers during afternoon trade on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in central Tokyo on May 30, 2024. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

site_title: Handbags and ball gowns: Princess Diana finery goes under the hammer
summary: The Princess Diana memorabilia auction, "Princess Diana’s Elegance & A Royal Collection," is underway in Beverly Hills, featuring nearly 50 pieces including gowns, shoes, handbags, and hats. The auction includes designs by Victor Edelstein, Murray Arbeid, and Catherine Walker, among others. The sale is the largest of Diana memorabilia since her death, with the midnight blue tulle dress and flamenco-style lace-up number expected to attract significant attention.

images.alt_text: The collection of dresses, shoes and handbags – some of which are familiar fashion moments from Princess Diana – is part of a 12-day exhibit at a Hong Kong mall which launched on Thursday (Apr 18).
Dresses that belonged to Princess Diana and a sketch study portrait are on display ahead of the auction Legends: Hollywood & Royalty at Julien's Auctions.

site_title: Tencent’s ‘Dungeon & Fighter’ game dominates China’s mobile download charts
summary: Tencent's 'Dungeon & Fighter' game has dominated China's mobile download charts, breaking the US$100 million revenue mark in just 10 days. The game topped the global mobile game revenue growth chart for May and ranked 8th in overall revenue. Its success contributes to a 12% growth in Tencent's mobile game revenue in May, surpassing the combined earnings of other popular titles. The game's early success comes amid ongoing tensions between Tencent and smartphone vendors over gaming revenue sharing.

images.alt_text: Tencent hastened the release of DnF Mobile to May after positive feedback in testing, touting the game as a blockbuster that would rekindle growth in its key domestic games division.
Currently, users can download and use WeChat on Huawei handsets.
Tencent’s move reflects the cautious mood in an office market showing early signs of weakness due to rising layoffs in sectors such as tech and finance, along with the shift to working from home.
Tencent and its controlled entity Tencent Music will buy the stake through a combination of cash and a minority stake in music streaming app JOOX Thailand, valuing GMM Music at US$700 million.
DnF Mobile is a key title for hit-hungry Tencent, as the world’s biggest games publisher replenishes its ageing games portfolio.

site_title: HK mall to get US$1 billion upgrade with help from Hermes, LVMH
summary: Hong Kong Land Holdings and luxury retailers, including Hermes and LVMH, plan a US$1 billion upgrade of Landmark mall in Central, creating multi-storey maison-style stores for 10 tenants. The renovation, spanning three years, will double the tenants' shop space and include new restaurants. The investment comes as Hong Kong's retail sector faces increasing competition, with sales declining 14.7% in April from a year earlier. Despite this, Landmark remains resilient due to its local customer base, with top shoppers spending a combined HK$1 billion last year and HK$500 million so far this year.

images.alt_text: With one of the highest debt ratios among Hong Kong peers, New World’s de-leveraging plan has been in the spotlight in the past year, especially after a string of defaults by Chinese property developers.
hong kong property housing Photographer: Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
New home projects have attracted much demand with their low prices.

The International Commerce Centre, second from left, is enshrouded in fog above Victoria Harbor in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, March 15, 2010. Hong Kong stocks fell today, dragging the benchmark index to a one-week low, after China Shenhua Energy Co. reported earnings that missed analyst estimates, and on concern China will act to cool inflation and slow economic growth. Photographer: Jerome Favre/Bloomberg

The developers and owners of The Corniche are distressed Chinese builders Logan Group and KWG Group Holdings.

site_title: Singapore port congestion shows global ripple impact of Red Sea attacks
summary: Global port congestion has reached an 18-month high, with 60% of ships waiting at anchor in Asia, due to prolonged vessel re-routing to avoid Red Sea attacks. This has disrupted global ocean shipping, causing bottlenecks in Singapore and other Asian and European ports. Retailers and manufacturers are battling surging rates, port backups, and shortages of empty containers, exacerbating the situation during the peak year-end shopping season. The annual peak shipping season has arrived earlier than expected, driven by restocking activities and customer shipping goods early in anticipation of stronger demand.

images.alt_text: Rates to ship goods across the Pacific have multiplied by a similar magnitude.
The bunching up of vessels outside Singapore's container port is pushing freight rates ever higher, with no immediate end to the congestion in sight.
Singapore-flagged bunker vessel Marine Honour, which was involved in the incident, anchored in the Western Anchorage on June 18.
Shipping, responsible for moving about 90 per cent of global trade, contributes nearly 3 per cent to the world’s carbon dioxide emissions.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate after Wall Street rebound, inflation in view
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Wednesday following a US tech-led rebound on Wall Street, as investors await US inflation data and prepare for potential interest rate cuts. The yen fell towards levels that have prompted Japan to intervene, while the euro remained under pressure ahead of French elections. Despite comments from US Federal Reserve policymakers indicating a potential rate cut, investors remain cautious, citing strong US economic data and concerns about valuations.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended 0.2 per cent lower on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.8 per cent lower at 39,112.16, while the broad-based S&P 500 closed 0.4 per cent higher at 5,469.30 on Tuesday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 47 to 44.

site_title: Vietnam PM says Q2 GDP growth seen faster than Q1
summary: Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh stated that Vietnam's GDP growth in the second quarter is expected to be faster than the 5.66% annual growth in the first quarter, with the country targeting a 6-6.5% GDP growth rate for the year. Chinh emphasized the country's focus on growth and flexible monetary policies, aiming to cut lending interest rates and boost public investment. Vietnam is also seeking China's support in developing its high-speed railway networks, including cross-border lines to promote trade between the two countries.

images.alt_text: Vietnam’s plans call for cross-border lines linking China’s Yunnan province to Vietnam’s northern port city of Haiphong and China’s Dongxing City to Haiphong.
The development underscores the limits of the JETP model, which is also being used to curb coal power in South Africa and Indonesia.
Domestic forecasts for next season’s harvest in Vietnam, the world’s second-biggest coffee producer, remain grim.
Vietnam has no nuclear power plants and scrapped plans to build its first two nuclear power plants in 2016.

site_title: Demand slips on latest Singapore Savings Bond with 10-year average return at 3.3%
summary: The latest Singapore Savings Bond (SSB) tranche received S$1.3 billion in applications for the S$1.1 billion on offer, down from S$1.6 billion in the previous June issuance. The July tranche offers a 3.26% first-year interest rate and a 10-year average return of 3.3%, down from 3.33% in the June issuance. Demand for SSBs has fallen as yields slipped below 3% in the first half of 2024, amid expectations of higher interest rates.

images.alt_text: Applications for the latest T-bill auction total S$15.5 billion for the S$6.6 billion on offer.
Applications for the latest T-bill auction totalled S$14.2 billion for the S$7.1 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.
The June issuance saw a total of S$1.6 billion in applications, exceeding the S$1 billion on offer. S$1.6 billion was applied within individual allotment limits.
Yields after 10 years climbed for four straight months, from 2.81 per cent in January’s tranche to 3.06 per cent in the issuance announced in April, which had an offered allotment of S$900 million.

site_title: ‘Wake-up call’: third of adults not doing enough physical activity
summary: A third of adults worldwide, approximately 1.8 billion people, do not get enough physical activity, posing a significant threat to global health. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends 150 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise or 75 minutes of vigorous exercise per week. If current trends continue, adult inactivity levels are projected to rise to 35% by 2030, falling short of the WHO's goal to reduce inactivity by 15% by 2030. The study, based on data from 163 countries, highlights a need for countries to promote physical activity through community sports and other initiatives.

images.alt_text: Nestle Health Science said the website will address specific needs such as preserving lean muscle mass, supporting gut health, and offering personalised diet assistance.
Alcohol causes nearly one in 20 deaths globally each year, through drink-driving, alcohol-induced violence and abuse, and a multitude of diseases and disorders.

site_title: Australia’s faster inflation raises risk of RBA rate hike
summary: Australia's inflation accelerated to 4% in May, exceeding economists' estimates, and sent the Australian dollar higher as traders boost bets on a Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) rate hike at its next meeting. The RBA has held rates since a surprise tightening in November, citing aggregate demand exceeding the economy's supply capacity. Traders expect a rate hike, with the RBA governor stating that policymakers remain vigilant to upside risks for inflation, and economists predicting a high-for-longer holding pattern.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pedestrians walk past the Reserve Bank of Australia building in central Sydney, Australia, February 10, 2017. REUTERS/Steven Saphore/File Photo/File Photo

The Reserve Bank of Australia has raised interest rates by a whopping 425 basis points since May 2022, but has held steady for five straight meetings with inflation running at 3.6 per cent, well above its target band of 2-3 per cent.
The supermarkets will face fines of up to 10 per cent of annual turnover for breaches of the code which mainly covers dealings with suppliers.
The Australian government is seeking to fight greenwashing and steer more capital into credible sustainable activities.

site_title: How Shein’s US IPO plans got derailed by China rift
summary: Shein, a Chinese e-commerce giant, is considering a London initial public offering (IPO) instead of a US listing due to regulatory scrutiny. The company's US IPO plans were derailed after concerns about its operations in China, including allegations of forced labor and environmental impact. Despite efforts to address these concerns, US investors may miss out on Shein's potential IPO, which could value the company at around $50 billion. The company's decision to pursue a London listing is seen as a way to avoid regulatory hurdles and boost the UK's capital market.

images.alt_text: Shein’s London filing marks a shift from its long-running US IPO plan, which has run into obstacles at home and abroad.
To deliver what could be one of the UK’s biggest-ever IPOs, Shein will need to convince regulators, politicians and investors that it meets their standards for inclusion.

Companies including Shein, PDD Holdings’ Temu and Alibaba’s AliExpress, which predominantly ship made-in-China products “cross border” to markets around the world have been rapidly growing in recent years.
Companies incorporated outside the UK must have a minimum free float of 25 per cent under stock exchange rules.

site_title: Thailand to trial system for data centres to buy green power
summary: Thailand is launching a pilot project allowing data centers to directly purchase renewable power, aiming to attract international tech giants to meet their green goals. The project, with a 2-gigawatt capacity, requires companies to have large investments and standard operations globally. The energy ministry will study the impact on state-owned producers, industrial users, and the public. This move is seen as a competitive advantage for Thailand, with Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin stating that "clean electricity is a very important competitive advantage."

site_title: Hong Kong May home prices fall 1.2% to snap two-month rise
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.2% in May, snapping a two-month rise, following the digestion of pent-up demand after the removal of purchase curbs in February. The city's property market is expected to continue softening until banks cut interest rates. A record number of unsold homes in 2023 is expected to hit a 20-year high this year, with experts predicting prices to fall 5-10% in 2024 due to oversupply and high interest rates.

images.alt_text: Home sales in the city remain weak, with high interest rates pricing out many buyers.
Private member clubs have been a staple of the former British colony’s social fabric ever since the Hong Kong Club was established in 1846.

site_title: ExxonMobil backs EV demand growth to turn its lithium bet into a win
summary: ExxonMobil plans to become one of the largest suppliers of lithium, a key material for electric vehicles, despite a slump in prices due to a supply glut. The company aims to ramp up output to support 1 million EVs annually by 2030 and plans to have its first lithium project online in 2027. ExxonMobil's CEO believes its oil business and lithium venture can co-exist, driven by growing demand for lithium-ion batteries. The company is in talks with potential customers and has signed a preliminary agreement to supply lithium to a South Korean battery maker.

images.alt_text: A majority of the traders — 25 out of 36 — declined to relocate, according to Fransy Van de Gucht of the ACLVB union.

ExxonMobil has said it was not planning to bid for Hess but could consider a larger stake in the Guyana joint venture.

site_title: Singapore stocks inch up on Wednesday as May factory output beats forecasts
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, driven by a 2.9% year-on-year growth in May factory output, beating forecasts. The Straits Times Index (STI) reached 3,331.7 points, with the electronics sector rebounding from the previous month's contraction. Key gainer Singtel rose 1.5%, while Seatrium fell 1.3%. The anticipated global easing of financial conditions is seen as a positive factor for global investment and consumption activity.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 47 to 44.
ST Engineering's new data centre will add 7.5 MW of capacity to its portfolio.

site_title: Singapore to strengthen asset recovery laws to enhance anti-money laundering regime
summary: Singapore plans to strengthen its asset recovery laws to enhance its anti-money laundering regime, allowing for the sale of seized assets before court cases conclude. The move aims to deprive criminals of their illicit gains and deter them from using the country to hide, move, or enjoy their assets. The government will also amend laws to extend probes to environmental crimes, such as illegal wildlife trading, and introduce a new bill to enable law enforcement agencies to conduct investigations in foreign countries.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong speaking at the Financial Action Task Force Plenary at the Sands Expo and Convention Centre Grand Ballroom on June 26, 2024. site_title: New Bahru, new lifestyle haunt
summary: New Bahru, a repurposed former school in Singapore's River Valley, is set to open in the third quarter of this year as a shopping, retail, and dining enclave. The complex features unique architecture and interior concepts, and showcases local talents and entrepreneurs, including established brands. New F&B concepts, event spaces, and a gym are also part of the offerings. Some tenants, such as Sushi Oono, are already up and running, offering a range of dining options. The project is a new venture by lifestyle group Lo & Behold.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output beats forecast with 2.9% rise in May
summary: Singapore's factory output surpassed expectations with a 2.9% year-on-year growth in May, beating the forecast of 1.4% expansion by private-sector economists. Excluding the volatile biomedical sector, output increased 10.1% year-on-year, marking a turnaround from the previous month's 1.2% contraction. This rebound is attributed to the electronics sector, which recovered from a contraction in the previous month.

images.alt_text: Finance, rather than manufacturing, is expected to drive economic growth this year, going by the latest survey.
OCBC chief economist Selena Ling expects the outlook for the manufacturing and electronics sector in H2 2024 to “remain supportive”, though she flagged geopolitical tensions as incoming headwinds.
This was worse than economists’ expectations, who predicted a median contraction of 0.5 per cent in a Bloomberg poll.

site_title: BHP uncertain net zero emissions target will be reached by 2050
summary: BHP Group, the world's largest mining company, may not meet its goal of cutting greenhouse emissions from customers and suppliers to net zero by 2050, according to its investor presentation. The company aims to slash Scope 1 and 2 operational emissions by a third by 2030, but is uncertain about reaching its Scope 3 goal due to the challenges of reducing carbon emissions in steelmaking. BHP still plans to achieve net zero by 2050 and has made progress in steelmaking and maritime decarbonization through partnerships and trials.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A small toy figure and mineral imitation are seen in front of the BHP logo in this illustration taken November 19, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

While Anglo has spurned BHP’s US$49 billion bid, it has agreed to talk to the company, which must now make a firm offer by May 29.

site_title: Disney World to take ride reservations in advance
summary: Disney World's Florida theme parks will allow visitors to reserve spots in shorter lines on rides up to one week in advance, starting July 24. Guests staying at Disney hotels can reserve spots for their entire stay, while others can do so three days in advance. The Lightning Lane Multi Pass will be renamed and will cost between $10 and $15, with a limit of three reservations per pass. The changes aim to reduce crowding and boost revenue, following recent changes made by Disney to its parks.

site_title: Singapore shares open almost flat on Wednesday; STI down 0.04%
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.04% lower at 3,324.95 on Wednesday, following mixed US equities and negative European shares. The Straits Times Index (STI) had 47 gainers and 44 losers, with Singtel rising 0.4% and Thai Beverage trading flat. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB up, while OCBC declined 0.2%. The US market ended mixed, with the Dow Jones down 0.8% and the Nasdaq Composite up 1.3%.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering's new data centre will add 7.5 MW of capacity to its portfolio.

site_title: Vietnam Air risks insolvency if state-backed loan isn’t extended
summary: Vietnam Airlines risks insolvency by July if a state-backed loan extension isn't granted, according to a National Assembly statement. The airline has received 4 trillion dong in low-cost loans, but delays in regulatory approvals have hindered refinancing efforts. The government recommended extending loan repayment deadlines to Dec 31, 2027, to allow the airline to complete restructuring. Vietnam Airlines aims for an after-tax profit of 4.2 trillion dong this year, focusing on asset restructuring and corporate governance reforms.

site_title: King Charles hails ties as Japan royals make UK state visit
summary: King Charles III welcomed Japanese Emperor Naruhito and Empress Masako on a three-day state visit to the UK, hailing the countries' "close friendship" during a lavish state banquet at Buckingham Palace. The visit, the first by a Japanese head of state since 1998, comes during a general election campaign and includes informal weekend engagements. Charles, hosting his first state visit since revealing his cancer diagnosis, praised shared values of freedom and democracy, while the emperor and empress met with British dignitaries, including Prime Minister Rishi Sunak.

images.alt_text: Japan's Emperor Naruhito, and Britain's King Charles, walk after inspecting the Guard of Honour, formed of the 1st Battalion Welsh Guards with the Band of the Welsh Guards during a state visit, in London, Britain, June 25, 2024. REUTERS/Kevin Coombs

Kate, married to heir-to-the-throne Prince William, notes that she has started to do “a little work from home” on days when she “feels well enough”.
The ruling Conservatives and the opposition Labour party have both pledged to scrap preferential tax treatment for non-domiciled residents – rich foreigners living in the UK.

site_title: Gold flat as dollar, yields firm; investors seek more US data
summary: Gold prices remained unchanged at $2,319.14 per ounce on Wednesday, as the US dollar and Treasury yields held firm ahead of key inflation data. The US dollar rose 0.1% against its rivals, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. Investors are awaiting the US first-quarter GDP estimates and personal consumption expenditures price index report to gauge the Federal Reserve's interest rate path.

images.alt_text: A selection of gold bars and one-ounce gold coins arranged at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers in London, UK, on Tuesday, May 21, 2024. site_title: Thai economy expected to grow in second half of 2024: central bank minutes
summary: The Bank of Thailand has forecast Thailand's economy to grow 2.6% this year and 3% next year, with growth expected in the second half of 2024 despite uncertainties. The central bank held its one-day repurchase rate steady at 2.50% for a fourth consecutive meeting, citing concerns over the "K-shaped" economic recovery and the impacts of fiscal stimulus. Exports are showing signs of recovery, while industrial manufacturing is bottoming out, and headline inflation is expected to be below the target range in the third quarter.

Thailand hopes to receive positive feedback and be accepted as Brics member as soon as the next summit to be held in Russia.

site_title: FTX customers to vote on multi-billion US dollar repayment plan
summary: FTX customers will vote on a multi-billion US dollar repayment plan to compensate victims whose assets were locked on the platform since its collapse. The plan, supported by customer committees, would return the majority of customers' assets with 119% of their original value. Other creditors could recover up to 143% of their owed amount. The plan, valued at $11.4 billion, is expected to be finalized by October, with a vote set to close on August 16.

images.alt_text: FTX has gathered as much as US$16 billion to repay customers by selling assets and filing lawsuits to claw back money paid by FTX before it collapsed.
Payouts are likely several months away, as FTX winds its way through the final stages of the bankruptcy case.
Former FTX chief executive Sam Bankman-Fried convicted by a federal jury in New York in November 2023 on seven counts of fraud, embezzlement and criminal conspiracy.

FTX cryptocurrency exchange founder Sam Bankman-Fried stands before US District Judge Lewis Kaplan as he is sentenced to 25 years in prison in New York City, US, March 28, 2024 in this courtroom sketch.

The sentence marked the culmination of Sam Bankman-Fried’s plunge from an ultra-wealthy entrepreneur and major political donor to the biggest trophy to date in a crackdown by US authorities on malfeasance in cryptocurrency markets.

site_title: The little secret I’ve learned from 30 years of watching debates with voters
summary: A presidential debate's impact on voters may not be determined by the facts, policies, or style, but rather how candidates make voters feel. Frank Luntz, a focus group moderator and communications strategist, notes that key debate moments that leave a lasting impression often involve candidates attacking each other in defining ways or undermining their opponents' cases. Effective debate moments can include memorable lines that speak to voters' feelings, instincts, and fears about America. Ultimately, it's not the substance of the debate, but the emotional connection made with voters that matters.

images.alt_text: The last debates between the two men in 2020 were tension-filled affairs, with Joe Biden at one point snapping “will you shut up, man?“ as Donald Trump repeatedly talked over him.

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Olam
summary: ST Engineering broke ground on a new data centre, adding 7.5 megawatts to its capacity. Capital expenditure will be S$120 million over three years. Keppel Infrastructure Trust secured a S$612.5 million sustainability-linked loan to refinance outstanding debt. Olam Group's indirect subsidiary, Olam Agri, obtained a US$550 million loan to repay existing loans and for general corporate purposes. These developments may impact trading of these companies' securities.

images.alt_text: The ST Engineering logo at the facade of the ST Engineering Hub located along Ang Mo Kio Electronics Park Road on 24 October 2019.

site_title: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son to tout AI healthcare in rare public showing
summary: SoftBank founder Masayoshi Son is set to host a panel discussion on harnessing AI in healthcare, marking a rare public appearance. He will discuss his company's venture with Tempus AI, a US startup that analyzes medical data, and plans to deploy $100 billion into AI-related chips. Son aims to change the world with "artificial super intelligence" and is expected to reveal more investment plans in the AI sector.

site_title: Bank of Korea warns of developers’ debt risks as profits shrink
summary: South Korea's Bank of Korea has warned of growing credit risks in the property market due to a market slump affecting developers' profits. The central bank notes that developers often borrow against expected future profits, making them vulnerable to economic downturns. With policy rates at 3.5%, the BOK expects construction companies to remain sluggish in profitability, potentially decreasing liquidity for smaller developers. The bank has kept policy rates restrictive since January 2023, limiting access to short-term loans and exacerbating the credit risks.

images.alt_text: Seoul’s package of aid move comes as the US presses allies to curb China’s access to semiconductor technology.
The BOK extended its interest rate pause for an 11th straight meeting in May.

site_title: Vietnam’s coal plant plans draw US scrutiny after phase-out deal
summary: Vietnam's plans to build a new coal plant, the 2.1-gigawatt Song Hau 2 power plant, are drawing scrutiny from the US and other international partners. The plant's construction could put Vietnam in breach of its US$15.5 billion "Just Energy Transition Partnership" (JETP) target, which aims to reduce coal power generation. The US State Department has expressed concern and will continue to engage with Vietnam to implement necessary reforms and phase out coal-fired power. This development highlights the challenges in implementing the JETP model, also used in South Africa and Indonesia.

site_title: Vietnam wants China’s help for high-speed railway development
summary: Vietnam is seeking China's assistance in developing its high-speed railway network, including cross-border lines linking Yunnan province to Haiphong and Lang Son to Hanoi. Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh requested Chinese help with railway design, construction, and technology transfers. This comes as China is Vietnam's top trade partner, with bilateral trade valued at around $200 billion last year. Vietnam also plans to build a 1,500-kilometer high-speed railway connecting northern and southern regions, with construction expected to begin in 2026-2027.

site_title: UK Conservatives’ 14 years of economic unrest
summary: The UK Conservative Party, led by Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, is expected to lose the July 4 general election due to economic turmoil stemming from Brexit, high taxation, and a budget exacerbating a cost-of-living crisis. The party's financial support during the Covid-19 pandemic has been overshadowed by these issues. The economic downturn has also led to a shrinking UK economy for the second month in a row, further weakening the party's chances.

images.alt_text: Public sector net debt, excluding state-controlled banks, reached £2.742 trillion (US$3.47 trillion) or 99.8 per cent of annual gross domestic product in May, up from 96.1 per cent a year earlier.

UK Inflation returned to its 2 per cent target last month, and morale has steadily recovered, but most households are still worse off tan before the inflation surge, weighing heavily on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s political chances in July 4‘s election.

The allegations that a second Conservative candidate was being investigated by Britain’s gambling regulator and may have attempted to profit from their political knowledge of the timing of the election is the latest setback in Rishi Sunak’s faltering efforts to stay in Downing Street.

A cost-of-living crisis in the G7 nation and the world’s sixth-biggest economy has left many Britons struggling to make ends meet, as bills for food, energy, rent and mortgages increase.
The BOE has said a return of inflation to its target is not enough on its own for it to start cutting interest rates.

site_title: Paramount talks with potential international streaming partners
summary: Paramount Global, parent of CBS and MTV, is in talks with potential international streaming partners, which could "significantly transform" its online service. Co-CEO Chris McCarthy stated that a deal could alter the service's scale and economics, making it profitable and driving long-term value. The company has also raised streaming prices, including a 33% hike in the ad-supported version of Paramount+, and plans to sell assets to reduce debt.

images.alt_text: The Paramount+ Essential subscription rate will increase by US$2, to US$7.99 a month for new subscribers, effective Aug 20.
The New York-based media giant has faced a change in the way consumers watch TV and films.

site_title: Google to showcase AI, new Pixel phones at surprise Aug 13 event, The Verge reports
summary: Google will host a surprise event on Aug 13 to showcase artificial intelligence (AI) features, updates to Pixel devices, and the Android platform. The event will be held at Google's Mountain View headquarters, starting with a 10 am PT (5 pm GMT) keynote and followed by a hands-on product experience. This marks a departure from Google's typical fall unveiling of new Pixel smartphones and watches. The announcement comes after rival Apple recently introduced new AI features for its iPhones.

site_title: US: Stocks finish mixed as Nvidia rebound boosts Nasdaq
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Tuesday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index rising 1.3% to 17,717.65, driven by Nvidia's 6.8% gain. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.8% to 39,112.16, while the S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 5,469.30. Consumer confidence data showed US consumers becoming slightly less optimistic about the economy, and the next major data release is Friday's inflation gauge.

site_title: OpenAI delays rolling out its ‘Voice Mode’ to July
summary: OpenAI has delayed the rollout of its 'Voice Mode' feature, initially planned for late June, to July due to technical issues. The realistic voice conversation experience will initially be released to a small group of ChatGPT Plus users to gather feedback before being made available to all Plus users in the fall, subject to safety and reliability checks. The company is also working on new video and screen-sharing capabilities, and is expected to release a new AI model called GPT-40 later this year.

OpenAI has pitched ChatGPT Enterprise, the enterprise version of its chatbot and its AI services known as APIs, to executives at large enterprises.

Newsrooms globally are working to address a new challenge with generative artificial intelligence, as tech giants and startups like Google and OpenAI build tools that can offer summaries of information and siphon traffic from news websites.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall as Airbus leads aerospace sell-off
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 ended 0.2% lower on Tuesday, with Airbus leading the decline after a profit warning and a 900 million euro charge for its space activities. The aerospace and defense index slid 3.8% to its lowest in over three months. Tech stocks rebounded, with the chipmakers index jumping 15% this year, as investors await the first round of French parliamentary elections and a US inflation report.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed 0.8 per cent lower at 39,112.16, while the broad-based S&P 500 closed 0.4 per cent higher at 5,469.30 on Tuesday.

site_title: Australia’s central bank says policy is restrictive, causing households pain
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia has stated that its monetary policy is restrictive, causing financial pain for households, despite raising interest rates by 425 basis points since May 2022 to combat inflation. The current cash rate of 4.35% is contributing to slower growth and lower inflation, with mortgage payments now 10% of household disposable income. The central bank has ruled out easing interest rates until inflation is under control, with markets predicting only a modest chance of a rate cut until April 2025.

images.alt_text: The Aussie hit 106.27 yen on Monday, the highest level since October 2007, having climbed a whopping 1.9 per cent last week. The next major target is the 2007 peak of 107.84.
The Australian government is seeking to fight greenwashing and steer more capital into credible sustainable activities.
Since the RBA’s last meeting, data has shown the Australian economy remains weak.

site_title: Volkswagen invests US$5 billion in EV startup Rivian to form joint venture
summary: Volkswagen has invested $5 billion in electric vehicle startup Rivian, forming a joint venture to develop next-generation battery-powered vehicles with leading-edge software. The investment provides Rivian with fresh capital after struggling to ramp up production and deliveries. Volkswagen gains access to Rivian's technology, software, and EV architecture, aiming to strengthen its technology profile and competitiveness. Both companies plan to introduce vehicles featuring the joint venture's technology in the second half of the decade, with Rivian's shares jumping 37% following the announcement.

images.alt_text: In 2023, the total pay and benefits for Oliver Blume, CEO of both Porsche and Volkswagen AG, amounted to less than 10m euros (US$10.8m) -- far less than some rivals get for just one role.
Carmakers are again finding themselves in the crosshairs of shifting global trade tectonics.

Volkswagen’s stock has fallen about 13 per cent since Blume took over.

site_title: Economists raise China growth forecasts as exports improve
summary: China's exports are expected to rise 4.3% this year, driven by strong demand from overseas and increasing competitiveness of Chinese producers, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists. This supports the country's growth, despite slowing consumer spending. Economists also expect China's economy to expand 5% this year, up from 4.9% previously forecast. However, they remain cautious about the sustainability of growth due to trade risks, weak domestic demand, and deflationary pressures.

images.alt_text: The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.
China has pledged greater fiscal stimulus to prop up its fragile economy.
The yuan has dropped to seven-month lows this week, alongside a reversal in equity investment flows into China.

site_title: South Korea kicks off 26 trillion won of chip loans, funds from July
summary: South Korea has launched a 26 trillion won ($25 billion) aid package to boost its chip industry, starting with an 18 trillion won package of measures including loans and investment capital. The government aims to support chipmakers and set up two funds totaling 1.1 trillion won, with the goal of building a semiconductor "mega cluster" outside of Seoul. The move comes amid US pressure on South Korea to curb China's access to semiconductor technology, and is part of a global trend of countries investing in strategic industries amid geopolitical tensions.

site_title: The oil market has worrying echoes of the Libor scandal
summary: The oil market has seen three major scandals in recent years, involving the world's biggest oil trading houses, Vitol, Trafigura, and Glencore, over manipulating fuel-oil prices. The misconduct, including submitting "false and misleading" bids and offers, resulted in millions of dollars in profits. The cases highlight a systemic problem in the market, where price reporting companies, such as Platts, rely on the assumption that prices posted by traders are truthful. Regulators, including the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission, have fined the companies, but the lack of enforcement action in Europe and Asia raises concerns about the industry's honesty and transparency.

images.alt_text: Trafigura Beheer BV, the parent company of Trafigura Group during the relevant period, has agreed to pay a criminal fine of US$80.5 million and forfeit another US$46.5 million after pleading guilty to a conspiracy to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
