site_title: Oil prices dip as investors fret over demand outlook
summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Tuesday, with Brent futures settling at $85.01 a barrel and US crude futures at $80.83 a barrel, following weak US consumer confidence data and concerns about the economic outlook. High inventory levels have made traders nervous about summer driving demand, and investors are also trying to discern the timing of Federal Reserve interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: Three major scandals in relatively quick succession, along similar lines and involving the oil trading industry’s biggest players, suggest the misconduct can’t be brushed aside as one-offs.
Brent futures for August delivery settled at US$86.01 a barrel, gaining 77 cents, or 0.9 per cent. US crude settled at US$81.63 a barrel, gaining 90 cents, or 1.1 per cent on Monday.

site_title: FedEx soars as cost cuts drive better-than-expected forecast
summary: FedEx reported better-than-expected earnings, with adjusted earnings per share of $5.41 in the fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates. The company forecast profit of $20 to $22 per share for the 2025 fiscal year and plans to buy back $2.5 billion of its stock. FedEx also hinted at a possible divestiture of its freight business and reported a 15% increase in its shares, its largest post-earnings gain in over a decade. The company's cost-cutting efforts are yielding results, with $2.2 billion in permanent cost reductions expected this fiscal year.

images.alt_text: FedEx expects the job cuts to help save between US$125 million and US$175 million on an annualised basis beginning in fiscal 2027.
FedEx's adjusted profit for the quarter ended Feb 29 rose to US$966 million, or US$3.86 per share, topping analysts' estimates.
The new buyback plan comes in addition to an existing US$600 million that remains under its 2021 initiative.

From left: EDB chairman Png Cheong Boon; FedEx president and CEO for airline and international Richard W Smith; Minister for Foreign Affairs Vivian Balakrishnan; Raj FedEx Corporation president and CEO Raj Subramaniam; US Ambassador to Singapore Jonathan Kaplan; and FedEx Express president for AMEA Kawal Preet.

site_title: England top Euro 2024 group but disappoint again in goalless Slovenia draw; Denmark through to last 16
summary: England topped Group C of the Euro 2024 tournament but failed to impress, drawing 0-0 with Slovenia in Cologne, thereby securing a spot in the last 16. The match was marred by boos and beer cups thrown by England fans, who were disappointed by the team's lackluster performance. England's star-studded forward line was neutralized by Slovenia's defense, and the team's inability to create clear-cut chances raised questions about their ability to win major tournaments. Denmark also advanced to the knockout stages after a goalless draw with Serbia.

images.alt_text: Premier League clubs’ revenue grew 11 per cent to top £6 billion for the first time, registering aggregate revenue of £6.1 billion (S$10.5 billion).
Albania's goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha concedes a goal during the Uefa Euro 2024 match between Albania and Spain in Duesseldorf, Germany, June 24, 2024.
Croatia's midfielder Luka Modric reacts to their probable Euro championship exit after the match between Croatia and Italy in Leipzig, Germany, June 24, 2024.
France's Kylian Mbappe scores their first goal from the penalty spot in their match against Poland in Dortmund, Germany, June 25, 2024.

site_title: Cash-strapped Stability AI raises US$80 million with new CEO and board
summary: Stability AI, a cash-strapped generative AI startup, has raised US$80 million in funding from investors including Coatue Management and Lightspeed Venture Partners. The firm has appointed industry veteran Prem Akkaraju as its new CEO, who has also invested in the company. This move comes after the exit of founder and CEO Emad Mostaque, which compounded the startup's troubles. Stability AI's AI image-generation tool rivals those made by Google and OpenAI.

images.alt_text: Stability, founded in 2019, is best known for Stable Diffusion, a popular image generation tool that helped kick off tech’s current AI frenzy.

site_title: A US$100 billion bet on China’s economy sours as warehouses empty
summary: The US$100 billion investment in China's economy is facing a significant downturn as logistics properties in east and north China experience high vacancy rates, approaching 20%, the highest in years. Warehouse owners are slashing rents and shortening lease terms, and shares of real estate investment trusts (Reits) have plummeted. Foreign investors, including Blackstone and Prudential Financial, are contemplating divestments or waiting out the downturn, while domestic companies are expanding despite the slowdown. The situation contrasts with other logistics markets in the US and Asia, where vacancies are at mid-single-digit percentage rates and rents are still rising.

images.alt_text: China’s exports beat expectations in April and May, reflecting strong demand from overseas and the increasing competitiveness of Chinese producers.
FILE PHOTO: A man arranges durians at a market stall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo
Shanghai’s luxury real estate market is a bright spot in China’s bleak property sector.
Sales during the marquee Singles Day shopping bonanza last year grew just 2 per cent.
The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.
China has pledged greater fiscal stimulus to prop up its fragile economy.
Kaisa has been working to restructure its offshore debt since defaulting on US$12 billion in offshore debt payments in late 2021.

site_title: UK Labour to seek economic growth of at least 2.5%, Keir Starmer says
summary: UK Labour leader Keir Starmer has set an economic growth target of at least 2.5% if his party wins the July 4 general election. This goal is a nod to the growth achieved during the last Labour government, and Starmer aims to position Labour as the party of wealth creation after the stagnation under the Conservative Party. The UK economy has struggled with high interest rates weighing on firms and households, but Starmer's promise of growth could influence voters' decisions if Labour wins.

site_title: 50 rising startups in Singapore
summary: Singapore has a list of 50 rising startups that have recently raised funding, according to Tech in Asia. The list covers companies up to the series E stage and includes key details about each funding round. Recent funding rounds include a US$2.2 billion sell-off of GoTo shares, OpenAI's release of a web browser to challenge Google Chrome, and Vietnamese AI company AI Hay's US$10 million Series-A funding. These startups are part of a growing tech ecosystem in Singapore, with many companies accelerating their moves to the city-state amid an intensifying AI race.

images.alt_text: Tech in Asia has generated a list of startups in Singapore that have recently raised funding

site_title: France denied top spot in Euros group by Austria after Poland stalemate
summary: France failed to top their Euro 2024 group, losing to Austria after a 1-1 draw with Poland. Kylian Mbappe scored his first European Championship goal in the 56th minute, but Poland equalized with 13 minutes remaining. Austria won 3-2 against the Netherlands to take top spot in Group D, denying France the chance to finish first. France will face the runners-up from Group E in the last 16.

images.alt_text: Premier League clubs’ revenue grew 11 per cent to top £6 billion for the first time, registering aggregate revenue of £6.1 billion (S$10.5 billion).
Albania's goalkeeper Thomas Strakosha concedes a goal during the Uefa Euro 2024 match between Albania and Spain in Duesseldorf, Germany, June 24, 2024.
Croatia's midfielder Luka Modric reacts to their probable Euro championship exit after the match between Croatia and Italy in Leipzig, Germany, June 24, 2024.

site_title: Waymo robotaxi service opens to all in San Francisco
summary: Waymo's robotaxi service is now available to anyone in San Francisco, after being invitation-only. Over 300,000 people have signed up for the service, which has logged 32.2 million km without major incidents. However, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) has launched an investigation into Waymo after reports of 22 incidents with its self-driving technology. Despite this, Waymo claims its safety record is "unparalleled." The service is now available in San Francisco, Los Angeles, and Phoenix, with plans to expand to Austin.

images.alt_text:
(FILES) A Waymo autonomous vehicle on Toland Street in San Francisco, on November 17, 2023. The Google-owned Waymo robotaxi service on June 25 became available to anyone in San Francisco interested in hailing a driverless ride.
Waymo has been cautiously expanding its robotaxi service, access to which had thus far been available on an invitation-only basis.
"With tens of thousands of weekly trips, our Waymo One service provides safe, sustainable, and reliable transportation to locals and visitors to the city alike," it said in a blog post. (Photo by Jason Henry / AFP)
Austin and Miami will mark the fourth and fifth public testing locations for Zoox.
Self-driving cars have been driving the streets of San Francisco in some form since 2009 and have been operating commercially since August.
Elon Musk has ordered Tesla’s biggest layoffs ever and staked its future on a next-generation, self-driving vehicle concept called the robotaxi.
Musk has long boasted of work Tesla is doing on its systems for electric cars to drive themselves.
A greater emphasis on robotaxis comes with more risk, say analysts.
Alphabet’s Waymo accounts for 36 per cent of the miles recorded without a safety driver.
Last month, Cruise paused all driverless and supervised car trips in the United States and expanded a safety review of its robotaxis.
Cruise is competing with Alphabet’s Waymo unit and others to develop the robot cars for wider production and deployment

site_title: Nissan to start producing EVs for Dongfeng Motor by year-end: Nikkei
summary: Nissan plans to start producing electric vehicles for its Chinese joint-venture partner Dongfeng Motor by year-end, aiming to reduce fixed costs and increase factory operating rates. The move follows slumping sales and declining production at one of its Chinese factories. Nissan will produce the Zhiyin EV for Dongfeng's Voyah brand at its Wuhan factory, which has an annual production capacity of 260,000 vehicles. The shift highlights pressure on Nissan's China business and its struggle to compete with local brands in the rapidly growing electric vehicle market.

images.alt_text: Nissan’s total production capacity in China's auto market is 1.6 million vehicles, with the Changzhou plant accounting for 8 per cent of that.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of Nissan Motor is seen on a car wheel at the automaker's showroom in Tokyo, Japan, Nov. 11, 2020. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
While Nissan’s electric sedans are still in the production plan, the company expects the SUVs to be rolled out faster than its sedans.
Nissan's operating profit for the three months ended Mar 31 came to 90.3 billion yen, far short of the average estimate of 118.2 billion yen.

site_title: Nestle launches website for individuals on weight loss drugs
summary: Nestle Health Science launched a website providing nutritional support for individuals on weight loss programs, including those using GLP-1 medications. The platform addresses needs such as preserving lean muscle mass and supporting gut health, offering personalized diet assistance. This move comes as GLP-1 drugs, including Novo Nordisk's Ozempic, gain popularity for weight loss and are projected to reach $150 billion in annual global sales by the early 2030s.

images.alt_text: Novo Nordisk would initially focus on patients paying out-of-pocket for Wegovy. Ozempic won approval from China in 2021.

Nestle’s hesitancy to name drugs like Novo Nordisk’s Wegovy and Ozempic on its packaging shows the uncertainty facing global food companies as they place big bets on selling products specifically geared towards millions of people taking the appetite-suppressing medicines.
There are holistic approaches that could help individuals to keep their weight in check, including adopting regular exercise, but some patients may need initial help to change their situation.

site_title: FEHT could join hands with tycoon Tanoto family to unlock value for the Reit
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) may team up with the Tanoto family to revitalize the Orchard-Tanglin corner with a joint redevelopment of the Orchard Rendezvous Hotel and Tanglin Shopping Centre. The proposed mixed-use integrated project could include hotel, retail, office spaces, and residences. FEHT could potentially benefit from the Urban Redevelopment Authority's Strategic Development Incentive (SDI) scheme, offering a higher plot ratio and flexibility on land use. A successful redevelopment could uplift FEHT's share price and generate buzz in the market.

site_title: ST Engineering announces fourth data centre, adds 7.5 MW of capacity to portfolio
summary: ST Engineering has broken ground for a new data centre in Jurong, adding 7.5 MW to its capacity, bringing the total to over 30MW across four facilities. The new Tier 3 facility will prioritize physical security and cater to highly secure AI workloads, with a focus on balancing business growth with market demands. The $120 million project will be completed over three years and meet international cybersecurity and AI standards, with plans to incorporate renewable energy and improve cooling capacity.

images.alt_text: Singtel-TM joint venture to develop data centres in Malaysia, enhance digital connectivity
STT GDC is one of the world’s fastest-growing data centre providers
Digital Realty's data centre facility in Loyang on May 13, 2024. ST PHOTO: KEVIN LIM ocdc13
Singapore is a regional data centre hub, with over 70 data centres.

site_title: US consumer confidence ebbs slightly in June
summary: US consumer confidence eased to 100.4 in June, down from 101.3 in May, but remained within a narrow range. Despite concerns about the economic outlook, households were upbeat about the labour market, with current labour market views continuing to outweigh future worries. Consumer inflation expectations fell to 5.3% from 5.4% in May. The slight decline in confidence was attributed to material weaknesses in the labour market, which could weaken confidence as the year progresses.

images.alt_text: SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 12: A customer shops for food at a grocery store on March 12, 2024 in San Rafael, California. According to a report by the Bureau of Labor and Statistics, inflation rose by 3.2 percent for the 12 months ended in February, up slightly from January’s annual reading of 3.1 percent.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Didn’t engage a professional in your legacy planning? You might have missed this
summary: Prudential Singapore's Opus by Prudential program equips high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) with dedicated resources and consultants to create comprehensive legacy plans. These plans help HNWIs transfer wealth to beneficiaries with minimal tax burdens, ensuring continuity and optimisation of their estate. A holistic approach to legacy planning, including asset protection, liquidity planning, and wealth preservation, is key to avoiding shortcomings. Prudential's private-wealth consultants, backed by experts in law, tax, and trust, facilitate expedited underwriting and bespoke services, including the launch of a novel indexed universal life plan, PRUVantage Legacy Index, designed for securing wealth and building lasting legacies.

images.alt_text: Tang Jia Hao, a final-year student at the National University of Singapore, looks forward to the flexibility and independence on offer as a wealth manager at Prudential Financial Advisers Singapore.

site_title: US judge rejects Visa, Mastercard US$30 billion swipe fee settlement
summary: A US judge rejected a $30 billion antitrust settlement between Visa and Mastercard, which aimed to limit fees charged to merchants for accepting their credit and debit cards. The decision could force the companies to negotiate a more favorable settlement or go to trial. The settlement, which was intended to resolve litigation over swipe fees, would have capped fees at 0.04 percentage points below the current average for three years. The rejection does not affect a separate $5.6 billion class action settlement.

images.alt_text: The deal, which was announced in March and was subject to court approval, would have allowed merchants to charge consumers extra in transactions involving Visa or Mastercard credit cards.
The deal will finally allow US merchants to charge customers extra when they are paying with certain types of Visa and Mastercard credit cards.
FILE PHOTO: Mastercard and Visa credit cards are seen in front of displayed Wirecard logo in this illustration picture taken June 26, 2020. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: China’s May net gold imports via Hong Kong down about 23% from April
summary: China's net gold imports via Hong Kong decreased by 23% in May to 26.722 tonnes, the lowest in eight months, as the central bank held off on adding gold to its reserves. This follows a 19.3% drop in total gold imports via Hong Kong. The decline may be attributed to rising spot gold prices, which have been influenced by US economic data and currency weakness.

images.alt_text: The World Gold Council’s Gold Demand Trends report for the first quarter this year said total global gold demand – including over-the-counter purchases – rose 3 per cent year on year to 1,238 tonnes, marking the strongest first quarter since 2016.
Gold consumption in China rose 6 per cent in the first quarter from a year earlier, according to the China Gold Association. It came on the heels of a 9 per cent increase last year.
Last year, China’s gold jewellery demand rose 10 per cent while bar and coin investments surged 28 per cent.

site_title: Bybit is now the world’s second-largest crypto exchange
summary: Bybit has become the world's second-largest cryptocurrency exchange, surpassing Coinbase, according to a report by Kaiko. The exchange's market share doubled to 16% in March, driven by the launch of spot Bitcoin exchange-traded-funds in the US and low trading fees. Bybit's growth was also influenced by a US Commodity Futures Trading Commission suit filed against Binance in March 2023, which led to a 6% decline in Binance's market share to 54%. Bybit was founded in Singapore and relocated its headquarters to Dubai.

site_title: Why OCBC’s offer for Great Eastern may hinge on two key shareholders
summary: OCBC plans to delist Great Eastern Holdings (GEH), but the lender's plans are contingent on owning and controlling a 90% stake in the company by July 12. As of June 24, OCBC and its concert parties own or have agreed to acquire 90% of GEH's shares, meeting the 10% free float threshold required for trading to continue. However, shareholders must decide whether to accept the offer, deemed "not fair but reasonable," or face uncertainty over their shareholdings if trading is suspended or delisted.

images.alt_text: OCBC says that its offer price for its insurance arm is final and that it does not intend to increase it.

David Gerald, chief executive of Sias, says that minority shareholders of Great Eastern Holdings feel they have to choose between accepting an offer deemed "unfair" or potentially having their money locked up in an unlisted company for a long time.
OCBC only needs to acquire slightly more than 4.7 million Great Eastern shares to push its stake in the insurer past the 90 per cent threshold.
In May, OCBC made a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$1.4 billion for the remaining 11.56 per cent stake in GEH that it does not own, with the aim to delist the insurer.
OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
OCBC needs to acquire only 7.4 million more Great Eastern shares to breach the 90 per cent threshold.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.

site_title: Navigating sustainability reporting assurance practices
summary: Investors rely on sustainability reports for decision-making, but assurance practices vary, leading to concerns about greenwashing. Assurance services are voluntary and come in two levels: limited and reasonable. Limited assurance provides a lower level of confidence, while reasonable assurance offers more comprehensive procedures and a higher level of confidence. Investors should assess the criteria used for assurance and the level of assurance provided to make informed decisions. Regulatory actions, such as the EU Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive and US climate-related disclosure rule, aim to improve transparency and consistency in sustainability reporting.

images.alt_text: Competition between the US and China is creating geopolitical realignment. Global supply chains are forging geopolitical alliances to source critical goods, such as semiconductors

site_title: It’s the culture, stupid
summary: The rise of the populist right in Western Europe and North America is attributed to growing disillusionment among the middle class with globalization's social-economic effects. The collapse of manufacturing sectors due to competition with emerging economies led to rising unemployment and lower living standards, fueling discontent with elites. This discontent manifested in the electoral success of Trumpism and similar populist movements, with blaming "neo-liberalism" as a simplistic explanation being less relevant.

images.alt_text: National Rally's election posters in Paris. A key question is not whether the far-right party will win the most votes in the French national election, but whether it will secure an overall majority.
Where centrism has worked : In Poland, Prime Minister Donald Tusk leads a coalition of opposition centre-left, centrist and centre-right parties.
French President Emmanuel Macron’s reputation as a reformer and steward of the economy has also suffered blows in recent months

site_title: Global 2% wealth levy a starting point for taxing super-rich, says proposal author
summary: French economist Gabriel Zucman proposes a global 2% annual levy on fortunes exceeding $1 billion to tax the world's richest individuals, generating $200-$250 billion in annual tax revenue. The proposal, commissioned by the Brazilian G20 presidency, aims to increase transparency on company ownership to aid tax authorities. Extending the tax to those with over $100 million could raise an additional $100-$140 billion annually, according to Zucman. The goal is to start a conversation on taxation, with citizens deciding the implementation through democratic deliberation.

site_title: Ford recalls 668,000 2014 F-150 pickup trucks over transmission issue
summary: Ford is recalling 668,000 2014 F-150 pickup trucks worldwide due to a transmission issue that can cause the vehicle to unexpectedly downshift into first gear, leading to loss of driver control or rear-wheel lockup. The issue can occur regardless of vehicle speed and has been reported in 482 vehicles, including 300 warranty reports, 96 field reports, and 124 customer complaints. Dealers will update the powertrain control module software to address the issue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Ford Halewood transmissions plant in Liverpool, Britain, December 1, 2022. REUTERS/Phil Noble/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: Ford CEO Jim Farley speaks during the official launch of the all-new Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck at the Ford Rouge Electric Vehicle Center in Dearborn, Michigan, U.S. April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Rebecca Cook/File Photo

site_title: Swiss hope to secure new deal with EU this year, president says
summary: Switzerland's President Viola Amherd announced plans to conclude negotiations with the European Union by the end of this year, aiming to update existing accords and conclude new sectoral agreements. The deal would grant unrestricted access to the EU market and address concerns about Swiss sovereignty. The Swiss government had previously attempted to negotiate a new treaty in 2021, but it was abandoned due to concerns about infringement on sovereignty. Amherd emphasized the importance of finding a deal quickly to benefit Switzerland's economy, industry, and research.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Trust unit obtains S$612.5 million green loan
summary: Keppel Infrastructure Trust's subsidiary, Keppel Merlimau Cogen, has obtained a S$612.5 million green loan to refinance a loan, with the interest rate incentivizing energy-efficient production. The loan's proceeds will be used to repay the outstanding portion of the loan maturing on June 30, 2027, with equal debt-servicing amounts paid every six months. The loan conditions include a cross-default clause that may affect S$2.1 billion in aggregate facilities if the trustee-manager changes or Keppel Energy acquires a majority stake in the borrower.

images.alt_text: The target price is based on the assumption that KIT does not acquire new assets and calls for fundraising exercises.

site_title: Chencharu, Lorong Chuan, Marina South among highlights of new state land sites unveiled for sale
summary: The Ministry of National Development has unveiled 10 new state land sites for sale under the Government Land Sales (GLS) programme in Singapore. The confirmed list includes sites in Media Circle, Lorong Chuan, and the Chencharu precinct, with the largest site being a 875-unit mixed-use development in Chencharu. The sites are expected to boost the supply of private homes by 5,050 units, with some analysts predicting an oversupply due to the lacklustre response in recent land tenders. The Housing and Development Board is expected to launch the Chencharu site in September.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of condos and private properties

site_title: Re-examining the concept of employee reward to achieve optimal value
summary: Employee rewards are evolving to meet changing workforce expectations, with a focus on flexibility, personalization, and human-centric approaches. Current approaches often prioritize defensibility and equity, but may miss the mark on employee value. Progressive companies are experimenting with flexible compensation models, and a human-focused reward approach may prioritize overall well-being and future employability. To achieve optimal value, organizations should adopt a clear purpose, work within their own context, and provide human value, while also ensuring compliance with tax reporting obligations.

images.alt_text:

Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area on Nov 30, 2023.

site_title: LVMH snaps up luxury Swiss clock maker L’Epee 1839
summary: LVMH, the world's largest luxury group, has acquired L'Epee 1839, a Swiss specialty clock maker, to boost its expertise in high-end watch making. The acquisition comes as luxury groups seek to cater to high-end shoppers amid rising cost of living and dampened demand for luxury goods. LVMH's watches division, led by Frederic Arnault, will benefit from the acquisition, further expanding its presence in the luxury market.

images.alt_text: Frederic Arnault, one of LVMH chairman and CEO Bernard Arnault’s five children, has worked for Tag Heuer since 2017.
Bernard Arnault’s shareholding in Richemont may still trigger questions around his intentions for the investment.
Generic pix of shoppers outside the luxury outlets/ stores at the Ion Orchard shopping mall on Oct 3, 2023.
LVMH has around 30 brands on Luxury Pavilion, the high-end site on Alibaba’s Tmall shopping platform.
Kering warned of a sharp decline in first-half profits, attributing it to weak demand in Asia, especially China, and challenges with revitalizing Gucci.

site_title: Huawei tops China smartphone sales leading to 618 festival, up 42.4% y/y
summary: Huawei dominated China's smartphone sales during the 618 shopping festival, with a 42.4% increase in sales compared to the previous year. The company's new 5G products drove this growth. Total smartphone sales in China rose 6.8% during the period, with Xiaomi and Apple also experiencing significant increases.

site_title: Eramet, BASF cancel plan to invest US$2.6 billion in refining complex in Indonesia
summary: French miner Eramet and German chemical company BASF have cancelled a US$2.6 billion investment project in a nickel-cobalt refining complex in Indonesia's Weda Bay. The decision comes after the companies concluded that existing high-pressure acid leach (HPAL) facilities in Indonesia make it easier to produce mixed hydroxide precipitate, rendering the need for a new facility unnecessary. The cancellation follows months of negotiations between the two companies and Indonesian officials, who had aimed to build a homegrown electric vehicle industry in the country.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This aerial picture taken on May 14, 2023 shows a general view of PT. Indonesia Morowali Industrial Park (IMIP), one of the biggest nickel producers in Konawe Utara. At least 13 people were killed and 38 injured in eastern Indonesia on December 24, 2023 in an explosion at a Chinese-funded nickel-processing plant owned by PT Indonesia Tsingshan Stainless Steel (ITSS) in the Morowali Industrial Park, the owner of the industrial park that hosts the facility said. (Photo by RIZA SALMAN / AFP)
Excavators transfer soil to transport trucks at a nickel mine operated by nickel mining company Vale Indonesia in Sorowako on July 28, 2023. (Photo by HARIANDI HAFID / AFP)

site_title: Canada's Trudeau under fresh pressure after special election 'disaster'
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faced fresh pressure after the ruling Liberal Party lost a safe seat in a special election in Toronto, marking the first time since 2015 the Conservatives broke the Liberals' control of vote-rich Toronto. The Conservatives won the Toronto-St Paul's constituency, with 42.1% of the vote compared to 40.5% for the Liberal candidate. This loss indicates Liberals in less safe Toronto seats might be vulnerable, challenging Trudeau's hold on power. The next federal election must be held by October 2025, and polls suggest the Liberals would lose badly to the Conservatives.

images.alt_text: Condominiums stand along the shore of Lake Ontario in this aerial photograph taken above Toronto, Ontario, Canada, on Monday, Oct. 2, 2017. Toronto housing prices fell for a fourth month in September as sales remained sluggish, particularly in the detached-home segment that has borne the brunt of the correction in Canada's biggest city. Photographer: James MacDonald/Bloomberg

site_title: Took a break from investing? Here’s what you need to consider if you wish to resume
summary: After taking a break from investing, it's essential to reassess your investment goals and strategy due to changes in life circumstances. Consider shifting priorities to more stable stocks or dividend-paying stocks, especially with family responsibilities or large purchases. Evaluate your investment options, including blue-chip stocks, Reits, and growth stocks, and stay informed about emerging trends and market changes. Retain sufficient liquidity to avoid rushing into investments and prioritize maintaining a safety net for emergencies. Gradually increase investment amounts as you gain experience and confidence, and always prioritize maintaining sufficient liquidity.

images.alt_text: Competition between the US and China is creating geopolitical realignment. Global supply chains are forging geopolitical alliances to source critical goods, such as semiconductors

site_title: Asian investors expected to grow gold investments: survey
summary: Asian investors are increasingly treating gold as a core asset in their portfolios, with 27% expected to increase gold investments in the next 12-18 months, according to a survey by State Street Global Advisors and the World Gold Council. The survey found that gold is being used as a hedge against market declines and economic uncertainty, with 76% of asset owners globally and 63% in Asia-Pacific having gold investments. Despite a lack of an established valuation framework, gold's intrinsic value remains a challenge, with 24% of investors not investing in gold.

images.alt_text: Analysts have remained confident that central banks’ gold purchases would continue.
Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,331.38 per ounce.
Demand for gold from central banks has been elevated in the last two years as some countries diversify their foreign currency reserves.
Asian gold markets have been boosted by central banks’ gold purchases and investors’ healthy buying, despite price surges.

site_title: US house prices increase steadily in April
summary: US single-family home prices rose 0.2% in April, marking a 6.3% increase over the past 12 months, according to the Federal Housing Finance Agency. The steady growth is expected to slow as higher borrowing costs weigh on demand, with mortgage rates reaching a six-month high of 7.22% in early May. Despite this, all nine census regions reported annual house price gains, with significant increases in New England and the Middle Atlantic. The housing market is showing signs of normalisation, with existing home sales decreasing for a third straight month in May.

images.alt_text: SANTA CLARITA, CALIFORNIA - SEPTEMBER 08: An aerial view of homes in a housing development on September 08, 2023 in Santa Clarita, California. According to the National Association of Realtors, the median existing-home sale price in the U.S. increased 1.9 percent in July following five straight months of declines, which was the longest stretch of declines in 11 years, amid high interest rates.   Mario Tama/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by MARIO TAMA / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
FILE PHOTO: A home for sale sign hangs in front of a house in Oakton in Virginia March 27, 2014

site_title: LVMH chief Arnault said to have bought stake in Cartier owner Richemont
summary: LVMH Chairman and CEO Bernard Arnault has acquired a "small" stake in Cartier parent company Richemont, according to people familiar with the investment. The stake is part of Arnault's broader portfolio of investments in publicly listed companies, and he intends to hold the stock only as an investment. Richemont's shares rose 3.1% following the news, while LVMH's shares rose 0.7%. Arnault's investment may still raise questions about his intentions, as Richemont has a strong defense against unwanted suitors due to its chairman, Johann Rupert, controlling 51% of voting rights despite owning only 10.2% of the capital.

images.alt_text: Antonio Belloni will give up his roles as group managing director and chairman of the executive committee at LVMH.
Bernard Arnault, the head of the world's top luxury group LVMH, has been grooming his children in a variety of roles at the company as he develops a succession plan.

Antoine Arnault, who is in charge of image and environment at LVMH, and credited with negotiating a high-profile deal for the company to sponsor next summer’s Paris Olympic Games, will remain chairman of Berluti.

site_title: JTC launches site in Kallang Way with condition for building to be retained
summary: The state landlord JTC has launched an industrial sales site in Kallang Way, requiring the retention of an existing terrace factory for continued industrial use. The site offers 114,239 sq m of gross floor area for industrial and retail uses, with a 32-year lease to allow for adaptive reuse works and necessary clearances. The successful tenderer must retain key architectural features, including protruding solar fins, and integrate adaptive reuse strategically to rejuvenate the area and reduce embodied carbon.

images.alt_text: SIT's Campus Court site is certified Green Mark Platinum, with two buildings being certified as Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings.

site_title: Von der Leyen up for second term under EU top jobs deal
summary: European Commission head Ursula von der Leyen has been selected for a second term under a deal struck by centre-right, centre-left, and liberal party alliances. Portuguese ex-premier Antonio Costa will become European Council president, and Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas will lead EU foreign policy. The deal, agreed upon by the three main centrist groups, will need to be confirmed by the European Parliament for von der Leyen's second term to be secure. The deal was initially agreed upon but was delayed due to disagreements among EU national leaders.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 open higher after Nvidia and other AI-linked stocks selloff
summary: The US stock market opened higher on Tuesday, with the S&P 500 rising 12.86 points, or 0.24%, to 5,460.73, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 75.34 points, or 0.43%, to 17,572.16. The Dow Jones fell 12.42 points, or 0.03%, at the open. The gains were driven by Nvidia and other AI-linked stocks after a selloff, as investors await cues on monetary policy.

site_title: 2.6 million die annually due to alcohol, says WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has reported that 2.6 million deaths annually are attributed to alcohol consumption, with nearly three-quarters of those deaths in men. The report found that alcohol causes nearly one in 20 deaths globally each year, primarily through drink-driving, violence, and diseases. The highest proportion of alcohol-attributable deaths was among people aged 20-39, with 13% of fatalities. The WHO emphasized the need to improve access to quality treatment for substance use disorders, citing stigma and misconceptions as barriers to treatment.

images.alt_text: Justin Timberlake (above), NFL star Travis Kelce of the Kansas City Chiefs and comedian Whitney Cummings own Hydrow machines and are some of the company's celebrity investors.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 25)
summary: Real wage growth in Singapore remained unchanged at 0.4% in 2023, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Condo resale prices rose slightly in May, while volumes decreased, and Singapore retained its spot as the most expensive city for high-net-worth individuals. The government released land for 5,050 private homes in H2 2024, taking the full-year supply to a decade high. Meanwhile, City Developments secured a S$400 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS to advance nature conservation and sustainable development. Singapore stocks ended higher on Tuesday, tracking regional gains.

site_title: US dollar reined in by threat of Japanese intervention; yen fragile
summary: The US dollar fell 0.1% to 159.43 yen, clinging to a tight range, as traders avoided testing the 160-yen level due to fears of a potential Japanese currency intervention. This follows a 9.79 trillion yen (S$85 billion) intervention in late April and early May. Meanwhile, Bitcoin recovered some lost ground after its worst day in over two months, driven by flows out of Bitcoin exchange-traded funds.

images.alt_text: South Korean Finance Minister Choi Sang-mok (L) and Japanese Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki said they “shared serious concerns about the recent sharp depreciation of the Korean won and the Japanese yen.”
The dollar index, which measures it against six major currencies, was last at 105.56, edging back from a nearly eight-week high of 105.91 it touched last week.
The dollar held its near five-week high against sterling, which remains flat at US$1.2649, around its lowest since mid-May.

site_title: ‘No U-turn’: Malaysia will enforce VEP on Singapore motorists from Oct 1, says transport minister
summary: Malaysia will enforce the Vehicle Entry Permit (VEP) requirement for foreign vehicles entering the country from Singapore starting October 1, according to Transport Minister Anthony Loke. Foreign vehicle owners must register, install, and activate their VEP-RFID tags, or risk being denied entry or fined up to RM2,000. The VEP system, first introduced in 2017, has been simplified, and the Malaysian government will use it to track traffic records and enforce fines for traffic offences.

images.alt_text: The Vehicle Entry Permit, renewable every five years, was announced in 2017.
Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim shake hands after holding a joint press conference in Malaysia on Jun 12, 2024.

site_title: Vietnam’s SeABank plans to issue nation’s first blue bond
summary: Vietnam's SeABank plans to issue the country's first blue bond, worth US$150 million, as part of a financing package from the International Finance Corporation (IFC). The bond will be used to fund sustainable aquaculture, fisheries, and renewable energy projects, helping Vietnam meet its goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. IFC's US$25 million blue bond and US$50 million green notes will be subscribed to support the lender's environmental and climate change initiatives. The move aims to attract new investors and address climate change in Vietnam, estimated to have lost 3.2% of GDP in 2020 due to climate change.

images.alt_text: The domestic economy has seen positive signs of recovery, according to Vietnam central bank.

site_title: US surgeon general declares gun violence a 'public health crisis'
summary: US Surgeon General Vivek Murthy has declared gun violence a "public health crisis," calling for wide-ranging firearm controls. This advisory marks the first major report on gun violence from a surgeon general, a role that plays a significant role in public health issues. The move follows a similar report on tobacco in the 1960s, which led to new regulations and a decline in consumption. The advisory aims to shift the perception of gun violence as a public health issue, similar to how tobacco was rebranded as a health risk.

According to Texas officials, at least 19 children and two adults were killed in the shooting on 24 May. The eighteen-year-old gunman was killed by responding officers.  EPA-EFE/TANNEN MAURY

site_title: Boeing’s Spirit Aero bid values 737 supplier at US$35 a share
summary: Boeing has proposed acquiring Spirit AeroSystems for about $35 per share, a 6% premium to Spirit's stock price, valuing the deal at $4.1 billion. This switch from an all-cash offer would ease Boeing's financial pressures, which have been exacerbated by the 737 Max crisis. The acquisition would reverse Boeing's largest outsourcing foray nearly two decades ago, giving it greater control over jetliner structure manufacturing. The deal, which includes a spin-off of manufacturing plants to Airbus, is still expected to be announced within days.

images.alt_text: Victims’ families have called for the criminal prosecution of Boeing and its executives, and are seeking a nearly US$25 billion fine.

A placard with photos of those killed on Ethiopian Airlines Flight 302 is held up as Boeing's CEO Dave Calhoun testifies before a Senate Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs Committee Investigations Subcommittee hearing on the safety culture at Boeing, on Capitol Hill in Washington, US, June 18, 2024.

site_title: Central banks must prepare for profound impact of AI: BIS
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) has urged central banks to harness the power of artificial intelligence (AI) to improve inflation-predicting abilities, but cautioned that AI should not replace humans in setting interest rates. The BIS has eight AI projects underway and sees AI as a tool to monitor data in real-time, reducing the risk of a repeat of past inflation surges. However, top officials emphasized that AI models should not be relied upon to set interest rates, citing concerns over their untested nature and potential for "hallucination."

images.alt_text: Analysts have remained confident that central banks’ gold purchases would continue.
Demand for gold from central banks has been elevated in the last two years as some countries diversify their foreign currency reserves.
The latest outlook, coming after a series of disappointingly high inflation readings in the US along with better-than-anticipated economic activity, is revamping the investment landscape.
The Bank of Japan is ahead of the game, signalling this week that less emphasis will be placed on ensuring its medium-term inflation outlook has to be 2 per cent.

site_title: UK's King Charles welcomes Japan's Emperor Naruhito for state visit
summary: King Charles welcomed Japan's Emperor Naruhito for a three-day state visit to London, marking the start of a visit aimed at deepening military, cultural, and scientific ties between the two countries. The visit comes after a postponement due to the pandemic and takes place ahead of the UK's general election on July 4. The trip includes a military parade, carriage procession, and state banquet, with Charles and Naruhito inspecting the Guard of Honour at Horse Guards Parade and viewing Japanese-related items from the royal collection at Buckingham Palace.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Princess Royal Anne attends a ceremony for unveiling the statue of a Canadian rifleman to commemorate the 80th anniversary of D-Day, in Normandy, France June 5, 2024. REUTERS/Hannah McKay/Pool/File Photo
Kate, married to heir-to-the-throne Prince William, notes that she has started to do “a little work from home” on days when she “feels well enough”.

Britain's King Charles III poses with service personnel after he officially handed over the role of Colonel-in-Chief of the Army Air Corps to Prince William, Prince of Wales, in front of a helicopter at the Army Aviation Centre in Middle Wallop, Britain May 13, 2024. Kin Cheung/Pool via REUTERS

site_title: Lufthansa raises ticket prices to meet environmental requirements
summary: Lufthansa plans to increase ticket prices by €1-72 for flights departing from EU countries, Britain, Norway, and Switzerland to cover rising environmental costs, such as sustainable aviation fuel. The airline aims to offset the additional costs resulting from EU regulations, which require progressively increasing amounts of sustainable aviation fuel. The price hike will apply to flights in 2025, with the airline stating it cannot bear the costs in the next few years. The surcharge is part of Lufthansa's efforts to make flying more sustainable.

site_title: Chinese AI firms woo OpenAI users as US company plans API restrictions
summary: Chinese AI firms are rapidly attracting OpenAI users as the US company plans to restrict access to its API in China and other countries. Following reports, Chinese startups have received emails warning of API blockage and are now being wooed by companies like Baidu, Alibaba Cloud, and Zhipu AI, offering free migration services and additional AI model tokens to OpenAI users. These firms aim to secure their own AI product development and compete with OpenAI.

images.alt_text: OpenAI has pitched ChatGPT Enterprise, the enterprise version of its chatbot and its AI services known as APIs, to executives at large enterprises.
“This is exciting because this is now, based on our evaluations and benchmarks, the best and most intelligent model in the industry,” Daniela Amodei, Anthropic’s co-founder and president, said.
The EU’s recently-passed AI Act is being rolled out in phases over the next two years, giving regulators time to implement the new laws while businesses grapple with a new set of obligations.
ChatGPT will be offered for free on Apple’s products, but OpenAI and Apple could still make money by converting free users to paid accounts.

To build Apple’s foundation AI models, the company’s engineers used its own framework software with a range of hardware, specifically its own on-premise graphics processing units (GPUs) and chips available only on Google’s cloud called tensor processing units (TPUs).

site_title: Cash-strapped Sri Lanka set to sign key debt deals with lenders
summary: Sri Lanka has finalized debt deals with bilateral lenders, including China, to meet a key condition for an IMF bailout. A treasury delegation is set to sign agreements in France, following months of negotiations. The deals, worth US$10.58 billion, account for 28.5% of Sri Lanka's current foreign debt. China is the largest single bilateral lender, providing US$4.66 billion. The agreements come as Sri Lanka seeks to repair its ruined finances over four years with a US$2.9 billion IMF rescue package.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka Photographer: Jonathan Wijayaratne/Bloomberg

site_title: China allows imports of fresh Malaysian durians; exporters see logistical barriers
summary: China has approved the import of fresh Malaysian durians, marking a significant opportunity for Malaysian exporters. The move comes after Chinese Premier Li Qiang's visit to Malaysia last week, which boosted demand for the fruit. However, logistical challenges, including the short shelf-life of durians, are a major concern, with traders worried about competition from cheaper Thai and Vietnamese varieties. Malaysian exporters are preparing to ship fresh durians, but are unsure about the feasibility of exporting fresh durians to China due to the challenges.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A man arranges durians at a market stall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Temasek commits S$150 million to workforce upskilling, education
summary: Temasek has committed S$150 million to support workforce upskilling and education in Singapore, focusing on vulnerable groups such as seniors, persons with disabilities, and neuro-diverse individuals. The investment will be used to develop job-redesign solutions, fill training gaps, and provide scholarships and fellowships for post-secondary students, particularly in STEM fields. The initiative aims to give individuals a core learning capability and prepare them for a future driven by technology.

images.alt_text: Ascott Orchard Singapore's pool has a ramp at the side and a grab bar, and some of the exercise equipment at the gymnasium can accommodate wheelchairs.

site_title: Canada to curb China EV imports as Trudeau responds to Biden move
summary: Canada is imposing a 30-day public consultation period to consider tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles, amid concerns of unfair competition from China's state-directed overcapacity policy. Finance Minister Chrystia Freeland announced the move, citing the need to protect Canada's auto industry. The US has already planned to nearly quadruple tariffs on Chinese-manufactured EVs, while the EU aims to increase tariffs to 48%. China has suggested lowering its existing tariffs on large-engine cars in exchange for scrapping the planned EV levies.

images.alt_text: China has repeatedly called on the EU to cancel its tariffs, expressing a willingness to negotiate.
The levies look to level the playing field by offsetting the Chinese aid with something of equal value

site_title: South Korea, Japan vow to take steps to defend their currencies
summary: South Korean and Japanese finance ministers, Choi Sang-mok and Shunichi Suzuki, expressed shared concerns over the sharp depreciation of the Korean won and Japanese yen. They vowed to take steps to defend their currencies and reaffirmed their commitment to addressing excess volatility and disorderly exchange rate movements. The ministers' meeting follows a trilateral meeting in April where US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen acknowledged their currency concerns. The pair also welcomed South Korea's efforts to improve foreign investor accessibility, including reforms to add its securities to the FTSE World Government Bond Index.

images.alt_text: Roughly 70 per cent of firms polled said they experienced drawbacks from the BOJ’s 25-year-long monetary easing measures including a weak yen that pushed up import costs.

site_title: Making scientific research accessible
summary: Scientists should provide plain language summaries of their work to educate the public and policymakers, making research accessible to everyone. Many studies are paywalled, and the average reader can only read at a sixth-grade level or lower, exacerbating the issue. To address this, scientists should release summaries alongside their studies, and journals should include easy-to-understand information prominently. News organizations can also help by giving scientists comments and publishing op-eds. Additionally, teaching high school students about the basics of science, including replication, is crucial for promoting a healthier information ecosystem.

images.alt_text: None of the released intelligence definitively point to lab-related work as the cause of the pandemic.
The first paper analysed the geographic pattern of Covid cases in the outbreak’s first month, December 2019, showing the first cases were tightly clustered around the Huanan Market.

site_title: Malaysia airports operator management to remain in Malaysians’ hands: PM Anwar
summary: Malaysia's airports operator, Malaysia Airports Holdings, will remain in Malaysian hands following a plan to take it private, Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said. A consortium led by Khazanah Nasional Bhd and the Employees Provident Fund (EPF) announced an offer to value the airport operator at US$3.9 billion, despite protests from lawmakers over foreign investors, including BlackRock, due to its investments in Israel. The privatisation plan will retain a 70% stake in Malaysia's hands through Khazanah and EPF, with Malaysian management and ownership remaining intact.

There would be no layoffs of MAHB’s current employees following completion of the deal, Khazanah Nasional said.

site_title: Developers are no longer hungry for housing sites
summary: Developers in Singapore are losing interest in housing sites, with the state tender for River Valley Green (Parcel A) drawing only two bidders. This marks the first time in over 20 years a state land tender closed with zero bids. The government has released land supply for 5,050 private homes, but market watchers expect good demand for HDB's June 2024 Build-to-Order (BTO) exercise. Condominium prices have also been resilient, with private home prices remaining stable despite a decline in rents for the second straight month in May.

images.alt_text: The recent high-profile money-laundering case has trained a spotlight on how Singapore is managing hot money flows being laundered through the city’s banking system, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
The landed property market seems to be stirring, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

As life expectancy rises, it may be prudent for any buyer seeking a private home to live in for the remainder of his life to pay more for a home with a sufficiently long remaining land lease, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
The latest ABSD hikes have hammered the market in prime areas, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Perhaps transparency and efficiency in HDB resale flat sales will improve with the launch of the HDB Flat Portal.

site_title: Shareholder support for SoftBank CEO Son’s reappointment falls to 79%
summary: SoftBank Group CEO Masayoshi Son's reappointment has lost shareholder support to 79.22%, following ISS's recommendation against his reappointment due to the company's average return on equity of less than 5% over the past five years. Shareholder support for external director Kenneth Siegel also fell to 68.46%, compared to 66.9% last year.

site_title: Malaysia inflation up 2% in May, highest in eight months
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate rose 2% in May, the highest in eight months, driven by higher utility charges and dining out expenses. Core inflation remained steady at 1.9%. For the first five months of 2024, inflation rose 1.8% compared to 3.4% for the same period last year. The country's economy appears to be vulnerable to external factors, prompting a potential rate cut to shield it from tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Economists anticipate that the CPI will rise in the coming months, as the Malaysian government has signaled its intention to implement subsidy rationalization measures soon.
Rates to ship goods across the Pacific have multiplied by a similar magnitude.
The official advance GDP estimates indicated that Malaysia’s economy is expected to expand by 3.9 per cent in the first quarter of 2024.
Diesel used to be the cheapest fuel in Malaysia and is widely used for diesel-powered commercial vehicles.

site_title: China companies seek assurances from Malaysia on avoiding US tariffs: FT
summary: Chinese companies are seeking assurances from Malaysian officials that they can avoid US tariffs if they relocate their battery, medical devices, and semiconductor manufacturing to the country. The move comes after the Biden administration introduced steep tariff increases on Chinese imports, including electric vehicle batteries and computer chips. Malaysian executives are lobbying against the US imposing tariffs on products made or assembled in Malaysia by Chinese groups. The surge in imports from South-east Asian countries, such as Vietnam, has been fueled by foreign investment from China, but uncertainty remains over new tariffs on Chinese-made goods in the region.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional gains on Tuesday; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% on Tuesday, tracking regional gains, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,326.28. The Nikkei 225 and Kospi Composite Index also gained 1% and 0.4% respectively. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB rose 0.3%, 0.7%, and 1.1% respectively. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI declined 0.3%. Market analyst Yeap Jun Rong attributed the gains to risk-taking sentiments and a weaker US dollar.

site_title: Thailand agrees to waive fees for hotels for 2 more years
summary: Thailand's cabinet agreed to extend a waiver on operating fees for hoteliers for two more years, from July, to support the recovery of the tourism sector. The waiver, which costs the government 54 million baht (S$1.99 million) in lost revenue, will help reduce expenses for hotel operators impacted by Covid-19. The move aims to aid the sector's recovery and may remain unable to recover.

images.alt_text: epa10953922 Tourists from India visit Wat Arun or Temple of Dawn in Bangkok, Thailand, 02 November 2023. The Thai cabinet approved a visa exemption for tourists from India and Taiwan to enter Thailand for a 30-day stay, effective from 10 November 2023 to 10 May 2024, as part of the government's policy to boost the tourism industry. The Thai government is targeting about 28 million visitors in 2023 with the hope that the tourism sector can revive the country's economy.  EPA-EFE/RUNGROJ YONGRIT

site_title: US probing China Telecom, China Mobile over Internet, cloud risks
summary: The US Commerce Department is investigating China Mobile, China Telecom, and China Unicom over concerns the state-backed firms could exploit access to American data through their US cloud and internet businesses by providing it to Beijing. Authorities have subpoenaed the companies and completed "risk-based analyses" of China Mobile and China Telecom, but are not as advanced in their probe of China Unicom. The investigation aims to prevent Beijing from exploiting Chinese firms' access to US data to harm companies, Americans, or national security, as part of a deepening tech war between the US and China.

summary: Tech titans had another tough day, with the US economy remaining strong. Oil prices rose due to fuel demand expectations, easing the US dollar. Singapore retained its spot as the most expensive city for high-net-worth individuals to live well. The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) edged down 0.1% at Tuesday's open, while Asian markets rebounded on bargain-buying but tech worries persisted.

site_title: 👾 ChatGPT, is AI coming for my job?
summary: A recent study found that freelance graphic designers and copywriters experienced a significant decline in job opportunities after ChatGPT's launch. However, industry watchers believe that AI will not fully replace workers, especially in multi-faceted roles. Instead, AI is likely to be integrated into various aspects of work, particularly in finance, healthcare, and education. Human oversight and management will still be necessary, and workers who learn to use AI as a tool will have the most to gain.

images.alt_text: Chloe Lim
While the US remains the leader in the AI race, industry watchers agree that Southeast Asia can carve out its niche with context-specific innovations and strategic initiatives.

site_title: English winemaker Chapel Down touts sale to fund growth plans
summary: English winemaker Chapel Down Group is conducting a strategic review to fund its long-term growth plans. The company, known for its sparkling wines, may consider a sale, investment from existing shareholders, or bringing in new investors. Chapel Down aims to invest in new vineyards, build a new winery, and develop its base in Tenterden, England, ahead of the 2026 harvest. The review follows the company's recent success, including its Rosé English sparkling wine being named to the Decanter World Wine list's top 50 globally. A sale or investment is not guaranteed.

site_title: EU charges Microsoft with abusive bundling of Teams with Office
summary: The European Union has charged Microsoft with abusing its dominant position in the market by bundling its Teams app with Office 365, a practice that was deemed insufficiently addressed by the company's recent unbundling efforts. The EU's competition watchdog was triggered by a 2020 complaint from Slack, a competing workspace messaging app. Microsoft has agreed to work with regulators to find solutions to address concerns, but the company has been accused of tying its communication and collaboration product to its productivity applications, stifling competition.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Teams app is seen on the smartphone placed on the keyboard in this illustration taken, July 26, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/

site_title: Five structural shifts supporting EM debt
summary: Emerging markets debt is poised to outperform other fixed income assets due to five structural shifts in the economic environment. These shifts include cyclical headwinds turning into tailwinds, maturation of emerging market economies, solid fundamentals with lower debt-to-GDP ratios, more favorable demographics, and the great power competition between the US and China. As inflationary pressures ease and global supply chains forge geopolitical alliances, emerging markets' growth is expected to regain its premium, surpassing and remaining above 2% for the foreseeable future. This could lead to attractive returns and total returns reaching double digits.

images.alt_text: The market has been abuzz with AI being an investment theme, with Nvidia which clocked in a nearly 10-fold gain from the lows in 2022 leading the pack.

site_title: Zurich Insurance adding 600 people in India following Kotak deal
summary: Zurich Insurance plans to expand its business in India by adding 600 people, a 40% increase in headcount over the next three years. The Swiss firm acquired a 70% stake in Kotak General Insurance Company for $666 million, becoming the first foreign insurer to enter the country after investment limits were relaxed in 2021. India is seen as a "super important, super attractive market" with opportunities for growth in various sectors, including commercial, small and medium enterprise, and general insurance, according to Zurich's CEO for Asia Pacific.

images.alt_text: GXBank CEO Pei-Si Lai (left) and Zurich Malaysia head Junior Cho (right).

Operating profit at Europe’s fifth-largest insurer rose 21 per cent to a record US$7.4 billion for the year to Dec 31, beating the US$7.1 billion average estimate in an analyst poll compiled by the company.

site_title: China premier warns decoupling will lead to ‘destructive spiral’
summary: China's Premier Li Qiang warned that economic decoupling would lead to a "destructive spiral" and negative consequences for the world, as nations compete for a smaller share of global markets. Despite a prolonged property slump, Li expressed optimism on China's economy, citing a 5% growth target for this year. Li also defended China's industrial policy, saying exploration should not be seen as a zero-sum game, and hinted at potential benefits for Germany if the EU scraps planned tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Sales during the marquee Singles Day shopping bonanza last year grew just 2 per cent.
The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.
China has pledged greater fiscal stimulus to prop up its fragile economy.
The yuan has dropped to seven-month lows this week, alongside a reversal in equity investment flows into China.

site_title: US dollar’s dominance secure, Brics see no progress on de-dollarisation: report
summary: The US dollar's dominance in the global economy remains secure, according to a report by the Atlantic Council's GeoEconomics Center. Despite efforts by Brics countries, including China, to shift towards alternative currencies, the US dollar continues to hold the top spot as the world's primary reserve currency. The report notes that China's renminbi (RMB) share in global foreign currency reserves has decreased to 2.3% due to concerns over Beijing's stance on the Russia-Ukraine war and potential geopolitical risks. The euro's international role is also weakening, with investors turning to gold instead.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which measures it against six major currencies, was last at 105.56, edging back from a nearly eight-week high of 105.91 it touched last week.
Euro, Hong Kong dollar, U.S. dollar, Japanese yen, British pound and Chinese 100-yuan banknotes are seen in a picture illustration shot January 21, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Lee/Illustration/File Photo

The US Treasury’s semi-annual currency report found that none of the countries examined met all three criteria triggering “enhanced analysis” of their foreign exchange practices during the four quarters through December 2023.

site_title: India's Adani Group to increase capex to US$15.6 billion in fiscal 2025, CFO says
summary: Adani Group, a major Indian ports-to-power conglomerate, plans to increase capital expenditures to $15.6 billion in fiscal 2025, up from $700 billion a year earlier. The group is betting on infrastructure spending, which is expected to grow at a 20-25% compounded annual rate. The company will allocate $340 billion to expand its renewable energy capacity by 6 gigawatts. Billionaire owner Gautam Adani stated the group is "well positioned" to capitalize on opportunities in India's booming infrastructure sector.

site_title: City Developments takes out S$400 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has secured a S$400 million sustainability-linked loan from DBS to advance nature conservation and sustainable development in Singapore. The loan, guided by targets set by CDL's adoption of the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) disclosures, aims to incentivize the company's efforts to achieve significant environmental, social, and governance (ESG) milestones. CDL plans to use the loan for general corporate funding and working capital purposes, including redevelopment of existing assets, to enhance its triple bottom line through sustainable development.

images.alt_text: City Developments is the first corporate to obtain the OCBC 1.5°C loan.
Kwek Leng Beng, executive chairman of CDL

site_title: Singaporean households can now redeem S$300 CDC vouchers
summary: Singaporean households can now claim S$300 in Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers for daily expenses. The vouchers can be claimed online and will be split equally for spending at participating hawkers, heartland merchants, and supermarkets. This is the first time two tranches of CDC vouchers have been given out in the same calendar year, totaling S$800 in 2024. The vouchers aim to support households with cost-of-living concerns and an uncertain economic outlook, with over S$1 billion spent across four tranches.

site_title: Jasper Investments to buy marine engineering company with additional S$13 million fundraise
summary: Jasper Investments agreed to acquire a 51% stake in Prosper Excel Engineering for S$7.5 million, funded by proceeds from its fundraising and debt capitalisation exercise. The acquisition aims to tap on Prosper's core strengths, including its vessel owner and offshore support vessel operator network. As part of the exercise, Jasper also entered into additional subscription agreements with new investors, raising S$13 million. The funding will be used to strengthen the company's balance sheet and pursue growth plans.

images.alt_text: Jasper is a mainboard-listed company that invests in marine and shipping activities.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei closes at highest since mid-April as value shares rally
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed at its highest level since April 15, rising 0.95% to 39,173.15. Investors shifted focus to value stocks, while a weaker yen supported export-related shares. The broader Topix index climbed 1.72% to 2,787.37. Sentiment towards artificial intelligence and chip-related shares remained subdued due to recent declines in US semiconductor stocks, including Nvidia's third consecutive loss.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore and Manila were all in the green, though Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta inched down on Tuesday.

site_title: Ozempic maker Novo plans another US$4.1 billion US factory
summary: Novo Nordisk, the maker of diabetes and weight-loss drugs Ozempic and Wegovy, plans to invest $4.1 billion in a new US factory in Clayton, North Carolina, doubling its US production footprint and adding 1,000 jobs. The facility, which will be completed between 2027 and 2029, is part of a $6.8 billion investment in production this year, up from $3.9 billion in 2023. The move aims to increase supply for the company's high-demand drugs amid criticism of their cost in the US.

images.alt_text: Novo Nordisk would initially focus on patients paying out-of-pocket for Wegovy. Ozempic won approval from China in 2021.

site_title: Asia: Markets rebound on bargain-buying but tech worries linger
summary: Asian markets rebounded on Tuesday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, and Manila all rising, while Wellington, Taipei, and Jakarta inched down. The rebound came despite another tough day for US tech stocks, raising concerns about a market correction. Investors remain uncertain about the Federal Reserve's interest rate plans, with the focus shifting to the release of the personal consumption expenditures index on Friday. The yen strengthened against the dollar, with officials warning of potential intervention to support the currency, which has hit 30-year lows.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.7 per cent higher, slightly below a nearly two-week high hit earlier in the session.
AI star Nvidia, which has risen spectacularly over the last year to attain a market capitalisation above US$3 trillion, fell 6.7 per cent in the stock’s third straight down day.
