A stable rupee and easing inflation boosting the prospect for rate cuts are other positives.

site_title: Atome Financial secures up to US$100 million in growth debt facility from EvolutionX
summary: Atome Financial has secured a US$100 million three-year term loan facility from EvolutionX Debt Capital to drive expansion of its profitable regional credit portfolio and launch new products in Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia. The debt facility's accordion feature will allow the company to increase the total loan amount. Atome Financial, part of Advance Intelligence Group, reported a 40% year-on-year increase in gross merchandise value for its buy-now-pay-later business in FY2023 and turned profitable in the first quarter of 2024.

images.alt_text: Gen Z, those between 18 and 24 years old, and young millennials between 25 and 34 years old, were among the bigger users of BNPL..

site_title: Olam Agri obtains US$550 million loan facility
summary: Olam Agri, a subsidiary of Olam Group, has secured a US$550 million revolving credit facility with a three-year tenor. The proceeds will be used to refinance existing loans and for general corporate purposes. The facility was initially guaranteed by Olam Group but will be transferred to Olam Agri following its planned initial public offering (IPO) and demerger.

images.alt_text: Olam's earnings per share stands at S$0.0567 for the half year, up from S$0.0478 the previous year.
Olam Group expects the acquisition, which is funded from a combination of existing cash and debt facilities, to be earnings accretive from 2024.
Namoi’s assets include gins, or “cotton engines” that separate cotton fibres from their seeds.

site_title: India kicks off US$11.5 billion spectrum auction; analysts expect lacklustre bidding
summary: India has kicked off a US$11.5 billion spectrum auction, offering 10 GHz of radiowaves for sale between 800 MHz to 26 GHz. Analysts expect a lacklustre bidding process, as telecom firms have already acquired sufficient spectrum in the previous auction. Bharti Airtel is expected to bid for expiring spectrum, while Jio is likely to be selective. The auction follows a delayed start, with the government offering a lower amount of spectrum than the previous year's auction.

images.alt_text: Bharti Airtel, India’s second-ranked telecom carrier by subscribers said consolidated revenue from operations rose 4.4 per cent to 375.99 billion rupees (S$6.1 billion) for the three months to Mar 31.

site_title: Novo Nordisk says its Wegovy weight-loss drug wins China approval
summary: Novo Nordisk's weight-loss drug Wegovy has been approved in China, paving the way for its sales in the world's second-largest economy. The company will initially focus on patients paying out-of-pocket for the weekly injectable drug, which has seen strong demand in other markets. This approval comes as Novo faces patent expiry in China and domestic drugmakers develop generic versions, following Ozempic's approval in 2021, which saw sales double to $698 million in the greater China region last year.

site_title: Saudi Arabia set to become world’s biggest construction market
summary: Saudi Arabia is poised to become the world's largest construction market, with a projected total construction output value of $181.5 billion by 2028, up 30% from 2023 levels. The country's efforts to diversify its economy, driven by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan, will focus on residential property and giga projects. This transformation aims to cater to a growing population and an influx of foreign tourists, with the capital city Riyadh at the forefront, hosting the World Expo in 2030 and possibly the World Cup in 2034.

images.alt_text: The latest data suggest improving sentiment as Riyadh seeks funding for projects to diversify the economy from oil and position it as a link between Asia and Europe.
The Saudi government owns about 82 per cent of Aramco, while the Public Investment Fund holds a further 16 per cent stake.
Aramco shares were priced at 27.25 riyals (S$9.77), near the bottom of a 26.7-to-29 riyals range used in marketing the sale.

site_title: Singapore shares edge down at Tuesday’s open; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.1% lower at 3,311.46 on Tuesday, following mixed US and European market performance. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 60 to 48, with Thai Beverage and Singtel declining 2.1% and 0.4%, respectively. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS rising 0.3% and OCBC slipping 0.4%. The global market was influenced by the US Dow Jones Industrial Average's 0.7% gain and the Europe-wide Stoxx 600's 0.7% rise.

images.alt_text: OCBC's offer for its insurance arm has been deemed not fair but reasonable.

site_title: Beijing’s support to boost Hong Kong IPOs in second half of year
summary: Beijing's support is expected to boost Hong Kong's IPOs in the second half of 2024, following a dismal start to the year. The number of IPO filings in Hong Kong rose 83% in the past two months, while cancellations of listings on the mainland tripled. Stricter rules and a stalled Chinese stock market may drive more major firms to Hong Kong, where proceeds from IPOs have dropped 33% year-on-year. New listings are expected, including those from technology companies, and recent performances of newcomers have added to optimism in the market.

images.alt_text: Home sales in the city remain weak, with high interest rates pricing out many buyers.
Private member clubs have been a staple of the former British colony’s social fabric ever since the Hong Kong Club was established in 1846.
A growing number of small firms from China and Hong Kong are turning to the Nasdaq to raise money, even as geopolitical tensions rise ahead of the US election.
Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75 to 7.85 per US dollar.

site_title: Real wage growth unchanged at 0.4% in 2023; fewer firms gave salary bumps: MOM
summary: Singapore's real wage growth remained unchanged at 0.4% in 2023, despite nominal wage growth of 5.2% due to lower headline inflation. The proportion of firms giving salary bumps declined to 65.6%, while the proportion of profitable businesses remained high at 82.1%. The job market remains tight, with vacancies outnumbering job seekers, and the government urges firms to press on with business and workforce transformation to support sustainable wage growth.

images.alt_text: Renald Yeo
Categorising jobs as needing either academic qualifications or technical skills is wasteful, said President Halimah Yacob.

site_title: Chinese developer Shimao sweetens debt revamp terms ahead of liquidation hearing: sources
summary: Chinese property developer Shimao Group has revised its debt restructuring terms in an effort to gain support from creditors ahead of a liquidation hearing. The revised offer comes after creditors opposed a plan laid out in March following a US$11.5 billion offshore debt default in 2022. Shimao faces a Hong Kong court hearing on June 25 over unpaid loans of HK$1.58 billion. The company aims to fend off a liquidation petition filed by China Construction Bank.

images.alt_text: China’s property sector has been in crisis since 2021 after a regulatory crackdown on high leverage among developers triggered a liquidity crisis.
Under the proposal, Shimao intends to restructure all of its debt, amounting to around US$11.7 billion in offshore notes, bonds and other credit facilities.

site_title: Mid-year outlook: Fed, AI and the US elections
summary: The US market is shifting its focus from traditional economic analysis to structural forces, particularly AI and interest rate trends. The Federal Reserve now expects only one to two rate cuts in 2024, down from an initial seven cuts, due to higher-than-expected inflation. Meanwhile, AI has emerged as a popular investment theme, with Nvidia leading the pack. As the labor market cools, services inflation is expected to fall, and the US dollar's role in the global economy is being reevaluated, with Asia poised to both drive and gain from dollar asset diversification.

images.alt_text: Moody’s projects green, social and sustainable bond issuance could reach US$950 billion in 2024.

site_title: Irish housing crisis turns employers into reluctant realtors
summary: Ireland's housing crisis continues to worsen, with the government committed to supplying an average of 33,000 units per year over the next decade. Businesses, particularly in the services industry, are stepping in to provide staffing accommodation by buying or renting real estate. Companies like Ryanair, Musgrave, and Windmill Healthcare are renting or purchasing properties to house their employees, with some spending millions of euros. The crisis is a significant constraint for big firms and a material issue for voters and businesses, with the central bank governor warning that it could impact foreign direct investment.

images.alt_text: Domestic banks now have a more diversified loan book making up a smaller share of their total balance sheet, a deliberate post-2008 move.
Ireland's Finance Minister Michael McGrath seen presenting the 2024 Budget in a live broadcast on Oct 10.

site_title: China lunar probe returns to Earth with samples
summary: China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe successfully returned to Earth with samples from the far side of the Moon after a 53-day mission, hailed as a "complete success" by the China National Space Administration. The probe, which collected soil and rocks, is believed to hold research promise due to the Moon's rugged features. The mission marks a significant achievement for China's space program, which aims to send a crewed mission to the Moon by 2030 and build a lunar base.

images.alt_text: A large screen shows news footage of China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe collecting a sample from the far side of the moon.

site_title: Fearing losses, banks are quietly dumping real estate loans
summary: Banks are quietly dumping commercial real estate loans, a sign of distress in the market, as high interest rates and low occupancy rates for office buildings lead to defaults. Deutsche Bank, Goldman Sachs, and CIBC have sold delinquent mortgages on office buildings in major US cities, with the troubled loans making up a small but significant portion of the $2.5 trillion in commercial real estate loans held by US banks. This marks a shift from the "extend and pretend" strategy, where banks extended loan terms to struggling property owners, as lenders now accept that defaults are inevitable, leading to potential big losses.

images.alt_text: Substantial revisions to the plan are more likely to meet Fed chair Jerome Powell’s goal of attracting broad support from the central bank’s board.
France’s BNP Paribas, Deutsche Bank and US lenders Citi and Bank of America are among those increasing staffing and courting smaller companies that form the bedrock of the Swiss economy.
Office rents have maintained growth momentum in spite of higher vacancies.
The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.
The banks will be required to detail how they will address those shortcomings, which had not been previously flagged, in September.

site_title: Oracle warns that a TikTok ban would dent revenue and profit
summary: Oracle warns that a potential US ban on TikTok could harm its revenue and profits, with estimated annual losses ranging from $480 million to $800 million. The company relies on TikTok as one of its largest US customers, hosting the app's data on its cloud infrastructure. A ban would require TikTok to find a new cloud vendor, with Oracle considering it a low priority if the app is sold. The US law, signed by President Biden, gives TikTok 270 days to find a buyer or face a ban.

images.alt_text: TikTok is challenging a law passed in April that requires its Chinese-parent ByteDance to divest TikTok’s US assets by Jan 19 or face a ban.
TikTok did not detail the exploit used by attackers, but media reports indicated it involved a direct messaging feature.
AFP, among more than a dozen other fact-checking organisations, is paid by TikTok in several countries to verify videos that potentially contain false information.
TikTok declined to comment on the paused rollout plans and said the company is “guided by demand.”

site_title: Wikileaks’ Julian Assange to plead guilty, ending years long US battle
summary: Wikileaks co-founder Julian Assange, 52, will plead guilty to leaking US national security secrets, ending a nearly 15-year battle over his prosecution. Under a plea agreement, Assange will appear in the US District Court for the Northern Mariana Islands, be sentenced to time served during his 62 months in UK prison, and then return to his native Australia. The deal avoids a potentially lengthy sentence in an American prison and brings an end to an international fight to prosecute Assange, who was accused of encouraging Chelsea Manning to obtain sensitive documents.

The Home Office said the interior minister "must sign an extradition order if there are no grounds to prohibit the (extradition) order being made" and the courts had found none. Assange has 14 days to appeal. (Photo by Daniel LEAL / AFP)

British interior minister Priti Patel on Friday approved the extradition of WikiLeaks’ founder Julian Assange to the United States to face criminal charges, bringing his long-running legal saga closer to a conclusion.

site_title: Gold prices inch lower as focus turns to US inflation data
summary: Gold prices decreased 0.1% to $2,329.64 per ounce as investors await US inflation data, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decisions. The San Francisco Federal Reserve Bank president, Mary Daly, expressed skepticism about rate cuts before inflation reaches 2%. Traders expect a 68% chance of a Fed rate cut in September. Spot palladium prices rose to a one-month high, while silver and platinum also made gains.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: China’s BYD launches third EV model in Japan
summary: China's BYD has launched its third electric vehicle, the Seal EV, in Japan, marking its expansion into the Japanese market. The sedan, priced at 5.28 million yen (S$44,760) for the rear-wheel-drive version, will be BYD's most expensive model in Japan. The vehicle starts from 179,800 yuan in China and offers a range of up to 640 km on a single charge. BYD's expansion in Japan could pose a worry for domestic automakers struggling in China.

images.alt_text: Singapore has also received commitments totalling US$16.9 billion.

site_title: China’s rich spend millions on Shanghai property, bucking crisis
summary: China's luxury real estate market in Shanghai is bucking the trend of the country's bleak property sector. Rich Chinese buyers, many from neighboring provinces, are snapping up homes worth millions, with a US$15 million penthouse sold in just hours. The market is driven by wealthy individuals seeking conservative investments, taking advantage of policy easing measures such as lower down-payment thresholds and relaxed price caps. This trend contrasts with other major Chinese cities, including Beijing, where luxury projects are failing to attract buyers.

images.alt_text: epa10854217 A general view of residential buildings in Beijing, China, 11 September 2023. Dalian and Shenyang in northeastern China, announced they will no longer restrict the amount of residential properties one can buy in most parts of the city, while offering subsidies for buyers and tax relief for sellers. These announcements come on the heels of a series of nationwide support measures for the property sector, including lower mortgage rates for first-time homebuyers.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO

site_title: Charting big tech’s US$70 billion spending spree in South-east Asia
summary: Big tech companies, including Nvidia, Apple, and Microsoft, have committed to investing a total of US$70 billion in South-east Asia over the past 18 months. The region's abundant tech talent, natural resources, and growing consumer markets have attracted investments in AI chip factories, data centers, electric vehicle plants, and cloud infrastructure. Malaysia has received the largest commitments, totaling US$32.9 billion, followed by Singapore with US$16.9 billion. AI projects have received the lion's share of investments, with Amazon Web Services leading the way with a US$22.6 billion commitment. However, some investments have fallen through due to internal issues and macroeconomic factors.

images.alt_text: While the US remains the leader in the AI race, industry watchers agree that Southeast Asia can carve out its niche with context-specific innovations and strategic initiatives.
Big Tech companies are following Apple's lead to deploy measures to manage capital more efficiently to drive earnings growth.

site_title: Condo resale prices up slightly in May; volumes dip as CCR deals fall: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose 0.4% month-on-month in May, while volumes dipped 5.5% from April, reaching 1,084 units. The Outside Central Region accounted for 51.7% of total volumes. Resale prices increased year-on-year by 4.2%, with the Core Central Region seeing a 1.9% drop. Experts attribute the moderation in volumes to the higher Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty for foreign buyers and seasonal factors. Resale prices are expected to continue to rise, with forecasts predicting a 4-6% increase in 2024.

images.alt_text: The city fringe and suburban regions continue to see healthy resale demand.
The parcel has a site area of 28,405.5 sq m and a maximum permissible gross floor area of 71,014 sq m.

site_title: Nvidia enters correction territory as slump erases US$430 billion
summary: Nvidia's shares fell 6.7% on Monday, entering correction territory, erasing about US$430 billion from its market capitalization. This marks the largest three-day value loss for any company in history, according to Bloomberg. The stock's three-day drop represents a 13% decline, surpassing the 10% threshold for a correction. The decline also affected other chipmakers, with the Philadelphia Stock Exchange Semiconductor Index falling 3% on Monday.

images.alt_text: For more than a year now, a surge in demand for Nvidia’s chips sparked by the frenzy surrounding AI has made a mockery of Wall Street’s quarterly financial estimates.
Washington allows the export of some Nvidia technology to the Middle East, but curbs exports of the company’s most sophisticated chips.
Nvidia this week briefly became the largest US company by market value on the back of a more than 1,000 per cent surge in share price since October 2022. It is up 206 per cent in the last 12 months.
The sooner AI is applied for niche purposes and not for everything, everywhere, all at once, the sooner the technology will be useful.

site_title: ‘It’s all happening again.’ The supply chain is under strain
summary: Global supply chain disruptions are intensifying, with shipping rates increasing by a similar magnitude to those during the 2020 pandemic. Houthi rebels in Yemen have targeted ships in the Red Sea, forcing vessels to take longer routes, while a severe drought in Central America has limited the Panama Canal's capacity. Dockworkers in the US and rail workers in Canada are threatening strikes, further straining the system. The World Shipping Council disputes claims that carriers are manipulating capacity and prices, but experts argue that the lack of competition on major routes allows carriers to raise prices.

images.alt_text: Françoise Huang, senior economist for Asia-Pacific at Allianz Trade, notes that while one in two of the companies surveyed say they are considering relocating parts of their supply chains, few are taking actions in this direction.
The Galaxy Leader cargo ship was seized by the Houthis in the Red Sea in early December. Such attacks forced shipping companies to change their routes.

site_title: Preparing Asean for crisis and growth
summary: Asean's economies have seen modest growth despite lingering pandemic effects, outperforming global norms. However, emerging regional and national-level issues pose risks, including regional conflict, security concerns, and potential terrorist reprisals. Asean should promote a more inclusive process, engage in quiet diplomacy, and foster closer economic integration. This includes aligning digital policies, developing infrastructure, and stepping up supply chain resilience. Politicking and potential distractions within member countries also pose challenges, with national-level infighting and politicking potentially misdirecting policies and eroding political will.

The budget debate comes as Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin faces a Constitutional Court case that could potentially lead to his dismissal.

site_title: English Premier League sets new mark as European football revenues soar
summary: The English Premier League set a new revenue record in the 2022-23 season, with total revenue reaching £6.1 billion, an 11% increase from the previous year. European football revenues soared 16% to 35.3 billion euros, driven by match-day revenue and sponsorship deals. The "big five" European leagues generated 19.6 billion euros, with the Bundesliga and Serie A recording the largest average percentage growth, 22% each. However, experts warn that European football is at an "inflection point" and must address challenges of maintaining competitive balance and governance.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Great Eastern, SingPost, Best World, LMIRT, Cordlife
summary: OCBC's offer for its insurance arm has been deemed not fair but reasonable. Great Eastern's shares will be suspended from trading after OCBC's offer closes on Jul 12, as the number of shares held by the public has fallen below the 10% threshold. Best World's exit offer has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by an independent financial adviser. LMIRT's aggregate leverage ratio is estimated to be marginally above the 45% regulatory limit. Cordlife Group has received a letter from a substantial shareholder stating that developments will be closely monitored.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers beat gainers 273 to 259 after 1.2 billion securities worth S$826.6 million changed hands.

site_title: UK government snubs GSK in favour of rival RSV shot from Pfizer
summary: The UK government has chosen Pfizer's Abrysvo vaccine to supply over 3.5 million doses to older adults and 1.4 million doses to pregnant mothers to protect against respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) in England and Northern Ireland over the next two years. This decision is a blow to GSK, which was locked in fierce competition with Pfizer for the contract. The vaccine deliveries are set to start in July, providing protection to the elderly and newborn babies before the next cold season, with Pfizer's shot being the only one cleared for both pregnant women and the elderly.

site_title: China floats perks for German carmakers to prevent EV levies
summary: China has offered to lower its existing 15% tariffs on large-engine cars from the EU in exchange for the bloc dropping planned levies on Chinese electric vehicle (EV) exports. The move came after the EU proposed hiking charges on electric cars to as high as 48% later this year. China's Commerce Minister Wang Wentao hinted at the possibility of advantages for German counterpart Robert Habeck during a meeting in Beijing. The EU and China are engaging in negotiations, with the EU seeking to level the playing field by offsetting Chinese state subsidies.

images.alt_text: China has repeatedly called on the EU to cancel its tariffs, expressing a willingness to negotiate.
The EU provisional duties are set to apply by Jul 4, with the investigation set to continue until Nov 2, when definitive duties, typically for five years, could be imposed.

Companies may cut back more on planned factories as European Union subsidies are hard to access due to bureaucracy and carmakers protect thin EV profit margins.

site_title: MND pares private housing land supply on H2 confirmed list
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) has pared the private housing land supply for the next half-year by 7.3% to 5,050 units, down from 5,450 units in the first half of 2024. This move follows a lacklustre response at recent state land tenders and a decline in new private homes sold last year. The annual private housing supply is expected to be the highest since 2013, with a total of 11,110 units, including 610 units from the Zion Road (Parcel B) reserve list.

images.alt_text: The confirmed list includes two parcels in Media Circle, a Lorong Chuan site, and the first mixed-use site in the upcoming Chencharu precinct.

site_title: Singapore retains spot as costliest city for high-net-worth individuals to live well: report
summary: Singapore has maintained its top spot as the most expensive city for high-net-worth individuals to live well, according to a Julius Baer report. The city-state retained its ranking for the second year in a row due to its reputation for political and economic stability, and pro-business environment. Hong Kong rose to second place, while London and Shanghai shifted positions. The Asia-Pacific region, once the most expensive, saw falling prices in some cities, mainly due to currency fluctuations and a decline in commodity prices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong and Singapore's performance keep Swiss destinations from the top spots for the second year in a row.
Public housing in Singapore continued to be the most attainable option for home ownership, ULI says.
Singapore is widely regarded as the most business-friendly city on earth, says Henley & Partners.

site_title: Britain's Princess Anne in hospital with head injury
summary: Princess Anne, 73, is in hospital with a head injury believed to be caused by a horse's head or legs. She was walking at Gatcombe Park when the incident occurred, and her medical team has confirmed a concussion and minor injuries. The princess is expected to return home this week, but upcoming engagements have been postponed. Her husband, Tim Laurence, and children, Zara and Peter, were present at the time of the incident. The royal family, including King Charles and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, have sent well-wishes for her speedy recovery.

images.alt_text: 'The Crown': Who is Princess Anne?

site_title: China’s Fosun to buy out Henlius Biotech, values it at HK$13.37 billion
summary: China's Fosun Pharma will acquire the remaining stake in Henlius Biotech, valuing the Hong Kong-listed drugmaker at HK$13.37 billion (S$2.3 billion). Fosun International, through its unit Shanghai Fosun Pharmaceutical, is offering HK$24.60 per Henlius share, a 30.6% premium to the target's last close. This deal comes as Fosun Pharma is the controlling shareholder of Henlius Biotech, owning 65.23% of the company.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A company logo is pictured at the headquarters of Shanghai Fosun Pharma Group in Shanghai, China September 13, 2016. REUTERS/Aly Song

site_title: LMIRT’s gearing exceeds 45% amid currency changes
summary: Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust's (LMIRT) gearing ratio has exceeded 45% due to a 3.5% appreciation of the rupiah against the Singapore dollar, reducing asset values. The manager claims this does not breach the 45% aggregate leverage limit set by the Monetary Authority of Singapore's Collective Investment Schemes code, citing depreciation in asset value as a circumstance beyond control. LMIRT's manager emphasizes the trust remains in compliance with financial covenants in its existing loans and will make a necessary announcement once unaudited financial statements are finalized.

images.alt_text: Lippo Karawaci has entered into a conditional sale and purchase agreement with Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) to sell the retail components of Lippo Mall Puri in West Jakarta for an aggregate consideration of US$260 million.
LMIRT's net property income had declined due to higher property operating and maintenance expenses, as well as lower net reversal for impairment loss on trade receivables.
Manulife US Reit’s Centerpointe I & II, in Fairfax, Virginia. The Reit halted distributions last year, following a breach in loan covenants after valuations fell.

site_title: Asia’s best-performing stock market looks primed for more gains
summary: Pakistan's stock market is expected to continue its upward trend, with analysts predicting a 10% gain by year-end. The KSE 100 Index has outperformed Asian peers with a 27% surge in US dollar terms this year, driven by cheap valuations, high positive real rates, and a stable currency. The country's budget and potential IMF loan are also seen as positives. However, political instability remains a concern, and a correction is possible if the market becomes overbought. Despite this, investors remain bullish, citing foreign buying, earnings growth, and robust local liquidity.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) has raised its key policy rate by 12.25 percentage points since April 2022, to curb soaring inflation.
The estimated provisional growth rate of gross domestic product (GDP) for the financial year ending June 2024 is 2.38 per cent, the Pakistan Bureau of Statistics said.
Earlier, in an interview with Reuters, Finance Minister Muhammad Aurangzeb said the country hoped to agree to the contours of a new IMF loan in May.

site_title: Empty Wellington shops send grim economic message to RBNZ hawks
summary: Empty shops in Wellington, New Zealand's capital, signal an economic gloom affecting multiple industries, with the economy heading for its worst year since the Global Financial Crisis in 2009. Despite record immigration, strong population growth, and low unemployment, retailers are struggling, and redundancies are on the rise. Local economists predict a sag in demand, with Retail NZ's CEO describing the current situation as "the worst they have ever felt" and a lack of light at the end of the tunnel.

images.alt_text: The economy is struggling as the RBNZ keeps its key interest rate at 5.5 per cent, the highest since 2008, to bring inflation back under control.
The RBNZ has undertaken its most aggressive policy-tightening since 1999, when the official cash rate was introduced, lifting it by 525 basis points since October 2021 to 5.50 per cent.
The RBNZ, which forecasts 0.2 per cent growth for the quarter, has kept monetary policy restrictive to curb demand and get inflation back under control.

Houses in the Lyall Bay suburb of Wellington, New Zealand, on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020. A housing frenzy at the bottom of the world is laying bare the perils of ultra-low interest rates. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai central bank sees current interest rate ‘robust to many scenarios’
summary: The Bank of Thailand's assistant governor, Piti Disyatat, stated that the current interest rate of 2.5% is "quite robust to many scenarios" and aims to ensure inflation is well-anchored. The central bank is not concerned about inflation, despite government pressure for a rate cut, and its target range remains aligned with economic fundamentals. Headline consumer inflation in May returned to the bank's target range of 1-3% for the first time in a year, and the central bank forecasts economic growth of 2.6% this year, with the potential to reach 3% if a government handout scheme is implemented.

images.alt_text: The BOT has also spurned repeated calls from the government for rate cuts, arguing instead that structural reforms are what the economy needs to spur growth.
Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin said that setting a new range for inflation may give more flexibility in reducing interest rates.
The Bank of Thailand’s (BOT) monetary policy committee voted 6-1 to hold the one-day repurchase rate at 2.5 per cent.
Thailand needs more financing to help with the transition as green and sustainably-linked loans accounted for only 1.4 per cent of total outstanding lending.
Customers at a store in Bangkok. The government has favoured cutting rates from a decade-high 2.5% to boost consumption and growth.
The BOT has previously said that rate cuts and fiscal stimulus would not help the economy much, and it favoured structural reforms to increase productivity.

site_title: Impact of Cordlife’s extended suspension being closely monitored: Nanjing Xinjiekou
summary: SAC Capital is closely monitoring Cordlife's extended suspension, which was ordered by the Ministry of Health up to three months. The company is still considering making a potential offer for Cordlife's remaining shares. SAC Capital has stated that it will "further the discussions" on the offer's terms, indicating ongoing negotiations.

images.alt_text: The arrests of Cordlife's directors and group chief executive are related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations regarding irregular temperatures in its storage tanks.

site_title: Best World’s exit offer ‘fair and reasonable’, says independent financial adviser
summary: Best World's exit offer, a selective capital reduction, has been deemed "fair and reasonable" by independent financial adviser Evolve Capital Advisory. The estimated value of each share ranges between S$1.36 and S$2.69, with the final exit offer price being a premium to the historical trading price and adjusted net asset value. The offer, if approved, will scrap approximately 34.9% of eligible shares, reducing the total share count to 280.3 million.

images.alt_text: Best World announced last month its exit offer by way of a selective capital reduction as it seeks to delist the company.
xxx
Best World says it will take no further action relating to the Mar 21 requisition letter.

site_title: Tencent’s new blockbuster game exceeds US$270 million in 30 days
summary: Tencent's new game, Dungeon & Fighter Mobile, has exceeded $270 million in revenue in its first 30 days, more than doubling the sales of its longstanding best-seller Honor of Kings. The game's success has sparked a rethinking of traditional models, with Tencent deciding to pull it from Android app stores to bypass commission cuts. Analysts predict the game will contribute 5% of Tencent's domestic game sales this year, with gross revenue estimates revised up to 15-18 billion yuan. The game's success marks a significant shift for Tencent, which has been struggling to replace aging titles.

images.alt_text: Currently, users can download and use WeChat on Huawei handsets.
Tencent’s move reflects the cautious mood in an office market showing early signs of weakness due to rising layoffs in sectors such as tech and finance, along with the shift to working from home.
DnF Mobile is a key title for hit-hungry Tencent, as the world’s biggest games publisher replenishes its ageing games portfolio.

site_title: China’s retail outlook dims after mid-year shopping festival flop
summary: China's mid-year online shopping festival, 618, saw a decline in e-commerce sales, marking the first time this has happened. The festival, which is a key indicator of household consumption, reflected the pressures on retailers locked in a price war. Sales growth was just 2% last year, down from previous years. Weak consumer sentiment, fueled by a real estate slump, stunted wage growth, and high youth unemployment, remains stubbornly low, with only 45% of respondents planning to spend more over the next six months. This may hinder China's economic growth goal of around 5% this year.

images.alt_text: Once a bustling tourist shopping destination, Hong Kong’s retail landscape has undergone a sea change after years of political turmoil and Covid closure.
Fosun Pharma is the controlling shareholder of Henlius Biotech and through its other affiliates, owns a total of 65.23 per cent in the Hong Kong listed drugmaker.
Shein’s London filing marks a shift from its long-running US IPO plan, which has run into obstacles at home and abroad.
Tencent hastened the release of DnF Mobile to May after positive feedback in testing, touting the game as a blockbuster that would rekindle growth in its key domestic games division.
The banks were instructed earlier this month to provide additional help to local government financing vehicles in Weifang in Shandong province.

site_title: European airport pollution threatens health of 52 million people: NGO
summary: A European NGO, Transport & Environment, has warned that high concentrations of ultrafine particles (UFPs) released during plane takeoffs and landings pose a health risk to 52 million people living near Europe's busiest airports. UFPs, 1,000 times smaller than a human hair, easily penetrate human tissues and are linked to serious health conditions. The NGO calls for better monitoring and UFP reduction targets, suggesting that reducing air traffic and improving jet fuel quality can mitigate the problem.

images.alt_text: Visitors are gradually returning to the beaches as recovery efforts following the oil spill make progress, says Minister for Sustainability and the Environment Grace Fu.
Singapore-flagged bunker vessel Marine Honour, which was involved in the incident, anchored in the Western Anchorage on June 18.
Experts say climate change doubled the likelihood of floods in southern Brazil and worsened the intense rains caused by El Nino.
Environmental activists lobbying against plastic pollution on International Earth Day (April 22, 2024) in Seoul.

Passengers queueing outside Terminal 1; Manchester Airport says that it was working with airlines to reschedule cancelled flights in the coming days, adding that flights scheduled for Monday would be unaffected.

FILE PHOTO: An aerial photo shows China Southern Airlines and Xiamen Airlines Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft at Boeing facilities at the Grant County International Airport in Moses Lake, Washington, September 16, 2019. REUTERS/Lindsey Wasson/File Photo

site_title: EU sanctions 19 Chinese firms over links to Russian war effort
summary: The European Union has imposed sanctions on 19 Chinese companies for allegedly supporting Russia's war in Ukraine, despite China's denials. The 61 new companies added to the EU's list include satellite giants and firms selling components and equipment to Moscow's military industry. The sanctions target "dual-use goods and technology" that could enhance Russia's defense and security sector. The US and Europe accuse China of indirectly supporting Russia's military efforts, while China claims the accusations are "false information".

images.alt_text: The sanctions targeted Kaspersky's leadership including the chief business development officer, chief operating officer, legal officer, corporate communications chief and others.

The potential benefits for joining Brics go beyond geopolitics. The bloc’s members have agreed to pool US$100 billion of foreign-currency reserves, which they can lend to each other during emergencies.

The new restrictions on inbound sales of Kaspersky software, which will also bar downloads of software updates, resales and licensing of the product, kick in on Sep 29, 100 days after publication, to give businesses time to find alternatives.
The Russian president is expected to participate in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un pose for a photo after the signing of a “comprehensive strategic partnership”.
Construction workers rebuild a destroyed district in Mariupol, Ukraine, on April 17, 2024 amid the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

site_title: OCBC garners over 90% of Great Eastern’s shares; trading in insurer to be suspended after offer closes
summary: OCBC Bank has acquired over 90% of Great Eastern's shares, with its offer price set at S$25.60 per share. The counter will be suspended from trading after the offer closes on July 12 due to the public's dwindling stake below 10%. The offer has been deemed "not fair but reasonable" by an independent financial adviser, and minority shareholders are advised to accept the offer as no other general offer is likely to succeed.

images.alt_text: OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.
For the overall OCBC Group, Great Eastern Holdings is its strategic insurance pillar.
The Great Eastern Life Insurance buliding.
The chairman and CEO of Great Eastern should pledge to invest a significant proportion of their total remuneration in Great Eastern shares
The Great Eastern logo on the facade of Great Eastern Centre located at Pickering Street on 4 Dec 2019.

David Gerald, chief executive of Sias, says that minority shareholders of Great Eastern Holdings feel they have to choose between accepting an offer deemed "unfair" or potentially having their money locked up in an unlisted company for a long time.
OCBC only needs to acquire slightly more than 4.7 million Great Eastern shares to push its stake in the insurer past the 90 per cent threshold.
In May, OCBC made a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$1.4 billion for the remaining 11.56 per cent stake in GEH that it does not own, with the aim to delist the insurer.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 24)
summary: Singapore's core inflation remained unchanged at 3.1% in May, meeting economists' expectations. The country is monitoring the impact of the recent oil spill on beach-front businesses, with estimated losses for Malaysian fishermen affected by the spill at RM480,000. Meanwhile, Singapore's stock market ended higher after inflation data came in line with expectations, with the STI up 0.3%. The World Bank urged Indonesia's President-elect Prabowo Subianto to intensify tax reform efforts to offset a widening fiscal deficit.

site_title: Tesla shareholders seem to fathom Musk’s package just fine
summary: Tesla shareholders have overwhelmingly voted to award Elon Musk a $56 billion pay package, despite a Delaware judge's earlier ruling that the 2018 package was unfair due to its price and process. The judge had found that Musk's pay package was "historically unprecedented" but that Tesla's performance and existence were also unparalleled, with a 1,100% shareholder return from 2018 to 2023. Shareholders are essentially making a bet that Musk's efforts will continue to drive Tesla's success, and the company's performance will justify the payout.

images.alt_text: Tesla and the legal team for Richard Tornetta have been wrestling over the best way to resolve the case and compensate the company’s chief executive.

Elon Musk, CEO of electric vehicle maker Tesla Motors, recently won a shareholder nod for a pay package of US$56 billion. The vote is not binding, but shows that shareholders don’t mind bestowing riches on those who also make them rich.

site_title: Airbus cuts guidance as supply-chain snags continue to bite
summary: Airbus has cut its earnings and aircraft-delivery goals for 2024 due to persistent supply-chain issues, including a shortage of vital components and skilled workers. The company now expects to deliver 770 aircraft this year, down from a previous goal of 800, and has pushed back its goal to produce 75 A320 single-aisle jets per month by one year to 2027. This setback comes as demand for Airbus' jets is at a record, and the company faces economic and geopolitical challenges that are expected to persist for the next 2-3 years.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A220 passenger jet stands in the final assembly line in Mirabel near Montreal, Quebec, Canada January 14, 2019.  REUTERS/Tim Hepher/File Photo

site_title: Paramount Global to raise prices for its streaming plans
summary: Paramount Global is raising prices for its streaming services, including the Paramount+ with Showtime plan, which will cost $12.99 a month, up from $11.99. The Paramount+ Essential subscription rate will increase to $7.99 a month, and the limited Paramount+ commercial option will cost $7.99 a month, starting August 20 and September 20, respectively. The price hikes are part of the company's efforts to recalibrate its business and pay off debt, following failed merger talks with Skydance Media.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Toy figures of people are seen in front of the displayed Paramount + logo, in this illustration taken January 20, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo/File Photo
The New York-based media giant has faced a change in the way consumers watch TV and films.
Paramount has also had discussions with Comcast about a streaming joint venture.
Paramount has been struggling to recover from last year’s months-long strikes by Hollywood writers and actors.

site_title: SingPost settles legal disputes with shares seller
summary: SingPost has settled long-standing legal disputes with a shares seller, Tan Ho Sung, related to a share-purchase agreement and shareholders' agreement for freight forwarder Famous Holdings. The terms of the settlement are confidential, but SingPost's board says it's in the best interests of the company and won't impact net tangible assets or earnings per share for the current financial year. The settlement follows arbitration proceedings started in FY2018 and involves the transfer of 37.5% shares in Famous Holdings.

images.alt_text: SingPost also intends to continue seeking opportunities for mergers and acquisitions, and future liquidity options.
SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.

Proceeds from the sale of SingPost Centre - that is if the divestment gets the green light from authorities and shareholders - will go towards paying off debt, funding investments and rewarding shareholders.
SingPost considers divesting S$1.1 billion SingPost Centre and floating Australian business
This represents the first time SingPost will be using MRT trains for postal collection.
SingPost to make second partial award in arbitration related to Famous Holdings
The completion of the transfer of option shares is fixed for Sep 22, 2023.

site_title: Apple charged with breaching EU tech rules, faces another probe
summary: European Union antitrust regulators charged Apple with breaching EU tech rules, citing breaches of the Digital Markets Act (DMA). The charge, the first under the landmark DMA, could result in a hefty fine for the iPhone maker. Apple faces another investigation into new fees imposed on app developers. The European Commission has until March 2025 to issue a final decision.

images.alt_text: Apple underscored its AI push earlier this month with a slew of new features and software enhancements for its iPhone and other devices to bolster sagging sales.

site_title: A list of fundraising startups from Asia and beyond
summary: Tech in Asia has compiled a list of fundraising startups from Asia and beyond. Notable startups include GoTo, which is expected to rebound after a $2.2 billion sell-off, and Vietnamese AI company AI Hay, which raised $10 million in Series-A funding. OpenAI is also set to release a web browser, challenging Google Chrome. Meanwhile, Chinese AI startup Manus is accelerating its move to Singapore amid an intensifying AI race. The list highlights various startups across Asia and globally, showcasing their fundraising efforts and innovative endeavors.

site_title: Oil prices rise on fuel demand expectations, easing US dollar
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday, driven by strong summer driving demand and concerns over supply due to Middle East tensions and drone attacks on Russian refineries. The easing US dollar also contributed to the price increase, with Brent futures settling at $86.01 a barrel and US crude at $81.63 a barrel. Analysts expect sustained strong petrol demand, but warn that inflation may erode summer travel spending and lead to a decline in demand in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows oil pump jacks outside Almetyevsk in the Republic of Tatarstan, Russia June 4, 2023. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk/File Photo
Brent crude futures slipped 5 cents to US$85.19 a barrel by 0417 GMT, after settling down 0.6 per cent on Friday. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures were at US$80.66 a barrel, down 7 cents.

site_title: Europe: Shares start the week higher on autos, banks
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 closed 0.7% higher, driven by gains in automobile and financial stocks, with banks rising 1.7% and automobile shares adding 1.5%. The European Union and China agreed to discuss tariffs on Chinese-made electric vehicles. Ahead of French parliamentary elections, analysts shifted their views, expecting a more fiscally responsible government, and the French benchmark closed 1% higher. German business morale fell in June, while US stocks edged down despite reaching fresh records.

images.alt_text: AI star Nvidia, which has risen spectacularly over the last year to attain a market capitalisation above US$3 trillion, fell 6.7 per cent in the stock’s third straight down day.

site_title: US Federal Reserve floats weaker version of planned bank-capital overhaul
summary: The US Federal Reserve has floated a revised version of its planned bank-capital overhaul, significantly lightening the load on Wall Street lenders. The revised plan would reduce the overall 16% capital hike to as low as 5%, a move seen as a victory for the banking industry. The changes would also walk back key parts of the original proposal, including one related to market risk, which could affect banks with large trading businesses. The revised plan is more likely to meet Fed Chair Jerome Powell's goal of attracting broad support from the central bank's board, but US officials have yet to reach an agreement and it's unclear if the revised package can be finalized before the US presidential election in November.

images.alt_text: It could be just a matter of time before the Fed cuts rates, which should take pressure off regional currencies
The banks will be required to detail how they will address those shortcomings, which had not been previously flagged, in September.
"Job number one is to make sure that we get inflation back to 2 per cent,” New York Fed Bank president John Williams said.

WASHINGTON, DC - JUNE 12: Federal Reserve Bank Chair Jerome Powell announces that interest rates will remain unchanged during a news conference at the Federal Reserves’s William McChesney Martin building on June 12, 2024 in Washington, DC. Following the two-day Federal Open Markets Committee meeting Powell said the Fed has decided to keep their current rate range of 5.25-5.50 percent and signaled that it believes long-run rates will stay higher than previously indicated.   Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Kevin Dietsch / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Hong Kong’s New World completes HK$35 billion loan arrangements, debt repayments this year
summary: Hong Kong's New World Development has completed HK$35 billion (S$6.1 billion) in loan arrangements and debt repayments, including refinancing a HK$9.25 billion hotel loan. The company has one of the highest debt ratios in Hong Kong's property sector and is working to de-leverage. New World has increased its use of yuan loans to reduce financing costs and plans to dispose of non-core assets worth HK$8 billion this year. The company aims to maintain a solid financial position through cost control measures.

site_title: Foxconn to invest US$383 million in Vietnam circuit board plant: state media
summary: Foxconn has invested US$383 million in a factory to produce printed circuit boards in Vietnam, according to state media. The plant in Bac Ninh province will produce 2.79 million products annually, expanding the company's existing investments of over US$3.2 billion in the country since the 2000s.

site_title: Apple spurned idea of iPhone AI partnership with Meta months ago
summary: Apple rejected a proposal to integrate Meta's Llama AI chatbot into the iPhone months ago due to concerns over Meta's privacy practices, according to sources. The companies had brief talks in March but did not progress to a formal partnership. Apple instead opted to partner with OpenAI and Alphabet's Gemini, citing their superior offerings and existing relationships with Google. Apple's chatbot technology, Apple Intelligence, will roll out later this year as part of its operating systems.

images.alt_text: An Apple store in San Francisco, California, US, on Tuesday, June 11, 2024. Apple Inc. shares rose to a record after it took the wraps off long-awaited new artificial intelligence features, betting that a personalized and understated approach to the technology will win over customers. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg
Apple is also expected to discuss partnerships with other AI companies in different regions such as China, where Microsoft-backed OpenAI chatbot ChatGPT is banned.
Apple underscored its AI push earlier this month with a slew of new features and software enhancements for its iPhone and other devices to bolster sagging sales.
Existing users of the BNPL service, Apple Pay Later will still be able to manage and pay open loans via the Wallet app, the company says.

site_title: Croatia’s Modric bemoans ‘cruel’ late draw with Italy at Euro 2024
summary: Croatia's Luka Modric expressed disappointment after a late 1-1 draw with Italy at Euro 2024, eliminating them from the tournament. Modric, the oldest goalscorer in European Championship history, scored the equalizing goal in the 55th minute, but Italy's Mattia Zaccagni equalized in the 88th minute. Croatia finished third in Group B behind Italy and Spain, and will be knocked out of the tournament if England beats Slovenia 3-0 or Denmark beats Serbia. Modric vowed to continue playing despite the heartbreak, saying it's "part and parcel of football."

images.alt_text: Fifa's new Club World Cup tournament has also been criticised by the player unions who say that it will put the world’s elite footballers under too much physical strain.
France's forward Kylian Mbappe, wearing a protective mask, at a training session at the Home Deluxe Arena Stadium in Paderborn, Germany, June 23, 2024.
Hungary's Kevin Csoboth scores their first goal past Scotland's Angus Gunn in stoppage time in Stuttgart, Germany, June 23, 2024.

site_title: Sri Lanka set to start next round of investor talks this week
summary: Sri Lanka is set to hold a second round of direct talks with bondholders this week to agree on the restructuring of $12 billion in defaulted bonds. The talks come as the country prepares for presidential elections in mid-October and need to reach deals with both bondholders and bilateral lenders to keep receiving IMF disbursements. A group of bondholders, known as the steering committee, will continue to negotiate on the government's new proposal, which is crucial for the country's debt overhaul and IMF bailout. Swift progress is key for Sri Lanka's economic stability.

site_title: Private markets outlook: from headwinds to tailwinds
summary: Institutional investors remain committed to private assets despite a challenging global economic environment. State Street's third global survey of private markets shows that investors expect sustained growth in demand for private assets, with nearly half of institutions planning to increase their exposures over the next five years. Demand for holistic data platforms is also on the rise, with a quarter of respondents citing it as "transformational" for their private markets operations. Regulatory developments and improved risk assessment are also driving growth in private markets, with institutions seeking better risk measurement and portfolio data to support their investments.

images.alt_text: Market data shows private equity and private credit have significantly outperformed traditional asset classes in recent years.
The UBS Singapore Family Wealth comes after UBS released its Global Family Office report in May.

site_title: Former European Investment Bank head Werner Hoyer in EU corruption probe
summary: Former European Investment Bank (EIB) head Werner Hoyer is under investigation by the European Public Prosecutor's Office (EPPO) for corruption, abuse of influence, and misappropriation of EU funds. Hoyer, who led the bank from 2012 to 2023, denies the allegations, calling them "absurd and unfounded." He claims to be fully cooperating with the investigation, which is focusing on compensation money paid to another EIB employee. The EIB has agreed to cooperate with the EPPO's investigation.

site_title: Heineken to close one of its breweries in Vietnam
summary: Heineken, the world's second-largest brewer, plans to close one of its breweries in Vietnam due to weak demand and stricter drink and driving laws. The facility in Quang Nam province, which has operated since 2007, will be shut down. Economic slowdown and tighter regulations have affected beer consumption in Vietnam, with the country's finance ministry planning to increase a special consumption tax on alcoholic drinks to 100% by 2030. This move is expected to further harm the industry.

site_title: Cracks appearing in Singapore’s prime office rental market as rent growth eases
summary: Singapore's prime office rental market is experiencing cracks as rent growth slows, with a 1.3% increase in the first half of 2024, compared to 2.5% in the same period last year. Vacancy rates rose to 5.4% in the second quarter, driven by the completion of new developments. Landlords are adjusting their rental expectations, and occupiers are taking advantage of the market to renegotiate rents. Despite this, some sectors, such as insurance and private-wealth, continue to support growth, and Knight Frank expects rents to grow 1-3% in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: A slowdown in the global economy remains the top risk that might adversely affect market sentiment in the next six months, a survey by Ireus has found.

site_title: Spain complete perfect Euro 2024 group stage as Albania go out
summary: Spain completed a perfect Euro 2024 group stage with a 1-0 win over Albania, as Ferran Torres scored the only goal in the 13th minute. The victory eliminated Albania from the tournament. Spain made 10 changes to their starting lineup, which had beaten Italy 1-0 four days earlier, showcasing their depth and resilience.

images.alt_text: Fifa's new Club World Cup tournament has also been criticised by the player unions who say that it will put the world’s elite footballers under too much physical strain.
France's forward Kylian Mbappe, wearing a protective mask, at a training session at the Home Deluxe Arena Stadium in Paderborn, Germany, June 23, 2024.
Hungary's Kevin Csoboth scores their first goal past Scotland's Angus Gunn in stoppage time in Stuttgart, Germany, June 23, 2024.
Croatia's midfielder Luka Modric reacts to their probable Euro championship exit after the match between Croatia and Italy in Leipzig, Germany, June 24, 2024.

site_title: US: Dow rises while Nasdaq drops on Nvidia retreat
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.7% to 39,411.21, while the S&P 500 dropped 0.3% to 5,447.87. The Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 1.1% to 17,496.82, weighed down by a decline in tech stocks including Nvidia, which fell 6.7% for its third straight down day. Analysts attribute the market's mixed performance to a wait-and-see mode ahead of major news events, including a US presidential debate and key inflation data.

images.alt_text: Traders work at the post where GameStop is traded on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 12, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Blaze in South Korea battery plant kills 22 workers
summary: A blaze at a lithium battery factory in Hwaseong, South Korea, killed 22 workers, mostly Chinese nationals, in a six-hour fire that began after a series of battery cells exploded. The fire spread too quickly for workers to escape, and officials say the high death toll may be due to the use of toxic materials. President Yoon Suk-yeol visited the scene, and Interior Minister Lee Sang-min called for measures to prevent chemical contamination. The company, Aricell, has 48 employees and is majority-owned by S-Connect, which saw its shares drop 22.5% after the incident.

images.alt_text: epa11433880 Firefighters retrieve the bodies of workers at the site of a fire at a primary lithium battery factory in Hwaseong, South Korea, 24 June 2024. The fire reportedly left about 20 workers dead.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP / POOL SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: Hedging China EV makers is getting pricey with imminent tariffs
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers are bracing for higher costs due to impending tariffs. The cost of Li Auto options traded in Hong Kong has reached its highest level since February 2023, while BYD and Geely Automobile Holdings' implied volatility is at an almost one-year high. Governments worldwide, including the US, EU, and Canada, are planning new tariffs on Chinese EVs, with levies of up to 48% on cars shipped from China. This adds to the headwinds faced by Chinese EV makers, which are already under pressure from export price cuts and pressure to cut emissions.

images.alt_text: The levies look to level the playing field by offsetting the Chinese aid with something of equal value
China has repeatedly called on the EU to cancel its tariffs, expressing a willingness to negotiate.
Xiaomi’s Lei Jun, who has nearly 24 million followers on the Chinese social media platform Weibo, is one executive piling pressure on his peers to up their social media game.

site_title: China foreign direct investment falls for 12 straight months
summary: China's foreign direct investment (FDI) declined for the 12th consecutive month, with a 28.2% drop in the first five months of 2024 to 412.51 billion yuan (S$76.87 billion). This follows a high comparison base and efforts by the Chinese government to attract foreign investment, with Premier Li Qiang focusing on stabilizing FDI this year. The decline in FDI underscores China's struggle to improve its appeal to overseas investors and boost growth, amid concerns about diminishing growth prospects.

site_title: UBS to sell partial stake of a joint venture to Beijing state asset manager
summary: UBS is selling a 36.01% stake in its joint venture, Credit Suisse Securities, to Beijing State-owned Asset Management (BSAM) for US$91.4 million. This sale comes after UBS started looking for a buyer last year, following the merger with Credit Suisse. The move is part of UBS's efforts to consolidate operations in China, as China's securities regulation prohibits any entity from having more than one majority-owned securities firm locally.

images.alt_text: UBS says the buyback programme will be worth up to US$1 billion this year.

site_title: France faces biggest uncertainty of Macron era
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron faces his biggest uncertainty as a leader, with his National Assembly dissolving for a fresh national election on June 30 and July 7. The National Rally party, led by Marine Le Pen, is expected to win the most votes, but securing an overall majority of 289 seats would be a significant blow to Macron's legacy. A National Rally victory could lead to a financial crisis in the eurozone's second-largest economy, prompting Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire to warn of a "Truss-style scenario." The outcome will be clear by 2027, when Macron's presidency is set to end.

images.alt_text: European election posters of the French far-right National Rally (Rassemblement National - RN) party with pictures of their leaders Marine Le Pen and Jordan Bardella are seen near the RN party headquarters in Paris, the day after French far-right win in European Parliament vote and the announcement of early legislative elections in France, June 10, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes

Despite the prospect of a hung parliament, French President Emmanuel Macron insisted he would finish out his term until 2027, defying calls from opponents to step down in case the far-right National Rally comes out on top.
France’s biggest lenders, including BNP Paribas and Societe Generale, drop more than 10 per cent over the week.
French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap legislative election after the defeat in the EU votes.

site_title: Sovereign green bonds: bigger, stronger and more diverse in 2024
summary: Sovereign green bonds saw a record 35 countries issue sustainable bonds totaling US$169 billion in 2023, with sovereigns accounting for 20% of the market. Moody's projects GSS bond issuance to reach US$950 billion in 2024, while S&P forecasts issuance to surpass US$1 trillion. Emerging market sovereigns, particularly those with climate finance gaps, are driving the growth. The European Union Green Bonds Standard will improve reporting and transparency in the market, and sovereigns are increasingly using GSS bonds to finance climate goals, with some issuers, such as Iceland and Brazil, entering the market for the first time.

images.alt_text: Moody’s projects green, social and sustainable bond issuance could reach US$950 billion in 2024.

site_title: Dubai to spend 30 billion dirhams on drainage after rains paralysed city
summary: Dubai has approved a 30 billion dirhams ($11 billion) project to build a drainage network, increasing the emirate's capacity to absorb 20 million cubic meters of water per day. The system will be built in stages and completed by 2033 after record rains in April caused widespread flooding, damage, and disruption, with estimated losses of hundreds of millions of US dollars. The project aims to improve Dubai's readiness to face future climate challenges, with the city's ruler, Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum, calling the exceptional weather event a "teaching moment" for the city's infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Dubai home values have risen for 15 consecutive quarters and are up 20 per cent for the year ending May, according to Cushman & Wakefield Core.
The casino will help attract gamblers but also offer families a slice of luxury.

Dubai’s reputation as a choice destination for wealthy families fleeing hostile regimes or wars has surged in recent years, exemplified by the Russian money that flooded in following the invasion of Ukraine.
Vehicles are stranded in flood waters along a highway in Dubai following heavy rains on April 18, 2024

site_title: US: Nasdaq drops as Nvidia, chips drag; inflation data in focus
summary: The US stock market opened lower on June 24, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 49.10 points, or 0.28%, to 17,640.26. This decline was driven by chip stocks, including Nvidia, which remained under selling pressure. Investors are cautious ahead of inflation data, which will shape bets on rate cuts this year. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.09%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.09%.

site_title: Singapore monitoring impact of oil spill on beach-front businesses: Grace Fu
summary: Singapore is monitoring the impact of the recent oil spill on beach-front businesses, particularly those operating sea-based activities. The government has made "good progress" in the cleanup efforts, with the first phase largely completed. Businesses affected by the perception of the smell and oil spill can resume operations once visitor confidence returns. However, businesses operating on the water, such as kayak rental shops, will not be able to resume operations until the cleanup is done. The recovery efforts are expected to take around three months, with some areas expected to reopen earlier than others.
