site_title: Three arrested for involvement in gold ingot bait-and-switch scam
summary: Three men aged 52-62 have been arrested for allegedly cheating a victim of S$4,000 with fake gold ingots. The suspects claimed to have found the gold ingots during excavations in Singapore and produced a document with old Chinese writings to give credibility to their scam. The incident occurred on June 19, and the suspects were arrested by the Singapore Police Force on June 21.

images.alt_text: Su Haijin was formerly a director of Catalist-listed food and beverage operator No Signboard.
E-commerce players will be required to verify users who advertise or post about sales of goods and services using government-issued records, among other measures.
Using a single SMS sender ID will make it easier for the public to identify authentic government communications sent via SMSes.

Warren Buffett, chairman and chief executive officer of Berkshire Hathaway., during the company's annual meeting in Omaha, Nebraska, in 2022. Berkshire Hathaway delivered about 20.5 per cent annually from 1965 to 2018.
The event attracted more than 800 seniors and skills – such as learning how to make digital payments – were imparted using a gamified approach.

site_title: American Express to buy restaurant booking platform Tock for US$400 million
summary: American Express is acquiring restaurant booking platform Tock for US$400 million to expand its presence in the travel and entertainment market. The deal will add 7,000 restaurants to AmEx's network and enable restaurants to target premium customers. This acquisition builds on AmEx's 2019 purchase of online restaurant reservation platform Resy. The buyout also includes the purchase of Rooam, a contactless payments platform used by restaurants and other businesses.

site_title: Apple to delay launch of AI-powered features in Europe, blames EU tech rules
summary: Apple plans to delay the launch of three AI-powered features in Europe due to EU tech rules requiring it to ensure rival products can function with its devices. The delayed features include Apple Intelligence and iPhone Mirroring on MacOS Sequoia. The US tech group aims to ensure that its devices can be compatible with other products and services, bolstering sagging sales. This decision comes after Apple recently highlighted its AI push with new features and software enhancements for its iPhone and other devices.

site_title: UK public debt rises to highest since 1961 ahead of election
summary: The UK's public debt has reached its highest level since 1961, standing at £2.742 trillion (US$3.47 trillion) or 99.8% of annual gross domestic product in May. This increase comes despite lower-than-expected government borrowing, and economists warn that the next government will face significant financial challenges. The UK's debt levels are still lower than those in the US, France, and Italy, but the country's slow growth and rising interest rates have put pressure on the public finances.

images.alt_text: UK Inflation returned to its 2 per cent target last month, and morale has steadily recovered, but most households are still worse off tan before the inflation surge, weighing heavily on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s political chances in July 4‘s election.
The BOE has said a return of inflation to its target is not enough on its own for it to start cutting interest rates.
The average British house price hit a record high in May and first-time homebuyers are facing the toughest financial environment in 70 years.

FILE PHOTO: A tourist shelters from the rain under an Union Jack umbrella near the Bank of England in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, February 13, 2024. REUTERS/Isabel Infantes/File Photo
Billings for temporary staff has dropped by the least since January.
Housing has become one of the flashpoints in the general election.
Factories’ prices rose by the most in a year after the fifth consecutive monthly acceleration in increases.
Rapid restaurant and hotel price rises and high mortgage rates mean the richest are now suffering more from persistent inflationary pressures.
Confidence about the broader economy was at its highest since September 2021.

site_title: MSCI keeps South Korea listed as emerging market amid ban on shorts
summary: MSCI has maintained South Korea's status as an emerging market despite the country's ban on short-selling stocks. The ban, which prohibits a common trading strategy, has introduced market accessibility restrictions and hurt the market's reputation. MSCI cited the ban as a barrier to an upgrade to developed status, citing concerns about sudden changes in market rules. The ban is expected to be temporary, but its impact on the market's appeal with foreign investors remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: A potential resumption of short selling has been a key focus among investors as the trading strategy is widely used in other markets.
South Korea’s Capital Markets Act bans ‘naked’ short-selling of stocks, in which an investor sells shares without first borrowing them or determining they can be borrowed.
South Korea’s Capital Markets Act bans ‘naked’ short-selling of stocks, in which an investor sells shares without first borrowing them or determining they can be borrowed.

site_title: In China’s Hainan, championship-level golf courses, food and spas galore
summary: Golf enthusiasts can experience championship-level courses in China's Hainan province, particularly at the Mission Hills Resort in Haikou city. The Blackstone course, described as one of the best in the world by Tiger Woods, offers a challenging 350-acre layout with ancient houses, shrines, and wetlands. The resort also features other courses, including the Lava Fields and the 36-hole The Dunes at Shenzhou Peninsula. Outside of golf, Hainan offers a range of culinary delights, including fresh longans and coconuts, and a variety of local restaurants serving traditional dishes. The city's old town quarter and Mission Hills Haikou's Volcanic Spring Valley spa resort also provide opportunities for relaxation and cultural exploration.

images.alt_text: For more experienced athletes, heart rate zone training can help improve speed and endurance.
Woods has failed to make the cut at any other major since the 2022 PGA Championship.
Ronaldo has invested in a range of businesses in recent years as he prepares for life after his sports career.
President Thomas Bach says IOC will use AI at Paris in different areas.

site_title: Aged to imperfection?
summary: Singapore is rapidly ageing, with a quarter of the population expected to be 65 years and older by 2030. Ageism, a form of prejudice against older people, is prevalent and can have serious consequences, including reduced quality of life, increased social isolation, and decreased productivity. The World Health Organization (WHO) has launched a global campaign to combat ageism, which is associated with a shorter lifespan, poorer physical and mental health, and cognitive decline. In Singapore, older workers face age discrimination at the workplace, with nearly two-thirds citing negative employer attitudes as a major challenge. To address ageism, the government plans to raise the retirement age to 65 and 70 by 2030, and has launched Healthier SG, a system of healthcare to promote health and prevent disease. Positive self-perceptions of ageing can have a profound impact on health and longevity, with older people who view ageing positively living 7.5 years longer than those with negative views.

images.alt_text: People are realising they are living significantly longer than they thought. They want to reinvent and reimagine their lives, not wind down.
Three old-school hiring practices that are no longer relevant in 2022
A longevity road map for happier, more fulfilling lives
Stamp out ageism in the Singapore workforce now

site_title: US existing home sales fall in May as prices hit record high, mortgage rates rise
summary: US existing home sales declined 0.7% in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.11 million units, marking a third consecutive month of decrease. Record-high prices and rising mortgage rates hindered potential buyers. Home resales dropped 2.8% year-on-year, while housing starts and building permits also declined. Despite increased housing supply, median prices surged 5.8% to an all-time high of $419,300.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A home for sale sign hangs in front of a house in Oakton in Virginia March 27, 2014

site_title: More Asian nations want to join Putin and Xi in expanded Brics
summary: Malaysia and Thailand have announced their intention to join the Brics economic bloc, expanding the group to 11 members. The bloc, which includes Russia, China, India, and South Africa, aims to pool $100 billion of foreign-currency reserves to lend to each other during emergencies. The move is seen as a hedge against Western-led institutions and a way to signal increasing frustration with the US-led international order. The expansion is also driven by China's efforts to increase its clout on the global stage, and Russia's success in pushing back against US attempts to isolate it over the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Thailand hopes to receive positive feedback and be accepted as Brics member as soon as the next summit to be held in Russia.
The Brics group of nations originally included Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, which gave it the acronym.

President of China Xi Jinping and South African President Cyril Ramaphosa at the China-Africa Leaders' Roundtable Dialogue on the last day of the Brics Summit, in Johannesburg, South Africa, Aug  24, 2023.

With AI and inequality being a key focus of Italy’s G7 economic agenda, Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni  says that she wants to focus on creating “ethical guard rails” for the development of the technology, including a potential steering committee to ensure greater G7 coordination.
The Brics bloc previously included Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, but is set to double with Saudi Arabia joining the United Arab Emirates, Egypt, Iran, and Ethiopia as new members.
Except for India, the Brics have underperformed their emerging-market peers over the last five years, according to Bloomberg Intelligence.

site_title: US business activity inches up in June; price pressures abating
summary: US business activity rose to a 26-month high in June, driven by a rebound in employment, but price pressures eased, suggesting a sustained slowdown in inflation. The S&P Global Composite PMI Output Index, which tracks manufacturing and services sectors, reached 54.6, the highest level since April 2022. Employment rose for the first time in three months, while input prices and output prices showed moderation, bringing inflation into line with the Federal Reserve's 2% target.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Solar panels are built at the QCells solar energy manufacturing factory in Dalton, Georgia, U.S., March 2, 2023. REUTERS/Megan Varner//File Photo

site_title: Thailand approves VAT on cheap imported goods, official says
summary: Thailand has approved the collection of 7% value-added tax (VAT) on imported goods sold for less than 1,500 baht from July to December. This change aims to address concerns over cheap imported Chinese goods hurting local manufacturers. The move will be followed by a law change in December allowing continued VAT collection on such products. The decision was made in response to Deputy Finance Minister Julapun Amornvivat's concerns about false declarations of cheap Chinese products in free trade zones.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People take escalators and walk inside Terminal 21 shopping mall in Bangkok on January 21, 2024. (Photo by Amaury PAUL / AFP)

site_title: OK Lim’s Good Class Bungalow in Tanglin Hill goes on sale for S$43 million
summary: OK Lim's Good Class Bungalow in Tanglin Hill has been put up for sale by tender at a guide price of S$43 million. The 15,636 sq ft, two-storey detached house has five bedrooms and a room for helpers, and is located near Orchard Road and the Singapore Botanic Gardens. The sale comes after several of Lim's Good Class Bungalows have been sold in recent months, with a similar property in Gallop Road selling for S$42.5 million.

OK Lim's Second Avenue bungalow being sold for S$33.39m

site_title: Debt ceiling standoff could trigger US rating downgrade
summary: A potential US debt ceiling standoff in 2025 could trigger another sovereign credit rating downgrade, with Standard & Poor's (S&P) at risk of downgrading its US sovereign rating from AA+ to AA. The Congressional Budget Office forecast a jump in the deficit to $1.915 trillion for fiscal 2024 and $1.938 trillion for 2025, fueling concerns over debt sustainability. A downgrade could occur as early as next year, potentially triggering a repeat of the 2011 crisis and prompting the passage of deficit reduction measures.

images.alt_text: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, a Democrat from New York, speaks during a news conference at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 1, 2023. The Senate passed legislation to suspend the US debt ceiling and impose restraints on government spending through the 2024 election, ending a drama that threatened a global financial crisis. Photographer: Ting Shen/Bloomberg
The short-term package is meant to give lawmakers time to complete negotiations on annual funding for the fiscal year that began Oct 1.

site_title: UK’s richest family get jail terms for exploiting staff at Swiss mansion
summary: A Swiss court sentenced four members of the UK's richest family, the Hindujas, to jail terms for exploiting Indian staff at their Geneva mansion. Prakash and Kamal Hinduja received 4 years and 6 months, while Ajay and Namrata Hinduja received 4-year terms. The family was acquitted of human trafficking charges but convicted of other offenses, including paying staff low wages and confiscating their passports. The prosecution argued the Hindujas abused their power to save money, but the defense claimed the staff were grateful for the better life offered by the family.

images.alt_text: Policemen raided buildings in Metro Manila on June 27, 2023 and rescued more than a thousand people allegedly trafficked into the country to work for an online casino. Chinese, Vietnamese, Singaporean and Malaysian nationals were among those found.

A casino building shut down by police  in Sihanoukville in Preah Sihanouk province. Experts say the trafficked captives are held in large compounds in converted casinos in Cambodia, and in special economic zones in Myanmar and Laos.

site_title: Japan PM extends fuel subsidy, temporary support for household utility bills
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the extension of a petrol fuel subsidy until the end of the year and the temporary reintroduction of relief on household utility bills, aiming to reduce consumer inflation by more than 0.5 percentage point a month. The measures were introduced to support households during the summer heat and will also be considered as a means to finance additional cash handouts to pensioners and low-income households. Kishida emphasized the need to improve productivity and expand workforce participation to achieve real economic growth of over 1% a year by the 2030s.

images.alt_text: Japan’s public debt stands at more than twice the size of its economy, by far the biggest among industrialised economies.
The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure was 3.04 million last month, steady from the level in April.
rowth in exports came amid mixed signals from key overseas markets.

Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the BOJ was not yet fully convinced that inflation will sustainably hit its 2 per cent target, stressing the need to spend “a bit more time” to scrutinise various data before raising interest rates again.

The Bank of Japan kept interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting but said it would “reduce its purchase amount of JGBs (Japanese Government Bonds) thereafter to ensure that long-term interest rates would be formed more freely”.

site_title: Dollar holds firm as US rate outlook diverges once more
summary: The US dollar held firm against other currencies, reaching an eight-week high against the yen and nearly five-week high against sterling. This follows a second consecutive rate cut by the Swiss National Bank and hints of a potential rate reduction by the Bank of England in August. The dollar index rose 0.2% to 105.79, setting the stage for a flat finish to the week. The divergent interest rate outlook between the US and other countries has contributed to the dollar's strength.

images.alt_text: Euro, Hong Kong dollar, U.S. dollar, Japanese yen, British pound and Chinese 100-yuan banknotes are seen in a picture illustration shot January 21, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Lee/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Nissan halts production at Changzhou plant as China woes persist
summary: Nissan has halted production at its Changzhou plant in China, citing a need to optimize operations. The plant, which produces the Qashqai SUV, had an annual capacity of 130,000 vehicles. Nissan operates eight factories in China, but has lost market share to local rivals. The company remains committed to China, but faces challenges from fast-moving electric vehicles priced similarly to internal combustion engines, similar to Mitsubishi's decision to end production at its Chinese joint venture.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nissan's Epic Concept electric vehicle is displayed at the Beijing International Automotive Exhibition, or Auto China 2024, in Beijing, China, April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, June 21, 2024 (Ep 86)
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, following Wall Street's losses, with Shanghai's Index falling below a key psychological level. Japan's inflation accelerated, and oil prices continued to rise. The US crude draw and jobs data fueled hopes of a rate cut. In contrast, Singapore shares edged up at the open, with the STI up 0.2%. The retreat in Asian markets was attributed to tech losses.

Brent crude futures settled at US$85.71 a barrel, up 64 cents or 0.75 per cent on Thursday. The session high of US$85.89 was the highest since May 1.

site_title: China, Australia to issue five-year visas to citizens for tourism, business
summary: China and Australia have announced a five-year visa arrangement for citizens, effective immediately, allowing for multiple-entry tourism and business travel. This move follows a recent visit by Chinese Premier Li Qiang to Australia, which marked a stabilization in bilateral relations after a period of frosty ties. Previously, Chinese citizens could apply for visas of up to one year or 10 years for frequent travelers. The new visa arrangement is seen as a sign of improving ties between the two countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 21)
summary: OK Lim's Good Class Bungalow in Tanglin Hill has been put up for sale by tender at a guide price of S$43 million. The property is located in the Ridley Park Good Class Bungalow Area and is one of several Good Class Bungalows belonging to Lim Oon Kuin, the founder of Hin Leong. The sale price is significantly lower than the S$100 million sale of his neighboring property in 2022.

site_title: Drinks maker Britvic rejects £3.11 billion takeover proposal from Carlsberg
summary: British soft drinks maker Britvic has rejected a £3.11 billion takeover proposal from Carlsberg Group, the second approach from the Danish brewer. The rejected offer of 1,250 pence per share represents a premium of over 23% to Britvic's closing share price. Britvic's shares jumped 14% to 1,153 pence, while Carlsberg's stock fell about 8%. The decision leaves Carlsberg with until July 19 to make a firm offer or walk away.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Taps for Carlsberg beer are seen in a bar in Copenhagen, Denmark, July 30, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: BlackRock will not take part in Malaysia Airports privatisation, GIP says
summary: BlackRock will not participate in Malaysia Airports Holdings (MAHB) privatisation, following criticism over its alleged ties to Israel. Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP), a consortium including Malaysian sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional, will retain control of the airport operator despite BlackRock's $12.5 billion acquisition of GIP. The deal, valued at $3.9 billion, aims to privatise MAHB, which manages 39 airports across Malaysia and an international airport in Turkey.

images.alt_text: Around 22 organisations have issued a joint statement urging the government to reconsider and block BlackRock’s participation in the deal worth about US$2.6 billion to take Malaysia Airports Holdings (MAHB) private, alleging the firm has ties with Israel.

site_title: Amazon mulls US$5 to US$10 monthly price tag for unprofitable Alexa service, AI revamp
summary: Amazon plans to revamp its decade-old Alexa service, dubbed "Remarkable Alexa," with a conversational generative AI. The service will have two tiers, with a superior version available for a monthly fee of around $5 to $10. The company aims to boost sales and is working towards a deadline of August to prepare the new version. Amazon's CEO Andy Jassy has taken a personal interest in reviving the service, which has struggled to turn a profit. The revamp aims to provide more proactive and trusted assistance, but some employees describe it as a "desperate attempt" to revitalize the service.

Amazon Flex, which works like on-demand ride-hailing service Uber, handles speedy deliveries of common household goods to customers through programmes such as Prime Now and Amazon Fresh.

site_title: Nvidia’s staggering gains leave investors wondering whether to cash in or buy more
summary: Nvidia's share price surged 1,000% since October 2022, briefly becoming the largest US company by market value, with a current value of over $3.2 trillion. The company's dominance in AI-chip sector and proprietary software framework drive bullishness among investors. However, some analysts express caution, citing the potential for competition and the difficulty in maintaining the company's lead. Despite this, many remain optimistic, with Nvidia's forward price-to-earnings ratio at 45, only modestly higher than its five-year average, and revenues expected to double to $120 billion this fiscal year.

site_title: Companies intending to delist should provide truly ‘fair and reasonable’ offer prices: Sias
summary: OCBC's voluntary unconditional general offer to acquire a 11.56% stake in Great Eastern Holdings, a Singaporean insurance arm, has raised concerns among minority shareholders. The offer price of S$25.60 per share is a 36.9% premium over GEH's last traded price, but a 30% discount to the company's embedded value per share. Sias CEO David Gerald has criticized the offer, stating that it creates a dilemma for minority shareholders who feel they are being forced to accept an "unfair" offer or risk being locked up in an unlisted company for a long time.

site_title: Asia: Markets retreat after tech losses hobble Wall Street
summary: Asian markets declined on Friday, following a weak lead from Wall Street, where tech giants drove a sell-off amid profit-taking. The US data showed a slowdown in the economy, with worse-than-forecast unemployment claims, falling housing starts, and a decline in business confidence. Despite this, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records. The yen retreated towards a three-decade low, prompting traders to watch for intervention. Singapore's stocks rose, while Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Seoul fell.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 ended up 0.9 per cent to hit a week’s high, led by a 1.8 per cent rise in technology stocks, while real estate stocks were another boost, rising 1.7 per cent.

site_title: German residential property prices keep falling in Q1
summary: German residential property prices fell by an average of 5.7% year-over-year in Q1, marking the most severe property crisis in decades. Following a 8.4% drop last year, analysts predict a 2% decrease in 2024, but a 2% growth in 2025. Rising demand for home ownership and easing monetary policy are expected to stabilize prices, according to economist Martin Gueth.

site_title: Duterte heir signals Philippine ambition with break from Marcos
summary: Philippine Vice-President Sara Duterte has resigned from her cabinet position, marking a significant shift in her alliance with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. The move comes after months of disagreements between the two influential families, and sets up a potential challenge for Marcos in the 2028 presidential elections. Sara's consolidation of support and potential candidacy against Marcos are seen as a significant threat to the president's power, despite Marcos' control of the presidency and the country's economic growth.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Friday even as region sees losses; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 3,306.02, despite regional losses, on Friday. DFI Retail was the biggest gainer, climbing 2.7% to US$1.92. Across the broader market, decliners outnumbered advancers 297 to 290, with 1.7 billion securities worth S$1.6 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: PHOTO: Asian traders tracked the weak lead, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Manila all down. Singapore, Sydney and Jakarta edged up while Tokyo was flat on Thursday.
A growing number of small firms from China and Hong Kong are turning to the Nasdaq to raise money, even as geopolitical tensions rise ahead of the US election.
Market observers say the Singapore Exchange could consider issuing guidance for listed companies to trade above book value, like the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
Narendra Modi's ruling party secured a narrow victory in India's elections; Modi now has to rely on allies for a coalition government.

site_title: UK retail sales rebound in May but shoppers still cautious
summary: British retail sales rebounded in May with a 2.9% increase, up from a 1.8% fall in April, but remain 0.5% below pre-pandemic levels. This minor boost may not be sustainable, with economists warning that consumers are cautious due to high inflation and rising wages. Sales growth was distorted by an extra trading day in May 2023 and other factors, and may not reflect a stronger recovery.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A tourist shelters from the rain under an Union Jack umbrella near the Bank of England in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, February 13, 2024. REUTERS/Isabel Infantes/File Photo

site_title: Think Nvidia looks dear? American shares could get pricier still
summary: US stocks are experiencing speculative excess, exemplified by GameStop's 40% share price increase since Keith Gill's return. Nvidia, the world's most valuable company, has a cyclically adjusted price-to-earnings ratio of nearly 36, fueling enthusiasm about artificial intelligence. As interest rates are poised to fall, investors may bid up pricey shares, leading to a potential melt-up. The US stock market has a long duration, making it vulnerable to rising interest rates. Despite concerns, investors seem willing to buy narratives that paint the rosiest picture, potentially leading to a correction or further price increases.

images.alt_text: The sooner AI is applied for niche purposes and not for everything, everywhere, all at once, the sooner the technology will be useful.
On Tuesday (Jun 18), that run culminated in Nvidia unseating Microsoft as the world’s most valuable company with a market capitalisation of US$3.34 trillion.
The California-based company, which is led by Jensen Huang, has seen profits soar due to torrid demand for its powerful GPU chips, which have set the industry’s pace in pushing new advances in AI.

site_title: Gold set for weekly gain on US rate-cut optimism, geopolitical woes
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,360.95 per ounce, poised for a second consecutive weekly gain, amid rising geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and optimism over potential US rate cuts later this year. Spot gold hit a two-week high in the previous session and gained over 1% for the week. Analysts attribute the bullish trend to safe-haven demand and expectations of a US rate cut, which could support gold prices above $2,300.

images.alt_text: Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,331.38 per ounce.

site_title: Major Chinese asset managers have no plans to phase out fossil fuel investments: Greenpeace
summary: Major Chinese asset managers have invested a combined $49.8 billion in high-carbon sectors and $4.9 billion in fossil fuels, with no plans to phase out these investments, according to a Greenpeace report. The 16 asset managers invested $267.2 billion in high-carbon sectors, with E Fund alone investing $40.6 billion in high-carbon sectors and $18.9 billion in fossil fuels. Despite China's push to be a global leader in the energy transition, fossil fuels remain dominant, accounting for 60% of China's electricity generation.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A coal-burning power plant can be seen behind a factory in the city of Baotou, in China's Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, October 31, 2010.  REUTERS/David Gray/File Photo

site_title: Japan vows to bring primary budget to surplus next fiscal year
summary: Japan reaffirmed its pledge to achieve a primary budget surplus by the next fiscal year, included in its annual economic and fiscal policy guidelines. The move aims to address concerns about its high public debt, which stands at over twice the size of its economy. However, economists question the feasibility of the target, citing plans to increase spending on childcare and military. The government estimates a primary balance deficit of 1.1 trillion yen, but notes that a surplus could be achievable with targeted measures to streamline spending and spur economic growth.

images.alt_text: With inflation exceeding its 2 per cent target for two years, the Bank of Japan has dropped hints that it will raise short-term rates to levels that neither cool nor overheat the economy - seen by analysts as somewhere between 1-2 per cent.

site_title: UK PM Sunak 'incredibly angry' about election date betting allegations
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak expressed "incredibly anger" over allegations that a Conservative candidate, Laura Saunders, was being investigated by Britain's gambling regulator for allegedly placing bets on the timing of the general election. The investigation also involves Saunders' husband, Tony Lee, who is the party's campaign director. Sunak vowed to take action if anyone breaks the rules, stating they should face the "full force of the law." Polls indicate a centre-left Labour government led by Keir Starmer is likely to win, with the Conservatives facing a historic defeat.

images.alt_text:
England's Harry Kane scores the first goal
in their match against Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, June 20, 2024.

site_title: As generations cross swords at work, can the divide ever be bridged?
summary: Generational fault lines at work are on the rise, with instances of friction between different age groups increasing. A 24-year-old worker, Minh Nguyen, experienced difficulties in adjusting to strict work hours at a meatpacking factory, despite his role requiring later duties. The issue highlights the need for empathy and communication to bridge the gap between generations at work. Employers must adapt to changing workforce demographics and find ways to accommodate diverse needs and preferences to prevent similar conflicts. Effective communication and understanding can help smooth over generational fault lines.

images.alt_text: Use opportunities like lunch breaks, coffee meetings or shared events to build and maintain relationships.

For Gen Z and some younger Millennials, the prospect of joining the hustle culture may seem daunting and exhausting. Instead, they want to be financially stable and successful without sacrificing their mental health and well-being.

site_title: China sets renewable power subsidies lower at 5.4 billion yuan in 2024
summary: China has set its 2024 renewable power subsidy at 5.4 billion yuan (S$1 billion), down from 7.4 billion yuan in 2023. The subsidies will include 1.96 billion yuan for solar power, 3.43 billion yuan for wind, and 17 million yuan for biofuel. The government aims to scale back support to push renewable power generators to compete on a market basis, after ending a guarantee for grid operators to buy nearly all renewable power at a rate tied to the coal index.

site_title: Eurozone business recovery slows sharply in June, PMI shows
summary: The Eurozone's business recovery slowed sharply in June, with the services industry showing signs of weakening and the manufacturing sector taking a turn for the worse. The HCOB's preliminary composite Purchasing Managers' Index fell to 50.8, confounding expectations of a rise. Despite this, inflationary pressures eased, strengthening the case for further ECB interest rate cuts. The services output prices index declined to 53.7, its lowest reading in over three years, while the manufacturing activity index dropped to a six-month low of 45.6.

images.alt_text: Skyscrapers in the central business district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The European Central Bank is poised to start lowering interest rates from record highs, confident that inflation is sufficiently contained to ease the burden on the economy. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg
The ECB projects inflation to return to 2 per cent in the final quarter of next year.

site_title: Enabling the electrification of transport on land and sea, Sustainability Impact Awards - THE BUSINESS TIMES
summary: A car dealer has announced its commitment to supporting a switch to sustainable transport, aiming to accelerate the adoption of electric vehicles. The company plans to offer incentives for customers to trade in their conventional cars for eco-friendly alternatives. Additionally, it will partner with charging point providers to increase the availability of public charging stations. The move is expected to reduce carbon emissions and contribute to a cleaner environment. The company's goal is to make sustainable transport more accessible and affordable for its customers, driving a "fast lane" to a greener highway.

site_title: Philippine business groups make rare statement amid South China Sea tensions
summary: Philippine business groups issued a rare joint statement, condemning the harassment of the country's military by Chinese coast guard vessels in the South China Sea. The groups, composed of 17 organizations, appealed for unity and a non-violent resolution that respects the Philippines' rights as a peace-loving nation. They also urged the government to transform the military and coastguard into a modern self-reliant force to protect the country's interests in the disputed waters. The statement comes after a recent clash between navy personnel and the Chinese coast guard.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Chinese Coast Guard vessels fire water cannons towards a Philippine resupply vessel Unaizah on May 4 as it made its way to the Second Thomas Shoal in the South China Sea, March 5, 2024. REUTERS/Adrian Portugal/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Cash is leaving China again, pressuring yuan
summary: China's yuan has dropped to seven-month lows, alongside a reversal in equity investment flows, as domestic investors are shelling expectations for an immediate recovery and fleeing to better-yielding assets. The yuan's decline is attributed to extensive outflows of cash from the mainland into Hong Kong, where investors are seeking higher yields and companies are preparing to pay annual dividends. This has added pressure on the currency, with Hong Kong's stockpile of yuan deposits growing as mainland investors use limited offshore investment channels.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Woman holds Chinese Yuan banknotes in this illustration taken May 30, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: New tensions between White House, Israeli PM
summary: Tensions between the White House and Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu have escalated over Netanyahu's criticism of US weapons deliveries to Israel. Netanyahu claimed the US has been withholding arms and ammunitions, while the White House described his comments as "vexing" and "disappointing." US officials, including Secretary of State Antony Blinken, have warned Israel against escalating tensions in the region. The spat is the latest in a series of disputes between the two sides since the start of the Gaza war, which began with an unprecedented Hamas attack in October.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.08, or 1.3 per cent, at US$85.33 per barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures ended US$1.24, or 1.5 per cent, higher at US$81.57 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Chinese developers face make-or-break week in liquidation cases
summary: Chinese developers face a make-or-break week as they seek to fight off liquidation cases, with Kaisa Group Holdings facing a hearing on Monday. Four defaulted developers, including Kaisa and Shimao, will appear in Hong Kong court to show progress in restructuring debt. Judges will order asset sales if they fail to demonstrate progress, amid a multiyear crisis in China's property sector. At least five builders, including China Evergrande, have already received wind-up orders from the city's high court, highlighting the sector's financial turmoil.

images.alt_text: Kaisa is one of many defaulted Chinese developers facing liquidation threats, as demonstrated by the historic wind-up order of China Evergrande Group.

Investors sit in front of a board showing stock information at a brokerage house on the first day of trade in China since the Lunar New Year, in Hangzhou, Zhejiang province, China February 3, 2020. China Daily via REUTERS/Files

site_title: Japan to trim liquidity enhancing super-long JGB issuance, sources say
summary: Japan's finance ministry is considering reducing the issuance of super-long government bonds in an August liquidity auction to address concerns about supply-demand balance. The plan would reduce the supply by 100 billion yen to 400 billion yen, while boosting issuance of existing bonds with shorter maturities. The overall annual issuance would remain unchanged. This move comes after the Bank of Japan ended eight years of negative interest rates in March, and the ministry aims to increase turnover in less traded parts of the government bond market.

images.alt_text: Since ending its unorthodox negative interest rates policy in March, the Bank of Japan has left markets guessing on further policy tightening.

site_title: Thai exports rise for second month in May, beat forecast
summary: Thailand's exports rose 12.6% in May, beating forecast expectations, marking the second consecutive month of growth. The agricultural sector drove this expansion, with exports of agricultural products surging 36.5% year-on-year. Industrial product shipments also rose 4.6% in May, while rice exports fell 22.5% year-on-year. The commerce ministry expects exports to continue rising this year, with a forecast of single-digit growth in June, maintaining its target of 1-2% annual growth.

images.alt_text: Thailand hopes to receive positive feedback and be accepted as Brics member as soon as the next summit to be held in Russia.

site_title: Investors prime for Bank of Japan by shorting the short end of bonds
summary: Global investors are short-selling Japan's shortest-term government bonds, positioning for the Bank of Japan's potential policy tightening, which may lead to a weaker yen. The BOJ has hinted at reducing its purchases of Japanese government bonds and possibly raising rates as early as July. Investors believe the yen's decline against the US dollar this year, largely due to the BOJ's quantitative easing, will continue. This has led to a significant short position in JGBs, with some investors betting on a flatter yield curve and rising short-term yields.

images.alt_text: The US Treasury’s semi-annual currency report found that none of the countries examined met all three criteria triggering “enhanced analysis” of their foreign exchange practices during the four quarters through December 2023.

With inflation exceeding its 2 per cent target for two years, the Bank of Japan has dropped hints that it will raise short-term rates to levels that neither cool nor overheat the economy - seen by analysts as somewhere between 1-2 per cent.
On Thursday, the yen fell for a sixth-straight session, the worst stretch of losses in three months, to end the day trading just shy of 159 per dollar – its weakest closing level since April 1990.
Japan's national flag flutters at the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo on May 30, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: The US housing market is weird and ugly
summary: The US housing market has defied economists' expectations, with higher interest rates making homes harder to afford but still attracting buyers. A severe shortage of homes for sale has driven up prices, particularly in some markets. New-home sales have been resilient, with developers offering affordable options to first-time buyers. Rents have also become unaffordable, with many renters spending over 30% of their income on housing. Experts suggest that lower interest rates or a gradual return to normalcy could break the logjam, but a collapse in prices is unlikely.

images.alt_text: Single-family housing starts, which account for the bulk of homebuilding, declined 5.2 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 982,000 units last month.
The National Association of Home Builders (NAHB)/Wells Fargo index of housing market conditions fell by two points to 43.

site_title: JPMorgan asset and wealth head sees China’s economic outlook improving
summary: JPMorgan CEO of asset and wealth management Mary Erdoes said China's economy is showing signs of improvement, with consumer spending recovery and government efforts to address real estate problems. The bank has seen a sluggish period in China, but Erdoes believes sentiment is turning bullish, and the company is continuing to grow its business there. Erdoes visited China last month to gauge investor sentiment and emphasized the importance of China as a market for JPMorgan.

images.alt_text: Phishing scams are a type of cyber attack where criminals attempt to trick victims into revealing sensitive information such as login credentials or financial account details.

The festival, named after the Jun 18 founding date of e-commerce provider JD.com but embraced by all platforms, is China’s second-biggest annual sales event after Singles Day in November and is seen as a key test of household consumption.
Authorities for the first time instructed local governments to buy unsold apartments through state-owned firms, facilitating up to 500 billion yuan for the purchases.
For now, the US economy is in a good place.  The biggest threat comes not from outside but has its origins in domestic strains.

Measures that redistribute income from central authorities to municipalities, curbing an addiction to land sales laid bare by China’s property crisis, will top the agenda of a leadership gathering in July, known as the third plenum.

Citi is automating processes and improving data reporting to meet regulators’ orders.

site_title: Facebook, WhatsApp, Carousell among platforms asked to comply with anti-scam rules
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Home Affairs has required popular social media platforms, including Facebook, WhatsApp, and Carousell, to comply with anti-scam rules effective June 26. The rules, part of the Online Communication Code, mandate platforms to proactively detect and prevent scams, as well as verify users who advertise or post about sales of goods and services. E-commerce platforms, including Carousell and Facebook's Marketplace, must also implement additional measures, such as verifying user identities and providing payment protection mechanisms. Failure to comply may result in penalties, including fines and implementation directives.

images.alt_text: Even before generative AI technology started being widely leveraged as a tool to drive more crime, cyberattacks in 2024 were already trending upwards
Using a single SMS sender ID will make it easier for the public to identify authentic government communications sent via SMSes.

site_title: Singapore shares edge up at Friday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.2% higher at 3,305.42, with gainers outnumbering losers 59 to 36. Yoma Strategic rose 2.7%, while Genting Singapore and Singtel also increased. Local banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and UOB up, while OCBC declined. The move follows overnight gains in Europe and a mixed close for US stocks, with the Nasdaq Composite down 0.8% and the S&P 500 down 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Keppel Reit's green notes will bear an interest at a floating rate based on the Bank Bill Swap reference rate, plus an agreed spread.

site_title: Dominant Spain brush past Italy to reach Euro 2024 knockouts
summary: Spain secured a 1-0 win over Italy, advancing to the Euro 2024 knockout rounds with a match to spare. Riccardo Calafiori's own goal 9 minutes after halftime was the only goal in the match. Spain dominated play, creating numerous scoring chances, and Nico Williams was the star for the team. Italy, despite a strong performance from Gianluigi Donnarumma, was unable to capitalize on its opportunities, and the loss was a reality check for the team. Spain will face Albania in the next round, while Italy can still qualify with a draw against Croatia.

images.alt_text: Portugal's Francisco Conceicao scores the team's second goal against Czech Republic in the dying minutes of the game at Leipzig Stadium, Leipzig, Germany, June 18, 2024.

site_title: UK GfK consumer sentiment rises to highest since Nov 2021
summary: UK consumer sentiment reached a two-and-a-half year high in June, with a reading of -14, surpassing forecasts. The improvement in morale is attributed to a better assessment of the broader economy, but households remain worse off due to the cost-of-living crisis. Despite inflation returning to its 2% target, most households are still struggling financially, weighing on Prime Minister Rishi Sunak's election chances.

images.alt_text: epa10783058 Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey gestures while speaking during a press conference at the Bank of England in London, Britain, 03 August 2023. UK mortgage owners are bracing for a further increase in interests rates 03 August. The Bank of England is set to raise interests rates by a quarter percent in a bid to being down inflation.  EPA-EFE/ANDY RAIN
Britain's last general election in 2019 was all about leaving the European Union but this time around, Brexit is hardly getting a mention.
A cost-of-living crisis in the G7 nation and the world’s sixth-biggest economy has left many Britons struggling to make ends meet, as bills for food, energy, rent and mortgages increase.
The BOE has said a return of inflation to its target is not enough on its own for it to start cutting interest rates.
Housing affordability is a hot political issue ahead of the UK election, with house prices up by around a fifth since the last election in December 2019.

The allegations that a second Conservative candidate was being investigated by Britain’s gambling regulator and may have attempted to profit from their political knowledge of the timing of the election is the latest setback in Rishi Sunak’s faltering efforts to stay in Downing Street.

site_title: Anthropic releases ‘most intelligent’ AI model in rivalry with OpenAI
summary: Anthropic, an AI startup, has released Claude 3.5 Sonnet, its fastest and most capable AI model yet, in a rivalry with OpenAI. The new model outperforms competitors on coding and text-based reasoning capabilities, with CEO Daniela Amodei stating it is the best and most intelligent model in the industry. Claude 3.5 Sonnet is twice as fast as its previous version and will be available for free on mobile and desktop, with paid subscribers gaining more access. The model is being used by pharmaceutical giant Pfizer to aid in drug discovery research.

images.alt_text: Anthropic’s Claude is a direct competitor to Microsoft-backed OpenAI’s ChatGPT, the chatbot that broke records when it reached 100 million monthly active users just two months after launch.

site_title: Lacklustre England held by Denmark at Euro 2024
summary: England held Denmark 1-1 in their Euro 2024 match, with Harry Kane scoring the opening goal for the Three Lions. Despite having the lead, England failed to build on it, and Denmark equalized with a long-range strike. The draw keeps England top of Group C, two points clear of Slovenia, who they face next. England manager Gareth Southgate acknowledged the team's underwhelming performance, stating they must improve to win the tournament.

images.alt_text: Italian defender Riccardo Calafiori (centre) hits the ball into his own net for the only goal of the game, an own goal during the match between Spain and Italy in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, June 20, 2024.

site_title: HDB, condo rents soften in May as leasing volumes dip: SRX, 99.co
summary: HDB and condo rents in Singapore softened in May, with HDB rents falling 0.3% month-on-month and condo rents easing 0.5% for the second straight month. The decline in demand, attributed to a weaker job market, led to a 13.2% drop in HDB rental volumes and a 12.2% decline in condo rental volumes. Market watchers expect rental activity to recover after the June holidays, while the softer rental market may benefit firms looking to expand their workforce.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024

site_title: SingPost appoints financial adviser for strategic review of Australia business
summary: SingPost appoints Merrill Lynch Markets Australia as a financial adviser to its board for a strategic review of its Australia business, aiming to achieve scale in the market. The review, completed three months ago, identified achieving scale as one of the company's five strategic thrusts for the next three years.

images.alt_text: SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.

site_title: Upturn in German business activity slows in June, PMI shows
summary: Germany's business activity slowed in June, with the HCOB German flash composite Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 50.6, below the forecast of 52.7. Manufacturing's weakness dragged on the services sector, which eased to 53.5. The composite index is now just above the 50 mark separating growth from contraction. Manufacturing's downturn deepened to 43.4, while the services sector index remained strong. Analysts attribute manufacturing's struggles to a failing demand for industrial goods, but note that Germany's economy is also supported by a robust services sector.

images.alt_text: Skyscrapers in the central business district of Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 6, 2024. The European Central Bank is poised to start lowering interest rates from record highs, confident that inflation is sufficiently contained to ease the burden on the economy. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

site_title: French infrastructure giant Vinci acquires Singapore engineering SME E+HPS for S$50 million
summary: French infrastructure giant Vinci has acquired Singapore engineering SME E+HPS for S$50 million, its second acquisition in the country after Wah Loon Engineering in 2018. E+HPS will gain support for large-scale projects and internationalization, with plans to expand into Malaysia and Indonesia. The acquisition is expected to boost Vinci Energies Asia-Pacific's revenue to 600 million euros in 2024. Vinci aims to tap into E+HPS' semiconductor and pharmaceutical client base, lacking a strong presence in these areas in Singapore.

images.alt_text: French giant Vinci buys majority stake in Singapore engineering firm for S$250m

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel Reit, Paragon Reit, SingPost
summary: Keppel Reit priced A$175 million of floating rate green notes due 2027, with interest based on the Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus an agreed spread. Paragon Reit entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement for The Rail Mall for S$78.5 million, to be used for debt reduction and potential acquisitions. SingPost appointed Merrill Lynch Markets Australia as a financial adviser to its board, planning to achieve scale in the Australia business.

site_title: China’s property sales outlook worse than ratings firms expect
summary: Global credit ratings firms S&P Global Ratings and Fitch Ratings have lowered their forecasts for China's property market, predicting a 15% drop in residential sales this year. This is worse than their earlier estimates, attributed to an accelerating slump in home prices. The decline in home prices has deterred buyers, and policymakers' recent stimulus measures have failed to revive the sector. The ratings firms' bleak outlook suggests a lack of confidence in the effectiveness of these measures to end the property slump, which is dragging on the world's second-largest economy.

images.alt_text: Signage for the China Evergrande Group. Royal Peak residential development in Beijing, China, on Friday, July 29, 2022. A mild rally in Chinese developers’ dollar bonds appears to be losing momentum, as investors express disappointment that a top leadership meeting failed to unveil stronger policy support for the crisis-ridden industry. Source: Bloomberg

site_title: What your heart rate can tell you about your fitness
summary: Wearable devices and fitness trackers provide valuable insights into heart rate data, allowing users to track their fitness levels and make data-driven decisions. By understanding heart rate zones, individuals can tailor their exercise plans to achieve specific goals, such as improving speed and endurance. Heart rate variability (HRV) can also be used to monitor recovery and fatigue, but experts caution against relying solely on data and encourage users to consider their own sense of effort and overall well-being. With proper interpretation, heart rate data can be a powerful tool for optimizing health and fitness.

images.alt_text: Someone with a higher VO2 max will be able to sustain a run or an aerobic activity at a given pace longer than those with a lower VO2 max.
Exercise: Why, how, and what

site_title: US finds no currency manipulation in 2023, Japan added to monitoring list
summary: The US Treasury's semi-annual currency report found no major trading partner manipulated its currency in 2023. However, Japan was added to the foreign exchange monitoring list, alongside China, Vietnam, Taiwan, Malaysia, Singapore, and Germany, which met two of the three criteria for enhanced analysis. The US added Japan due to its large trade surplus and current account surplus, as well as its recent foreign exchange interventions to prop up the yen's value. The report noted that Japan's interventions, while transparent, raised concerns about potential unfair competitive advantages in international trade.

summary: The price of diesel in Peninsular Malaysia has risen over 50% after the removal of subsidies. Indonesia reported a May trade balance surplus that declined more than expected, while Myanmar's gas exports to Thailand plummeted 23%. Thailand's Prime Minister proposed a 3.75 trillion baht budget to revive the economy. A financial digital infrastructure initiative was launched in Cambodia and Singapore. site_title: American Airlines’ flight attendants prepare to strike
summary: American Airlines' flight attendants are preparing to strike after contract negotiations failed to produce an agreement, citing a lack of pay raises in over five years. The Association of Professional Flight Attendants, which represents 28,000 flight attendants, had offered a 17% wage increase but was unanimously rejected. The airline claims an agreement is "within reach" and will continue to negotiate, but the flight attendants say they will not back down. The strike is the latest development in a year-long negotiation process that began in 2020.

The two fatal crashes of Boeing 737 MAX planes occurred in 2018 and 2019 in Indonesia and Ethiopia and led to the best-selling plane’s worldwide grounding for 20 months.

site_title: Japan’s May core inflation perks up, keeps rate hike prospect intact
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 2.5% in May, exceeding the 2% target for the second year, indicating the Bank of Japan may raise short-term interest rates to levels between 1-2%. This decision comes as inflationary pressures remain, despite a recent drop in consumption. Analysts predict a potential 0.25% rate hike this year, with some speculating it may occur in July. The BOJ aims to balance inflation and economic growth, with Governor Kazuo Ueda stating the central bank will raise rates if domestic demand and wages drive inflation to 2%.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, the yen fell for a sixth-straight session, the worst stretch of losses in three months, to end the day trading just shy of 159 per dollar – its weakest closing level since April 1990.
Japan's national flag flutters at the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo on May 30, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Market observers say the Singapore Exchange could consider issuing guidance for listed companies to trade above book value, like the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure was 3.04 million last month, steady from the level in April.
The diminishing presence of the BOJ heightens the need for the government to find stable buyers of JGBs and avoid a bond sell-off that could trigger a damaging spike in yields.
The market value of the lender’s strategic holdings amounted to a little over 1.1 trillion yen as at March, bigger than its own market capitalisation.
rowth in exports came amid mixed signals from key overseas markets.

site_title: Frederique Constant bets on affordable luxury watches to win post-pandemic market
summary: Swiss luxury watch brand Frederique Constant is betting on affordable timepieces to win back post-pandemic market share. CEO Niels Eggerding believes the young and budget-conscious will drive demand for mid-range luxury watches, citing the popularity of Tissot's PRX. Frederique Constant, with a core price range of S$1,064 to S$6,084, is poised to capture market share with its limited-edition tourbillon perpetual calendar and other high-quality watches. Despite competition from Citizen Watch, Eggerding plans to grow the brand's business over the next three years, prioritizing logistics and accessibility over price increases.

site_title: Biden and Trump suit up for first televised clash of 2024
summary: US President Joe Biden and former President Donald Trump are set to clash in their first televised debate of the 2024 presidential election next Thursday. Biden is preparing by rehearsing attack lines and rebuttals at Camp David, while Trump has been holding informal consultations with influential senators and vice-presidential candidates. The debate will be moderated by CNN, which has implemented measures to maintain decorum, and will focus on key issues such as abortion and democracy. Biden aims to project stability and highlight Trump's perceived instability, while Trump is betting on a strong debate performance to cement his image as the "chaos candidate."

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen testifies before a Senate Appropriations Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee hearing on President Biden’s proposed budget request for the Department of Treasury, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 4, 2024. REUTERS/Anna Rose Layden/File Photo

The new restrictions on inbound sales of Kaspersky software, which will also bar downloads of software updates, resales and licensing of the product, kick in on Sep 29, 100 days after publication, to give businesses time to find alternatives.

Migrants, seeking asylum in the United States and who previously requested an appointment on the US Customs and Border Protection (CBP) One application, attend their appointment at the Paso del Norte International border bridge, in El Paso, Texas. June 14, 2024.
Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event, Racine, Wisconsin, June 18, 2024.

site_title: US: Nvidia suffers rare retreat as Nasdaq streak ends
summary: The US stock market experienced a rare retreat on Thursday, with the Nasdaq Composite Index falling 0.8% to 17,721.59, despite seven consecutive record highs. The S&P 500 declined 0.3% to 5,473.17, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.8% to 39,134.76. The tech-heavy Nasdaq's decline was attributed to a drop in Nvidia, a leader in artificial intelligence, which fell 3.5% despite being up nearly 20% in June. Market analysts remain cautious, citing slowing economic growth and the need for more evidence of inflation coming down before interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A specialist trader works at his post on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 3, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Yen’s six-day slump highlights risk of Japan intervention
summary: The Japanese yen has fallen to a 34-year low, trading just shy of 159 per dollar, after a sixth-straight session of losses. The currency's weakness is attributed to a persistent divergence in yields between Japan and its major peers, including the US. The Bank of Japan's inaction on reducing bond buying has fueled speculation that officials will intervene to prop up the currency. Traders expect the yen to reach 160 per dollar, a level that has triggered previous interventions, and analysts warn that the US-Japan rate differential may continue to support yen selling.

images.alt_text: Japan's national flag flutters at the Bank of Japan headquarters in Tokyo on May 30, 2024. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)
Masayoshi Son aims to go on the offensive again after years of missteps at the Vision Fund, the sovereign wealth fund-backed investment group he set up to bet on startups
Market observers say the Singapore Exchange could consider issuing guidance for listed companies to trade above book value, like the Tokyo Stock Exchange.
The diminishing presence of the BOJ heightens the need for the government to find stable buyers of JGBs and avoid a bond sell-off that could trigger a damaging spike in yields.
The market value of the lender’s strategic holdings amounted to a little over 1.1 trillion yen as at March, bigger than its own market capitalisation.
rowth in exports came amid mixed signals from key overseas markets.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates at 5.25% ahead of UK election
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) kept its main interest rate at 5.25% ahead of the UK's July 4 election, defying expectations of a rate cut. The decision was made by the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) voting 7-2 to keep rates on hold, with Governor Andrew Bailey stating that inflation is still too high to cut rates. The decision is seen as a move to ensure inflation stays low, and markets now price in an 88% chance of a first quarter-point cut by September's meeting.

images.alt_text: The SNB cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.25 per cent.

site_title: Singapore seeks proposals on coastal protection and flood management
summary: Singapore's national water agency, PUB, is seeking innovative solutions for coastal protection and flood management through a grant call worth S$125 million. The focus areas include sustainable construction materials, smart structural health monitoring, and decision-making for adaptive planning. The grant aims to address the need for sustainable materials that can withstand rising sea levels and support the country's climate adaptation efforts, with a focus on five key areas. The proposal submission deadline is August 6.

images.alt_text: One of the Marine Honour's oil cargo tanks was ruptured on Friday. MPA patrol craft were immediately deployed to spray dispersants on the oil spill.
Singapore, home to the world’s second-largest container seaport, is the latest to be hit by congestion, according to Linerlytica.

site_title: Nestle, Coke take cautious approach to catering to Ozempic users
summary: Global food companies are cautious in marketing products to people taking weight-loss medications like Wegovy and Ozempic, due to regulatory concerns. Nestle's new Vital Pursuit line of frozen meals won't name the medications on packaging, instead focusing on high protein, fibre, and nutrient content. Coca-Cola and Danone also avoid referencing the medications, instead highlighting their low sugar or high protein offerings. Companies like Herbalife and Conagra Brands take a more direct approach, marketing products as "companions" to the medications, but avoid using brand names to avoid regulatory scrutiny.

images.alt_text: In late 2017, Novo launched Ozempic the GLP-1 drug that, while technically for diabetes, put weight-loss shots into the cultural consciousness.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise after Swiss rate cut, Bank of England decision
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.9% to a week's high, driven by a 1.8% gain in technology stocks and a 1.7% rise in real estate stocks. The Swiss National Bank cut interest rates by 25 basis points, while the Bank of England maintained its main interest rate unchanged. Norwegian stocks rose 0.4% despite the central bank's decision to hold its key policy interest rate at a 16-year high. Global sentiment was lifted by upbeat US equity gains and interest rate decisions from three central banks.

images.alt_text: Both the Nasdaq and the S&P 500 retreated from records, while the Dow pushed higher following an up session on European bourses.

site_title: China says EU mandated its EV firms turn over ‘unprecedented’ amounts of data
summary: China's commerce ministry says the European Commission demanded an unprecedented amount of data from Chinese automakers during an investigation into subsidized electric vehicle imports. The data included sourcing raw materials, manufacturing components, pricing, and sales channels. The EU imposed duties on Chinese EVs, prompting Beijing's rebuke and spying allegations. China has launched a dumping investigation into EU pork imports in retaliation. Chinese automakers deemed non-cooperating will face a 38.1% tariff on EU cars once the duties take effect in July.

images.alt_text: Companies may cut back more on planned factories as European Union subsidies are hard to access due to bureaucracy and carmakers protect thin EV profit margins.
Beijing has shown a willingness to use auto tariffs as a tool in previous trade wars.
Chinese authorities have previously hinted at possible retaliatory measures through state media commentaries and interviews with industry figures.
China imported US$6 billion worth of pork in 2023, including offal, with the EU accounting for more than half.

site_title: BMW cancels 2 billion euros battery cells contract with Northvolt
summary: BMW cancels a 2 billion euros contract for battery cells with Northvolt due to the Swedish company's inability to deliver on time. The two companies have decided to focus Northvolt's activities on developing next-generation battery cells. BMW still expresses interest in establishing a high-performance battery cell manufacturer in Europe, citing the need for circular and sustainable battery cells.

site_title: Reimagining a retirement fit for boomers, and those who are next in line
summary: Michael Clinton, author of "Roar: Into the Second Half of Your Life (Before It's Too Late)", argues that traditional retirement is outdated as people live longer and are more tech-savvy, fit, and driven. Clinton, a 70-year-old re-imagineer, advocates for a new retirement concept that focuses on reinventing one's life, career, and passions. The book has inspired the creation of Roar Forward, an online platform for individuals aged 50 and over who are redefining their second half of life. Clinton emphasizes the need to challenge ageism and the concept of retirement, and encourages people to reclaim their passions and pursue new careers.

images.alt_text: man, old, view
Barring a disaster, there are going to be far more very old people: in 1990, there were only 95,000 people over 100 years old in the world. Today, there are over half a million, and rising.
Longevity is your friend in retirement planning

site_title: Hot stock: Heavy trading in Yoma Strategic as shares hit 16-month high
summary: Yoma Strategic, a Myanmar-focused company, posted a net profit of US$20.9 million for the second half-year ended March, reversing a US$32.7 million net loss from the same period last year. The company's shares rose 6.2% in early trading, reaching a 16-month high, with the counter gaining S$0.007 to S$0.12. This marks the most heavily traded security by volume on the Singapore Exchange since February 2023.

images.alt_text: CMG20240429-HengYY02 / 王彦燕 / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）

site_title: Yellen: US ties with Vietnam don't require it to sever ties with Russia, China
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen stated that the US upgraded partnership with Vietnam does not require Vietnam to sever ties with Russia or China. Yellen defended President Biden's increased tariffs on Chinese goods, citing protection of electric vehicles, solar energy products, and semiconductors from excess Chinese capacity. She also noted that Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump's tariff proposals would be broader and more costly for consumers, aiming to protect US firms from "coordinated Chinese dumping."

site_title: US single-family housing starts fall in May
summary: US single-family housing starts fell 5.2% in May to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 982,000 units, the Commerce Department's Census Bureau reported. This decline follows the revision of April's data to 1.036 million units. The average 30-year fixed mortgage rate eased to 6.95% last week, easing labor market conditions that may prompt two Federal Reserve rate cuts this year. Permits for single-family home construction also dropped 2.9% to 949,000 units in May.

site_title: Supreme Court upholds US tax on foreign business income
summary: The US Supreme Court upheld a 2017 tax on American-owned businesses' foreign profits in a 7-2 decision, rejecting an appeal that could have saved companies hundreds of billions of dollars. The tax, known as the mandatory repatriation tax, was established to offset a Republican-backed tax cut and was seen as having potential implications for Democratic proposals to impose a wealth tax. The court ruled that Congress has the constitutional power to tax people and companies on their share of undistributed corporate income, but did not address hypothetical taxes.

images.alt_text: Nvidia urges the justices to take up its appeal, arguing that the 9th Circuit’s ruling would open the door to “abusive and speculative litigation”.

site_title: Malaysia’s Genting inks US$1 billion energy deals with two Chinese firms
summary: Malaysia's Genting has signed two deals worth over US$1 billion with Chinese firms to boost its clean-energy capacity. The conglomerate will acquire a 49% stake in SDIC Jineng (Zhoushan) Gas Power Generation for US$18.6 million and build a floating liquefied natural gas (FLNG) facility in Indonesia with Wison New Energies for over US$1 billion. The deals aim to power up Genting's clean-energy goals and expand its energy-generating capacity to surpass 5,000 MW.

images.alt_text: Genting Singapore operated Resorts World Sentosa. Singapore sees most of its gaming crowd from China and neighbouring countries such as Malaysia and Indonesia.

The Chinese Premier is in Malaysia on an official three-day visit.  EPA-EFE/MALAYSIA'S DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION   HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES HANDOUT EDITORIAL USE ONLY/NO SALES

site_title: Nvidia’s explosive growth masks AI disillusionment
summary: Nvidia, the world's most valuable company, is experiencing explosive growth due to the artificial intelligence (AI) rally. However, tech companies, including Alphabet, Amazon, and Microsoft, have warped expectations for AI's contribution to profits by framing it as a general-purpose tool. This has led to disillusionment among businesses, with 63% of global companies planning to cut back on AI spending. Experts warn that AI is more useful when applied to niche purposes, and companies should narrow down its potential use cases more explicitly. Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang must sustain this growth, but the company's success relies on managing expectations and resisting the temptation to pitch AI as a general-purpose quick fix.

images.alt_text: The California-based company, which is led by Jensen Huang, has seen profits soar due to torrid demand for its powerful GPU chips, which have set the industry’s pace in pushing new advances in AI.
A few successful companies have begun to publicly experiment with the notion of an AI leader, even if at the moment it might largely be a branding exercise.

site_title: Paragon Reit to divest The Rail Mall for S$78.5 million
summary: Paragon Reit has entered into a sale-and-purchase agreement to divest The Rail Mall for S$78.5 million, expected to be completed in H2 2024. The divestment is part of the Reit's portfolio management strategy and won't impact net asset value or distribution per unit for FY2024. Proceeds will be used to pare down debt, finance potential acquisitions, and make distributions to unitholders.

images.alt_text: 铁道广场（The Rail Mall）外观。
