The Rail Mall is on a site sold by the state with 99-year leasehold tenure from March 1947; this leaves a balance of about 21 years and nine months.

site_title: Policy flip-flops, overcapacity dull Indonesia’s ambitious solar energy goals
summary: Indonesia's ambitious solar energy goals are being hindered by regulatory flip-flops and overcapacity in the energy sector. Despite holding the largest potential for renewable energy in the region, the country relies heavily on domestic fossil fuels, chiefly coal. The government's decision to revoke the net-metering scheme for rooftop solar installations has raised concerns among investors, increasing costs and reducing the economic viability of solar PV installations. To avoid setbacks, the country must incentivise renewable energy and reduce its reliance on coal, with industry experts calling for regulatory certainty and disincentives for the coal industry.

images.alt_text: Tech billionaire Elon Musk (2nd L) speaks next to Indonesia's Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin (L) during a ceremony held to inaugurate satellite unit Starlink at a community health center in Denpasar on Indonesia's resort island of Bali on May 19, 2024. Musk launched on May 19 his Starlink service on Indonesia's resort island of Bali as the country aims to extend internet to its remote areas. Millions of people in Indonesia, a vast archipelago of more than 17,000 islands, are not currently hooked up to reliable internet services. (Photo by SONNY TUMBELAKA / AFP)
Only less than 2 per cent of the vehicles on Indonesian roads are electric, with the vast majority still dominated by combustion engine vehicles.

site_title: Thailand eyes Brics membership at October summit, begins OECD application
summary: Thailand aims to join the BRICS group of emerging economies at the October summit in Russia, following a formal request submitted by the foreign ministry. The country also seeks OECD membership, with accession discussions set to begin. Thai officials believe membership in both groups will attract foreign investment, generate income, and improve quality of life. The decision comes as Thailand looks to expand its economic influence and challenge a Western-dominated world order. No set timeline has been established for joining the groups.

images.alt_text: Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput, governor of the Bank of Thailand, speaks during an interview in Bangkok, Thailand, on Tuesday, June 18, 2024. Thailand’s central bank governor warned that any move to raise the monetary authority’s inflation target may unanchor expectations and result in quickening price gains, which carries risks for economic growth. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg
The budget debate comes as Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin faces a Constitutional Court case that could potentially lead to his dismissal.

(FILES) (FILES) A member of the LGBTQIA+ community holds a placard calling for marriage equality during a pride march in Bangkok on June 4, 2023. The Thai senate will debate on April 2, 2024 a bill to legalise same-sex marriage, as the kingdom moves towards becoming the first Southeast Asian country to recognise marriage equality. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)
The BOT has also spurned repeated calls from the government for rate cuts, arguing instead that structural reforms are what the economy needs to spur growth.

site_title: Swiss financial regulations not yet tough enough post-Credit Suisse, central bank says
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) has expressed concerns that Switzerland's financial regulations are not yet tough enough to prevent future crises, citing the recent takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS. The central bank has called for strengthened capital and liquidity requirements, as well as improved crisis preparedness and recovery planning. It also supports a review of the liquidity coverage ratio and the use of forward-looking components in capital regulation. The SNB's proposals aim to address weaknesses that emerged during the Credit Suisse crisis and to ensure the stability of the Swiss economy.

images.alt_text: There has been vigorous debate in Switzerland about the size and power of UBS since it took over Credit Suisse last year in a state-engineered rescue.
The UBS Singapore Family Wealth comes after UBS released its Global Family Office report in May.
The SNB cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.25 per cent.

site_title: Sri Lankan favourites return to new Kotuwa restaurant at New Bahru
summary: Kotuwa, a Sri Lankan restaurant, has relocated to a new premises in New Bahru, Singapore. The restaurant, run by Rishi Naleendra, offers a mix of traditional Sri Lankan dishes, including devilled cashews, crab croquettes, and mutton rolls, in a hipster setting. The new space is larger and features a semi-dark interior with ethnic artworks. Despite some drawbacks, such as long wait times and limited server knowledge, the restaurant's food remains hearty, spicy, and enjoyable. A set menu is available, and prices range from S$20 to S$42.

images.alt_text: Sushi Ryujiro takes over the old Aoki premises.

site_title: Li Ka-shing’s CK Asset invests in ex-JPMorgan banker’s AI firm
summary: Li Ka-shing's CK Asset Holdings has invested in NEXX Global, a robotics-driven warehousing logistics firm, as its first strategic shareholder in a pre-series A funding round. The partnership aims to bolster NEXX's artificial intelligence capabilities. The funding round will help NEXX expand its services into South-east Asia, Europe, and the US this year. NEXX was founded by a former JPMorgan Chase banker, Houston Huang, and has received support from a team including logistics industry experts and a local university AI scientist.

images.alt_text: The credits will provide early-stage generative AI startups free access to computing power, a variety of AI models, and infrastructure, if they build their companies on AWS.
Brain.Q is developing a cloud-based platform to map brain network activity using machine learning algorithms to extract biological insights that translate into therapies.
Masayoshi Son has moved on to new obsessions, inspired in part by the success of Arm.

Hong Kong’s retail outlets, restaurants and bars have been hammered by a record number of residents heading across the border, where there’s a booming array of entertainment and dining options at low prices.
A exterior view of Cheung Kong Centre is seen in the Central district of Hong Kong, China, on Saturday, July 29, 2017. Photographer: Anthony Kwan/Bloomberg

site_title: Birth rates halve in richer countries as costs weigh, OECD report says
summary: Birth rates have dropped sharply in many rich OECD countries, with the total fertility rate averaging 1.5 children per woman in 2022, down from 3.3 in 1960. Many people are choosing to have children later in life or not at all due to economic concerns and a desire to prioritize other aspects of life. The average age of women giving birth has increased, and childlessness is on the rise, particularly in countries like Korea, Italy, and Spain. This trend is attributed to a combination of economic uncertainty and societal pressures.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Newborn babies inside a ward at the Tambak Maternity Hospital in Jakarta, on September 19, 2022. Babies born by cesarean section don't acquire the same healthy bacteria as those delivered vaginally, a setback to the development of their immune system thought to increase their risk of certain diseases later in life. But a new study, published on June 15, 2023, in the journal Cell Host & Microbe, finds that applying the mother's vaginal fluids on C-section babies after birth successfully restores this microbial balance, and has neurodevelopment benefits, too. (Photo by Adek BERRY / AFP)

site_title: Keppel Reit prices A$175 million floating rate green notes due 2027
summary: Keppel Reit has priced A$175 million of floating rate green notes due 2027, with proceeds to fund the acquisition of a Grade A office building in Sydney's central business district. The notes will bear interest at a floating rate based on the Bank Bill Swap reference rate plus an agreed spread, payable quarterly. DBS has been appointed the sole lead manager and bookrunner of the offering. The notes are expected to mature on June 26, 2027, meeting Keppel Reit's green financing framework.

images.alt_text: Higher net property income was mainly due to higher rentals as well as contributions from 2 Blue Street, said the Reit’s manager.
Retail investors increased their net outflow from the local banks from S$109 million in Q1 2024 to S$597 million in Q2 2024, up to Jun 13.
The 131 billion won revolving credit facility was obtained by Keppel No 4 General Investors’ Private Real Estate Investment Liability Company, a unit of Keppel Reit.

site_title: Vaccine group Gavi seeks US$9 billion to immunise world's poorest children
summary: Gavi, a global vaccine organisation, is seeking $9 billion over five years to immunize the world's poorest children. The group has already raised $2.4 billion, including $1.58 billion from the US. Gavi aims to reach 500 million children, including 50 million with the malaria vaccine, and plans to expand its work to include a dengue vaccine and a pandemic response fund. The organization plans to accelerate vaccine distribution and offer more vaccines, including expanding a malaria vaccine roll-out and catching up on routine programs.

images.alt_text: A different variant of bird flu, H5N1, has been spreading for weeks among dairy cow herds in the United States, with a small number of cases reported among humans.
AstraZeneca has previously admitted in court documents that the vaccine causes side effects such as blood clots and low blood platelet counts.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq open higher on Nvidia boost
summary: The S&P 500 and Nasdaq opened higher on Thursday, June 20, driven by a rally in Nvidia, while investors assessed economic data and US Federal Reserve commentary. The Dow Jones fell 30.13 points, or 0.08%, to 38,804.73. The S&P 500 rose 26.76 points, or 0.49%, to 5,499.99, and the Nasdaq Composite gained 51.71 points, or 0.29%, to 17,913.94. Investors are betting on interest rate cuts this year amid recent economic data and Fed commentary.

site_title: The emerging tech transforming how we shop
summary: Emerging technologies like augmented reality (AR) and artificial intelligence (AI) are transforming the retail industry, enabling consumers to shop virtually and interact with brands in new ways. Industry giants such as Sephora, Ikea, and Gucci are embracing AR, using it to create immersive brand experiences and drive online sales. The technology also fosters emotional connections with customers, reducing product returns and increasing customer satisfaction. As the global AR market is projected to reach $88.4 billion by 2026, businesses that adopt emerging technologies will be better positioned to thrive in an increasingly digital marketplace.

images.alt_text: From predicting product demand to optimising logistics, designing spaces and assessing investments, GenAI can drive improvements in critical areas such as lease writing, valuation, and legal processes.

Snap is adapting the augmented reality (AR) technology behind its popular filters and lenses  – tools that can add glittery makeup or cartoon eyes to someone’s video selfie – to help retailers use AR on their own websites and apps.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fell in latest week
summary: US initial jobless claims fell 5,000 to 238,000 in the week ended June 15, reversing a surge in the prior week. The number of people on benefits rolls rose to a 10-month high, indicating a cooling US job market. Economists expect further interest rate hikes to tame inflation, with the Federal Reserve maintaining its benchmark rate range of 5.25-5.5%. The data suggests labor market momentum is ebbing, leading to inflation pressures subsiding and financial markets anticipating potential rate cuts this year.

images.alt_text: In updated forecasts, the Congressional Budget Office said it now expects the federal budget deficit to be US$1.9 trillion in the 2024 fiscal year, which rises to around US$2.0 trillion when accounting for a shift in the timing of certain payments.
FILE PHOTO: Solar panels are built at the QCells solar energy manufacturing factory in Dalton, Georgia, U.S., March 2, 2023. REUTERS/Megan Varner//File Photo
Retail sales rose 0.1 per cent last month after a downwardly revised 0.2 per cent drop in April.
The survey’s reading of one-year inflation expectations was unchanged at 3.3 per cent.
US Import prices dropped 0.4 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.9 per cent surge in April.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen testifies before a Senate Appropriations Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee hearing on President Biden’s proposed budget request for the Department of Treasury, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 4, 2024. REUTERS/Anna Rose Layden/File Photo
The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.2 per cent last month after advancing by an unrevised 0.5 per cent in April.
In the 12 months through May, the CPI advanced 3.3 per cent after increasing 3.4 per cent in April.

site_title: Honeywell strikes US$2 billion deal to buy aerospace and defence firm CAES Systems
summary: Honeywell has agreed to buy aerospace and defense technology company CAES Systems for approximately $2 billion from private equity firm Advent International. This is Honeywell's second acquisition in recent months to strengthen its aerospace technologies unit. CAES, formerly known as Cobham Advanced Electronic Solutions, designs electronics for aerospace and defense companies. The all-cash deal was not immediately commented on by Honeywell or Advent International.

site_title: Biden to ban US sales of Kaspersky software over ties to Russia: source
summary: US President Joe Biden will announce plans to ban the sale of Kaspersky software in the United States, citing the company's ties to the Russian government and potential risks of cyberattacks. The restrictions, set to take effect on September 29, will bar downloads of software updates, resales, and licensing of Kaspersky products, and will also impact white-labelled products integrating the software. The move is aimed at mitigating risks of Russian cyberattacks and follows a national security probe into the software.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 3D printed models of people working on computers and padlock are seen in front of a displayed Kaspersky logo in this picture illustration taken, February 1, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Dollar rises, pound, Swiss franc drop on busy central bank day
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% to 105.42 against six peers, while the pound and Swiss franc declined after central bank meetings. The dollar index has been volatile over the past 10 days due to mixed signals from the US economy and European markets. The Bank of England kept interest rates unchanged, and the Swiss National Bank cut rates to 1.25%, contributing to the pound's 0.2% drop to US$1.2691 and the Swiss franc's decline.

site_title: Singapore startup Carro first to tap US$1 billion HSBC Asean Growth Fund
summary: Singapore startup Carro has secured a S$75 million multi-currency loan from HSBC, making it the first company to tap the US$1 billion Asean Growth Fund. The loan will be used to fund Genie Financial Services, an automotive financing subsidiary, and diversifies Carro's funding channel in Malaysia. Carro reported a record US$34 million in earnings before interest, depreciation, and amortisation, following previous funding from SoftBank Vision Fund and sovereign funds.

images.alt_text: Singapore-headquartered Carro, a South-east Asian online used-car marketplace, has acquired a 50 per cent stake in the rental unit of Indonesian automotive group PT Mitra Pinasthika Mustika Tbk for nearly US$54 million, both companies said in a joint statement on Monday.

site_title: Putin says Russia is keen to partner with Vietnam in energy and security
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed interest in partnering with Vietnam in energy and security, amid a pivot to Asia after Western sanctions. During a visit to Hanoi, Putin stated that Russia and Vietnam aim to build a reliable security architecture in the Asia-Pacific region. He also announced plans to increase energy cooperation and set up long-term liquefied natural gas (LNG) supplies to Vietnam. This comes after Russia has long cooperated with Vietnam in the oil and gas sector, with a joint venture producing 250 million barrels of crude oil by Friday.

images.alt_text: The Russian president is expected to participate in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum.

site_title: 20 wines under US$20, hot weather edition
summary: A list of 20 wines under $20, specifically chosen for hot weather, includes light-bodied and low-alcohol options. Most are from small producers and may not be widely available, but good wine merchants can suggest alternatives. The author, Eric Asimov, has shifted his approach to wine consumption, focusing on personal preference rather than seasonal pairings, and recommends these wines for their refreshing qualities during the summer months.

images.alt_text: Former NBA star Carmelo Anthony developed a reputation as a wine guy during his time at the Denver Nuggets.
China’s tariffs on wine were part of broader trade restrictions imposed on Australia after Canberra called for an inquiry into the origins of Covid-19.

site_title: Bank of Japan warns of potential hit to lenders from rising rates
summary: The Bank of Japan warns that rising interest rates could lead to potential losses for Japanese lenders, as their profitability has decreased significantly over the past 25 years. If interest rates rise sharply, financial institutions may incur latent losses on their securities holdings, potentially discouraging them from lending. This could affect banks' lending to low-profit firms, which have grown reliant on ultra-low interest rates.

images.alt_text: The diminishing presence of the BOJ heightens the need for the government to find stable buyers of JGBs and avoid a bond sell-off that could trigger a damaging spike in yields.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 20)
summary: Singapore's re-entry rate of retrenched workers declined, while job vacancies increased in the first quarter of 2024, according to the Ministry of Manpower. Passenger car COE premiums rebounded after a drop in the previous round. Civil servants received a 0.45-month mid-year bonus and junior officers may get up to S$250. The Public Service Division also warned of non-bank money laundering risks in sectors like corporate services and real estate. Meanwhile, investors shifted focus to private credit as a hedge against volatile stock market movements.

images.alt_text: PUB plans to ensure adequate space for recreational water activities after the installation of the system.

site_title: India’s Modi criticised for exam irregularities amid lack of jobs
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi faces criticism for exam irregularities amidst high unemployment, particularly among youth, at 18% last year. The opposition and students have accused Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party of unfair practices in government-run tests for college admissions and teaching jobs. The party now faces local elections in Haryana and Maharashtra, where it performed poorly in the national vote. Modi's government is struggling to address joblessness and maintain its parliamentary majority.

images.alt_text: While the Indian economy grew at a world-beating 8.2 per cent in 2023 to 2024, consumption has grown at half that pace.
India’s stocks suffered their worst day in more than four years after Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party garnered fewer seats than expected in the election.

What India needs now are reforms to promote jobs: lower tariffs to promote trade, investments in health and education, a less interventionist agricultural policy, and more liberal land and labour laws.

site_title: Singapore to seek compensation from owner of ship that was hit in oil-spill incident
summary: Singapore's government agencies will seek compensation from the owner of the ship that leaked 400 tonnes of fuel into the sea after being hit by another vessel on June 14. The ship, Marine Honour, has insurance coverage to meet the liability. Under Singapore's Merchant Shipping (Civil Liability and Compensation for Oil Pollution) Act 1998, the shipowner is strictly liable for the pollution damage, regardless of fault. The government will cover costs for cleanup measures, infrastructure damage, and economic losses.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, June 20, 2024 (Ep 85)
summary: The US interest rate outlook continues to impact Asian markets, with China's yuan reaching its weakest point since November. Mapletree Investments has increased its focus on maximizing returns. These market movements are part of the ongoing trend of interest rate fluctuations affecting regional economies.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks open muted at the opening bell on Thursday.
Asian markets were mixed in early trade on Thursday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta edging up.
The weakness in China’s currency is symptomatic of deteriorating sentiment towards the world’s second-largest economy.
The amenities at the Cottages of Boone include a fitness centre, a library and conference rooms.

site_title: Philippine peso skids on dollar's strength
summary: The Philippine peso hit a 10-day low, weakening 0.22% against the dollar to 58.77, amid expectations of a potential interest rate cut by the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP). The peso's decline is in line with other Asian currencies, including the Indonesian rupiah and Taiwan's dollar. Policymakers are expected to cut interest rates ahead of the US Federal Reserve's decision, which could put the BSP ahead of major central banks in rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The timing of the BSP’s easing in relation to the Fed is being closely watched as the peso continued to trade near a record low of 59 against the US dollar
Recently, the central bank also sought “to project a single voice to the public when communicating the intention and direction of monetary policy”.

site_title: China will struggle to undo US dominance
summary: The US economy is in a strong position, despite some domestic challenges. The country's growth and labour market are enviable, and its currency is increasingly seen as a strategic asset. Unlike the China of the past, the US has shifted from being seen as a declining power to a rising one, with numerous external threats having fizzled or been exaggerated. Domestic strains, such as potential economic slowdowns, remain the biggest threats to the US economy's dominance.

site_title: Considering a lab-grown diamond? You’ll be spoilt for choice
summary: Lab-grown diamonds (LGDs) are estimated to make up a fifth of the total diamond market today, with various colors and cuts available. Local jewellers such as JannPaul Diamonds and The Better Diamond showcase stunning LGD specimens, including bridal collections and custom-made rings. Priced from S$1,300 to S$10,800, LGDs offer a more affordable and sustainable alternative to natural diamonds.

images.alt_text: JannPaul's The White Series Diamond collection are patented cut diamonds.

site_title: Danone steps up health focus to boost growth
summary: Danone, a French food group, aims to boost growth by focusing on health and medical nutrition, targeting 3-5% annual like-for-like net sales growth from 2025 to 2028. This aligns with its 2024 goal and should deliver a double-digit return on invested capital. The company plans to diversify, scaling up in medical nutrition and seeking acquisitions, as CEO Antoine de Saint-Affrique seeks to stabilize sales and build predictable revenues.

images.alt_text: Sales rose 4.1 per cent to 6.79 billion euros (S$9.85 billion) in the first quarter, beating expectations for 3.4 per cent growth in a company-compiled consensus of 17 analysts.

site_title: Civil servants to get 0.45-month mid-year bonus; one-time payment of up to S$250 for junior officers
summary: Civil servants in Singapore will receive a 0.45-month mid-year bonus, the highest since 2019, with junior officers eligible for an additional one-time payment of up to S$250. The payouts were decided in consultation with public sector unions, taking into consideration the better economic outlook and global economic risks. The government will continue to monitor the economic situation and consider guidelines from the National Wages Council when determining the year-end bonus.

site_title: Singapore flags corporate service providers, real estate among non-bank money laundering risks
summary: Singapore has identified corporate service providers, real estate, and precious stones as high-risk sectors for money laundering, according to the updated Money Laundering National Risk Assessment. The banking sector, including wealth management, poses the highest risk. The assessment, published in 2024, highlights the need for vigilance in these sectors to prevent money laundering. Designated non-financial businesses and professions also pose significant risks. The assessment is the first update since 2014, when the last national risk assessment was published.

images.alt_text: The assets seized in the S$3 billion money laundering case range from luxury watches to cars.
The Council of Estate Agencies, the industry regulator, is investigating property agents who had facilitated transactions associated with the S$3 billion money laundering case.

site_title: Philippine central bank says restrictive policy settings appropriate
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) maintains its stance of keeping monetary policy settings restrictive to control inflation, which is expected to stay within the 2-4% target range for 2024 and 2025. The peso has weakened due to global conditions, but the central bank remains optimistic about macroeconomic conditions. The key policy rate is at a 17-year high of 6.50%.

site_title: Rupee hits record low, hurt by likely outflows, importer dollar demand
summary: The Indian rupee hit a record low of 83.6650 against the US dollar, falling to a lifetime low, due to likely outflows and strong dollar demand from local importers. The currency's weakness was exacerbated by a broader stronger dollar and weakness in the Chinese yuan. Despite the Indian economy's strong growth, the rupee has been hovering around record lows for weeks. The central bank's tight band to prevent sharp appreciation or depreciation was absent on Thursday, allowing the currency to fall.

images.alt_text: While the Indian economy grew at a world-beating 8.2 per cent in 2023 to 2024, consumption has grown at half that pace.

Options trading has soared in India in the last five years, fuelled mainly by retail investors so that the notional value of index options traded more than doubled in 2023-24 to US$907.09 trillion from the year before, exchange operator NSE has said.

site_title: In London, a houseboat used to be the affordable option. Not anymore
summary: London's affordable houseboat option is disappearing as the city's canal system becomes increasingly congested. With land-based home prices skyrocketing, over 4,000 houseboats now occupy London's 160-kilometer canal network, a 86% increase in the past decade. Despite being cheaper than land-based housing, the rising costs of boat maintenance, fuel, and licenses are making it difficult for boaters to afford the lifestyle. The Canal & River Trust is not limiting the number of boats, but instead, is cracking down on rogue mariners and implementing new pricing bands for wider boats.

images.alt_text: Berkeley, which operates across London, Birmingham and the south of England, reported an 8 per cent fall in pretax profit to £557.3 million (S$958 million) for the year ended Apr 30.

site_title: India shuns China's calls to resume passenger flights after 4 years, officials say
summary: India is resisting China's calls to resume direct passenger flights after a four-year halt, citing ongoing border tensions and concerns about Chinese companies investing in India. The halt in flights has benefited carriers like Emirates and Singapore Airlines, while China's economy struggles to recover from the pandemic. China's Foreign Ministry has expressed hope for a resumption of flights, but an Indian official said peace on the border is necessary for the rest of the relationship to move forward.

images.alt_text: In Thailand, where tourism is an economic mainstay, the number of Indian tourists – though fewer than Chinese in absolute terms – is only about 14 per cent lower than it was in 2019.

site_title: STI dips 0.1% on Thursday as regional central banks hold rates steady
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index closing at 3,300, as regional central banks maintained their benchmark lending rates. The People's Bank of China left its one-year loan prime rate at 3.45% and its five-year rate at 3.95%, while Bank Indonesia maintained its interest rate at 6.25%. In Singapore, Seatrium rose 3.3% after settling its arbitration case, while Keppel fell 1.7%. Markets across the region ended mixed, with Japan's Nikkei up 0.2% and Indonesia's IDX Composite up 1.4%.

images.alt_text: The central bank is holding interest rates because lowering them would widen China’s policy divergence with the Federal Reserve.
Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,331.38 per ounce.

site_title: Guzman Y Gomez shares jump 36% in biggest Australian IPO this year
summary: Guzman Y Gomez, a Mexican food chain, made its Australian IPO debut with a 36% jump in its first trading day, marking the country's third-best performing IPO in five years. The company raised A$335.1 million and saw its market capitalisation increase to about A$3 billion. Despite forecasting a second consecutive net loss for 2024, Guzman Y Gomez's shares closed slightly higher, sending a hopeful signal about investor sentiment. The IPO marks a positive trend after a record 2021 and a low June half for Australian listings in 2024.

images.alt_text: The VanEck Bitcoin ETF is scheduled to debut on the ASX on Jun 20.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality debuts in Taiwan with over 200-key Taipei serviced apartment
summary: Frasers Hospitality, a business unit of Frasers Property, has debuted in Taiwan with the launch of Fraser Residence Taipei, a serviced apartment offering over 200 suites in Taipei's Beitou District. The residence is set to open in 2027, marking Frasers Hospitality's expanded presence in North Asia, following existing properties in China, Japan, and South Korea. This marks a strategic entry into the Taiwanese market, catering to the enclave of corporate executives and foreign expatriates in the Tianmu neighbourhood.

images.alt_text: Frasers Property’s capital recycling transactions total S$1.1 billion in H1 2024

site_title: Passenger car COE premiums bounce back after previous round’s drop
summary: COE prices for passenger car categories A and B increased following a significant drop in the previous round, with Category A at S$90,889 and Category B at S$102,334. In contrast, motorcycle premiums rose marginally, while open and goods vehicle categories decreased. The mixed results differ from the previous round, where all categories experienced a drop in COE premiums.

images.alt_text: Industry observers attribute the plunge in ultra-luxury car registrations to higher taxes on more expensive cars and reduced rebates that mean higher cost of ownership.
COE premiums for all categories dipped in June's first round of bidding, with passenger car categories leading the way.

site_title: South Korea’s SK Innovation and SK E&S to pursue merger, report says
summary: SK Innovation, the parent of South Korea's largest oil refiner and battery maker SK On, is expected to pursue a merger with energy affiliate SK E&S, creating a 106 trillion won (S$104 billion) asset company. The merger aims to shore up SK On's loss-making battery business by combining with a profitable company. The move is part of SK Group's efforts to reduce affiliates and reevaluate investments, excluding artificial intelligence and chip-related sectors. A decision on the merger is pending shareholder approval, set for late June.

site_title: IHH, Sunway among bidders for Affinity’s Malaysian hospital: sources
summary: IHH Healthcare and Sunway Medical Centre are among bidders for Malaysia's Island Hospital, owned by Affinity Equity Partners, in a potential $1 billion sale. Non-binding bids were due on June 11, and Affinity plans to shortlist bidders for a next round with a sale expected by year-end. Private equity firms CVC Capital Partners and TPG Capital also submitted initial bids. The sale comes as investors seek opportunities in the South-east Asian healthcare sector, driven by a growing affluent and aging population.

Mount Elizabeth Novena Hospital is operated by IHH Healthcare. The healthcare group plans to add more than 15 new clinics and around two to three ambulatory care centres in Singapore.

site_title: Five excellent shows at Gillman Barracks
summary: Gillman Barracks continues to showcase outstanding art exhibitions despite recent concerns about its future. Five notable shows include Nelo Akamatsu's mesmerizing glass vessels at Mizuma Gallery, Myanmar artist Po Po's conceptual works at Ames Yavuz, Robert Zhao Renhui's retrospective at ShanghArt Singapore, Ng Joon Kiat's deconstructed paintings at Yeo Workshop, and a collection of works on paper at Fost Gallery featuring artists such as Ian Woo, Yeo Tze Yang, and Wyn-Lyn Tan. These exhibitions highlight the intersection of art and science, and demonstrate the art cluster's continued relevance and value.

site_title: Mapletree Investments divests North Carolina student housing asset
summary: Mapletree Investments has divested its student accommodation asset, The Cottages of Boone in North Carolina, for an undisclosed amount. The asset, which houses 894 beds, was part of Mapletree's strategy to drive value and maximize returns through strategic dispositions. The divestment comes after the global real estate giant posted a full-year net loss of S$577.2 million due to industry headwinds. This is the second major move by Mapletree in recent months, following the acquisition of 8,192 student housing beds in the UK for £1 billion.

"We need to weigh the costs and benefits... We don't get much more savings, but it's the right thing to do," said Mapletree's Wong Mun Hoong.
Revenue for the year is flat at S$2.8 billion, as compared to S$2.9 billion in the previous financial year.

site_title: Indonesia central bank keeps rates unchanged, as expected
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, maintained its interest rate at 6.25% on June 20, as expected, to stabilize the weakened rupiah. The rupiah has fallen to its lowest level in four years due to global economic uncertainties and capital outflows. Despite this, the central bank is confident that the rupiah will strengthen, citing a potential decline in US Federal Reserve funds rate and low inflation pressures. Economists warn that the decision may provide short-term relief but underscores broader economic vulnerabilities if the rupiah continues to weaken.

images.alt_text: Analysts expect that the goods trade surplus for Southeast Asia’s largest economy will shrink this year with a manageable current account deficit.

site_title: China’s key plenum aims to fix decades-old tax revenue imbalance
summary: China's key plenum aims to address a decades-old tax revenue imbalance by redistributing income from central authorities to local governments. The move is expected to curb provinces' addiction to land sales, a major contributor to local debt. Policymakers hope to ease concerns over a $13 trillion local government debt pile, posing risks to financial institutions and economic growth. The plenum will discuss the biggest changes to China's fiscal system in three decades, aiming to balance revenues with expenditures and stop municipal debt accumulation.

images.alt_text: Beijing is seeking to create new, sustainable sources of income for local governments as their finances get squeezed by a years-long housing slump.

site_title: Swiss National Bank presses ahead as rate cutting front-runner
summary: The Swiss National Bank (SNB) cut its policy rate by 25 basis points to 1.25% for the second consecutive time, easing price pressures and maintaining its position as a front-runner in global policy easing. The move follows a recent rebound in economic growth and a decline in inflation, with the SNB's inflation forecasts now expecting inflation at 1.0% by 2027. The SNB chairman, Thomas Jordan, attributed the rate cut to the decrease in underlying inflationary pressure, allowing the central bank to maintain "appropriate monetary conditions."

images.alt_text: Thomas Jordan, Chairman of the SNB, says retail CBDC could fundamentally alter the current monetary system and the role of central banks and commercial banks, with far-reaching consequences for the financial system.

Using tokenization, which involves recording assets on a blockchain, has the advantage of combining messaging and settlement aspects of a payment in one transaction, Bank for International Settlements (BIS) says.
The Swiss National Bank has become the first major central bank to ease its policy with a surprise 25 basis point cut to its key rate.

site_title: Swiss watch exports drop in May as China slowdown persists
summary: Swiss watch exports declined 2.2% in May to 2.3 billion Swiss francs, due to a slowdown in demand in China and Hong Kong, with shipments to Hong Kong plummeting 23%. The decline follows a period of waning demand for premium watches amid higher interest rates, economic growth concerns, and geopolitical conflicts. Exports to the US were flat in May, while exports of watches priced above 3,000 francs showed some strength, gaining 0.7% in value.

site_title: Oil spill: ‘Are we all complicit?’
summary: A new play, "Playing With Fire," explores Singapore's petrochemical industry and its environmental implications. The play, written by Cheyenne Alexandria Phillips, is based on interviews with industry players who acknowledge the industry's impact on the environment, but also express pride in their work and a desire to transition to sustainable sources. The play aims to spark a conversation about shared responsibility and the need for a collective effort to transition to green energy, featuring a cast of actors and directed by Claire Wong.

site_title: Latest Singapore 6-month T-bill offers cut-off yield of 3.74%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) released the results of its latest 6-month Treasury bill auction, showing a cut-off yield of 3.74%. Demand increased, with S$15.5 billion in applications for the S$6.6 billion on offer, a 2.34 bid-to-cover ratio. This marks a decrease from the previous auction, where the yield was 3.76% and the median yield declined to 3.54%.

images.alt_text: Applications for the latest T-bill auction totalled S$14.2 billion for the S$7.1 billion on offer, representing a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.

site_title: China loosens grip on yuan with weakest fixing since November
summary: China set the yuan's daily reference rate at 7.1192 per US dollar, its weakest since November, as policymakers loosen their grip on the currency. The move comes amid deteriorating sentiment towards the world's second-largest economy, with the onshore yuan little changed around 7.26 and the offshore currency at its weakest this year. The weakening of the yuan is attributed to worsening capital outflows and the US dollar's approach to this year's peak, with traders betting on higher interest rates in the US.

The PBOC’s caution is a sign that Chinese leaders are leaning more on fiscal stimulus to achieve their ambitious growth goal of around 5 per cent for this year.
The PBOC is expected to hold its liquidity operations on the first working day after the Chinese New Year holiday ends, which would be Sunday.

site_title: Europe’s EV battery plans fade on China price war, US subsidies
summary: The European Union's efforts to boost its battery industry and compete with China and the US are fading due to high costs and bureaucratic hurdles. Companies such as Volkswagen, Stellantis, and Mercedes-Benz are scaling back or refocusing battery projects, while Chinese manufacturers are slashing costs and the US is offering lucrative subsidies. Europe risks falling behind in the EV battery market, with China controlling over 80% of the market and having a head start on next-generation cell technology. The EU needs to provide substantial support to new entrants to secure market shares, but so far, investments have been directed mainly towards cell manufacturing rather than mining and refining.

site_title: Citi sees AI displacing more finance jobs than any other sector
summary: Citigroup has released a report stating that artificial intelligence (AI) will displace more jobs across the banking industry than in any other sector, with 54% of banking jobs having high potential to be automated. However, the bank also believes that AI may not lead to a drop in headcount, as financial firms will need to hire AI managers and compliance officers to oversee the technology's use. The bank is already experimenting with AI technologies, including generative AI, to boost productivity and cut costs.

site_title: Greater interest in private credit as investors move away from bonds as hedging tools: UBS forum panellist
summary: Investors are shifting away from bonds as hedging tools and into private credit and other uncorrelated assets due to rising volatility in the stock market. According to Bobby Jain, CEO of Jain Global, many investors are "underweight" in alternative assets, including private credit and hedge funds. Private credit is expected to nearly double in size to $2.8 trillion by end-2028, driven by increased demand from ultra-high-net-worth individuals. The trend is backed by research from Preqin and reflects a broader shift in the investment landscape.

images.alt_text: More wealth is being generated, and faster than ever before, says Hannes Hoffmann, global head of Citi’s family office group.
Better risk models are needed as the private credit industry matures and absorbs money from high-net-worth individuals and family offices.

site_title: Malaysian, Chinese firms sign deals worth US$2.8 billion in potential investments
summary: Malaysian and Chinese firms signed agreements worth US$2.8 billion in potential investments during Chinese Premier Li Qiang's visit. The collaborations include oil and gas, education, banking, and power sectors. Deals include a floating liquified natural gas facility in Indonesia and a gas-fired power plant in China. The agreements were made to foster economic growth and cooperation between the two countries.

site_title: Stonehenge monument sprayed orange in UK climate protest
summary: Two environmental activists from the Just Stop Oil group were arrested in the UK after spraying an orange substance on the ancient Stonehenge monument to demand the next government commit to phasing out fossil fuels by 2030. The activists, Niamh Lynch and Rajan Naidu, used "orange cornflour" that was expected to wash away with the rain. English Heritage and police are investigating the damage, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak condemning the act as "a disgraceful act of vandalism."

images.alt_text: Fairy masquerade dances to drums along the streets during the kankurang Festival in Janjanbureh on January 27, 2024. Listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2005, Kankurang, a combination of the Mandingo words "kango" and "Kurango", literally translated as "voice" and "force", ensures the transmission and teaching of the values and practices that form the basis of Mandingo cultural identity, a West African people whose historical home was the Mali empire. (Photo by MUHAMADOU BITTAYE / AFP)

epa11017366 Scaffolding inside the nave of the Notre-Dame de Paris Cathedral, as restoration works continue in Paris, France, 08 December 2023. French President Emmanuel Macron is visiting Notre Dame Cathedral on 08 December, to mark the one-year countdown to its reopening in 2024 following extensive restoration after the fire four years ago. Macron's visit, continuing his annual tradition since the blaze on 15 April 2019, is aimed to highlight the progress in the works, including the near completion of the cathedral spire.  EPA-EFE/SARAH MEYSSONNIER / POOL  MAXPPP OUT
Peru has put forth the “preparation and consumption of ceviche” for which the recipe is “inherited from generation to generation”.

site_title: Former hedge fund trader builds US$135 million burrito fortune
summary: Former hedge fund trader Steven Marks has built a US$135 million "burrito fortune" through his restaurant chain Guzman y Gomez (GYG), which boasts 185 restaurants in Australia, Singapore, Japan, and the US. GYG shares are trading on the Australian Securities Exchange, valuing the company at A$2.2 billion. Marks, 52, is the second-largest shareholder after TDM Growth Partners, and plans to expand to 1,000 restaurants in Australia. Despite analysts questioning the company's valuation, GYG aims to maintain attractive store economics and grow to 30-40 new restaurants annually.

images.alt_text: A tourist from the US (second left) sings karaoke as "mama-san" Kuri Awaji (left), who runs a snack bar, waves a glow stick at Kuriyakko in Tokyo, Japan, March 22, 2024.
Disfrutar in Barcelona tops the best restaurant list.

US-based market watchers have suggested that Paradise Dynasty – whose signature dish is xiao long bao soup dumplings – could pose a threat to Taiwanese rival Din Tai Fung, which has eight outlets in California.

site_title: China’s e-commerce giants dig deep on pitches to jolt wary buyers
summary: China's top e-commerce companies, including Alibaba Group and ByteDance, are intensifying their marketing efforts during the annual "618" shopping festival to boost sales. The companies are offering deep discounts, enlisting A-list celebrities to promote products, and providing no-questions-asked returns. The move is part of a bid to shake off the industry's post-Covid slowdown and return to pre-2020 growth levels. The efforts are expected to attract Chinese shoppers, who are increasingly wary of the industry's growth prospects.

images.alt_text: The festival, named after the Jun 18 founding date of e-commerce provider JD.com but embraced by all platforms, is China’s second-biggest annual sales event after Singles Day in November and is seen as a key test of household consumption.
Sendo recruits households to become its pickup stations, where customers collect their groceries after placing an order online on Sendo Farm.

Companies including Shein, PDD Holdings’ Temu and Alibaba’s AliExpress, which predominantly ship made-in-China products “cross border” to markets around the world have been rapidly growing in recent years.

site_title: Vietnam welcomes Putin in boost to ties, ignoring US criticism
summary: Vietnam welcomed Russian President Vladimir Putin on June 20, 2024, in a move that underscores the country's decades-old relationship with Moscow, despite US criticism over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Putin is expected to participate in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Ho Chi Minh Mausoleum and meet with Vietnamese officials. Vietnam has long relied on Russia for weapons and has used Russian backing to explore and drill for oil and gas in the South China Sea, where China's claims threaten Vietnamese sovereignty.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin and North Korea's leader Kim Jong Un pose for a photo after the signing of a “comprehensive strategic partnership”.
Russia's President Vladimir Putin’s trip to North Korea would be his first since July 2000.

site_title: Nasdaq boosts scrutiny of investors in IPOs from China, Hong Kong
summary: Nasdaq is scrutinizing small initial public offerings (IPOs) from China and Hong Kong, seeking to prevent a repeat of wild price swings seen in 2022. The exchange is questioning the identity and independence of pre-IPO investors, the backgrounds of selling shareholders, and the valuation of private shares. Several companies, including AMTD Digital and Addentax Group, surged 32,000% in their 2022 IPOs before crashing, prompting the increased scrutiny. No IPOs have been halted, but the process has been lengthened, adding uncertainty and costs to the review.

images.alt_text: Bae Jin Soo’s Money Game, one of the two webtoons he wrote that inspired Netflix’s The 8 Show (pictured), follows a young man who becomes debt-ridden after a failed crypto investment.

site_title: Families of Boeing 737 MAX crash victims ask US to seek US$24 billion fine
summary: Families of Boeing 737 MAX crash victims have asked the US Justice Department to seek a fine of up to $24.78 billion against the planemaker, citing the deadliest corporate crime in US history. The request comes after the Justice Department found Boeing violated a 2021 deferred prosecution agreement related to the 2018 and 2019 fatal crashes that killed 346 people. The families are seeking a maximum fine of $24.78 billion, with $14-22 billion suspended in exchange for compliance improvements and a corporate monitor.

site_title: SoftBank’s Masayoshi Son is ready for next big bet after hiatus
summary: SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son is poised to make his next big tech bet, potentially investing in artificial intelligence (AI), after years of missteps at the Vision Fund. Son warned that his next move could be a hit or miss, but SoftBank needs to take risks to stay ahead. The company aims to increase its renewable power generation business to supply AI's power needs, particularly in the US. Son is seeking up to $100 billion to fund a chip venture to compete with Nvidia and supply semiconductors for AI.

images.alt_text: It is the second time Elliott has targeted SoftBank, once among the world’s biggest and most influential tech investors.
SoftBank Group has already priced 650 billion yen of notes this year, including a separate 550 billion yen note in March.
Japan prides itself on its high standard of customer service but the issue of harassment of staff working in the service industry has gained more awareness in recent years.
FILE PHOTO: The logo of SoftBank Group Corp is displayed at SoftBank World 2017 conference in Tokyo, Japan, July 20, 2017. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo
Masayoshi Son has moved on to new obsessions, inspired in part by the success of Arm.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, Wing Tai
summary: Seatrium's wholly owned subsidiary, Seatrium New Energy, has entered into a settlement agreement with Awilco Drilling and two of its units. RigCo will pay a US$57 million settlement sum, along with other costs, related to a contract with Seatrium New Energy. Meanwhile, Wing Tai's unit placed the top bid of nearly S$464 million for a state land plot next to Great World MRT station, amid reduced appetite for private residential sites.

site_title: Singapore’s re-entry rate of retrenched workers down, job vacancies up in Q1
summary: Singapore's re-entry rate of retrenched workers declined to 59.4% in Q1, down from 61.5% in the previous quarter, while job vacancies rose to 81,900. The decline was driven by sectors such as information and communications, financial and insurance services, and professional services. Despite this, the unemployment rate remained low at 2.1%, with resident long-term unemployment at 0.8%. The Ministry of Manpower expects continued improvements in employment due to an improved economic outlook and sustained hiring optimism.

images.alt_text: Six out of nine sectors reported weaker hiring sentiments compared to the previous quarter.
Employers’ increased flexibility and openness to a wider talent pool has made them better able to fill vacancies, resulting in the proportion of harder-to-fill spots trending down, says MOM.
Office workers at Robinson Road, 29 April 2024. Can use for stories on finance, business, trusted securities, insight, global market, manpower, employment
Singapore’s employment growth eases in Q1, as tighter foreign worker quotas kick in for construction firms

site_title: Gold edges higher as weak US data lifts Fed rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $2,331.38 per ounce, driven by weak US economic data and expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate cut this year. The US Fed is looking for confirmation that inflation is cooling, with recent data showing moderation in the labor market and price pressures. Traders now price in a 66% chance of a Fed rate cut in September, citing lower interest rates as a benefit for holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Spot gold held its ground at US$2,327.76 per ounce.

site_title: Booking.com sounds alarm on AI-enabled travel scams
summary: Booking.com's Internet safety boss warns of AI-enabled phishing scams targeting travelers. The company has seen a 500-900% increase in phishing attacks globally, with scammers using generative AI to launch more sophisticated attacks. Travel websites, including Booking.com, are vulnerable to phishing scams as they require sensitive information from users. To stay safe, travelers and hosts should sign up for two-factor authentication and be cautious when clicking on links or opening attachments, especially if they appear suspicious.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Visitors sit at the stand of online accommodation booking website Booking.com during the International Tourism Trade Fair (ITB) in Berlin, Germany, March 9, 2016. REUTERS/Fabrizio Bensch/File Photo
Booking Holdings said it expects growth of 4 to 6 per cent in room-night bookings, less than the 7.4 per cent increase analysts were expecting.
Booking.com works as an intermediary between property owners and guests.
The company has greater exposure in Europe and the Middle East than rivals such as Expedia Group.

site_title: China plans new measures to attract venture capital investment
summary: China plans to introduce new measures to attract venture capital investment, including setting up yuan funds for international investors and encouraging qualified institutions to issue corporate bonds. The goal is to boost domestic technology sector investments and advance chip design and manufacturing to counter US policy threats. Following a 7% decline in venture capital investment in 2023, the total value fell to $69.9 billion, the lowest since 2019. The new measures aim to protect China's technological self-sufficiency and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders assess rates outlook
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed trading session on Thursday, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, Seoul, Wellington, Taipei, and Jakarta edging up, while Tokyo, Sydney, Manila, and Singapore declined. Investors are assessing the outlook for US interest rates, which is expected to have a limited impact, and closely following developments in France ahead of crucial elections. Despite recent data indicating the world's top economy is slowing, analysts predict only one rate cut this year, with some concern that the rally could see a correction.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong piled on more than one per cent after a recent run of weakness, while Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Manila and Taipei financial markets also rose.

site_title: Forwards become Malaysia’s favoured tool for boosting the ringgit
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, has been using currency forwards to prop up the ringgit, boosting the currency to its strongest since the 1997-98 Asian Financial Crisis. The central bank's net forward FX position widened to a record negative US$27.7 billion in April, while its foreign-exchange reserves remain little changed this year. This approach has raised concerns about the ringgit's vulnerability to shifts in global sentiment, but experts argue the currency is undervalued and not at risk of a currency crisis.

images.alt_text: A worker hands out a stack of Malaysian fifty ringgit banknotes at a currency exchange store in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, on Friday, March. 1, 2024. Policymakers have stepped up their rhetoric to rein in the local currency’s fall after it reached the weakest level since the height of the Asian financial crisis in 1998 last week. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg
Policymakers have taken coordinated measures to shore up the local currency after it slid to a 26-year-low in February.
Rising foreign inflows and income repatriation by state firms are fuelling the optimism.
Malaysia’s central bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged in view of benign inflation and a rosy growth outlook.

site_title: Chinese banks hold lending rates following PBOC’s caution
summary: Chinese banks maintained benchmark lending rates for a 10th consecutive month, with the one-year loan prime rate at 3.45% and the five-year rate at 3.95%. This decision was made to avoid policy divergence with the Federal Reserve, which is expected to keep rates higher. However, weak borrowing demand and the longest deflationary streak since the 1990s have led to speculation that rates may be lowered in the second half of the year to stimulate demand. The People's Bank of China has left the medium-term lending facility rate unchanged for the 10th month.

images.alt_text: Outstanding yuan loans rose 9.3 per cent last month from a year earlier compared with 9.6 per cent growth in April.

The PBOC said SOEs’ purchases of unsold homes should adhere to “voluntary participation, demand-based ordering and reasonable pricing” to ensure business sustainability, while any new local hidden debt should be strictly prohibited.

After adding to its gold reserves for 18 consecutive months, official data from the People’s Bank of China showed its holdings were unchanged in May, sending global spot prices down sharply on Friday.

site_title: Australia regulator raises concerns over Olam’s A$145 million bid for Namoi Cotton
summary: Australia's competition regulator has raised concerns over Olam's A$145 million bid for Namoi Cotton, citing potential reduced competition in the supply of cotton ginning services. The proposed acquisition would leave only one alternative cotton gin in the region, potentially leading to higher prices for cotton growers. The regulator also flags concerns over the impact on the supply of cotton lint classing services in Australia.

site_title: US billionaire eyes TikTok takeover to save Internet from Big Tech
summary: US billionaire Frank McCourt is campaigning to buy TikTok and create a "new Internet" free from major platforms like Instagram and YouTube. He claims these platforms are harming children and contributing to societal problems. McCourt, a former owner of the Los Angeles Dodgers and current owner of Olympique de Marseille, aims to rescue the internet from what he sees as destructive influence. His plan involves acquiring TikTok to control the platform and potentially create a new internet structure.

images.alt_text: TikTok did not detail the exploit used by attackers, but media reports indicated it involved a direct messaging feature.
AFP, among more than a dozen other fact-checking organisations, is paid by TikTok in several countries to verify videos that potentially contain false information.

site_title: Singapore stocks open muted on Thursday; STI up 0.01%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.01% higher on Thursday, edging up 0.27 points to 3,304.27. The broader market saw 57 decliners outnumbering 45 advancers, with 43 million securities worth S$53.7 million changing hands. Banking stocks posted mixed performances, with DBS and OCBC rising, while UOB fell. The move followed losses in European real estate and technology stocks, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 closing 0.2% lower.

images.alt_text: XXX

site_title: Site near Great World City draws two bids; top bid of S$1,325 psf ppr from Wing Tai
summary: Two developers, Wing Tai Holdings and Hong Realty, submitted bids for a 99-year leasehold private housing site near Great World City, with Wing Tai's top bid of S$1,325 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) for nearly S$464 million. The site, River Valley Green (Parcel A), can generate about 380 private homes. The outcome is within market expectations, reflecting developer caution amid high interest rates and business risks. Analysts expect developers to remain cautious due to uncertainty about private housing demand and competing supply from upcoming projects.

site_title: China eyes trade war targets across Europe for counterstrikes
summary: China is preparing to retaliate against the European Union's proposed tariffs on electric vehicles by targeting specific products, including automotive parts. This approach is similar to its strategy against Australia in a previous trade dispute. Beijing has already identified potential products and is expected to impose auto tariffs, which could have a significant impact on European industries. The move is seen as a response to the EU's decision to impose tariffs on EVs, sparking concerns of a new trade war between the two parties.

images.alt_text: Chinese authorities have previously hinted at possible retaliatory measures through state media commentaries and interviews with industry figures.
China imported US$6 billion worth of pork in 2023, including offal, with the EU accounting for more than half.
Under the EU’s proposal, Chery’s imports will incur tariffs of 21 per cent.
Tesla assembles Model Y sport utility vehicles in Germany, it imports Model 3 sedans into the bloc from the China plant.

site_title: Meituan’s worst-to-first stock rally has street looking for more
summary: Meituan's shares have surged over 90% from a late-January low, making it one of the best-performing technology stocks in China this year. Analysts predict another 17% rise over the next year due to record earnings projections, cost cuts, and potential overseas expansion. With rivals backing off from market share attempts, Meituan is poised for further gains, reversing its position as the biggest loser on the Hang Seng Tech Index last year.

images.alt_text: The global expansion is emblematic of a push by Chinese companies to seek growth abroad as competition at home intensifies.Source: Bloomberg

Meituan, which operates an app providing services as varied as bike-sharing, ticket-booking and maps, reported revenue in the three months to Mar 31 of 73.3 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion), against 58.62 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.
Meituan’s global expansion is emblematic of a push by Chinese companies abroad, seeking growth as local competition intensifies even while consumption wanes.

site_title: China’s LNG boom threatened by growing menu of alternative fuels
summary: China's liquefied natural gas (LNG) market is facing a growing threat from alternative fuels as the country's emissions may peak ahead of schedule and its government is subsidizing coal power to support intermittent renewable energy. Despite billions of dollars in investment by global majors like Shell and TotalEnergies, China's LNG imports may only rise 13-14% this year, down from 18% in 2021. The country is instead relying on domestic production, pipeline supplies from Russia, and other alternative fuels to meet its energy needs.

images.alt_text: Headquartered in Singapore, Pavilion Energy is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Temasek that trades and ships LNG in Asia and Europe.
The decision to go ahead with the facility is the latest sign of Adnoc’s ambition to expand in the market globally.

LNG accounts for around 3 per cent of the global marine fuels market, according to Wood Mackenzie, with the early adopters the gas tankers themselves, followed by container ships. It’s considered one of the most promising alternatives to fuel oil, along with methanol, ammonia and biofuels.
CNOOC's Lingshui 36-1 gas field, located in the western South China Sea, has been tested to produce over 10 million cubic metres per day of open flow natural gas.

site_title: Huawei, Tencent near deal to exclude WeChat from revenue sharing
summary: Huawei and Tencent are nearing a deal to exclude WeChat from revenue sharing, allowing WeChat to operate fully on Huawei's Harmony mobile platform without a fee. The agreement would be a concession for Huawei, which is seeking to monetize its smartphone platform and surpass Apple in China. In return, Tencent would maintain and update the WeChat app, which generates significant revenue through mini programs. The deal is seen as crucial for Huawei, as it would ensure WeChat's continued support and readiness for Huawei's transition to its new Harmony OS.

images.alt_text: Huawei is weighing a commission lower than the typical 30 per cent cut that Apple and Alphabet’s Google take for payments made via their mobile stores for things like apps, games, movies and music subscriptions.
Huawei’s luxurious flagship stores display premium products ranging from smartphones to tablets, smartwatches, televisions and even electric vehicles.
Huawei has launched the Pura 70’s four smartphone models in late April and the series quickly sold out.

site_title: Singapore needs a trained workforce to become an AI capital
summary: Singapore aims to become an AI capital, but workers still harbor work-related anxieties. Despite 86% of Singaporeans using AI at work, nearly three-fourths express concern about job redundancy. To address this, the government and businesses must give workers a voice in AI integration, upskill employees with training, and manage data and reputational risks. Up to 75% of finance and tech professionals lack AI talent, and 54% of Singaporeans report seeing incorrect AI-generated outputs. To succeed, Singapore must invest in a robust and confident talent pool.

images.alt_text: The AI talent crunch is not unique to any one country but a pressing issue worldwide. In fact, any country that hopes to dominate the global AI race must overcome their first and most basic battle: the war for talent.
Singapore had more than 800 AI startups in 2021, the latest year for which Enterprise Singapore has data, with the number having grown at a compounded 18 per cent a year since 2018.

site_title: UK house prices edge higher in sign of stability after downturn
summary: The UK housing market has shown signs of stability, with average home prices rising 1.1% to £281,000 in April, according to the Office for National Statistics. This follows a 0.9% gain in March and marks an end to eight months of declines. Experts predict a rebound in the second half of the year, driven by potential interest rate cuts from the Bank of England as inflation returns to target. Mortgage rates have also fallen, with average rates now at 5.03% for a five-year fixed mortgage.

images.alt_text: A cost-of-living crisis in the G7 nation and the world’s sixth-biggest economy has left many Britons struggling to make ends meet, as bills for food, energy, rent and mortgages increase.

epa10498611 A row of houses in London, Britain, 02 March 2023. UK house prices in February dropped by the most in more than 10 years according to mortgage lender Nationwide showing signs of a slowdown in the housing market due to high inflation and rising borrowing costs.  EPA-EFE/NEIL HALL

site_title: Bitcoin ETF lists on main Australian stock market for first time
summary: The VanEck Bitcoin ETF has listed on Australia's main stock market, marking the first time a Bitcoin ETF has been listed on the exchange. The ETF has a seed investment of around A$985,000 and is a feeder fund for the US$647 million VanEck Bitcoin Trust in the US. This listing follows the launch of similar Bitcoin ETFs in the US and Hong Kong, and is seen as a step towards the potential of virtual-asset ETFs in the Asia-Pacific region, which could reach over US$3 billion in the next few years.

images.alt_text: Stubborn inflation has led traders to scale back expectations for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts this year.
The VanEck Bitcoin ETF is scheduled to debut on the ASX on Jun 20.
The Australia listing comes as US$58 billion has been amassed by US Bitcoin ETFs that debuted this year.

site_title: Europe: Shares lose ground on real estate, tech losses
summary: European shares fell 0.2% as real estate and technology stocks declined, while basic resources stocks rose 0.6% following a rebound in metal prices. The UK's FTSE 100 closed up 0.2% despite high inflation remaining above target, with the Bank of England likely to wait longer before cutting interest rates. Market focus shifts to interest rate decisions from central banks in Britain, Norway, and Switzerland later this week.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed nearly 0.7 per cent higher on Tuesday, with utilities leading sectoral gains, up 1.5 per cent.

site_title: Seatrium settles US$57 million arbitration case with Awilco unit
summary: Seatrium has settled a US$57 million arbitration case with Awilco unit Awilco Rig 2 (AR2) for a contract to construct a mid-water semi-submersible drilling rig. The settlement, along with other costs, will be covered by RigCo Holding, which holds the rig assets. The agreement does not impact Seatrium's net tangible assets or earnings per share in the current fiscal year. This settlement follows a previous arbitration award granted to Seatrium New Energy against Awilco Rig 1 (AR1) in April 2023.

images.alt_text: Keppel FELS terminates US$425m contract to build drilling rig
The arbitration was commenced in June last year by Keppel FELS to enforce its rights against Awilco Rig 1 (AR1).

site_title: Oil dips after hitting seven-week highs on demand hopes, war jitters
summary: Oil prices dropped on Wednesday after reaching seven-week highs due to a combination of summer demand optimism and concerns over escalating conflicts. Brent crude futures fell 0.1% to $85.27 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude slipped 0.1% to $81.47 a barrel. The decline comes despite an industry report showing an unexpected rise in US crude inventories, and analysts citing green shoots indicating a more optimistic outlook. Tensions in the Middle East, including a possible "all out war" between Israel and Lebanon's Hezbollah, also contributed to the price drop.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.08, or 1.3 per cent, at US$85.33 per barrel. US West Texas Intermediate crude futures ended US$1.24, or 1.5 per cent, higher at US$81.57 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: China’s Xi says army faces ‘deep-seated’ problems in anti-corruption drive
summary: China's President Xi Jinping stated that the Chinese military faces "deep-seated problems" in its politics, ideology, work style, and discipline during a military political work conference. Xi emphasized the need for senior cadres to expose their shortcomings and undergo self-reflection. The purge has already led to the removal of nine PLA generals and at least four aerospace defence industry executives, with more expected as the Third Plenum meeting approaches. Xi aims to strengthen supervision of senior cadres and develop new tools to combat corruption.

images.alt_text: This year, 25 senior officials have been investigated, on track to surpass last year’s record of 45 under Xi Jinping, according to a tally of probes announced by CCDI.
The Communist Party has put an increasing focus on corruption among cadres and corporate executives.

site_title: LTA awards Japanese joint venture a $242m contract to build tunnels for Cross Island Line
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a $242 million contract to a Japanese joint venture, Nishimatsu Construction and Okumura Corporation Singapore Branch, to design and build tunnels for the second phase of Singapore's Cross Island Line (CRL). The twin 2.4km tunnels will run beneath Sungei Pandan canal and key infrastructure, with construction expected to begin in 2024 and completed by 2032. The tunnels will be up to 40m deep due to the challenging ground conditions, and real-time monitoring and safety measures will be implemented to ensure a safe and minimally impactful construction process.

site_title: India approves US$9-billion port to boost trade with Europe
summary: India's Cabinet has approved a $9-billion deep-water port project on the western coast, approximately 150 km from Mumbai, at a cost of 762 billion Indian rupees (S$12.3 billion). The Vadhavan port will have terminals for mega vessels and various imports, with an annual capacity of 298 million tonnes. The project is part of India's plan to connect with Europe through sea and rail links via the Middle East, with the first phase expected to be completed by 2029. This will be a crucial part of the India-Middle East corridor, a major multiplier of economic activity.

site_title: India central bank says high food prices hindering disinflation trajectory
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) warned that high food prices may hinder its efforts to control inflation, despite a temporary drop in May. Annual retail inflation fell to 4.75% in May, below the forecast, but core inflation remains a concern. The RBI expects sustained domestic demand momentum and GDP growth to remain steady, with prospects for agriculture improving due to expected above-normal monsoons. The central bank urged caution against "adventurism" and continued focus on bringing down inflation to the target, despite growing calls for a pivot in monetary policy.

images.alt_text: While the Indian economy grew at a world-beating 8.2 per cent in 2023 to 2024, consumption has grown at half that pace.

site_title: UK probes Hewlett Packard Enterprise's US$14 billion deal for Juniper Networks
summary: The UK's Competition and Markets Authority is investigating whether Hewlett Packard Enterprise's planned $14 billion acquisition of Juniper Networks would result in competition concerns in the country. The regulator has until August 14 to decide whether to refer the deal to a deeper probe. The acquisition, announced in January, aims to enhance HPE's artificial intelligence offerings and is expected to double its networking business.

images.alt_text: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of Hewlett Packard Enterprise logo in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

site_title: US mortgage rates drop below 7% for first time since March
summary: US mortgage rates dropped below 7% for the first time since March, with a 30-year fixed mortgage rate decreasing eight basis points to 6.94% and a five-year adjustable-rate mortgage rate falling 18 basis points to 6.27%. This decline is attributed to a broad cooling in inflationary pressures, prompting traders to boost bets on potential interest-rate cuts by the Federal Reserve. The decrease in mortgage rates has led to an increase in financing applications for home purchases, with the index of mortgage applications rising 1.6% to its highest level since March.

images.alt_text: The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home increased 8.6 per cent in the week ended Jun 7 to 143.7, the highest level since May 3.
Home maintenance accounted for the largest share of ownership costs in Bankrate’s findings.
The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home decreased 4.4 per cent in the week ended May 31.
The Commerce Department’s Census Bureau on Monday (Jun 3) said construction spending fell 0.1 per cent after slipping 0.2 per cent in March.
The NAR said its pending home sales index fell 7.7 per cent in April to 72.3 from an upwardly revised 78.3 reading in March.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increased four basis points in the week ended May 24 to 7.05 per cent.
New home sales dropped 4.7 per cent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 634,000 units in April.

site_title: Business leaders see political instability as a threat to Europe
summary: Business leaders in Europe rank political instability, including upcoming elections and populism, as the second-biggest risk, after increased regulatory burden. A survey of over 500 executives by consulting firm EY found that greater political stability, reduced red tape, and lower energy prices are needed to reverse falling foreign direct investment. This comes as Europe struggles with economic challenges, including surging prices and the fallout from Russia's war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: The ECB projects inflation to return to 2 per cent in the final quarter of next year.

The proportion of unpaid loans on the balance sheet of eurozone banks has shrunk to a historic low since the financial and debt crises of 15 years ago, partly thanks to the ECB’s own pressure on lenders.
Sentix’s index for the eurozone rose to 0.3 points for June from -3.6 in May.
Net trade provided the biggest contribution to growth in the three-month period.
An index measuring manufacturing activity rose to 47.3 in May from April’s 45.7.

site_title: IMF urges Denmark to introduce more property risk safeguards
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has urged Denmark to introduce more property risk safeguards, particularly for highly leveraged households. The IMF proposes lowering the maximum loan-to-value ratio below 95% or requiring mandatory amortization until a certain equity threshold is reached. Denmark's financial supervisor must ensure banks are adequately provisioning for commercial property exposures and that their capital calculations cover potential risks. The IMF also warns of potential downside risks to prices due to high interest rates and the impact of troubled Sweden's real estate market on Denmark's properties.

images.alt_text: The wind farms, to be completed by 2030, are crucial if Denmark is to meet its target to reduce CO2 emissions by 70 per cent from 1990 levels by the end of this decade.

site_title: Tougher policy could help Singapore achieve better energy efficiency
summary: Singapore may adopt tougher energy efficiency policies to align with European Union standards. The European Union's Energy Performance of Buildings Directive aims to renovate buildings with poor energy performance, which are considered "stranded" assets. In Singapore, the Building and Construction Authority's Mandatory Energy Improvement regime, set to be implemented by the end of the year, will require energy audits and improvements for large commercial buildings. This could push landlords to make energy-efficient upgrades, benefiting the environment and occupants, and aligning with the country's economic and environmental goals.

images.alt_text: Banks in the EU are already reacting by setting stricter conditions around commercial real estate financing.
To date, Raffles City Singapore will be Singapore's largest integrated development to adopt cooling-as-a-service.

site_title: New Zealand economy returns to growth, exiting recession
summary: New Zealand's economy exited recession with a 0.2% expansion in the first quarter, beating expectations of 0.1% growth. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) maintains its key interest rate at 5.5%, the highest since 2008, to control inflation. Despite strong immigration and tourism, steep borrowing costs curb consumer spending and business investment.
