Economists predict a rate cut in the final months of 2024 or early 2025, with GDP per capita still declining for the sixth straight quarter.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ has undertaken its most aggressive policy-tightening since 1999, when the official cash rate was introduced, lifting it by 525 basis points since October 2021 to 5.50 per cent.
The RBNZ, which forecasts 0.2 per cent growth for the quarter, has kept monetary policy restrictive to curb demand and get inflation back under control.

Houses in the Lyall Bay suburb of Wellington, New Zealand, on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020. A housing frenzy at the bottom of the world is laying bare the perils of ultra-low interest rates. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg

site_title: Amazon invests 10 billion euros to expand cloud and logistics in Germany
summary: Amazon plans to invest 10 billion euros in expanding its cloud and logistics in Germany, bringing the total investment to 17.8 billion euros. The majority of the investment, 8.8 billion euros, will be spent on expanding its cloud infrastructure by 2026, driven by growing demand for AI-driven technologies in Europe. The investment is expected to create over 4,000 jobs this year, with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz praising the investment as underlining the country's attractiveness for investors.

site_title: Crypto firm Consensys says US regulator has closed inquiry into Ethereum 2.0
summary: US regulator the SEC has closed its investigation into Ethereum 2.0, a blockchain protocol, after cryptocurrency firm Consensys filed a lawsuit against the commission in April. Consensys founder Joseph Lubin described the decision as a "significant victory" but noted that it is not enough to ensure clear and fair regulations. The SEC previously approved applications from major exchanges to list spot ether ETFs, a surprise move that pleased the cryptocurrency industry. Consensys plans to continue its lawsuit to challenge the SEC's authority to regulate the Ethereum blockchain.

images.alt_text: The SEC still has to approve the ETF issuers’ registration statements detailing investor disclosures before they can start trading.
Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to become a digital asset hub after rolling out a dedicated regulatory regime last year.

site_title: No bids for Upper Thomson Road housing site at URA tender
summary: A state land site in Upper Thomson, Singapore, drew no bids at a tender that closed on June 19, marking the first time in over 20 years that a government land sale site has gone unsold. The 2.44-hectare plot required developers to incorporate serviced apartments, which analysts believe deterred potential bidders due to higher costs and management expertise. This is the second site in the same category, following a failed bid in April for an adjacent plot in Upper Thomson Road.

images.alt_text: River Valley Green (Parcel A), on the confirmed list of the first-half 2024 Government Land Sales Programmej, can yield about 380 private housing units.
The land plots at Dairy Farm Walk and Tengah Garden Avenue are on the confirmed list, while the Bayshore Road site sits on the reserve list.
Last year, a Perennial Holdings unit was awarded a tender for a private assisted-living development in Parry Avenue for S$71.9 million.

site_title: US homebuilder confidence slides to lowest level this year
summary: US homebuilder confidence plummeted to 43 in June, the lowest level this year, due to high mortgage rates near 7% limiting buyer interest and weighing on demand. The NAHB/Wells Fargo index fell 2 points, and measures of current sales and buyer traffic also dropped to the lowest level this year. Builders cited high mortgage rates, construction loan costs, labor shortages, and a lack of buildable lots as challenges. However, cheaper financing costs may soon provide relief, potentially easing the impact of elevated resale prices.

images.alt_text: The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage decreased eight basis points to 6.94 per cent in the week ended Jun 14
The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home increased 8.6 per cent in the week ended Jun 7 to 143.7, the highest level since May 3.
Home maintenance accounted for the largest share of ownership costs in Bankrate’s findings.
The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home decreased 4.4 per cent in the week ended May 31.
The Commerce Department’s Census Bureau on Monday (Jun 3) said construction spending fell 0.1 per cent after slipping 0.2 per cent in March.
The NAR said its pending home sales index fell 7.7 per cent in April to 72.3 from an upwardly revised 78.3 reading in March.

site_title: Stockholm exchange fined US$10 million for insider trading lapses
summary: The Financial Supervisory Authority of Sweden fined Nasdaq Stockholm nearly $10 million for failing to detect and report suspected insider trading. The exchange was investigated for deficiencies in trading monitoring at four major companies, including ICA and Lundin Energy, and for initiating trades in violation of regulatory frameworks. Despite the violations, the authority did not withdraw the exchange's authorization. The fine was issued as a "remark and administrative fine of $9.6 million." Nasdaq Stockholm maintains it had sufficient capabilities to detect insider dealings and will assess the FSA's interpretation of its obligations.

images.alt_text: Dirty-money ties worried some at Swedbank while bosses kept mum

site_title: Dell, Super Micro providing server racks for xAI’s supercomputer
summary: Dell Technologies and Super Micro Computer are partnering to provide server racks for xAI's supercomputer, a project led by Elon Musk's artificial intelligence startup. Dell is assembling half of the racks, while Super Micro will supply the remaining half. The supercomputer aims to power the next version of xAI's chatbot Grok, which requires tens of thousands of power-hungry chips. The project, aiming to be completed by fall 2025, is a significant step for xAI, a challenger to Microsoft-backed OpenAI and Alphabet's Google.

images.alt_text: Almost half of Michael Dell’s fortune comes from the Texas-based computer maker, which he started 40 years ago while a student at the University of Texas.
Fuelled by optimism about demand for its AI-optimised servers, Dell’s stock has more than doubled this year and hit a record high earlier this week.
Dell AI-capable PCs will come with the Qualcomm Snapdragon X series chips that feature neural processing units dedicated to processing complex AI tasks.
The layoffs come after sluggish demand for its PCs for nearly two years partly contributed to a 11 per cent drop in revenue in fourth-quarter earnings posted last month.

site_title: With stock market in doldrums, SGX may want to listen to new voices for solution
summary: New groups and initiatives have emerged in an attempt to revive the struggling Singapore Exchange (SGX), which is struggling to attract fresh listings and improve liquidity. The Singapore Venture & Private Capital Association (SVCA) has called for authorities to invest in the local market, while a new research organization called Corporate Monitor has been formed by industry observers. These efforts come as the SGX faces challenges in attracting new companies to list on the exchange.

images.alt_text: Retail investors increased their net outflow from the local banks from S$109 million in Q1 2024 to S$597 million in Q2 2024, up to Jun 13.
The exchange noted that open interest across key equity, foreign exchange and commodity derivatives also rose to record highs.

site_title: Greenback struggles for direction, euro close to 1½ month low
summary: The US dollar struggled for direction, dropping overnight as retail sales suggested economic activity remained lacklustre, leading to speculation that the Federal Reserve will cut rates sooner. The euro remained close to a 1½-month low due to concerns over a new French government potentially weakening fiscal discipline. Sterling rose after data showed stronger-than-expected service inflation in the UK. The dollar index was flat at 105.27, with markets pricing in a 65% chance of a Fed rate cut in September and nearly 50 basis points of cuts expected this year.

images.alt_text: Against a basket of currencies, the dollar was up 0.1 per cent at 105.40.

site_title: Son of Myanmar's Suu Kyi 'concerned' as mother marks birthday in junta detention
summary: Myanmar democracy leader Aung San Suu Kyi is marking her 79th birthday in military detention, with her son expressing concern over her health and circumstances. Suu Kyi, serving a 27-year sentence, has spent nearly a quarter of her life under house arrest. Despite her popularity in Myanmar, she has been largely hidden from view, with no communication with her son since her detention in 2021. Authorities arrested those marking her birthday, including 22 people in Mandalay for wearing flowers in their hair.

images.alt_text: epa10779215 (FILE) - Myanmar State Counselor Aung San Suu Kyi (R) waits for the arrival of Chinese President Xi at the presidential house in Naypyitaw, Myanmar, 17 January 2020 (reissued 01 August 2023). According to state media, Myanmar's Chairman of the State Administration Council granted amnesty on 01 August 2023 to ousted civilian leader Aung San Suu Kyi for a number of offenses, more than two years after she was detained in the 2021 military coup.  EPA-EFE/NYEIN CHAN NAING

site_title: KitKat maker sees chocolate demand ebbing as cocoa costs creep in
summary: Nestle, the maker of KitKat, warns that rising cocoa costs will lead to higher prices for chocolate, potentially reducing demand. Cocoa futures have more than doubled this year due to a global shortage, forcing manufacturers to raise prices. Companies that secured supplies in advance have been shielded, but those that haven't will likely pass on higher costs to consumers, expecting demand to decrease as prices rise.

images.alt_text: Pressure is growing on food companies to make their range of products healthier.
Nestle’s net profit rose sharply by about 20 per cent to US$12.76 billion.

site_title: British bank NatWest to close Polish business, cutting 1,600 staff
summary: NatWest will close its business in Poland by the end of 2025, resulting in the loss of 1,600 jobs, with 45% of roles eliminated permanently and the remaining 55% transferred to Britain and India. The decision follows the completion of a financial crime project in Poland. The bank aims to become a simpler and more efficient organization, with equivalent jobs created in the two remaining hubs.

site_title: EU drafts plan to exempt long-haul flights from new emissions rules
summary: The European Commission has drafted a proposal to initially exempt long-haul flights from new emissions rules, allowing them to avoid tracking and reporting non-CO2 emissions for two years. International flights departing or landing in Europe from non-European destinations will be excluded, mirroring current EU rules that only apply to flights within Europe. The International Air Transport Association and low-cost European carriers oppose the exemption, citing concerns it could misdirect non-CO2 mitigation measures.

images.alt_text: The EU’s strict carbon-pricing regime may be the best chance the world has to achieve the Paris climate agreement’s ambitious emissions-reduction goals.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 19)
summary: PUB, Singapore's national water agency, plans to install a 55 megawatt-peak floating solar photovoltaic (FPV) system at Pandan Reservoir to ensure adequate space for recreational water activities. This move aims to promote sustainability and efficient use of space. The project is part of PUB's efforts to integrate renewable energy sources and minimize environmental impact.

site_title: Amazon invests US$11 billion to expand cloud and logistics in Germany
summary: Amazon invests US$11 billion to expand cloud and logistics in Germany, with 8.8 billion euros (S$12.7 billion) allocated to expand cloud infrastructure by 2026. The investment is expected to create over 4,000 jobs this year. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz praised the investment, citing the country's attractiveness for investors. The move aims to capitalize on growing demand for cloud services and retail goods in Europe, particularly in AI-driven technologies. This investment brings Amazon's total planned investments in Germany to 17.8 billion euros.

site_title: US exceptionalism is dead no matter who wins the election
summary: The US is shedding its exceptionalism, moving away from its role as a moral beacon or crusader, and instead becoming another great power pursuing selfish interests. This shift will have significant implications for international relations, as the US will prioritize realism over idealism, focusing on interests rather than values. The country's foreign policy will become more transactional, with a focus on negotiating spheres of influence and a new balance of power, potentially using limited war as an instrument. This change is already underway, with the US's economic policy turning protectionist and nationalist, and its support for international law and institutions fading.

images.alt_text: America’s liberal political culture made a huge difference to the liberal international order that has existed since WWII.
Has America lost its entrepreneurial edge?

site_title: Getting industrial policy right is a tricky business
summary: The Biden administration's Inflation Reduction Act promotes industrial policy with multiple goals, including place-based manufacturing and lowering emissions. This shift marks a significant change from the US's historic role as a proponent of the open world economy. Industrial policy has become more pervasive worldwide, with a 5.8-fold increase in interventions from 2017 to 2022, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research. The rise of industrial policy in high-income countries has led to accusations of hypocrisy, with critics arguing that these nations have more fiscal room to intervene.

images.alt_text: Workers at Terray Therapeutics in Monrovia, Calif., on April 19, 2024. Companies like Terray are building big, high-tech labs to generate data to help train artificial intelligence to produce more effective drugs. (Spencer Lowell/The New York Times)

site_title: Saudi Arabia dethrones China as top emerging-market borrower
summary: Saudi Arabia has surpassed China as the top emerging-market borrower, issuing over $33 billion in bonds this year, according to new data. The kingdom's record borrowing pace is driven by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan to diversify the economy from oil and position itself as a link between Asia and Europe. Despite concerns from some money managers, Saudi Arabia's borrowing is seen as a positive sign, with improving sentiment and healthy demand for its bonds.

images.alt_text: A sputtering recovery in the world’s second-biggest economy has driven a record-breaking rally in Chinese government bonds over the past few months.
The People's Bank of China has repeatedly hinted at its discomfort over the bond rally in the past few months as long-term yields touched two-decade lows.
In late May, it was disclosed that Riyadh and Washington were close to a "final agreement" for a new security and economic cooperation pact.

Under the new agreement that also involves other sellers, Ardian and PIF will acquire 22.6 per cent and 15 per cent respectively of FGP Topco, which is the parent company of Heathrow Airport Holdings, for a total of £3.26 billion (S$7.1 billion).
The Saudi government owns about 82 per cent of Aramco, while the Public Investment Fund holds a further 16 per cent stake.
The initiative underscores the increasing importance of semiconductors for Saudi Arabia as it seeks to tap into new industries.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, June 19, 2024 (Ep 84)
summary: Market updates for Wednesday show tempered expectations for U.S. interest rate cuts, with Hong Kong stocks leading gains in Asia. Disappointing U.S. retail sales figures also influenced market movements.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 78 to 33.
Hong Kong piled on more than one per cent after a recent run of weakness, while Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Manila and Taipei financial markets also rose.

site_title: Australia cracks down on ESG investing industry with new rules
summary: The Australian government plans to introduce environmental, social and governance (ESG) labelling requirements for investment products marketed as "sustainable" by 2025. The new rules will force large businesses and financial firms to incorporate climate disclosures based on the Australian Accounting Standards Board's guidelines. The move aims to combat greenwashing and steer more capital into credible sustainable activities. Australia's plan puts the country on track to follow Asian financial hubs Singapore and Hong Kong in building ESG requirements, ahead of the European Union's review of its regulatory framework.

images.alt_text: Some sectors are more sensitive to sustainability themes than others. The energy sector, for instance, requires investors to be concerned about carbon emissions.
Singapore’s proactive policies and robust clean energy ecosystem offer international businesses and investors a platform to explore technology possibilities in the energy transition.

site_title: Fitch sees Asian tourism rebounding to pre-Covid levels by 2025
summary: Fitch Ratings predicts Asian tourism will rebound to pre-Covid levels by 2025, driven by weaker currencies, government efforts, and increased outbound travel from China. The Asia and Pacific region is expected to surpass pre-pandemic tourist arrivals in the first half of 2025, with Thailand, Indonesia, and Singapore expected to benefit from the growth. However, risks include elevated airfares, energy prices, and geopolitical tensions, which could dampen demand for travel and spending.

images.alt_text: People relax on Lamai beach on Koh Samui island in the southern Thai province of Surat Thani on April 8, 2024. (Photo by Lillian SUWANRUMPHA / AFP)

site_title: Swiss regulator rules out UBS antitrust action over Credit Suisse deal
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator FINMA has ruled out antitrust action against UBS over its takeover of Credit Suisse last year, despite recommendations from the country's antitrust watchdog. The regulator stated that the merger won't eliminate effective competition in any market segment, drawing a line under the issue. UBS will continue to implement its integration of Credit Suisse. The decision comes after a report by competition authority Comco, which had assessed the impact of the merger on competition concerns.

images.alt_text: UBS says the buyback programme will be worth up to US$1 billion this year.

site_title: Is the party over for lab-grown diamonds?
summary: Lab-grown diamond sales have seen a decline in recent years due to increased competition and technological advancements. Diamond giant De Beers has announced it will stop producing lab-grown diamonds for jewelry, and some experts believe the market's heyday is over. With no resale value and a surplus of stones, the future of lab-grown diamonds is uncertain. Experts and jewelers have expressed concerns about the market's sustainability, with prices continuing to fall despite the growth of the market in the past few years.

site_title: Philippine VP resigns as education minister as Marcos alliance crumbles
summary: Philippine Vice-President Sara Duterte resigned from her positions as education minister and anti-insurgency task force vice-chair, marking a significant crack in her alliance with President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. Duterte cited "true concern for teachers and the youth" as the reason, but Marcos accepted her resignation without explanation. This move comes as the Marcos alliance appears to be crumbling, with Duterte's resignation being the latest sign of a growing rift between the two. Duterte's resignation is seen as a significant development in the Philippines.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. delivers his speech during a joint press statement with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen (not pictured) at Malacanang Presidential Palace in Manila on July 31, 2023. The two leaders are expected to hold bilateral meetings to bolster European Union-Philippines relations and discuss matters on trade, security and global challenges in infrastructure. (Photo by Aaron Favila / POOL / AFP)

site_title: UK's Vodafone sells US$1.8 billion stake in India's Indus Towers
summary: UK's Vodafone has sold a 18% stake in India's Indus Towers for $1.82 billion, nearly doubling the initial 10% stake sale due to strong investor demand. Local operator Bharti Airtel picked up shares, increasing its stake to nearly 50%. Vodafone will use the proceeds to repay debt, which includes 1.8 billion euros in bank borrowings. Indus Towers' stock slid 4.3% after the sale, while Vodafone Idea shares were mostly flat.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a Vodafone store in Ronda, Spain, October 3, 2022. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

site_title: German rappers spark buzz with rhubarb-bar blabber
summary: A German rap song about rhubarb, titled "Barbaras Rhabarberbar," has become a viral hit, reaching No. 12 on TikTok's music charts ahead of Beyoncé. The song's tongue-twisting title and lyrics, performed by comedian Bodo Wartke, have inspired a viral dance routine and over 47 million views on TikTok. The song's success has also helped to dispel stereotypes about the German language being serious or boring, with Wartke hoping it will promote a more positive image of German culture.

images.alt_text: Rappers Travis Scott, Drake sued over deadly Texas concert crush

site_title: More worries for China, sales at big e-commerce festival drop for first time
summary: China's major online platforms experienced a 7% decline in combined gross merchandise volume (GMV) during the "618" e-commerce festival, marking the first time sales have dropped. The event, which has grown in size over the past few years, was seen as a key test of household consumption. Consumer demand remains sluggish due to concerns over the economy and job market, with sales peaking at nearly 800 billion yuan in 2023. The decline in sales is a worrying sign for China's economic growth.

images.alt_text: YNAP’s exit comes as China’s middle class, an important source of revenue for global luxury brands, turns more cautious on spending.

Companies including Shein, PDD Holdings’ Temu and Alibaba’s AliExpress, which predominantly ship made-in-China products “cross border” to markets around the world have been rapidly growing in recent years.
Troubles run deeper in the US, where lawmakers have alleged Temu and rival Shein exploit loopholes to the disadvantage of US competitors.
An advertisement campaign featuring former England soccer captain David Beckham will run in conjunction with the Uefa tournament and encourage consumers to “score more with AliExpress”

site_title: NEA pledges additional S$90 million for environmental services industry
summary: The National Environment Agency (NEA) has pledged an additional S$90 million in funding through the Productivity Solutions Grant to support Singapore's environmental services industry in adopting technological solutions and equipment. This funding will help companies improve productivity, strengthen capabilities, and build a skilled workforce. NEA is also exploring new technologies for waste management, including alternative disposal methods for mixed municipal solid waste. The funding support will be available until March 31, 2027, and will build on the success of previous grants, which supported over 600 companies.

images.alt_text: Senoko waste-to-energy plant is the third such plant built in Singapore.

site_title: US-China gap widens to record in South Korea’s current account
summary: South Korea's current account surplus with the US reached a record $91.2 billion in 2023, while the deficit with China hit a record $30.9 billion, marking the largest gap between the two nations in central bank data since the late 1990s. The US has held the lead since 2020, as South Korea strengthens ties with the US under President Yoon Suk Yeol, while China's growing shortfall is likely to fuel questions for policymakers, amid US efforts to restrict technology exports to China and Beijing's struggles to recover from a consumption slump.

images.alt_text: The BOK extended its interest rate pause for an 11th straight meeting in May.

site_title: UK homebuilder Berkeley targets rental market, raises outlook
summary: UK homebuilder Berkeley targets the rental market, raising its earnings outlook for the first time in over two years. Despite a 8% fall in pretax profit to £557.3 million, the company expects a 5% increase in its 2025 outlook due to strong demand for rental homes in London and South East England. Berkeley plans to develop a 10-year build-to-rent platform, targeting 4,000 homes across 17 brownfield sites, amid a growing rental crisis in the UK.

images.alt_text: A cost-of-living crisis in the G7 nation and the world’s sixth-biggest economy has left many Britons struggling to make ends meet, as bills for food, energy, rent and mortgages increase.
Housing affordability is a hot political issue ahead of the UK election, with house prices up by around a fifth since the last election in December 2019.
The real estate data and information company CoStar Group estimates that at the beginning of June this year, 33 million square feet of office space across 2,775 buildings was on offer in the UK.
The average British house price hit a record high in May and first-time homebuyers are facing the toughest financial environment in 70 years.
The S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers’ Index rose to 54.7 in May from 53 in April.

site_title: TSMC nears US$1 trillion valuation as target upgrades boost rally
summary: TSMC is nearing a US$1 trillion valuation after a stock rally, making it the eighth-largest company globally by market capitalization. The foundry sector leader has benefited from the widening adoption of artificial intelligence, with its cutting-edge technology and valuation attracting global investors. Wall Street brokerages have lifted their price targets, citing surging AI-related demand and potential price hikes in 2025. Analysts see TSMC as a key beneficiary of the growing positive sentiment around AI, with Goldman Sachs increasing its 12-month price target by 19% to NT$1,160.

images.alt_text: An arbitrage strategy on Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co's American depositary receipts and Taiwan-listed shares may turn painful for investors,.
TSMC uses extreme ultraviolet lithography equipment to produce more advanced 3nm chips, but such tools cannot be sold in China due to export controls.
FILE PHOTO: TSMC logo is seen at TSMC Museum of Innovation in Hsinchu, Taiwan May 29, 2024. REUTERS/Ann Wang/File Photo
ASML’s new machine can imprint semiconductors with lines that are just eight nanometres thick, 1.7 times smaller than the previous generation.
Since tech tensions with the United States heated up in 2018, China has ramped up efforts to develop self-sufficiency in chips, pumping huge sums into the sector.

site_title: Indonesia posts narrowing trade balance surplus of US$2.93 billion in May
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of US$2.93 billion in May, narrower than expected, driven by a 2.86% year-on-year growth in exports to US$22.3 billion. Despite a decline in the rupiah exchange rate, the surplus fell due to weak demand for commodities and a contraction in imports. Analysts predict the goods trade surplus will shrink this year, with a manageable current account deficit, and expect Indonesia's current account to decline to -0.7% of GDP.

images.alt_text: “I believe that the FTA (free trade agreement) will certainly have a positive and mutually beneficial impact for Indonesia and EEU,” Indonesia's Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto said.

site_title: China approves autonomous driving startup Momenta’s US IPO
summary: China's securities regulator approved autonomous driving startup Momenta Global Limited's initial public offering (IPO) in the US. Momenta plans to issue up to 63,352,856 ordinary shares and list on the Nasdaq Stock Market or the New York Stock Exchange. This approval comes as China grants approval to nine automakers to test advanced autonomous driving technologies on public roads, aiming to accelerate adoption of self-driving cars.

site_title: PUB calls tender for floating solar panel project at Pandan Reservoir
summary: PUB, Singapore's national water agency, has launched a tender for a 55 MWp floating solar photovoltaic (FPV) system at Pandan Reservoir. The project, set to be completed in 2028, aims to generate enough solar energy to power 16,000 flats and reduce carbon emissions by 27 kilotonnes annually. This is PUB's second large-scale FPV project, following the 2021 installation at Tengeh Reservoir. The system will cover 22% of the reservoir space and aligns with PUB's strategy to replace carbon-based energy sources with renewable energy.

images.alt_text: The solar farm is expected to be able to produce 141 megawatt-peak of clean energy.

site_title: ‘Storm has truly passed’: Top Glove swings back into the black with RM50.7 million Q3 profit
summary: Top Glove Corporation, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a net profit of RM50.7 million (S$14.5 million) for the third quarter ended May 31, reversing a loss of RM130.6 million in the same period last year. The company's revenue increased 20% to RM636.9 million, driven by stronger glove demand and cost optimization measures. Top Glove aims to roll out more production lines and meet growing glove demand, with a forecast of 30-35% increase in sales volumes in the next quarter. The company's managing director, Lim Cheong Guan, expressed optimism that the "storm has truly passed" and the outlook is bright.

images.alt_text: The group attributes the improved results to its ongoing quality- and cost-optimisation initiatives, coupled with operational enhancements it had previously laid out in its turnaround plan.

An employee handles latex gloves at an automated production line at a Top Glove Corp. factory in Setia Alam, Selangor, Malaysia, on Tuesday, Feb. 18, 2020. The world’s biggest glovemaker got a vote of confidence from investors in the credit market, as the coronavirus fuels demand for the Malaysian company’s rubber products. The World Health Organization is taking an unprecedented step of negotiating directly with suppliers to improve access to gloves, face masks and other forms of protective equipment. Photographer: Samsul Said/Bloomberg

site_title: Nvidia’s 591,078% rally to most valuable stock came in waves
summary: Nvidia has become the world's most valuable company, surpassing Microsoft's market capitalization of US$3.34 trillion. The company's 591,078% rally since its IPO in 1999 was fueled by its early success in graphics chips for video-game consoles and its recent growth in data-center sales, driven by the surge in demand for AI products. Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang's vision of "accelerated computing" has been instrumental in the company's success, and analysts praise the company's defensible position in the industry, despite concerns about the sustainability of its current rally.

images.alt_text: The California-based company, which is led by Jensen Huang, has seen profits soar due to torrid demand for its powerful GPU chips, which have set the industry’s pace in pushing new advances in AI.
Nvidia urges the justices to take up its appeal, arguing that the 9th Circuit’s ruling would open the door to “abusive and speculative litigation”.
The split, aimed at lowering per-share value to make it more affordable for employees and investors, increases the Nvidia’s outstanding shares without changing the stock’s valuation.
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's wealth has surged more than US$62 billion this year as demand for Nvidia chips used to power artificial intelligence tasks remains insatiable.

site_title: Thai central bank renews case to limit US$14 billion stimulus
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, has renewed its opposition to a proposed US$14 billion stimulus program aimed at boosting consumption, citing the need to focus on vulnerable households rather than the general public. Governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput argues that private consumption is expected to expand 4% this year, making a nationwide stimulus unnecessary. The bank suggests limiting the stimulus to welfare cardholders, who are in greater need.

images.alt_text: The BOT has also spurned repeated calls from the government for rate cuts, arguing instead that structural reforms are what the economy needs to spur growth.
Customers at a store in Bangkok. The government has favoured cutting rates from a decade-high 2.5% to boost consumption and growth.

site_title: STI inches up 0.1% on Wednesday, tracking US rally
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% on Wednesday, following overnight gains in the US, which hit new records with chip company Nvidia becoming the world's most valuable publicly traded company. The STI closed at 3,304, with Jardine Cycle & Carriage being the biggest gainer for the second consecutive day. Markets across the region ended mixed, with Japan's Nikkei up 0.2% and South Korea's Kospi up 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong piled on more than one per cent after a recent run of weakness, while Tokyo, Singapore, Seoul, Manila and Taipei financial markets also rose.
The California-based company, which is led by Jensen Huang, has seen profits soar due to torrid demand for its powerful GPU chips, which have set the industry’s pace in pushing new advances in AI.
All three major indices rose on Wall Street, with the broad-based S&P 500 rising 0.3 per cent to reach a new all-time high of 5,487.03 on Tuesday.
Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 78 to 33.

site_title: Japan visitors top 3 million for third month as yen fuels boom
summary: Japan welcomed over 3 million visitors in May for the third consecutive month, with the weak yen fueling a record tourism boom. Arrivals were up 60% from the same period last year and 9.6% from 2019. Travelers spent a record 1.75 trillion yen (S$15 billion) in the first quarter of 2024. However, concerns over "overtourism" have been raised, with some areas considering charging higher fees to manage overcrowding. The influx of foreign visitors, particularly from India and the UAE, has helped offset the decline in Chinese tourists, which remain 30% lower than pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: As Golden Week gets underway this week, local travellers are opting for Kochi in the south, Atami near Tokyo and other popular spots such as Okinawa and Hokkaido.
The total of 3.08 million represented an increase of 69.5 per cent from March 2023 and a 11.6-per cent gain compared to March 2019 before the pandemic battered global tourism.
The number of foreign visitors for business and leisure was 2.69 million last month, down slightly from 2.73 million in December.

site_title: China issues measures to enhance reforms of tech-focused STAR Market
summary: China's securities regulator has issued eight measures to enhance the reform of the tech-focused STAR Market, aiming to drive innovation and development of "new productive forces". The measures include supporting "hard tech" companies, improving stock and bond financing, and enriching ETF and ETF options products. The regulator will also crack down on market misbehaviors, strengthen regulation of high-frequency trading, and protect small investors. The STAR Market, launched in 2019, has seen a 12% decline in the SSE Star 50 Index this year, compared to a 3% gain in the broader market.

images.alt_text: The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) said it will maintain a “zero-tolerance” stance on illegal activities in the capital market.
Many investors say the risk of buying shares in smaller companies is increasing, while brokerages have forecast a record number of delistings this year.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Wednesday’s open; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.6% higher at 3,319.93, driven by a positive start to the US market where Nvidia became the world's most valuable public company, surpassing Microsoft. The broader market saw 78 gainers outnumbering 33 losers, with banking stocks trading higher. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 also reached new highs, while European shares rose nearly 0.7% on a decline in government bond yields.

images.alt_text: XXX

site_title: Singaporean investors welcome to explore opportunities in Cambodia’s burgeoning market: Hun Manet
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet welcomed Singaporean investors to explore opportunities in Cambodia, citing areas of fintech, innovation, and green energy for growth. The two nations can drive innovation and build robust economic ties, creating a more prosperous future. A two-day business forum was held in Singapore during Hun Manet's official visit, providing a platform for discussion and potential collaboration.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Hun Manet, commander of the Royal Cambodian Army and eldest son of Prime Minister Hun Sen, shows his finger after he casts his vote at a polling station in Phnom Penh on July 23, 2023. (Photo by -STR / AFP)
Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong (left) invited Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet on an official visit to Singapore.

site_title: China to regulate lithium-ion battery industry amid fast expansion
summary: China's Ministry of Industry and Information Technology has issued guidelines to regulate the rapidly expanding lithium-ion battery industry, aiming to promote high-quality development and reduce environmental impact. The guidelines require firms to scale back manufacturing projects, enhance technology innovation, and trim output costs. Projects built on farmland and ecological zones will be shut down or reined in. The new regulations, effective Thursday, follow a proposal in May and aim to address the sector's rapid expansion, which has led to plummeting prices and eroding company profits in the world's largest market for lithium-ion batteries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Lithium ion batteries are seen on a production line inside a factory in Dongguan, Guangdong province, China October 16, 2018. Picture taken October 16, 2018. REUTERS/Joyce Zhou/File Photo

site_title: Trafigura proposes employee share clawbacks for confidentiality breaches: sources
summary: Trafigura, a Swiss-based commodity trader owned by its employees, has proposed share clawbacks for current and former employees who breach confidentiality or the company's code of conduct. This move is part of the company's efforts to enforce its values and maintain its unique ownership structure. The proposal, made in a letter sent to employees, is typically used by financial firms to recover money paid to employees in cases of misconduct or poor performance.

images.alt_text: The agreements with employees illegally impeded them from voluntarily communication with the CFTC’s enforcement staff during their investigation.
Commodity trader Trafigura dominates the South-east Asian ranking of the Fortune 500 list with sales of US$244 billion.

site_title: Rare bulls in China property market stick to their bets
summary: China's central government has instructed local governments to buy unsold apartments through state-owned firms, providing up to 500 billion yuan (S$93 billion) for purchases. This move has boosted expectations that more funds could be made available to stabilize the ailing property sector. Despite a faltering stock market and doubts over the effectiveness of previous support packages, bullish analysts, including Citi and Bank of America, remain optimistic, citing the central government's prominent role in coordinating measures.

images.alt_text: epa10854217 A general view of residential buildings in Beijing, China, 11 September 2023. Dalian and Shenyang in northeastern China, announced they will no longer restrict the amount of residential properties one can buy in most parts of the city, while offering subsidies for buyers and tax relief for sellers. These announcements come on the heels of a series of nationwide support measures for the property sector, including lower mortgage rates for first-time homebuyers.  EPA-EFE/WU HAO
Funding for property developers has stayed weak since China's government drew up a “white list” of property firms that are eligible for loans late last year.

The PBOC said SOEs’ purchases of unsold homes should adhere to “voluntary participation, demand-based ordering and reasonable pricing” to ensure business sustainability, while any new local hidden debt should be strictly prohibited.
Real estate stocks have retreated amid scepticism over a broad support package unveiled by the central government on May 17.
Chinese banks are expected to extend cheaper loans to SOEs via the facility, backed by the central bank.

site_title: China may overhaul consumer taxes as plenum looms, Goldman says
summary: China is considering overhauling its consumer taxes as the ruling Communist Party prepares for its key meeting, known as the Third Plenum, which could set the course for economic policy. Goldman Sachs suggests reforms could include broadening the tax base, increasing rates, and sharing revenue with local governments. The goal is to create new, sustainable sources of income for local governments as their finances are squeezed by a years-long housing slump. Potential changes also include simplifying the value-added tax system and higher tax rates on luxury goods and energy.

images.alt_text: FILE -- An electric vehicle factory in Ningbo, China, April 9, 2024. Emerging market and developing economies are growing at a rate of 4 percent, led by China and Indonesia. (Gilles Sabrie/The New York Times)
A sense of resigned gloom also pervaded a slim-pickings job fair in Shanghai.
The lending slowdown is spurring debate over various alarming scenarios for China’s economy.

China’s economy has struggled to motor on despite the end of stringent Covid-19 curbs in late 2022, mainly due to the ripple effects of a prolonged property sector crisis on investor, business and consumer confidence.

site_title: Japan lays groundwork to sell shorter debt as Bank of Japan eyes rate hike
summary: Japan's government is preparing to sell shorter-term debt to attract investors, as the Bank of Japan (BOJ) exits its radical stimulus program and eyes potential interest rate hikes. The BOJ has started tapering its bond buying, reducing its holdings of government bonds. A finance ministry panel suggests issuing shorter-duration debt and introducing floating-rate notes to reduce interest-rate risk and attract new investors, aiming to maintain a stable market for Japan's huge public debt.

images.alt_text: This photo taken on March 15, 2024 shows shoppers walking past a row of banners advertising the upcoming 2025 Expo, due to open in April 2025, along a shopping street in downtown Osaka. (Photo by Richard A. Brooks / AFP)

Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the BOJ was not yet fully convinced that inflation will sustainably hit its 2 per cent target, stressing the need to spend “a bit more time” to scrutinise various data before raising interest rates again.

The Bank of Japan kept interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting but said it would “reduce its purchase amount of JGBs (Japanese Government Bonds) thereafter to ensure that long-term interest rates would be formed more freely”.

Markets are focusing on how Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda, at his post-meeting briefing, reconciles recent weak signs in the economy with the bank‘s current projection that Japan will make steady progress towards achieving its price target.

site_title: Taiwan’s Cathay United Bank follows client money to Singapore
summary: Cathay Financial Holding, Taiwan's largest financial firm by assets, is expanding its presence in Singapore with plans to hire around 200 staff by 2025, up from 100 two years ago. The move follows shifting regional money flows as US-China tensions prompt companies to diversify investments and manufacturing in South-east Asia. Cathay United Bank, a subsidiary of Cathay Financial Holding, is adding staff in information technology, risk management, and capital solutions to serve corporate clients expanding in the region.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks, with 220,000 outlets nationwide, have long been distributors for financial products from insurance policies to mutual funds to earn fees.

site_title: Hot stocks: Glove makers rally after Top Glove reports turnaround in Q3
summary: Top Glove and Riverstone glove makers rose in afternoon trading after the companies reported profit turnarounds for the third quarter. Top Glove gained 10.4% to a two-year high, while Riverstone jumped 4.6% to S$1.01. The companies attributed the turnaround to stronger glove demand from customers replenishing inventories after using up excess stock. Riverstone's Q1 2024 net profit rose 54.5% to RM72.2 million, and Top Glove reported a net profit of RM50.7 million for the three months ended May 31.

images.alt_text: UG Healthcare said that its new joint venture with UG Nitrex will expand the group's product portfolio.
Reza Namazie eyes West Africa as the next market for growth.
Jarinya Jirojkul, chief executive of Sri Trang Gloves. The manufacturer sees higher sales volume on the back of recovering global demand for gloves.
Mr Wong Teek Son, founder and CEO Riverstone Resources.

site_title: UK inflation returns to target for first time since 2021
summary: The UK's inflation rate returned to its 2% target in May for the first time in nearly three years, according to official figures. This marks a sharp decline from the 41-year high of 11.1% in October 2022, driven by a cut in regulated household energy bills. Despite this, the Bank of England has stated that a return to target is not enough to prompt an interest rate cut, and economists expect a rate cut in August. The UK economy continues to face challenges, with consumer prices up 20% over the past three years.

images.alt_text: The average British house price hit a record high in May and first-time homebuyers are facing the toughest financial environment in 70 years.

FILE PHOTO: A tourist shelters from the rain under an Union Jack umbrella near the Bank of England in the City of London financial district in London, Britain, February 13, 2024. REUTERS/Isabel Infantes/File Photo
Billings for temporary staff has dropped by the least since January.
Housing has become one of the flashpoints in the general election.

site_title: Chinese automakers seek retaliatory tariffs on EU cars, state media reports
summary: Chinese automakers are urging Beijing to impose tariffs on European petrol-powered cars in retaliation for the EU's decision to place curbs on Chinese electric vehicle exports. The proposed tariffs, reportedly up to 25%, come after the European Commission's June 12 announcement of anti-subsidy duties of up to 38.1% on imported Chinese EVs. This move is seen as a response to EU trade policy aimed at protecting its market from cheap goods, including EVs, and follows US tariffs on Chinese cars. The move could escalate the West's trade war with Beijing.

images.alt_text: China imported US$6 billion worth of pork in 2023, including offal, with the EU accounting for more than half.
Under the EU’s proposal, Chery’s imports will incur tariffs of 21 per cent.
Tesla assembles Model Y sport utility vehicles in Germany, it imports Model 3 sedans into the bloc from the China plant.
Nio said it will continue to serve its users and explore new opportunities within Europe despite protectionism.

site_title: Cleaning dishes with tech
summary: Micro 2000, an IT solutions provider, has transformed dishwashing company GreatSolutions through digitalization, increasing revenue by 30% year-over-year to $11.9 million. The acquisition in 2022 allowed Micro 2000 to expand its operations, gaining a strong base of medical clients and on-premise dishwashing services. The company has applied IT expertise to automate processes, using RFID software to track dishware and streamline operations. With plans for further acquisitions, Micro 2000 expects 30% year-on-year revenue growth over the next two years, driven by dishwashing, new F&B outlets, and corporate solutions.

images.alt_text: Singapore's three local banks observed a rise in sustainable loan financing to SMEs.

site_title: Ferrari’s first electric car to cost at least 500,000 euros: source
summary: Ferrari's first electric car is set to cost at least 500,000 euros, significantly higher than the average sale price of 350,000 euros for a Ferrari in the first quarter of this year. The luxury automaker plans to launch the electric model late next year, confident that ultra-wealthy drivers are ready for it, despite mass-market rivals slashing EV prices amid faltering demand. The high price tag may boost group production by up to a third.

images.alt_text: Danish driver Nicklas Nielsen crosses the finish line to win the Le Mans 24-hours endurance race for Ferrari.

The 12Cilindri features a 12-cylinder engine delivering 819 horsepower, drawing inspiration from Ferrari’s touring cars of the 1960s.
Exor chief executive officer John Elkann says Ferrari and Stellantis were again the largest contributors to Exor’s gross asset value last year – at nearly 60 per cent.

site_title: Russia’s Putin, North Korea’s Kim sign mutual defence pact
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin signed a mutual defense pact with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, marking a significant shift in Russia's post-Soviet policy towards North Korea. The pact, part of a comprehensive strategic partnership, includes a mutual defense clause in case of aggression against either country. Putin linked Russia's deepening ties with North Korea to the West's growing support for Ukraine, and Kim praised Russia for making a strategic move to support North Korea. The agreement could alter the strategic balance in Northeast Asia, with Russia's backing behind North Korea.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin’s trip to North Korea would be his first since July 2000.

Russian President Vladimir Putin said Russian regions outside the capital needed to have more economic opportunities and that plans were being discussed to move the head offices of major corporations and state companies to the regions.

In this pool photograph distributed by the Russian state agency Sputnik, Russia's President Vladimir Putin and China's President Xi Jinping exchange documents during a signing ceremony following their talks in Beijing on May 16, 2024. (Photo by Sergei BOBYLYOV / POOL / AFP) / ** Editor's note : this image is distributed by Russian state owned agency Sputnik **

It's Vladimir Putin’s first trip abroad since his March re-election and the second in just over six months to China, an economic lifeline for Russia after the West hit it with unprecedented sanctions over its military offensive in Ukraine.

site_title: Rising UK homelessness keeps housing crunch in front of voters
summary: The UK's homelessness crisis has worsened, with nearly 90,000 households reported as homeless in England in 2023, the highest in a decade. A surge in mortgage rates and slow new construction have made buying a property unaffordable, pushing voters to make housing a top issue ahead of the election. Labour promises 1.5 million new homes and an "Ending Homelessness Unit," while the Conservatives pledge 1.6 million new homes. The shortage of social housing has left many struggling with the cost-of-living crisis, with the private sector exacerbating the gap.

images.alt_text: The average British house price hit a record high in May and first-time homebuyers are facing the toughest financial environment in 70 years.
Affordability is a hot political issue ahead of the July 4 national election, with house prices up by around a fifth since the last election in December 2019.

site_title: There is no shame in being Chinese
summary: US-China relations are strained, prompting some Chinese firms to downplay their connections to China. Companies like Shein Group, founded in China, claim to be "American companies" despite having suppliers in China. This is seen as an attempt to avoid Beijing's wrath and attract US investors. However, erasing one's Chinese features is impossible, and doing so can limit growth opportunities. The article argues that Chinese companies should celebrate their Chinese heritage and access to efficient supply chains, rather than trying to distance themselves from their origins.

images.alt_text: To deliver what could be one of the UK’s biggest-ever IPOs, Shein will need to convince regulators, politicians and investors that it meets their standards for inclusion.

site_title: Thai PM proposes 3.75 trillion baht budget to parliament to revive economy
summary: Thai Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin proposed a 3.753 trillion baht (S$138 billion) budget for the 2025 fiscal year to boost the country's sluggish economy. The budget aims to help the economy grow at its full potential, with expected growth of 2.5-3.5% and inflation of 0.7-1.7% in 2025. The proposal comes as Thavisin faces a Constitutional Court case that could potentially lead to his dismissal, adding to the economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Central would continue to run the stores and would now seek to renegotiate the rent agreements for the retail outlets, according to KaDeWe Group.
AstraZeneca (Thailand) planned to invest 6.2 billion baht in the country in a three-year period starting in 2024.

(Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)

The case against Thaksin Shinawatra, twice elected premier and ousted in a 2006 military coup, is one of four before the courts that could unleash fresh political instability in the coup-prone kingdom.

site_title: In South China Sea dispute, Philippines’ bolder hand tests Beijing
summary: The Philippines has adopted a bolder stance against China in the South China Sea dispute, releasing previously undisclosed photos of a laser allegedly pointed at a Philippine ship and launching a transparency policy to highlight China's actions. The move has raised tensions, with China accusing the Philippines of provoking China and Manila seeking to build international support for its claims. Despite increased incidents, including Chinese water cannons and a collision, the Philippines has managed to constrain Beijing's ability to escalate matters at sea, but risks provoking China into a harder approach, such as non-tariff barriers and tourism restrictions.

images.alt_text: China's Premier Li Qiang met Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim in the administrative capital of Putrajaya for a visit to mark 50 years of diplomatic ties between the two countries.
Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (right) shakes hands with China's Premier Li Qiang during a signing ceremony at Parliament House in Canberra on Jun 17.
Chinese and Philippine vessels have had a series of confrontations around the Second Thomas Shoal.
US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin says Indo-Pacific will continue to be America’s “priority theater of operations”.
Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (second from left) meeting Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the Istana on May 31. Marcos Jr is in Singapore till Saturday,

During the meeting with his Chinese counterpart, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin expressed concern about Chinese military activity near Taiwan, including after the island’s presidential election and the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te this month.

site_title: China eyes plan to connect South-east Asian rail links
summary: China is considering a plan to connect Malaysia's $10-billion East Coast Rail Link to China-backed railway projects in Laos and Thailand, potentially expanding Beijing's Belt and Road initiative across South-east Asia. Chinese Premier Li Qiang announced the proposal during a visit to Malaysia, marking 50 years of diplomatic ties, and aimed to promote regional connectivity and deepen the Asean community. The plan would link the proposed Pan-Asia Railway from Kunming to Singapore, enhancing international trade corridors.

images.alt_text: The Brics group of nations originally included Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, which gave it the acronym.
Diesel used to be the cheapest fuel in Malaysia and is widely used for diesel-powered commercial vehicles.
To help buttress recovery, Sri Lanka entered negotiations with multiple countries on free trade deals.
Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong (left) and Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim shake hands after holding a joint press conference in Malaysia on Jun 12, 2024.

site_title: Japan’s exports grow most since 2022 on boost from weak yen
summary: Japan's exports grew 13.5% in May, the largest since November 2022, driven by a weak yen that boosted their value. This marks the sixth consecutive month of gains, surpassing economists' estimates of a 12.7% increase. Car exports rose 13.6% as automakers resumed production after a safety certification scandal, while imports increased 9.5% and the trade deficit widened to 1.2 trillion yen. The strong yen also provided a tailwind for exporters, despite concerns about cost-push inflation.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the BOJ was not yet fully convinced that inflation will sustainably hit its 2 per cent target, stressing the need to spend “a bit more time” to scrutinise various data before raising interest rates again.

The Bank of Japan kept interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting but said it would “reduce its purchase amount of JGBs (Japanese Government Bonds) thereafter to ensure that long-term interest rates would be formed more freely”.

Markets are focusing on how Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda, at his post-meeting briefing, reconciles recent weak signs in the economy with the bank‘s current projection that Japan will make steady progress towards achieving its price target.

The data complicates the Bank of Japan’s decision on how soon to raise interest rates, as price rises driven by cost pressures could cool consumption and dampen the chances of achieving the kind of demand-driven inflation it wants to see before further phasing out stimulus, analysts say.

site_title: MGM weighs Macau resort expansion in bid to go beyond casinos
summary: MGM China Holdings is considering expanding its Macau resort, adding hotel rooms and wellness services, as part of efforts to attract mass-market tourists beyond traditional high rollers. The project, at an early stage, may include hundreds of new hotel rooms and spas. This move aims to bolster non-gaming offerings and capitalize on China's crackdown on junkets, which has shifted the market towards the mass market segment.

images.alt_text: The MGM Cotai casino resort, developed by MGM China Holdings Ltd., in Macau. Photographer: Eduardo Leal/Bloomberg

site_title: Asia: Most markets advance after latest Wall Street record
summary: Asia's stock markets advanced on Wednesday, following a record day on Wall Street, driven by data boosting US interest rate cut hopes. US retail sales figures fell short of expectations, suggesting the US economy is slowing, giving the Federal Reserve room to ease monetary policy. Tech firms, including Nvidia, which became the world's most valuable publicly traded company, were among the big winners. However, cautious comments from Federal Reserve officials tempered expectations, with only one expected interest rate cut before January.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 78 to 33.
The Stoxx 600 closed nearly 0.7 per cent higher on Tuesday, with utilities leading sectoral gains, up 1.5 per cent.
All three major indices rose on Wall Street, with the broad-based S&P 500 rising 0.3 per cent to reach a new all-time high of 5,487.03 on Tuesday.

site_title: Jaguar Land Rover to revive Freelander as a made-in-China EV
summary: Jaguar Land Rover is reviving the Freelander as an electric vehicle (EV) made in China. The company, in partnership with Chery Automobile, will produce the EV at its Changshu facility, initially targeting the Chinese market before exporting globally. This move aims to gain share in the world's largest auto market, where local brands are popular, and help Tata Motors' electric business reach profitability. The Freelander EV will be manufactured using Chery's components and facilities, marking a decade since the original Freelander's production ceased.

site_title: Gold holds ground as traders gauge Fed rate-cut bets
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $2,327.76 per ounce, as traders awaited potential Federal Reserve rate cuts amid softer-than-expected US retail sales data. The data reinforced bets of imminent rate cuts, with traders pricing in a 67% chance of a Fed rate cut in September. Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, supporting gold prices. Economists expect the Fed to ease monetary policy by the end of the year, with central banks also planning to add to their gold reserves due to macroeconomic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Lower rates also make non-yielding gold more attractive.

site_title: After success in China, homegrown retailer Motherswork takes on South-east Asia
summary: Motherswork, a Singapore-based retailer of premium mother and baby products, plans to expand into South-east Asia, with flagship stores in Vietnam, Thailand, and Indonesia. The company, which has been active in Singapore and China, aims to take the region in the next three years. After opening its first store in Ho Chi Minh City in April 2024, Motherswork plans to open a second store in Hanoi in 2025. The company's strategy is to focus on experiential retail, with fewer stores and more emphasis on community engagement and online services, rather than competing with local players on sheer numbers.

site_title: Netflix uses ‘Squid Game’ playbook for untapped South-east Asia market
summary: Netflix is ramping up local production in South-east Asia to boost its subscriber base in the region, aiming to reach more viewers beyond domestic markets. The company plans to release 10 original titles in Thailand, the most of any country in the region, and increase production budgets in Indonesia. This move contrasts with major rivals, such as Walt Disney and Amazon.com's Prime Video, which are pulling back amid shareholder pressure to prioritize profitability. Netflix aims to make localized content a key part of its strategy, leveraging the region's large, young demographic.

images.alt_text: Netflix has been emphasising engagement time as a key metric, telling investors it is the “best proxy for customer satisfaction”.
Much of the rebound – up 34 per cent year to date – reflects Netflix’s success in reassuring investors about its ability to keep growing, even in mature markets.
Expect high heels, glamorous styling and tours of multimillion-dollar homes..

site_title: US: Stocks hit fresh record as Nvidia becomes most valuable public company
summary: US stocks hit a new record, with the S&P 500 rising 0.3% to 5,487.03, as Nvidia became the world's most valuable publicly traded company with a market capitalization of around $3.3 trillion. The chip company surged 3.5% after edging ahead of Microsoft and Apple. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.2%, and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index finished up less than 0.1%. Other chip companies, including Qualcomm and Micron, also saw gains.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 3, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Bayer looks to AI to combat herbicide resistance faster
summary: Bayer is leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to combat herbicide resistance in crops. The company's Icafolin product, set to launch in Brazil in 2028, will be its first new mode of action herbicide in nearly 30 years. AI helps Bayer match the protein structure of weeds with target molecules, speeding up the discovery process and increasing the number of new modes of action compared to previous years. This technology could lead to more effective and targeted herbicides, ultimately benefiting farmers and the environment.

images.alt_text: Bayer swung to a 2.9-billion-euro loss (S$4.2 billion) in 2023 after booking a net profit of 4.15 billion euros a year earlier.

site_title: Ozempic frenzy lures rich Indians to brave the grey market
summary: India's obesity crisis is driving the country's rich to the grey market for weight-loss drugs, despite limited availability of approved treatments. The grey market offers counterfeit and alternative medications, including imported bulk packs, at significantly lower prices. Novo Nordisk's Rybelsus pill, approved in India, is seen as less effective than blockbuster injectibles like Ozempic and Wegovy. The grey market is expected to grow as pharmaceutical distributors import injectables from Europe, with costs ranging from $1,200 for a monthly supply. Supply shortages and patents set to expire in 2026 are expected to bring generic weight-loss drugs to the market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows Ozempic pens, as they are assembled at the Novo Nordisk facility in Bagsvaerd, on the outskirts of Copenhagen, Denmark, March 8, 2024. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo

site_title: Best Buy trains 30,000 for Microsoft AI laptops launch
summary: Best Buy is training over 30,000 employees to sell and repair Microsoft's Copilot+ PCs, the retailer's exclusive AI Windows laptops, ahead of their June 18 launch. This is the retailer's largest training effort in a decade, with Geek Squad tech support agents set to demonstrate the computers in hundreds of stores. The AI PCs will contain chips made by Qualcomm and come with features such as summarization and a paint function, with Best Buy aiming to reverse declining same-store sales and drive growth in the industry.

images.alt_text: Microsoft in May announced the new AI-powered personal computers, or “AI PCs”, which will use the company’s software under the Copilot Plus brand.
The chip is based on Arm’s ready-made designs, which can significantly speed development because less design work is needed using ready-made, tested chip components.
The Games Showcase comes at a crucial time for Xbox and Microsoft as the gaming industry faces a downturn and publishers grapple with softer sales, layoffs and studio shutdowns.

site_title: HDB launches nearly 7,000 BTO flats in June exercise
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched nearly 7,000 Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in June, with eight projects offering a total of 6,938 flats in various locations. The flats are available in Jurong East, Kallang/Whampoa, Queenstown, Tampines, Woodlands, and Yishun, with prices ranging from $120,000 to $582,000. Analysts expect higher demand ahead of the new BTO classification system, which will be introduced in October, with some buyers waiting for the October launch for more attractive locations and subsidies.

images.alt_text: A 791-unit project in Woodlands, Marsiling Peak I, has a waiting time of two years and 11 months.

site_title: RBNZ chief economist Conway says progress being made on bringing inflation back to target
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank chief economist Paul Conway stated that progress is being made in bringing inflation back to the target band of 1-3% by the end of 2024. The RBNZ has aggressively raised the official cash rate by 525 basis points since October 2021 to 5.50%. Conway expects spare capacity in the economy to reduce inflation pressure, but notes that the process may occur more quickly or slowly than projected. The central bank faces remaining challenges in bringing inflation sustainably back to target.

images.alt_text: Since the RBA’s last meeting, data has shown the Australian economy remains weak.
The RBNZ, which forecasts 0.2 per cent growth for the quarter, has kept monetary policy restrictive to curb demand and get inflation back under control.
Australia's Prime Minister Anthony Albanese (right) shakes hands with China's Premier Li Qiang during a signing ceremony at Parliament House in Canberra on Jun 17.
Li Qiang, China's premier. Photographer: Liesa Johannssen-Koppitz

site_title: Japan’s regional banks are pressured to cut cross-shareholdings
summary: Japan's regional banks face pressure to cut cross-shareholdings, also known as policy shares, at their annual general meetings. Institutional Shareholder Services recommends denying Kyoto Financial Group president Nobuhiro Doi a new term due to the bank's significant holdings in major customers, including Nintendo and Nidec. Other regional banks, such as Shiga Bank and Bank of Nagoya, are taking steps to reduce their policy shareholdings, while Hachijuni Bank opposes the idea. The practice of policy shares has been criticized for shielding management and tying up capital that could be better used elsewhere.

site_title: Luxury sneaker maker Golden Goose postpones planned IPO
summary: Luxury sneaker maker Golden Goose has postponed its planned initial public offering (IPO) due to a "significant deterioration in market conditions" amid a selloff in luxury stocks and concerns over European politics. The company had planned to price its IPO at 9.75 euros a share, but will now delay the listing. This decision reflects the ongoing challenges for private equity firms to exit companies and the impact of luxury sector woes, including doubts over earnings and Chinese demand.

images.alt_text: Golden Goose is targeting net sales of about 1 billion euros by 2029, up from 587 million euros last year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, SIA, Seatrium, Mooreast, Sabana Reit
summary: Singtel's Nxera partners Malaysian telco TM to develop data centers, with a focus on one in Johor. Singapore Airlines reported a 10.2% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in May 2024. Seatrium's unit will acquire a 1.1 million square foot facility to quadruple Mooreast's production capacity. Sabana Reit priced S$100 million of sustainability-linked bonds at 4.15%.

site_title: China needs a green Marshall Plan for the Global South
summary: China is shifting its foreign direct investment (FDI) from developed democracies to emerging economies, with over 343 billion yuan (S$64 billion) invested in the first four months of 2024. This trend could help China build alliances and counterbalance its growing wealth and environmental concerns. By investing in renewable power projects and electric vehicles in developing countries, China can provide energy and capital to help these nations grow and reduce its own carbon footprint. This approach could be seen as a "green Marshall Plan," emulating the US post-war aid package that helped rebuild Europe.

images.alt_text: FILE -- An electric vehicle factory in Ningbo, China, April 9, 2024. Emerging market and developing economies are growing at a rate of 4 percent, led by China and Indonesia. (Gilles Sabrie/The New York Times)

site_title: Sabana Reit prices S$100 million in sustainability-linked bonds due 2029 at 4.15%
summary: Sabana Reit priced S$100 million in sustainability-linked bonds due 2029 at 4.15%. The bonds will be issued on June 25, 2024, with a coupon rate of 4.15% per annum. The Reit manager aims to reduce indirect emissions by 30% by 2028 through partnerships with Keppel Infrastructure. The issuance has drawn criticism from activist investor Quarz Capital, who claims it could impede internalisation and entrench the current Reit manager. The Reit manager defends the issuance, stating it has been planned since 2022 and does not restrict internalisation.

images.alt_text: Tenant of 30 & 32 Tuas Avenue 8, GDMC, accounted for about 2.4 per cent of Sabana Reit's total gross rental income for the financial year ended 31 Dec, 2023.
'I'm not the kingmaker,' says Sabana Reit director whom Quarz wants voted out
Quarz Capital's interest fully aligned with independent unitholders of Sabana Reit: CIO
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee intends to hold an EGM at a date to be determined.
Quarz Capital alleged that Sabana Industrial Reit's upcoming bond issuance may put the trust in "financial jeopardy".

site_title: Mouse shakers, power naps: Corporate America fights ‘keyboard fraud’
summary: US banking giant Wells Fargo fired over a dozen employees for "simulating keyboard activity" as corporate America battles "keyboard fraud" in the post-pandemic era of hybrid work. Employers are using sophisticated monitoring software to track productivity, prompting workers to use tools like mouse movers to fake activity. The trend highlights a culture of faking work, with some employees using devices to appear active while taking power naps or doing laundry. This "tattleware" or "bossware" has become a growing concern in the age of remote work.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit charges Elon Musk and SpaceX with sexual harassment, discrimination, retaliation, and wrongful termination.
The Perito Morena glacier in Patagonia, Afgentina is one of the attractions on an Oceania cruise.

site_title: Black hole observed 'awakening' for the first time
summary: Astronomers have observed a supermassive black hole "awakening" for the first time, causing the galaxy's centre to shine brighter than ever before. The galaxy, 300 million light years from Earth, was previously quiet but suddenly began radiating a variety of rays in late 2019. The black hole, with a mass 1.5 million times that of the Sun, is believed to be the first to be observed in real-time, with the team analyzing data from multiple telescopes to determine if the activity is temporary or long-term.

images.alt_text: The M87 supermassive black hole as it was originally imaged by the EHT in 2019 (L) and the newly generated image using the Primo algorithm technology (R).

site_title: Tracking Ukraine’s reconstruction funds
summary: Ukraine's post-war reconstruction is expected to be the most significant and expensive undertaking in Europe since the Marshall Plan, requiring nearly $500 billion over the next decade. Digital tools can streamline the process, increase transparency, and provide accountability. The Ukrainian government has established the Digital Restoration Ecosystem for Accountable Management (Dream) and a coalition of NGOs has developed the Big Recovery Portal to collect and publish open data on recovery projects. However, lessons from the rebuilding of Aceh after the 2004 tsunami suggest that data collection and analysis remain labor-intensive, excessive planning can delay efforts, and tracking financial commitments and disbursements is crucial for efficient aid delivery.

images.alt_text: Buildings damaged by shelling in Orikhiv, Ukraine. The country has released a  recovery plan for not only rebuilding but also transforming itself.

Ukrainian soldiers undergoing training in the Donetsk region. The European Union and its allies can contribute to the resilience of the Eastern European country through military assistance, security guarantees and wider economic support such as access to the EU’s single market.

site_title: Nintendo surprises fans by announcing new ‘Zelda’ game
summary: Nintendo has announced a new 'Zelda' game, The Legend of Zelda Echoes of Wisdom, set for release on the Switch console on September 26. The game will feature Princess Zelda as the protagonist, a first for an official entry in the series. Producer Eiji Aonuma revealed that Link has vanished, and it's up to Princess Zelda to step into his role. The game will have cartoon-style graphics similar to Link's Awakening and follows the franchise's tradition of open-world gameplay.

images.alt_text: The move signals greater interest from Nintendo to bring in content to bolster the offerings from its in-house creative studios.
Nintendo expects to sell 13.5 million Switch units in the current financial year as the company squeezes out sales of the aging device.
Movie still: The Super Mario Bros Movie
Nintendo is looking to clamp down on the operations of a company called Tropic Haze, registered in the US state of Rhode Island, which owns and runs Yuzu, a popular video game emulator.

site_title: Nvidia becomes world’s most valuable company on stock market
summary: Nvidia surpassed Microsoft and Apple to become the world's most valuable publicly traded company, with a market capitalization of approximately $3.3 trillion. The California-based company's profits soared due to strong demand for its powerful GPU chips, driving its revenue to nearly $26 billion in the latest fiscal quarter. Analysts predict Nvidia's market value could reach $4 trillion in the next year, fueled by its dominance in the AI industry.

site_title: Citi CFO Mark Mason says investment banking fees likely up 50%
summary: Citigroup expects banking fees to surge 50% in the second quarter, driven by improved prospects for merger advice and debt and equity underwriting. Revenue from the markets business is expected to be flat to down slightly, while net interest income excluding the markets business will be modestly down. The forecast follows a strong first quarter and a 18% share price increase this year. Citigroup is pitching a turnaround story, focusing on its banking franchise and wealth-management arm, and plans to list its Banamex subsidiary in Mexico in 2025.

images.alt_text: Citi is automating processes and improving data reporting to meet regulators’ orders.
Citigroup’s network, closely entwined with its leading foreign exchange teams, grew out of a decades-long campaign to piece together a global banking franchise.
Citigroup will now allow colleagues two weeks of paid leave annually to care for an immediate family member who’s seriously ill and incapable of self-care.

site_title: AI goes mainstream as ‘AI PCs’ hit the market
summary: Microsoft has launched AI-powered personal computers, or "AI PCs," which use the company's software under the Copilot Plus brand. The new devices aim to provide users with AI capabilities on their devices without relying on the cloud, reducing energy consumption and improving the AI experience. This move follows the trend of wider AI adoption, with tech companies pushing to make AI programs more accessible and user-friendly.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies can no longer buy the most advanced AI chips from Nvidia, but Huawei is developing its own AI accelerators, called Ascend.
Taiwan’s water supply mainly comes from reservoirs fed by rainfall, but “climate change and extreme hydrological events have disrupted these patterns,” CTCI said.
Snap’s advancements will now allow AR developers to create more realistic lenses.
