Shipping, responsible for moving about 90 per cent of global trade, contributes nearly 3 per cent to the world’s carbon dioxide emissions.
The tool uses deep learning algorithms to identify and foresee market patterns.
While the US remains the leader in the AI race, industry watchers agree that Southeast Asia can carve out its niche with context-specific innovations and strategic initiatives.

site_title: Justin Timberlake arrested, charged with drunk driving outside New York City
summary: Justin Timberlake, 43, was arrested on June 18, 2024, for driving while intoxicated in Sag Harbour, New York, outside of New York City. He was pulled over after failing to stop at a stop sign and was found to have bloodshot eyes and performed poorly on sobriety tests. Timberlake claimed he had only had one martini and was following his friends home. He was released on his own recognizance and is set to appear in court virtually on July 26.

images.alt_text: Celine Dion at the screening of I Am: Celine Dion in New York City on Jun 17. She calls her decision to speak out about her condition both “the greatest gift and the greatest responsibility”.
Jonathan Groff lands his first Tony for his lead role in "Merrily We Roll Along".
Dry Boney is a savoury tomato cocktail served in an elegantly tall glass, reflecting Tamba’s own figure.
The last Bond outing, 2021’s "No Time To Die", was the final installment to star Daniel Craig, with no replacement yet announced, and Amazon has since bought 007 studio MGM.

site_title: Beyond oil spills, Singapore will have to study risks of ammonia spills at sea
summary: Singapore, a major maritime hub, is preparing to address the risks of ammonia spills at sea, a growing concern as the shipping industry transitions to cleaner alternative fuels. A 2022 study found that ammonia spills have a smaller dispersion distance and lower persistence compared to oil leaks, but can still harm sensitive ecosystems, including estuaries and wetlands. The city-state, which is set to host a project supplying low-carbon ammonia, must study the ecological impact of ammonia spills and develop new technologies to contain the fallout.

site_title: JTC commits S$4 million to support Jurong Innovation District tenants’ carbon-saving solutions
summary: JTC has committed S$4 million to support Jurong Innovation District (JID) tenants in reducing their Scope 3 emissions through a crowd-sourced innovation call. The initiative aims to lower energy and water consumption, reduce waste output, and decrease the district's carbon footprint. Tenants and lessees will co-develop and implement solutions at the Decarbonisation Living Lab @ JID. A multi-agency panel will evaluate proposals, with plans to replicate the model in other estates if successful. The project aims to reduce JTC's Scope 3 emissions, which account for the majority of its total carbon emissions.

site_title: Boeing CEO recognises ‘gravity’ of safety crisis but sees ‘progress’
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun acknowledged the company's imperfect safety culture during a US congressional hearing, but insisted progress is being made. Calhoun apologized to family members of victims from two 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019 and committed to improving safety. A previous hearing featured a Boeing engineer who testified that he was punished for raising safety questions about the 787 Dreamliner and 777. Calhoun's testimony marked a step towards addressing concerns about Boeing's safety culture.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Boeing logo is seen on the side of a Boeing 737 MAX at the Farnborough International Airshow, in Farnborough, Britain, July 20, 2022.  REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/File Photo
File photo of Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun. Since the Jan 5 mid-air blowout of a door plug on a 737 MAX 9 jet, scrutiny of the planemaker by regulators and airlines has intensified.

REUTERS/Alyssa Pointer/File Photo
Boeing investigates quality problem on undelivered 787s, sources say
Boeing has been under a microscope since a Jan 5 incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines was forced to make an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.

site_title: Commercial properties are fast becoming stranded across Europe
summary: Commercial properties across Europe are facing stranded assets due to new energy-efficiency requirements. A study by Deepki found that over 50% of European commercial real estate portfolio managers acknowledge that 30% of their assets are stranded, losing value due to poor energy performance. Banks in the EU are setting stricter conditions for commercial real estate financing, with some targeting cuts of up to 41% in emissions intensity by 2030, and increasing interest rates for non-compliant clients. This development is exacerbating the commercial market's struggles with high interest rates and volatile occupancy rates.

images.alt_text: Demand for office space remains weak, and interest rates and other costs are higher than they have been in many years.
Rendering of The Dubai Mall.

While the EU’s rollout of the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive is likely to play out over several years, it’s already clear that buildings that fall behind risk turning into stranded assets that can no longer be sold or rented.

site_title: Biden offers citizenship path to spouses of Americans in sweeping election-year move
summary: US President Joe Biden announced a citizenship path to spouses of Americans in the US illegally, aiming to benefit an estimated 500,000 spouses who have lived in the country for at least 10 years. The move contrasts with Republican rival Donald Trump's plan for mass deportations and will allow spouses and their children to apply for permanent residence without traveling abroad. The program, set to roll out in coming months, will also grant deportation relief and work permits to 528,000 people brought to the US as children through the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program.

images.alt_text: Among the Chinese goods targeted by the new US levies are EVs, batteries and semiconductors – the lifeblood of a greener, more AI filled digital future.

Chinese companies can no longer buy the most advanced AI chips from Nvidia, but Huawei is developing its own AI accelerators, called Ascend.
Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump speaks during a campaign event, Racine, Wisconsin, June 18, 2024.

site_title: US budget office sees larger 2024 deficit due to Ukraine aid, student debt
summary: The Congressional Budget Office (CBO) has revised its forecast, expecting the US federal budget deficit to reach $1.9 trillion in 2024 and $2.0 trillion in 2025, a 27% increase from previous projections. The increase is mainly due to a $145 billion rise in projected outlays related to student loans and $60 billion in security aid for Ukraine, Israel, and Indo-Pacific countries. The net interest payments on government debt are projected to rise to 3.1% in 2024 and 3.4% in 2025, the highest interest cost in relation to GDP since 1940.

images.alt_text: Chinese companies can no longer buy the most advanced AI chips from Nvidia, but Huawei is developing its own AI accelerators, called Ascend.

Luxury properties in the Kensington and Chelsea district of London, UK, on Monday, Aug. 21, 2023. Britain's intensifying mortgage crunch is now forcing London’s wealthiest home sellers to agree to discounts or risk deals falling through. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Europe: Shares advance as French political concerns subside
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by gains in the utilities sector. Government bond yields decreased as investor concerns over French political instability eased, while a weak US consumer spending report boosted fixed-income investments. The US S&P 500 also advanced, and European shares are expected to be influenced by data and central bank policy decisions.

images.alt_text: All three major indices rose on Wall Street, with the broad-based S&P 500 rising 0.3 per cent to reach a new all-time high of 5,487.03 on Tuesday.

site_title: Oil settles over 1% higher on mounting tension in Europe, Middle East
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Tuesday due to escalating geopolitical tensions in Europe and the Middle East, with Brent crude futures settling at US$85.33 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures ending at US$81.57 per barrel.

images.alt_text: Oil sheen on the surface of the water between HarbourFront Centre and Sentosa on June 17.
Berkshire disclosed in a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Monday (Jun 17) that it paid about US$176 million in three separate purchases of Occidental shares since Thursday.
US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained by US$1.88, or 2.4 per cent, to settle at US$80.33 a barrel on Monday, the highest since the end of April.

site_title: Trump Media sinks as SEC declaration may dilute existing holders
summary: Trump Media, the parent company of Truth Social, fell 15% to $26 in late trading after the SEC declared a regulatory filing effective, potentially diluting long-time investors. The filing lets investors swap warrants for shares, which could add up to $247 million to the company's balance sheet but also dilute existing shareholders. The stock has slid 36% this month, and the warrants fell 32% to $14. The company's CEO, Devin Nunes, expects to pursue TV streaming and mergers and acquisitions with the new funding.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump owned 64.9 per cent of Trump Media & Technology Group as of Apr 26, which is worth US$5.7 billion.

site_title: JPMorgan’s latest fintech fight highlights the pain of sellers’ remorse
summary: JPMorgan Chase and Viva Wallet, a Greek payments business, are embroiled in a lawsuit over the valuation of Viva. The dispute began after JPMorgan, which invested in Viva in 2022, accused the company of blocking its growth plans in the US to drive down its value. The majority owners, led by Viva's founder Haris Karonis, sued JPMorgan, claiming the bank deliberately blocked their plans to expand into the US. A recent London judgment allowed both sides to claim a win, but the case highlights the challenges of partnering with big banks in the digital arms race.

images.alt_text: JPMorgan agrees to acquire 49% stake in Greek fintech Viva Wallet

site_title: Rich valuations leave little room for disappointment in Indian equities
summary: India's newly formed coalition government under Prime Minister Narendra Modi may cause delays in reforms, hindering growth. Modi's third term in office follows narrower-than-expected election results, a setback for the leader who drove significant reforms and delivered high economic growth. The stock market reacted with volatility, with the Sensex Index plummeting 6% on election day, its worst trading session in four years.

images.alt_text: Indian stocks have been scaling new peaks since the ruling party secured sufficient support from key allies to form a coalition government.
Japan emerges as a compelling opportunity for diversification, boasting a well-diversified stock market and low correlations to other asset classes.

site_title: Fed officials steer cautiously as they await data confirming inflation slowdown
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are cautiously awaiting data confirming a slowdown in inflation, with recent data showing consumer prices did not rise in May. Despite this, officials are still concerned about the strong labor market, with Fed President John Williams stating that the key is for price pressures to ease persistently in services and goods. The Fed is expected to consider policy easing later this year, with financial markets pricing in a potential rate cut in September. Officials, including Williams and Richmond Fed President Thomas Barkin, emphasize that the data will dictate the Fed's next moves, with no clear timeline for rate cuts.

images.alt_text: New York Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams speaks to Economic Club of New York, in New York City, U.S., May 30, 2024.  REUTERS/Andrew Kelly

site_title: US seeks allies’ help in curbing China’s AI chip progress
summary: The US is seeking help from Japan and the Netherlands to restrict China's ability to make high-end memory chips needed for artificial intelligence (AI). US Under Secretary of Commerce Alan Estevez will visit the two countries to ask for fresh restrictions on Chinese semiconductor companies, including ASML Holding and Tokyo Electron, which produce dynamic random access memory dies. Chinese companies, such as Huawei and Yangtze Memory Technologies, are developing high-bandwidth memory (HBM) chips, a crucial component of AI hardware. The US aims to create a global blockade to limit China's access to advanced semiconductors.

images.alt_text: China’s copper waste and scrap imports overall climb 25 per cent to 783,004 tonnes in the first four months of this year, according to Trade Data Monitor.
Among the Chinese goods targeted by the new US levies are EVs, batteries and semiconductors – the lifeblood of a greener, more AI filled digital future.
The US has already imposed numerous restrictions on the sale of advanced semiconductors and chipmaking tools to China.
China’s surplus in manufacturing trade, which is close to record levels, points to a much broader surge in exports.

site_title: Ford plans further job cuts in Europe, German works council says
summary: Ford plans to cut further jobs in Germany, Spain, and the UK, with the number of additional cuts to be determined by the end of June. This is on top of a previous restructuring plan that cut 2,300 jobs in Germany, reducing staff to 13,000. The company has already announced up to 1,600 job cuts in Spain and is shifting to electric vehicle production, which requires less personnel. The restructuring plan aims to support Ford's shift to EV production and is part of its efforts to improve efficiency and competitiveness.

images.alt_text: The 2024 Ford F-150 Lightning electric pickup.
Brands led by BYD sold 13.4 million new vehicles last year, beating the 11.9 million units delivered by American brands such as Ford and Chevrolet
John Lawler (middle), Ford’s CFO since October 2020, would take on the additional role of being the company’s vice-chair.

site_title: Citi emphasises focus on regulatory fixes as it lays out growth targets
summary: Citi is intensifying efforts to address regulatory challenges, including its "living will," to boost future profits. The bank is automating processes and improving data reporting to meet regulators' orders. CEO Jane Fraser cited progress in strengthening risk and controls, while CFO Mark Mason emphasized the importance of addressing consent orders for long-term success. The company's services business, which processes $5 trillion in payments daily, remains a key growth area. Citi's stock rose 2% in early trading after the investor day presentation.

images.alt_text: Citigroup’s network, closely entwined with its leading foreign exchange teams, grew out of a decades-long campaign to piece together a global banking franchise.

Some home offices will have to be listed with regulators as so-called “residential supervisory locations”.
Singapore’s commercial real estate market has defied a global property downturn, with office rents hitting a 15-year high in the first quarter.

site_title: Trump holds rally in Wisconsin city where his promises of new jobs fell short
summary: Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump held a campaign rally in Racine, Wisconsin, where he previously promised a $10 billion investment by Taiwanese technology group Foxconn, but the facility now expects to create only 1,500 jobs instead of 13,000. The largely working-class city serves as a symbol of unmet promises, with vacant fields and empty roadways. Trump attempted to present himself as the best candidate for the US economy despite the failed project.

images.alt_text: Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm says the US could hasten the rate of replenishing the strategic oil stockpile as maintenance is completed by the end of the year.

site_title: Shareholders deserve more metrics against which they can benchmark CEO pay
summary: Singaporean CEOs Wee Ee Cheong of UOB and Piyush Gupta of DBS have been paid significantly, with Wee's total remuneration increasing by 11.9% to S$15.9 million and Gupta's decreasing by 27% to S$11.2 million. While Gupta's bank faced disruptions, Wee's increase is seen as reasonable given UOB's 26% increase in core profit. Singaporean banks compensate their CEOs more than most locally listed companies, and transparency on remuneration is lacking, with only Singtel disclosing the CEO pay ratio in its latest sustainability report.

images.alt_text: The salary of DBS CEO Piyush Gupta was slashed in FY2023 despite the lender reporting a record year of profits due to banking disruptions throughout 2023.
Perhaps executive salaries should be capped at a multiple of the wages of the lowest-paid worker, or to at least disclose this multiple.

site_title: Barclays’ UK corporate bank to cut costs by £100 million, expand lending
summary: Barclays plans to cut £100 million in annual costs from its UK corporate banking business by 2026 through cost-saving measures, including consolidating five online portals into one. The move aims to deepen lending relationships with corporate clients, with only 35% currently borrowing from the bank. CEO Matt Hammerstein said the bank will achieve growth through cross-selling products to clients with £6.5 million to £350 million in turnover. The newly created corporate banking unit will grow income amid cost-cutting.

images.alt_text: Barclays has been seeking to deepen its ties with buyout firms as part of a broader push to boost returns at the company’s investment bank.
Newly created funds will need to comply immediately, while existing ESG funds will be subject to a nine-month window to either prove compliance or abandon the label.
Changes taking effect soon will require brokerages to list some home offices in regulatory records.

site_title: China and Britain face exodus of millionaires, study shows
summary: A report by Henley Private Wealth Migration Report reveals that the UK is on track to lose 9,500 millionaires this year, with over 7% of projected global millionaire migration set to leave the country. This is more than double the number that left in 2023, and lags only China, which is expected to lose 15,200 millionaires. The UK's economic and political uncertainty, particularly ahead of the election, is driving the exodus, with the top destinations being the UAE, US, and Singapore.

images.alt_text: The ruling Conservatives and the opposition Labour party have both pledged to scrap preferential tax treatment for non-domiciled residents – rich foreigners living in the UK.

site_title: Apple turns to third parties for ‘buy now, pay later’ after sunsetting product
summary: Apple is discontinuing its independent "buy now, pay later" service, Apple Pay Later, and instead partnering with third-party providers, such as Affirm, to offer similar loans. Existing users can continue to manage and pay open loans through the Wallet app. The new solution, launching later this year, will allow for flexible payments with Apple Pay-enabled banks and lenders, and will enable Apple to bring flexible payments to more users globally. This move follows a surge in BNPL loans, which drove US$75 billion in online spending in 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A person is silhouetted against a logo sign of the Apple Store in the Grand Central Terminal in the Manhattan borough of New York City, New York, U.S., January 4, 2022.  REUTERS/Carlo Allegri/File Photo

site_title: Taiwan’s CTCI plans water plant as chipmakers clamour for supply
summary: Taiwan's CTCI plans to develop and operate a 508 million euro water-desalination plant, worth S$737 million, amid rising demand from chipmakers due to climate change and extreme hydrological events disrupting traditional water supply patterns from reservoirs. The 15-year operation and maintenance contract was awarded by the Water Resources Agency to a group including Hung Hua Construction and France's Suez. The move aims to support Taiwan's vast semiconductor industry, which drives technologies like artificial intelligence and 5G networks.

images.alt_text: TSMC is the world’s biggest contract chipmaker and the centrality of the island to the semiconductor supply chain is seen as an essential element of its international security.
“We are progressing very well on all fronts. A lot of manufacturing is ongoing – some of it is completed even before schedule,” Orsted’s Asia-Pacific president Per Mejnert Kristensen says.

site_title: Goldman sees US jobs at inflection point, sticks to two interest rate cuts
summary: Goldman Sachs economist Jan Hatzius believes the US labor market is at an "inflection point" where a decline in labor demand could impact jobs, not just job openings. Despite rising initial and continuing jobless claims, the current strength of labor demand is unclear. Goldman expects two interest rate cuts in September and December, contradicting the Federal Reserve's "surprisingly hawkish" projections. The economic growth outlook is expected to moderate in the second half, with inflation expected to cool and core goods prices to remain flat.

images.alt_text: The survey’s reading of one-year inflation expectations was unchanged at 3.3 per cent.

site_title: Parent of India's Vedanta proposes to cut debt by US$3 billion over next three years
summary: Vedanta Resources' UK-based parent company plans to cut its debt by US$3 billion over the next three years, according to chairman Anil Agarwal. The company, which has cut its debt by US$3.70 billion in the last two years, will utilize its newly acquired "newfound liquidity" from maturing bonds worth US$3.20 billion to fund key projects. Vedanta Resources aims to operationalize coal blocks, expand steel and aluminum capacities, and set aside US$1.90 billion in capital expenditure for fiscal 2025.

site_title: US business inventories rebound in April
summary: US business inventories rebounded 0.3% in April, matching economists' expectations, after dipping 0.1% in March. This rebound may contribute to economic growth this quarter, as inventories rose 1.0% year-on-year. Private inventory investment has been a drag on GDP for two straight quarters, but retail inventories and motor vehicle inventories showed significant increases, while wholesale inventories and manufacturer stocks also rose. The rebound sets a positive note for the US economy after it grew at a 1.3% annualized rate in the January-March quarter, the slowest pace in nearly two years.

images.alt_text: Retail sales rose 0.1 per cent last month after a downwardly revised 0.2 per cent drop in April.
FILE PHOTO: Solar panels are built at the QCells solar energy manufacturing factory in Dalton, Georgia, U.S., March 2, 2023. REUTERS/Megan Varner//File Photo

site_title: Huawei weighs app store fees as it surpasses iPhone in China
summary: Huawei is considering a lower commission fee for in-app purchases on its Harmony mobile operating system, potentially below 30% compared to Apple's 30% and Google's 30%. The company has been discussing a 20% fee with developers, particularly for games, as it seeks to attract more users and app makers to its ecosystem. Huawei's move suggests the company feels it has grown its user and developer base, allowing it to begin collecting revenue.

images.alt_text: A view of the Huawei Booth at the Smart China Expo in Chongqing,  China, on Monday, 04 April  2023.

site_title: Pop star Justin Timberlake arrested for drunk driving in New York
summary: Justin Timberlake was arrested on Tuesday, June 18, 2024, in New York state on charges of driving under the influence of alcohol. He was expected to be arraigned on Tuesday morning. Timberlake has upcoming concerts scheduled in Chicago and New York City, but details on his current status and potential impact on his performances are not available.

site_title: HSBC Switzerland breached money laundering rules: Swiss watchdog
summary: HSBC Switzerland's local branch has breached money laundering rules, according to the Swiss financial watchdog FINMA. Suspicious transactions totaling $300 million between 2002 and 2015 were carried out with two politically exposed persons, transferring funds between Lebanon and Switzerland. FINMA has ordered HSBC to review its business relationships with politically exposed individuals and halt new relationships. The bank has declined to comment, planning to appeal the decision.

site_title: From fairway to greenway
summary: The US-Singapore Free Trade Agreement (FTA) celebrates its 20th anniversary, marking a significant milestone in bilateral relations. The US-Driven Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF), launched in 2022, promotes clean energy cooperation among 14 Indo-Pacific partners, aiming to address climate change, foster economic growth, and enhance energy security. Singapore's proactive policies and robust clean energy ecosystem make it an attractive platform for international businesses and investors to explore technology possibilities in the energy transition, with initiatives such as the IPEF Clean Economy Investor Forum showcasing its catalytic role in fostering dialogue.

images.alt_text: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam at IPEF on 5 June 2024 at Sands Expo and Convention Centre
An "antifascist rally" in Toulouse, France, on Jun 10, following the European parliamentary election results that showed a significant swing to the right across the continent.

site_title: Singapore, Cambodia launch financial digital infrastructure initiative to boost SME trade
summary: Singapore and Cambodia launched a financial digital infrastructure initiative to boost small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) trade between the two countries. The initiative, known as the Singapore-Cambodia financial transparency corridor, aims to enhance data accessibility and facilitate greater availability of financing for SME trade. Participating financial institutions from both countries include Anext Bank, Liquid Group, and others. The goal is to execute the first live financing transactions in the second half of this year, with the launch held in conjunction with Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet's official visit to Singapore.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Hun Manet, commander of the Royal Cambodian Army and eldest son of Prime Minister Hun Sen, shows his finger after he casts his vote at a polling station in Phnom Penh on July 23, 2023. (Photo by -STR / AFP)

site_title: Double-digit US stock returns are in the past, bubble or not
summary: US stocks have more than doubled since 2020, with the S&P 500 Index up 14% annually since 2010. However, valuations are comparable to the dot-com era, with the S&P 500 trading at 22 times forward earnings, down from 30 times in 1999. Despite this, the market is considered higher quality, with companies being more profitable, having stronger balance sheets, and lower debt. Historically, high valuations have been followed by below-average returns, suggesting that the current market may be due for a correction.

images.alt_text: Goldman Sachs says index volatility increases before the election during election years, but following the election, volatility typically subsides and the S&P 500 Index rebounds to an even higher level.
It would be wiser for investors to be globally diversified. You may get a lower return than investing in a single index but you are able to stay invested to get the returns you need.

site_title: KKR-Singtel consortium to invest S$1.75 billion in data centre provider ST Telemedia GDC
summary: A KKR-Singtel consortium has invested S$1.75 billion in data-centre provider ST Telemedia Global Data Centres (STT GDC), the largest digital infrastructure investment in South-east Asia this year. The initial investment will be via redeemable preference shares with detachable warrants, with an additional S$1.24 billion to be injected upon warrant exercise. The consortium, which beat out Stonepeak for the stake, now holds 18.3% of STT GDC, with KKR and Singtel holding 14.1% and 4.2% respectively. The investment will support STT GDC's expansion and growth plans.

images.alt_text: Singtel-TM joint venture to develop data centres in Malaysia, enhance digital connectivity
The KKR-Singtel consortium is competing with alternative investment firm Stonepeak for a stake of up to 20 per cent, sources told Reuters.

site_title: China securities regulator vows to strengthen oversight, resolve risks
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), vows to strengthen oversight and resolve risks in the capital market with a "zero-tolerance" stance on illegal activities. The regulator will increase monitoring of trading behavior, improve regulation of quantitative trading and high-frequency trading, and strengthen scrutiny of company listings and delistings. The move aims to improve and reform financial markets amid a wobbly economic recovery, as China's stock market struggles to recover from five-year lows.

images.alt_text: Many investors say the risk of buying shares in smaller companies is increasing, while brokerages have forecast a record number of delistings this year.
FILE PHOTO: The company logo is seen on the headquarters of China Evergrande Group in Shenzhen, Guangdong province, China September 26, 2021. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

China's national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing. Securities brokerages that used to offer some of the highest remunerations last year reported declines in average salaries for the second straight year.
China is tightening scrutiny of hedge funds, with new rules unveiled last month raising the asset threshold and curbing their use of leverage and derivatives.

site_title: Hitachi to plan selling stake in Johnson Aircon JV
summary: Hitachi plans to sell its 40% stake in the air-conditioning joint venture with Johnson Controls International, which could lead to the outright sale of Johnson Controls-Hitachi Air Conditioning. The joint venture's value could be around $4.28 billion. Hitachi's decision is aimed at enhancing its corporate value, and the company has a first right of refusal on Johnson's stake. The move comes after Johnson explored a sale of its heating and ventilation assets, including the joint venture, for months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Hitachi is seen at an office building in Zurich, Switzerland September 10, 2020. REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo

site_title: Snap launches AI tools for advanced augmented reality
summary: Snapchat owner Snap has launched its latest iteration of generative AI technology, allowing users to see more realistic special effects in phone cameras. The move aims to stay ahead of social media rivals and attract new users and advertisers. AR developers can now create AI-powered lenses, and users can use them in content. Snap also upgraded its developer program, Lens Studio, to reduce development time and produce more complex AR effects, enabling the creation of more realistic and complex lenses, such as full-body AR experiences.

images.alt_text: Youth advocates and lawmakers have long accused social media platforms like Facebook, Instagram, TikTok and Snapchat of what they say is a harmful effect on kids, including shortened attention spans, promoting negative body images, and making them vulnerable to online bullies and predators.
The company forecast first quarter revenue between US$1.1 billion and US$1.14 billion.

“In order to best position our business to execute on our highest priorities, and to ensure we have the capacity to invest incrementally to support our growth over time, we have made the difficult decision to restructure our team,” Snap says.

site_title: French watchdog asks court to fine Carrefour over franchise operations
summary: The French finance ministry's General Directorate for Competition Policy has asked a court to fine Carrefour over contracts with franchisee stores, claiming the agreements were unbalanced in its favor. The watchdog seeks to declare several clauses null and void and impose a 200 million euro penalty. Carrefour contests the allegations, saying the fine is unfounded and that it has "full confidence" in its contracts. The case involves nearly 170 franchisees who brought proceedings against the company last year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A customer pushes his shopping trolley in front of a Carrefour Hypermarket store in Saint-Herblain near Nantes, France January 15, 2021. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
From Thursday (Jan 4), shelves with PepsiCo products at Carrefour stores in France will be accompanied by a note saying “We are no longer selling this brand due to unacceptable price increases”.

site_title: US: Wall Street steady at open after retail sales data
summary: The US stock market opened flat to slightly higher on Tuesday, June 18, after soft retail sales data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.02 points to 38,779.12, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 2.92 points, but the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.26 points. The market awaited commentary from Federal Reserve officials later in the day.

site_title: SIA Group passenger traffic rises 10.2% in May
summary: SIA Group reported a 10.2% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in May 2024, carrying 3.2 million passengers. Passenger capacity rose 12.6%, with a load factor of 86.1%. Cargo loads increased 18.5% due to strong e-commerce demand and sea freight disruptions. Scoot started flights to Koh Samui on its Embraer E190-E2 aircraft, expanding the group's network to 123 destinations in 36 countries.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Airlines (SIA) B747-400F aircraft is one of SIA’s seven freighters used for delivering essential items around the world. A distinctive feature of the SIA B747-400F freighter is the nose cargo door which can swing upwards, allowing exceptionally long items of over 50m in length to be loaded.

site_title: Mooreast to acquire 1.1 million sq ft facility from Seatrium for S$13.5 million
summary: Mooreast Holdings has agreed to acquire a 1.1 million sq ft facility from Seatrium for S$13.5 million, which will significantly expand its manufacturing capabilities. The acquisition is expected to quadruple Mooreast's production capacity, allowing the company to meet anticipated demand for floating offshore renewable energy forms. This move is part of Mooreast Asia's efforts to increase its capacity and meet market demand, according to founder and CEO Sim Koon Lam.

images.alt_text: Mooreast Holdings founder and chief executive Sim Koon Lam with mid-water arch buoys that the company developed for Japan’s first commercial floating wind farm in Nagasaki.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 18)
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports rose 0.1% year-on-year in May, beating analyst expectations. Electronics shipments recovered due to the global tech upswing. Air freight at Changi Airport jumped 20% year-on-year to 170,000 tonnes in May. New private home sales plummeted 78.7% year-on-year, while commodity trader Trafigura topped the inaugural Fortune 500 list for South-east Asia. Stocks rose 0.1% on the Singapore Stock Exchange, tracking regional bourses.

site_title: US industrial production comes in hot in May
summary: US industrial production rose 0.9% in May, significantly higher than expected, according to the Federal Reserve. Despite the Fed holding interest rates at a 23-year high to combat inflation, the manufacturing sector staged a rebound. This increase pushed factory output into positive territory year-over-year, with a 0.4% gain since May 2023. The sharp monthly rise was attributed to strong gains in mining and utilities production, with mining production increasing 0.3% and utilities production rising 1.6%.

images.alt_text: Retail sales rose 0.1 per cent last month after a downwardly revised 0.2 per cent drop in April.

site_title: Boeing may have installed bad 737 parts, whistleblower alleges
summary: A Boeing quality inspector alleges the company "intentionally hid" improperly stored non-conforming parts, including rudders and flaps, from the US Federal Aviation Administration ahead of an inspection. As of last year, Boeing had lost up to 400 faulty 737 Max aircraft parts and deleted records from its internal cataloguing system. The whistleblower claims Boeing prioritized speed and cost over quality and safety, amid an ongoing investigation by multiple federal agencies, including the Justice Department and the FAA.

images.alt_text: File photo of Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun. Since the Jan 5 mid-air blowout of a door plug on a 737 MAX 9 jet, scrutiny of the planemaker by regulators and airlines has intensified.

site_title: Strong momentum in India's economic activity seen sustaining, says central bank chief
summary: Reserve Bank of India Governor Shaktikanta Das said India's economic activity has continued to show strong momentum in the first quarter of the new financial year, driven by private investment and improved rural demand. External demand is expected to remain strong, supporting India's merchandise and services exports. Despite global growth yet to pick up, Das stated that inflation is moderating but at a slow pace, with core inflation at a historical low of around 3%. The RBI kept the key repo rate unchanged at 6.5% for an eighth straight policy meeting.

site_title: Greenback pares gains after US retail sales miss expectations in May
summary: The US dollar pared its gains against the euro after retail sales data in May showed signs of exhaustion among US consumers, boosting the case for Federal Reserve rate cuts later this year. US retail sales increased less than expected, with lower petrol and motor vehicle prices weighing on receipts at service stations and auto dealerships. This trend suggests that households are prioritizing essentials and cutting back on discretionary spending, potentially easing the Fed's task of returning CPI to target.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda says he will not rule out raising interest rates in July as weakness in the yen pushes up import costs.
FILE PHOTO: Japanese yen and U.S. dollar banknotes are seen with a currency exchange rate graph in this illustration picture taken June 16, 2022. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo
The euro is on track for a 1.2 per cent weekly fall – its biggest since April – and was last down 0.61 per cent on the day at US$1.0668, the lowest since May 1.

site_title: Vodafone to sell 10% stake in India's Indus Towers for up to US$1.1 billion
summary: Vodafone plans to sell a 10% stake in India's Indus Towers for up to US$1.1 billion through stock market block deals. The sale, valued between US$996 million and US$1.1 billion, will help Vodafone repay part of its US$42.17 billion net debt. The stake sale will involve roughly 268 million shares sold at a price range of 310 to 341 rupees per share.

images.alt_text: Vodafone announced the sale of its Spanish business to Zegona in October, marking an exit from a market that has dragged on performance for years.

site_title: Singtel-TM joint venture to develop data centres in Malaysia, enhance digital connectivity
summary: Singtel and Malaysia's TM have formed a joint venture to develop a data centre campus in Johor, the largest for both companies. The campus will be built to latest standards of reliability, security, and sustainability, offering local and international connectivity. The initial phase will be 64 MW, with plans to scale up to 200 MW. The partnership aims to serve hyperscalers, AI providers, and enterprises pursuing digitalisation and cloud adoption in the region, and will also expand submarine cable connectivity and partner with institutes of higher learning to nurture talent.

images.alt_text: Singtel intends to move its customers to its first new artificial intelligence data centre in Tuas.

site_title: US retail sales rise less than expected in May
summary: US retail sales rose 0.1% in May, less than expected, after a revised 0.2% drop in April. This suggests the economy remained lacklustre in the second quarter. Inflation and higher interest rates are forcing households to prioritize essentials, leading to reduced discretionary spending. Despite this, economists expect the Federal Reserve to consider cutting interest rates in September, citing a modest slowdown in consumption growth. The labour market remains solid, but wage increases are moderating, and savings are decreasing.

images.alt_text: The survey’s reading of one-year inflation expectations was unchanged at 3.3 per cent.
US Import prices dropped 0.4 per cent last month after an unrevised 0.9 per cent surge in April.

FILE PHOTO: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen testifies before a Senate Appropriations Financial Services and General Government Subcommittee hearing on President Biden’s proposed budget request for the Department of Treasury, on Capitol Hill in Washington, U.S., June 4, 2024. REUTERS/Anna Rose Layden/File Photo
The producer price index for final demand dropped 0.2 per cent last month after advancing by an unrevised 0.5 per cent in April.

A combination of strong growth and a strong US dollar means that America’s share of global GDP at market exchange rates, which should fall as others catch up to the world’s biggest economy, is instead growing.
In the 12 months through May, the CPI advanced 3.3 per cent after increasing 3.4 per cent in April.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, June 18, 2024 (Ep 83)
summary: Asian equities rose on Tuesday, with possible snap legislative elections in France causing market fear. China's sovereign bonds closed at a record high, while Singapore's Changi Airport reported a 20% year-on-year jump in air freight handled.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 96 to 56.
Asian investors extended the buying, with Tokyo and Taipei up more than one per cent, while there were also healthy gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Wellington.
People at a demonstration against the far-right RN party, which is known for its anti-immigration stance.

site_title: Can Big Tech stocks continue to lead the equities rally?
summary: Big Tech stocks continue to lead the equities rally, driven primarily by earnings growth rather than speculative valuation gains. The Nasdaq 100 has delivered nearly 13.5% CAGR earnings growth over the past decade, outpacing non-tech segments of the market. Legacy Big Tech leaders, including Apple, Alphabet, Amazon, Meta Platforms, and Microsoft, have begun deploying measures to manage capital more efficiently to drive earnings growth, such as share buybacks and cash dividends. This foundation of internally driven earnings growth provides technology investors with a margin of safety, despite potential risks from tax increases and low bond yields.

images.alt_text: Alphabet last month announced a dividend of 20 US cents a share, sparking a 10 per cent gain in the shares of the Google parent.

Apple, which had taken its time to formulate its AI strategy, lost its long-held top spot in January as investors rewarded Microsoft’s unabashed rollout of new generative AI products under its CoPilot brand.

site_title: Temasek to divest entire stake in Pavilion Energy to Shell
summary: Temasek is divesting its entire stake in Pavilion Energy to Shell Eastern Trading, a subsidiary of the global oil giant. The transaction is expected to be completed by the first quarter of 2025, subject to regulatory approval. Pavilion Energy markets and trades liquefied natural gas (LNG) in Europe and Asia, with a diverse portfolio of about 6.5 million tonnes per annum of LNG supply contracts. The deal will allow Shell to grow Pavilion Energy's business and strengthen its global LNG hub in Singapore.

images.alt_text: CMG20231025-HengYY03 / 王彦燕 / 淡马锡 Temasek International office at Orchard Road [Temasek International Pte. Ltd. 60B Orchard Road #06-18 Tower 2. The Atrium@Orchard Singapore 238891]

site_title: Australia holds key rate at 12-year high on inflation worries
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) held its cash rate at a 12-year high of 4.35% for a fifth consecutive meeting, aiming to slow consumer prices while maintaining significant job gains since the pandemic. The decision was made despite a mixed economic data, as the RBA remains vigilant to upside risks to inflation. The RBA governor, Michele Bullock, has repeatedly signaled that inflation will only return to target in late 2025, and the central bank is not ruling out further interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: A Chinese official (right) tries to block cameras from filming Chinese-born Australian journalist Cheng Lei (seated in second row), who is attending a signing ceremony by Premier Li Qiang and Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at the Australian Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, June 17, 2024.
Once the reforms are in place, the RBA will launch a “holistic review” of retail payments regulations, Connolly says.
The increase in duties is expected to encourage more properties to be made available to New South Wales residents.

site_title: China opens tit-for-tat anti-dumping probe into European pork
summary: China has launched an anti-dumping investigation into European pork imports, focusing on pork intended for human consumption and by-products. The investigation, which began on June 17, aims to respond to EU curbs on Chinese electric vehicle exports and could impact pork exports from Spain, the Netherlands, and Denmark. The investigation is expected to be completed by June 17, 2025, but could be extended by six months. EU officials are monitoring the situation, and European pork producers are bracing for potential tariffs.

images.alt_text: China imported US$6 billion worth of pork in 2023, including offal, with the EU accounting for more than half.

While it remains unclear which products China could target for retaliation, whey powder, cream and fresh milk were the top export items in the EU’s 1.7 billion euros (S$2.4 billion) worth of dairy exports to China last year, according to data from the European Commission’s Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.

site_title: EU says to delay core element of Basel bank capital rules
summary: The European Union will delay implementing a core element of Basel bank capital rules by one year to January 2026 due to the "highly likely" delay in the US. The EU had initially planned to introduce the final leg of Basel III in January 2025, but will now push back the section on covering market risks in trading books. This delay aims to ensure a global level playing field for European banks competing with other global players, allowing more time to assess other countries' progress.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Union flags fly outside the European Commission headquarters in Brussels, Belgium, March 1, 2023.REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: Climate investing opportunities in Asia: green bonds, renewables and transition credits
summary: Climate investing opportunities in Asia are emerging, with green bonds, renewables, and transition credits gaining traction. Despite sufficient capital available, obstacles to effective climate action need to be identified and removed. Regulators in Asia have proposed mandatory ISSB-aligned reporting rules to build momentum for the financial sector to be a bigger enabler of climate action. Investors are increasingly interested in climate-related investments, with asset managers like BlackRock launching climate-focused funds and seeing growing interest in transition investing. The Singapore government's push for transition credits may make it more economically viable for companies to phase out coal plants early and invest in renewables.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the logo of the International Energy Agency in Paris, France, December 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier//File Photo
Experts say climate change doubled the likelihood of floods in southern Brazil and worsened the intense rains caused by El Nino.
China has vowed to peak carbon before 2030, a key milestone on its road to zeroing out emissions by 2060.

site_title: More central banks to increase gold reserves within 12 months
summary: Central banks are expected to increase their gold reserves within the next 12 months, with 29% of respondents in a World Gold Council survey predicting an increase. This is the highest level since the survey began in 2018. 81% of respondents expect global central bank gold reserves to increase, citing gold as a long-term store of value, inflation hedge, and effective portfolio diversifier. The top storage locations are domestic vaults (41%) and the Bank of England (55%).

images.alt_text: Lower rates also make non-yielding gold more attractive.

site_title: China’s rich ditch flashy luxury as global sales stall: Bain
summary: China's richest individuals are opting for more discreet luxury spending, shifting away from flashy items due to economic uncertainty and social stigma. Global luxury sales are expected to grow between 0-4% this year, the weakest market since 2020. This slowdown is largely attributed to China, where middle-class shoppers are cautious about luxury purchases. The trend may not last, with some luxury brands, like Hermes, expected to fare better in the current market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People stand with Hermes shopping bags as they wait at a traffic light in Tsim Sha Tsui, a bustling shopping hotspot, in Hong Kong, China December 5, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Sri Lanka court blocks gender equality Bill
summary: Sri Lanka's Supreme Court blocked the Gender Equality Bill, citing concerns that it could lead to the decriminalization of homosexuality and same-sex marriage, which is seen as undermining conservative values. The bill aimed to promote equal opportunities for all regardless of sex or gender identity. President Ranil Wickremesinghe urged lawmakers to form a select committee to overturn the ruling, calling it "judicial cannibalism" that undermines progressive decisions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) (FILES) A member of the LGBTQIA+ community holds a placard calling for marriage equality during a pride march in Bangkok on June 4, 2023. The Thai senate will debate on April 2, 2024 a bill to legalise same-sex marriage, as the kingdom moves towards becoming the first Southeast Asian country to recognise marriage equality. (Photo by MANAN VATSYAYANA / AFP)

site_title: Music platform BandLab CEO says AI is not the enemy
summary: BandLab CEO Meng Ru Kwok disagrees with critics who view AI as a threat to human creativity, stating that AI is a tool that enhances creativity, not replaces it. The platform's AI music creation tool, SongStarter, generates song ideas, but users must still use their own creativity to build on those ideas. Kwok believes the shift towards self-production is inevitable and that AI will change the definition of music creators, but not eliminate them.

images.alt_text: Sony sent letters to more than 700 companies in an effort to protect its intellectual property, which includes album cover art, metadata, musical compositions and lyrics, from being used for training AI models.

site_title: BOJ index shows more Japan firms passing on wage costs in services prices
summary: The Bank of Japan's business-to-business price index for services with high labour costs rose 2.8% in April, the fastest increase in nearly four years, reaching a 106.4 level, the highest since comparable data became available in 1985. This uptrend reflects companies' expectations of steady wage increases, prompting them to charge more for their services, a trend seen as a prerequisite for the central bank to consider raising interest rates.

images.alt_text: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the BOJ was not yet fully convinced that inflation will sustainably hit its 2 per cent target, stressing the need to spend “a bit more time” to scrutinise various data before raising interest rates again.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise, tracking regional bourses; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% on Tuesday, driven by a rebound from the Hari Raya Haji holiday. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,301.78, with 1.3 billion securities worth S$1.1 billion changing hands. Decliners outnumbered advancers 306 to 269, indicating a mixed market.

images.alt_text: Demand for gold from central banks has been elevated in the last two years as some countries diversify their foreign currency reserves.

The BOK extended its interest rate pause for an 11th straight meeting in May.

site_title: SingHaiyi-led group to launch Jurong East condo Sora at S$2,180 psf average
summary: A SingHaiyi-led joint venture will launch previews for its 99-year leasehold condominium project, Sora, on June 22. The project, located along Yuan Ching Road, occupies a 17,834.8 sqm site with a gross plot ratio of 2.1. Prices start at S$1,850 psf for one-bedroom units and S$3.05 million for four-bedroom units, with an average price of S$2,180 psf. The majority of units are two- and three-bedders, with some featuring private lifts.

images.alt_text: Gramercy Park, a condominium related to the money laundering case.
The land plots at Dairy Farm Walk and Tengah Garden Avenue are on the confirmed list, while the Bayshore Road site sits on the reserve list.
The Council of Estate Agencies, the industry regulator, is investigating property agents who had facilitated transactions associated with the S$3 billion money laundering case.

site_title: SP Group to design district cooling, heating system for Chengdu development
summary: SP Group has secured a 19-year contract to design, build, develop, and operate a district cooling and heating system for the International Sports Park City in Chengdu, China, with an estimated investment of over 200 million yuan. The system, expected to begin operations in 2025, will achieve energy savings of 2,900 megawatt hours and reduce carbon emissions by 1,700 tonnes. This is SP Group's largest district cooling system in Chengdu, and the project aligns with China's urban transformation and decarbonisation goals.

images.alt_text: Representatives from SP Group, Qingda Environment, and Chinese officials at the groundbreaking ceremony for the aquavoltaic farm on Apr 26. 2024..

site_title: German home building permits nosedive in April as slump continues
summary: German home building permits fell 17% in April from a year earlier, to 17,600, marking a nearly 44% drop over two years. This is the lowest number of permits issued since May 2022. The decline in permits is attributed to a severe slump in the construction and real estate industry, which has been impacted by high inflation and interest rates. The German Construction Industry Federation says the number of building permits has only gone in one direction: downwards, since May 2022.

images.alt_text: According to the study, the only growth area will be commercial construction, with an increase in sales of 1.5 per cent.
Foreign buyers accounted for 35 per cent of purchases of commercial real estate in the first quarter, data from BNP Paribas Real Estate shows.

FILE PHOTO: Construction sites are photographed in Frankfurt, Germany, July 19, 2023. REUTERS/Kai Pfaffenbach/File Photo

site_title: How Monopoly can help to make a better investor
summary: Monopoly can provide valuable lessons for investors, highlighting the contrast between easy-to-learn investing strategies and the complexity of mastering the task. While buying shares may be straightforward, investing requires perseverance and analysis to maximize returns. A group of Monopoly players held a 70-day game, demonstrating the dedication required to succeed in investing, with some players even analyzing property values for potential returns. This game-like approach can help investors adopt a strategic mindset, making informed decisions and navigating the challenges of investing.

images.alt_text: Hunting for winners in the AI race is akin to panning for gold during the Californian Gold Rush in 1849.
It can be tempting to do dollar-cost averaging for a portfolio that is a tad under the weather.  But we may only be throwing good money after bad in the hope that our average losses will look better.

site_title: China's property measures give sales a boost, but only in big cities
summary: China's property measures have boosted transactions in major cities like Beijing and Shanghai, but had little impact on smaller localities. The measures, announced on May 17, cut mortgage rates and downpayments, and instructed municipalities to buy unsold apartments to turn them into social housing. However, the uneven impact suggests more pain ahead for the country's real estate market, with smaller cities struggling to recover. The measures only revived demand in megacities, highlighting the significant disparities within China's economy.

images.alt_text: China’s new home prices have dropped 5.7 per cent as at April from the 2021 high, while existing home prices are down 11.4 per cent.
Guess who’s angry at China’s real estate bailout: homeowners

site_title: Motor racing: Brad Pitt's F1 movie set for release in June 2025
summary: Brad Pitt's upcoming Formula One movie is set for release on June 25, 2025, with a North American debut two days later. The film, directed by Joseph Kosinski, will feature Pitt as a former driver making a comeback alongside Damson Idris, and is being made in cooperation with teams and drivers. Production is expected to complete at the Abu Dhabi Grand Prix in December. The movie will be distributed by Warner Bros Pictures in cinemas and IMAX, and has a worldwide budget not mentioned.

images.alt_text: Brad Pitt's production house, Plan B Entertainment, has three best picture Oscar winners to its name.

site_title: Blackstone makes US$1.7 billion bid for Japan e-comics platform Infocom
summary: Blackstone has made a US$1.74 billion bid to acquire Japanese digital comic distributor Infocom private, including a tender offer of 6,060 yen per share. The current parent Teijin will sell its 58% stake in Infocom for 134.4 billion yen in a share buyback after the buyout is completed. The deal marks the largest private equity transaction in Japan this year and follows a surge in global investor interest in Japanese companies due to a weak yen, strong public markets, and corporate governance changes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: Signage is seen outside the Blackstone Group headquarters in New York City, U.S., January 18, 2023. REUTERS/Jeenah Moon/File Photo

site_title: AI can help shipping industry cut down emissions, report says
summary: A new report by Orca AI suggests that deploying artificial intelligence for sea navigation can help the global shipping industry reduce carbon emissions by 47 million tonnes per year. This technology can optimize routes, reduce fuel consumption, and lower close encounters with marine targets. The International Maritime Organization aims to cut emissions by 20% by 2030, but the ongoing Red Sea crisis threatens to undermine this target. By implementing AI-powered navigation systems, shipping companies can shave off 38.2 million nautical miles per year and save $100,000 in fuel costs per vessel.

images.alt_text: SONY DSC

Nearly six months of regular attacks on vessels in the Red Sea has stretched capacity in an industry responsible for moving about 80 per cent of all international goods trade, leading to bottlenecks in some of Asia’s biggest ports.
XXXX

The longer route around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid attacks by Yemen’s Houthis has pushed up shipping costs, as about 12 per cent of world total shipping traffic historically sailed through the Red Sea and Egypt’s Suez Canal.

site_title: Voter rolls updated; public inspection opens from Jun 19 to Jul 2
summary: Singapore's voter rolls have been updated with the names of all eligible electors as of June 1, 2024, and are open for public inspection from June 19 to July 2. The update comes amid speculation of an early general election, which must be held by November 2025. Citizens can check their particulars online or in person at various locations, and can file claims or objections to correct errors or remove names from the register. Those whose names were removed due to not voting in a past election can also apply to have their names restored, but must do so early due to time constraints.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank downgrades Grab to ‘hold’ on monetisation hurdles
summary: Maybank Securities downgraded its rating on Grab to "hold" from "buy" due to monetization hurdles and mild growth headwinds. The firm cites concerns over pricing and commission pressure from consumers and driver-merchant partners, which could affect Grab's take-rate. Despite maintaining room for sustained high growth, Maybank reduced its target price to US$4 from US$4.50, implying an upside of 11% to the counter's last closing price.

images.alt_text: The ride-hailing sector in South-east Asia is predicted to reach a market size of US$10.5 billion by 2028.

site_title: Celine Dion offers a portrait of resilience in vulnerable documentary
summary: Celine Dion's documentary, "I Am: Celine Dion," premieres on June 25, showcasing her soaring career and recent challenges with a rare neurological disorder, Stiff Person Syndrome (SPS). Despite health struggles, Dion vows her passion as a performer will never disappear. The intimate film features archival footage, tender scenes at home, and documents the severity of her pain, including a seizure sequence. Dion hopes the documentary will inspire people with similar obstacles, stating it's "the greatest gift and the greatest responsibility."

images.alt_text: Celine Dion made a surprise appearance at the Grammy Awards in February, when she presented the Album of the Year award to Taylor Swift.

site_title: Australia flags concern over ‘ham-fisted’ China diplomats
summary: Australia has expressed concern over the "ham-fisted" actions of Chinese diplomats during a press event, where they attempted to block cameras from filming Australian journalist Cheng Lei. The incident occurred during a signing ceremony at the Australian Parliament House, where Premier Li Qiang was meeting with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese. Albanese criticized the behavior, stating it was a "pretty clumsy attempt" by the diplomats to block Cheng Lei's appearance. The incident occurred during a visit by Li, which aimed to promote trade and friendship between the two countries, but also highlighted lingering "differences" between them.

images.alt_text: China has vowed to peak carbon before 2030, a key milestone on its road to zeroing out emissions by 2060.
Premier Li Qiang’s visit is the first trip to Australia by a Chinese leader of his seniority since 2017.
China is traditionally a hugely important market for adidas. Its sales there suffered in recent years during long-running coronavirus lockdowns but had started recovering strongly.
A sputtering recovery in the world’s second-biggest economy has driven a record-breaking rally in Chinese government bonds over the past few months.
The People's Bank of China has repeatedly hinted at its discomfort over the bond rally in the past few months as long-term yields touched two-decade lows.
Funding for property developers has stayed weak since China's government drew up a “white list” of property firms that are eligible for loans late last year.
Since households have been reluctant to spend, China has turned to export-led growth instead.

site_title: Thailand passes landmark Bill recognising marriage equality
summary: Thailand's Senate passed a landmark marriage equality law, making the country the first in South-east Asia to recognize same-sex couples. The law, which gained nearly unanimous support from upper house lawmakers, will be sent to the palace for royal approval and will come into force 120 days after publication. This move is seen as a "monumental step forward" by LGBTQ+ advocates, who hail Thailand's leadership in promoting human rights and gender equality in the region.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka's President Ranil Wickremesinghe delivers a speech during the Nikkei Forum "Future of Asia" in Tokyo on May 25, 2023. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

A member of the LGBTQ community holds a placard calling for marriage equality during a pride march in Bangkok on June 4, 2023. The Thai senate will debate on April 2, 2024 a bill to legalise same-sex marriage.

site_title: Thailand’s Thaksin indicted for insulting monarchy
summary: Thailand's former prime minister Thaksin Shinawatra has been indicted for insulting the monarchy under the kingdom's strict royal insult laws. Thaksin, 74, was accused of lese-majeste over comments made in 2015 and faces up to 15 years in prison. The indictment is part of four cases before the courts that could spark fresh political instability in Thailand. Thaksin was granted bail and will defend his case, which comes amid concerns the laws are used to stifle legitimate debate and following recent youth-led protests.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin looks on during an interview with Reuters in Koh Samui, Surat Thani province, Thailand, April 7, 2024. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa/File Photo
Thailand's Constitutional Court says it will hear a case against Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin on Tuesday.

Thaksin Shinawatra, Thailand's former prime minister, arrives at Don Mueang airport after returning from self-exile in Bangkok, Thailand, on Tuesday, Aug. 22, 2023. Thaksin, who faced three guilty sentences for corruption cases handed down in absentia, was ordered by the Supreme Court today to serve a total of eight years in jail. Photographer: Valeria Mongelli/Bloomberg
The case against Thaksin Shinawatra relates to comments he made in 2015 to South Korean media and is the latest in a series of legal battles he has fought.

Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin speaks during a joint statement with French President Emmanuel Macron (not pictured) at the Elysee Palace in Paris, France, March 11, 2024. Teresa Suarez/Pool via REUTERS
Pichit Chuenban's appointment as minister to the prime minister’s office had breached the constitution, as he has a criminal record.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment adopts cooling-as-a-service at flagship Singapore properties
summary: CapitaLand Investment has adopted cooling-as-a-service systems in its flagship Singapore properties, Raffles City Singapore, Plaza Singapura, and The Atrium@Orchard. The systems cover 4.8 million square feet of gross floor area and have a combined installed capacity of 15,000 refrigerant tonnes. This move aims to drive sustainability and cost efficiency, with the company continuing its efforts to reduce its environmental impact. The adoption of cooling-as-a-service is a significant step for the company, making Raffles City Singapore the largest integrated development to adopt this technology.

images.alt_text: The investment management arm of CapitaLand Group has obtained a licence from the International Financial Services Centres Authority or IFSCA to run a fund management company at the country’s newest financial hub.

site_title: Seche Environnement to buy Singapore hazardous waste firm ECO for S$605 million
summary: French industrial group Seche Environnement agreed to buy Singapore's ECO Industrial Environmental Engineering for approximately S$605 million. ECO, the number one operator in Singapore's hazardous waste recovery and treatment market, generated sales of around S$96 million in 2023. The acquisition is expected to accelerate Seche Environnement's strategy of profitable growth in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: garbage cans, the garbage container, garbage disposal

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway boosts stake in Occidental Petroleum to nearly 29%
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, led by billionaire Warren Buffett, has increased its stake in Occidental Petroleum to nearly 29% after acquiring 2.95 million shares worth about $176 million. The purchases bring Berkshire's total Occidental shares to 255.3 million, valued at approximately $15.37 billion. This move has sparked speculation about potential future acquisitions, which could diversify Berkshire's energy portfolio. Buffett has previously stated he has no plans to acquire Occidental, but analysts see the move as a strategic investment.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo for Occidental Petroleum is displayed on a screen on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, U.S., April 30, 2019. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: OCBC launches new tool that uses AI to pick stocks
summary: OCBC Securities has launched AI Oscar, a tool using deep-learning algorithms to predict stock price movements and generate personalized stock ideas. The tool analyzes investor data, including risk appetite, past trading activity, and demographic information, to curate 15 stocks every week from exchanges in Singapore, Hong Kong, and the US. AI Oscar was trained with data from over 4,000 stocks and aims to triple active young investors over the next three years, following a 50% increase in trading activity among young investors aged under 35 between October 2023 and April 2024.

images.alt_text: OCBC group CEO Helen Wong highlights that compared to HNWIs in the US and Europe, Asean families are likely to be only in their second or third generations of wealth.
Singapore's three local banks observed a rise in sustainable loan financing to SMEs.
In May, OCBC made a voluntary unconditional general offer of S$1.4 billion for the remaining 11.56 per cent stake in GEH that it does not own, with the aim to delist the insurer.
The event attracted more than 800 seniors and skills – such as learning how to make digital payments – were imparted using a gamified approach.

site_title: Bitcoin touches a one-month low in a broad crypto market sell-off
summary: Bitcoin fell to a one-month low, shedding 2.7% on Tuesday, as traders scaled back expectations for Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts due to stubborn inflation. The largest digital asset traded at $65,740, following outflows from digital-asset investment products and concerns over higher borrowing costs. The decline is part of a broader crypto market sell-off, with smaller tokens also sinking, and marks a reversal from the asset's outperformance in traditional markets earlier this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Smartphone with Tether logo is placed on displayed U.S. dollars in this illustration taken, May 12, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Tether's investment plan highlights the growing financial clout and ambition of the issuer of the world’s largest stablecoin, a type of cryptocurrency designed to track a real-world asset one-to-one.
Bitcoin hit a record of US$73,798 in March.

site_title: Singapore’s air freight up 20% in May; port’s box throughput highest this year
summary: Singapore's Changi Airport reported a 20% year-on-year jump in air freight to 170,000 tonnes in May, driven by e-commerce and spillover from ocean freight congestion. This is the second-highest monthly figure this year, following March's 176,000 tonnes. The January-to-May period saw a 14.9% year-on-year rise in freight to 803,000 tonnes.

images.alt_text: The Singapore Airlines (SIA) B747-400F aircraft is one of SIA’s seven freighters used for delivering essential items around the world. A distinctive feature of the SIA B747-400F freighter is the nose cargo door which can swing upwards, allowing exceptionally long items of over 50m in length to be loaded.

site_title: Thai central bank chief warns against inflation target reset
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput warned against raising the country's inflation target, citing the risk of unanchored expectations and quickening price gains, which could harm economic growth. The Bank of Thailand has rejected repeated calls from the government for rate cuts, instead advocating for structural reforms to spur growth. The central bank's inflation target range of 1-3% is currently in place, and any change could lead to higher borrowing costs and inflation.

images.alt_text: Thailand's Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin said that setting a new range for inflation may give more flexibility in reducing interest rates.
The Bank of Thailand’s (BOT) monetary policy committee voted 6-1 to hold the one-day repurchase rate at 2.5 per cent.
Customers at a store in Bangkok. The government has favoured cutting rates from a decade-high 2.5% to boost consumption and growth.
The BOT has previously said that rate cuts and fiscal stimulus would not help the economy much, and it favoured structural reforms to increase productivity.

site_title: Toyota shareholders re-elect chairman but question governance
summary: Toyota's chairman, Akio Toyoda, was re-elected at the company's annual meeting, but shareholders questioned governance and governance amid an ongoing probe of vehicle safety certifications. Toyoda vowed to rebuild customer trust and transfer authority to the factory floor. The re-election was seen as a referendum on the company's management and strategy, with some shareholders voting against Toyoda and CEO Koji Sato. The vote comes as Toyota faces criticism for its hybrid-only approach to electrification and certification issues among its affiliates.

images.alt_text: Toyota says shipment halts will impact two assembly lines responsible for the production of 130,000 units a year.
Toyota is also unwinding cross-shareholdings within its network of manufacturing partners.
Toyota, which has long prided itself on its reputation for safety and reliability, was the only automaker to undergo an on-site inspection.

epa11261494 A view of a Toyota dealership logo in Round Rock, Texas, USA, 05 April 2024. In the initial quarter, Toyota Motor North America (TMNA) disclosed sales figures of 565,098 vehicles, marking a 20.3 percent increase in volume and a 17.2 percent rise in DSR compared to March 2023. Electrified vehicle sales for the same period amounted to 206,850 units, constituting 36.6 percent of the total sales volume.  EPA-EFE/ADAM DAVIS

site_title: Meteoric rise of South Korea’s webtoons powers Nasdaq IPO
summary: South Korea's webtoon industry has seen explosive growth, with Webtoon Entertainment, owned by Naver, filing for a Nasdaq IPO valued at over $2.6 billion. The business, which has been around for 20 years, has become a billion-dollar industry, with creators earning up to $1 million annually. Webtoons have inspired successful K-dramas and film adaptations, including Netflix's "The 8 Show," and continue to gain popularity globally. The format allows for real-time storytelling and has become a cultural export for South Korea, with 170 million monthly active users worldwide.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The Google and YouTube logos are seen at the entrance to the Google offices in Los Angeles, California, November 21, 2019. Two US lawmakers appealed to YouTube on June 5, 2024 to restore a Hong Kong pro-democracy anthem, saying blocking video boosted authoritarianism and went beyond a local court order. YouTube last month said it was complying with a Hong Kong court order and would block access to 32 videos of "Glory to Hong Kong," originally written for protesters who took to the streets in a failed 2019 movement to stop China's stifling of the city's autonomy. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)
Netflix has been emphasising engagement time as a key metric, telling investors it is the “best proxy for customer satisfaction”.
Much of the rebound – up 34 per cent year to date – reflects Netflix’s success in reassuring investors about its ability to keep growing, even in mature markets.
The TV+ service is Apple’s answer to Netflix or Disney+, and the company has spent heavily on feeding it with original content.
Hollywood studios are keen to discuss ways to use AI to reduce costs while also protecting themselves from having their work stolen.
Analysts believe that the local telecoms industry is due for consolidation, which should help improve margins.

site_title: Thousands of Israelis turn out for anti-government protest
summary: Thousands of Israelis protested in Jerusalem on Monday against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's government over the ongoing Gaza war and failure to release hostages. The protest, part of a week of disturbance, called for a ceasefire and fresh elections. Protesters, including 73-year-old retired civil engineer Moshe Sandarovich, urged Netanyahu to prioritize the release of remaining hostages and an end to the conflict, with many saying it's time for equality and unity in the country.

images.alt_text: The longer route around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid attacks by Yemen’s Houthis has pushed up shipping costs, as about 12 per cent of world total shipping traffic historically sailed through the Red Sea and Egypt’s Suez Canal.

FILE PHOTO: Members of the U.N. Security Council vote on a U.S.-drafted resolution backing a proposal outlined by U.S.President Joe Biden for a ceasefire between Israel and Palestinian militants Hamas in the Gaza Strip, at U.N. headquarters in New York City, U.S., June 10, 2024. REUTERS/Stephanie Keith/File Photo
Flags of the G7 nations and the EU are seen at Castello Federiciano, the venue where the G7 summit's first dinner is scheduled to take place on Jun 13, in Brindisi, Italy.
The semiconductor giant has been present in Israel for fifty years, with the opening of a research centre in Haifa.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu (right) welcoming US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during a meeting in Jerusalem, June 10, 2024.
