site_title: EV maker Fisker files for bankruptcy after its glitchy SUV flops
summary: Fisker, an electric vehicle startup co-founded by Henrik Fisker, filed for bankruptcy on June 17, citing production issues and technical glitches with its Ocean SUV. The company listed between $500 million and $1 billion in assets and $100 million to $500 million in liabilities. Fisker struggled with production delays and software bugs, leading to a significant decrease in deliveries to customers. The company's bankruptcy follows other EV startups, including Charge Enterprises, Lordstown Motors, Proterra, and Electric Last Mile Solutions, as the industry faces slowing sales in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Fisker flagged substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern in February and paused investments in future projects until it secured a partnership with an automaker.

site_title: Asia: Markets rise with Wall Street as traders eye latest US data
summary: Asian markets rose on Tuesday, tracking a tech-driven record on Wall Street, with Tokyo and Taipei up over 1% and other cities experiencing healthy gains. Investors await US economic data to gauge inflation outlook and interest rate plans. The Federal Reserve's guidance on rate cuts this year will be closely watched, with analysts confident markets are well-positioned for gains.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 96 to 56.
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.1 per cent higher, coming off its worst weekly percentage fall so far this year.
The Nasdaq Composite Index led the major indices, climbing 1.0 per cent to 17,857.02 on Monday, a closing record for the sixth straight day.

site_title: At the Ambani wedding celebrations, a dazzling display of jewels
summary: Indian business magnate Mukesh Ambani's wedding celebrations featured an extravagant display of rare and historic Indian jewels, rivaling those of the Raj era. The jewels, including necklaces, earrings, and rings, were valued for their rarity and grandeur, with some pieces said to have been hidden by former royal families in the decades following India's nationalization of their treasuries. The display showcased the country's rich history of opulence in the jewel trade, with pieces like the Patiala Necklace featuring 2,930 diamonds and the Indore Pears, two closely matched diamonds owned by a former ruler.

images.alt_text: The Serpenti Aeterna necklace is the most precious high jewellery Bvlgari has ever crafted.
Tadao Ando x Serpenti pays tribute to the changing of the seasons.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Maybank reinitiates coverage on Sea with ‘buy’ call
summary: Maybank Securities has reinitiated coverage on Sea with a "buy" call and a target price of US$90, citing healthy revenue growth and scale advantages. The analyst estimates a 16% compound annual growth rate (CAGR) in revenue from 2023 to 2026, driven by growth in the logistics and livestreaming sectors. Sea's own logistics support over half of its gross merchandise value, providing superior unit economics and customer experience, according to the analyst.

images.alt_text: A pertinent growth driver for Shopee has been the expansion of its in-house logistics arm, SPX Express.
Sea chief executive Forrest Li said that the company has a “clear roadmap for profitable growth”.
Garena's performance has not been as glowing as before, with its potential a lot dimmer than Sea's other business units.

site_title: New private home sales dive 78.7% year on year in May amid market slump
summary: New private home sales plummeted 78.7% year-over-year in May, the lowest recorded since 2008, with 221 condo units sold. The slump is attributed to a lack of new launches, a seasonal mid-year lull, and sales sagging in recent months. Experts predict a subdued market until mortgage rates drop or government cooling measures ease. Primary market sales are forecast to drop to levels seen during the 1998 Asian Financial Crisis. Despite this, prices are expected to grow 3-4% in 2024, with a recovery in developers' sales not expected until 2025.

images.alt_text: The Council of Estate Agencies, the industry regulator, is investigating property agents who had facilitated transactions associated with the S$3 billion money laundering case.
The land plots at Dairy Farm Walk and Tengah Garden Avenue are on the confirmed list, while the Bayshore Road site sits on the reserve list.
Redeveloping bungalows into semi-detached and terrace houses can help meet demand for landed homes.

site_title: Is there a better use for Good Class Bungalow land?
summary: Singapore's Good Class Bungalow (GCB) areas, where large mansions are often reserved for the super-rich, may be better utilized by redeveloping them into high-density housing or smaller landed properties, according to some experts. This could optimize land usage and address housing needs. Meanwhile, a recent money laundering bust has highlighted the city's management of hot money flows through its banking system, with assets seized and put up for sale. Singapore's status as a wealth hub comes with high costs, including being the second most expensive city for expatriates.

images.alt_text: The landed property market seems to be stirring, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

As life expectancy rises, it may be prudent for any buyer seeking a private home to live in for the remainder of his life to pay more for a home with a sufficiently long remaining land lease, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
The latest ABSD hikes have hammered the market in prime areas, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
It’s no secret that suburban malls are strongholds for retail landlords, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Perhaps transparency and efficiency in HDB resale flat sales will improve with the launch of the HDB Flat Portal.

site_title: South Korea central bank chief says inflationary pressure easing
summary: South Korea's central bank governor, Rhee Chang-yong, stated that inflationary pressure is easing, with consumer inflation expected to continue slowing. The Bank of Korea is likely to cut interest rates by 50 basis points in the fourth quarter, supporting analysts' consensus. The central bank extended its interest rate pause for an 11th straight meeting, keeping rates restrictive after a 300 basis point increase since mid-2021. Headline inflation slowed to a 10-month low of 2.7% in May, and core inflation eased to 2.2% from 2.3% in April.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk on a zebra crossing in front of the buliding of Bank of Korea in Seoul, South Korea, July 14, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Boeing CEO to tell US Congress planemaker’s culture is ‘far from perfect’
summary: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun will tell a US Senate committee that the company's culture is "far from perfect" and is taking action to address concerns raised after a January mid-air emergency involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9. Calhoun stated that Boeing is committed to upholding aerospace safety and has taken steps to prevent similar incidents. The incident has intensified scrutiny of Boeing by regulators and airlines, and the company is in talks to reacquire Spirit AeroSystems. The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations will hold a hearing to discuss Boeing's safety culture and the company's response to the incident.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Boeing Chief Executive Dave Calhoun speaks during a press conference about a multibillion-dollar deal with Ryanair for as many as 300 Boeing jets at Boeing headquarters in Arlington, Virginia, U.S., May 9, 2023. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein/File Photo

FILE PHOTO: An exterior view of the Southern regional Federal Aviation Administration(FAA) building at Hartsfield-Jackson Atlanta International Airport is pictured after the FAA had ordered airlines to pause all domestic departures due to a system outage in Atlanta, Georgia, U.S., January 11, 2023. REUTERS/Alyssa Pointer/File Photo
Boeing investigates quality problem on undelivered 787s, sources say
Boeing has been under a microscope since a Jan 5 incident in which a 737 MAX operated by Alaska Airlines was forced to make an emergency landing after a fuselage panel blew out mid-flight.
United Airlines, a prominent customer of Boeing, has been hit by the planemaker’s safety crisis.
“Aviation needs a strong Boeing,” says Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson.

site_title: Malaysia preparing to join Brics economic group, media report says
summary: Malaysia is preparing to join the Brics economic group, according to Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim. The group, originally consisting of Brazil, Russia, India, China, and South Africa, has expanded its membership to include Saudi Arabia, Iran, Ethiopia, Egypt, Argentina, and the United Arab Emirates. Over 40 countries have expressed interest in joining the group, which aims to challenge the dominance of Western economies. Malaysia's membership would mark the country's entry into the group, which is seen as a significant step towards its economic integration with emerging markets.

images.alt_text: South African delegates sit behind a glass with BRICS logo as the BRICS summit is held in Johannesburg, South Africa August 23, 2023. REUTERS/Alet Pretorius

site_title: Hong Kong to allow trading during typhoons from late September
summary: Hong Kong to end its decades-long practice of shutting markets during typhoons, starting on September 25, allowing trading to continue during extreme weather. The decision, made by Chief Executive John Lee, follows broad support and aims to modernize the city's financial hub. Typically, five to eight typhoons hit Hong Kong each year, but not all bring disruptions. The change is expected to minimize lost flows through the Stock Connect link to Shanghai and Shenzhen markets.

site_title: These are the world’s most expensive cities for expats in 2024
summary: Hong Kong and Singapore have topped Mercer's 2024 Cost of Living report as the world's most expensive cities for expatriates, with high rental costs surpassing Zurich, Geneva, and other Swiss destinations. Rising housing costs and volatile inflation trends are putting pressure on expat workers' compensation packages, according to Mercer's global mobility leader. The report highlights the challenges of cost-of-living for multinational organizations and their employees, with some cities experiencing significant lifestyle adjustments or struggling to meet basic needs.

images.alt_text: Singapore is now the world's 6th most resilient city, thanks to an influx of people choosing to live and work in the city state, Savills said on Monday (Mar 25).

site_title: Economists expect tech upcycle to lift Singapore’s key exports in H2 after better-than-expected 0.1% slide in May
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 0.1% year-over-year in May, better than expected, driven by electronics growth. The sector's recovery is expected to continue lifting exports in the second half of 2024, driven by the global tech upswing. Despite this, downside risks such as geopolitical conflicts and supply chain disruptions may dampen the recovery. Economists forecast a recovery in NODX growth momentum in H2 2024, with electronics sector growth expected to support electronic production.

images.alt_text: Singapore NODX could come at ‘lower range of 4-6% forecast’: EnterpriseSG

Simulations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) have showed that even if the nominal exchange rate had not been raised, the Singapore dollar would still have appreciated similarly in real terms, chief economist Edward Robinson said.
On a seasonally adjusted monthly basis, NODX declined/grew x per cent in April.

site_title: Hot stock: Seatrium falls as much as 7.8% amid heavy trading
summary: Seatrium's shares fell as much as 7.8% on June 18, 2024, amid heavy trading after the company announced involvement in a joint investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department. The investigation is related to a decade-old bribery case in Brazil, known as "Operation Car Wash". Two former Seatrium executives, Wong Weng Sun and Lee Fook Kang, were charged with corruption and obstruction of justice. The company's shares traded near this level for the first time since May.

images.alt_text: Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Bank of Japan may raise rates in July depending on data, says Governor Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda said the central bank may raise interest rates in July, depending on economic and price data. The BOJ aims to sustainably hit its 2% inflation target, but Ueda emphasized the need for more time to scrutinize data before making a decision. The BOJ has already announced plans to trim its bond purchases and reduce its balance sheet, taking steps toward unwinding its monetary stimulus. The decision heightens uncertainty about whether the BOJ will hike short-term interest rates or hold off until later in the year.

site_title: Citi pitches money-moving ‘crown jewel’ as central to revamp
summary: Citi is focusing on its services business, a division that handles international payments and cash management, as a key area for growth and profitability. The segment has produced nearly half of the bank's profits last quarter and counts major clients such as Amazon and Uber. CEO Jane Fraser and CFO Mark Mason will pitch the division's potential to investors, highlighting its steady profit and competitive advantage. The move aims to boost the stock price, which has risen 17% this year, and prove the bank's turnaround strategy.

images.alt_text: Citigroup will now allow colleagues two weeks of paid leave annually to care for an immediate family member who’s seriously ill and incapable of self-care.
Some home offices will have to be listed with regulators as so-called “residential supervisory locations”.
Singapore’s commercial real estate market has defied a global property downturn, with office rents hitting a 15-year high in the first quarter.
Citi joins dozens of other financial institutions preparing for the shift.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Tuesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 0.2% to 3,303.77. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 96 to 56, with banking stocks leading the gains. The US market started the day strong, with the Nasdaq Composite Index reaching a record high. European markets also rebounded, with the pan-European Stoxx 600 closing up 0.1%.

site_title: Foxconn billionaire’s eight-year stock target finally comes true
summary: Foxconn Technology Group, the Taiwanese company co-founded by billionaire Terry Gou, has reached a stock price target of NT$200, a goal he had set in 2016. The company's shares have surged over 90% this year, driven by investor enthusiasm for artificial intelligence servers and potential for the latest Apple products. Hon Hai Precision Industry's strong performance is part of the island's contract manufacturers' transformation to higher-value-added offerings, including AI servers and electric vehicles. Gou's company is expected to report record revenue in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: Foxconn is the world’s biggest contract electronics maker and builds devices for several global brands, most notably Apple’s iPhone.
Foxconn, formally Hon Hai Precision Industry, is the world’s largest contract electronics manufacturer.

epa10924768 The logo of Foxconn during Hon Hai Technology Day (HHTD23) in Taipei, Taiwan, 18 October 2023. Foxconn showcased their EV line up, including their new Model N cargo van and signaled mass production plans for Model B, a 'sporty and intelligent crossover'.  EPA-EFE/RITCHIE B. TONGO

site_title: New York City hikes prices 2.75% for rent-stabilised apartments
summary: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board voted to increase rent prices for rent-stabilised apartments by 2.75% for one-year leases and 5.25% for two-year leases, starting October 1 or later. This marks the third consecutive year of price increases for tenants, who face rising costs and are already rent-burdened. The increases are larger than market-rate apartment prices, with median asking rent up 2% in May. The decision has been met with criticism from tenants' groups and property owners, who argue that the prices are unsustainable and do not cover inflation.

images.alt_text: The total value of the condos is about US$100 million, according to Madison 33 Partners’ bankruptcy petition.
The city plans to add 200,000 households to the list.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Great Eastern, Seatrium, ST Engineering, OUE Reit, Sasseur Reit, Sabana Reit
summary: OCBC's privatisation offer for Great Eastern Holdings is deemed reasonable by an independent financial adviser, despite being a 30% discount to the company's embedded value. Meanwhile, Seatrium faces a joint investigation by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Commercial Affairs Department regarding a decade-old bribery case. ST Engineering wins ammunition orders worth over $100 million from Europe, while OUE Reit issues $250 million green notes at a 4.1% fixed rate. Sasseur Reit and Sabana Reit also see developments, with Sasseur Reit confident in its long-term growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares fall amid mixed regional showing; STI down 0.8%

site_title: Gold prices edge higher as US Treasury yields soften
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,320.60 per ounce, driven by lower US Treasury yields. The benchmark 10-year US Treasury yield fell to 4.2673%, making non-yielding gold more attractive to investors. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut its benchmark interest rate this year, with Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker stating that a rate cut is possible if his economic forecast is realized. Investors will focus on upcoming comments from Federal Reserve officials and economic data releases, including US retail sales data and jobless claims.

images.alt_text: Asian gold markets have been boosted by central banks’ gold purchases and investors’ healthy buying, despite price surges.

site_title: Sabana Reit manager, trustee deny allegations that bond issuance impedes internalisation or is ‘highly abnormal’
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust's manager and trustee have denied allegations that the trust's upcoming sustainability-linked bond issuance could put it in "financial jeopardy" or impede its internalisation process. Quarz Capital alleged the bond issuance was "highly abnormal" and could result in "substantial disruptions" if the sponsor ceases to hold at least 50.1% of the Reit manager. The manager and trustee responded, stating the bond issuance was planned to diversify funding sources and mitigate refinancing risks, and that it is a common practice to plan ahead for refinancings.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio. The Reit's trustee intends to hold an EGM at a date to be determined.
Tenant of 30 & 32 Tuas Avenue 8, GDMC, accounted for about 2.4 per cent of Sabana Reit's total gross rental income for the financial year ended 31 Dec, 2023.
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio; the Reit manager said the letter contained "unsubstantiated allegations".

site_title: Have fewer GCBs, more semi-detached and terrace homes to better meet landed housing dreams
summary: Singapore's government may consider redeveloping landed homes in Good Class Bungalow (GCB) Areas into semi-detached and terrace houses to meet demand for landed housing. Despite the absence of GCBs, the super-rich may still choose to live in Singapore due to its stability, ease of doing business, and other amenities. Redesignating GCB Areas for mixed-landed homes could help optimize land use and encourage local residents to own landed homes, potentially leading to a more interesting urban landscape and multi-generational living. Taxing GCB owners based on land area may also be a strategy to discourage ownership of large landed homes.

images.alt_text: The newly built bungalow in Bin Tong Park has a built-up area of about 18,000 sq ft.
The sale comes after Singapore’s high-end property market saw a tepid 2023, dented by a major money laundering scandal and high interest rates.
The house Liqian Ma, is buying has a long driveway.

site_title: China’s surge in solar and hydro point to early carbon peak
summary: China's carbon emissions have surged, with power generation from fossil fuels dropping 4.3% in May and hydroelectric output jumping 39% after heavy rains. Solar energy also saw a 29% increase. These numbers suggest China may have peaked its emissions years before its 2030 target, but a rapid decline in emissions is crucial to meet its 2060 goal of zeroing out emissions. However, the trajectory of China's economy and other factors such as metals production and infrastructure spending could offset the gains made in power generation, and grid constraints and industry crises may hinder the adoption of renewables.

images.alt_text: Some sectors are more sensitive to sustainability themes than others. The energy sector, for instance, requires investors to be concerned about carbon emissions.
Singapore's three local banks observed a rise in sustainable loan financing to SMEs.
Aerial view of the construction site of the Jawa 9 & 10 power plant in Banten Province, west of Jakarta. Indonesia.

site_title: Australia will launch ‘holistic’ payments review under new remit
summary: Australia's central bank is modernizing its regulatory framework for retail payments with a "holistic review" of the sector. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) will regulate newer players, including payment gateways and digital wallet providers, and focus on issues such as transparency of payment services, merchant payment costs, and mobile wallet fees. The review aims to set regulatory priorities for the next few years and address growing online retail payments, with 40% of consumer payments made online in 2022. The reforms are expected to promote competition that benefits end users.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Qiang’s visit is the first trip to Australia by a Chinese leader of his seniority since 2017.
The Australia listing comes as US$58 billion has been amassed by US Bitcoin ETFs that debuted this year.
The Reserve Bank of Australia meets next week and is widely expected to hold interest rates at 4.35 per cent for a fifth straight meeting.

site_title: Serial Achieva seeks access to capital markets to grow regional IT distribution business
summary: Serial Achieva, a Singapore-based IT products distributor, is seeking access to capital markets through a reverse takeover transaction with Catalist-listed Axington Inc. The deal aims to expand into the enterprise space, particularly in South-east Asia, where Serial Achieva currently has a presence in Malaysia and Thailand. Chairman Sean Goh hopes the listing will shine a light on Achieva's potential as a separate business, enabling the company to tap capital markets for funds. The transaction is expected to be completed on June 27.

images.alt_text: Axington warned that any cash exit offer to shareholders will be “highly unlikely” in the event it is not granted the time extension and will be delisted from SGX-ST.

Serial System notes in a filing to the Singapore Exchange that the net loss is primarily due to loss allowance for trade receivables, net foreign exchange loss, inventory obsolescence and higher interest expenses.

site_title: YouTube tests context ‘notes’ feature for videos
summary: YouTube is testing a new "notes" feature on mobile devices, initially available to US users in English. The feature allows users to add context to videos, such as clarifying song parodies or pointing out product updates. Third-party evaluators will rate the helpfulness of notes to train the system, with a potential broader rollout planned. This feature is similar to X's Community Notes, which allows select contributors to add context to posts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Silhouettes of laptop and mobile device users are seen next to a screen projection of the YouTube logo in this picture illustration taken March 28, 2018.  REUTERS/Dado Ruvic//File Photo

site_title: Trafigura agrees to pay US$55 million to settle CFTC charges
summary: Trafigura Trading has agreed to pay a US$55 million civil fine to settle US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) charges of fraud, manipulation, and impeding whistleblower communications. The firm allegedly traded petrol with material non-public information, manipulated an oil pricing benchmark, and required employees to sign agreements that barred them from sharing company information. Trafigura neither admitted nor denied the findings, and has agreed to modify its non-disclosure provisions to boost its compliance program.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trafigura logo is seen in this illustration taken, April 23, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: US Surgeon General calls for social media warning labels to protect adolescents
summary: US Surgeon General Vivek Murthy calls for a warning label to be added to social media apps to protect adolescents from harm, citing shortened attention spans, negative body images, and online bullying. A warning label alone won't make social media safe, but it can increase awareness and change behavior. The US Congress would need to pass legislation requiring the label. This proposal comes amid growing concerns about social media's impact on young people, with some states already passing legislation to safeguard children from social media's effects.

images.alt_text: Meta has been pouring significant resources into AI technology in an effort to keep pace with other tech giants.
Meta will train its large language models using content that people in the European Union have chosen to share publicly on its platforms such as Instagram, Facebook.
Meta has been ramping up efforts to earn money off WhatsApp, its biggest app in terms of daily users.

(FILES) The Google and YouTube logos are seen at the entrance to the Google offices in Los Angeles, California, November 21, 2019. Two US lawmakers appealed to YouTube on June 5, 2024 to restore a Hong Kong pro-democracy anthem, saying blocking video boosted authoritarianism and went beyond a local court order. YouTube last month said it was complying with a Hong Kong court order and would block access to 32 videos of "Glory to Hong Kong," originally written for protesters who took to the streets in a failed 2019 movement to stop China's stifling of the city's autonomy. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)
TikTok did not detail the exploit used by attackers, but media reports indicated it involved a direct messaging feature.
AFP, among more than a dozen other fact-checking organisations, is paid by TikTok in several countries to verify videos that potentially contain false information.
Donald Trump is in a close race with Democratic incumbent Joe Biden ahead of the Nov 5 presidential election.

site_title: Singapore-based Trafigura tops inaugural Fortune 500 ranking for S-E Asia
summary: Trafigura, a Singapore-based commodity trader, tops the inaugural Fortune 500 ranking for South-east Asia with sales of $244 billion. Four other Singapore-based companies, including Wilmar, Olam, Flex, and DBS, also made the top 10 list. The ranking includes companies from seven nations in the region, with Indonesia dominating the list. The top 10 companies reported revenues of $650 billion, accounting for more than a third of the total revenues of the Southeast Asia 500 companies, which reported $1.8 trillion in revenue for fiscal year 2023.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Trafigura logo is pictured in the company entrance in Geneva, Switzerland March 11, 2012. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

Weaker Q1 earnings seen for Singapore banks amid volatility, lower risk appetites

Trafigura Beheer BV, the parent company of Trafigura Group during the relevant period, has agreed to pay a criminal fine of US$80.5 million and forfeit another US$46.5 million after pleading guilty to a conspiracy to violate the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act.
Shaken by spiking commodities, trading houses adapt to survive
The agreements with employees illegally impeded them from voluntarily communication with the CFTC’s enforcement staff during their investigation.

site_title: Apple to discontinue ‘buy now, pay later’ service in US as it plans new loan programme
summary: Apple plans to discontinue its "buy now, pay later" service, Apple Pay Later, in the US and replace it with a new loan programme. Existing users with open loans will still be able to manage and pay them through the Wallet app. The new programme will offer instalment loans through credit, debit cards, and lenders when checking out with Apple Pay, starting later this year. This move aims to provide flexible payments to more users worldwide in collaboration with Apple Pay-enabled banks and lenders.

site_title: Tesla sues ex-supplier over EV battery trade secrets
summary: Tesla has filed a lawsuit against Matthews International, alleging the supplier stole trade secrets related to its battery-manufacturing process. Tesla claims Matthews shared the secrets with competitors, including selling machines embodying the trade secrets, and claimed them as its own in patent filings. The lawsuit seeks to block Matthews from misusing the trade secrets, hand over patent applications, and request over $1 billion in monetary damages.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Tesla factory is seen in Fremont, California, U.S. June 22, 2018. REUTERS/Stephen Lam/File Photo

site_title: Mbappe breaks nose as France win Euro 2024 opener, Slovakia stun Belgium
summary: France edged Austria 1-0 in their Euro 2024 opener, with Maximilian Woeber scoring an own goal 7 minutes before halftime. Meanwhile, Slovakia stunned Belgium 1-0, while Romania beat Ukraine 3-0. France's Kylian Mbappe suffered a broken nose in the game and is uncertain to play in the next match. The results give France top of Group D with 3 points, tied with the Netherlands, while Austria, Belgium, and Ukraine trail behind.

images.alt_text: Southgate's contract expires after Euro 2024 and there have been reports that the Football Association would like him to stay and lead England into the 2026 World Cup.
Ronaldo has invested in a range of businesses in recent years as he prepares for life after his sports career.
Jamal Musiala is named man of the match and praises German fans for getting his side off to a flyer.

site_title: Tether announces a new synthetic dollar that is backed by gold
summary: Tether Holdings has introduced a new synthetic dollar, Tether Gold, backed by physical gold stored in Switzerland, with a market capitalization of about $573 million. The token, created on the Alloy by Tether platform, will trade as aUSDT via smart contracts on the Ethereum Mainnet blockchain. Tether aims to expand beyond its USDT stablecoin, a token backed by US Treasury bills and other securities, and plans to allow for the creation of other tethered assets. The new offering highlights Tether's ambitions to stabilize assets through over-collateralization and secondary market liquidity pools.

images.alt_text: Tether's investment plan highlights the growing financial clout and ambition of the issuer of the world’s largest stablecoin, a type of cryptocurrency designed to track a real-world asset one-to-one.
The agreement marks a major step forward for Tether in its plan to become a major Bitcoin miner.
Stablecoins can be used as a form of payment, as well as to convert in and out of other tokens, such as Bitcoin when trading on crypto exchanges.

Tether, a cryptocurrency pegged to the US dollar, and blockchain analytics company Chainalysis have launched new tools to identify transactions associated with sanctioned entities and analyse the activity of major holders of the token.

site_title: China to include Australia in visa waiver programme, Premier Li Qiang says
summary: China will include Australia in its visa waiver program, allowing citizens to enter China for tourism, business, and visiting family members without a visa for up to five years. Premier Li Qiang announced the move during a meeting with Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, following a series of high-level talks to strengthen relations between the two countries. The agreement comes after seven years of diplomatic tensions, with China and Australia signing five agreements on education, cultural exchanges, and trade.

images.alt_text: A sputtering recovery in the world’s second-biggest economy has driven a record-breaking rally in Chinese government bonds over the past few months.
The People's Bank of China has repeatedly hinted at its discomfort over the bond rally in the past few months as long-term yields touched two-decade lows.
Funding for property developers has stayed weak since China's government drew up a “white list” of property firms that are eligible for loans late last year.
Since households have been reluctant to spend, China has turned to export-led growth instead.

site_title: Hyundai Motor shares hit record high as investors bet on India IPO
summary: Hyundai Motor's shares hit a record high of 285,000 won (S$280) after investors bet on the company's plan to list its India unit in Mumbai. The IPO, which could be the nation's biggest, will see Hyundai Motor sell a stake of up to 17.5% in the company. The shares rose 3.9% to close at a record high, lifting the market capitalization to 58.3 trillion won. Analysts believe investors are betting on Hyundai Motor's growth in the Indian market, which could accelerate plans for the region, including electric vehicle production.

images.alt_text: Hyundai Motor India will be the country’s first car maker to go public in two decades since Maruti Suzuki in 2003.
Hyundai Motor India is India’s second-biggest carmaker by sales.
Hyundai Motor India plans to file for an IPO in June.

site_title: IMF calls for stronger social safety net to 'broaden' gains from AI
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) recommends that governments implement stronger social safety nets to mitigate the negative effects of generative AI, which could exacerbate job losses among white-collar professions. To achieve this, the IMF suggests raising additional revenue and supporting people who lose their jobs through more generous unemployment insurance and sector-based training. The organization opposes a special tax on AI products, instead advocating for corporate tax breaks that encourage productivity growth and strengthening taxes on capital income to offset rising wealth inequality.

images.alt_text: Even before generative AI technology started being widely leveraged as a tool to drive more crime, cyberattacks in 2024 were already trending upwards
FILE PHOTO: Adobe logo is seen on smartphone in this illustration taken June 13, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

Newsrooms globally are working to address a new challenge with generative artificial intelligence, as tech giants and startups like Google and OpenAI build tools that can offer summaries of information and siphon traffic from news websites.
Meta has been pouring significant resources into AI technology in an effort to keep pace with other tech giants.

site_title: AI whistleblowers are stepping up; it’s about time
summary: Thirteen former OpenAI and Google DeepMind employees have published an open letter calling for greater accountability in artificial intelligence. The letter highlights the need for whistleblowers to be able to raise concerns about AI risks without fear of financial reprisal. In response, OpenAI has dropped non-disparagement agreements for its past employees, allowing them to speak out about AI harms. Britain's AI Safety Institute, a government-backed organization, has also been established to test AI models for national-security risks and has secured agreements from leading tech companies. This shift towards greater oversight is a promising step towards making AI more accountable.

images.alt_text: US Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer speaking on bipartisan efforts to create Senate AI policy at a press conference in Washington, DC, USA, on May 15, 2024.

The artificial intelligence (AI) summit in Seoul this week aims to build on a broad agreement at the first conference held in the United Kingdom six months ago and to better address a wider array of risks.

Multiple senior leaders had privately shared grave concerns with the former OpenAI board, saying they believed that CEO Sam Altman cultivated “a toxic culture of lying” and engaged in “behaviour (that) can be characterised as psychological abuse”.
The national AI strategy advocates a “pragmatic approach”: supporting experimentation and innovation, while still ensuring that AI is developed and used responsibly.
Earlier this month, leading AI developers agreed to work with governments to test new frontier models before they are released to help manage the risks of the rapidly developing technology.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch up as banks, tech rebound; Topdanmark shines
summary: European shares rose 0.1% on Monday, rebounding from last week's worst weekly percentage fall, as banks and technology stocks advanced. The Stoxx 600 index hit a six-week low earlier in the session, but recovered as top Danish insurer Topdanmark surged 22.2% after a buyout bid. Markets were under pressure after French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap election, but uncertainty is expected to linger until voting intentions and party platforms are clear.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite Index led the major indices, climbing 1.0 per cent to 17,857.02 on Monday, a closing record for the sixth straight day.

site_title: GameStop shares tumble after CEO says store network will shrink
summary: GameStop shares plummeted 11.6% to $25.38 after CEO Ryan Cohen revealed plans to shrink the store network and boost sales with "a smaller network and more value-added" items. Cohen did not provide details on using the company's $4 billion cash pile. Analysts were expecting more strategic plans to revitalize the business. Despite a 36% profit margin in recent filings, competition remains intense and the used software market is drying up, leading to a decline in sales.

images.alt_text: The company’s last shareholder meeting in June 2023 took less than 15 minutes and included a brief statement from CEO Ryan Cohen.

GameStop, which largely relies on brick-and-mortar stores and has been grappling with customers turning to e-commerce firms for buying video games and collectibles.
GameStop has surged over 160 per cent in 2024.

GameStop, widely regarded as the first meme stock, is a video game retailer struggling to adapt in an era dominate by online commerce and digital downloads. Its sales are expected to drop by dougle digits.
GameStop shares are trading almost 68 per cent below their January 2021 peak.

site_title: US Supreme Court to hear Nvidia bid to scuttle shareholder lawsuit
summary: The US Supreme Court agreed to hear Nvidia's appeal to dismiss a securities fraud lawsuit accusing the company of misleading investors about the impact of cryptomining on its revenue growth. The lawsuit, led by a Stockholm-based investment firm, claims Nvidia and its CEO Jensen Huang made false statements about crypto-related purchases in 2017 and 2018. The 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals revived the case, and Nvidia urges the justices to take up its appeal, arguing it would lead to "abusive and speculative litigation".

Broadcom is widely considered to be making custom chips for Google and Meta.

Apple unveiled an improved Siri virtual assistant that can answer a wider range of queries and accomplish more complicated tasks than earlier versions.

The iPhone is by far Apple’s biggest business, accounting for more than half its fiscal 2023 revenue.

site_title: G7 summit success shows West can still lead
summary: The G7 summit in Italy has delivered significant geopolitical wins, with Western leaders delivering a series of big announcements on Ukraine, China, and the Global South. A $50 billion G7 loan to Ukraine was announced, using profits from frozen Russian assets, and a 10-year bilateral agreement with the US was signed, seen as a potential transition point for Ukraine to join NATO. The G7 also issued a stark warning to China over its support for Russia, threatening more sanctions if Beijing continues to transfer defense-related materials.

images.alt_text: Flags representing the participants of the Group of Seven (G-7) leaders summit at the Borgo Egnazia resort in Savelletri, Italy, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. Buildings damaged by shelling in Orikhiv, Ukraine. The country has released a  recovery plan for not only rebuilding but also transforming itself.

site_title: New Zealand economy seen exiting recession by a whisker
summary: New Zealand's economy narrowly exited recession in the first quarter with a 0.1% growth in gross domestic product, according to economists' forecasts. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) maintains a restrictive monetary policy to curb demand and control inflation, despite a tourism recovery and record immigration. Consumer confidence has slumped, businesses are pessimistic, and the services sector is in its deepest contraction in nearly three years. Most economists expect the RBNZ to cut interest rates in the fourth quarter, possibly sooner than initially projected.

images.alt_text: Houses in the Lyall Bay suburb of Wellington, New Zealand, on Saturday, Nov. 28, 2020. A housing frenzy at the bottom of the world is laying bare the perils of ultra-low interest rates. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg
New Zealand finance minister Nicola Willis presents the budget at Parliament in Wellington, New Zealand, May 30, 2024.
The survey’s headline measure showed a net 11.2 per cent of respondents expected the economy to improve over the year ahead, versus a 14.9 per cent optimism level in the previous poll in April.

site_title: US: Nasdaq, S&P 500 close at new record highs
summary: US stocks closed at new record highs, with the Nasdaq Composite Index leading the way, climbing 1.0% to 17,857.02, a sixth consecutive day at a record. The S&P 500 also reached an all-time high, rising 0.8% to 5,473.23, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.5%. Enthusiasm over artificial intelligence and recent share price gains of tech companies like Apple, Microsoft, and Nvidia fueled the rally, with some analysts pointing to improved US monetary policy expectations.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians walk along Wall Street near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, May 16, 2024. The Dow Jones Industrial Average eclipsed 40,000 for the first time on Thursday as investors grow confident that the stock market rally can keep running on hopes the Federal Reserve will start cutting interest rates later this year. Photographer: Alex Kent/Bloomberg
The funds were net sellers of US equities last week, with the selling largely in macro products such as index funds and exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Lagarde says ECB is watching markets after French turbulence
summary: ECB President Christine Lagarde stated that the central bank is "attentive" to financial market developments, following a week of turmoil in France that wiped $258 billion from market capitalization. Despite her colleague Philip Lane's reassurance that the market dynamics are "orderly," Lagarde expressed concern, while ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos warned of illiberal movements threatening European integration. The ECB sees no cause for alarm and remains committed to its inflation target of 2% by 2025.

images.alt_text: Philip Lane, chief economist of the European Central Bank, reiterates the bank's confidence in bringing consumer-price growth back to the 2 per cent target in the second half of 2025
The ECB projects inflation to return to 2 per cent in the final quarter of next year.

site_title: Berkshire Hathaway sells HK$310.5 million of shares in China's BYD
summary: Berkshire Hathaway, owned by Warren Buffett, sold 1.3 million shares of electric-vehicle maker BYD for HK$310.5 million, reducing its holdings to 6.9% of BYD's issued H-shares. The sale occurred on June 11, marking the latest step in Berkshire's reduction of its stake in BYD, which was finalized in 2008.

site_title: Oil jumps, settles at highest in over a month on demand optimism
summary: Oil prices surged to their highest settlement levels in over a month, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rising by 2.4% to $80.33 a barrel, and global benchmark Brent crude gaining 2% to $84.25 a barrel. The gains were driven by optimism over improving demand forecasts and reassurances from Opec+ about its production plan, which could be paused or reversed based on market conditions. This followed last week's first weekly gain in four weeks, as investors repurchased petroleum and economic data from China supported hopes of stronger oil demand.

images.alt_text: Energy Secretary Jennifer Granholm says the US could hasten the rate of replenishing the strategic oil stockpile as maintenance is completed by the end of the year.

site_title: Family office growth continues as new generation of super rich seeks professional management
summary: Singapore remains a global wealth hub, attracting Asian families seeking international investment opportunities. A growing number of high net worth individuals, particularly in Asia, are forming family offices to manage their wealth, driven by demands for transparency, technology, and international presence. This trend is expected to continue, with families allocating more assets to their region, including China. Private equity funds and direct investments in Asia are also gaining popularity, with family offices seen as a smart and long-term source of capital for companies.

images.alt_text: Family office is a broad label used to describe an organisation set up to manage the wealth and affairs of rich clans.
Family offices are typically run by a CEO or chief investment officer and as many as 10 staff members.

Dubai’s reputation as a choice destination for wealthy families fleeing hostile regimes or wars has surged in recent years, exemplified by the Russian money that flooded in following the invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: India and US to address barriers to trade and cooperation
summary: India and the US have committed to addressing barriers to bilateral trade, technology, and industrial cooperation, amid mutual concerns about China's rise in the Indo-Pacific region. A new strategic semiconductor partnership and co-investment plans were announced, including a lithium resource project and a rare earths deposit. The two countries also agreed to conclude a bilateral critical minerals pact and discussed co-production of land warfare systems.

images.alt_text: “Uniting countries who are partners and non-partners is a difficult mission in itself for Ukraine, when the war is not in its first month,” Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy said.

In the draft, leaders of Britain, Canada, France, Italy, Germany, Japan and the US promised sanctions against entities that helped Russia circumvent sanctions on its oil by transporting it fraudulently.

G7,  European Council and European Commission leaders at the start of their summit on June 13, at

site_title: Hedge funds turn cautious on stocks even as Wall Street strategists get bullish
summary: Hedge funds have become increasingly cautious about US equities due to the Federal Reserve's reluctance to cut interest rates, softer economic data, and narrow stock market breadth. Despite Wall Street strategists raising their year-end targets for the S&P 500, hedge funds decreased their long-short gross leverage, selling macro products and buying single stocks for the first time in six weeks. The funds are concerned about trade-down risk and the state of the low-end consumer, and are now seeking more selective investments.

images.alt_text: Notable M&A deals include ConocoPhillips’ US$22.5 billion offer for Marathon Oil in May.
Chinese banks, with 220,000 outlets nationwide, have long been distributors for financial products from insurance policies to mutual funds to earn fees.

site_title: How worrying is the rapid rise of Chinese science?
summary: China's science and innovation are rapidly progressing, making it a leading scientific power, particularly in chemistry, physics, and materials science. Chinese researchers produce more highly cited papers and contribute to cutting-edge research. The country's advanced laboratories and talent pool, including researchers who studied or worked in the West, are driving innovation. China's commercial innovation is also on the rise, with state-of-the-art batteries and electric vehicles. However, China's innovation is inefficient due to the state's heavy hand in guiding research spending. America should focus on sharpening its own innovative edge, rather than trying to constrain Chinese science, by enhancing openness, academic collaboration, and market mechanisms.

site_title: India considering personal tax rate cuts to boost consumption, sources say
summary: India's government is considering lowering personal tax rates for individuals earning over 1.5 million rupees (S$24,287) annually, aiming to boost consumption and increase savings for the middle class. This move comes as voters expressed concerns about inflation, unemployment, and decreasing incomes in a post-poll survey. The plan could be announced in July as part of the first federal Budget after the Bharatiya Janata Party failed to win a majority on its own.

site_title: A bird flu pandemic in people? Here’s what it might look like
summary: A bird flu pandemic in people is a potential threat, despite no efficient person-to-person transmission of the H5N1 virus. Accumulating evidence from animal studies suggests the virus could spread among people if it acquires the necessary mutations. The US has seen three farmworkers infected, with mostly mild symptoms, and no forms of the virus have spread efficiently among humans. Experts warn that a human-to-human version could spread rapidly, and that the severity of illness depends on various factors such as age, exposure to virus, and genetic background. Vaccines are being developed, but a sufficient supply may not be available for months.

site_title: Malaysia-based AGX Singapore carves niche in aerospace logistics
summary: Malaysia-based AGX Singapore is carving a niche in aerospace logistics, aiming to benefit from the booming sector and China+1 strategy. Managing director Mark Penu notes that AOG logistics services are critical, as every minute a plane sits on the tarmac means money lost for airline operators. The company's specialized segment offers fat margins of up to 35% due to the high demand for parts and engines. AGX Singapore operates in Southeast Asia, including Singapore, the Philippines, and other countries, capitalizing on the region's strategic location.

site_title: Paytm is in talks with Zomato to sell movie, ticketing business
summary: Paytm, an Indian fintech firm, is in talks with Zomato to sell its movie and ticketing business, a non-core asset that would allow Paytm to focus on payment and financial services. The deal, if successful, would be margin-accretive for Zomato, valued at 20 billion rupees, and would enable Paytm to revive sales hurt by a regulatory crackdown. Paytm has vowed to trim non-core assets and focus on travel, deals, and cash-backs to broaden its merchant base and grow sales.

site_title: Private equity won’t stop gorging on debt to pay investors
summary: Private equity firms are relying on dividend recaps, where they refinance debt to pay investors, due to a lack of mergers and acquisitions (M&As) and initial public offerings (IPOs). $30.2 billion of leveraged loans were sold in the first half of 2024, matching 2021 levels. This approach increases debt and leverage, making it harder for companies to cope in slow economies. Despite concerns, debt investors are snapping up leveraged loans to fund investor payouts, driving spreads tighter and fueling the trend.

site_title: Upskilling to stay resilient
summary: Singaporean SMEs face growing pressure to upskill their workforce due to rapid technological advancements transforming job roles. Experts emphasize the need for critical thinking, problem-solving, and creativity skills to remain competitive. Digital technology, such as AI and cloud computing, is a key driver of economic growth, but SMEs struggle to adapt due to limited resources and operational redundancies. Key strategies for upskilling include securing management buy-in, leveraging government grants, and setting up a company training committee. SMEs must prioritize skill gaps, establish a culture of learning, and foster an open mindset towards talent management to remain competitive.

site_title: UBS begins major share buyback programme
summary: UBS has initiated a share buyback programme worth up to US$1 billion this year, repurchasing 44.8 million Swiss francs worth of shares last week. The programme aims to reduce the proportion of stock held by investors and return cash to shareholders, potentially sending the shares higher. Analysts attribute the move to the bank's takeover of Credit Suisse last year, as share buybacks and dividends are seen as a reason for investors to put money into UBS stock.

site_title: Asian gold buying spree burnishing Singapore’s status as precious metals hub
summary: Singapore is solidifying its position as a key precious metals hub in Asia, driven by central banks' gold purchases and investors' healthy buying despite price surges. The country's proximity to emerging gold markets, political stability, and favorable tax regime are attracting investors, with Asian retail and institutional investors stocking up on physical gold and gold-backed ETFs. China leads the buying spree, with the People's Bank of China buying gold for 18 consecutive months. Singapore's logistics infrastructure, including refining and vaulting facilities, is also being developed to meet growing demand.

site_title: China EV makers: Who’s ahead in the race so far?
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker BYD is expected to remain the top EV maker in China for at least the next two years, despite a European Union tariff hike on its exports. BYD's exports to Europe can still make a net profit margin of 8.6% or 13.8% even with a 30% or 80% tariff increase. Analysts from Citi and other firms, including Morningstar and S&P Global Ratings, are bullish on BYD's prospects, citing its cost advantages, diversified offerings, and proprietary technologies. Other Chinese EV makers, such as Geely Automobile, Li Auto, and Nio, are also expected to perform well, but with varying degrees of success.

site_title: Why markets like to see new political faces
summary: Mexico's president-elect Claudia Sheinbaum's victory has raised concerns about a potential shift towards a socialist agenda, sparking market reactions. Sharp market fluctuations have been observed in India, Mexico, and South Africa, with questions about the economic impact of different government compositions. The article suggests that companies are seeking new, non-incumbent leaders, and that market reactions to elections may be influenced by the desire for change and fresh faces, rather than just the ideology of the party in power.

site_title: Canadian housing market suffers ‘sleepy month’ ahead of rate cut
summary: Canada's housing market experienced a 0.6% decline in sales in May, with the benchmark home price falling 0.2% to C$714,300. The slump is attributed to high interest rates, which reached 20-year highs, making buying more difficult. Ahead of the Bank of Canada's interest rate cut in May, the market is expected to recover, with buyers having more options as newly listed properties increased 0.5% in May. Experts anticipate further rate cuts, which could ease housing affordability issues.

summary: European Union leaders will discuss and decide on top jobs at a June 27-28 summit, with Ursula von der Leyen seemingly on track for a second term as European Commission head. Von der Leyen's European People's Party won the EU Parliament elections, cementing her bid for five more years in charge. French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz have weakened, and the EU is looking for geographic and political balance in the top jobs. A consensus is emerging, with von der Leyen needing support from 15 of 27 countries for a qualified majority.

site_title: Foreign investors raise China onshore bond holdings in May
summary: Foreign investors in China raised their onshore bond holdings for the ninth consecutive month in May, reaching 4.22 trillion yuan. This increase was driven by a rally in short-term debt instruments, with foreign institutions holding 457 billion yuan in negotiable certificates of deposits. Despite a record-breaking rally in Chinese government bonds, yields on 30-year bonds decreased by as much as 40 basis points this year. The yield gap between US and China's 10-year Treasuries remains substantial, exerting pressure on bond inflows.

site_title: GameStop's fans await shareholder meeting, after high demand derailed first attempt
summary: GameStop's annual shareholder meeting is set for Monday, June 17, amid high demand and speculation among retail investor fans. The meeting comes after Keith Gill, aka Roaring Kitty, reappeared and disclosed a large position in GameStop, causing the stock to gyrate wildly. The previous meeting in June 2023 took less than 15 minutes, and it's unclear what issues will be discussed this time. Analysts and investors are speculating about Gill's potential presence or online participation, and some have created memes ahead of the meeting.

site_title: High stakes in petrodollar 2.0 deal proposal
summary: The US-Saudi Arabia petrodollar agreement, which expired on June 9, 1974, was a 50-year-old deal that allowed the US to finance its deficit by buying oil from Saudi Arabia and recycling the dollars into US Treasury bills. The agreement was signed in 1974 and was crucial in maintaining the US dollar as the world's reserve currency. A new security and economic cooperation pact between Riyadh and Washington is reportedly close to being finalized, with the goal of maintaining the greenback's dominance amidst growing global economic shifts.

site_title: Home-swopping becoming trendy alternative to Airbnb
summary: Home-swapping, a long-overlooked travel alternative to Airbnb, is gaining popularity amid high inflation and rising hotel rates. Home exchange companies like HomeExchange, ThirdHome, and Kindred have seen double-digit growth in 2023, with Kindred experiencing an 800% year-over-year increase in home swops. The models involve users earning "credits" for hosting others, redeemable for stays elsewhere. To mitigate risks, these platforms vet members and offer host protection. Developers are also partnering with home-swapping platforms to offer free memberships to new vacation home buyers, driving growth and attracting more users.

site_title: Oil spill incident: Singapore fish farms in Johor Strait not affected, local fish safe to eat, says SFA
summary: A June 14 incident involving a Netherlands-flagged dredging boat and a Singapore-flagged bunker vessel resulted in an oil spill at Pasir Panjang Terminal. The oil leak caused no significant impact on local fish farms in the Johor Strait, where Singapore's fish farms are located, and local fish remains safe to eat, according to the Singapore Food Agency (SFA). The SFA is monitoring the situation closely and has reported no significant wildlife casualties. The cleanup efforts are ongoing.

site_title: India's 'heat trap' cities make summers worse, says government official
summary: India's cities are becoming "heat traps" due to unbalanced growth and increasing greenhouse emissions, exacerbating the country's scorching summer. Most states have implemented heat action plans, but there's no clear mandate for long-term strategies. The India Meteorological Department has forecast above-normal temperatures for June, with Delhi experiencing record-high temperatures. Climate change, urban growth, and reduced water bodies contribute to the heat, making nights nearly as uncomfortable as days. While some states have implemented short-term plans, long-term strategies require financial backing, which cities struggle to provide.

site_title: M&A-focused hedge funds lead the pack in May: Goldman Sachs
summary: Hedge funds focusing on mergers and acquisitions (M&A) led the pack in May, with a 7.7% return in the first five months of 2024, outperforming those with other strategies. This rebound in deal-making comes as companies gain confidence from declining interest rates and a stabilizing economic backdrop. Despite a 23% increase in global M&A to $1.3 trillion, it remains below the 2021 record levels. site_title: US regulators have vertical integration in their sights
summary: US regulators are shifting their focus from horizontal deals to vertical integration, with the Federal Trade Commission (FTC) seeking to block major acquisitions such as Microsoft's Activision purchase and Illumina's Grail acquisition. Vertical integration allows companies to exert more control over suppliers and sales channels, increasing efficiency and reducing regulatory risks. However, competition watchdogs are concerned that this trend could lead to abuse of power and foreclose competition. The FTC has successfully blocked some vertical mergers, and more cases are in the works, suggesting that this trend may persist beyond the Biden administration.

site_title: Best and worst moments from the 2024 Tony Awards
summary: The 2024 Tony Awards ceremony took place on June 16, with all eight acting winners receiving their first Tony Awards. Jonathan Groff won for his lead role in "Merrily We Roll Along," while ARIANA DeBose hosted the ceremony for the third time. The awards were spread among several shows, with "The Outsiders" and "Stereophonic" winning top prizes. The ceremony saw improvements in pacing, dialogue, and camera work, making it a more dignified and entertaining event. Notable moments included a performance of "Empire State of Mind" from "Hell's Kitchen," and heartfelt speeches from showmen George C Wolfe, Jack O'Brien, and Billy Porter.

site_title: ECB sees market repricing but not disorderly dynamics, chief economist says
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) chief economist Philip Lane says recent market turbulence in France is a "repricing" and not disorderly dynamics. He expresses confidence in bringing consumer-price growth back to the 2% target in the second half of 2025 and does not rule out another rate reduction in July. Lane emphasizes the ECB's commitment to preventing unwarranted market dynamics that could disrupt monetary policy, but notes that officials are not pre-committing to a specific path.

summary: Adidas shares dropped 3.5% on the Frankfurt Dax index after confirming an investigation into allegations of senior employees embezzling millions in China. An anonymous letter, allegedly written by adidas China employees, accused several Chinese employees by name of embezzling funds. The company stated it's "intensively investigating" the matter with external legal counsel, taking allegations seriously and committed to complying with regulations. site_title: US dollar stays strong, political uncertainty saps euro
summary: The US dollar remains strong, while the euro falls to one-month lows due to European political uncertainty. French financial markets experienced a sell-off, but the European Central Bank has no plans to discuss emergency bond purchases. The Bank of Japan's governor, Kazuo Ueda, is open to raising interest rates in July due to the yen's weakness, which increases import costs. site_title: Cambodia PM Hun Manet to make official visit to Singapore from Jun 18-19
summary: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet will make a two-day official visit to Singapore from June 18-19, marking his first visit as prime minister. During his stay, he will meet with Singapore's President Tharman Shanmugaratnam, Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, and Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Hun Manet will also attend the Cambodia-Singapore Business Forum and visit Keppel's Infrastructure@Changi building, a solar-powered building that received the highest Green Mark Platinum Positive Energy accolade. The visit aims to strengthen relations between the two ASEAN member states and promote bilateral trade and investment.

site_title: Rental value of Hong Kong tycoon’s skyscraper drops 33% since 2019
summary: Hong Kong's commercial property market has seen a 33% drop in rental values for major offices since 2019, with billionaire Li Ka-shing's Cheung Kong Center leading the decline. The city's vacancy rate reached a historic high of 16.7% in the first quarter, attributed to a weak economy and multinational companies' retreat. New buildings, including The Henderson, also contributed to the decline in rental income. This slump underscores the pain in Hong Kong's commercial market, which has been affected by a combination of economic and company-related factors.

site_title: China steps up warnings on relentless bond-buying frenzy
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, has issued warnings to investors about the relentless bond-buying frenzy, citing concerns over long-term yields touching two-decade lows. The PBOC has cautioned that investors should not bet on further declines in market rates, as bond funds may struggle to sustain the returns exceeding 10% this year. The warnings come as signs of the bond rally's persistence, including a recent 50-year special bond auction and declining 30-year government bond yields.

site_title: Australia’s main stock market to list first spot-Bitcoin ETF
summary: Australia's main stock market, the ASX, is set to list the VanEck Bitcoin ETF on June 20, marking the first time a Bitcoin ETF will be listed on the exchange. The listing follows similar products in the US and Hong Kong, and is part of a growing trend in crypto investing. VanEck is the only applicant approved for a listing so far, with other issuers, including BetaShares Holdings and DigitalX, also planning to launch spot-Bitcoin ETFs. The move is expected to increase access to Bitcoin for Australian investors.

site_title: Goldman Sachs raises S&P 500 year-end target to 5,600

summary: ING targets annual total income growth of 4-5% from 2024 to 2027, prioritizing local scale in retail banking and building wholesale banking as a separate pillar. site_title: India's monsoon rains a fifth below normal so far
summary: India's monsoon season has delivered a fifth less rain than normal, with nearly half the country's farmland depending on the annual rains, which usually run until September. The India Meteorological Department reported 20% less rainfall since June 1, with significant shortfalls in central and northwestern states, while southern states received more rainfall. The monsoon's progress is stalled, but officials predict it can revive and erase the rain deficit in a short burst. Heatwave conditions persist in northern states, but temperatures may start coming down from the weekend.

summary: High-end outdoors magazines, such as Adventure Journal and Ori, are experiencing success in print, catering to readers who prefer a digital-free experience. The magazines are part of a growing trend of small-batch, independent publications that are finding analogue success. A production facility in California is printing and binding thousands of copies of these magazines, which are then stacked into boxes for distribution.
