FILE PHOTO: The logo of the luxury goods company Richemont is pictured at its headquarters in Bellevue near Geneva, Switzerland, June 2, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Ardian, Saudi’s PIF to buy 37.6% stake in Heathrow, Ferrovial keeps 5%
summary: Ardian and Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) will acquire 37.6% stake in Heathrow Airport, with Ferrovial retaining 5%. Under the new agreement, Ardian and PIF will purchase 22.6% and 15% of FGP Topco, respectively, for £3.26 billion. The deal values Heathrow at £8.66 billion, a decrease from the initial £9.48 billion valuation. The sale is subject to regulatory approval and expected to be completed by the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, passenger numbers at Changi Airport in the first three months of 2024 – at 16.5 million people – have exceeded 2019 levels.
According to the global industry body, Middle East passenger traffic will double in the next 20 years, climbing to 530 million passengers by 2043.
The two parties have long been at commercial loggerheads, including a years-long court battle over fees and capital costs under Qantas’ former CEO, Alan Joyce.

Around 22 organisations have issued a joint statement urging the government to reconsider and block BlackRock’s participation in the deal worth about US$2.6 billion to take Malaysia Airports Holdings (MAHB) private, alleging the firm has ties with Israel.
Analysts have mostly recommended that investors accept the buyout offer.

site_title: DP World plans US$3 billion African ports investment by 2029
summary: DP World plans to invest $3 billion in new port and logistics infrastructure in Africa by 2029, with a focus on ports ($2 billion) and logistics ($1 billion). The investment aims to meet growing demand for critical mineral exports, driven by the global electrification drive and demand for commodities like cobalt and lithium. Despite economic challenges in the region, DP World sees long-term growth opportunities in Africa, where eight of the world's 15 fastest-growing economies will be this year.

images.alt_text: Caisse de Depot et Placement du Quebec, Canada's second-largest pension fund manager, is teaming up with Dubai-based DP World Ltd to create a C$5 billion (S$5.3 billion) venture that will invest in ports around the world, including regions such as Asia and Latin America.

site_title: Bacardi wins appeal reviving US Trademark Office fight over ‘Havana Club’ rum
summary: The 4th US Circuit Court of Appeals has ruled in favor of Bacardi, allowing the company to challenge the US Patent and Trademark Office's decision to renew Cuba's "Havana Club" trademark 10 years after Bacardi claimed it should have expired. Bacardi had argued that the Cuban government unlawfully seized the trademark name and assets from Jose Arechabala in 1960. The court's decision allows Bacardi to continue its federal court challenge, which is separate from a pending lawsuit over the USPTO's rejection of its trademark cancellation request.

images.alt_text: China’s tariffs on wine were part of broader trade restrictions imposed on Australia after Canberra called for an inquiry into the origins of Covid-19.
“Wine is something that civilised countries have offered, and we have had this for thousands of years, says Sergiy Klimov.
Age-worthy bottles from the 2022 crop of Beaujolais. Beaujolais, and its prices, are not what they used to be.
Former NBA star Carmelo Anthony developed a reputation as a wine guy during his time at the Denver Nuggets.

site_title: Kirin to buy Fancl for 220b yen in shift away from beer
summary: Kirin is set to acquire Japanese skincare brand Fancl for approximately 220 billion yen (S$1.9 billion), marking a significant shift away from its beer business. The acquisition is a 43% premium on Fancl's closing price, and Kirin will acquire two-thirds of the shares it doesn't already own. The deal aims to reduce Kirin's reliance on beer and expand its presence in the skincare market.

images.alt_text: A Fancl outlet at Takashimaya Shopping Centre. Japanese skincare brand Fancl prepares to close its 13 stores in Singapore by the end of March 2014.
Fancl is expected to support the takeover by Kirin and will be delisted when the acquisition is completed.

site_title: Kuehne owner sees triple-digit million hit on Signa investment
summary: Billionaire Klaus-Michael Kuehne of Kuehne Holding expects triple-digit million-euro losses from investments in insolvent real estate firm Signa Prime Selection, due to falling property values and rising interest rates. The losses are manageable, according to Kuehne, who had previously invested over 100 million euros in the company. Signa Prime's luxury holdings, including Selfridges and KaDeWe, are struggling, and Kuehne is considering further investment to rescue the Elbtower project in Hamburg.

site_title: Tesla CEO Musk’s pay package gets support from 77% of votes at investor meet
summary: Tesla CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package has been approved by 77% of investor votes at the company's annual meeting, despite opposition from some institutional investors and proxy advisory firms. The pay package, the largest in US corporate history, was previously voided by a Delaware judge in January but was reinstated after receiving overwhelming support from retail investors. The approval does not resolve a pending lawsuit on the pay package, which could continue for months.

images.alt_text: (FILES) Tesla CEO Elon Musk speaks at the 27th annual Milken Institute Global Conference at the Beverly Hilton in Los Angeles on May 6, 2024. Tesla and SpaceX tycoon Elon Musk lashed out June 10, 2024 at a partnership between OpenAI and Apple, saying the threat to data security will make him ban iPhones at his companies. (Photo by Frederic J. BROWN / AFP)

site_title: Shanghai allows Tesla to carry out Full Self-Driving pilot
summary: Shanghai authorities have approved a pilot test of Tesla's Full Self-Driving (FSD) software on 10 vehicles, paving the way for its rollout in China. This move could intensify a price war in the world's largest auto market, where Tesla competes with local rivals. Tesla has been offering FSD with restricted features in China for four years. The successful rollout could strengthen Tesla's position in the market and lead to a battle over less expensive driver assistance features.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk past a showroom outside Tesla China headquarters at China Central Mall in Beijing, China July 11, 2018. REUTERS/Jason Lee/File Photo

site_title: Oil dips, but posts weekly gain on solid 2024 demand outlook
summary: Oil prices rose nearly 4% for the week, despite settling slightly lower on Friday, due to forecasts for solid demand in 2024. Brent crude futures rose to $82.62 a barrel, while US crude futures rose to $78.54. A survey showing US consumer sentiment weakened in June limited gains, but forecasts for strong demand and a supply deficit until winter supported prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$82.75 a barrel, up 15 cents, or 0.2 per cent on Thursday.

site_title: Taiwan envoy says island deepening ties with US to deter China
summary: Taiwan's de facto ambassador, Alexander Tah-Ray Yui, stated that the island is deepening ties with the US to deter China's potential invasion. Yui expressed hope for a second trade agreement between Taiwan and the US, aiming to reduce regulatory red tape and boost investment. China has launched military drills following Taiwan's new president, Lai Ching-te's inauguration, and Yui attributes the aggression to China, not Taiwan or the US. The diplomat is working with US officials to resolve defense order delays and coordinate on supply-chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk past a Taiwanese flag in New Taipei City on January 13, 2024. Taiwan's freshly elected lawmakers will meet from February 1, 2024 with a new party emerging with an outsized influence over legislation after breaking through the self-ruled island's long-entrenched two-party system. (Photo by Sam Yeh / AFP)

site_title: Finternet – the new financial architecture
summary: A proposed financial system, dubbed "Finternet," aims to empower individuals and businesses by connecting multiple financial ecosystems, much like the internet. The system would use unified ledgers to record ownership and transactions, and tokenisation technology to enable secure and fast transfers. The Finternet would retain traditional financial system structures, such as central banks and commercial banks, but with advanced technological representations. Regulatory compliance and governance would be crucial to the system's success, as it seeks to provide inclusive, convenient, secure, and affordable financial services to the world's population, particularly underserved segments.

images.alt_text: An unwelcome pest is how many financiers and regulators would describe the crypto industry. Criminals use cryptocurrencies to launder money. Terrorists use them to make payments. Hackers demand ransoms in bitcoin.

The development of various digital currencies over the past few years implies a need for digital representations of money, and it is the job of the central banks to meet this need, said Agustin Carstens, general manager of BIS.

site_title: 2024 Rolls-Royce Cullinan Series II review: Polishing Rolls’ jewel
summary: The 2024 Rolls-Royce Cullinan Series II boasts a refined design, emphasizing its vertical form, with new daytime running lights and a polished stainless steel bumper. The 6.75-liter V12 engine remains unchanged, delivering soft power and effortless handling. The Cullinan Series II features a light touch update, with the brand's user-friendliness allowing nine out of 10 owners to drive the car themselves. The Black Badge edition offers a distinct driving experience with firmer suspension and a more urgent gear change. The Cullinan Series II is expected to retail for at least S$2 million at the end of 2024.

images.alt_text: The Volkswagen ID.5 GTX's acceleration won’t cause various sphincters to clench, like in some dual-motor EVs, but the performance feels like what you used to get from a good six-cylinder engine.

site_title: Election concerns in France give euro worst week in two months
summary: The euro is on track for its biggest weekly fall in two months against the US dollar, driven by concerns over a potential snap parliamentary election in France that could worsen the country's fiscal situation. The euro has fallen 0.34% to US$1.0699, while the dollar index has risen 0.3% to 105.55. The yen has also fallen to a six-week low against the dollar, rebounding after the Bank of Japan surprised markets with a dovish monetary policy update. French markets have seen a significant jump in the premium investors demand for French government debt, and bank stocks have tumbled.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan kept interest rates unchanged after a two-day meeting but said it would “reduce its purchase amount of JGBs (Japanese Government Bonds) thereafter to ensure that long-term interest rates would be formed more freely”.
The yen remained under heavy pressure ahead of a Bank of Japan meeting on Friday and traders prepared for more volatility in the currency.
Data shows US consumer prices in May have risen less than economists expected, adding to bets that the Federal Reserve may begin cutting interest rates as soon as September.

site_title: US: Stocks slip as markets eye cautious Fed
summary: US stocks slipped on Friday, June 14, as investors weighed hawkish Federal Reserve projections against a cooling economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 118.71 points, or 0.31%, to 38,528.39, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also dropped. The decline followed strong rallies on the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, which reached fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: Europe: French stocks drag continent-wide shares lower on political turmoil
summary: European stocks declined 1% on Friday, marking a five-week low and the worst single-week drop of the year, amid French political turmoil. The Stoxx 600 and CAC 40 indexes fell 1% and 2.7%, respectively, with a seven-year high risk premium on French bonds. Germany reportedly attempted to prevent or soften the EU's tariffs, but the sell-off was widespread, with bank and healthcare sectors dragging down the market. The decline follows weeks of uncertainty in France and raised concerns about the EU's economic stability.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 1.3 per cent lower on Thursday.

site_title: Four things you need to know about the Copa America
summary: The 48th edition of the Copa America is set to begin on June 21 in the US, featuring 16 teams competing for the top spot. Argentina, led by Lionel Messi, are the favourites to defend their title, while Brazil, without Neymar, aim to stop them. Other top contenders include Colombia, Uruguay, and Canada. The grand final will be held at the 65,000-seater Hard Rock Stadium in Miami Gardens, Florida. Key players to watch include Vinicius Jr for Brazil and Christian Pulisic for the US.

site_title: Thailand’s Central buys rest of German luxury retail business KaDeWe
summary: Thailand's Central Group has acquired the assets of German luxury retail business KaDeWe Group, which includes the iconic Berlin department store KaDeWe. Central will continue to operate the stores and renegotiate rent agreements. This follows Central's April purchase of KaDeWe, with plans to also acquire Alsterhaus in Hamburg and Oberpollinger in Munich. The move comes as Signa, the property empire of tycoon Rene Benko, has declared insolvency due to the European real estate crisis. Financial terms of the deal have not been disclosed.

site_title: AI to erase abusive posts to athletes at Paris Olympics: IOC
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) will deploy AI to block abusive posts on social media directed at 15,000 athletes and officials at the Paris Olympics, starting July 26. The tool will automatically erase abusive posts, covering all types of abuse, not just political attacks. IOC President Thomas Bach stated that the measure is necessary to safeguard athletes from cyberabuse, given the expected half a billion social media posts during the event. Russian and Belarusian athletes will compete as neutral athletes, and the measures will not be affected by ongoing conflicts in Ukraine and Gaza.

site_title: Learning from the world’s greatest investors on avoiding investment scams
summary: The world's greatest investors, including Jim Simons, George Soros, and Warren Buffett, have delivered annual returns of 20-66% in the long term, but these outperformances come with risks. Investing in multi-asset classes like stocks, bonds, and commodities is key. However, investment funds offering extremely high returns with "no risks" are likely scams. Index funds, such as the S&P 500, offer a more reliable option with average annual returns of around 11%. Investing for 30 years or more can yield positive returns, but there will be declines, and there is no certainty in financial markets. To avoid investment scams, be wary of unusually high returns, resist the temptation to get rich quickly, and invest via official platforms with thorough research.

images.alt_text: Scammers also have their eyes on the money and many Japanese people are easy prey due to their lack of financial education.

site_title: How Chinese savings can support the global green transition
summary: China's excess savings, totaling 45% of GDP, are driving cheap low-carbon goods, such as electric vehicles, to the global market. This is a challenge for the EU, which should welcome these products, but critics argue that Chinese subsidies and state policies are the issue. However, these actions are symptoms of a deeper problem, and a slowdown in construction spending is inevitable unless China reduces its savings and invests in other sectors. The EU's focus on specific Chinese government actions overlooks the root cause of the problem.

Among the Chinese goods targeted by the new US levies are EVs, batteries and semiconductors – the lifeblood of a greener, more AI filled digital future.

site_title: Musk wins pay approval but still faces Tesla's floundering stock and rich valuation
summary: Tesla shareholders approved CEO Elon Musk's $56 billion pay package, seen as an endorsement of his leadership. Despite this, the company's stock remains down 27% this year, with its market value halved to $582 billion from its 2021 high. Musk still faces a potential long legal fight to validate the pay package.

images.alt_text: Investors holding 1.76 billion shares voted in favour of the pay package, which is the largest in US corporate history, while 528.9 million shares voted against and 20.6 million shares abstained, Friday’s filing showed.

site_title: US import prices unexpectedly fall in May
summary: US import prices dropped 0.4% in May, the first decline in five months, due to lower energy product prices. This benign report and tame inflation readings keep a September interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve on the table. However, a survey showed consumer sentiment hitting a seven-month low in June, and the central bank has pushed back rate cut expectations to December, with a single quarter-percentage-point reduction projected for this year.

Twenty-two per cent of owners reported that inflation was their single most important problem in operating their business.

site_title: Income Insurance says it is in discussion with Allianz for potential transaction of shares
summary: Income Insurance is in discussions with Allianz for a potential transaction involving the sale of shares, which could lead to a partnership or Allianz buying a stake in the Singaporean insurer. The talks follow reports that Income is exploring options to expand across the Asia-Pacific region. There is no assurance that a transaction will materialize, and Income will make further announcements if any developments warrant disclosure.

site_title: US home sales crumble in May on higher rates, record prices, says Redfin
summary: US home sales declined to the lowest levels in the past decade in May, with 407,959 homes sold, according to Redfin. The slowdown is attributed to high mortgage rates and record home prices, resulting in a 1.7% month-over-month drop in sales and a 2.9% year-over-year decline. Despite this, median home prices reached a record high of $439,716, up 1.6% month-over-month and 5.1% year-over-year. The number of homes for sale remains 25% below pre-pandemic levels, with new listings rising 0.3% month-over-month but still 20% below pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: The average British house price hit a record high in May and first-time homebuyers are facing the toughest financial environment in 70 years.

site_title: Man fined record S$600,000 for unauthorised dormitory use of private homes
summary: A 72-year-old Singaporean man, Tan Hock Keng, has been fined a record S$600,000 for using private residential properties as unauthorized dormitory accommodation. He was charged with three counts of violating the Planning Act and had eight additional charges taken into consideration. Tan converted eight properties into dormitories, each housing over six unrelated occupants, despite knowing the regulations limit private homes to six unrelated persons. The fine is the maximum of S$200,000 imposed for each of the three charges.

site_title: Indonesia vows to crack down on ‘blood sucking’ online gambling
summary: Indonesia has shut down over 2 million websites offering illegal online gambling services, targeting an estimated $20 billion industry that affects 1.5% of the country's GDP. Communications Minister Budi Arie Setiadi vowed a "universal war" against online gambling, prohibited in the world's largest Muslim-majority nation, where more than 3 million Indonesians engaged in the activity last year.

site_title: China sells 50-year bonds at record-low yield as demand swells
summary: China sold 35 billion yuan (S$6.5 billion) of 50-year special government bonds at a record-low yield of 2.53%, exceeding demand by five times. This sale is part of China's one trillion yuan special sovereign notes issuance for 2024, with investors buying bonds amid lingering economic pessimism despite warnings of a bond bubble. The People's Bank of China has not cut interest rates since August, citing a wider yield gap with the US, which could increase yuan depreciation pressure.

site_title: Adobe set for biggest gain since 2020 after AI sales success
summary: Adobe reported a 10% increase in sales to $5.31 billion in its fiscal second quarter, driven by strong demand for its creative products, including AI-based tools. The company expects an acceleration in new creative business through the rest of the fiscal year, raising its profit forecast to as much as $18.20 a share. Adobe's proprietary AI model, Firefly, has been integrated into products such as Photoshop and Illustrator, and the company is working on developing similar technology for its video-editing software, Premiere.

images.alt_text: Adobe’s Premiere Pro app is widely used in the television and film industries.

site_title: Japan watchdog recommends action on MUFG units over sharing of client data
summary: Japan's securities watchdog recommended that Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) units be penalized for unauthorized sharing of client data between 2020 and 2023. The investigation found 26 instances of confidential client information being shared between MUFG Bank and its two securities firms with Morgan Stanley. The Securities and Exchange Surveillance Commission also found that MUFG Bank offered preferential lending rates to clients that did business with the group's securities brokerages. The recommendation is expected to lead to punishments from the Financial Services Agency, which will strengthen control systems to prevent recurrence.

site_title: US consumer sentiment ebbs in June; inflation worries linger
summary: US consumer sentiment declined in June to its lowest level since November, falling to 65.6, due to worries about inflation and incomes. Despite a decline in inflation pressures, consumers remain concerned about high prices. The University of Michigan attributed the decline to a transition to web-based interviews, but economists point to concerns about inflation staying in the forefront of consumer finances. One-year inflation expectations remained unchanged at 3.3%, and longer-term expectations rose to 3.1%. The decline in sentiment may suggest softer consumer spending, but its correlation is weak.

site_title: Singapore stocks book net retail inflow of S$1.01 billion year to date, see significant bank outflows in Q2

However, significant bank outflows in the second quarter, particularly from UOB, offset some of this gain. Retail investors have increased their net outflow from local banks to S$597 million in Q2, with UOB seeing the most net selling at S$366 million. site_title: FAA investigating counterfeit titanium used in some Boeing and Airbus jets, NYT reports

The FAA, along with Spirit AeroSystems, is trying to determine the short- and long-term safety implications for planes equipped with the parts. site_title: Market volatility is about to make a comeback
summary: The US economy is likely entering a period of higher interest rates and inflation, which may lead to increased market volatility. This could result in higher returns but also more variability in stock valuations. Historically, the past 15 years have seen relatively low returns and high variability, similar to previous 15-year periods. The last decade has been marked by smooth gains, but the current market environment may be about to change.

images.alt_text: Cheap money leads to financial excess. Does no one learn?
Mark Haefele, CIO of UBS Global Wealth Management, said bond yields are now at attractive levels after central banks hiked rates to tame inflation.

site_title: Great Eastern privatisation deal deemed ‘not fair but reasonable’; OCBC says offer price ‘final’
summary: OCBC's voluntary unconditional general offer for Great Eastern Holdings (GEH) has been deemed "not fair but reasonable" by the independent financial adviser (IFA). The IFA advises the independent directors to recommend accepting the offer of S$1.4 billion, which represents a 36.9% premium over GEH's last traded price. However, the offer price is lower than the IFA's derived range of values for GEH's shares, and the IFA notes that the offer does not ascribe a value to GEH's one-year new business.

images.alt_text: OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
OCBC needs to acquire only 7.4 million more Great Eastern shares to breach the 90 per cent threshold.
The chairman and CEO of Great Eastern should pledge to invest a significant proportion of their total remuneration in Great Eastern shares
The Great Eastern Life Insurance buliding.
For the overall OCBC Group, Great Eastern Holdings is its strategic insurance pillar.
OCBC is "not just a pure bank", but rather a financial conglomerate comprising two banking licences, an insurance arm and an asset manager, said its chairman Andrew Lee.

site_title: China new bank loans rise far less than expected in May as demand wobbles
summary: China's new bank loans rose 9.3% in May, lower than expected, as demand wobbles. This is a significant drop from the 9.6% growth in April. New yuan loans issued by Chinese banks reached 950 billion yuan, down from 730 billion yuan in April. This is below analysts' predictions of 1.255 trillion yuan. The data suggests China's economy is still struggling to regain momentum despite efforts to boost confidence.

images.alt_text: Many are opening accounts to tap a wider range of investment options to capture the Asian financial hub’s higher interest rates and escape mainland China’s moribund markets.
China banks face growing profitability pressures as they are nudged by Beijing to support the economy with cheaper loans and aid the struggling property sector.
Some economists expect the PBOC to cut rates or inject more cash into the financial system by reducing the amount of reserves banks must keep in the coming months.
Officials will discuss ways to expand the so-called white list of supported developments to include previously disqualified housing projects, according to Caixin.
The banks have typically relied on so-called additional Tier-1 and Tier-2 bonds in recent years to replenish capital.
CICC has been slashing bonuses for the past three years amid a slump in deal-making.

site_title: Ukraine summit attracts world leaders but fails to isolate Russia
summary: World leaders, including US Vice-President Kamala Harris and French President Emmanuel Macron, will attend a Ukraine summit this weekend, but Russia is not invited. The event aims to explore ways to end the conflict, but Kyiv's goal of isolating Moscow is unlikely to be achieved. Around 90 countries and organisations will attend, with a focus on parts of Ukraine's 10-point peace plan that are palatable to most participants. The summit declaration will condemn Russia's actions and uphold international law, but China's absence and Russia's refusal to participate may limit its effectiveness.

images.alt_text: Flags representing the participants of the Group of Seven (G-7) leaders summit at the Borgo Egnazia resort in Savelletri, Italy, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. site_title: Hot stock: Soilbuild Construction hits 5-year high on Tuas Port contract win
summary: Soilbuild Construction's shares surged 113.9% after the company won a S$647.5 million contract at Tuas Port, a project expected to be completed by the third quarter of 2027. The stock reached its 5-year high, surpassing levels last seen in May 2019. Trading volume was high, with 17.1 million securities transacted by midday.

images.alt_text: The Tuas Port terminal in Singapore. The contract awarded to Soilbuild involves constructing warehouse buildings, gate buildings, main intake substation and ancillary buildings at the port.

site_title: Apple sued by female employees claiming pay discrimination
summary: Two female Apple employees claim the company systematically pays women less than men for similar work. They allege that Apple determined starting salaries before 2018 by asking employees for their compensation history, perpetuating historic pay disparities. The women also claim that performance reviews and bonuses favor men, resulting in lower pay for women. The lawsuit, filed in California state court, seeks unspecified wages owed to over 12,000 current and former female employees.

images.alt_text: ChatGPT will be offered for free on Apple’s products, but OpenAI and Apple could still make money by converting free users to paid accounts.

A customer exits an Apple store in Walnut Creek, California, US, on Tuesday, June 11, 2024. Apple unveiled an improved Siri virtual assistant that can answer a wider range of queries and accomplish more complicated tasks than earlier versions.

site_title: G7 vows action against ‘unfair’ China business practices
summary: G7 leaders have vowed to take action against China's "unfair" business practices, including excess industrial capacity that distorts local markets. They also warned of sanctions against Chinese financial institutions that helped Russia obtain weaponry for its war against Ukraine. The G7 pledged to protect businesses from unfair practices, level the playing field, and remedy ongoing harm. Additionally, the group committed to reducing methane emissions by 75% by 2030 and accelerating the transition away from fossil fuels to achieve net-zero by 2050.

Leaders gathering at the Jun 13-15 summit in Italy hosted by Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni are expected to focus heavily during their private meetings on the threat posed by burgeoning Chinese-Russian trade to the fight in Ukraine, and what to do about it.

site_title: Chanel billionaire’s son builds US$110 million private equity firm
summary: David Wertheimer, 37, son of Chanel billionaire Gerard Wertheimer, has founded Luxembourg-based private equity firm 1686 Partners, targeting fashion, cosmetics, and gourmet foods with a $110 million investment. The firm, which has hired key team members, aims to back innovative companies with a focus on sustainable materials and eco-responsible practices. Wertheimer's father and uncle, who own equal shares in Chanel, have a combined net worth of $106 billion. The firm's first investments include a European ski clothing brand, luxury watch seller, and stock management company.

images.alt_text: Chanel is among the companies that have so far weathered the downturn in demand – revenues rose 16 per cent last year to almost US$20 billion.

site_title: Global container shipping prices keep rising amid port congestion
summary: Global container shipping prices continue to rise, with spot rates to the US and Europe from Asia increasing to over $6,000 for a 40-foot equivalent unit, according to the Drewry World Container Index. The recent surge is attributed to six months of regular attacks on vessels in the Red Sea, stretching capacity and leading to bottlenecks in major ports, including Singapore and China. The industry is also experiencing solid demand for goods, particularly in the US, with imports at the Port of Los Angeles remaining above pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Bitcoin miners pivot to South-east Asia after China crackdown
summary: Bitcoin miners are shifting their operations to South-east Asia, particularly Malaysia, after China's crackdown on cryptocurrency mining. The region's abundant power, skilled labor, and existing infrastructure make it an attractive location for miners. Despite the challenges, including police raids and electricity theft, significant growth is expected in the region's mining and manufacturing sectors. The US launch of spot Bitcoin ETFs has also contributed to the growth, with Bitcoin's value quadrupling since the start of last year to trade at around $67,000.

site_title: Thailand expects at least 800 billion baht investment pledges in 2024
summary: Thailand expects to secure at least 800 billion baht ($29.4 billion) in investment pledges in 2024, a significant increase from last year's 848 billion baht. The country's total investment applications rose 31% in the first quarter of 2024, with China being the largest foreign investor. The government aims to boost foreign direct investment through easing business regulations. AstraZeneca (Thailand) plans to invest 6.2 billion baht over three years, while the Thailand Board of Investment approved eight new projects worth 57 billion baht.

site_title: Barclays told to review leveraged finance as UK probes industry
summary: UK regulators have ordered Barclays to review its leveraged finance business due to concerns over lenders' exposure to private equity giants and their portfolio companies. This move comes as the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) has found that few banks conduct stress testing for these relationships. Barclays is seeking to deepen ties with buyout firms as part of a push to boost returns at its investment bank. The review is the first of many expected by the PRA, which has warned that private equity may pose a risk to the UK's financial system.

images.alt_text: Barclays eyes move into lucrative world of private credit

site_title: Tesco sales rise as shoppers switch from rival grocers
summary: Tesco's sales rose 4.6% in the quarter through May 25, driven by customers switching from rival grocers as food price inflation eases. The company expects a retail operating profit of at least £2.8 billion this fiscal year. Tesco's market share grew the most in two years, as it attracted customers from Marks & Spencer, Waitrose, and Aldi by matching prices. The company's chief executive officer, Ken Murphy, attributed the growth to easing inflation and the recent increase in the national minimum wage, which benefits Tesco's customers.

images.alt_text: Britain's Tesco opens checkout-free store in London

site_title: AI can pick stocks better than you can
summary: A recent study by researchers at the University of Chicago found that a large language model (LLM) was able to accurately predict earnings and create model portfolios that outperformed the broad stock market. The model, trained on financial statements from 1968 to 2021, was able to achieve accuracy rates of 60% in predicting earnings direction, surpassing human analysts. The study suggests that LLMs could democratize financial information processing and potentially replace human analysts, raising questions about the future of the profession.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An AI (Artificial Intelligence) sign is seen at the World Artificial Intelligence Conference (WAIC) in Shanghai, China July 6, 2023. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo

site_title: Indonesian developer Agung Podomoro plans 4.5 trillion rupiah housing project in new capital
summary: Indonesian developer Agung Podomoro plans to build apartment buildings worth over 4.5 trillion rupiah (S$373 million) in the new capital of Nusantara, through a public-private partnership scheme. The project is one of the first by a private company in the city, expected to move forward despite recent doubts about its future. President Joko Widodo aims to relocate thousands of civil servants from overcrowded Jakarta to Nusantara by September, with the housing deal seen as a key step towards the city's development.

site_title: China firms seek anti-dumping probe of EU pork imports
summary: China has formally requested an anti-dumping probe into pork imports from the European Union, amid escalating tensions following the EU's imposition of anti-subsidy duties on Chinese-made electric vehicles. China imported $6 billion worth of pork from the EU in 2023, with the EU accounting for more than half. The move could lead to retaliatory measures and impact European pork suppliers, including Spain and France, which are major exporters to China.

images.alt_text: While it remains unclear which products China could target for retaliation, whey powder, cream and fresh milk were the top export items in the EU’s 1.7 billion euros (S$2.4 billion) worth of dairy exports to China last year, according to data from the European Commission’s Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
Among the Chinese goods targeted by the new US levies are EVs, batteries and semiconductors – the lifeblood of a greener, more AI filled digital future.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment to start an operation in India’s GIFT City
summary: CapitaLand Investment, the investment management arm of CapitaLand Group, has obtained a licence from the International Financial Services Centres Authority (IFSCA) to run a fund management company in India's GIFT City. This move aims to serve global clients and offers private funds focusing on commercial real estate, including IT parks and data centers. India's GIFT City is part of the country's push to develop a rival financial hub to Singapore and Dubai, with exemptions from rules and taxes. CapitaLand's entry marks the latest addition to the zone, which also includes ANZ Group Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking.

site_title: Issue 104: Palm oil investors don’t care about the green; MAS, BIS take on climate data gap
summary: A study by National University of Singapore researchers found that palm oil companies with better ESG transparency tend to trade at lower price-to-earnings ratios. The study looked at 36 publicly listed palm oil companies, including 29 members of the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil, and found a negative correlation between ESG transparency and price-to-earnings ratios. However, the study's limitations include correlation not necessarily causing causation and a lack of analysis on liquidity. The study suggests that the discount on more sustainable palm oil stocks may reflect increased ESG risk, but it's unclear if this translates to operational risk.

site_title: Uniqlo’s high-tech checkout charts path to 10 trillion yen in sales
summary: Uniqlo's parent company, Fast Retailing, is investing in high-tech checkout systems and data collection to reach its goal of 10 trillion yen ($86 billion) in annual sales. The technology, developed by Chief Information Officer Takahiro Tambara, uses radio-frequency chips embedded in items to tally purchases at checkout. Tambara plans to introduce the technology across the company's supply chain and sales operations, aiming to drive sales and reduce costs. Despite initial challenges, the technology has been successful, and Fast Retailing is now considering tracking products from production to sales using RFID and QR codes.

site_title: Gold holds steady, on track for first weekly gain in four
summary: Gold prices held steady at US$2,303.43 per ounce, on track for its first weekly gain in four, despite the US Federal Reserve projecting only one interest rate cut this year. The Fed's decision reduced the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion, while US producer prices unexpectedly fell in May, indicating a subsiding inflation rate.

images.alt_text: China is the biggest official sector buyer of gold.

site_title: CDG Engie, Volt Singapore win contracts to deploy fast public EV charging points
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded contracts to deploy fast public electric vehicle (EV) charging points to CDG Engie and Volt Singapore. The first site is expected to be ready by the end of 2024, with the charging points mainly fast-charging and located in HDB commercial complexes and publicly accessible car parks. This marks the first public EV charger deployment contracts since a large-scale tender in 2022.

images.alt_text: One of the 120 kilowatt direct-current fast charging stations for electric vehicles at HDB Hub in Toa Payoh.

site_title: UK housebuilders bemoan lack of new election housing pledges
summary: UK housebuilders are disappointed with the lack of radical measures to address the country's housing shortage in the election manifestos of both major parties. Despite both Labour and Conservative parties promising 1.5 million new homes over the next five years, industry executives say the planning system is slow and land supply is constrained. While Labour is seen as more radical in its approach, the parties' similar targets have raised concerns about the effectiveness of their plans.

site_title: Japan could be energy-independent by 2060 thanks to renewables: Rystad Energy CEO
summary: Japan could achieve energy independence by 2060 through the expansion of solar and wind power, along with storage batteries, according to Rystad Energy CEO Jarand Rystad. The country aims to reduce its reliance on coal and LNG to under 40% by 2030. By 2060, Japan could achieve energy sufficiency with 45% solar power, 30% offshore wind, and 15% nuclear power, with the remaining 10% covered by other renewable sources. Japan has already installed 87GW of solar capacity, and Rystad suggests that continued growth could meet this goal.

images.alt_text: Japan to ban coal imports from Russia

site_title: Bonds are beating Bitcoin as doubts gather over crypto rebound
summary: Bitcoin has underperformed other assets this quarter, with stocks and bonds delivering better returns, amid growing doubts over a crypto rebound. The largest digital asset shed 5% from April's start, while gold outpaced it. Analysts attribute the decline to a rotation away from digital wallets to spot-Bitcoin ETFs and lower inflows, which may not continue for the rest of the year, with estimates at US$12 billion this year, lower than 2021 and 2022 levels.

site_title: Wanted: New auditor, because the last one tried to raise fees
summary: Smaller accounting firms in Singapore face a dilemma: raise audit fees to maintain quality and viability or risk losing clients to competitors due to stagnant prices. With depressed margins and rising business costs, firms must find ways to increase revenue. Some possible solutions include increasing prices, growing revenue through new clients, and exploring less-qualified staff to conduct audits. However, this could compromise audit quality. Regulators can set a "floor price" to prevent undercutting, and companies may view audits as a necessary evil rather than a value-added service, making it harder for firms to raise fees.

site_title: Evergrande liquidation law firm probing PwC, others for potential claims, sources say
summary: Lawyers appointed by Evergrande's liquidators are investigating former auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers, along with other service providers, to potentially recoup losses for creditors. The liquidation process, initiated after a Hong Kong court ordered the developer's liquidation in January, could take over a decade to complete and serve as a blueprint for future Chinese corporate winding up processes. Evergrande's offshore debt of $23 billion was deemed in default, and the company's liquidation has significant implications for creditors and the global financial markets.

site_title: Singtel’s Optus to defend proceedings by Australian authorities
summary: Optus, the Australian unit of Singtel, is defending proceedings filed by the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA) over a 2022 cyberattack. The ACMA alleges 3.6 million breaches of the Australian Telecommunications (Interception and Access) Act, while Optus claims only 10,200 customers had their personal information published online. Optus has taken steps to mitigate the harm, but the quantum of penalties, if any, is yet to be determined by the Federal Court.

site_title: Asia: Markets, yen drop ahead of key Bank of Japan decision
summary: Asian markets and the yen dropped ahead of the Bank of Japan's policy decision, with investors trading cautiously. The yen weakened against the dollar, while the euro remained under pressure due to French parliamentary elections. The Bank of Japan is expected to start reducing its government bond holdings, marking a fresh step away from ultra-loose monetary policy.

site_title: China Evergrande's ex-CEO sells Hong Kong home at almost half of purchase price
summary: China Evergrande's former CEO, Xia Haijun, has sold his Hong Kong home for HK$82 million, a loss of HK$74 million from the purchase price. The 2,834 sq ft duplex flat, bought in 2019, was sold at a 49% discount from its original asking price of HK$160 million. Xia stepped down from the embattled developer in 2022 amid an internal probe into loan diversion. He has been deemed "uncontactable" by Chinese regulators, who fined Evergrande chairman Hui Ka Yan 47 million yuan and barred him from the securities market.

site_title: China waits anxiously for economic plan as gloom reigns
summary: China is awaiting the outcome of its Third Plenum meeting, which will provide guidance on economic direction, amid a slowing economy and rising youth unemployment. The meeting comes as the country struggles with a property crisis, mounting debt, and stagnant wages. President Xi Jinping has emphasized the need to address youth unemployment, a top priority. Economic growth has slowed, and the job market is experiencing difficulties, with many employers citing a lack of jobseekers relative to available positions. The government has resisted big stimulus measures, instead focusing on high-tech innovation and domestic consumption.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Soilbuild
summary: Singapore Stocks: Mapletree Logistics Trust plans to divest 119 Neythal Road in Jurong for S$13.8 million, 34% above its valuation, with completion expected by 2Q 2024/2025. Singtel's Australian unit Optus Mobile defends cyberattack proceedings, with 10,200 customers affected. Soilbuild Construction clinches a S$647.5 million construction contract, bringing its order book to S$1.23 billion.

site_title: US government returns US$156 million worth of 1MDB funds to Malaysia
summary: The US Department of Justice has returned approximately US$156 million in misappropriated 1MDB funds to Malaysia, bringing the total repatriated amount to about US$1.4 billion. This follows a month after Malaysia sought extra compensation from US authorities after the US formally ended its criminal case with Goldman Sachs. The funds were looted by officials in Malaysia, sparking a multibillion-dollar scandal and probes across continents, with assets seized totaling US$1.7 billion since 2016.

site_title: UBS taps China over Citadel Securities on Credit Suisse unit
summary: UBS Group has entered final negotiations with Beijing State-Owned Assets Management to sell its majority stake in Credit Suisse Securities (China) to the Beijing government, which will own 85% of the venture. UBS plans to sell most of its stake and then buy Beijing's 33% holding in UBS Securities to attain full ownership. The deal brings an end to a months-long rivalry for Credit Suisse's investment bank in China, with UBS retaining a 15% stake in the venture.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pedestrian walks past a logo of Credit Suisse outside its office building in Hong Kong, China March 21, 2023. REUTERS/Lam Yik/File Photo

site_title: Bank of Japan to scale down huge bond-buying programme
summary: The Bank of Japan (BoJ) has announced it will scale down its huge bond-buying programme to ensure long-term interest rates are formed more freely. The central bank kept interest rates unchanged but will reduce its purchase amount of Japanese Government Bonds (JGBs) to achieve this goal. The move is part of the BoJ's efforts to normalise its monetary policy and support the yen. A detailed plan for the reduction of its purchase amount will be decided at the next monetary policy meeting in July, and further rate hikes are likely, but the timetable remains unclear due to yen volatility.

images.alt_text: The yen remained under heavy pressure ahead of a Bank of Japan meeting on Friday and traders prepared for more volatility in the currency.

The data complicates the Bank of Japan’s decision on how soon to raise interest rates, as price rises driven by cost pressures could cool consumption and dampen the chances of achieving the kind of demand-driven inflation it wants to see before further phasing out stimulus, analysts say.
The BOJ has a variety of options for trimming its bond buying.
In early business, the Nikkei was marginally lower, while the yen was also slightly down against the dollar.

Markets are focusing on how Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda, at his post-meeting briefing, reconciles recent weak signs in the economy with the bank‘s current projection that Japan will make steady progress towards achieving its price target.

site_title: Microsoft faces heat from US Congress over cybersecurity
summary: US Congress members pressed Microsoft to explain a breach of senior US officials' emails by a Chinese hacking group, citing a "cascade of avoidable errors." Microsoft President Brad Smith accepted responsibility for the issues, assuring the committee that cybersecurity is being integrated into the company's culture. The Cyber Safety Review Board found that Microsoft's corporate culture was at odds with customer trust and identified avoidable errors, including a failed laptop check after a corporate acquisition. Microsoft has committed to developing a plan for security reforms and tying cybersecurity accomplishments to senior executive bonuses.

images.alt_text: Brad Smith, president of Microsoft Corp., during a House Homeland Security Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 13, 2024. The Biden administration will call on the tech industry on Thursday to design artificial intelligence models to improve public welfare in the coming decades, including by reducing car crashes and accelerating medical research. Photographer: Tierney L. Cross/Bloomberg

site_title: Thai bourse picks outsider for new president amid market slump
summary: The Stock Exchange of Thailand has appointed Asadej Kongsiri, a 53-year-old Deloitte Thailand executive, as its new president, starting a four-year term in September. This move comes amid the bourse's worst period in five decades, marked by a 7% decline in the equities benchmark this year, erasing about $180 billion in market value from its 2023 peak. The appointment is seen as an effort to lead the bourse out of the slump, following corporate scandals and an exodus by foreign funds.

images.alt_text: Thai market weakness on proposed transaction tax a buying opportunity: CGS-CIMB

site_title: Oil edges higher as Opec comments feed demand hopes
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at $82.75 a barrel, up 15 cents or 0.2%. The increase was supported by OPEC's forecast for demand growth and easing US labor market and inflation data, which sparked hopes for Federal Reserve rate cuts. West Texas Intermediate crude futures also gained 12 cents, or 0.2%, to $78.62 a barrel.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A pump jack drills oil crude from the Yates Oilfield in West Texas’s Permian Basin, near Iraan, Texas, U.S., March 17, 2023. REUTERS/Bing Guan/File Photo

site_title: Singapore shares slip at Friday’s open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.2% lower at 3,319.11 on Friday, mirroring overnight losses in Europe. The market saw 18.1 million securities traded worth S$24.7 million, with Soilbuild Construction rising 52.8% after securing a S$647.5 million contract. Local banking stocks, including DBS, OCBC, and UOB, fell 0.6-0.2%. The Dow Jones and S&P 500 closed at record highs, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Mapletree Logistics Trust expects the divestment of 119 Neythal Road in Singapore to be completed by the second quarter of the 2024/2025 fiscal year.

site_title: Can art save the world? Or is that too much to ask?
summary: The Art for Tomorrow conference in Venice explored the role of art in a just world and its potential to address societal issues. American lawyer and social justice activist Bryan Stevenson emphasized the need for art to change narratives and combat false narratives, citing the US's high incarceration rate and racial injustice. Artists and experts debated whether art can change the world, with some arguing it can change people and narratives, while others stated it cannot. The conference also touched on the impact of artificial intelligence on creativity, with some seeing it as a tool for hybrid forms of creativity and others expressing concerns about its potential effects. Overall, the conference highlighted the importance of art in promoting social justice and improving the human condition.

images.alt_text: Dwight Mackintosh, 'Untitled,' 1981; Felt-tip pen and acrylic paint on paper.
Even Pope Francis has visited the Venice Biennale, stating that “the world needs artists” to tackle xenophobia, racism and other forms of discrimination.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise to 10-month high
summary: US weekly jobless claims rose to a 10-month high of 242,000 in the week ended June 8, surpassing economists' forecast of 225,000. The labor market is cooling due to the Federal Reserve's interest rate hikes, with the unemployment rate increasing to 4% in May, its highest level since January 2022. The Fed kept interest rates steady at 5.25-5.50% and expects only a single quarter-percentage-point reduction for this year, citing a relatively tight but not overheated labor market.

images.alt_text: US weekly jobless claims fall as labour market tightens, seasonal factors revised

site_title: Judge likely to kill US$30 billion Visa, Mastercard swipe-fee deal
summary: A US$30 billion settlement between Visa, Mastercard, and retailers to cap credit-card swipe fees is likely to be rejected by a federal judge in Brooklyn, potentially killing the deal. The proposed settlement aimed to cap fees charged to merchants for processing card payments, but the judge expressed doubts about its terms, which included allowing merchants to charge consumers extra for transactions involving Visa or Mastercard cards.

images.alt_text: EBay has lost significant market share to other e-commerce giants in recent years.

Attendees during the Visa Payments Forum in San Francisco, California, US, on Wednesday, May 15, 2024. Visa’s token technology has been scrutinised by the US Justice Department after vendors who eschewed the tokens were charged more than those using them.
Travel trends in Asia Pacific, which lifted pandemic curbs later than the rest of the world, continued to be a drag due to tougher comparisons from last year.
The ruling Conservatives and the opposition Labour party have both pledged to scrap preferential tax treatment for non-domiciled residents – rich foreigners living in the UK.

site_title: ByteDance may axe 1,000 Indonesia jobs; VinFast has the wood on Chinese EV makers
summary: ByteDance may cut up to 1,000 jobs at its Indonesian e-commerce platform Tokopedia following this year's merger with TikTok Shop. Meanwhile, Chinese electric vehicle makers are competing with Vietnam's VinFast in the local market. The Philippines has seen record-breaking heat, with temperatures above 38°C in April and May, but tourism remains strong. The region is also seeing a surge in foreign direct investment, with South-east Asia accounting for a larger share of global inflows.

Amazon data centres under construction in the US. Its cloud computing platform expects its latest investment to support an estimated average of 12,300 full-time equivalent jobs in local Singapore businesses each year.

site_title: Why X is hiding which posts you ‘like’ from other users
summary: Elon Musk's social media platform X has made a change to hide which posts users "like" from others, citing a need to protect user privacy. This update follows a series of changes made by Musk since acquiring the platform in 2022, including the removal of content moderators and the introduction of paid subscription features. The change affects all users, not just paid subscribers, and users can still see who has liked their own posts and the number of people who like a post. Musk has stated that the change is meant to allow users to express support without fear of backlash.

images.alt_text: Artists and creators like Billie Eilish are publicly complaining of their likeness being ripped off by bots before they can even object.

site_title: Germany primed for Europe’s biggest football party as Euro 2024 kicks off
summary: Germany is set to host the European Championship, Euro 2024, which kicks off this weekend with 24 teams competing in 51 matches across 10 cities. Despite Germany's stellar football history, a recent survey found that 27% of Germans have zero interest in the tournament. Economists believe the event will have a minimal impact on Germany's economy, which is currently experiencing a modest 0.3% expansion. UEFA expects Euro 2024 to generate 2.4 billion euros in revenue, with a cumulative global audience of over 5 billion viewers.

site_title: Fed needs more time to gain confidence before it starts loosening monetary policy
summary: The US Federal Reserve curbed market enthusiasm by maintaining a cautious stance on monetary policy, despite a softer-than-expected reading of the consumer price index (CPI). Fed Chairman Jerome Powell stated that inflation is moving towards the 2% target, but emphasized that it may take longer to gain confidence before loosening policy. The Fed kept interest rates unchanged, and the median projection for future policy moves shifted from three interest rate cuts to a single cut in 2024. This decision may help prevent a market surge, which could be seen as an attempt to keep the lid on market bullishness.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures were up US$1.33, or about 1.6 per cent, to US$83.25 a barrel at 1338 GMT on Wednesday, with US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude futures also up by US$1.33, or roughly 1.7 per cent, to US$79.23.
Federal Reserve Bank Chair Jerome Powell announces that interest rates will remain unchanged during a news conference in Washington, DC, June 12, 2024.
The unexpectedly benign inflation report has triggered a jump in market-based expectations for Fed's rate cut as soon as September, and another one in December.
In the 12 months through May, the CPI advanced 3.3 per cent after increasing 3.4 per cent in April.

site_title: China’s Chery Auto: EU factory will help mitigate EV tariffs
summary: China's Chery Auto plans to mitigate the impact of EU tariffs on imports by establishing a manufacturing site in Europe. The company, China's largest automaker by export volume, aims to start EV production at its Barcelona factory in Spain by the end of the year. The move is part of Chery's expansion plans in Europe, where it plans to sell its Omoda and Jaecoo brand cars. The company's vice-president, Charlie Zhang, stated that local production will help offset the impact of EU tariffs on imports, which will incur tariffs of 21 per cent.

images.alt_text: Chery Automobile will be the eighth automaker from China to set up a manufacturing plant in Thailand.

site_title: Europe: Automakers lead shares lower; Italian stocks slide
summary: European stocks closed 1.3% lower on Thursday, with automakers falling 2.4% due to concerns over EU tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles. Italy's benchmark stock index dropped 2.2%, and European banks fell 2.4%. The European Central Bank's interest rate cut and French political uncertainty also weighed on markets. The US Federal Reserve held interest rates steady, pushing out rate cuts to December. Global markets remain cautious ahead of US-EU trade talks.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 climbed 0.2 per cent to 5,433.74, while tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.3 per cent to 17,667.56 on Thursday.

site_title: Bank of Japan to keep ultra-low rates, may signal bond taper
summary: The Bank of Japan is likely to maintain ultra-low interest rates, possibly signaling a gradual reduction in its massive monetary stimulus. Despite weak economic signs, including sluggish consumption and doubts over inflation, the BOJ may consider scaling back its balance sheet. The decision comes as other central banks, such as the Federal Reserve and European Central Bank, tighten monetary policy to combat inflation. The BOJ's post-meeting briefing will provide insight into its strategy, which may ease market jitters and provide clarity on its taper plan.

images.alt_text: The yen remained under heavy pressure ahead of a Bank of Japan meeting on Friday and traders prepared for more volatility in the currency.

The data complicates the Bank of Japan’s decision on how soon to raise interest rates, as price rises driven by cost pressures could cool consumption and dampen the chances of achieving the kind of demand-driven inflation it wants to see before further phasing out stimulus, analysts say.
The BOJ has a variety of options for trimming its bond buying.

An index measuring sentiment among service-sector firms like taxi drivers and restaurants stood at 45.7 in May, down 1.7 point from the previous month and hitting the lowest level since August 2022, the survey showed.
Japan is facing a “critical moment” in shifting away from a deflation-prone economy that prioritised cost cuts.
Analysts expect the Japanese economy to have bottomed out in the first quarter.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at records for fourth straight day
summary: US stocks reached new records for the fourth consecutive day, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.2% and 0.3%, respectively. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dipped 0.2%. Broadcom surged 12.2% after lifting its full-year forecast, while Tesla rose 2.9% following shareholder backing of Elon Musk's compensation plan. The strong earnings and improving inflation data provided a boost to investors, but the market's advance was limited due to consolidation of recent gains.

site_title: Units in 3 luxury condo developments linked to money-laundering associates up for sale
summary: Several luxury condo units linked to Singapore's S$3 billion money laundering case are up for sale, including four at Gramercy Park, units at The Marq on Paterson Hill, and South Beach Residences. Units range from S$6.8 million to S$9.05 million, with some having outstanding loans and ties to associates involved in the case. The sale of these properties comes after DBS accepted offers totaling over S$100 million for 13 mortgaged shophouses linked to money launderers.

site_title: Lloyds to move thousands back into refurbished City of London HQ
summary: Lloyds Banking Group plans to reopen its refurbished 33 Old Broad Street office in November as its new head office, housing 5,000 staffers. The move reduces its office footprint by about 30% and marks a shift back to in-person work for some employees. The lender has been whittling down its office space since 2022, with offices at 125 London Wall set to close. The new office will be the third location for Lloyds in London, following outposts at 10 and 25 Gresham Street.

site_title: Tesla shareholders back huge payout for CEO Musk, company says
summary: Tesla shareholders backed a plan to pay CEO Elon Musk up to $56 billion, overturning a Delaware court's invalidation of the original 2018 compensation package. The vote follows a campaign by the company to revive the plan after the court ruled it was "deeply flawed." The outcome could strengthen Tesla's appeal of the ruling, and analysts say it likely ensures Musk's continued leadership of the company. Musk had hinted he might exit without a large enough stake in Tesla, but the vote suggests shareholders support his role.

site_title: World Bank to issue US$200 million bond to boost Amazon reforestation
summary: The World Bank plans to issue a $200 million principal-protected bond to support reforestation efforts in Brazil's Amazon rainforest through Brazilian startup Mombak. The bond will provide financing for reforestation initiatives that generate carbon credits, which can be sold in carbon markets. This is the World Bank's second outcome bond, following a $100 million bond for plastic-reduction projects in Ghana and Indonesia. The move aims to support the nascent carbon removal industry in Brazil and potentially unlock debt markets for other reforestation initiatives.

images.alt_text: Biodiversity loss threatens economic stability: central banks report

site_title: F&N, Sheng Siong, QAF among Asian food procurers that fall short of investors’ sustainability standards: report
summary: A report by Asia Research and Engagement found that Asian food procurers, including F&N, Sheng Siong, and QAF, failed to meet investors' sustainability standards. The 100 companies assessed scored below 50% on sustainable sourcing strategies, with labor and just transition issues being the only areas where they excelled. The report highlights the need for these companies to boost efforts to reduce sustainability risks in their supply chains to protect value for themselves, investors, and lenders.

images.alt_text: With the launch of SFA's Aquatic Animal Health Services, farms can turn to aquatic animal health vets and other experts for consultations and disease investigations.
Despite the low animal cell count, Good Meat says it has received positive consumer feedback on the product’s taste, texture, and look during testing.
Cultivated meat is thought to be kinder and more sustainable as it is slaughter-free and uses less water and land to produce.
Australian alternative protein firm Vow has received the regulatory approval from the Singapore Food Agency to sell their product here.

site_title: Japan’s Kirin to buy remaining stake of skin care company Fancl for 210 billion yen: Nikkei
summary: Japan's Kirin Holdings plans to acquire the remaining stake in skin care company Fancl for approximately 210 billion yen (S$1.8 billion) through a tender offer. Kirin, which already holds a 33% stake, aims to complete the deal by the end of the year to diversify its portfolio amid a flat beer market. Fancl will support the takeover and be delisted upon completion.

site_title: G7 to tap frozen Russian assets for US$50 billion to Ukraine
summary: The G7 nations have agreed to provide Ukraine with approximately $50 billion in fresh aid, with the funds to be repaid using profits generated from Russia's frozen assets worth around $280 billion. The loans are expected to start flowing by the end of the year and will be used to support Ukraine's defense, economy, and reconstruction. The deal aims to send a strong message to Russia that the G7 is willing to stand by Ukraine for the long term, and the repayment process will take several years.

images.alt_text: Flags of the G7 nations and the EU are seen at Castello Federiciano, the venue where the G7 summit's first dinner is scheduled to take place on Jun 13, in Brindisi, Italy.

site_title: Seized money-laundering assets exceeding S$2 billion yet to be surrendered to the state
summary: Singapore's authorities have yet to receive S$2 billion in seized assets from the 17 foreigners still under investigation in relation to the S$3 billion anti-money laundering case. The assets range from luxury watches, high-end property, and cars to handbags, jewelry, and cryptocurrencies. While S$944.5 million in assets have already been surrendered, the remaining amount will be held by the police until the case is closed. The assets are expected to be forfeited to the state, with some assets being sold in auctions to pay into the consolidated fund.

images.alt_text: Clockwise from top left: The 10 money launderers are Su Baolin, Su Haijin, Chen Qingyuan, Su Wenqiang, Lin Baoying, Zhang Ruijin, Wang Dehai, Su Jianfeng, Vang Shuiming and Wang Baosen.

site_title: Thyssenkrupp Steel to put forward Duisburg green steel plan in August
summary: Thyssenkrupp Steel Europe plans to unveil proposals for a green steel plant at its Duisburg site in August. The project aims to switch to direct reduction steelmaking, replacing the fossil fuel-based conventional blast furnace route, and achieve climate-neutral production by 2045. Germany's government has earmarked 2 billion euros in subsidies to support the project. The company's CEO, Bernhard Osburg, defended the due diligence involved, citing the significant taxpayer money involved in the project.

images.alt_text: Thyssenkrupp raises outlook again as global recovery takes hold

site_title: Singapore offers carbon tax rebates for refiners near term: sources
summary: Singapore is offering carbon tax rebates of up to 76% to refiners and petrochemical companies until 2025 to ease cost stress and remain competitive. The tax concessions are estimated to cost between 80 cents and $1 per barrel of crude input basis, reducing the final costs to between $6 and $10 per tonne of emissions. This move aims to soften the added tax burden on refineries amid growing competition with newer plants in China and the Middle East, with the rate set to increase to $45 per tonne by 2026-2027.

images.alt_text: The World Bank's principal-protected bond will provide financing for reforestation initiatives selected by Brazilian startup Mombak.

The EU’s strict carbon-pricing regime may be the best chance the world has to achieve the Paris climate agreement’s ambitious emissions-reduction goals.

site_title: Samsung chief Lee discusses cooperation with Meta, Amazon and Qualcomm
summary: Samsung Electronics Chairman Jay Y Lee met with Meta's Mark Zuckerberg, Amazon's Andy Jassy, and Qualcomm's Cristiano Amon to discuss cooperation on artificial intelligence, cloud services, and chips. The meetings spanned topics such as high-end memory for AI, semiconductors, and chip contract manufacturing. Lee's discussions will inform Samsung's company-wide strategic meeting at the end of June. The meetings follow Samsung's efforts to regain ground in the chip market, particularly in high-end memory for AI.

images.alt_text: Samsung Electronics expects global chip industry revenue to grow to US$778 billion by 2028, boosted by AI chips.

site_title: UK’s Labour pitches for power with ‘wealth creation’ pledge
summary: Labour Party leader Keir Starmer has pledged to restore economic stability and promote "wealth creation" if the party wins the UK's July 4 election. The party's "manifesto for wealth creation" aims to boost economic growth and address the 11.1% inflation rate in October 2022, its highest in 40 years. Labour has consistently led the Conservatives by around 20 points, suggesting Starmer is likely to become the next prime minister. The party's centre-left policies focus on economic growth and stability, marking a shift in their opposition stance.

images.alt_text: Truss rules out fresh UK windfall tax; Sunak open to idea

site_title: US job market resembling pre-pandemic environment: Yellen
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen said the US job market is resembling the pre-pandemic environment, with wages increasing but at a slower rate. This slower wage growth is not a threat to inflation. Yellen also noted that a substantial part of remaining inflation is in housing markets, where recent rent drops are slower to take effect. Despite rising wages, higher costs of housing, education, and healthcare affect Americans' view of the economy. Yellen will continue to address the high cost of living through initiatives such as negotiating drug prices down.

images.alt_text: A robust jobs market has allowed consumers to continue spending even in the face of elevated interest rates – giving the US economy a boost.

The employment gain last month was almost exactly in line with the 12-month trailing average of nearly 276,000 jobs and exceeded the average of 188,000 over the 10 years prior to the Covid-19 pandemic by 84,000.
US central bankers meeting next Tuesday (Jun 11) and Wednesday are still widely expected to leave the policy rate in the current 5.25 to 5.5 per cent range, where they have kept it since last July.

site_title: EU’s new AI rules ignite battle over data transparency
summary: The European Union's recently passed AI Act is being rolled out in phases over the next two years, requiring companies to be more transparent about the data used to train their AI systems. The new laws aim to address concerns over data usage and copyright breaches in the rapidly growing generative AI industry. Companies will need to provide clear information about their data sources and obtain necessary permissions for copyrighted content. This move aims to promote data transparency and accountability in AI development.

AI-driven job matching platforms can help individuals from disadvantaged backgrounds find job opportunities that match their skills, reducing the impact of discrimination in the job market.

To build Apple’s foundation AI models, the company’s engineers used its own framework software with a range of hardware, specifically its own on-premise graphics processing units (GPUs) and chips available only on Google’s cloud called tensor processing units (TPUs).

site_title: Ford expands EV offerings to all US dealers in bid to juice sales
summary: Ford will sell its electric vehicles through all 2,800 US dealers, eliminating the need for dealership facility upgrades. The move comes as the automaker seeks to boost EV sales, which have slowed down. Ford is scrapping a $1.2 million investment requirement and will stock EVs in all dealerships, aiming to increase geographic coverage and customer convenience. This shift in strategy follows Ford's $12 billion spending reduction, factory capacity cuts, and price slashes. The company expects to lose up to $5.5 billion in its EV unit this year.

images.alt_text: John Lawler (middle), Ford’s CFO since October 2020, would take on the additional role of being the company’s vice-chair.
