site_title: Hunter Biden found guilty of lying about drug use to buy gun
summary: Hunter Biden, son of US President Joe Biden, was found guilty by a jury on all three counts of lying about his drug use to illegally buy a gun. This conviction makes him the first child of a sitting US president to be convicted of a crime. The verdict may be seized upon by Democrats to counter Donald Trump's claims of a justice system being weaponized against him. Hunter Biden, 54, showed little reaction to the verdict.

images.alt_text: Hunter Biden leaving after the third day of his gun charge trial at the J Caleb Boggs Federal Courthouse in Wilmington, Del.aware, on June 5, 2024.
Hunter Biden faces three felony charges stemming from his purchase of a .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver in 2018 when, by his own admission, he was heavily addicted to drugs.

site_title: Tories pay the price for the harms of Brexit
summary: The UK Conservative government's pursuit of Brexit has led to significant economic and trade consequences. Despite promises of an "easy" trade deal, the UK's withdrawal from the EU has resulted in barriers, customs checks, and increased form-filling for businesses. Trade deals with non-EU countries have been limited, and the UK's trade intensity has not recovered as expected. The government's handling of Brexit has damaged Britain's most important trading relationship and hurt the party's prospects in the upcoming general election. Productivity is expected to be 4% lower due to Brexit, leading to a lower standard of living and worse public services.

images.alt_text: Polls predict British PM Rishi Sunak will lead the Conservatives to a shuddering defeat to the main opposition Labour party in the July 4 election.
The ruling Conservatives and the opposition Labour party have both pledged to scrap preferential tax treatment for non-domiciled residents – rich foreigners living in the UK.
Lord Mayor of the City of London Michael Mainelli speaks at the annual Lord Mayor's Easter Banquet in London in May 2024.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower as markets prepare for CPI data, Fed meet
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday, June 11, 2024, as investors became cautious ahead of crucial inflation data and a Federal Reserve policy announcement on Wednesday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.19% to 38,795.71, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell, with the S&P 500 down 0.15% and the Nasdaq 0.19%. The market's decline was attributed to uncertainty surrounding inflation data and potential US-EU trade tensions.

site_title: BlackRock will expand offerings for overseas investors in Japan
summary: BlackRock's Japan unit plans to expand its investment offerings for overseas clients, increasing staff by 20% to attract foreign funds. This comes as changes in corporate governance and decarbonization push in Japan may raise foreign investors' asset allocation in the country. The move is part of BlackRock's strategy to grow its business in Japan, with plans to continue increasing staff in the country.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The BlackRock logo is seen outside of its offices in New York City, U.S., October 17, 2016.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Oil edges up as Opec sees relatively strong growth in 2024 oil demand
summary: Oil prices edged up slightly on Tuesday as Opec maintained its forecast for relatively strong growth in global oil demand in 2024, despite lower-than-expected use in the first quarter. Brent crude futures rose 0.6% to $82.11 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 0.6% to $78.15. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) attributed the expected growth to travel and tourism in the second half of the year, despite concerns about oversupply and low demand.

images.alt_text: Brent futures rose US$2.01, or 2.5 per cent, to settle at US$81.63 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude rose US$2.21, or 2.9 per cent, to settle at US$77.74 on Monday.

In the recent meeting of Opec+, members signalled their intention to maintain 3.6 million barrels per day of production cuts until the end of the year, and begin tapering off 2.2 million barrels per day of production cuts starting from October.

The longer route around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid attacks by Yemen’s Houthis has pushed up shipping costs, as about 12 per cent of world total shipping traffic historically sailed through the Red Sea and Egypt’s Suez Canal.

site_title: GM approves US$6 billion buyback on growth in EV business
summary: General Motors (GM) approved a new $6 billion share buyback plan and raised its quarterly dividend by 33% due to improving profitability in its electric vehicle operations. The company expects to exhaust the remaining $1.1 billion of the prior plan by the end of the quarter. This decision builds on GM's momentum from the first quarter, where it raised its full-year profit forecast. The stock gained 1.1% on the announcement, with shares rising 32% this year.

images.alt_text: General Motors did not increase chief executive officer Mary Barra’s target compensation for 2024.
General Motors reported that net income in the first quarter rose 24.4 per cent over the year-ago period to US$3 billion, on a 7.6 per cent rise in revenue to US$43 billion.

site_title: Sunak offers more tax cuts as election polls refuse to budge
summary: British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak has pledged to cut £17.2 billion in taxes and reduce welfare spending by £12 billion a year, as part of the Conservative Party's manifesto. The plans aim to deliver "financial security" and enable working people to keep more of their earnings. However, polls show the Conservatives are lagging behind Labour by 20 points, with many voters questioning why the party has not done more during its 14 years in power. The election is set for July 4, and Sunak faces a challenge from the right-wing Reform UK party.

images.alt_text: Polls predict British PM Rishi Sunak will lead the Conservatives to a shuddering defeat to the main opposition Labour party in the July 4 election.
Cuts to National Insurance contributions are seen as a way to encourage more people into the labour market, although two recent two-point cuts have failed to stem the rise in inactivity.

site_title: Hamas says it accepts UN-backed Gaza truce plan, US cites ‘hopeful sign’
summary: Hamas has accepted a UN-backed ceasefire plan for the Gaza Strip, with senior official Sami Abu Zuhri stating the group is ready to negotiate details. However, both Hamas and Israel have expressed skepticism about the plan, with Israel saying it would enable Israel to achieve its war goals and Hamas stating it must be implemented immediately. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken, who met with Israeli officials, described the Hamas statement as a "hopeful sign" but noted definitive word is still needed. Discussions on post-war plans for Gaza will continue, with Blinken addressing security, governance, and reconstruction.

images.alt_text: Flags of the G7 nations and the EU are seen at Castello Federiciano, the venue where the G7 summit's first dinner is scheduled to take place on Jun 13, in Brindisi, Italy.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu (right) welcoming US Secretary of State Antony Blinken during a meeting in Jerusalem, June 10, 2024.

epa11392972 A Palestinians inspects the damages at a destroyed UNRWA school building following an Israeli airstrike in Al Nusairat refugee camp in the central Gaza Strip, 06 June 2024. According to the Palestinian News Agency Wafa, at least 32 people  were killed and dozens others were injured on early 06 June following an Israeli strike on a UNRWA school sheltering displaced Palestinians, located in the Nuseirat refugee camp in the central Gaza strip. The Israeli army said that it had "conducted a precise strike on a Hamas compound", whose members were " embedded in the UNRWA school".  More than 36,000 Palestinians and over 1,400 Israelis have been killed, according to the Palestinian Health Ministry and the Israel Defense Forces (IDF), since Hamas militants launched an attack against Israel from the Gaza Strip on 07 October 2023, and the Israeli operations in Gaza and the West Bank which followed it.  EPA-EFE/MOHAMMED SABER

FILE — Visitors make their way through the Tower of Faces at the United States Holocaust Memorial in Washington, D.C., April 22, 2013. Students who visit Holocaust museums are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza? (Drew Angerer/The New York Times)
Palestinians put out a fire at the site of an Israeli strike on an area designated for displaced people, in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, May 27, 2024.

Protests at the University of California, Berkeley, during a graduation ceremony on May 11, 2024. More than a dozen universities struck agreements with protesters that effectively conceded to some of their demands. Already, the agreements are under fire from all sides.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as French political tremors rattle banks
summary: European shares ended lower on Tuesday, with the Stoxx 600 dropping 0.9% and Italy's and Spain's bank-heavy benchmarks shedding 1.9% and 1.6%, respectively. The decline was fueled by French political uncertainty, with President Emmanuel Macron's snap election call and the far-right National Rally's potential rise to power. Banks led the selloff, with the sector closing down 2.2%. The yield on the French 10-year bond reached its seven-month highs, and the basic resources index lost almost 2% due to firmer dollar and demand concerns in China.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite Index finished at 17,343.55, up 0.9 per cent on Tuesday, a second straight record close.

site_title: Tether to invest more than US$1 billion in deals over next year
summary: Tether Investments, the investment arm of cryptocurrency company Tether Holdings, plans to invest over $1 billion in deals over the next 12 months. The company, which backs the world's largest stablecoin USDT, has a growing team of 15 people evaluating pitches from startups in areas such as emerging markets, artificial intelligence, and biotech. Tether expects to invest a percentage of its remaining profits in deals, with a focus on alternative financial infrastructure and technology that helps disintermediate traditional finance.

images.alt_text: The agreement marks a major step forward for Tether in its plan to become a major Bitcoin miner.
Stablecoins can be used as a form of payment, as well as to convert in and out of other tokens, such as Bitcoin when trading on crypto exchanges.

site_title: Oil settle slightly up on forecasts for strong global demand
summary: Oil prices rose slightly on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures increasing 29 cents to $81.92 a barrel, as the US Energy Information Administration raised its global oil demand growth forecast for 2024 to 1.10 million barrels per day. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec) maintained its forecast for strong growth in global oil demand, citing expectations for travel and tourism in the second half. This recovery comes as fears of oversupply have eased, and oil prices are expected to continue their sharp recovery.

images.alt_text: Opec maintained its 2024 forecast for relatively strong growth in global oil demand, despite lower than expected use in the first quarter, saying travel and tourism would support consumption in the second half of the year.

The longer route around the Cape of Good Hope to avoid attacks by Yemen’s Houthis has pushed up shipping costs, as about 12 per cent of world total shipping traffic historically sailed through the Red Sea and Egypt’s Suez Canal.

site_title: WeWork CEO Tolley to step down as company exits bankruptcy
summary: WeWork CEO David Tolley will step down after the company emerges from bankruptcy, following a months-long restructuring process. The company, once valued at $47 billion, expanded rapidly but accumulated steep losses due to its over-extended real estate portfolio. WeWork will name a new top boss later in the day, marking the end of a challenging period for the flexible workspace provider.

images.alt_text: WeWork said its restructuring cuts its future rent obligations in half, or about US$12 billion overall.

site_title: Thailand unveils rules to classify cannabis as narcotics again
summary: Thailand's government has unveiled a draft regulation to reclassify cannabis as a "category five" narcotic from January 1, 2025, in an effort to curb recreational use. However, the use of cannabis roots and leaves will remain legal. The Ministry of Public Health will accept public feedback until June 25, and Health Minister Somsak Thepsutin has stated that he will consider suggestions from both cannabis advocates and opponents. This policy change is a U-turn from Thailand's previous move towards decriminalizing cannabis.

images.alt_text: The bud on a marijuana plant inside an indoor greenhouse at Actera's cannabis cultivation facility in Samut Prakan, Thailand, on Thursday, May 30, 2024. The majority of Thais support Prime Minister Srettha Thavisin’s plan to reclassify cannabis as a narcotic and limit its use to medical purposes, according to a survey. Photographer: Sirachai Arunrugstichai/Bloomberg

site_title: Biden the Pragmatist
summary: US President Joe Biden is adopting an "America First" agenda, shifting from free trade to prioritizing the country's interests. This move is seen as a reversal of his previous stance, with critics labeling him as inconsistent. However, Biden's pragmatism, as described by John Maynard Keynes, is a key factor in his decision-making process. By reevaluating policies and adapting to changing circumstances, Biden is trying to find solutions to pressing issues such as record illegal border crossings and Russia's potential victory in Ukraine. This approach is reminiscent of previous US presidents, including Franklin D. Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan, who also applied pragmatic thinking to address economic and national security concerns.

images.alt_text: The Ukraine aid of US$61 billion will be combined with funding for Israel and Taiwan, for a foreign assistance package totalling US$95 billion.

Biden faces huge problems that undercut his chances of getting re-elected, including doubts about his physical and mental fitness for office, looming fears over the country’s immigration crisis at the southern border, and continuing gloom about inflation despite falling prices.

site_title: Euro drops to a one-month low; US dollar firms ahead of key inflation test
summary: The euro dropped to a one-month low of US$1.0725, down 0.3% from Monday's close, amid concerns over European politics and the upcoming French election. The US dollar, however, firmed up ahead of key inflation data and the Federal Reserve's interest rate forecasts. The dollar index rose 0.2% to its highest since May 14, while sterling hit a 22-month high against the euro. The Fed is expected to maintain a status quo at its policy meeting, but analysts expect a hawkish signal if the Fed projects only one expected cut for 2024.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: 20 Euro banknotes are seen in a picture illustration, August 1, 2016. REUTERS/Regis Duvignau/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Sabana Reit’s tenant in Tuas Avenue 8 placed under provisional liquidation
summary: Sabana Reit's tenant, biotechnology company GDMC, has been placed under provisional liquidation at its premises in Tuas Avenue 8. GDMC accounted for 2.4% of the Reit's total gross rental income for FY 2023. The Reit's manager expects a 2.3% impact on pro forma distribution per unit. The manager plans to take legal advice and limit losses by entering the premises, marketing the asset, and offsetting outstanding rental payments. Units in Sabana Reit closed flat following the announcement.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio; the Reit manager said the letter contained "unsubstantiated allegations".
New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.

site_title: With Fed likely to stand pat on rates, all eyes are on its ‘dot plot’ for fresh clues on outlook
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged for the seventh consecutive meeting, following a recent uptick in consumer price and producer price indices. The "dot plot" - a tool showing central bankers' expectations for rate changes - is uncertain, with some officials considering putting rate increases back on the table to ensure the central bank hasn't prematurely declared victory over inflation. The latest inflation data and Fed Chairman Jerome Powell's press conference will be key indicators of the Fed's plans, with analysts predicting a possible shift in the "dot plot" and potential rate cuts in December.

images.alt_text: The employment gain last month was almost exactly in line with the 12-month trailing average of nearly 276,000 jobs and exceeded the average of 188,000 over the 10 years prior to the Covid-19 pandemic by 84,000.
Home maintenance accounted for the largest share of ownership costs in Bankrate’s findings.

site_title: A weakened Modi could make India stronger
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi is weaker than expected, but his weakened state could be beneficial for the country. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) lost 63 seats in the recent election, leading to a coalition government. To stay in power, Modi must cater to other members, including regional powerbrokers. India needs reforms to promote jobs, including lower tariffs, investments in health and education, and liberal land and labor laws. A more liberal approach could make India stronger.

images.alt_text: Indian women waiting to cast their votes at a polling station during the first phase of the general election in Imphal, Manipur, on Apr 19.

site_title: Customer refunds, business suspension send Cordlife S$11.6 million into the red in Q1
summary: Cordlife Group reported a net loss of S$11.6 million for Q1 2024, reversing a net profit of S$1.2 million in the same quarter last year. The loss was primarily due to refunds for compromised cord-blood samples, resulting in a revenue reversal of about S$9.7 million. Excluding the refunds, revenue would have been approximately S$9.4 million, a 33% decline from the year-ago figure. The company's net cash position remains healthy at S$78.8 million, but the Ministry of Health has extended the suspension of operations by another three months.

images.alt_text: The Business Times previously reported that the lapses in tank temperature warrant compensation, but a class action-type suit would be difficult to mount in Singapore due to it being logistically complex to organise.

The arrest of non-independent non-executive director Chen Xiaoling was related to alleged breaches-of-disclosure obligations by Cordlife on the matter of irregular temperatures in a certain cryogenic storage tank.
Cordlife

site_title: Daiwa Securities to buy Aozora Bank stake from activist fund
summary: Daiwa Securities Group will purchase 9.1% of Aozora Bank from activist fund City Index Eleventh, increasing its stake to 24% in the unprofitable Japanese bank. The deal is part of an alliance to cooperate in areas such as wealth management and mergers and acquisitions. Aozora's shares rose 1% following the announcement, while Daiwa's shares fell 4.6%. The investment aims to help Aozora recover from a failed US commercial property market foray and benefit from rising interest rates.

images.alt_text: The Aozora Bank Ltd. headquarters in Tokyo Japan, on Thursday, Feb. 1, 2024. Japan's Aozora Bank became the second lender in a span of hours to surprise investors with losses tied to US commercial property, sending shares down by the limit and heightening concern over global banks' exposure to souring real estate bets. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Beijing Capital-owned Singapore waste firm ECO draws infrastructure investors: sources
summary: Beijing Capital-owned Singapore waste firm ECO is drawing interest from infrastructure investors, including Actis and I Squared Capital, as the company considers selling its waste management business. The sale, which could fetch $300-400 million, is part of a global trend of investors seeking opportunities in the growing waste management sector in Southeast Asia. The deadline for bids is as early as the end of the month, with deliberations still ongoing. ECO provides waste management services in Singapore, and Beijing Capital acquired the company from private equity firm Navis Capital in 2015.

images.alt_text: Environmental activists lobbying against plastic pollution on International Earth Day (April 22, 2024) in Seoul.

site_title: Temu lures more repeat customers than eBay, pressures Amazon
summary: Temu, a Chinese e-commerce upstart, is attracting more repeat shoppers than eBay, with 34% of respondents buying from Temu at least once a month, compared to eBay's 29%. Amazon remains the market leader, with 75% of respondents shopping there at least once a month. Temu's success is attributed to its low prices and direct-from-China shipping, which typically takes a week or more to arrive. The company's aggressive advertising and discounting strategy is also contributing to its growth.

images.alt_text: Companies including Shein, PDD Holdings’ Temu and Alibaba’s AliExpress, which predominantly ship made-in-China products “cross border” to markets around the world have been rapidly growing in recent years.
Troubles run deeper in the US, where lawmakers have alleged Temu and rival Shein exploit loopholes to the disadvantage of US competitors.
Temu, Pinduoduo’s sister app, sells a wide variety of products, many of them made in China, for rock-bottom prices

FILE PHOTO: The logo of Temu, an e-commerce platform owned by PDD Holdings, is seen on a mobile phone displayed in front of its website, in this illustration picture taken April 26, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, June 11, 2024 (Ep 79)
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday, with Singapore shares rising 0.2% and the SIA offering compensation to injured SQ321 passengers. In China, stocks slumped as consumption slows, and property developer Dexin China received a liquidation order. The mixed market movements were ahead of a key Federal Reserve announcement.

images.alt_text: Singapore equities began trading in positive territory at the opening bell on Tuesday.
Hong Kong, Shanghai and Sydney stocks all sank on their return from an extended weekend break, while Singapore, Manila and Jakarta stocks were also down on Tuesday.
Passengers who sustained minor injuries from the turbulence-hit flight on May 20 are being offered US$10,000 in compensation.
Real estate stocks have retreated amid scepticism over a broad support package unveiled by the central government on May 17.

site_title: Crunching the numbers behind Sats’ FY2028 targets
summary: Sats, an in-flight caterer and ground handler, has set ambitious targets for FY2028, including a revenue goal of over S$8 billion, a return on equity (ROE) of 15%, and a market capitalization of S$10 billion. The company's full-year revenue for FY2024 reached a record S$5.1 billion, with net profit climbing into positive territory for the first time since the pandemic. Analysts expect Sats to raise its turnover by 12% every year for the next four years to achieve its top line target. The company's acquisition of Worldwide Flight Services (WFS) in 2023 has contributed to its improved financial results, with WFS generating a top line of S$2.9 billion in its first year of integration.

images.alt_text: DBS' higher target price on Sats is the result of the research house rolling forward its valuation peg to FY2025.
Sats reports impressive earnings for both H2 and full year.

site_title: Singapore’s Tolaram to buy Diageo’s shareholding in Guinness Nigeria
summary: Singapore-based Tolaram agreed to buy Diageo's 58.02% shareholding in Guinness Nigeria, with the transaction expected to be completed in 2025 subject to regulatory approvals. Diageo will retain ownership of the Guinness brand, licensing it to Guinness Nigeria, along with locally manufactured products. This move follows Guinness' significant loss before tax in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: China’s Premier Li Qiang to visit Australia this week
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will visit Australia from June 15 to 18, marking the first visit by a Chinese premier since 2017. During the four-day trip, Li will meet with Australian and Chinese business leaders, as well as Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, to discuss improving ties and trade. The visit comes as China is Australia's largest trading partner, with Australian resources and energy exports dominating trade flow. Albanese plans to raise several issues, including the case of Australian writer Yang Hengjun and a recent incident involving a Chinese military jet.

images.alt_text: Li Qiang’s trip to New Zealand follows a visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in March.
South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol (right) with Chinese Premier Li Qiang during a meeting at the Presidential Office in Seoul on Sunday.
Samsung Electronics Chairman Lee Jae-yong (left) shaking hands with  Chinese Premier Li Qiang prior to their meeting in Seoul, South Korea, May 26, 2024.

site_title: Construction of S’pore’s largest floating solar farm at Kranji Reservoir to begin in 2025
summary: Singapore is set to begin construction of its largest floating solar farm, Kranji Reservoir, in 2025. The 141MWp solar farm will produce 112.5MWp of clean energy, contributing 7% of the country's 2GWp solar target by 2030. The project, which will be operational from 2027-2028, has been deemed environmentally friendly after an assessment found that impacts on biodiversity can be adequately managed with mitigation measures. The solar farm will cover 21.5% of the reservoir's surface area, with a 50m boundary established between the panels and the western shoreline to protect migratory and resident waterbirds.

images.alt_text: Vietnam's northern province of Bac Giang, home to suppliers for Apple, Samsung Electronics and other MNCs, struggled with blackouts in 2023.

site_title: ECB says many eurozone banks dragging their feet on loan-loss provisions
summary: The European Central Bank's top supervisor, Claudia Buch, expressed concerns that many eurozone banks are not meeting accounting rules on loan-loss provisions, despite progress in factoring in climate risks. The proportion of unpaid loans on eurozone banks' balance sheets has shrunk to a historic low since the 2008 financial crisis. However, banks are relying on broad "overlays" to capture potential risks, which may underestimate true default risks. Buch emphasized the need for banks to improve their risk management by using more precise simulations and scenarios to consider novel risks.

images.alt_text: Net trade provided the biggest contribution to growth in the three-month period.
ECB’s remarks led investors to slightly reduce their bets on future monetary easing, which had increased in the days before its policy decision on the back of US data.

The ECB cut interest rates from record highs on Thursday in a long-telegraphed move, but held back from any pledge to ease policy further after inflation and wage growth data in recent weeks came in above its expectations.
The ECB lowered its interest rates for the first time since 2019 on Jun 6, signalling a shift away from its aggressive policy to put an end to a surge in inflation.
The rate reduction is tipped to fuel the bullish outlook for European stocks and with it prospects for the equity capital market, enticing companies to activate listing plans.
The ECB welcomed the fall in price growth as it trimmed its deposit rate to 3.75 per cent from a record 4 per cent, its first cut since 2019.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as macroeconomic concerns weigh; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.4% to 3,309.21 on Tuesday, as investors awaited US consumer price index and Federal Reserve meeting data, sparking macroeconomic concerns. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 rising 0.3% and South Korea's Kospi gaining 0.2%. Jardine Cycle & Carriage was the top performer, while CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) fell 2%. The decline was attributed to a stronger US dollar and uncertainty surrounding the European political situation.

[Raffles Place]

site_title: PM Wong meets Brunei sultan, reaffirms commitment to strengthening ties
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong concluded a visit to Brunei, reaffirming the commitment to strengthening ties between the two countries. He expressed appreciation for Sultan Hassanal Bolkiah's support over 40 years of diplomatic relations and pledged to expand cooperation in areas such as finance, defense, and sustainability. Wong also announced plans to meet with Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim in his next visit to the region.

images.alt_text: PM Wong will meet the Bruneian royal family and Malaysia's prime minister on the visits.

Singapore’s foreign policy was among many issues discussed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his final media interview before relinquishing his role, alongside politics, social issues and the economy.

site_title: China issues draft rules to expand cross-border e-commerce
summary: China has issued draft rules to expand cross-border e-commerce, aiming to promote the growth of overseas warehouses and cross-border e-commerce businesses. The move is expected to boost foreign trade, particularly for companies like Shein, PDD Holdings' Temu, and Alibaba's AliExpress, which ship made-in-China products globally. The rules also focus on improving data management, supervising exports, and facilitating financing channels for cross-border e-commerce companies.

site_title: French bosses fear far right's vague economic plans
summary: French business leaders are uncertain about the outcome of snap elections called by President Emmanuel Macron, which may strengthen the far-right National Rally party. The party's leader, Marine Le Pen, has proposed vague economic plans, including a moratorium on new wind energy construction, incompatible with France's climate commitments. Business groups are calling for clearer economic policies, with Medef warning about the potential cost of Le Pen's plans. The upcoming election has sparked concerns about the impact on the economy, particularly in the renewable energy sector, where a far-right victory could hinder the country's climate goals.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4 per cent, with other regional markets, including Germany’s DAX and Spain’s IBEX down 0.4 per cent each on Monday.
French President Emmanuel Macron’s shock decision amounts to a roll of the dice on his political future.
“France is used to holding elections, they will do it one more time, there will be a new government and everyone will support the Olympics “, IOC president Thomas Bach said.

site_title: Bank of Korea board members cautious on easing monetary policy, minutes show
summary: Bank of Korea board members expressed caution on easing monetary policy due to uncertainty over price pressures. The central bank last month held interest rates at a 15-year high of 3.5% amid stronger-than-expected economic growth and inflationary pressures. Despite a 10-month low in consumer inflation, board members cited factors to monitor, including inflationary pressures from economic growth and monetary policy changes in major countries. The majority of board members saw the policy interest rate staying at 3.5% for the next three months.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People walk on a zebra crossing in front of the buliding of Bank of Korea in Seoul, South Korea, July 14, 2016.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/File Photo

site_title: Cryptoverse: Soccer tokens shine ahead of summer of sport
summary: Cryptoverse: Soccer tokens have seen increased activity ahead of the Euro 2024 European soccer championship and the Copa América, with the market value of Chiliz cryptocurrency rising to over $1.07 billion. Trading volumes of fan tokens have also picked up, reaching over $170 million. However, critics argue that fan tokens can encourage financial speculation, while proponents see them as a way for supporters to engage with their teams. The sector's growth remains slow, with the number of fan tokens increasing but growth being hindered by the speculative nature of the assets.

images.alt_text: Mining stocks closely track Bitcoin as a higher price boosts their profits margins.
Against a basket of currencies, the dollar dropped 0.08 per cent at 104.52.

site_title: Golden Goose boosts Europe IPOs in 558 million euros shoe listing
summary: Golden Goose Group is set to raise approximately 558 million euros in its initial public offering, targeting net sales of about 1 billion euros by 2029. The luxury sneaker brand plans to sell about 30% of its share capital at 9.50 to 10.50 euros per share, valuing the company at 1.7 billion to 1.9 billion euros. The IPO will be Milan's largest since Lottomatica's 599 million euros sale last year, contributing to Europe's resurgence in listings.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A woman uses a mobile phone as people shop at fast-fashion brand Shein's pop-up store in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada May 18, 2024. REUTERS/Blair Gable/File Photo
The rate reduction is tipped to fuel the bullish outlook for European stocks and with it prospects for the equity capital market, enticing companies to activate listing plans.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 11)
summary: Singapore will begin trials for battery charging and swapping and mobile charging systems for electric heavy goods vehicles (e-HGVs) in the second half of 2024. Power-Up Tech will provide mobile charging for up to 10 e-HGVs in a new trial. Singapore Airlines is offering individual compensation starting from US$10,000 to passengers injured during last month's turbulence-hit SQ321 flight. SNEF president Robert Yap has resigned after a routine review found governance lapse.

site_title: Morgan Stanley downgrades Indonesian stocks to underweight
summary: Morgan Stanley has downgraded Indonesian stocks to "underweight" due to near-term uncertainty over the country's fiscal policy and a stronger US dollar. Strategists cited potential fiscal burdens from President-elect Prabowo Subianto's campaign pledges and a deteriorated earnings outlook. The downgrade comes ahead of the Federal Reserve's rate decision and Bank Indonesia's decision next week, which may further impact the Indonesian rupiah.

site_title: US plans to award US$23.9 million to Rocket Lab to boost chips for satellites, spacecraft
summary: The US Commerce Department plans to award Rocket Lab $23.9 million to boost production of space-grade solar cells, crucial for powering satellites and spacecraft. The award will increase Rocket Lab's compound semiconductor production by 50% within three years, supporting the US military, NASA, and the commercial space industry. This is part of the Biden administration's $52.7 billion chip manufacturing and research subsidy programme, benefiting companies like Samsung Electronics and Intel.

images.alt_text: In April 2023, Space Pioneer launched a kerosene-oxygen rocket, the Tianlong-2, or “Sky Dragon”, becoming the first private Chinese firm to send a liquid-propellant rocket into space.
Firefly's small-launch vehicle, Alpha, will fly Lockheed’s spacecraft and payload into low-Earth orbit from its facilities on west and east coasts.
The H3 rocket, built by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries for Japan Aerospace Exploration Agency (JAXA), takes off at Tanegashima Space Centre, Japan, Feb 17, 2024.
The SpaceX Starship stands on the launchpad ahead of the SpaceX Starship flight test from Starbase in Boca Chica, Texas on April 16, 2023.
The 164-foot (50-metre) tall Starship spacecraft sits atop the 230-foot tall Super Heavy rocket.

site_title: Russian real estate in Finland pose security risk, PM warns
summary: Finland's Prime Minister Petteri Orpo has warned of a potential security threat posed by Russian property owners in the country, particularly those holding land near critical infrastructure. The warning comes after Finland's neighbor, Russia, launched a full-scale war against Ukraine in 2022. Orpo has announced plans to map Russian holdings and take action if a genuine risk to national security is observed.

images.alt_text: Russia's President Vladimir Putin’s trip to North Korea would be his first since July 2000.

site_title: ECB must neither rush nor dally after decisive cut, Villeroy says
summary: Bank of France Governor Francois Villeroy advises the European Central Bank (ECB) to adopt a "pragmatic gradualism" in interest-rate cuts, neither rushing nor procrastinating, following last week's decisive move to loosen monetary policy. This stance contrasts with some ECB colleagues who have called for caution. Villeroy emphasizes the need to look through volatility in inflation readings, suggesting the ECB should focus on long-term economic goals rather than reacting to short-term fluctuations.

images.alt_text: The proportion of unpaid loans on the balance sheet of eurozone banks has shrunk to a historic low since the financial and debt crises of 15 years ago, partly thanks to the ECB’s own pressure on lenders.

site_title: Australian dance teacher on board SQ321 left paralysed from chest down
summary: An Australian dance teacher, Kerry Jordan, 52, was left paralysed from the chest down after suffering severe spine injuries on Singapore Airlines flight SQ321, which experienced extreme turbulence over Myanmar on May 21. Jordan broke her spine, suffered a brain bleed, and fractured ribs, and is now undergoing months of rehabilitation. The incident, which also resulted in the death of one passenger and dozens of injuries, has left Jordan unable to perform basic daily tasks with her hands and has taken a significant toll on her physical and emotional well-being.

images.alt_text: Passengers who sustained minor injuries from the turbulence-hit flight on May 20 are being offered US$10,000 in compensation.

With SIA's new in-flight service protocol, cabin crew will have to be seated and strapped in whenever the seat-belt sign comes on.

site_title: American business will regret writing off democracy
summary: US business leaders, including Blackstone's Stephen Schwarzman and JPMorgan Chase's Jamie Dimon, are endorsing Donald Trump's presidential candidacy, despite his history of undermining democratic governance and the rule of law. By doing so, they risk "writing off democracy" and embracing legal uncertainty, which is detrimental to their own power and interests. Business leaders rely on democratic institutions and the law to maintain their influence, but Trump's disregard for these principles makes him an unreliable partner. This strategy may ultimately harm businesses, as seen in Hong Kong, where state control has tightened and businesses have lost autonomy.

images.alt_text: Schwarzman, a lifelong Republican and megadonor to the party, has stuck by Trump after his defeat in 2020 and the Jan 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, but turns away from him after many of the candidates Trump has hand-picked lost their midterm races in 2022.

site_title: Toyota’s faulty certifications also breach UN rules: Yomiuri
summary: Toyota's faulty certifications breach UN rules, affecting 130,000 units per year, according to Japan's transport ministry. The company submitted faulty data during pedestrian-safety tests and used modified test vehicles during collision-safety tests for four past models. Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda apologized for the mistakes, stating the vehicles were safe to drive. Shipment halts will impact two assembly lines, with the company holding its annual shareholder meeting next week. The incident may lead to vehicles being ordered off the roads in places outside Japan, including the European Union.

images.alt_text: Toyota is also unwinding cross-shareholdings within its network of manufacturing partners.

site_title: Fixed income portfolios in a new era: the prospect of real, positive income
summary: Fixed income markets are experiencing a resurgence, with yields rising to a positive real return for the first time in 10 years. This shift is driven by rapidly rising inflation and central banks' aggressive interest rate hikes. As a result, fixed income can now appeal to a wide range of institutional investors seeking income generation, duration, and diversification. With yields expected to remain positive in the foreseeable future, fixed income could once again offer real income to investors, savers, and financial institutions, potentially offering a more conventional means of meeting their needs.

site_title: Chinese developers’ troubles continue as Dexin gets liquidated
summary: Hong Kong's court has ordered the liquidation of Dexin China Holdings, a Chinese developer, amid ongoing financial troubles. The decision comes three months after a petition was filed by China Construction Bank (Asia) and a year and a half after Dexin defaulted on its senior notes. The move adds to a growing list of Chinese developers facing court-ordered liquidation in Hong Kong, including Jiayuan International Group and China Evergrande Group. The liquidation highlights lingering distress in China's property sector, despite the government's efforts to help the industry recover.

images.alt_text: Chinese banks are expected to extend cheaper loans to SOEs via the facility, backed by the central bank.

site_title: One thing everyone’s missing about Hunter Biden’s case
summary: Hunter Biden's case is not primarily about law or politics, but rather about the consequences of his addiction. As the daughter of a former president, Patti Davis shares her personal experience of living under a spotlight and being defined by mistakes. She believes Hunter Biden's addiction has caused pain to his loved ones and may endanger his father's legacy. Ultimately, Biden is responsible for his actions, and his past mistakes continue to affect him, making it difficult for him to move forward.

images.alt_text: Hunter Biden faces three felony charges stemming from his purchase of a .38-caliber Colt Cobra revolver in 2018 when, by his own admission, he was heavily addicted to drugs.

site_title: HSBC adds over 300 to China headcount after Citi wealth acquisition
summary: HSBC has expanded its headcount in China by over 300 after completing the acquisition of Citigroup's consumer wealth portfolio. The portfolio, valued at $3.6 billion, has been integrated into HSBC as part of the deal. This move follows HSBC's efforts to expand in China, one of its key markets, to focus on Asia and exit less profitable geographies. The acquisition demonstrates HSBC's commitment to the Chinese market and its clients, with the bank's wealth invested assets in mainland China growing 53% in 2023.

site_title: Singapore to trial battery swapping and mobile charging for electric heavy goods vehicles
summary: Singapore will launch four-year trials for battery swapping and mobile charging systems for electric heavy goods vehicles (e-HGVs) in the second half of 2024. Mobile charging company Power-Up Tech will provide mobile charging for up to 10 e-HGVs. The trials aim to understand technical, operational, and safety requirements of these technologies, which will inform the development of Singapore's national electric vehicle charging standard, Technical Reference 25.

site_title: Moody’s issues France credit rating warning over snap elections
summary: Moody's has issued a credit rating warning for France due to the country's snap parliamentary elections, which it considers "credit negative" for the Aa2 rating. The elections increase risks to fiscal consolidation and potential political instability, which could lead to a downgrade of the rating to "negative" if debt metrics worsen. France's debt burden is already over 110% of GDP, higher than other similarly rated countries, and has seen a near-continuous increase since the 1970s. The ratings agency's warning follows a similar downgrade by S&P Global earlier this month.

site_title: Australian business conditions soften in May, cost pressures pick up
summary: Australian business conditions eased in May to below their long-run average, with the National Australia Bank survey showing a decline in sales and profits indices. The business confidence index fell 5 points to -3, while the employment index rose. Cost pressures showed signs of re-accelerating. Markets indicate interest rates may stay at the current level for longer, with a first-rate cut not fully priced in before July next year.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Seatrium, Kimly
summary: Seatrium's director Lai Chung Han will resign on June 30. The offshore and marine giant saw shares rise 2.4% to S$1.74. Kimly's wholly owned subsidiary, Choh Dee (S204) Food House, acquired a coffee shop property in Serangoon for about S$13.2 million. Shares of Kimly rose 1.6% to S$0.32.

site_title: Despite SIA’s multiple strengths, shareholders need to brace for turbulence
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) faces turbulence due to its global business and numerous staff, suppliers, and customers. Despite recovering well post-pandemic, SIA's leaders must excel in crisis management to preserve the airline's reputation, crucial to revenue generation. SIA and low-cost carrier Scoot achieved record passenger load factors for the financial year ended March 31, 2024, indicating a strong recovery in the air travel industry.

site_title: Blueprint for investors’ first stock purchase
summary:
Investors should approach their first stock purchase with a clear understanding of the underlying business, its growth potential, and the stock's value. Three key principles to consider are: 

1. Being a joint owner of a business, understanding its operations, and tracking its long-term growth. 
2. Separating short-term price fluctuations from long-term value. 
3. Focusing on the stock's long-term reflection of its underlying business value.

Successful investors have diverse approaches, and there's no one-size-fits-all method. It's essential to find an approach that resonates with individual investors. Investing is a learning process, and making mistakes is inevitable. By following a business closely, investing small, and focusing on long-term growth, investors can increase their chances of success.

site_title: Dragon Boat Festival data show China tourists underspending 2019 levels
summary: China's domestic tourist spending during the recent Dragon Boat Festival holiday rose 8.1% to 40.4 billion yuan, but average spending per traveler was 12.3% below 2019 levels. Despite a 6.3% increase in domestic traffic to 110 million trips, the data highlights a "cautious spending" trend, with demand diverted to lower-tier cities or value/discount packages. The tourism ministry did not compare the data to 2019 figures, and shares in China's tourism sector fell after the disappointing data.

site_title: Rise in UK jobless rate muddies Sunak’s message to voters
summary: The UK's unemployment rate rose to 4.4% in April, the highest since 2021, amid a cooling labour market, despite strong wage growth. The number of employed people fell by 207,000, while unemployment increased by 190,000. The opposition Labour Party is on course to win the national election, with Prime Minister Rishi Sunak facing a challenge to his message to voters. Sunak plans to cut social security contributions by a further two percentage points if his Conservative Party wins, but two recent cuts have failed to stem the rise in inactivity.

site_title: China’s call for ‘open mind’ spurs hope of new housing measures
summary: China's State Council has urged officials to keep an "open mind" on policies to reduce housing inventory, signaling potential new measures to address the country's housing market slump. The call comes after a real estate rescue package was unveiled last month, relaxing mortgage rules and encouraging local governments to buy unsold homes. Economists predict additional funding and new measures to destock inventories and stabilize prices if the market doesn't improve.

site_title: China’s May car sales fall for second month on weak demand
summary: China's passenger car sales declined for a second consecutive month in May, with overall sales down 2.2% and exports falling 9% to 378,000 units. This follows a 5.8% decline in April, amid a slowdown in demand in the world's largest auto market, which is also experiencing a sputtering economic recovery. The decline is partly due to an anti-subsidy probe by the European Union on China-made electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: BYD is also considering a second European plant in 2025.

site_title: Hyundai plans to file for India unit IPO in June: sources
summary: Hyundai Motor plans to file for an initial public offering (IPO) for its India unit by the end of the year, aiming to raise approximately $2.5 billion. The IPO would value the company at up to $25 billion, making it one of the largest in Indian history. The company's advisers, including Citigroup and HSBC Holdings, will help facilitate the process. Hyundai plans to use the proceeds to expand operations and further solidify its position as India's second-largest carmaker by sales.

site_title: Siemens Energy eyes biggest wind turbine to rival China
summary: Siemens Energy plans to produce its largest wind turbine, capable of generating 21 megawatts of power, potentially by the end of the decade. The offshore generator would surpass Chinese competitors and be 40% more powerful than the company's current largest turbine. This move could reignite a competition among Western companies to release larger machines, following a period of industry consolidation. Siemens Energy's wind unit has faced supply-chain issues, soaring costs, and quality problems, but the new turbine could signal a shift in the market and help the company maintain its lead in the wind energy sector.

site_title: Look east: Hong Kong and China equities at inflection point
summary: China's real estate sector is poised for gains as the government announces measures to boost consumption and growth, including easing rules on property purchases and removing mortgage rate floors. The MSCI China Index rebounded 20% from its January 2024 trough, entering a technical bull phase that outperformed global indices. The country's economy is forecast to grow 5% this year, driven by policies to boost consumption and growth, and a comprehensive real estate policy playbook. Hong Kong's capital markets regulations also support its position as a regional financial center, with potential inflows of domestic funds improving liquidity.

site_title: Vietnam eyes greener power but banks on coal to avert blackouts
summary: Vietnam is struggling to balance its energy needs with its climate change commitments, with the country relying heavily on coal to meet electricity demands amid a heatwave. The nation's top power utility, EVN, is investing in infrastructure upgrades, but may not be enough to prevent blackouts. Vietnam aims to increase the use of cleaner energy sources by 2030, but faces challenges in implementing reforms and addressing administrative hurdles. The country's reliance on coal has raised concerns about its commitment to reducing fossil fuel use, and experts say broader sector-wide reforms are needed to address the power crisis.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed ahead of key Fed announcement
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Tuesday ahead of the Federal Reserve's policy decision and US inflation data, with Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Sydney stocks sinking and Singapore, Manila, and Jakarta also down. The euro struggled due to European political uncertainty. Speculation on the Fed's interest rate cuts continues, with some officials warning against moving too soon to avoid rekindling inflation. The main interest is the Fed's "dot plot" forecast for future rate changes.

site_title: Philippine central bank wants inflation firmly settled near target midpoint, governor says
summary: The Philippine central bank wants inflation to settle near the midpoint of its 2.0-4.0% target range, according to Governor Eli Remolona. Annual inflation quickened to 3.9% in May, bringing the five-month average to 3.5%. The central bank, which kept its benchmark rate steady, will review policy on June 27. Remolona stated that policymakers are more concerned about inflation than growth, and the bank is "hawkish, but less than before."

site_title: North China bakes under searing heatwave

Authorities in Beijing have issued an orange alert for extreme heat, urging residents to stay indoors and drink plenty of water. The heatwave is part of a larger trend, with the past 12 months being the hottest on record, and China, as the world's largest greenhouse gas emitter, is particularly vulnerable to its effects.

site_title: Blinken in Israel to push Gaza ceasefire plan backed by UN
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken held talks with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, pushing a ceasefire plan backed by the UN to end eight months of war in the Gaza Strip. The UN Security Council adopted a US-drafted resolution supporting the plan, which includes an immediate ceasefire, hostage release, and withdrawal of Israeli forces from Gaza. Despite recent clashes, Blinken's visit aims to bolster diplomacy and a potential truce, following a deadly hostage rescue mission in Gaza that killed 274 people and wounded over 700.

site_title: Brookfield sells Seoul Conrad hotel for about US$300 million
summary: Brookfield Asset Management sold the Conrad hotel in Seoul to ARA Korea REF for approximately US$300 million. The five-star hotel, acquired in 2016, is part of the International Finance Center property portfolio in Seoul's financial hub. The sale is part of Brookfield's efforts to raise US$15 billion for its fifth flagship real estate fund, which has already collected over US$8 billion for its first close.

site_title: Access fully restored to key channel after Baltimore bridge debris removed

The debris removal, which began in April, was completed after a survey certified the riverbed as safe for transit. The fully operational channel will allow two-way traffic and end additional safety requirements. The incident, which killed six people, was attributed to the cargo ship Dali losing power before crashing into the bridge in March.

site_title: SNEF president Robert Yap resigns after routine review finds governance lapse
summary: Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF) president Robert Yap resigns after a routine review found a governance lapse. Yap has served for 10 years and cited it as an honour to advance members' interests and tripartism. An external consultant is conducting an independent review, with Yap stating that reviewing governance procedures is essential for improvement. The Ministry of Manpower (MOM) and National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) have been informed, with MOM requesting updates on the review's outcome and no indication of financial implications. Yap's departure will not affect the tripartite process, and SNEF will continue building on its strengths.

site_title: Franklin Templeton hires former BNP executive as head of private banks and family offices
summary: Franklin Templeton has appointed Gaurav Bathija as its head of private banks and family offices, effective May 27. Bathija brings 25 years of experience in capital markets, private equity, and private banking, previously working at BNP Paribas Wealth Management and Citi Private Bank. In his new role, Bathija will focus on deepening existing client relationships and developing new ties with global and regional private banks in Asia. He reports to Franklin Templeton's head of wealth for Asia, Christian Bucaro, and aims to deliver bespoke investment solutions for private banks and ultra-high-net-worth channels.

site_title: Gold edges lower as traders eye US inflation data, Fed meeting
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,306.38 per ounce as investors await US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's policy announcement. The May CPI inflation report and Fed meeting are expected to influence interest rate expectations. China's central bank is expected to resume gold purchases once prices ease from record highs. Spot silver, platinum, and palladium also declined, with silver falling 0.7%. The Fed is expected to show fewer interest rate cuts than anticipated, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: China’s central bank to return to gold buying as prices ease: analysts
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, is expected to resume buying gold once prices ease from record highs, as analysts believe the fundamental case for gold remains. After adding to its reserves for 18 months, the bank's holdings remained unchanged in May, causing global spot prices to drop. Industry players expect China to resume buying gold if prices correct to around $2,200 per ounce, driven by geopolitical tensions and economic worries.

site_title: Bank of Japan expected to weigh bond buying cuts as rate hike timing nears
summary: The Bank of Japan is expected to discuss cutting bond purchases at its policy meeting, marking its first step towards quantitative tightening. The central bank is likely to keep the policy rate between 0-0.1% and cut bond buys from around 6 trillion yen per month. This move is seen as a precursor to raising interest rates next month, as the BOJ considers the timing of reducing bond purchases.

site_title: Apple’s AI push could reinvigorate iPhone sales as customers look to upgrade
summary: Apple showcased its AI technology at its developer conference, aiming to invigorate iPhone sales. The company's AI features, including a chatbot tie-up with ChatGPT, will be available on the iPhone 16, which is expected to release this autumn. Analysts predict the upgrade cycle may be the biggest since 2020, with some estimating 15% of Apple's installed base will upgrade to the new iPhone. While some analysts are skeptical, others see AI as a key draw for early adopters and a way to differentiate Apple from competitors.

images.alt_text: IPhones are on display as people shop at an Apple store in a shopping mall in Tehran on May 28, 2024. Ever since the Islamic republic banned 14 and 15 series iPhones in February 2023, users of the latest iPhone models are no longer allowed to register their devices in the country. (Photo by AFP)

site_title: SIA to compensate injured SQ321 passengers at least US$10,000 each for now
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has offered compensation to passengers injured in a turbulence-hit SQ321 flight on May 21. Passengers with minor injuries will receive at least US$10,000, while those with serious injuries will receive an advance payment of US$25,000. SIA will also provide a full airfare refund and delay compensation to all passengers, regardless of injury. The airline has apologized for the traumatic experience and has a comprehensive insurance policy in place to cover such incidents.

images.alt_text: With SIA's new in-flight service protocol, cabin crew will have to be seated and strapped in whenever the seat-belt sign comes on.

The incident on Flight SQ321 is SIA’s first fatal aviation accident since 2000.

site_title: UK’s Sunak to unveil manifesto promising ‘financial security’
summary: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is set to unveil his Conservative party manifesto, promising "financial security" to voters ahead of the July 4 general election. Polls suggest the Tories will lose to the main opposition Labour party, led by Keir Starmer, with a predicted 20-point lead. Sunak's campaign has faced criticism and a recent tax cut promise. Despite this, the Conservative leader will emphasize the need to protect household income, accusing Labour of wanting to increase taxes.

site_title: Bitcoin drops to one-week low as traders await CPI, Fed decision
summary: Bitcoin fell to a one-week low of $68,000, dropping 2.5% as traders await US inflation data and the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision. The largest digital asset had hit a record of $73,798 in March, but has struggled to reach new highs since then. The inflation data and Fed outlook may lead to fears that interest rates will stay higher, making it a tough backdrop for speculative assets like crypto.

site_title: Apac M&A falls to 11-year low in first 5 months of 2024: London Stock Exchange
summary: Global mergers and acquisitions activity rose 23% to $1.3 trillion in the first 5 months of 2024, despite a 26% decline in Asia-Pacific M&A to an 11-year low of $179 billion. The energy and power sector led the rise, while European M&A increased 37% to $259 billion. The US accounted for 56% of global M&A activity, with the UK being the second most targeted nation.

The upstart airline that took on British Airways back in the 1980s is now entering its fifth decade of service.

site_title: Trading places, improving mobility
summary: Singapore's landed property market appears to be reviving, with the government introducing measures to curb price growth. Single citizens aged 55 and above can claim a refund of Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) paid on a second property if they sell their first property within a specified timeframe. This refund can amount to S$300,000. Experts argue that a more lenient ABSD regime could benefit younger singles and permanent resident couples who want to move house, rather than just those trading down. The government may consider revising its ABSD policies to promote housing mobility.

images.alt_text: As life expectancy rises, it may be prudent for any buyer seeking a private home to live in for the remainder of his life to pay more for a home with a sufficiently long remaining land lease, writes BT senior correspondent Leslie Yee.
The latest ABSD hikes have hammered the market in prime areas, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
It’s no secret that suburban malls are strongholds for retail landlords, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Tuesday’s open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore shares started trading in positive territory on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening 0.2% higher at 3,760.29. The broader market saw gainers outnumber losers 57 to 27, with notable movers including Geo Energy Resources and Seatrium. Banking stocks were mixed, while global markets followed overnight gains, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.2% and the S&P 500 gaining 0.7%.

site_title: Branson plans one-stop travel shop as Virgin Atlantic turns 40
summary: Virgin Atlantic Airways is celebrating its 40th anniversary and plans to integrate its airline, cruise ships, and hotel businesses into a one-stop travel shop. Founder Richard Branson aims to make the brands work more seamlessly, offering loyalty points and adding more hotels in destinations the carrier flies to. The airline will also focus on personalized travel experiences and differentiate itself with innovations such as a rooftop gym. Despite fierce competition, Branson remains confident in the airline's prospects, citing its ability to compete with British Airways on key routes.

images.alt_text: A huge carrier plane takes off from a runway, gains altitude for around 50 minutes, and then releases from under its wings a spaceplane that soars at supersonic speed to the edge of space, where passengers can enjoy a few minutes of weightlessness and admire the Earth’s curve.
The results highlight Virgin’s slow but steady path to establishing a routine cadence of spaceflights for paying customers.

site_title: Tourists get taste of old Japan at hidden ‘snack bars’
summary: A Tokyo-based tour company, Snack Yokocho, is offering guided tours to Japan's hidden "snack bars" – small, retro establishments that serve drinks and snacks in a cozy, intimate atmosphere. The bars are typically run by women nicknamed "mama" and have a history dating back to Japan's post-war era, when they emerged as a way for women to make a living without sex work. Today, the bars are a place for socializing and relaxation, with the focus on convivial conversation rather than sex. The tours aim to introduce tourists to Japan's unique bar culture and provide a glimpse into the country's history.

images.alt_text: The renewed pressure on the government comes months after a new series of lawsuits was filed to challenge the single-surname system, long criticised for perpetuating gender inequality.

site_title: In China, a search for identity boosts Lululemon, premium sportswear brands
summary: Premium sportswear brands, such as Lululemon, On, and Hoka, are experiencing robust growth in China's $55 billion sportswear market, driven by the country's focus on health and wellness. The market is expected to grow 7% this year, outpacing other non-sportswear apparel and footwear. Niche brands are benefiting from targeted marketing and social media influencer partnerships, while established brands like Nike and Adidas struggle to compete. Lululemon, in particular, has seen a 45% growth in China, driven by its slow-and-steady expansion strategy, and plans to open 220 stores by 2026.

images.alt_text: Despite slackening shopper appetite in the United States, strong China demand has helped sales for the brand.

site_title: UOB Thailand appoints new chief executive
summary: UOB Thailand has appointed Richard Maloney as its new chief executive, effective July 1. Maloney will expand product offerings and connect clients to local and regional market opportunities. He will also lead efforts to deepen digital capabilities. Tan Choon Hin will return to Singapore to take on a deputy head of group governance role. Vira-Anong C Phutrakul will step up as head of wholesale banking and deputy chief executive of UOB Thailand.

site_title: Singapore’s Ryde completes secondary listings in Germany, eyes investors in Europe
summary: Singaporean ride-hailing company Ryde has completed secondary listings on the Frankfurt and Stuttgart stock exchanges, aiming to expand its customer base in Europe. The firm, which operates primarily in Singapore, closed at US$6.89 with 50 shares changing hands on June 7. Ryde's founder and CEO, Terence Zou, stated that the listings will make its "unique value proposition" more accessible to European investors. The move comes as the company seeks to capitalize on a global investor base, despite posting widening losses and a negative working capital in recent years.

Singapore-based ride-hailing app Ryde is scrapping driver commission charges from Jan 2, 2024.

site_title: Looking for love in all the new places
summary: Lonely individuals are increasingly turning to AI companion apps for companionship, with 225 million lifetime downloads on the Google Play Store as of March. Users customize their AI mates' appearances and personalities, and some even introduce them to family members. While some view this trend as a replacement for human relationships, others see it as a necessary accommodation for those who struggle to form connections. As societal pressures and anxieties rise, the line between virtual and human relationships becomes increasingly blurred, raising questions about the future of intimacy and connection.

images.alt_text: Today’s frontier AI models are approaching the “universal” computers that Alan Turing could only imagine, capable of vastly more functions.

site_title: Carlyle sets sights on 300 Japanese businesses as PE deals boom
summary: Carlyle Group, a US private equity firm, is studying around 300 Japanese businesses as part of its pipeline, indicating a continued boom in private equity deals in the country. The firm, which has been operating in Japan since 2000, plans to announce two or three transactions this year, despite competition increasing. Carlyle's Japan buyout fund, raised 430 billion yen, is 70% funded by international investors, and the firm is looking across three sectors for investments, including general industries, consumer and healthcare, and technology, media and telecommunications.

site_title: Lai Chung Han leaving Seatrium board to take on permanent secretary role at MOF
summary: Lai Chung Han, 51, will resign as a director of Seatrium on June 30, 2024, to assume the role of Permanent Secretary (Development) at the Ministry of Finance on July 1. Han will step down from his current role at Seatrium and relinquish his position as Permanent Secretary (Education). This change comes after Han's appointment to the Ministry of Finance role, which he will assume from July 1.

site_title: Chip stocks lose shine as hedge funds snap up software instead
summary: Hedge funds have shifted their focus from semiconductor stocks, which have been boosted by the artificial intelligence (AI) boom, to software stocks. This reversal comes as software stocks show signs of slower growth due to AI. Despite the shift, both sectors experienced gains, with the S&P Software and Services index logging its best week since January. The divergence marks a significant change in the tech sector's performance, with semiconductor stocks continuing to set all-time highs, while software stocks lag behind the broader market.

site_title: Batteries not included: China EV makers struggle to break VinFast’s dominance in Vietnam
summary: China's electric vehicle (EV) makers are struggling to break VinFast's dominance in Vietnam, despite the country's growing EV sales. VinFast secured nearly 28,000 pre-orders for its affordable mass-market model VF 3 in just 66 hours, but Chinese EV makers are responding with lower prices. Wuling's Hongguang Mini EV, priced at 194 million dong, is now about one-third cheaper than the battery-included VF 3. Vietnam's EV sales have more than doubled last year, driven by supportive government policies and attractive pricing. VinFast aims to deliver at least 20,000 units of the VF 3 in 2024, but faces competition from Chinese brands.

site_title: New York City landlord to sell office building at roughly 67% discount
summary: A New York City office building owned by Related Cos affiliate is set to be sold at a 67% discount, with Empire Capital Holdings and Namdar Realty Group purchasing the property for under $50 million. The building, with 220,000 square feet of space, was originally valued at $153 million in 2018. The sale is a short sale, where the loan balance is less than the sale price, amid declining office property valuations and rising borrowing costs due to the rise of remote work.

site_title: Tesla must face California’s false-marketing claims concerning Autopilot
summary: California's administrative judge rejected Tesla's bid to dismiss claims by a top state regulator that the company misled consumers about its self-driving capabilities. The Department of Motor Vehicles (DMV) accused Tesla of overstating its vehicles' Autopilot and Full Self-Driving technology, stating they "could not at the time of those advertisements, and cannot now, operate as autonomous vehicles." The ruling favors the DMV, which had accused Tesla of false marketing claims.

site_title: Musk to ban Apple devices if OpenAI is integrated into OS
summary: Elon Musk threatened to ban Apple devices from his companies if OpenAI's AI software is integrated at the operating system level, citing a security risk. Musk co-founded OpenAI but had a falling out with the startup. He expressed concerns about the safety implications of generative AI technology and the potential for data tracking. Apple plans to roll out OpenAI's ChatGPT chatbot through Siri later this year, with built-in privacy protections.

site_title: Oil prices up 3% to one-week high on hopes of higher summer fuel demand
summary: Oil prices rose 3% to a one-week high on Monday, reaching $81.63 a barrel for Brent futures and $77.74 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate crude. The increase was driven by hopes of higher summer fuel demand despite a stronger US dollar and expectations of higher interest rates from the US Federal Reserve. Analysts expect solid summer transport demand to push the oil market into a deficit of 1.3 million barrels per day in the third quarter, leading to further price increases.

images.alt_text: Crude has been falling since early April on a weakening demand outlook.

site_title: Nvidia sparks chatter over possible Dow inclusion after stock split
summary: Nvidia's 10-for-1 stock split has sparked speculation about the company's chances of joining the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The split aims to make the stock more affordable for employees and investors, increasing outstanding shares without changing valuation. Analysts note that stock splits tend to attract individual investors, but historical data suggests minimal impact on trading activity. Despite this, Nvidia's recent market value surge and strong forecast have raised hopes for its potential inclusion in the Dow, potentially pushing out Intel.

images.alt_text: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang's wealth has surged more than US$62 billion this year as demand for Nvidia chips used to power artificial intelligence tasks remains insatiable.
Nvidia has been arguably the biggest beneficiary of a massive flood of AI spending.

site_title: OpenAI plays minor role in Apple’s artificial intelligence event
summary: Apple briefly mentioned its partnership with OpenAI's ChatGPT at its Worldwide Developers Conference, touting it as part of its Apple Intelligence AI tools. The chatbot will be supported through Siri voice assistant, with users needing permission before using it. Apple plans to keep the technology separate from its own tools, and other AI models, including Google's Gemini chatbot, are expected to be added in the future. The features will be available for free on iPhone, iPad, and Mac software later this year.

site_title: Mammoth waste problem a test of resolve
summary: India's municipal solid waste management remains ineffective, with the country generating an estimated 11.2 billion tonnes of waste annually. Rapid urbanization and consumption contribute to the problem, and the government's "Clean India Mission" launched in 2014 has been described as a failure. The situation is not unique to India, as global waste generation continues to rise, with an estimated 73% increase in waste generation by 2050. A circular economy model is proposed as a solution, aiming to prolong the lifecycle of products through sharing, leasing, reusing, and recycling.

Garbage piles up in a street near the city's Old Port due to a strike by garbage collection workers, who denounce poor working conditions, ahead of the arrival of the Paris 2024 Olympic flame in Marseille, France, May 6, 2024.

site_title: Generative AI to ‘transform’ gaming but at a cost, says Ubisoft CEO
summary: Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot says generative AI will transform the gaming industry, making open-world games feel "more alive" with interactive non-playing characters. However, the technology's high capital costs are a major hurdle. Guillemot welcomes cloud gaming and the adoption of AI chips in hardware, which could ease costs and bring more intelligence to games. Despite the potential, adoption will take time, and the industry still needs to overcome the cost issue.

images.alt_text: Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot (C) is joined by members of the Ubistoft team on stage at the Ubisoft Forward 2024 showcase presentation at the Belasco Theater in Los Angeles, California on June 10, 2024. (Photo by Robyn Beck / AFP)

site_title: Apple debuts long-awaited AI tools, including ChatGPT tie-up
summary: Apple unveiled its long-awaited AI tools, including a partnership with ChatGPT maker OpenAI, at its Worldwide Developers Conference. The new AI platform, Apple Intelligence, will help summarize text, create original images, and retrieve relevant data. The company is also revamping Siri and introducing features such as personalized emoji, automated photo editing, and a redesigned Photos app. Apple Intelligence will roll out later this year, with some features arriving next year. The partnership with OpenAI will allow customers to access ChatGPT via Siri at no extra cost, while paid subscribers will receive additional features.

site_title: TSMC’s premium over SMIC shows challenges for China’s chip fund
summary: TSMC's stock price has surged 48% this year, while SMIC has lost 7.5%, creating a significant gap between the two Taiwanese and Chinese chipmakers. This disparity is attributed to TSMC's advanced 3nm chip production capabilities, which cannot be sold in China due to export controls. China's largest semiconductor investment fund, Big Fund III, is struggling to develop the local sector, highlighting the challenges Beijing faces in building a competitive domestic chip industry. This gap is the largest since 2005, amid US efforts to limit China's growth.

site_title: Britain’s payments industry calls for delay and cut in scam compensation rules
summary: Britain's payments industry is calling for a delay and reduction in compensation rules for scam victims, citing concerns that the new rules would increase burdens on companies and damage competition. The Payment Systems Regulator (PSR) plans to introduce a cap of £415,000 for reimbursement, but the industry argues that this is too high. The Payments Association is seeking a delay of a year and a cap of £30,000, citing the need to combat authorised push payment fraud, which totalled £239.3 million in the first half of last year.
