site_title: Europe: French stocks send Stoxx 600 lower on political uncertainty
summary: French stocks fell 1.4% on Monday, pushing the CAC 40 index to a three-month low, amid President Emmanuel Macron's call for a snap election after his allies' heavy trouncing in European Union parliamentary elections. The move could hand major power to far-right Marine Le Pen's National Rally party, potentially leading to a "cohabitation" period and a change in economic policy. The Stoxx 600 index fell 0.4% as other regional markets, including Germany's DAX and Spain's IBEX, also declined.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 climbed 0.3 per cent to 5,360.79 while the tech-rich Nasdaq Composite Index advanced 0.4 per cent to 17,192.53 on Monday.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as investors prepare for inflation data, Fed meeting
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as investors awaited key inflation data and a Federal Reserve meeting, seeking hints on policy easing. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 14.09 points, or 0.04%, to 38,784.90, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell. Investors are cautious ahead of the Fed meeting, which may influence inflation data released later in the week.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq end at fresh records
summary: US stocks closed at fresh records on Monday, with the S&P 500 rising 0.3% to 5,360.79 and the Nasdaq Composite Index advancing 0.4% to 17,192.53. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 0.2% higher at 38,868.04. Investors await the Federal Reserve meeting and a key consumer price report, while individual stocks like Southwest Airlines and Diamond Offshore jumped following news of significant investments.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A street sign for Wall Street is seen in the financial district in New York, U.S., November 8, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Aramco’s venture arm, Mubadala back Dubai-based real estate fintech
summary: Dubai-based real estate fintech startup Stake has raised US$14 million from investors, including Saudi Aramco's venture arm Wa'ed Ventures and Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund, in a Series A funding round. The platform, which uses the fractional-ownership model to facilitate property investments, has over 500,000 users and plans to enter Saudi Arabia, where it aims to triple its headcount to 15 by the end of the year. The funding will be used to expand into the Saudi market, following a successful launch in Dubai.

images.alt_text: Dubai's housing sales smash record on rebound, Russian demand
Luxury home prices to climb 5.7% this year: Knight Frank
Dubai to close shutters on lavish world fair

site_title: The ‘good’ and ‘bad’ news inside the US jobs report
summary: The US jobs report showed a 272,000 jobs gain in May, exceeding estimates and the 12-month trailing average, but the unemployment rate rose to 4%, snapping a 27-month streak below 4%. This increase was due to people leaving the workforce and more reporting as unemployed, rather than job losses. Key demographics, such as prime-aged workers and women, saw increases in participation rates, while the immigration wave continues to drive workforce growth. The report highlights the ongoing debate about the Federal Reserve's ability to tame inflation without sending millions to the jobless rolls.

images.alt_text: A robust jobs market has allowed consumers to continue spending even in the face of elevated interest rates – giving the US economy a boost.
US central bankers meeting next Tuesday (Jun 11) and Wednesday are still widely expected to leave the policy rate in the current 5.25 to 5.5 per cent range, where they have kept it since last July.
Demand from banks is fuelling sales of floating-rate, collateralized mortgage obligations (CMO), which are constructed from simpler mortgage securities.
The overall gap was US$74.6 billion, growing from March’s revised US$68.6 billion figure.
Unit labour costs, meanwhile, rose at a 4 per cent annualised rate, down from the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ first estimate of 4.7 per cent.

An attendee signs into a career fair hosted by the New Hanover NCWorks and the Cape Fear Workforce Development Board in Wilmington, North Carolina, US, on Tuesday, June 20, 2023. The Department of labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on June 22. Photographer: Allison Joyce/Bloomberg

The stronger-than-expected services reading stood in contrast to ISM’s report on the manufacturing sector released on Monday, which showed factory activity contracted for the second straight month in May.
Private payrolls increased by 152,000 jobs last month after rising by a downwardly revised 188,000 in April, the ADP Employment report showed.
Upcoming job openings data will show hiring slowed for a second month in April, according to the median estimate in a Bloomberg survey.

site_title: Political turmoil in France won’t affect Paris Olympics, IOC head says
summary: IOC President Thomas Bach stated that France's upcoming parliamentary elections, scheduled for June 30 and July 7, will not affect preparations for the 2024 Paris Olympics. Bach expressed confidence in the unity of French political leaders in their support for the Games, despite President Emmanuel Macron's surprise call for new elections. Paris Mayor Anne Hidalgo criticized Macron's decision, calling it "one more coup" by the president. Despite the uncertainty, Paris 2024 chief Tony Estanguet said his team remains determined to make the Games a success.

site_title: Meta Platforms to use social media posts from Europe to train AI
summary: Meta Platforms plans to use publicly shared social media content from the European Union to train its large language models, similar to its approach globally. The company will draw from content on platforms such as Instagram and Facebook. This shift aligns with its global approach, despite initial caution due to stringent EU regulations. Meta's decision comes as the EU rolls out AI code with broad copyright and transparency rules.

images.alt_text: Meta has been ramping up efforts to earn money off WhatsApp, its biggest app in terms of daily users.

Meta’s latest study on “coordinated inauthentic behaviour” on its platforms comes as fears mount that generative AI will be used to trick or confuse people in upcoming elections worldwide, notably in the United States.

site_title: ISO global sugar deficit forecast jumps to 2.954 million tonnes
summary: The International Sugar Organization (ISO) has raised its global sugar deficit forecast for the 2023/24 season to 2.954 million tonnes, up from a previous estimate of 689,000 tonnes in February. Global production is expected at 179.270 million tonnes, down from a previous forecast of 179.749 million, while consumption is expected to rise to 182.224 million tonnes. The ISO attributed the shift in forecast to downward revisions in North America and upward revisions in Thailand and China, leading to a more bullish outlook over the next three months.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Agriculture’s Foreign Agricultural Service predicts India wheat imports at 2 million tonnes in the season that began on Apr 1 on steady local demand.
StoneX has projected that global sugar production exceed total demand by 3.9 million tonnes, up from 3.4 million tonnes seen in February.

site_title: Hiring sentiment in Singapore remains soft, but most sectors still looking to boost headcount: survey
summary: Singapore's hiring sentiment remains soft, with 44% of employers planning to hire for the July-September period. The financials and real estate sector showed the largest change in hiring outlook, declining 30 percentage points to a +15% Q3 outlook. The remaining sectors, including manufacturing, construction, and services, also expect to increase headcount. However, 24% of employers anticipate a decrease in staffing levels, while 32% expect no change. This marks the third consecutive quarter of weakening hiring sentiment.

images.alt_text: In order to maintain its global competitiveness and drive innovation, the city-state needs to continue attracting and retaining top professionals from all over the world.

site_title: Indian’s Modi unveils coalition Cabinet dominated by his party
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi unveiled his coalition government, with 71 members taking the oath of office. The cabinet is dominated by his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), with 11 posts going to coalition allies, including five in top 30 cabinet positions. Key posts remain unchanged, with BJP loyalists holding key portfolios. Modi's decade-long rule has seen him cultivate an image as an aggressive champion of the majority Hindu faith, but his cabinet lacks Muslim lawmakers for the first time.

images.alt_text: President Droupadi Murmu (in purple) administered the oath of office to Modi (in blue) at a grand ceremony at the Rashtrapati Bhavan, the president’s palace in New Delhi, attended by thousands of dignitaries, including the leaders of seven regional countries, Bollywood stars and industrialists.
The Reserve Bank of India said the economy will grow at 7.2 per cent this year, against the earlier forecast of 7 per cent.
Fitch expects capital expenditure to continue to be a key priority for the India's new government, which is due to present the full-year budget in July.
It is the first time in a decade that Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) has needed the support of regional parties to form the government.

India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks after releasing the Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) manifesto ahead of country's upcoming general elections, at the party headquarters in New Delhi on April 14, 2024. (Photo by Sajjad HUSSAIN / AFP)

TOPSHOT - India's Prime Minister and leader of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) Narendra Modi (C) with chief minister of Maharashtra state Eknath Shinde (L) and their deputy chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis (R) waves to the crowd during his roadshow in Mumbai on May 15, 2024, ahead of the fifth phase of voting of India's general election. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP)

site_title: Real Madrid say they will play in Club World Cup as Ancelotti takes back comments
summary: Real Madrid manager Carlo Ancelotti clarified his comments on the Club World Cup, stating that he never intended to reject the tournament. In a social media post, Ancelotti expressed his interest in playing in the tournament, calling it a "great opportunity" to continue fighting for major titles. The club reiterated its participation, saying it would take part "as planned" with pride and enthusiasm. The comments came after Ancelotti previously quoted as saying that Fifa undervalued the compensation Real Madrid should receive in the tournament.

images.alt_text: Manchester City, champions for a record fourth year running, had record revenue of £712.8 million in the 12 months through Jun 30 last year, ranking it second globally behind only Spain’s Real Madrid, based on exchange rates at the time.
epa11384873 Jude Bellingham of Madrid celebrates winning the UEFA Champions League final match of Borussia Dortmund against Real Madrid, in London, Britain, 01 June 2024.  EPA-EFE/TOLGA AKMEN
Premier League clubs will likely be limited to spending 85 per cent of their revenue on transfers, wages and agents fees.
Real Madrid beat Borussia Dortmund 2-0 at London’s Wembley Stadium in Saturday’s Champions League final.
Kylian Mbappe, the captain of the French national team, who will be available on Jun 30 when his contract with Paris Saint-Germain expires, has decided to sign for Real after seven seasons in Paris.

site_title: Picasso Museum opens vast online archive
summary: The Picasso Museum in Paris launched an online portal providing access to 19,000 previously unseen photos, artworks, and other memorabilia from the artist's archives. The digital portal, set to be joined by a study centre later this year, will also digitize 200,000 texts from Picasso's workshops. The online archive comes ahead of the study centre, which will cater to researchers and artists-in-residence, and offers a glimpse into Picasso's vast collection of artworks, essays, conferences, podcasts, and interviews.

images.alt_text: French painter Françoise Gilot, who was Pablo Picasso's partner from 1946 to 1953, pursued a career as a renowned artist after leaving him, has died aged 101.
Christie’s valuation of about US$140m on this opulent Picasso ranked as one of the highest estimates ever put on an artwork at auction in 2015. But Picasso's appeal and popularity may be waning.

site_title: Japan should let married women keep names, business lobby says
summary: Japan's big business lobby, Keidanren, urged the government to allow married couples to have separate surnames, citing a business risk due to current laws forcing married women to use their husbands' names. The proposal comes months after lawsuits challenged the single-surname system, which has been criticized for perpetuating gender inequality. Japan is the only country enforcing such a rule, and the issue contributes to the nation's lag in gender equality, ranking 125th out of 146 countries in the Global Gender Gap report.

images.alt_text: Gender disparities – in opportunities, outcomes and levels of representation – have detrimental effects on both micro- and macroeconomic indicators.
Women are stereotyped as better-equipped to take on care-giving duties, while men feel the pressure to be breadwinners.
The World Bank's report assesses, for the first time, how 190 countries are implementing existing laws to protect women. It reveals a 'shocking' gap between policy and practice.
Job seekers at a career fair. The Bureau of Labor Statistics has reported that the annual average weekly earnings for women last year was US$1,005, or 83.6 per cent of the US$1,202 earned by men.

site_title: Cuba woos Russians, Chinese to revive ailing tourist sector
summary: Cuba is offering perks to attract tourists from Russia and China, including direct flights, no visa for Chinese visitors, and acceptance of Russia's Mir payment cards. The strategy has seen a surge in Russian visitors, with over 66,000 visiting in the first three months of 2024, double that of the same period in 2023. However, experts warn that these gains are unlikely to compensate for the decline in US and European visitors, and Cuba is unlikely to meet its goal of 3.2 million tourists this year, with estimates ranging from 2.6 to 2.7 million.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, passenger numbers at Changi Airport in the first three months of 2024 – at 16.5 million people – have exceeded 2019 levels.
The hot weather has not thinned crowds at popular beach and resort destinations such as Terengganu in Malaysia.
Spending by foreign tourists on the mainland this year is expected to hit 715 billion yuan, about a quarter below 2019 levels.
China in recent months loosened visa restrictions for people from Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Abbott secures FDA clearance for two over-the-counter glucose monitors
summary: Abbott Laboratories has secured FDA clearance for two new over-the-counter glucose monitoring devices, expanding its presence in the multi-billion-dollar market. The devices, one for health-conscious individuals and another for those with type 2 diabetes, follow the successful FreeStyle Libre, which generates over $1 billion in quarterly sales. The new devices, Libre Rio, target people with type 2 diabetes who manage their condition through lifestyle modifications, marking a shift towards over-the-counter sales. This move is seen as a strategic expansion for Abbott, increasing its market presence and revenue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker waters plants next to an advertisement billboard of Abbott in Mumbai, India, November 12, 2015. To match Special Report INDIA-MEDICINE/ABBOTT    REUTERS/Danish Siddiqui/File Photo

Sales of Abbott’s medical devices have been strengthened in recent quarters due to a resurgence in the demand for joint replacements as well as other surgeries that were delayed during the Covid-19 pandemic.
Abbott says the protein shake is first among the range of products lined up to be launched under its new brand, called Protality.
FILE PHOTO: Abbott Laboratories logo is displayed on a screen at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., October 18, 2021.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Kimly unit to buy coffeeshop property at Serangoon for S$13.2 million
summary: Kimly, a Singaporean food outlet operator, has agreed to purchase a coffeeshop property at Serangoon for S$13.2 million. The 358 sqm property has 60 years left on its lease and is valued at S$14 million, with Kimly paying S$13.7 million based on an independent valuation report. The acquisition is part of Kimly's strategy to expand its network of food outlets in Singapore and is expected to be completed by Dec 10, 2024, pending HDB approval.

images.alt_text: Kimly’s outlet management and food retail divisions contributed to its higher revenue, with three coffeeshops opened in FY2023 and another two opening in FY2024.

site_title: Indonesia to conclude free trade talks with Russia-led union in July
summary: Indonesia is set to conclude free trade talks with the Russian-led Eurasian Economic Union (EEU) in July, according to Coordinating Minister for Economic Affairs Airlangga Hartarto. The talks aim to create a mutually beneficial agreement for both countries, with Indonesia seeking to promote its palm oil exports to the EEU. The EEU is one of Indonesia's largest palm oil importers, and a successful agreement could help mitigate the impact of the EU's law banning the import of commodities linked to deforestation.

site_title: Euro dives on political uncertainty; sterling also down
summary: The euro plummeted 0.6% to its lowest level since May 9, following French President Emmanuel Macron's surprise decision to call a snap national election amid gains by far-right parties in the European Parliament. The euro also fell 0.4% against sterling to a two-year low. The uncertainty in France added to market volatility, which will be further fueled by the US inflation data and Federal Reserve policy meeting on Wednesday. The dollar index rose 0.22% to a one-month high, while the Japanese yen fell 0.7% after a strong US jobs report.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap legislative election after the defeat in the EU votes.
The dollar rose 0.6 per cent against the yen to 156.64. It was still down 0.4 per cent on the week, on track for its worst weekly performance since late April.
The dollar index, which tracks the currency against the euro and five other major rivals, rose 0.6 per cent to 104.76.

site_title:
Money and happiness: a lesson I learnt 
after 30 years in wealth management
summary: A wealthy investor, who accumulated a significant fortune in the late 1990s, shared a crucial lesson with the author after 25 years. He emphasized that accumulating wealth doesn't necessarily lead to happiness, and in fact, excessive focus on wealth can cause more unhappiness. The investor's strategy of only buying at all-time highs during the Asian financial crisis resulted in a significant increase in his wealth, while others lost everything. The author reflects on his own experience, realizing that the pursuit of wealth can lead to stress, comparison, and an endless pursuit of more, rather than true happiness and fulfillment.

images.alt_text: man, old, view

site_title: Pakistan’s central bank cuts interest rates to boost economy
summary: Pakistan's central bank cut its key interest rate by 150 basis points to 20.5% in a move to boost growth amid declining retail inflation. The decision comes two days ahead of the annual budget and follows a 30-month low inflation rate of 11.8% in May. The State Bank of Pakistan attributed the inflation slowdown to the significant decline in inflation since February. This is the first rate reduction in nearly four years, aiming to stimulate economic growth.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the State Bank of Pakistan (SBP) is pictured on a reception desk at the head office in Karachi, Pakistan July 16, 2019. REUTERS/Akhtar Soomro

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, June 10, 2024 (Ep 78)
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday ahead of the Federal Reserve's decision on Wednesday. The Euro hit a one-month low after French President Macron called for a snap election, while Malaysia cut diesel subsidies. SingPost shares dropped after Alibaba sold $33.3 million worth of shares. The Singapore shares index rose 0.1% on Monday, but overall regional markets declined due to strong US jobs data that reduced hopes for a rate cut.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, losers outnumber gainers 59 to 54.
Asian equities struggled on Monday, with Tokyo rising but losses in Seoul, Singapore, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington.
French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap legislative election after the defeat in the EU votes.
SingPost Centre at 10 Eunos Road 8 near Paya Lebar MRT station on Nov 03, 2020. Can be used for stories on mail, postage, post, postman, courier, parcel, envelope, stamp and delivery.

site_title: CEL, SingHaiyi units to build 367 apartments, strata office and retail tower on Peace Centre site
summary: CEL and SingHaiyi's joint development of the Peace Centre site in Sophia Road is moving forward with planning approval received in late 2023. The project will feature 367 residential units, strata office spaces, and retail areas, with completion expected by 2028. Launch of residential and strata office units is anticipated for Q3 this year, pending further approval from authorities.

images.alt_text: The sale outcome for the mixed-use development project was much lower than expected by market watchers who had anticipated a take-up rate of at least 20 per cent, going by response to recent launches.
En bloc die-hard Peace Centre finally nails it with S$650m deal
Chip Eng Seng, KSH and SingHaiyi are in talks to acquire 160-unit Park View Mansions for S$260 million.

site_title: PM Wong to make introductory visits to Brunei and Malaysia
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong will visit Brunei and Malaysia from June 11 to 12 for introductory trips to the two countries. During the visits, he will meet with the Bruneian royal family and Malaysia's prime minister. This trip follows a series of customary introductory visits to South-east Asian capitals, a tradition started by former Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong in 2004.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s foreign policy was among many issues discussed by Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong during his final media interview before relinquishing his role, alongside politics, social issues and the economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 10)
summary: Singapore's business sentiment continued its upward trend for the fourth consecutive quarter in Q3, according to the Singapore Commercial Credit Bureau. Standard Chartered established its first global fund management entity in Singapore. David Sin, Fullerton Health co-founder, was granted approval to leave Singapore for 2 months to visit family in China. The S$3 billion anti-money laundering bust concluded with 10 individuals jailed. Singapore stocks fell 0.3% due to weaker-than-expected hopes for an early Fed rate cut.

site_title: Top 20 China-linked SGX stocks reap total median returns of 8.4% year-to-date
summary: The top 20 China-linked stocks listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) have generated median total returns of 8.4% year-to-date, in line with the total returns of the FTSE China A50 Index at 9% and the CSI 300 Index at 5.1%. These stocks, which account for over 100 SGX-listed companies, have seen a net institutional inflow of S$200 million, led by the industrials sector. The top performer was Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, with a total return of 67.9%, followed by Sri Trang Agro-Industry and Best World.

images.alt_text: The exchange noted that open interest across key equity, foreign exchange and commodity derivatives also rose to record highs.

site_title: Nokia CEO makes world’s first ‘immersive’ phone call
summary: Nokia CEO Pekka Lundmark made the world's first "immersive" phone call, using a new technology that provides 3D audio and lifelike interactions. The call was made with Finland's Ambassador of Digitalisation and New Technologies and demonstrated improved sound quality over current monophonic technology. The technology, part of the 5G Advanced standard, can be implemented by transmitting spatial characteristics of a call in real-time and has potential for conference calls and person-to-person interactions. Nokia aims to get licensing opportunities for the technology, which is expected to take a few years to be widely available.

images.alt_text: The Nokia Oyj headquarters in Espoo, Finland, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Nokia Oyj plans to cut as many as 14,000 jobs, or 16% of its workforce, as a dearth of investment in fifth-generation mobile infrastructure forces it to take cost-cutting measures. Photographer: Roni Rekomaa/Bloomberg
Nokia in January forecast a demand recovery in the second half of 2024.

The Nokia Oyj headquarters in Espoo, Finland, on Thursday, Oct. 19, 2023. Nokia Oyj plans to cut as many as 14,000 jobs, or 16% of its workforce, as a dearth of investment in fifth-generation mobile infrastructure forces it to take cost-cutting measures. Photographer: Roni Rekomaa/Bloomberg
Nokia currently supplies 4G and 5G technology that allows in-house communications or helps industrial companies connect to data from machine sensors, among other uses.

site_title: Can Apple catch up with rivals in the AI race?
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to unveil iOS 18, a new operating system and major software update, at its developers conference. This marks the beginning of Apple's broader plan for generative AI, a technology that promises to enable devices to understand vast amounts of information and offer humanlike responses. As Google and Microsoft lead the innovation in this field, Apple risks being left behind, highlighting the tech industry's AI race. The move aims to catch up with rivals, but the challenge remains in delivering a comparable level of generative AI capabilities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Apple logo is pictured in an Apple store in Paris, France, March 6, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo
Apple’s plan to use its own chips and process AI tasks in the cloud was hatched about three years ago.

site_title: Dubai takes on Abu Dhabi in race for supremacy in family offices
summary: Dubai and Abu Dhabi are competing to become the hub for family offices in the Middle East. The UAE's reputation as a destination for wealthy families fleeing hostile regimes has surged in recent years. Dubai's financial centre, the Dubai International Financial Centre, has opened the DIFC Family Wealth Centre, a registry for family offices with minimum net assets of $50 million. In contrast, Abu Dhabi's Abu Dhabi Global Market offers flexible and discreet structures for billionaires' investment entities, with a reputation for low- to no-tax regimes. Both cities are attracting a diverse range of families, including those from India, Russia, and Africa, but face challenges in creating cohesion among these groups.

images.alt_text: The new Julius Baer recruits will focus on non-resident Indians, a lucrative segment of the bank’s wealth management offering that’s been bolstered by the growing number of wealthy Indians living overseas.
Rendering of The Dubai Mall.
DMCC chief operating officer Feryal Ahmadi noted that artificial intelligence is projected to add US$15 trillion to the global economy by 2030.
Office towers in the Dubai International Financial Centre Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
Indonesia’s chief investment minister Luhut Pandjaitan said that rich families had approached him to ask if it was possible for Jakarta to adopt a common law system in Bali.
Family offices are typically run by a CEO or chief investment officer and as many as 10 staff members.
Before co-founding the firm, Lee holds multiple positions at Pictet, CIC, and Indosuez during his 15-year private banking career.
Some 35 per cent of global family offices said they will allocate more assets to Asia-Pacific in the next five years.

site_title: Two companies will guide global supply chains
summary: Taiwanese companies TSMC and Foxconn are expanding their global supply chains, with TSMC partnering with Sony, Toyota, and Denso to serve Japan's automotive and electronics industries, and Foxconn investing in Mexico, India, and Southeast Asia. This shift is driven by China's diminishing role as a factory to the world, with rising labor costs and stiff competition. As a result, manufacturers and logistics providers are advised to follow TSMC and Foxconn's lead, as their global influence and technical dominance make them irreplaceable in the supply chain.

site_title: SBMA launches retail gold investment committee in collaboration with World Gold Council
summary: The Singapore Bullion Market Association (SBMA) has launched a Retail Gold Investment Committee in collaboration with the World Gold Council, chaired by Singapore-based precious metal dealing firm Silver Bullion. The committee aims to enhance trust and transparency in gold investments, implementing the Retail Gold Investment Principles established by the WGC. This move marks a significant step in developing Singapore as a premier hub for precious metals in the Asia-Pacific region, according to SBMA. The committee's launch follows a recent Asia Pacific Precious Metals Conference.

images.alt_text: The Monetary Authority of Singapore recently completed on-site inspections of some banks that were involved in the case.
Maintaining team stability may become more difficult as the private markets industry grows.
The MSCI China Index has climbed 24 per cent from a January low.

site_title: Putin set for rare visits to security partners North Korea and Vietnam
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin is set to visit North Korea and Vietnam in the coming weeks, marking rare trips to Moscow's traditional security partners. Putin's visit to North Korea would be his first since 2000 and could boost the regime's economy, with aid potentially worth billions of dollars. The timing of the visit comes as Ukraine receives billions of US dollars in fresh arms from its allies, narrowing the window for a Russian breakthrough. Putin's cooperation with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un has vexed Washington and its global partners, who accuse North Korea of sending massive amounts of artillery shells to Russia.

images.alt_text: Russian President Vladimir Putin said Russian regions outside the capital needed to have more economic opportunities and that plans were being discussed to move the head offices of major corporations and state companies to the regions.

In this pool photograph distributed by the Russian state agency Sputnik, Russia's President Vladimir Putin and China's President Xi Jinping exchange documents during a signing ceremony following their talks in Beijing on May 16, 2024. (Photo by Sergei BOBYLYOV / POOL / AFP) / ** Editor's note : this image is distributed by Russian state owned agency Sputnik **

site_title: Julius Baer targets rich Indians in Dubai with UBS, JPMorgan hires
summary: Swiss wealth manager Julius Baer hired senior bankers from UBS and JPMorgan to boost its business catering to rich Indians in Dubai, with a focus on non-resident Indians. The hires come as global private banking firms expand their presence in the Gulf to cater to a growing number of wealthy clients. The UAE attracted 4,500 new millionaires last year, with Dubai seeing a 53% rise in registered foundations. The new recruits will report to Tarun Jalali and will focus on wealth management offerings for NRIs.

images.alt_text: Benjamin Graham describes the market as a voting machine in the short run and a weighing machine in the long run.
Malcolm Tay joins the bank from Credit Suisse, where he was most recently deputy market group head and market leader for Indonesia.
Julius Baer has been under pressure since late last year when it revealed it had run up about US$700 million in loans to Signa and its founder, Austrian tycoon Rene Benko.
Julius Baer has announced its exit from the private debt business following steep losses from loans made to real estate group Signa, which collapsed under the weight of higher interest rates.

site_title: France faces ‘consequential’ vote as far-right rout prompts Macron gamble
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron has called a snap election on June 30, amid a bruising loss to the far-right in European parliament elections. The election, which could result in a hung parliament, will give the far-right National Rally party a significant chance to gain power. Macron's decision aims to reclaim the initiative and force the far-right into election mode faster. The election's outcome will determine Macron's ability to set the domestic agenda, with a possible loss of power to the far-right.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron’s reputation as a reformer and steward of the economy has also suffered blows in recent months

“I don’t think that we’ll be rolling back on (climate) policies. But I do think that it will be more complicated to get new policies off the ground,” Bas Eickhout, head of the European parliament’s Greens lawmaker group said.
French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap legislative election after the defeat in the EU votes.

European Commission President and EPP lead candidate Ursula von der Leyen speaking after the European Parliament election in Brussels on June 9, 2024. Given the results, she may need to make significant concessions to right-wing parties to secure support for a second terms as EC president.

site_title: Unicorns ruled for a decade, but tech needs a new beast now
summary: The term "unicorn" has lost its allure in the tech industry, with the number of startup unicorns created globally declining to 95 in 2023 from 621 in 2021. Investors are shifting focus to startups with strong fundamentals and at least $100 million in annual revenue, dubbed "thoroughbreds." This change aims to promote rational investing and avoid desperate measures to achieve a high valuation. European startups, with their transparency requirements, are well-positioned to benefit from this shift, and British investors are poised to make bigger bets in the tech sector.

images.alt_text: The tech and telco sector represents merely 2 per cent of the total number of listed companies on Vietnam's local bourses
AI services contributes seven percentage points in growth to Azure, up from six percentage points in the October-to-December quarter.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall as hopes for early Fed rate cut dim; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% on Monday, June 10, as hopes for an early Fed rate cut dimmed after stronger-than-expected US jobs figures. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,322.08. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on local markets, with Maybank's Thilan Wickramasinghe raising his year-end STI target to 3,583. Regional markets were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 gaining 0.9%, while South Korea's Kospi fell 0.8%.

images.alt_text: Asian equities struggled on Monday, with Tokyo rising but losses in Seoul, Singapore, Manila, Jakarta and Wellington.
Phillip Capital expects Oiltek's dividends to grow by 13 per cent in the current fiscal year.

site_title: Court lets Fullerton Health co-founder David Sin leave Singapore for 2 months to visit family in China
summary: David Sin, co-founder of Fullerton Health, has been granted permission to leave Singapore for 2 months to visit his family in China, where his wife and newborn child are staying. He was originally granted a S$200,000 bail, but an additional S$100,000 bail was imposed for him to leave the country. Sin is facing corruption charges related to falsifying entertainment claims and providing bribes to a former Aon executive.

images.alt_text: From left: Former CEO of insurance broker Aon Risk Solutions Collin Chiew; former Fullerton Healthcare founders David Sin, Daniel Chan and Michael Tan.
Chiew Collin (left), Sin David, Chan Pai Sheng, and Tan Kim Song.

site_title: Homeownership costs in the US jumped 26% since pandemic began
summary: US homeownership costs jumped 26% since the pandemic began, with the average annual outlay for a single-family home increasing to $18,118, or $1,510 more per month than in 2020. Home maintenance accounted for the largest share of costs, followed by taxes, insurance, and utilities. States with high purchase prices saw bigger percentage jumps, with Utah's costs rising 44% and Hawaii's at 38%. Experts advise homeowners to be over-prepared and save extra money, as the totals may be understated.

images.alt_text: US central bankers meeting next Tuesday (Jun 11) and Wednesday are still widely expected to leave the policy rate in the current 5.25 to 5.5 per cent range, where they have kept it since last July.
Demand from banks is fuelling sales of floating-rate, collateralized mortgage obligations (CMO), which are constructed from simpler mortgage securities.
The overall gap was US$74.6 billion, growing from March’s revised US$68.6 billion figure.
Unit labour costs, meanwhile, rose at a 4 per cent annualised rate, down from the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ first estimate of 4.7 per cent.

An attendee signs into a career fair hosted by the New Hanover NCWorks and the Cape Fear Workforce Development Board in Wilmington, North Carolina, US, on Tuesday, June 20, 2023. The Department of labor is scheduled to release initial jobless claims figures on June 22. Photographer: Allison Joyce/Bloomberg

site_title: Oil edges higher after weekly loss as focus turns to US Fed rates
summary: Oil prices edged higher after a weekly drop as traders digest the Opec+ decision to restore supply, with Brent trading near $80 a barrel. The market awaits industry reports and a US Federal Reserve decision on interest rates, which may impact borrowing costs. Despite Opec's announcement, officials emphasized the supply increase is provisional and could be paused. Crude has been falling since early April due to a weakening demand outlook, with concerns that Fed rates will remain high.

images.alt_text: Oil prices have been buttressed by support from Opec+ members Saudi Arabia and Russia, indicating readiness to pause or reverse oil output increases.

site_title: Eurozone investor morale rises more than expected in June
summary: Eurozone investor morale rose to 0.3 points in June, a 7.8-point increase from May, marking the eighth consecutive month of improvement. This rise in Sentix's index, despite expectations of a -1.8 points increase, suggests the economic recovery is proceeding with difficulty. Analysts attribute the sluggish improvement to Germany's economy not sending a clear signal of momentum. The sluggish growth indicates the ECB may cut interest rates further, but Sentix notes that inflation remains unfavorable, and Germany's economy only shows moderate progress in stabilizing.

images.alt_text: Net trade provided the biggest contribution to growth in the three-month period.
ECB’s remarks led investors to slightly reduce their bets on future monetary easing, which had increased in the days before its policy decision on the back of US data.
An index measuring manufacturing activity rose to 47.3 in May from April’s 45.7.
The unexpected inflation rise likely will not prevent the ECB from cutting record-high borrowing costs next week but may lead to a pause in July and slower future rate reductions.

site_title: Standard Chartered sets up first global fund management entity in Singapore
summary: Standard Chartered has launched its first global fund management entity in Singapore, Standard Chartered Funds VCC (SC Fund), catering to the bank's high-net-worth clients. The entity will offer custom-curated investment strategies, partnered with industry-leading global fund managers. Initially, the funds will be available to select clients in Singapore, Hong Kong, and Dubai, with plans to expand to other key markets. The bank aims to provide a long-term strategic asset allocation as part of a client's foundation portfolio.

images.alt_text: Jnoted that income from international banking clients have grown two times since 2021, while the number of such clients have also grown two times since 2021 as well.

site_title: S$3 billion anti-money laundering bust wraps up with 10th and final individual jailed
summary: Singapore's 10th and final individual in a S$3 billion anti-money laundering bust has been sentenced to 17 months in prison. Su Jianfeng, along with nine others, was arrested in August 2023 and charged with money laundering, fraud, and forgery. The group, believed to hail from Fujian, China, laundered ill-gotten gains through property purchases and online gambling operations. Assets totaling S$3 billion were initially seized, with nearly S$1 billion more discovered during further investigations. The court sentenced the group to between 13 and 17 months in prison, with some members deported upon completion of their terms.

images.alt_text: The police will maintain the prohibition against disposal and custody of the seized assets until the assets are dealt with by the court at the conclusion of the case.
The Monetary Authority of Singapore recently completed on-site inspections of some banks that were involved in the case.

The money launderers held millions in cryptocurrency, bags from top brands and glitzy cars. Also in the mix, collectible statues known as BE@RBRICKs, golf club memberships and a Daniel Arsham x Dior Eroded Basketball sculpture worth US$13,333.
Su Jianfeng at an awards ceremony in 2019. He is the last person to be sentenced in Singapore's largest money laundering case, and faces the longest jail term of 17 months.

site_title: Commonwealth Bank of Australia may exit Vietnamese bank after foreign investor cap vote
summary: Vietnam's Vietnam International Joint Stock Bank (VIB) will vote on a proposal to lower the foreign investor cap from 20.5% to 4.99%, potentially leading to the exit of its main overseas investor, Commonwealth Bank of Australia (CBA), which holds 19.8% of VIB's shares. The move aims to avoid fragmentation of foreign shareholding and may allow CBA to sell its stake. If approved, the new cap would apply from July 1, but its applicability to new investors is unclear.

images.alt_text: The massive bailout of SCB’s depositors has so far cost the central bank the equivalent of 6 per cent of Vietnam’s 2023 gross domestic product in special loans.

Corporate deposits at banks as of end-January fell by about 2.4 per cent from the end of last year to 6,670 trillion dong (S$357.1 billion), while deposits by individuals fell 0.5 per cent to 6,500 trillion dong, the latest central bank data shows.

site_title: Euro, French stocks hit by shock Macron call for snap election
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron called for a snap legislative election after being defeated in the European Union vote by the far-right. The euro fell 0.5% to a one-month low, while French bonds and stocks dropped, with Paris blue-chip stocks falling 2%. The election could lead to a loss of Macron's authority and impact on the euro, with economists warning of uncertainty and potential market volatility.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron’s reputation as a reformer and steward of the economy has also suffered blows in recent months

European Commission President and EPP lead candidate Ursula von der Leyen speaking after the European Parliament election in Brussels on June 9, 2024. Given the results, she may need to make significant concessions to right-wing parties to secure support for a second terms as EC president.
The euro was up 0.04 per cent at US$1.0872, not far from a two-and-a-half month top of US$1.0916 hit earlier in the week.

site_title: Japan’s service sector mood hits nearly 2-year low in May
summary: Japan's service sector sentiment reached a nearly 2-year low in May, with an index of 45.7, down 1.7 points from the previous month. This is the lowest level since August 2022, attributed to rising fuel and food costs from a weak yen, which dragged on household spending. The data suggests a fragile nature of consumption, making it harder for the Bank of Japan to justify further interest rate hikes.

site_title: Uphill road for Europe’s climate plan after EU election
summary: A more rightward-leaning European parliament may make it harder to pass ambitious EU climate policies, but existing green policies are likely to stay in place. The EU's 2040 climate target, aiming for a 90% emissions cut, may be delayed due to populistic reasons. While new climate measures face a tougher ride, a full-scale reversal of existing policies would be legally difficult. The EU's existing climate measures are expected to deliver its 2030 climate target, and broad rollbacks are unlikely, with officials and analysts expecting changes in individual pieces of legislation instead.

images.alt_text: European Commission President and EPP lead candidate Ursula von der Leyen speaking after the European Parliament election in Brussels on June 9, 2024. Given the results, she may need to make significant concessions to right-wing parties to secure support for a second terms as EC president.

Net trade provided the biggest contribution to growth in the three-month period.

site_title: Volvo is shifting EV production to Belgium from China
summary: Volvo Cars is shifting electric vehicle production from China to Belgium due to trade frictions between the EU and China. The European Union is set to impose tariffs on China-made electric vehicles, affecting Volvo's manufacturing operations. Volvo may also move assembly of some models bound for the UK. The decision reflects the company's ambition to build cars where they are sold, and not to speculate on potential measures. China has accused the EU of working to "suppress" its companies, while the EU has denied any wrongdoing.

images.alt_text: The EX90 SUV with a battery passport is due to start production soon at Volvo’s plant in Charleston, South Carolina, and will be delivered to customers in Europe and North America from the second half of the year.

A male worker cleans a Volvo logo as it sits on a sign at the Volvo Cars display stand, ahead of the 85th Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday, March 2, 2015. site_title: Singapore business sentiment improves further in Q3 2024: Commercial Credit Bureau survey
summary: Singapore's business sentiment has continued its upward trend for the fourth consecutive quarter in Q3 2024, with the business optimism index rising to +4.94 percentage points, up from +4.82 in Q2. The transportation, construction, and financial industries are the most optimistic sectors, with three out of six indicators positive for each. The manufacturing sector remains downbeat, while the wholesale sector reports slightly improved sentiments. SCCB CEO Audrey Chia notes a relatively upbeat outlook for local businesses, citing growth in transportation and construction sectors, but also warns of downside risks such as escalating geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Office workers walking at Raffles Place Park within the heart of Singapore's financial centre in the CBD area, 2 March 2023. Can be used for stories on money, property, land, commercial, office, invest, budget, income, bank, finance, financial, population, economy

site_title: Euro drop on election risk a taste of more to come, analysts say
summary: The euro dropped 0.5% to $1.0751 on Monday, its lowest in a month, after French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz suffered losses in European elections. The outcome may lead to increased volatility in the currency, particularly if Macron's ability to push through legislation is hindered by the far-right. Strategists warn that this could undermine the euro-positive sentiment and lead to widened sovereign yield spreads, negatively affecting the currency.

images.alt_text: French President Emmanuel Macron’s reputation as a reformer and steward of the economy has also suffered blows in recent months
The euro was up 0.04 per cent at US$1.0872, not far from a two-and-a-half month top of US$1.0916 hit earlier in the week.

site_title: Binance-linked token’s record cements founder Zhao as richest US inmate
summary: Zhao Changpeng, co-founder of Binance, has become the richest person ever to serve a US federal sentence, with his net worth increasing by $4.1 billion in 2024. The BNB token, linked to Binance, surged to a record high during his four-month jail sentence for failing to safeguard the world's largest crypto exchange against money laundering. This rally solidifies Zhao's status as the 40th richest person in the world, cementing his position as a wealthy individual despite his incarceration.

images.alt_text: Zhao Changpeng arriving at federal court in Seattle, Washington, on Tuesday. The sentence he received was far below the three years requested by prosecutors, who had sought to make an example out of Zhao to a heavily scrutinised industry rebounding from a slew of high-profile scandals.
Former Binance chief Changpeng Zhao pleaded guilty to violating US anti-money laundering laws. Binance agreed in February to pay US$4.3 billion to settle the charges.
The most obvious change is that Zhao Changpeng has relinquished his role as the public face of the company.

site_title: Tang family scion seeking S$83 million for Victoria Park mansion
summary: A scion of the Tang family, behind Singapore's iconic department store chain, is seeking to sell his Victoria Park mansion for S$83 million. The 0.7-acre property features eight bathrooms, a swimming pool, and covered parking. This sale comes amid an increase in mansion transactions in Singapore, following a lull triggered by rising interest rates and a major money laundering investigation.

site_title: Saudis said to hand about 60% of Aramco offer to foreigners
summary: Saudi Aramco's US$11.2 billion stock sale saw foreign investors allocated about 60% of the shares, a significant shift from the 2019 listing that was largely dominated by local buyers. The deal drew strong demand from the US, Europe, and Asia, with orders worth over US$65 billion. The Saudi government, which owns 82% of Aramco, retained its majority stake, with the Public Investment Fund holding 16%. The offering generated US$11.2 billion in proceeds, which will help fund the kingdom's economic transformation.

images.alt_text: The shares opened at 27.95 riyals a share, after closing the previous session on Thursday at 28.3 riyals, but climbed to 28.35 riyals by 0730 GMT.
Aramco shares were priced at 27.25 riyals (S$9.77), near the bottom of a 26.7-to-29 riyals range used in marketing the sale.

(FILES) This picture shows Aramco tower at the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh on April 16, 2023. Saudi Arabia has ordered energy giant Aramco to maintain its oil production capacity at 12 million barrels per day, abandoning a planned increase, the firm said on January 30, 2024. "Aramco announces that it has received a directive from the ministry of energy to maintain its maximum sustainable capacity (MSC) at 12 million barrels per day" instead of ramping it up to 13 million bpd, the firm said in a statement. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)
The contract is for Sinopec Oilfield Service to procure and construct the third-phase of the Master Gas System in Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Thailand aiming for at least 3% growth this year, more tourists
summary: Thailand aims for at least 3% economic growth this year, seeking to attract more foreign tourists and boost public and private investment. The country's growth slowed to 1.5% in the first quarter, lagging regional peers. Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira plans to increase foreign tourists to 36.7 million, with a focus on credit access for borrowers and a 50 billion baht credit guarantee scheme. The government also aims to disburse at least 70% of its 2024 investment budget by the end of September.

images.alt_text: Most economists expect the key rate to remain steady at a more than decade high of 2.5 per cent next week.
Thailand needs more financing to help with the transition as green and sustainably-linked loans accounted for only 1.4 per cent of total outstanding lending.
Customers at a store in Bangkok. The government has favoured cutting rates from a decade-high 2.5% to boost consumption and growth.
Yoma says any past or present property sales events related to condominiums in Bangkok are unconnected to Yoma Land or the group in any way.

site_title: Europe rocked by far-right gains
summary: The far-right has made significant gains in the European Parliament election, with the Rassemblement National party winning 31.4% of the vote in France, surpassing Emmanuel Macron's centrist alliance. This has led to a potential snap election in France and may influence the formation of a new European Commission, with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen potentially needing to make concessions to right-wing parties to secure support. The election marks a rightward shift in European politics, with far-right groups projected to hold around one quarter of the seats, and could lead to a more protectionist EU with global implications.

images.alt_text: European Commission President and EPP lead candidate standing for re-election, Ursula von der Leyen speaking during the 16th European Economic Congress (EEC) in Katowice, Poland on May 7, 2024.
A potential second term as European Commission chief for Ursula von der Leyen will have a huge role in defining the EU’s longer-term political and economic character.
French President Emmanuel Macron’s reputation as a reformer and steward of the economy has also suffered blows in recent months

site_title: Make ABSD less punitive for younger local singles and PR couples trading owner-occupied homes
summary: Singapore has relaxed its policies for older singles and PR couples buying second homes, aiming to increase housing mobility. From Budget 2024, eligible individuals can claim a refund of up to S$300,000 on Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) for a second home purchase. To qualify, they must sell their first home within six months and the value of the second home must be lower than the sold first home. This change is expected to reduce transaction costs and facilitate household needs changes.

images.alt_text: Data from the Urban Redevelopment Authority showed that private home price growth slowed to 6.8 per cent in 2023, from 8.6 per cent in 2022 and 10.6 per cent in 2021.
Some property buyers used the “99-to-1” arrangement to reduce the rightful ABSD payable on the purchase of a residential property.

site_title: Chinese Premier Li Qiang to visit New Zealand this week
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang will visit New Zealand later this week, marking 10 years since the conclusion of the New Zealand-China Comprehensive Strategic Partnership. The visit comes amid rising tensions between Beijing and Western trading partners, particularly over trade and security issues. Li's trip follows a visit by Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi in March, and New Zealand Prime Minister Christopher Luxon is seeking to deepen ties with like-minded nations while also engaging with China on key issues. The visit is seen as a test of New Zealand's commitment to balancing its relationships with China and Western countries.

images.alt_text: The MSCI China Index has climbed 24 per cent from a January low.
Over recent months, a flurry of data has shown different parts of the US$18.6 trillion economy recovering at varying speeds, heightening uncertainty about the outlook.
Business confidence levels also eased to a seven-month low amid concerns about the global economic environment and rising prices.
China’s surplus in manufacturing trade, which is close to record levels, points to a much broader surge in exports.

site_title: Su Jianfeng gets 17 months jail, the longest sentence among the ten money launderers
summary: Su Jianfeng, a 36-year-old Vanuatu national, was sentenced to 17 months in prison for money laundering and forgery in Singapore's largest money laundering case. The significant amount of money laundered and his agreement to forfeit 95% of seized assets stood as aggravating factors. Su Jianfeng faces 14 charges in total, including four counts of corruption and seven counts of forgery. He is the last to be sentenced among the 10 foreign nationals charged, with nine others receiving sentences ranging from 13 to 16 months.

images.alt_text: Wang Dehai, last of the 10 money laundering accused to plead guilty, sentenced to xx months of jail on Friday.
Su Jianfeng, a 36-year-old Vanuatu national involved in Singapore's S$3 billion money laundering case, pleaded guilty on Thursday to one count of money laundering and one count of forgery.
Lin Baoying, one of the 10 foreigners arrested in the S$3 billion money laundering case.
Su Jianfeng now faces 14 charges in total in Singapore’s biggest money laundering case involving more than S$3 billion in assets.

site_title: China’s home de-stocking push to bring developers little cheer
summary: China's home de-stocking push to convert unsold homes into affordable housing is unlikely to help cash-strapped developers, as the program's limited size and potentially low prices are expected to deter them. The 300 billion yuan lending facility, backed by the central bank, may only benefit a handful of distressed developers. Analysts estimate that the program would only cover 12% of housing inventories at average market prices, and even if developers profit from selling to state-owned enterprises (SOEs), they may be required to use proceeds to finish existing projects rather than repay debt.

images.alt_text: China’s new home prices have dropped 5.7 per cent as at April from the 2021 high, while existing home prices are down 11.4 per cent.
Guess who’s angry at China’s real estate bailout: homeowners
Cities with more than three million people are expected to take the lead in developing affordable housing.
Outstanding PSL loans stood at 2.95 trillion yuan at the end of May, compared with 3.03 trillion yuan at end-April, says the People’s Bank of China.

site_title: European nations compete for Chinese EV factories, jobs even as EU weighs tariffs
summary: European nations are competing for Chinese electric vehicle (EV) factories and jobs, despite EU investigations into China's auto subsidies and potential tariffs. Chinese automakers like BYD, Chery, and Saic Motor are investing in Europe to build their brands and save on shipping costs. Hungary secured the first European factory investment by a Chinese automaker, while Spain and Italy are also attracting investment. EU tariffs could help European automakers compete, but may also spur Chinese investment. Sales of Chinese-brand cars are forecast to hit 7% of the European market by 2028, with Hungary, Spain, and Italy leading the competition.

images.alt_text: Trade frictions between the EU and China have led to a barrage of anti-dumping probes against Beijing amid allegations of unfair subsidies.
China’s surplus in manufacturing trade, which is close to record levels, points to a much broader surge in exports.
China has repeatedly rebuked the EU for its probe.
Great Wall Motors reportedly sold about 6,300 cars in Europe in 2023, excluding Russia, accounting for about 2 per cent of its overall exports.

site_title: Asia: Markets fall as strong US jobs data dents rate cut hopes
summary: Asian markets fell on Monday as a strong US jobs report raised concerns about interest rate cuts, despite easing worries about the US economy. The mixed jobs report, which showed the world's largest economy added more jobs than expected, led to losses in Seoul, Singapore, and other Asian markets. Investors await the Federal Reserve's updated "dot plot" outlook for borrowing costs, with some predicting zero to three rate cuts this year. The euro fell against its peers due to uncertainty in the European Union following far-right party victories.

images.alt_text: Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, Wellington, Taipei and Jakarta all fell, while Sydney, Singapore, Seoul and Manila were in the green.

site_title: Donald Trump to sit for probation interview on Monday following conviction
summary: Donald Trump will participate in a virtual interview with a New York City probation officer on Monday, following his conviction on 34 counts of falsifying business records. The guilty verdict, related to hush-money payments to Stormy Daniels, makes Trump the first former US president to be convicted of a felony. Trump's sentencing is scheduled for July 11, with a possible probationary term due to his age and first-time offender status. Trump's campaign has vowed to appeal the case, and he remains a strong contender for the Republican nomination despite the conviction.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Former US President and Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump walks to speak to the press after he was convicted in his criminal trial at Manhattan Criminal Court in New York City, on May 30, 2024. A New York jury convicted Donald Trump on all charges in his hush money case on May 30, 2024 in a seismic development barely five months ahead of the election where he seeks to recapture the White House. (Photo by JUSTIN LANE / POOL / AFP)

Donald Trump is in a close race with Democratic incumbent Joe Biden ahead of the Nov 5 presidential election.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Phillip Capital initiates ‘buy’ on Oiltek with S$0.70 target price
summary: Phillip Capital has initiated a "buy" call on Oiltek International with a target price of S$0.70, citing the company's growing book orders and asset-light business model. Analyst Paul Chew forecasts 13% dividend growth and expects Oiltek's order book to mark a fifth straight year of record orders. The company's focus on sustainable aviation fuel, particularly hydrogenated vegetable oil, is seen as a key growth opportunity. As of Monday, Oiltek's shares rose 13.7% or S$0.05 to S$0.415.

Oiltek chief executive Henry Yong says Oiltek aims to continue its momentum of contract acquisitions from the prior year.

site_title: Microsoft unveils all-digital Xbox consoles, ‘Doom’ title at Games Showcase
summary: Microsoft unveiled its all-digital Xbox consoles, a disc-less version of the Xbox Series X and S consoles, and a special edition of the Series X with 2TB storage. The company also showcased trailers for over a dozen games, including the next "Call of Duty" title and "Doom: The Dark Ages." The hardware refresh aims to boost Xbox sales, competing with Sony's PlayStation 5, and highlights Microsoft's commitment to Xbox Game Pass, which will feature many of the showcased games.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain February 27, 2024. REUTERS/Bruna Casas/File Photo
Microsoft is taking AI technology into a number of fields of the business world with what it calls Copilot technology.
For customer support tasks, the new AI tool will be able to scour a company’s help manuals and materials to train chatbots with better answers to questions that customers might ask in a chat window.
The layoffs will impact teams including Azure for Operators and Mission Engineering, according to the report.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, Sabana Reit, Q&M Dental
summary: Alibaba Group's subsidiary Alibaba Investment sold 72.5 million shares of SingPost for S$33.3 million, reducing its stake to 327.6 million shares. Sabana Reit's unitholders urged the manager to hold an EGM with amended resolutions. Q&M Dental's new AI platform is set to improve service quality and standards, with one project expected to increase revenue by 10%.

site_title: The world’s flying again and jets are burning fuel like it’s 2019
summary: The world is experiencing a surge in air travel, with passenger numbers exceeding 2019 levels in Singapore and other key hubs. According to industry data, 10.5 million flights are scheduled for the third quarter, and record passenger numbers are anticipated this year. This trend is driving an increase in jet fuel consumption, which is expected to reach 99 billion gallons, a 3% jump from 2019. However, efficiency gains are mitigating the growth, with some analysts predicting that fuel consumption will not surpass 2019's level this year.

images.alt_text: Oneworld plans to launch a technology platform later this year that will allow travellers to check-in, including their luggage, just once across different carriers.
CAAS says such registry will align with internationally recognised sustainability standards.

IATA director-general Willie Walsh (above, in Dubai on Sunday) recommends keeping the current system of taxing airlines in the country where they are headquartered, because "only the battalions of accountants needed to manage the reporting mess" would be happy if the change is made.

site_title: Gold steadies after slide below key US$2,300 level
summary: Gold prices steadied at US$2,396.69 per ounce, up 0.2%, after a decline below the key US$2,300 level due to stronger-than-expected US jobs data. This reduced expectations for an early interest rate cut this year, making gold more expensive for other currency holders. The US dollar rose 0.2% against its rivals, while benchmark US 10-year Treasury yields edged up.

images.alt_text: Spot prices for gold fell 1.5 per cent after the People’s Bank of China said its bullion holdings were unchanged at the end of May.

site_title: Japan’s Q1 GDP fell less than first reported on revised capex
summary: Japan's economy contracted 1.8% annually in the first quarter, less than the initial reported 2.0% decline, according to revised government data. The capital expenditure component fell 0.4%, contributing to the upward revision, while private consumption and external demand also declined. Analysts expect the economy to have bottomed out in the first quarter, but a weak yen and plant disruptions weigh on the outlook. The revised GDP data comes ahead of the Bank of Japan's interest rate decision, with investors seeking clues on further rate hikes.

images.alt_text: Sluggish private consumption is a source of concern for policymakers striving to achieve sustained economic growth underpinned by solid wages and durable inflation.
Wage gains resulting from annual pay tend to be reflected gradually in workers’ paychecks from April through the summer.
The central bank has signalled a cautious approach to further tightening due to a fragile economic recovery.

site_title: Japan government to call for flexible policy amid price uncertainty, draft blueprint shows
summary: Japan's government will propose a flexible policy approach to address the uncertainty surrounding inflation and consumption, as the country faces a "critical moment" in shifting away from a deflation-prone economy. The draft blueprint highlights the need for close coordination with the Bank of Japan to maintain inflation around 2% and create an environment where wages rise faster than inflation. The government aims to facilitate smoother cost pass-through in industries such as construction and transportation, and will submit legislation to next year's parliament to achieve this goal.

images.alt_text: Shoppers make their way at a shopping district in Tokyo, Japan March 19, 2024. REUTERS/Kim Kyung-Hoon
