Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Alibaba unit dumps S$33.3 million in SingPost shares
summary: Alibaba Investment, a subsidiary of Alibaba Group, sold 72.5 million SingPost shares for S$33.3 million, reducing its stake to 11.34% from 14.56%. The shares were sold at S$0.46 apiece, below SingPost's closing price of S$0.485. This transaction marks a significant decrease in Alibaba's investment in SingPost, which first invested in 2014 with a 10.4% stake.

images.alt_text: Alibaba gets nod to raise SingPost stake

site_title: Saudi Arabia set to raise US$11.2 billion selling Aramco shares at lower end of expectations
summary: Saudi Arabia is set to raise over $11.2 billion by selling shares in oil giant Aramco at a price near the lower end of expectations. The shares were priced at 27.25 riyals (S$9.77), covering four to five times the offering. Foreign demand was stronger than expected, driven by interest from China, Asia, and Europe. The funds are likely to be channeled into the Public Investment Fund's $925 billion budget, aiming to diversify away from oil reliance and address the kingdom's budget deficit.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This picture shows Aramco tower at the King Abdullah Financial District (KAFD) in Riyadh on April 16, 2023. Saudi Arabia has ordered energy giant Aramco to maintain its oil production capacity at 12 million barrels per day, abandoning a planned increase, the firm said on January 30, 2024. "Aramco announces that it has received a directive from the ministry of energy to maintain its maximum sustainable capacity (MSC) at 12 million barrels per day" instead of ramping it up to 13 million bpd, the firm said in a statement. (Photo by Fayez Nureldine / AFP)
The contract is for Sinopec Oilfield Service to procure and construct the third-phase of the Master Gas System in Saudi Arabia.
The government is selling 1.545 billion Aramco shares, representing a 0.64 per cent stake, at a price range of 26.70 to 29 riyals apiece.
Proceeds from the share sale will help fund big initiatives to diversify the Saudi economy away from oil.

site_title: Eurozone economy resumed growth thanks to trade and spending
summary: The Eurozone economy resumed growth in the first quarter with a 0.3% GDP increase, surpassing initial estimates. Net trade contributed 0.9 percentage points, while consumer spending added 0.1 percentage point, offsetting drops in investment and inventory. The growth marks the end of a contraction in the final quarter of 2023, and confidence in a sustained recovery is building. Economists predict a full-year pace of 0.7% growth, with countries experiencing varying growth drivers, including tourism and construction.

images.alt_text: The ECB cut interest rates from record highs on Thursday in a long-telegraphed move, but held back from any pledge to ease policy further after inflation and wage growth data in recent weeks came in above its expectations.
The ECB lowered its interest rates for the first time since 2019 on Jun 6, signalling a shift away from its aggressive policy to put an end to a surge in inflation.
ECB’s remarks led investors to slightly reduce their bets on future monetary easing, which had increased in the days before its policy decision on the back of US data.
An index measuring manufacturing activity rose to 47.3 in May from April’s 45.7.
The unexpected inflation rise likely will not prevent the ECB from cutting record-high borrowing costs next week but may lead to a pause in July and slower future rate reductions.
A sentiment indicator published on Thursday (May 30) by the European Commission rose to 96 in May from 95.6 the previous month.
The European Central Bank looks set to lower interest rates next week after its biggest ever streak of hikes brought down inflation to just above its 2 per cent target but also choked off credit.
Expectations for inflation in the next 12 months eased to 2.9 per cent from 3 per cent a month earlier to hit their lowest level since September 2021.

site_title: As diners economise, Sydney’s top restaurants are shutting their doors
summary: Sydney's top restaurants are shutting down due to the ongoing cost-of-living crisis and lingering pandemic effects. Celebrity chef Kylie Kwong announced the closure of her eatery Lucky Kwong, while Tetsuya's will close in July. Industry owners blame elevated interest rates, rising wages, and high prices for the decline. The Australian hospitality sector is experiencing a five-year high in insolvencies, with sticky inflation and stubborn interest rates to blame. The rate of insolvencies is expected to accelerate, with small to medium operators being the hardest hit.

images.alt_text: Disfrutar in Barcelona tops the best restaurant list.

Hong Kong’s retail property market is also being helped by the return of tourists after the pandemic.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, June 7, 2024 (Ep 77)
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday, with Mitsubishi and Sumitomo Mitsui banks divesting 1.32 trillion yen in Toyota shareholdings. Changi Airport Group reported a 13-fold increase in full-year net profit to S$431 million, driven by post-Covid recovery. Meanwhile, Singapore shares rose 0.2% at the open, as traders eyed the major US jobs report.

site_title: Issue 103: Singapore courts data centres; Indonesia traces commodities
summary: Singapore has the highest land cost in the Asia-Pacific for building medium-range data centres, with a focus on higher-value sustainable solutions. Indonesia is also addressing environmental concerns, with plans to improve supply chain accountability following Europe's deforestation ban.

Singapore’s government plans to reinvent petrochemical base Jurong Island as a sustainable energy and chemicals park.

site_title: Oil set for weekly loss after Opec+ supply plan rattles market
summary: Opec+ announced a plan to return some oil supply this year, causing oil prices to rebound and set the market for a weekly decline. Despite reassurances from Saudi Arabia and other Opec+ members, Brent futures are trading near $80 a barrel, on track for a third weekly drop. West Texas Intermediate is also expected to fall, with prices influenced by ongoing demand concerns and geopolitical risks in the Middle East. The market reaction is mixed, with some analysts predicting a bearish effect and others expecting the plan to maintain full cuts into next year.

site_title: ECB policymakers warn about inflation challenge
summary: European Central Bank policymakers cut interest rates from record highs but held back from further easing policy, citing inflation and wage growth data above expectations. ECB officials warned that pushing inflation down to 2% could be challenging, with some seeing room to ease policy further in 2024. However, most policymakers refrained from making specific predictions, and the next possible rate cut is expected to be in September, provided data supports it.

images.alt_text: The ECB lowered its interest rates for the first time since 2019 on Jun 6, signalling a shift away from its aggressive policy to put an end to a surge in inflation.
The rate reduction is tipped to fuel the bullish outlook for European stocks and with it prospects for the equity capital market, enticing companies to activate listing plans.
The ECB welcomed the fall in price growth as it trimmed its deposit rate to 3.75 per cent from a record 4 per cent, its first cut since 2019.

site_title: India Modi’s alliance unanimously elects him to lead as PM for third term
summary: India's Narendra Modi was unanimously elected by lawmakers of his National Democratic Alliance (NDA) to serve as prime minister for a historic third consecutive term. The BJP secured 240 seats, far short of the 272 needed to govern on its own, and needed the support of regional parties to form the government. Modi will meet President Droupadi Murmu on Sunday to present his claim to form a new government, with a swearing-in ceremony scheduled for the same day.

images.alt_text: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi speaks after releasing the Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) manifesto ahead of country's upcoming general elections, at the party headquarters in New Delhi on April 14, 2024. (Photo by Sajjad HUSSAIN / AFP)

(Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP)
Investors have prospered under Prime Minister Narendra Modi, as India’s equity benchmarks have more than tripled since he started as leader in May 2014.
Indian women waiting to cast their votes at a polling station during the first phase of the general election in Imphal, Manipur, on Apr 19.

Indian stocks tumbled the most in four years on Tuesday after Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party lost its majority in parliament.

site_title: Analysts anticipate more interest rate cuts with ECB expected to start ‘dialling back’
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered its interest rates for the first time since 2019, signaling a shift away from its aggressive policy to combat inflation. The ECB's president, Christine Lagarde, stated that the inflation outlook had improved "markedly," and there was a "strong likelihood" of a "dialling-back phase." Analysts predict further rate cuts, with some forecasting 50 basis points of reductions in the second half of 2024, and others expecting modest cuts in the third and fourth quarters of this year.

images.alt_text: Chong Xin Wei
Brent crude futures settled US$1.46 higher or 1.86 per cent at US$79.87 a barrel.
The euro was up 0.04 per cent at US$1.0872, not far from a two-and-a-half month top of US$1.0916 hit earlier in the week.
The ECB welcomed the fall in price growth as it trimmed its deposit rate to 3.75 per cent from a record 4 per cent, its first cut since 2019.
ECB’s remarks led investors to slightly reduce their bets on future monetary easing, which had increased in the days before its policy decision on the back of US data.

site_title: Europe, US fearful of China electric cars, says BYD founder
summary: BYD chairman Wang Chuanfu says European and US politicians are "afraid" of Chinese electric vehicles, citing the strength of China's car industry. The European Union is expected to unveil tariffs on Chinese electric cars, which China may retaliate with. Despite being a small market, Chinese EVs made by brands like MG Motors and BYD are gaining popularity, with sales expected to rise to 20% of battery-only vehicles in Europe by 2027. Wang calls for greater competition in the industry to manage the transition to electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: BYD intensified the price war by cutting the prices of many popular models in February which led others to follow.

A sign outside a BYD Co. electric vehicle showroom, operated by Schiller Auto, in Budapest, Hungary, on Monday, May 27, 2024. Chinese EV giant BYD plans to set up its first European car plant in Hungary. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
BYD has stopped producing cars powered by fossil fuels entirely in early 2022.
FILE PHOTO: The BYD logo is displayed at the Beijing International Automotive Exhibition, or Auto China 2024, in Beijing, China, April 25, 2024. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Since Beijing phased out a national subsidy programme for EV purchases in 2022, some smaller manufacturers have been pushed to the brink.

site_title: Asean – the hotspot for foreign direct investments
summary: ASEAN economies, particularly six major ASEAN nations, are experiencing a surge in foreign direct investments due to supply chain diversification and the "China+1" strategy. Malaysia aims to attract RM500 billion in semiconductor investments, while Vietnam faces regulatory gaps hindering growth and a trade dispute with the US. Meanwhile, Indonesia and Singapore are strengthening their clean energy partnerships. Despite challenges, some ASEAN countries are seeing growth, such as Vietnam's stocks rising due to sweetened US trade terms and GoTo's potential rebound. Regulatory efforts and partnerships are expected to drive future growth in the region.

site_title: Far East Shopping Centre owners reject lower S$850 million offer; sale falls through
summary: Far East Shopping Centre's owners rejected a S$850 million offer, falling short of the 80% mandate required for a collective sale. The lower offer, 8% below the guide price of S$928 million, received only 60-odd% backing from unit owners. This is the second failed attempt at a collective sale for the 999-year leasehold property on Singapore's prime retail belt, following a previous deal in September 2023 that unraveled due to URA approval issues.

images.alt_text: Katong Plaza has received outline planning approval from URA to convert it for hotel use, says Huttons Asia.
A  5,554 sq ft space at Block 210 New Upper Changi Road near Bedok MRT station is among the 19 units DBS has accepted offers for.
The tender for Pine Grove condominium is the latest in a long series of unsuccessful collective sale attempts.

site_title: UK house prices stagnate with small dip in May, Halifax says
summary: The UK housing market stagnated in May, with Halifax reporting a 0.1% drop in property values, following a 0.9% decline in March. The market has been constrained by high interest rates and a shortage of available properties, with prices remaining largely static. Labour has pledged mortgage guarantees to first-time buyers, while the government has promised measures to boost the supply of new homes. Despite a 1.5% year-over-year increase, prices are still lower than pre-pandemic levels.

images.alt_text: Beijing focuses on low-cost housing in new land supply for rental homes

site_title: Meituan prepping Middle East foray while exploring Europe, Asia
summary: Meituan, a Chinese food delivery giant, is preparing for its first expansion beyond China, with a potential entry into the Middle East. The company, led by founder Wang Xing, has spent months preparing to debut its KeeTa app in Riyadh and is also exploring markets in Europe and Southeast Asia. Despite a 25% quarterly sales rise, Meituan faces intensifying competition at home and a challenging consumer spending environment in China. The company's global expansion aims to capitalize on its success in Hong Kong, where its KeeTa app has become the No. 2 spot.

images.alt_text: Meituan, which operates an app providing services as varied as bike-sharing, ticket-booking and maps, reported revenue in the three months to Mar 31 of 73.3 billion yuan (S$13.6 billion), against 58.62 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.
Meituan’s global expansion is emblematic of a push by Chinese companies abroad, seeking growth as local competition intensifies even while consumption wanes.
Meituan reported sales of 73.7 billion yuan (S$13.8 billion) in the December quarter, versus the 72.7 billion yuan average projection.

site_title: BTO scheme led to early marriages but may also have contributed to more divorces: study
summary: A study by three NUS professors found that the Build-to-Order (BTO) scheme in Singapore may have contributed to both early marriages and higher divorce rates. The scheme, which provides subsidized public flats, led to an increase in marriages among women aged 25-29 and men aged 30-34 between 2000 and 2010. Divorce rates also rose during this period, with women aged 30-34 experiencing a 3.5% to 7.2% increase and men aged 35-39 experiencing a 3.5% to 6.3% increase. The study suggests that the BTO scheme may have rushed marriage decisions, leading to an increase in divorce rates.

site_title: Five young stars to watch out for at Euro 2024
summary: Five young football stars to watch at Euro 2024 include Jude Bellingham (England), Nico Williams (Spain), Xavi Simons (Netherlands), Florian Wirtz (Germany), and Arda Guler (Turkey). Bellingham, 20, has had a stellar season with Real Madrid, while Williams, 21, has impressed with Athletic Bilbao. Simons, 21, has excelled on loan at RB Leipzig, and Wirtz, 21, has been instrumental in Bayer Leverkusen's dominance in the German Bundesliga. Guler, 19, has also made a name for himself at Real Madrid. These young players are expected to make a significant impact at the tournament.

site_title: China’s Luckin Coffee is back from the brink and beating Starbucks
summary: Luckin Coffee, once plagued by accounting scandals, has staged an extraordinary comeback as China's biggest coffee retailer, surpassing Starbucks in sales. The company's focus on automation, digitalisation, and cashless, takeout kiosk counters has enabled it to undercut Starbucks. Luckin's recent growth was led by a push into the vast hinterland, where Starbucks has not yet ventured, and the development of drinks catering to local preferences. The company's recovery shows there's still growth to be found in an economy grappling with deflation and a property crisis. Luckin's private equity backing and new store openings, including a US$120 million coffee roasting plant, have helped it maintain an edge over competitors, including its founder's rival coffee chain Cotti.

images.alt_text: Cotti Coffee has expanded its footprint to more than 330 of China’s nearly 400 county-level cities,

site_title: Thai headline inflation at year-high in May, back to central bank target range
summary: Thailand's headline inflation reached 1.54% in May, its highest in 13 months, and returned to the central bank's target range of 1-3% for the first time in a year. The increase was driven by higher energy and food prices, but economists expect the key interest rate to remain steady at 2.5% next week, easing pressure on the central bank to cut borrowing costs. The central bank retained its forecast for a 0-1% inflation rate for 2024.

images.alt_text: Thailand needs more financing to help with the transition as green and sustainably-linked loans accounted for only 1.4 per cent of total outstanding lending.
Customers at a store in Bangkok. The government has favoured cutting rates from a decade-high 2.5% to boost consumption and growth.
Thailand expects to earn more revenue than neighbouring countries that operate casinos and will also introduce a ‘sin tax’ that will be used for social benefits, Julapun Amornvivat told reporters.
The BOT has previously said that rate cuts and fiscal stimulus would not help the economy much, and it favoured structural reforms to increase productivity.

site_title: UK rents rise at the slowest pace since 2021 as demand eases
summary: UK rents rose at the slowest pace since 2021, easing to 6.6% annual inflation in April, down from 10% a year ago. Competition for properties decreased, with 15 enquiries per rented home, more than double the pre-pandemic level. Average monthly UK rent was £1,226, up £80 over the last year, with 41% of gross earnings spent on rent, the highest level in a decade. The UK's shortage of homes to let remains, with no change in the overall stock of private rented homes since 2016.

Median incomes in Britain grew by 6 per cent between 2007 and 2019 while wages rose by 12 per cent in the US and 16 per cent in Germany.

site_title: Netflix tests biggest TV app redesign in 10 years
summary: Netflix has rolled out its biggest TV app redesign in 10 years, aiming to increase engagement time and retain customers by making it easier to find content. The redesign simplifies the home screen, enlarging title cards and reorganizing information. The new format, tested by a subset of its 270 million users, includes a "My Netflix" tab and a menu button moved to the top of the screen. The redesign is part of Netflix's effort to increase engagement time and promote its lower-cost plans with advertising.

images.alt_text: Much of the rebound – up 34 per cent year to date – reflects Netflix’s success in reassuring investors about its ability to keep growing, even in mature markets.
Expect high heels, glamorous styling and tours of multimillion-dollar homes..

Sports is the most valuable live programming in the world.

site_title: Gold prices edge down ahead of US jobs data, but set for weekly gain
summary: Gold prices fell 0.2% to $2,371.04 per ounce, but are set for a weekly gain, driven by investors awaiting US non-farm payrolls data for interest rate cut clues. The US dollar hovered near an eight-week low, making gold more attractive. Despite a dip in physical demand, consultancy Metals Focus expects gold to hit a record high this year due to US-China tensions and conflict. A 68% chance of a September rate cut is priced in by traders, reducing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Eurozone yields on track for biggest weekly fall since mid-March after ECB cut, US data
summary: Eurozone government bond yields are on track for their biggest weekly fall since mid-March after the European Central Bank's rate cut and weak US economic data. Germany's 10-year yield rose one basis point to 2.55%, while Italy's 10-year yield increased to 3.87%. The ECB's remarks led investors to slightly reduce bets on future monetary easing, which had increased in the days prior to the policy decision.

images.alt_text: Europe's inflation challenge amplified as energy prices soar

site_title: Crypto exchange Kraken is in talks for pre-IPO fundraising round
summary: Kraken, a leading cryptocurrency exchange, is in talks for a pre-IPO fundraising round, potentially raising over $100 million ahead of a possible initial public offering (IPO). The fundraising may be completed by year-end, with the exchange seeking a "marquee" company to join its board and help with a successful IPO. This comes as the digital-asset market rallies and US regulators appear more favorable towards crypto, with the SEC recently approving Bitcoin and Ether exchange-traded funds.

images.alt_text: Robinhood has sought to expand its offerings beyond those geared towards retail traders in the US, adding credit card and retirement products.

The lawsuit in San Francisco federal court is the latest step in SEC Chair Gary Gensler’s push to bring cryptocurrency under his agency’s purview, by contending that crypto assets are investment contracts subject to federal securities laws.

site_title: Hong Kong’s property rally proves short-lived as sales fall
summary: Hong Kong's property market is experiencing a downturn, with new home sales plummeting 46% in May and secondary market sales dropping 40% in the first weekend of June. The decline is attributed to high interest rates, weak economy, and dimmed prospects for salary growth, with used-home prices down 2.3% since the beginning of the year. Analysts predict a decrease in residential values by low single digits in the second half of the year, citing ample supply and a reversal of the three-year high transactions seen in March.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s retail landscape has been hit by a surge in cross-border travel.
Trips to Shanghai will be shortened to 11 hours from 19.5 hours, according to Hong Kong’s mass railway operator.
Hong Kong’s property market is in a prolonged downturn due to higher interest rates and China’s slowing economy.
Many are opening accounts to tap a wider range of investment options to capture the Asian financial hub’s higher interest rates and escape mainland China’s moribund markets.

site_title: Markets in Chaos – past is not prologue
summary: Financial markets are experiencing chaos, with cheap money leading to financial excess, as seen in historical crises such as Weimar Germany, Japan in the 1990s, and Iceland and Indonesia during the global financial crisis. A new book, "Markets in Chaos," by Brendan Hughes, CFA, analyzes these events to educate readers and investors on navigating macroeconomic dislocations. The author emphasizes the importance of fiscal probity, proper oversight, and prudent bank-lending policies to avoid economic fragility and volatility. The book concludes that history does not repeat itself, and investors should stay invested, diversify, and avoid market timing to make informed decisions.

images.alt_text: Funds that claim to offer a hedge for geopolitical uncertainty strip out companies the managers say threaten national security or are vulnerable to state takeover or US sanctions.
There are hard and easy ways to gauge sentiment; both now reveal more bulls in the market ahead.
The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index, which tracks the US currency against 12 of its major peers, has risen by more than 4 per cent this year.

site_title: Indonesia braces for wider deficit and swelling debt in 2025 budget plan
summary: Indonesia is set to face a larger budget deficit and higher debt in 2025 due to high interest rates and a weakened rupiah. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani has proposed expanding the deficit to 2.45-2.82% of GDP and increasing the debt-to-GDP ratio to 39.8-40.1%. The government aims to finance campaign programs, while maintaining prudent fiscal policy to uphold investor trust. Economic growth is forecast to fall within 5.1-5.5% in 2025, lower than previous projections.

images.alt_text: Only less than 2 per cent of the vehicles on Indonesian roads are electric, with the vast majority still dominated by combustion engine vehicles.
As the influence of Eid al-Fitr gradually diminishes, economists foresee Indonesia’s inflationary pressures continuing their downward trajectory in the months ahead.

site_title: China’s homeowners and banks are trapped in a mortgage mess
summary: China's housing market is experiencing a fourth-year downturn, with new home prices down 5.7% and existing home prices down 11.4% from 2021 highs. Many homeowners are struggling to pay their mortgages, with some forced to sell properties at a loss or rely on family savings to cover debt. Household debt has reached 145% of disposable income, and banks are grappling with rising bad loans and depressed margins. The specter of negative equity is concerning banks, with at least two lenders raising the issue with regulators. Defaults are increasing, and homeowners face foreclosure and damaged credit records.

images.alt_text: Real estate stocks have retreated amid scepticism over a broad support package unveiled by the central government on May 17.
In Shanghai, second-hand sales last weekend were 50 per cent higher than the daily average for the month.
Commercial and residential buildings stand in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 6, 2014. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The Chinese government's renewed housing policy focuses on building affordable homes and renovating run-down inner-city districts.

site_title: Asia: Markets swing as traders eye major US jobs report
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Friday as investors await the US jobs report, which could influence the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. Tokyo, Hong Kong, Shanghai, and other Asian markets fell, while Sydney, Singapore, Seoul, and Manila rose. The report, set to be released on Friday, is closely watched by the Fed for labor market data and inflation. Most policymakers have warned they will only cut rates if data shows a softening labor market and lower inflation, with some expecting a rate cut in September.

images.alt_text: Asian markets built on the gains, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all enjoying buying interest.

site_title: China’s May exports rise solidly, but slower imports temper outlook
summary: China's exports grew 7.6% year-over-year in May, beating forecasts, while imports increased 1.8% at a slower pace. The data suggests factory owners are finding buyers overseas, providing some relief to the economy, but domestic demand remains weak due to a protracted property crisis. The export growth may not be sustainable, and analysts expect China to roll out more policy support measures to foster a broad-based economic recovery. The International Monetary Fund upgraded its China growth forecast for 2024, but warned of risks from the property sector troubles.

images.alt_text: Business confidence levels also eased to a seven-month low amid concerns about the global economic environment and rising prices.
China’s surplus in manufacturing trade, which is close to record levels, points to a much broader surge in exports.
In Shanghai, second-hand sales last weekend were 50 per cent higher than the daily average for the month.
China’s economy has been squeezed by a protracted property crisis, which has weighed on business and consumer confidence.
Spending by foreign tourists on the mainland this year is expected to hit 715 billion yuan, about a quarter below 2019 levels.

site_title: Samsung workers in South Korea stage first ever strike: union
summary: Samsung Electronics workers in South Korea staged the first-ever strike at the company, with tens of thousands of employees participating, on June 7, 2024. The strike, which is only one day, was called by the National Samsung Electronics Union due to disagreements over wages. The strike does not affect production lines, and the company is not expected to experience significant disruptions. The historic strike marks a shift towards labor empowerment in South Korea, where Samsung previously resisted unionization for nearly 50 years.

images.alt_text: Investors have become increasingly concerned about Samsung’s response to SK Hynix, which recently reported its fastest pace of revenue growth since at least 2010.
More than 2,000 unionised Samsung workers  gathered in Seoul last week to hold a rare rally to demand better wages.

Samsung has been trying to pass Nvidia’s tests for HBM3 and HBM3E since last year, the three sources said. According to two of the people, the results of a recent failed test for Samsung’s 8-layer and 12-layer HBM3E chips came in April.
The move comes as Samsung has fallen behind in one of the key growth areas for memory chips, its core business.

site_title: Mitsubishi, Sumitomo Mitsui banks to divest 1.32 trillion yen in Toyota shareholdings
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group will divest 1.32 trillion yen ($11.4 billion) worth of strategic shareholdings in Toyota Motor, starting with a sale of approximately 700 billion yen. The banks plan to sell their stakes over several years to minimize the impact on Toyota's share price, following the company's plan to buy back its own shares worth one trillion yen. This move could trigger a broader wave of unwinding cross-shareholdings in Japan, a trend driven by government pressure to reduce corporate ties.

site_title: Should you buy expensive stocks?
summary: A new paper by three economists suggests that investors should buy expensive stocks, such as Nvidia, as they are likely to increase payouts in the future. The study argues that prices move only when investors receive news that changes their expectation of future payouts, rather than being driven by valuation measures. This challenges the conventional view that low yields indicate poor returns, and instead suggests that investors are correctly predicting growth for these stocks. The economists' model fails to effectively challenge the alternative view, which attributes price movements to factors such as risk appetite and discount rates.

site_title: Creating an AI-ready workforce for Singapore and beyond
summary: Singapore is poised to reap significant economic benefits from artificial intelligence (AI) adoption, with a potential gain of S$200 billion by 2030. However, a study found that people in Singapore are optimistic about AI but identify education as a major barrier. To overcome this, the government and businesses must invest in AI education and skills development, provide opportunities for experimentation, and foster a culture of learning. Google is supporting this effort through initiatives such as AI education programs and innovation sandboxes.

images.alt_text: The age of generative AI calls for more workers who are competent in critical thinking, creativity, and “teaching and training”.

The AI talent crunch is not unique to any one country but a pressing issue worldwide. In fact, any country that hopes to dominate the global AI race must overcome their first and most basic battle: the war for talent.
In an increasingly technology-led world, exceptional soft skills, including in-person networking, critical thinking and problem-solving are increasingly valuable.

site_title: New Zealand house prices fall for second month amid high rates and listings
summary: New Zealand's house prices fell 0.2% in May, marking the second consecutive month of decline, due to high interest rates and increased listings. Despite annual price growth of 1%, the market remains cautious, with buyers facing expensive home loans. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has signaled that it won't lower interest rates until 2025, further hindering price growth. Economists expect subdued house price growth in 2024, with listings expected to increase after a government tax change on July 1.

site_title: Billionaire families fuel US$20 billion private equity buyout wave
summary: Wealthy individuals and families worth over $150 billion are fueling a US$20 billion private equity buyout wave, providing capital for high-profile acquisitions amid expensive borrowing. Billionaires such as the Viessmann and Dell families are co-investing in deals, helping private equity firms secure deals. This trend is expected to continue, with over a third of family office clients planning to increase their allocations to direct private equity opportunities. The involvement of ultra-rich individuals is seen as a growing trend, with Blackstone, KKR, and Carlyle Group already launching dedicated platforms to serve high-net-worth clients.

The Reliance-NGIC partnership is also a diplomatic win for India, which has sought to counter China’s surging influence in Africa via measures such as digital inclusion.

site_title: Hertz weighs US$700 million sale of secured debt, convertibles
summary: Hertz Global Holdings is considering selling at least $700 million in secured debt and offering convertible notes to bolster its balance sheet after reporting a $1.28 share loss in April. The company, led by former Delta Air Lines executive Gil West, aims to improve liquidity and operations, and reduce costs. Hertz's struggles stem from cost issues, not revenue, and the sale of secured debt could help fill cash gaps while the company addresses its fleet issues, including the disposal of Tesla electric vehicles.

images.alt_text: Hertz has been struggling under the weight of a strategic error it made in doubling down on EVs, sinking precious cash into 100,000 Teslas in 2021.

summary: Nio's adjusted net loss widened to 4.9 billion yuan (S$911.7 million) in the first fiscal quarter due to increased competition in the electric vehicle market. Sembcorp announced plans to work with US fuel cell provider Bloom Energy on low-carbon power generation technologies in Singapore, while signing an in-principle agreement with Japanese corporates for green ammonia offtake.

site_title: China’s US$2 trillion stock rally lures global fund holdouts despite risks
summary: Global fund managers are increasingly investing in China, with the MSCI China Index rising 24% from its January low. The rally has added over $2 trillion to Chinese and Hong Kong stocks. Despite lingering risks, including the property market and consumer sentiment, investors see room for further gains, with Goldman Sachs calling the recent pullback a "better entry point." Funds are flowing back into the market, with the iShares MSCI China ETF seeing its first weekly inflows of the year in May.

site_title: Meta’s WhatsApp launches new AI tools for businesses
summary: Meta has launched AI-driven ad targeting tools for businesses on WhatsApp, marking a shift towards monetizing the encrypted messaging service. The new tools use Facebook and Instagram user behavior to target ads to receptive customers who have opted-in to receiving marketing materials. The move aims to increase revenue from WhatsApp, which has contributed only a sliver to Meta's total revenue since its $22 billion acquisition in 2014.

site_title: Optica cuts ties with Huawei after secret funding exposed
summary: The Optica Foundation has severed ties with Huawei after a Bloomberg report revealed the Chinese company secretly funded the research competition. Huawei's funding "diverted attention" from the program's mission, according to Optica CEO Elizabeth Rogan. The foundation will return all Huawei donations and has already selected winners for this year's challenge. The move comes after US lawmakers expressed concerns over the funding arrangement, which compromised US research institutions' ability to comply with laws restricting ties with foreign adversaries.

images.alt_text: Nvidia’s H800 and A800 are banned in China due to US sanctions aimed at limiting China’s capabilities in becoming a tech powerhouse.
The discounting comes as Apple seeks to defend its position in the high-end smartphone market, where it faces increasing competition from local rivals such as Huawei.

site_title: Japan consumer spending rises in April for first time in 14 months
summary: Japan's household spending rose 0.5% in April for the first time in 14 months, exceeding market forecasts. This growth was driven by a 0.5% increase in wages, but private consumption still showed a reluctant spending pattern, falling 1.2% on a seasonally adjusted basis from the previous month. The tepid growth is a source of concern for policymakers aiming for sustained economic growth underpinned by solid wages and durable inflation.

images.alt_text: Wage gains resulting from annual pay tend to be reflected gradually in workers’ paychecks from April through the summer.
The central bank has signalled a cautious approach to further tightening due to a fragile economic recovery.
Weak corporate investment bodes ill both for the economy and the central bank as it indicates companies are concerned about persistent inflation and uncertainties.
The inflation strains prompted manufacturers to raise their selling prices at the fastest pace in a year last month.

site_title: Asia’s heatwaves are not deterring tourists – for now
summary: South-east Asia's heatwaves, which reached record temperatures in April and May, have not deterred tourists, with crowds remaining at popular beach and resort destinations. However, the growing frequency of extreme weather may shift travel patterns towards indoor activities or cooler spots. Experts warn that if heatwaves persist, safety and comfort will become significant considerations for travelers, potentially altering destination choices. The impact on tourism demand is likely to be felt in the long term, as travelers increasingly prioritize their well-being.

images.alt_text: The hot weather has not thinned crowds at popular beach and resort destinations such as Terengganu in Malaysia.
Heat action plans are in place in countries such as India, the WWA scientists note, albeit not at a sufficient scale to protect the most vulnerable from temperature stress.
A record-breaking heatwave is broiling parts of Asia, helping drive surging demand for cooling options, including air-conditioning.

site_title: Robinhood to buy crypto exchange Bitstamp in global push
summary: Robinhood Markets will acquire European cryptocurrency exchange Bitstamp for $200 million, marking the company's first foray into the institutional business. The deal, expected to close in the first half of 2025, aims to expand Robinhood's cryptocurrency offerings and attract more users. The acquisition comes as Robinhood seeks to diversify its business beyond the US, where cryptocurrency regulation is volatile. The deal is seen as a strategic move to enhance Robinhood's presence in the global market.

Robinhood is seeking to expand its offerings beyond the retail brokerage services and commission-free trading that made the company a household name.

Robinhood said it received a so-called “Wells notice,” which the SEC issues when it is planning to bring enforcement action against them.

The credit card, available exclusively to Robinhood Gold customers, comes two years after its launch of a debit card to allow spare change investing, with the Menlo Park, California-based company looking to broaden its product offerings.

site_title: Tight quarters, ticking clock: Local animal shelters face expiring tenancies – again
summary: Singapore's animal shelters face uncertainty as their tenancies at The Animal Lodge in Sungei Tengah are set to expire in December 2026. The 12 remaining animal welfare groups housed at the facility, which was built in 2018, are anxious about their future due to competition for space and stringent land-zoning laws. The Animal Lodge, a facility built by AVS and JTC, has 20 two-storey blocks and 112 units, but the space is smaller than the groups' previous locations. The government's push for Singapore's "30 by 30" goal, which aims to produce 30% of the country's nutritional needs domestically by 2030, has led to land tenders for agricultural use, potentially affecting the animal shelters.

site_title: Hong Kong retail landlords face squeeze in north as shoppers flock to mainland
summary: Hong Kong's retail landscape is being impacted by a surge in cross-border travel, with residents flocking to mainland China for cheaper goods and services. Retail rents in districts near the border with Shenzhen are expected to decline, while those in core locations such as Central and Tsim Sha Tsui are likely to remain resilient or recover this year. This shift is attributed to the weakening yuan and increased travel time between Hong Kong and Shenzhen, with residents restricting purchases at home and splurging in mainland China during the weekends.

site_title: US trade gap widens to largest in 18 months
summary: The US trade deficit widened to $74.6 billion in April, the largest in 18 months, despite a more resilient-than-expected US consumption. Imports rose 2.4% to $338.2 billion, driven by increased demand for automotive vehicles, while exports rose 0.8% to $263.7 billion. The goods deficit with China decreased by $2.5 billion to $22.1 billion. The widening trade deficit has raised concerns about export growth, but US consumption has supported imports.

images.alt_text: Unit labour costs, meanwhile, rose at a 4 per cent annualised rate, down from the Bureau of Labor Statistics’ first estimate of 4.7 per cent.

site_title: Boeing Starliner carrying Nasa astronauts reaches International Space Station
summary: Boeing's Starliner spacecraft successfully docked with the International Space Station, marking a critical flight test for NASA. Astronauts Sunita "Suni" Williams and Barry "Butch" Wilmore arrived at the space station after a delayed docking process due to malfunctioning thrusters. The mission is a key test for Boeing, which has faced numerous delays and setbacks since its first crewed test flight in 2019. The astronauts will spend about a week on the space station, performing tasks and testing procedures for future long-term stays.

site_title: F1 teams harnessing AI for speed and strategy
summary: Formula One teams are increasingly leveraging artificial intelligence (AI) to gain a competitive edge in speed and strategy. AI-based software, such as Epicor's, helps detect patterns in competitors' behavior, automates tasks, and performs millions of calculations in real-time. Teams like Red Bull are using AI to optimize their vehicles, reduce resources, and improve safety. With the $145 million budget cap, AI is seen as a key factor in reducing the gap between teams, and its potential to improve safety is also being explored.

site_title: Can Singapore become the world’s climate-tech hub?
summary: Singapore has a chance to establish itself as a leading climate-tech ecosystem, driven by its business-friendly policies, regional leadership, and need for self-resilience. The country's government is proactively addressing climate challenges through initiatives like the Singapore Green Plan 2030. Climate-tech startups in Singapore have raised US$685 million in equity funding, with 58% of that coming from the country. However, challenges remain, including a critical labour shortage and high operational costs. Despite these obstacles, Singapore's climate-tech ecosystem has opportunities to take a global lead in areas such as decarbonizing supply chains and developing fossil fuel alternatives, which could serve as a model for other countries.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the logo of the International Energy Agency in Paris, France, December 15, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier//File Photo
Singapore is a regional data centre hub, with over 70 data centres.

site_title: US proposes to boost Internet security, citing Chinese carrier action
summary: The US Federal Communications Commission (FCC) has voted to advance a proposal to boost the security of the Internet by requiring broadband providers to create Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) security plans and file reports on risk-mitigation progress. The move comes after US government agencies revealed that China Telecom misrouted US Internet traffic at least six times using BGP vulnerabilities. The FCC chair, Jessica Rosenworcel, cited the Chinese carrier's actions as a reason for the proposal, aiming to enhance the security and integrity of the Internet's global routing system.

images.alt_text: China’s surplus in manufacturing trade, which is close to record levels, points to a much broader surge in exports.
Since tech tensions with the United States heated up in 2018, China has ramped up efforts to develop self-sufficiency in chips, pumping huge sums into the sector.
Middle Eastern governments are ploughing in billions of US dollars to upgrade their infrastructure, offering Chinese companies and financial institutions new avenues for growth.
Those wishing to export items including aerospace structural components as well as equipment and software used in engine manufacturing, among other things, will need to apply for an export licence.

site_title: US productivity growth slowed in early 2024
summary: US productivity growth slowed to a 0.2% annualized rate in the first quarter, revised down from an initial estimate of 0.3%. Unit labor costs rose at a 4% annualized rate, down from the initial estimate of 4.7%. This data may not alleviate concerns from Federal Reserve officials about turning to rate cuts, as improved worker efficiency had previously been seen as a factor in favor of rate cuts to dampen inflation.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims rise in latest week
summary: US initial jobless claims rose 8,000 to 229,000 for the week ended June 1, exceeding economists' forecasts. The labor market remains strong, with underlying indicators supporting the economy despite a slight increase in claims. Continuing claims increased to 1.792 million, and employers announced the fewest job cuts since December, with layoffs running behind last year's pace. The labor market has been rebalancing back toward pre-pandemic levels, with interest rate hikes since March 2022 contributing to this trend.

images.alt_text: The stronger-than-expected services reading stood in contrast to ISM’s report on the manufacturing sector released on Monday, which showed factory activity contracted for the second straight month in May.

site_title: China securities regulator seeks to ease market panic over delisting risks
summary: China's securities regulator, the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC), has downplayed concerns about a near-term spike in delistings, saying the "survival of the fittest" mechanism is gradually taking shape but won't lead to an evident increase in delisted companies in the short term. The regulator has vowed to regulate with "teeth and thorns" to revive confidence in the stock market, but investors remain anxious about the risks of buying shares in smaller companies, with brokerages forecasting a record number of delistings this year.

images.alt_text: China's national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing. Securities brokerages that used to offer some of the highest remunerations last year reported declines in average salaries for the second straight year.
China is tightening scrutiny of hedge funds, with new rules unveiled last month raising the asset threshold and curbing their use of leverage and derivatives.
The Communist Party has put an increasing focus on corruption among cadres and corporate executives.

site_title: GameStop surges almost 50% as ‘Roaring Kitty’ teases livestream
summary: GameStop shares surged nearly 50% on Thursday after "Roaring Kitty" influencer Keith Gill posted a YouTube livestream teaser, rekindling a volatile trading trend that began last month. The stock has surged over 160% in 2024, with shares closing at $46.55. Gill's recent return to social media has fueled rallies in GameStop and other meme stocks popular with individual traders.

images.alt_text: GameStop, widely regarded as the first meme stock, is a video game retailer struggling to adapt in an era dominate by online commerce and digital downloads. Its sales are expected to drop by dougle digits.
GameStop shares are trading almost 68 per cent below their January 2021 peak.
FILE PHOTO: GameStop logo is seen in front of displayed Reddit logo in this illustration taken February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
GameStop says that its preliminary first-quarter net sales were between US$872 million and US$892 million.

site_title: Sinopec unit agrees 7.956 billion yuan deal to build gas pipelines for Saudi Aramco
summary: Sinopec Oilfield Service has signed a 7.956 billion yuan (S$1.5 billion) deal to build natural gas pipelines for Saudi Aramco as part of the Master Gas System's third-phase. The contract includes 2,630 km of trunk lines and 1,340 km of branch lines. Construction is expected to be completed by May 2027. This deal is part of Aramco's plan to expand gas distribution across Saudi Arabia.

site_title: Apple to debut passwords app in challenge to 1Password, LastPass
summary: Apple is set to debut a new passwords app, called Passwords, in iOS 18, iPadOS 18, and macOS 15, aiming to simplify password management and bolster device privacy. The app, powered by iCloud Keychain, will sync passwords across devices and allow users to import from rival services. It features a list of logins, auto-fill capabilities, and support for verification codes, competing with third-party password managers like 1Password and LastPass. The new app will be unveiled at Apple's WWDC on June 10.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has been arguably the biggest beneficiary of a massive flood of AI spending.
Siri is limited mostly to broader commands such as playing music playlists, looking up information or controlling smart home appliances.
The TV+ service is Apple’s answer to Netflix or Disney+, and the company has spent heavily on feeding it with original content.
Apple is defending its App Store fees on multiple fronts, including a lawsuit at home in the US and challenges in Europe, South Korea and Japan.

site_title: IPOs in Europe set for handy boost from ECB rate cut, BofA says
summary: The European Central Bank's interest rate cut is expected to boost the European stock market and IPOs, according to Bank of America. The rate reduction, made before a potential cut by the Federal Reserve, may fuel a flurry of IPO deals before the summer lull. Companies such as Exosens and Golden Goose Group are set to debut, and the market has seen a 10% gain this year. The ECB's move also encourages more companies to list, with Bank of America citing successful debuts by Planisware and Galderma Group as examples.

images.alt_text: The ECB welcomed the fall in price growth as it trimmed its deposit rate to 3.75 per cent from a record 4 per cent, its first cut since 2019.
By embarking on a new cycle of interest-rate cuts now, the ECB appears to be relying too heavily on flawed forecasts and ignoring economic and geopolitical realities.
Investors will be keenly watching to see if ECB president Christine Lagarde provides any guidance about the pace of cuts going forward in her post-meeting press conference.

site_title: Oil settles higher on hopes Fed will track European Central Bank rate cuts
summary: Oil prices rose 2% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures settling at $79.87 a barrel, amid hopes the Federal Reserve will follow the European Central Bank's interest rate cuts. The ECB cut rates for the first time since 2019, citing progress in tackling inflation. Analysts predict the Fed will cut rates in September, driven by lower fuel costs and easing supply snags. However, economists note the slowdown in the labor market may not prompt the Fed to cut rates. Opec+ ministers reassured investors the latest output agreement could change depending on market conditions.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 89 US cents higher, or 1.2 per cent, at US$78.41 a barrel.

site_title: Gloom over Indonesia’s new capital city; Rupiah drops to fresh low
summary: Indonesia's new capital city is facing gloomy prospects following the sudden departure of its head, Bambang Susantono. The Rupiah has dropped to a fresh low, sparking speculation among investors. The sudden change has raised concerns about the project's viability and the country's economic stability.

images.alt_text: Harnessing solar energy could make the desalination process more economical and effective, says tech billionaire Elon Musk (in green), seen here during his recent trip to Bali.
Residents receive food aid in Indonesia. The Indonesian government is considering extending its rice handout scheme.

Amazon data centres under construction in the US. Its cloud computing platform expects its latest investment to support an estimated average of 12,300 full-time equivalent jobs in local Singapore businesses each year.
Indonesian President Joko Widodo (right) speaks with Microsoft chairman and chief executive Satya Nadella at the Merdeka Palace in Jakarta.
The Vietnam central bank has an exclusive right to produce gold bars. PHOTO: BT FILE

site_title: US banks tap complex mortgage product to fight deposit flight risk
summary: US banks are increasing investments in floating-rate collateralized mortgage obligations (CMOs) to mitigate deposit flight risk amid high interest rates. Demand from banks fueled $25 billion in new CMO sales in April, the highest monthly figure in nearly three years. Banks are reworking their balance sheets by cutting longer-term bond holdings and boosting investments in shorter-term securities to retain deposits and manage interest-rate risk. CMOs offer attractive yields and low duration, making them an attractive option for banks to match deposit growth.

images.alt_text: The Mortgage Bankers Association’s (MBA) index of mortgage applications to buy a home decreased 4.4 per cent in the week ended May 31.
The contract rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage increased four basis points in the week ended May 24 to 7.05 per cent.
As interest rates in the US remain higher for longer, the American dream of affordable homeownership is unattainable for longer – and maybe for good.

site_title: Dozens reported killed in Israeli strike on UN school in Gaza
summary: A US-backed ceasefire proposal is underway in Gaza, but an Israeli airstrike on a UN school killed up to 40 people, including women and children, as Hamas officials dispute Israel's claim that the strike targeted Hamas fighters. The US, along with other countries, has called on Israel and Hamas to make compromises to finalize a deal. Israel's military has denied any civilian casualties, but UN officials and survivors describe the destruction and loss of life. The attack has raised concerns about the prospects for a ceasefire, which has been elusive for eight months.

images.alt_text: Palestinians put out a fire at the site of an Israeli strike on an area designated for displaced people, in Rafah, in the southern Gaza Strip, May 27, 2024.

site_title: Changi Airport Group full-year net profit up 13 times to S$431 million on post-Covid recovery
summary: Changi Airport Group reported a 13-fold increase in full-year net profit to S$431 million, driven by a 45% rise in revenue to S$2.7 billion. Passenger movements reached 62.5 million, or 91% of pre-Covid levels, while air traffic movements totaled 344,000, or 90% of pre-pandemic heights. Despite a slower recovery in concessions revenue, the airport's total handling capacity has reached 90 million passengers per year.

images.alt_text: As airport operators expand capacity, there will be more demand for airfield technologies and ground support systems and equipment.
Changi Airport Group (CAG) said that the airport handled about 5.4 million passengers movements each in January and February, and around 5.7 million passenger movements in March.

Passengers queueing at the departure hall of Changi Airport Terminal 3 on Mar 31, 2023. Delays are expected across some land and air checkpoints due to a disruption in the immigration clearance system. The Immigration and Checkpoints Authority (ICA) announced the disruption on Facebook at 11.28am on Friday, adding that it “regrets the inconvenience caused to travellers and seeks their understanding and patience”. In an update at 12.03pm, it advised travellers to postpone all non-essential travel.

site_title: English Premier League to trial Squad Cost Rules in 2024-25
summary: The English Premier League will trial the Squad Cost Rules (SCR) and Top to Bottom Anchoring Rules (TBA) in the 2024-25 season. SCR aims to regulate clubs' spending to 85% of revenue and net profit/loss on player sales, while TBA seeks to protect competitive balance. The trials are non-binding and follow the league's decision to keep Video Assistant Referees (VAR) and maintain existing Profitability and Sustainability Rules (PSR).

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain Football Soccer - Chelsea v Liverpool - Premier League - Stamford Bridge - 16/9/16 General view of the Premier League trophy before the match  REUTERS/Dylan Martinez
The clubs have tentatively agreed to put a limit on how much money they can spend, with the cap based on how much money the lowest-earning club in the league makes from television rights.
Premier League clubs will likely be limited to spending 85 per cent of their revenue on transfers, wages and agents fees.
Fanatics will obtain the rights for the Premier League and all 20 of its soccer clubs, including high-profile names such as Manchester United, Arsenal and Liverpool.

site_title: US: Wall Street steadies after labour market data; Nvidia boosts Nasdaq
summary: US stocks steadied after labour market data showed growing weakness, while Nvidia's gains boosted the Nasdaq. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 18.07 points, and the S&P 500 opened higher by 3.77 points. Nvidia's 0.8% gain, marking its crossing of the $3 trillion market valuation, contributed to the Nasdaq's 0.10% increase. Despite the steady opening, the market remains sensitive to US-EU tariff tensions and labour market data.

site_title: Serial biopharma entrepreneur’s wife buys bungalow behind Four Seasons Park for S$32.5 million
summary: A former lawyer and husband of a serial biopharma entrepreneur buys a bungalow in Jalan Tupai for S$32.5 million, or S$3,093 psf, for redevelopment. Another bungalow in Dalkeith Road sells for S$24.88 million, or S$2,500 psf, and a soon-to-be-completed GCB in Sixth Avenue sells for S$27.5 million, or S$2,985 psf. Experts predict an end-user buyer will redevelop the sites into big bungalows, while developers may consider semi-detached houses and small bungalows subject to approval. The sales reflect the trend of rising land prices in Singapore's landed property market.

images.alt_text: The house Liqian Ma, is buying has a long driveway.
The newly built bungalow in Bin Tong Park has a built-up area of about 18,000 sq ft.
The bank's properties include OCBC Centre, OCBC Centre South and OCBC Centre East.
The 2C Mandai Estate site has a freehold land area of 50,630 sq ft. It is being bought by a consortium that includes Ding Zhou Group and Unitedland Development.
The Rail Mall is on a site sold by the state with 99-year leasehold tenure from March 1947; this leaves a balance of about 21 years and nine months.

site_title: Non-executive directors arrested – a common cause and cure
summary: A string of listed companies have faced trouble with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) and the law, resulting in non-executive directors (NEDs) being arrested for possible crimes. NEDs are expected to exercise supervisory functions, including compliance with regulations, and are required to announce material information to the market. Failure to do so can lead to criminal sanctions and penalties. Recent cases involve deliberate non-disclosure of adverse information, highlighting the importance of prompt disclosure to ensure efficient and effective public markets. NEDs are advised to follow the adage "when in doubt, disclose" to avoid liability.

images.alt_text: Directors serving on boards of non-profit organisations can apply for funding support to attend courses such as the Governance for Outstanding Organisation Directors programme.
Progressive boards and nominating committees recognise that cohesive boards with the right mix of competencies, skills and perspectives can be a strategic asset.
A deliberate succession plan for the board and chair are critical, as businesses navigate an increasingly complex landscape.

site_title: Aramco’s US$12 billion sale said to draw strong foreign demand
summary: Saudi Aramco's US$12 billion share sale drew significant foreign demand, with Western and Asian investors bidding in large numbers. The offering was more successful than the 2019 listing, which was largely local. Demand from overseas investors more than fully covered the offering, while Asian investors, including those from China and India, also showed strong interest. This marks a positive turn for Aramco, which has become a more attractive stock despite concerns over climate change and the energy transition.

images.alt_text: The government is selling 1.545 billion Aramco shares, representing a 0.64 per cent stake, at a price range of 26.70 to 29 riyals apiece.

site_title: Sri Lanka legislates to revamp power sector, attract renewables investment
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament approved a law to attract investment in renewable energy and reduce losses in its state-run power monopoly, the Ceylon Electricity Board. The Electricity Bill aims to make the CEB monopoly more profitable and generate 70% of power via renewables by 2030. The law also sets a three-year reform timeline to establish wholesale power markets and open access. The move is part of a US$2.9 billion IMF program to reform state-owned companies and reduce losses.

images.alt_text: Sri Lanka’s telecommunications regulator gave preliminary approval for Starlink after a public consultation, the president’s office said in a short statement.
Sri Lanka’s economy is expected to grow 3 per cent in 2024 after Colombo secured a US$2.9 billion lending programme from the IMF last March.

site_title: US: S&P 500, Nasdaq dip on the eve of US payrolls data
summary: US stocks retreated from record highs on June 6 ahead of the key labor market report on Friday, which may indicate a easing of the labor market and potential interest rate cuts by the Fed. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite fell 0.02% and 0.1% respectively, while the Dow Jones rose 0.2%. The tech-heavy Nasdaq was impacted by a decline in Nvidia, which dropped after surpassing Apple to become the world's second most valuable company. Investors await the US non-farm payrolls report, which could influence the Fed's decision on interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the trading floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 5, 2024. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo

site_title: Netflix record back in sight on push into sports and live events
summary: Netflix is poised to drive its stock price back to record highs as it expands into live events and sports, with the potential to boost its ad business. The company's success in advertising-supported subscriptions and its ability to reassure investors about growth in mature markets have contributed to a 34% year-to-date rebound. With exclusive rights to sports programming and live events, including NFL games and boxing matches, Netflix is expected to attract more advertising revenue and attract a larger global subscriber base.

images.alt_text: Expect high heels, glamorous styling and tours of multimillion-dollar homes..
The company has 270 million subscribers overall.
Sports is the most valuable live programming in the world.

site_title: China's CNOOC reports major gas breakthrough in South China Sea
summary: CNOOC, a state-owned Chinese oil and gas firm, has achieved a major breakthrough in the South China Sea, testing the Lingshui 36-1 gas field to produce over 10 million cubic meters per day of open flow natural gas. This breakthrough expands the resource base for a trillion-cubic-meter gas region in the South China Sea, according to CNOOC CEO Zhou Xinhuai. The company plans to step up exploration and development of hydrocarbon resources in the area to enhance its energy supply capacity.

site_title: India's opposition leader seeks probe into stock market moves during election
summary: India's opposition leader Rahul Gandhi demanded a parliamentary investigation into sharp stock market moves before and after the country's general election, which saw Prime Minister Narendra Modi's alliance win with a slim majority. The stock markets surged on Monday following exit polls, but crashed to a four-year low on Tuesday after election results showed Modi's party lost its outright majority. Gandhi wants to investigate the role of Modi, Home Minister Amit Shah, and BJP members in the stock market trades, which some had predicted would surge when election results were declared.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi (C) flashes victory sign as he arrives at the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) headquarters to celebrate the party’s win in country's general election, in New Delhi on June 4, 2024. Modi claimed election victory for his party and its allies on June 4, but the opposition said they had "punished" the ruling party to confound predictions and reduce their parliamentary majority. (Photo by Arun SANKAR / AFP)

site_title: Steady euro takes ECB rate cut in stride
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates by 25 basis points, but the euro remained stable at US$1.0872, largely due to market expectations of the move. The US dollar index also rose 0.07% at 104.31, with investors focusing on upcoming US payrolls data. The ECB's rate cut was seen as a response to falling eurozone inflation, but progress may stall due to signs of sticky inflation. Markets now await US payrolls data on Friday, with the Federal Reserve expected to keep rates unchanged at its next meeting.

images.alt_text: The ECB welcomed the fall in price growth as it trimmed its deposit rate to 3.75 per cent from a record 4 per cent, its first cut since 2019.
Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.
The dollar index was up 0.3 per cent at 104.41.
As the US currency found a footing, the dollar index was up 0.27 per cent at 104.32, having fallen to its lowest since mid-April overnight at 103.99.

site_title: India’s exit polls spark criticism, tears and call for probes
summary: India's exit polls, which predicted a landslide victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party, were widely inaccurate, with the final results showing the coalition won 293 seats instead of over 350. Critics point to structural challenges, limited resources, and biases in surveys as reasons for the large miss. Polling companies have defended their data, citing sample size and logistical issues, but the mismatch has sparked calls for investigations into possible manipulation.

images.alt_text: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi gestures, at the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) headquarters in New Delhi, India, June 4, 2024. REUTERS/Adnan Abidi

site_title: Sembcorp partners Bloom Energy to produce low-carbon power in Singapore
summary: Sembcorp Industries has partnered with US fuel cell provider Bloom Energy to produce low-carbon power in Singapore. The collaboration will utilize Bloom Energy's Energy Server platform, which converts natural gas into electricity with low or no-carbon emissions. The deal aims to support Singapore's net-zero emissions target by 2050 and is expected to contribute to the growing demand for green energy, particularly in the data centre sector.

images.alt_text: At the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework Clean Economy Investor Forum are (from left): Ken Saito, Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan; Shigeya Kusano, managing executive officer of Sojitz Corporation; Hachiman Yokoi, general manager of the energy Solutions Business Department at Sojitz Corporation; Vipul Tuli, chairman of South Asia, chief executive of hydrogen business and Middle East, and executive director of UK Sembcorp Industries; Wong Kim Yin, group president and chief executive of Sembcorp Industries; Dr Tan See Leng, Singapore's Minister of Manpower and second Minister for Trade and Industry; and Shri Sunil Barthwal, Commerce Secretary of India's Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

site_title: ECB starts cutting rates even as inflation fight continues
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) cut its deposit rate to 3.75% from a record 4%, its first reduction since 2019, amid progress in its battle against high inflation. However, the ECB acknowledged that the fight against inflation is far from over, with inflation expected to remain above target until next year. The move joins other central banks, including Canada, Sweden, and Switzerland, in undoing steep interest rate hikes. The ECB also raised its inflation forecasts and stressed that further rate reductions will depend on incoming data.

images.alt_text: Christine Lagarde will discuss the situation at a 2.45 pm briefing in Frankfurt – 30 minutes after the ECB’s policy announcement.
By embarking on a new cycle of interest-rate cuts now, the ECB appears to be relying too heavily on flawed forecasts and ignoring economic and geopolitical realities.
Investors will be keenly watching to see if ECB president Christine Lagarde provides any guidance about the pace of cuts going forward in her post-meeting press conference.
The unexpected inflation rise likely will not prevent the ECB from cutting record-high borrowing costs next week but may lead to a pause in July and slower future rate reductions.
Communicating the ECB’s intentions without locking in a specific scenario may – once again – be the biggest challenge for Lagarde.

site_title: In search of self: Why people are travelling to stay centred
summary: In an uncertain economy and with growing anxiety, more people are turning to travel to find meaning and themselves. According to various reports, 68% of employees struggle with work pace and volume, and 46% feel burnt out. Travellers are seeking introspective and rejuvenating experiences, such as learning kintsugi, harvesting and composting, and exploring remote destinations like the Amazon River. Experts predict that these trends are long-term, driven by a desire for respite from modern pressures and a growing recognition of mental health importance.

images.alt_text: Umana Bali overlooks the sacred site of Melasti Beach.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 6)
summary: Advanced economies of the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) are injecting public funds into the region's clean-economy transition. A global coalition, including Singapore's Temasek and GIC, has committed to $25 billion in infrastructure investments in emerging markets. The 14 IPEF participating countries signed a clean economy agreement with new programs, including one on small modular reactors. Meanwhile, Singapore parents expect financial support from children in old age, and shares of Jasper Investments surged after securing $9 million in capital from strategic investors.

site_title: Sushi stalwart Aoki stages comeback with new restaurant, still serving good-value chirashi sets
summary: Veteran chef Kunio Aoki has reopened his eponymous restaurant in Millenia Walk, Singapore, after 20 years. The new eatery still serves its signature good-value chirashi sets, now priced at S$60 for the standard set and S$70 with uni. Aoki has maintained the same concept, but with reduced seating to create a more intimate atmosphere. The restaurant features handmade Japanese wooden screens and offers a range of omakase menus based on customer preference. Prices have increased slightly, with lunch sets starting from S$60 and dinner sets from S$80.

images.alt_text: The entrance of Aoki restaurant.

site_title: Modi’s allies want funds, Cabinet positions as coalition gears to form new government
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's coalition government is negotiating for funds, cabinet positions, and special status for regional states in exchange for their support. The Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) won 240 seats, making the Telugu Desam Party (TDP) and Janata Dal (United) (JD(U)) kingmakers with 16 and 12 seats, respectively. TDP and JD(U) are demanding special status, cabinet positions, and funds for their states, including irrigation projects and building a new capital. Negotiations are underway to form the new government, with Modi set to meet President Droupadi Murmu to present his claim.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - India’s Prime Minister Narendra Modi (C) flashes victory sign as he arrives at the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) headquarters to celebrate the party’s win in country's general election, in New Delhi on June 4, 2024. Modi claimed election victory for his party and its allies on June 4, but the opposition said they had "punished" the ruling party to confound predictions and reduce their parliamentary majority. (Photo by Arun SANKAR / AFP)

site_title: No change to STI constituents following June review
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) will not undergo any changes to its constituents following its June quarterly review, according to FTSE Russell. The reserve list, which comprises companies that may replace ineligible constituents, will also remain unchanged. The STI reserve list includes CapitaLand Ascott Trust, ComfortDelGro, Keppel DC Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit), Keppel Reit, and Suntec Reit. The next review will take place in September.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, June 6, 2024 (Ep 76)
summary: Asian markets rallied following Wall Street records, while Indian stocks extended their rally as Prime Minister Modi secured coalition support. The Japanese Yen saw its biggest decline in a month, and Chinese property stocks plummeted 20% from their May high due to investor skepticism over government measures.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumbered losers 73 to 21.
Asian markets built on the gains, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta all enjoying buying interest.
Real estate stocks have retreated amid scepticism over a broad support package unveiled by the central government on May 17.

site_title: Malaysia can hit target of 400 e-payment transactions per head each year before 2026: PM Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim set a target of 400 e-payment transactions per head by 2026, but believes it can be achieved earlier with the entry of more digital banks. Boost Bank, the country's third digital lender and first fully home-grown, aims to be profitable within 3-5 years. Anwar called on industry players to promote Boost Bank's benefits to all segments of society, intensifying efforts to reach the target.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (middle) at the Boost Bank launching event. Boost Bank is the first primarily Malaysian-owned digital bank in the country.
(From left to right) GXS chairman Hsieh Fu Hua, Datuk Johan Merican, GXBank CEO Pei Si Lai and Datuk Zaiton Hassan, chairperson of GXBank, at the public launch of GXBank.
GXBank CEO Pei-Si Lai (left) and Zurich Malaysia head Junior Cho (right).

site_title: China’s Chang’e-6 transfers moon samples to spacecraft, set for return to Earth
summary: China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe successfully transferred moon samples to a spacecraft in lunar orbit, with the expected landing in China's Inner Mongolia region on June 25. This marks the first time China has returned lunar matter from the far side of the moon, a permanently hidden side. The samples, which scientists hope can reveal more about the solar system's origins, come as the US expresses growing concerns about China's advances in lunar and space exploration programs.

images.alt_text: The ascender and lander is captured by China's Chang’e-6 lunar probe after it landed on the moon on June 2.
