China in 2019 became the first and so far only country to land on the moon’s far side.

site_title: China’s Space Pioneer raises 1.5 billion yuan to fund development of reusable rockets
summary: China-based rocket developer Space Pioneer has secured 1.5 billion yuan (S$280 million) in funding to develop reusable rockets. This round of funding will support the first flight of its Tianlong-3 rocket and mass production. Space Pioneer aims to slash mission costs for clients with a reusable rocket and plans to launch a satellite constellation to counter the dominance of SpaceX's Starlink satellites. The company's development and mass production of the Tianlong-3 rocket will enhance China's competitiveness in the satellite Internet constellation era.

images.alt_text: A large screen shows news footage of China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe collecting a sample from the far side of the moon.
The ascender and lander is captured by China's Chang’e-6 lunar probe after it landed on the moon on June 2.
Those wishing to export items including aerospace structural components as well as equipment and software used in engine manufacturing, among other things, will need to apply for an export licence.
China in 2019 became the first and so far only country to land on the moon’s far side.

site_title: 👪 Mom, Dad, do you have enough to retire?
summary: A recent article from the Thrive newsletter, titled "Mom, Dad, do you have enough to retire?", raises concerns about Singaporeans' financial readiness for retirement. The article emphasizes the importance of having a retirement checklist and provides guidance on investing CPF, buying life insurance, and navigating GenAI financial advisers. It also highlights the need for financial literacy among young adults, particularly Gen Z, who may be struggling with financial illiteracy. The article aims to provide practical tips and advice for young adults to plan for a secure retirement.

images.alt_text: BT
Reliance on children to provide for parents as they get older is not unique to Singapore
2023’s Financial Wellness Index score fell to 60 points – the lowest since the inception of the index in 2019, OCBC said.
Financial survival for older parents

site_title: Palm oil companies with high ESG transparency are poorly valued: NUS study
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore found that palm oil companies with high environmental, social, and governance (ESG) transparency are poorly valued. The study, which analyzed 36 publicly listed palm oil companies, found a direct negative relationship between price-to-earnings valuations and ESG scores, indicating that companies with high ESG transparency were discounted relative to their peers. This trend may be due to the sector's association with high ESG risks, which eroded investor confidence and raised perceived financial risks.

images.alt_text: Bumitama CSO Lim Sian Choo
Indonesia has launched several programmes to improve governance in its massive palm oil industry, amid criticism by environmentalists of the crop’s impact on deforestation.
The finalists of the Emerging Enterprise Sustainability Award have created products and solutions that aim to reduce their carbon footprints.

site_title: UK firms’ wage growth expectations fall sharply, BOE survey shows
summary: The Bank of England's Decision Maker Panel survey revealed a sharp drop in wage growth expectations, falling to 4.1% in May from 4.6% in April. This decrease may ease policymakers' concerns about reaching their 2% inflation target. Average earnings excluding bonuses rose 6% in the first quarter of 2024, higher than the 3% rate viewed as consistent with the inflation target. The survey also showed businesses expect inflation to remain at 2.9% in a year's time.

images.alt_text: Median incomes in Britain grew by 6 per cent between 2007 and 2019 while wages rose by 12 per cent in the US and 16 per cent in Germany.

site_title: India's Zee Entertainment to raise nearly US$240 million
summary: Zee Entertainment Enterprises has secured approval to raise nearly US$240 million to enhance its strategic flexibility and pursue future growth opportunities. The company plans to use the funds through equity shares or other eligible securities via private placements, qualified institutions placements, and preferential issues. This comes after the company faced setbacks, including failed deals with Sony and Walt Disney, and increased competition from a merged Reliance and Disney media behemoth. Zee shares rose 5.2% after the fundraise announcement, despite a 4.5% decline since the Sony merger in January.

site_title: Nio’s loss exceeds expectations as EV competition crimps sales
summary: Nio reported a 18.1% increase in its adjusted net loss to 4.90 billion yuan (S$911.7 million) in the first quarter, exceeding analyst expectations. The Shanghai-based EV maker's revenue fell 7.2% to 9.9 billion yuan, and deliveries slowed 3.2% to 30,053 vehicles. Despite challenges, Nio's margins improved to 4.9% and it expects to deliver a total of 54,000 to 56,000 vehicles in the next quarter, with its mass-market second brand, Onvo, expected to contribute to profitability once deliveries hit 20,000 units a month.

images.alt_text: The company's cumulative deliveries since inception has hit 515,811 cars in May.
Nio is primarily listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with secondary listings in Hong Kong and Singapore.
“Electric vehicles are very important for positive development of the environment, they should never be used as a political target,” Nio founder William Li said.
Since Beijing phased out a national subsidy programme for EV purchases in 2022, some smaller manufacturers have been pushed to the brink.

site_title: Singapore household net worth continues to climb, up 8% to almost S$2.9 trillion in Q1
summary: Singapore households' net worth rose 8% to almost S$2.9 trillion in Q1 2024, driven by a 7.9% year-on-year increase in residential property assets, valued at S$1.4 trillion. Financial assets, including currencies and deposits, stood at S$1.8 trillion, a 6.7% increase. Household liabilities rose 1.7% to S$364.8 billion, despite a slowdown in housing markets. Experts expect a slower growth rate for residential assets, with a 6-7% increase by end-2024, but overall household balance sheets remain in good shape.

images.alt_text: Residential properties accounted for a smaller share of the pie in Q2, with growth in its asset values slowing down to 9.1 per cent, from 11.7 per cent last quarter.

site_title: UK construction sector records fastest growth in two years, PMI shows
summary: The UK construction sector experienced its fastest growth in two years, according to the S&P Global UK Construction Purchasing Managers' Index, which rose to 54.7 in May from 53 in April. This marks the first rise in house-building since Liz Truss' mini-budget and surpasses the median forecast of a decline. The sector's growth follows weak data in the previous quarters, with output falling 0.9% in both the final quarter of 2023 and the first quarter of this year.

images.alt_text: Newly built homes on a Redrow housing estate in Goffs Oak, UK, on Tuesday, June 27, 2023. Rising mortgage payments are squeezing the finances of millions of borrowers in Britain, threatening to undermine household spending and the broader economy. Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg
The average UK house cost around nine times the average earnings in late 2022, the highest since 1876.
In London, fewer than half of new homes were sold before being built last year.

site_title: Clean energy investment set to run at double fossil-fuel spend
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that investment in clean energy technologies will reach US$2 trillion in 2024, surpassing fossil fuel spending for the first time. Two-thirds of this investment will go towards renewables, electric vehicles, nuclear power, and grids, while the remaining US$1 trillion will be spent on coal, gas, and oil. Despite higher financing costs, clean energy investment is driven by strong economics, cost reductions, and energy security concerns. Solar power is leading the transformation, with US$500 billion in investment this year, and China will account for the largest share of clean energy investment.

images.alt_text: Massively deploying solar, wind and other renewable power is crucial to meeting another major agreement reached at COP28: transitioning away from fossil fuels.

site_title: Chinese food delivery leader Meituan beats estimates with value focus
summary: Meituan, China's leading food delivery group, reported a 25% increase in quarterly revenue to 73.3 billion yuan, beating estimates, as it targeted cost-conscious consumers with value-for-money products and services. The company's profit rose 59.9% to 5.2 billion yuan. Meituan's CEO, Wang Xing, emphasized the importance of global expansion, citing early-stage exploration into new markets, including Gulf countries and European markets.

images.alt_text: Meituan’s global expansion is emblematic of a push by Chinese companies abroad, seeking growth as local competition intensifies even while consumption wanes.
Meituan reported sales of 73.7 billion yuan (S$13.8 billion) in the December quarter, versus the 72.7 billion yuan average projection.

site_title: Sifa 2024: A strong finish
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts concluded on a high note, showcasing three fine productions: Refuge by The Observatory, a mesmerizing multimedia spectacle; Sun & Sea, a climate change-themed opera that debuted in Singapore; and The Prose and The Passion, a poignant and emotional theatre piece exploring social class, identity, and human connection. Refuge, featuring Indonesian singer Rully Shabara, left a lasting impact, while Sun & Sea's understated style challenged audiences to reflect on their daily choices and global climate crisis. The Prose and The Passion, a collaboration between two Singaporean theatre-makers, was a moving exploration of human need and connection.

images.alt_text: Suara / Oro Rua explores what voice, song and movement could be in a post-human world. at the Singapore International Festivals of Arts 2024.
Moby Dick by Plexus Polaire combines puppetry and live action to tell the classic tale of man versus nature.

site_title: Sembcorp inks in-principle agreement to supply Japan with green ammonia produced in India
summary: Sembcorp Industries has signed a heads of terms agreement with Japanese corporates Sojitz Corporation and Kyushu Electric Power to supply green ammonia produced in India to Japan. This follows a memorandum of understanding signed in December 2023. Sembcorp will develop facilities in India, utilizing renewable energy to produce 200,000 tonnes per annum of green ammonia. The deal aims to support Japan's transition to a low-carbon economy.

site_title: Barcelona’s Disfrutar is world’s best restaurant; Singapore’s Odette drops from 14th to 25th spot
summary: Disfrutar in Barcelona, Spain, has been named the world's best restaurant by the World's 50 Best organization. This is the first time a Spanish restaurant has topped the list, with Asador Etxebarri in Axpe coming in second. Other Spanish restaurants, Diverxo in Madrid, and Quique Dacosta in Denia, also ranked highly. The top 10 list also features restaurants from the US, France, and Asia. This marks the third time a Spanish restaurant has taken the top spot, following El Bulli and Arzak.

images.alt_text: Sézanne, which serves French cuisine from the Four Seasons Hotel Tokyo at Marunouchi, advanced from second place to top of the list.
Noi in Hong Kong climbed to two stars in the new Michelin rankings.
People watch the first sunrise of the new year from a footbridge overlooking the city skyline in Seoul on January 1, 2024. (Photo by Jung Yeon-je / AFP)

site_title: Breast cancer: things you can do to reduce risks
summary: Breast cancer remains the most common cancer in women in Singapore, with 1 in 13 women diagnosed by age 75. Between 2016 and 2020, 12,303 cases were reported, with only 2,245 fatalities, largely due to early detection and modern treatment advances. A new approach for diagnosed women involves minimally invasive breast removal and reconstruction, offering a potential solution to reduce risks.

images.alt_text: Dr Fang says the Onco-PDO test can be used on all known types of solid tumours.

site_title: Old and new lessons from the Ukraine war
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has lasted two years, contradicting predictions of a quick victory for Russia. The conflict has instead strengthened Ukrainian national identity, with President Putin's denial of Ukraine's sovereignty ultimately boosting Ukrainian independence. The war has also highlighted the limitations of traditional military strategies, with Russia's inability to capture Kyiv and its reliance on energy infrastructure strikes. The conflict has also led to a reevaluation of global power dynamics and the effectiveness of international interventions.

images.alt_text: Time is running out, Zelensky says, as he made his call for international support for Kyiv amid fresh Russian offensives a fortnight ahead of the Ukraine-backed peace summit.

Remnants of cluster munitions that Oleksandr Chaplik has found on his farmland near Sievierodonetsk, Ukraine, where Russian and Ukrainian troops have been battling for control in heavy street fighting in recent days, June 1, 2022. The countryside around his farm is under almost constant bombardment by Russian forces trying to encircle the easternmost Ukrainian forces. (Finbarr O'Reilly/The New York Times)

site_title: Sri Lanka gives preliminary approval to Musk's Starlink
summary: Sri Lanka's telecommunications regulator has given preliminary approval for Elon Musk's Starlink to provide internet services in the country. This decision comes after a public consultation and a meeting between Musk and President Ranil Wickremesinghe in Indonesia. The approval aims to expand internet connectivity in rural Sri Lanka and may also involve collaboration on renewable energy.

site_title: Russia says rejecting its gas will have cost Europe 1 trillion euros by end-2024
summary: Russia's Gazprom reported a net loss of $7.1 billion in 2023, its first annual loss in over 20 years. Europe's cumulative "losses" from cutting Russian gas purchases have reached 700 billion euros ($761 billion) and are expected to reach 1 trillion euros ($1.46 trillion) by the end of 2024, primarily due to substituting Russian gas with liquefied natural gas. This reflects the significant economic impact of sharply reduced dependence on Russian energy since the start of the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Will this work for me? A test that identifies drugs one’s cancer responds to
summary: A test called Onco-PDO has been developed to identify which cancer drugs a patient's cancer responds to, improving chemotherapy efficiency, reducing treatment cost, and saving time. The test, backed by 8 years of validation data, uses Patient Derived Organoids to replicate a patient's tumour behavior and test against chemotherapeutic drugs. It can be used on all known types of solid tumours except blood cancer, with a 75-80% positive predictive accuracy and 99% accuracy in identifying resistant drugs. The test costs between US$8,000 and US$10,000.

images.alt_text: Mammograms, a special type of X-ray of the breasts, is used to detect tumours as part of cancer screening.

site_title: Most regional indices boosted by ECB rate-cut expectations, but STI ends flat
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended flat at 3,330.81 after a marginal 0.02% increase, despite expectations of the European Central Bank's interest rate cut. Regional peers, such as Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Japan's Nikkei 225, rose 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively. The STI was led by ST Engineering and local banks, while City Developments was the top drag. Analysts note that the rate cut prediction comes despite inflation not reaching the 2% target, raising questions about the timing of the easing.

images.alt_text: Megan Cheah

Singapore leads South-east Asia in startup investments with a total of US$6.1 billion in 2023, even amid a global downturn in funding. But of the US$5.8 billion raised by the region's IPO markets, only US$35 million comes from the city-state.
Jasper is a mainboard-listed company that invests in marine and shipping activities.

site_title: Thai banks to announce products for green business transition in Q3, central bank says
summary: Thai banks are expected to announce financial products supporting a green business transition in Q3, according to Bank of Thailand deputy governor Ronadol Numnonda. The move comes as Thailand needs more financing, with green and sustainably-linked loans accounting for only 1.4% of total outstanding lending. Environmental, social and governance bonds made up 5% of outstanding bonds last year.

site_title: China’s dwindling ‘snowball’ derivatives deliver a big payout
summary: China's snowball derivatives, a type of index-linked product, saw a surge in payouts in May, with 64 products triggering payouts and a combined value of nearly 20 billion yuan. This marks a reversal from earlier this year, when indexes fell and threatened coupon payments and investor capital. The growth in payouts has stoked investor interest, but regulators have introduced new rules limiting hedge fund investments and retail investors to lower-return products.

images.alt_text: Fund-raising efforts may gather pace as signs of cooling momentum in the Chinese stocks rebound spur a sense of urgency to firms.
The rush of funds into higher-yielding assets indicates efforts by Chinese policymakers to boost risk appetite are starting to bear fruit.
Some market watchers are pinning hopes on a pickup in property demand to drive momentum.
The China tech index is still more than 60 per cent off its 2021 peak.

site_title: Guess who’s angry at China’s real estate bailout: homeowners
summary: China has relaxed restrictions on home buying to boost purchases, but existing homeowners are upset as they worry prices for their properties will depreciate. Many Chinese homeowners saved to buy apartments as a main household investment and fear the new policies will hurt their wealth. The central government has lowered downpayment requirements and relaxed mortgage rules, and urged local governments to buy unsold homes and convert them into public housing. The move has sparked Nimby-ism, with homeowners demanding compensation for the discounts. The government must balance addressing the property market's collapse while avoiding a backlash from homeowners.

images.alt_text: Real estate stocks have retreated amid scepticism over a broad support package unveiled by the central government on May 17.

site_title: Singapore parents expect financial support from children in old age: survey
summary: Singapore parents rely on their children for financial support in retirement, with 60% of respondents viewing them as a "great investment" for retirement. However, this expectation contrasts with the burden of supporting elderly parents, with 55% of respondents seeing this responsibility as a financial burden. The survey highlights the need for discussions around financial independence and proactive retirement planning to break the cycle of financial obligations.

images.alt_text: Cleaner Hu Dexi, 67, works at a shopping mall in Beijing, China, April 10, 2024. China’s latest statistics showed some 94 million working people - around 12.8 per cent of China’s 734 million labour force - were older than 60 in 2022. This figure is set to skyrocket as 300 million more Chinese reach their 60s in the coming decade.
Many Japanese retirees are not only saving for the cost of their own care, but also for the cost of their parents’, who are still alive.

site_title: US probes Microsoft’s deal with AI firm Inflection
summary: The Federal Trade Commission is investigating Microsoft's $650 million deal with AI startup Inflection, which may have been structured to avoid scrutiny. The unusual "acqui-hire" deal, where Microsoft hired Inflection's staff without acquiring the company, has raised regulatory concerns. This comes amid heightened scrutiny of the AI sector and the Justice Department's focus on competition in the space. The FTC is seeking information on how the partnership was negotiated, while antitrust agencies are also looking into the dependency of popular AI startups on established tech companies for financing and infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Microsoft is taking AI technology into a number of fields of the business world with what it calls Copilot technology.

site_title: Opec+ ministers reject bearish reaction to output increase
summary: Opec+ ministers rejected bearish reactions to their decision to gradually increase crude production by 2 million barrels a day starting in October. The group remains committed to oil market stability and can adjust production if necessary. Despite a 3% drop in crude prices, ministers predict the market will eventually recognize the group's policy as correct. Oil demand remains resilient, with global consumption rising 2.3 million barrels a day in the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 89 US cents higher, or 1.2 per cent, at US$78.41 a barrel.

site_title: Sumitomo Mitsui weighs broader expansion in India’s low-tax hub
summary: Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group plans to establish a branch in India's low-tax hub, Gujarat International Finance Tec­City, with around 10 initial employees, expected to grow over time. The move joins other global banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Deutsche Bank, and HSBC Holdings, betting on the hub's potential to rival offshore centers in Asia. The branch will initially focus on foreign currency-denominated lending business, offering exemptions from withholding tax, which lowers costs for borrowers. The expansion aims to tap into India's growing demand for loans and investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: Jefferies headquarters in New York. Photographer: Jeenah Moon/Bloomberg
“India’s economic growth is just so fast, that’s really attractive,” says CEO Toru Nakashima in an interview.

site_title: Vietnam tycoon on death row for massive fraud moved US$1.5 billion abroad
summary: Vietnam real estate tycoon Truong My Lan, sentenced to death for massive financial fraud, has been accused of transferring US$1.5 billion abroad and moving US$3 billion into the country through money laundering. Lan's role in siphoning off more than US$12 billion from Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB) has also been linked to US$23.6 billion in laundered funds. An investigation into her transfers and accomplices has been completed, but further details have not been released.

site_title: Billionaire Richard Li’s FWD Group revives Hong Kong IPO plan: sources
summary: Billionaire Richard Li's FWD Group has revived plans to list the pan-Asian insurer in Hong Kong, with a potential valuation of up to $9 billion. The previous attempt in 2022 was shelved due to volatile market conditions. FWD could target a Hong Kong IPO, with the deal timeline and offering size yet to be decided. The revival comes as Hong Kong's financial hub seeks to boost listings amid a Chinese economic slowdown and geopolitical tension.

images.alt_text: FWD was started in 2013 by Li, a Hong Kong tycoon who also runs PCCW, one of the city’s major telecom companies.
FWD's job cuts take place mainly in Hong Kong and Singapore.

site_title: China property stocks fall 20% from May high as concerns linger
summary: China's property stocks have fallen 20% from their May high, amid concerns over the government's efforts to bolster the sector. Real estate stocks retreated after initial enthusiasm over a broad support package, with analysts questioning its effectiveness in reviving demand and addressing a housing inventory glut. Fitch Ratings lowered its estimates for new home sales value in 2024, predicting a 15-20% decline due to weaker-than-expected sales trends. The bear market warning comes as investors await further evidence of the government's rescue package's impact.

site_title: Gold prices drift higher ahead of US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $2,365.40 per ounce ahead of US payrolls data, which may influence interest rate cuts this year. The US dollar index declined 0.1%, and Treasury yields remained near a two-month low, making gold more attractive to investors. Investors await Friday's non-farm payrolls data to gauge the US economy's health and potential interest rate cuts. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut its key interest rate in September, with a 70% chance of a rate cut, according to a Reuters poll.

images.alt_text: Lower interest rates reduce the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion.

site_title: Airline group aims to lure travellers by cutting transit hassles
summary: Oneworld, a global airline group led by American Airlines and British Airways, plans to launch a technology platform later this year that allows travellers to check-in, including their luggage, just once across different carriers. This move aims to make airport transits more seamless and attractive, saving costs for airlines and generating revenue. The platform will simplify the check-in process, reducing hassles associated with flying multiple airlines to reach a destination.

images.alt_text: Under the joint venture, the airlines will together manage flight capacity on chosen routes, coordinate schedules and share revenues but it will involve no equity investment or cost-sharing
CAAS says such registry will align with internationally recognised sustainability standards.

IATA director-general Willie Walsh (above, in Dubai on Sunday) recommends keeping the current system of taxing airlines in the country where they are headquartered, because "only the battalions of accountants needed to manage the reporting mess" would be happy if the change is made.

FILE PHOTO: Willie Walsh, Director General of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) speaks during an interview with Reuters in Istanbul, Turkey June 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dilara Senkaya/File Photo
Aviation companies, long accustomed to thin profit margins, see AI as the newest way to boost productivity and gain a competitive edge.

site_title: Hong Kong announces blanket ban of e-cigarettes
summary: Hong Kong has announced a blanket ban on e-cigarettes, extending the existing ban on possession for commercial purposes to retail buyers. The move aims to reduce smoking prevalence, with the goal of decreasing the rate to 7.8% by next year. The ban is part of a broader set of smoking curbs, including a ban on smoking while queueing and flavoured tobacco. The World Health Organization reports that 34 countries have banned the sale of e-cigarettes, and Hong Kong authorities hope to implement the ban and other proposals in the legislature this year.

images.alt_text: Under the new rules, fines for retailers selling e-cigarettes to those under the age of 18 will increase, there will be a review of the licensing of vaping retailers, and all disposable vapes will be banned.
Borne says the government is drawing up plans for a national programme to fight tobacco use that she said was responsible for 75,000 deaths a year in France.
Australia will ban single-use disposable vapes, halt imports of non-prescription versions, and restrict how much nicotine e-cigarettes may contain.

site_title: Modi looks forward to closer ties with Taiwan after re-election
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi expressed his desire for closer economic and technological ties with Taiwan, following the island's newly-elected president. Modi stated he looks forward to a "mutually beneficial partnership" that will contribute to peace and prosperity in the Indo-Pacific. This comes as Modi faces challenges in managing India's tense relationship with China, which claims Taiwan as its own. India and Taiwan have been strengthening their economic ties, including a potential labor-supply pact that could see up to 100,000 Indian workers hired.

images.alt_text: Taiwan’s gross domestic product this year is now expected to be 3.94 per cent higher than last year.

site_title: Amazon’s robotaxi unit Zoox to begin testing in Austin, Miami
summary: Zoox, Amazon's robotaxi unit, plans to start testing its autonomous vehicles in Austin, Texas, and Miami, marking its first trial sites outside the western US. The company will deploy test fleets with human safety drivers in areas near business districts. This follows an investigation by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration into 500 Zoox vehicles after two crashes. Zoox has established operations in San Francisco, Las Vegas, and Seattle, and is exploring cities for commercial offerings after its initial launch in Las Vegas and San Francisco.

images.alt_text: Amazon is the latest company to gain approval from the FAA to fly drones more freely amid the proliferation of rapid delivery services.
AWS’ investment in Italy would be in the billions but it might not reach the scale of its plans for Spain, according to one of the sources.
AWS is facing increasing competition from rivals such as Microsoft, which is mounting its own global expansion.

site_title: Jasper Investments volume, price surge on S$9 million from investors including Koh Boon Hwee
summary: Jasper Investments, a mainboard-listed marine and shipping company, has secured S$9 million in capital from strategic investors, including board director Koh Boon Hwee, Azure Capital's CEO Terence Wong, and others. The investment led to a 300% surge in shares, trading at S$0.004. The company plans to use the funds to expand its commercial activities in the maritime sector. Jasper was previously placed on the Singapore Exchange's watch list due to consecutive pre-tax losses.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Financial’s executive chairman and chief executive officer, Ren Yuanlin, described the joint venture as “an exciting milestone" that aligns with the group’s growth objectives of increasing their asset under management for their maritime fund.
The offshore and marine specialist said that it is expected to carry out certain early engineering works on BP’s Kaskida floating production unit project.

From left: Dr Leslie Teo, senior director of AI products at AI Singapore; Wong Hwee Lim, head of digital international at CapitaLand Investment; and Victor Liang, head of data science for geo services at Grab at a breakfast panel on harnessing AI for the good of businesses and society.

site_title: Country Garden’s Hong Kong liquidation hearing further adjourned to July
summary: Country Garden, a Chinese property developer, has had its Hong Kong liquidation hearing further adjourned to July 29. The company, whose shares have been suspended since April, is seeking to push back against a liquidation petition filed by Ever Credit Limited due to progress in debt restructuring talks. Advisers are conducting due diligence on the developer's balance sheet, and a debt restructuring proposal is planned for the second half of the year. The hearing was originally adjourned from May to June 11, and the latest adjournment was announced on June 6.

images.alt_text: The sales drought may exacerbate the cash crunch for Country Garden, whose crisis entered a new chapter.
Country Garden, a major focal point in China’s real estate crisis, is scouring for capital to appease creditors after extending some yuan bond repayments last month.
Country Garden applied for the adjournment to prepare more evidence.
If the judge decides against Country Garden, it would mark a dramatic downfall for what was once China’s largest developer by sales.

site_title: BOJ chief Ueda reaffirms resolve to trim bond buying
summary: Bank of Japan governor Kazuo Ueda reaffirmed his resolve to trim the central bank's massive bond buying, potentially leading to a full-fledged tapering as early as its policy meeting next week. Ueda emphasized the need to reduce the nearly US$5-trillion balance sheet as the central bank moves toward an exit from massive monetary stimulus. This move comes after the BOJ ended its eight-year period of negative interest rates and yield curve control in March. The central bank aims to maintain a monthly bond purchase of roughly six trillion yen to stabilize yields.

images.alt_text: epa11301918 Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda holds a press conference at the Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, 26 April 2024. After holding a two-day monetary policy meeting, the Bank of Japan (BOJ) decided to hold steady on its policy rate, a decision triggering a new fall of the yen against the US dollar which traded to 156 yen per the USD.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON

The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday, March 19, 2024. The BOJ ended the most aggressive monetary stimulus program in modern history, scrapping the world's last negative interest rate and a raft of unconventional tools, while leaving the course of additional hikes unclear. Photographer: Akio Kon/Bloomberg

site_title: Indo-Pacific partners ink clean economy deal with new programme on nuclear energy
summary: The Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) has signed a clean economy agreement with 14 participating countries, including the US, Japan, and Singapore. The agreement includes three new work programmes: one on small modular reactors (SMRs), emissions intensity accounting, and e-waste urban mining. The SMR programme aims to support partners in developing the necessary infrastructure and workforce to deploy SMRs safely and sustainably. The signing of the clean economy agreement is part of the IPEF's four pillars, including trade, supply chains, and fair economy, with the goal of advancing regional cooperation in clean energy technology and sustainable infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Wind farm in Bac Lieu city in Vietnam.
President Tharman Shanmugaratnam at IPEF on 5 June 2024 at Sands Expo and Convention Centre
“We’re going to finalise all of those agreements at the ministerial,” says US Commerce Secretary Gina.
Singapore is keen to work with the US, a leader in artificial intelligence (AI), on jointly developing "guardrails" on the safe and secure development and use of AI.
Members of the US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity (IPEF) at the Apec Summit in San Francisco.

At the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework Clean Economy Investor Forum are (from left): Ken Saito, Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry of Japan; Shigeya Kusano, managing executive officer of Sojitz Corporation; Hachiman Yokoi, general manager of the energy Solutions Business Department at Sojitz Corporation; Vipul Tuli, chairman of South Asia, chief executive of hydrogen business and Middle East, and executive director of UK Sembcorp Industries; Wong Kim Yin, group president and chief executive of Sembcorp Industries; Dr Tan See Leng, Singapore's Minister of Manpower and second Minister for Trade and Industry; and Shri Sunil Barthwal, Commerce Secretary of India's Ministry of Commerce and Industry.

site_title: Abu Dhabi’s first IPO of the year draws US$20 billion in orders
summary: Abu Dhabi's first initial public offering (IPO) of the year drew US$20 billion in orders, with Alef Education's IPO priced at 1.35 dirhams per share, raising 1.89 billion dirhams (S$693.2 million) and valuing the company at 9.45 billion dirhams. The offer was 39 times covered by local, regional, and international investors, indicating a healthy appetite for listings in the Gulf.

images.alt_text: Mubadala is GlobalFoundries’ largest shareholder with an 85 per cent stake before this sale.
The move to open an office in Abu Dhabi will allow Sydney-based Barrenjoey to provide extended coverage during European and US trading hours, it said in a statement.

site_title: Brokers’ take: SAC Capital initiates ‘buy’ on ISEC Healthcare with S$0.44 price target
summary: SAC Capital has initiated a "buy" call on International Specialist Eye Centre (ISEC) Healthcare with a target price of S$0.44, representing a 15% upside from the current share price. The research house is optimistic on the company's growth due to its expansion plans, medical tourism industry prospects, and strong financial results, including a new record revenue and net profit. ISEC is expected to pay out a dividend of S$0.0173 per share in FY2024.

images.alt_text: ISEC Healthcare looking to fully acquire, subscribe for shares in 5 eye clinics in Malaysia
ISEC Healthcare to buy four medical clinics in diversification
ISEC Healthcare clinics in Malaysia to administer Covid-19 vaccinations

site_title: UN chief urges fossil fuel ad ban as heat records pile up
summary: UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres urged a ban on fossil fuel ads, citing the planet as "the meteor" that drove dinosaurs to extinction. The past 12 months were the hottest on record, with global temperatures 1.63°C above the pre-industrial average. Guterres warned that humanity faces an 80% chance of exceeding the 1.5°C warming limit in the next five years, emphasizing the need for a 9% annual decline in emissions to meet the Paris Agreement targets.

images.alt_text: The Illawarra metallurgical coal project owned by Australian mining and metals company South32 is in the process of being sold as the company focuses on commodities critical in the transition to a low-carbon future.
The fund has said the step is necessary after efforts to engage with fossil-fuel producers and get them to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions proved ineffective.
Solar panels on Dave Duttlinger's farmland that is leased to Dunns Bridge Solar LLC in Wheatfield, Indiana, US, April 5, 2024.
Smoke from a chimney in Harbin, China.

site_title: Temasek, GIC part of global coalition investing US$25 billion in Indo-Pacific emerging markets
summary: A global coalition of investors, including Singapore's Temasek and GIC, has committed $25 billion to infrastructure investments in emerging markets in the Indo-Pacific region. The investments aim to support the region's transition to a green economy and align with the Indo-Pacific Economic Framework for Prosperity's (IPEF) economic development and sustainability goals. 20 infrastructure projects worth $6 billion were deemed investment-ready and presented to investors at a business-matching session, with the remaining projects worth $17 billion recognized as potential investment opportunities.

images.alt_text: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam at IPEF on 5 June 2024 at Sands Expo and Convention Centre
“We’re going to finalise all of those agreements at the ministerial,” says US Commerce Secretary Gina.
The success of the US-Singapore FTA demonstrates how countries can benefit from an open, inclusive, rules-based multilateral trading order, said Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong.

site_title: Lockheed Martin to buy up to 25 rocket launches from Firefly Aerospace
summary: Lockheed Martin has entered a purchase agreement with Firefly Aerospace for up to 25 launches of its Alpha rocket by 2029, providing lower-cost launch options for the company's technology demonstration missions. The deal will allow Firefly's Alpha to fly Lockheed's spacecraft and payload into low-Earth orbit from both west and east coasts. The financial details of the agreement were not disclosed. This partnership aims to reduce risk for Lockheed's self-funded missions and builds on the companies' existing collaboration, which includes a joint venture with Boeing.

site_title: Cut-off yield on latest Singapore 6-month T-bill rises to 3.76%
summary: The cut-off yield on Singapore's 6-month T-bill has risen to 3.76%, up from 3.65% in the previous auction. Demand for the latest auction fell, with applications totaling S$14.2 billion for the S$7.1 billion on offer, resulting in a bid-to-cover ratio of two.

The June issuance saw a total of S$1.6 billion in applications, exceeding the S$1 billion on offer. S$1.6 billion was applied within individual allotment limits.
While the Fed exerts control over short-term Treasuries, the research is mixed on how much influence it has on longer-term bonds.
Investors typically hold more cash than they should for its perceived safety.

site_title: Clash over phone hacking article preceded exit of Washington Post editor
summary: Washington Post editor Sally Buzbee abruptly resigned amid a tense relationship with CEO Will Lewis over a planned article about a British hacking scandal. The article, which could have implicated Lewis in a plan to conceal evidence of hacking, was published despite his objections. The incident was not the primary reason for Buzbee's resignation, which was also driven by a plan to reorganize the newsroom and a demotion. Lewis had offered Buzbee a role overseeing social media and service journalism, but she declined, and he instead selected another editor.

images.alt_text: TikTok did not detail the exploit used by attackers, but media reports indicated it involved a direct messaging feature.

site_title: Timing for US ether ETF launches depends on how fast issuers can move, SEC chair says
summary: US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) Chair Gary Gensler says the timing for exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tied to cryptocurrency ether to begin trading depends on how quickly issuers respond to the SEC's queries. The SEC approved applications from Nasdaq, CBOE, and NYSE to list spot ether ETFs last month, and the process of approving ETF issuers' registration statements detailing investor disclosures is ongoing. Gensler cites last year's court challenge that forced the SEC to approve spot bitcoin ETFs as an influence on his thinking, stating that the correlations between ether and bitcoin futures are relatively similar.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is vying with the likes of Singapore and Dubai to become a digital asset hub after rolling out a dedicated regulatory regime last year.
The debuts mark the first launch of spot cryptocurrency ETFs in Asia and come just three months after the US launched its first ETFs to track spot Bitcoin.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Thursday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) opened 0.3% higher at 3,341.31, tracking global gains overnight. The broader market saw 73 gainers for every 21 losers, with DBS rising 1% to S$35.72, while Singtel and Keppel Reit also gained. Global markets rose as US chip designer Nvidia topped $3 trillion in market value, and European shares rose on technology stocks ahead of the European Central Bank's key rate decision.

images.alt_text: The net proceeds of OUE Reit Treasury's offering will be used to finance or refinance new or existing eligible green projects.

site_title: Oil rises 1% as Fed rate cut optimism offsets demand fears
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Wednesday as hopes of a US Federal Reserve interest rate cut in September outweighed concerns over demand. Brent crude futures climbed 1.2% to $78.41 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 1.1% to $74.07. A build in US crude stocks and expectations of a rate cut boosted prices, despite concerns over fuel inventories and Opec+ supply. The Fed is now seen with a nearly 69% chance of cutting rates in September, according to forecasters.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled down 84 US cents, or 1.07 per cent, at US$77.52 a barrel.

site_title: The moral limits of bankruptcy law
summary: The US bankruptcy system is being misused by companies to shield themselves from accountability for corporate wrongdoing, such as product liability and cover-ups. Companies are using Chapter 11 bankruptcy to permanently cap liability, despite its original purpose of restructuring debt for financially distressed businesses. This practice, known as the "Texas two-step," has been used by companies like Purdue Pharma and Johnson & Johnson to avoid civil liability. The Supreme Court is considering whether this practice violates the rights of individuals seeking accountability and potentially undermines the justice system's ability to deter bad behavior.

images.alt_text: 3M’s exit from the category comes 20 years after management phased out an early, popular form of PFAS, known as PFOS, in 2002 under pressure from scientific studies about its potential harms.
3M plans to funnel US$1 billion to a trust that would pay people suing over the earplugs and has set aside US$240 million to fund the bankruptcy itself.

CEO of bankrupt Purdue Pharma to get US$1.3m bonus

site_title: Australian home loans jump as rental yields lure investors
summary: Australian home loans to investors jumped 5.6% in April, reaching A$10.9 billion, a 36.1% increase from last year. The surge is attributed to surging residential rents, making housing an attractive investment. This marks the third consecutive month of growth for investor loans, outpacing owner-occupier loans.

images.alt_text: Gen Z consumers, or those aged between 18 and 25, form the majority of BNPL users, data from fintech firms shows.
The RBA predicts annual economic growth will trough at 1.2 per cent in the middle of this year, before regaining momentum.
The new minimum rate will be A$915.90 (S$823) a week, or A$24.10 an hour, from Jul 1.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street record as US jobs fuel rate cut hopes
summary: Asian markets surged on Thursday, June 6, 2024, as US job data fueled hopes for interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve this year. Softening labor market data and below-par factory gauge data led investors to bet on rate cuts, with traders pricing in almost two cuts before the end of 2024. The rally extended across Asia, with Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, and other markets enjoying buying interest, as investors await the release of the non-farm payrolls report and the Fed's policy meeting.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Wellington all enjoyed buying interest, though Tokyo, Shanghai and Jakarta were in the red.

site_title: Singapore builder Oxley seeks up to US$120 million private loan
summary: Oxley Holdings, a Singapore property developer, is seeking a private credit loan of $100 million to $120 million to repay a Singapore dollar bond due next month. The loan, with a two-year tenor, will be backed by two property projects in Kuala Lumpur and London. Oxley plans to use part of the proceeds to repay its Singapore dollar-denominated bond due in July. The move comes as Singapore's property sector slows due to weaker economic growth and government interventions to cool the market.

images.alt_text: Oxley Holdings' H1 loss of S$1.1 million was partially offset by the sale of a tower in Kuala Lumpur.

site_title: Money laundering case: Bulk of S$3 billion  worth of assets seized from 17 foreigners, not from 10 arrested
summary: Singapore's police have seized S$3 billion worth of assets in the country's largest money laundering case, belonging to 27 individuals, not just the 10 arrested in August 2023. Eight of the arrested foreigners have been convicted and sentenced to jail, with two expected to plead guilty. Seventeen other individuals, linked to around S$2.1 billion in assets, are under investigation and include those who fled the country, with some facing Interpol Red Notices. The police will maintain the prohibition on disposal of seized assets until the case is concluded.

images.alt_text: Cypriot national Wang Dehai received four additional charges under the Employment of Foreign Manpower Act on Jun 4.
(From left) Su Baolin, Su Haijin and Vang Shuiming were deported from Singapore on May 25, May 28 and June 1 respectively.
Su Jianfeng now faces 14 charges in total in Singapore’s biggest money laundering case involving more than S$3 billion in assets.
Su Jianfeng faces 12 charges for forgery and fraud. Four cars, including a red Porsche 911 Targa, were towed away by the authorities from a GCB he resided in before his arrest.

Over S$200 million of Lin Baoying's (right) assets have been seized, BT reported previously. This includes cash, properties and vehicles, including some that were held collectively with Zhang Ruijin (left).

site_title: China’s big chip fund to exceed US$47.5 billion goal, adviser says
summary: China's National Integrated Circuit Industry Investment Fund, also known as the "Big Fund," is expected to exceed its initial goal of $47.5 billion, according to a senior adviser. The fund, which aims to create a self-sufficient domestic semiconductor industry, will likely receive additional investments from state-backed firms. The third vehicle of the fund, launched last month, will operate for 10 years, potentially leading to a "Big Fund 3.5" phase. The government's efforts aim to overcome US sanctions and bridge the technology gap with the US.

site_title: US crypto advocacy group tops one million members after Biden veto
summary: US crypto advocacy group Stand With Crypto has surpassed 1 million members after President Joe Biden's veto of a measure aimed at creating a new regulatory framework for the digital asset industry. The group's rapid growth shows the potential voting power of cryptocurrency users, who are spending tens of millions of US dollars in US elections to boost crypto-friendly candidates and defeat those pushing for more regulation. Coinbase CEO Brian Armstrong attributes the surge in membership to frustration over Biden's veto and strong support for a Republican-sponsored bill.

images.alt_text: The SEC still has to approve the ETF issuers’ registration statements detailing investor disclosures before they can start trading.
The agreement marks a major step forward for Tether in its plan to become a major Bitcoin miner.
Bitcoin has quadrupled since the start of last year, helped by the ETFs, in a powerful recovery from a deep bear market in 2022.
Hong Kong has also allowed Bitcoin and Ether ETFs, but they have received a tepid response from investors there.

site_title: UG Healthcare makes acquisitions in Spain, Germany
summary: UG Healthcare has formed a joint venture with UG Nitrex in Spain, acquiring a 50% stake in the reusable glove distributor for 500,000 euros. The move aims to drive growth in the group's downstream distribution business in Europe. This follows UG Healthcare's full acquisition of Unigloves Germany in May for 16.9 million euros, granting the company full ownership of the German associate company. The joint venture is expected to expand the group's product portfolio and enable growth into neighboring countries.

images.alt_text: gloves, medical gloves, medical supply

site_title: Why China’s tightening its IPO regulation
summary: China has introduced new guidelines for its initial public offering (IPO) system, aiming to improve oversight and regulation of the equity market, enhance the quality of listed companies, and restore investor confidence. The guidelines, released by the State Council, focus on listing standards, delisting rules, and supervision of intermediaries. However, analysts warn that the measures could jeopardize the landmark overhaul of the IPO system introduced five years ago and shut out innovative small companies in emerging industries. The tightened regulations are expected to make it more difficult for companies to list on domestic stock markets, potentially leading to a decline in IPO financing this year.

images.alt_text: China's national flag flutters outside the China Securities Regulatory Commission in Beijing. Securities brokerages that used to offer some of the highest remunerations last year reported declines in average salaries for the second straight year.
China is tightening scrutiny of hedge funds, with new rules unveiled last month raising the asset threshold and curbing their use of leverage and derivatives.
The investment link between mainland China and Hong Kong will be broadened to include real estate investment trusts (Reits) and yuan-denominated stocks listed in Hong Kong.
The Communist Party has put an increasing focus on corruption among cadres and corporate executives.

site_title: Chanel’s record dividend brings owners’ windfall to US$12 billion
summary: The Wertheimer family, owners of luxury brand Chanel, will receive a US$12.4 billion payout from the company's earnings over the past three years, contributing to a 26% increase in their net worth. The largest annual dividend since Chanel began publishing results in 2018, it follows a US$5.7 billion payout in 2023, US$1.7 billion in 2022, and US$5 billion in 2021. This windfall comes as the luxury sector experiences a softening, with Chanel's revenues rising 16% to almost US$20 billion last year.

images.alt_text: Generic pix of shoppers outside the luxury outlets/ stores at the Ion Orchard shopping mall on Oct 3, 2023.
Net profit rises by 3 per cent to US$4.7 billion, a slowdown from the 14.3 per cent profit growth registered in 2022.
Chanel said the young shoppers in China were interested in luxury purchases as longer term financial investments.
Exclusive luxury brands are known to enjoy strong pricing power, meaning they can apply increases without necessarily losing customers.

site_title: Banks’ drive to ‘tokenise’ assets moves slower than expected
summary: Banks' efforts to "tokenise" assets, creating blockchain-based versions of assets like bonds and currencies, are moving slower than expected. Despite predictions that 5-10% of all assets will be tokenised by 2030, executives say the shift is taking longer due to fragmentation across platforms and lack of a liquid secondary market. Banks are experimenting with tokenised deposits and bonds, but live applications are scarce, with Citibank's head of digital assets stating that the technology is "not yet ready" for widespread adoption.

images.alt_text: Industry players have disparate views about how to use distributed ledger technology and the benefits it can bring.
The British companies have a market capitalisation of £200 billion, equivalent to 8 per cent of the stock market

Using tokenization, which involves recording assets on a blockchain, has the advantage of combining messaging and settlement aspects of a payment in one transaction, Bank for International Settlements (BIS) says.

site_title: US services sector rebounds in May
summary: The US services sector rebounded in May with a 53.8 non-manufacturing purchasing managers index, the highest since August, surpassing economists' expectations. This growth contrasted with the manufacturing sector's contraction for the second straight month. The strong services reading may reinforce the Federal Reserve's hesitance to shift toward interest rate cuts, despite a long history of interest rate increases since 2022.

images.alt_text: Private payrolls increased by 152,000 jobs last month after rising by a downwardly revised 188,000 in April, the ADP Employment report showed.

site_title: ASML to ship its US$380 million chip machine to TSMC this year
summary: ASML Holding will ship its $380 million high-NA extreme ultraviolet (EUV) chipmaking machine to Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) this year. The machine can imprint semiconductors with lines as thin as 8 nanometres, 1.7 times smaller than the previous generation. This shipment follows Intel's recent receipt of the same machine, and both companies are expected to benefit from the advanced technology.

images.alt_text: ASML’s new machine can imprint semiconductors with lines that are just eight nanometres thick – 1.7 times smaller than the previous generation.

ASML and the city of Eindhoven have signed a letter of intent to explore an expansion large enough to house 20,000 new employees in a relatively undeveloped area in the north of Eindhoven near the city’s airport.
ASML is one of the world’s leading manufacturers of equipment to make state-of-the-art semiconductor chips, which power everything from mobile phones to cars.

site_title: Nomura’s head of markets returns to Singapore after revamp
summary: Nomura Holdings' head of global markets, Rig Karkhanis, is returning to Singapore after a year in London, where he revamped the business and made significant executive hires. Karkhanis oversaw the addition of over 400 new employees to diversify the business and achieve stable earnings. He aims to deliver 20% revenue gains for the global markets unit over the next few years. Karkhanis will be joined by the unit's chief operating officer, Aleem Jivraj, in his return to Asia.

site_title: Elon Musk’s xAI to develop new supercomputer in Memphis
summary: Elon Musk's xAI is planning to develop a new supercomputer facility in Memphis, Tennessee, marking the largest multibillion-dollar investment in the city's history. The project, valued at over $24 billion, aims to boost the company's capacity in AI-powered tools, including chatbots. Details on the total cost and job creation are pending, but the city is offering tax breaks and other business incentives to lure the project. This move comes as xAI secures $6 billion in new funding and Musk plans to complete a "gigafactory of compute" by 2025, competing with other tech giants like OpenAI and Google.

images.alt_text: The Series B round, announced in a blog post on May 26, comes less than a year after xAI’s debut and marks one of the bigger investments in the nascent field of developing AI tools.

site_title: Indonesia risks falling behind in regional EV race despite rich nickel reserves
summary: Indonesia is lagging behind in the regional electric vehicle (EV) market despite having rich nickel reserves, a key component in EV batteries. The country's domestic EV adoption rate is less than 2%, with combustion engine vehicles dominating the roads. Investor sentiment is dampened due to the slow uptake of EVs, which may prompt global manufacturers to reconsider their investment prospects. Indonesia aims to produce 600,000 electric cars by 2030 to reduce oil consumption and emissions, but faces challenges such as high initial costs, limited charging infrastructure, and lack of spare parts. The government has introduced financial and tax incentives to boost domestic EV manufacturing, but more needs to be done to accelerate adoption.

images.alt_text: Visitors trying mini-electric car Wuling Air EV launched at Indonesia's largest auto show - Gaikindo Indonesia International Auto Show - that runs from Aug 11 to 21, 2022. Wuling Motors will produce 300 electric four-seaters to welcome delegates convening for the G20 Summit in Bali in November.
Indonesia is grappling with a notable scarcity of skilled information and communications technology workers.

site_title: ECB to begin cuts but path beyond gets murkier
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is set to start lowering interest rates from record highs, with analysts predicting a quarter-point cut to 3.75% on Thursday. ECB President Christine Lagarde has declared inflation in the eurozone "under control," paving the way for monetary policy loosening before the US Federal Reserve or Bank of England. However, some economists question the timing and pace of rate cuts, citing stronger-than-anticipated economic growth and inflation. The ECB's path forward remains unclear, with expectations for three rate cuts this year pared back by investors.

images.alt_text: By embarking on a new cycle of interest-rate cuts now, the ECB appears to be relying too heavily on flawed forecasts and ignoring economic and geopolitical realities.
Investors will be keenly watching to see if ECB president Christine Lagarde provides any guidance about the pace of cuts going forward in her post-meeting press conference.
The unexpected inflation rise likely will not prevent the ECB from cutting record-high borrowing costs next week but may lead to a pause in July and slower future rate reductions.
Communicating the ECB’s intentions without locking in a specific scenario may – once again – be the biggest challenge for Lagarde.

site_title: Changi Business Park emptying out as global tech, finance layoffs take toll
summary: Changi Business Park, a 71-hectare business hub in Singapore, is rapidly emptying out due to global tech and finance layoffs, as well as the push to work from home. The park, which was once a major draw for tech giants and global banks, now has over 40% vacancy rates, with some buildings having "For Rent" signs. IBM, UBS, and Standard Chartered have all reduced their presence in the park, with IBM occupying just two floors of its former 12-floor space. The government's efforts to promote the park have been hindered by the challenges of attracting workers who prefer the central business district.

images.alt_text: Residents of the Chempaka housing estate in the Bedok area are grappling with their land lease expiring in 10 years.
The Rail Mall is on a site sold by the state with 99-year leasehold tenure from March 1947; this leaves a balance of about 21 years and nine months.
Home owners said they hope to get more clarity on the fate of the land after the lease runs out.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Reit, Yangzijiang Financial, UG Healthcare
summary: OUE Reit priced its S$250 million green notes, with net proceeds to finance or refinance green projects. Yangzijiang Financial entered a joint venture to acquire a dry-bulk vessel, while UG Healthcare acquired a 50% interest in reusable glove distributor UG Nitrex. OUE Reit's units rose 1.9%, Yangzijiang Financial's shares fell 1.5%, and UG Healthcare's shares dropped 4.4% following the announcements.

site_title: Lululemon beats quarterly revenue estimate, announces more share buyback
summary: Lululemon Athletica beat quarterly revenue estimates with $2.21 billion in net revenue, driven by strong international sales and a 6% increase in comparable sales. The company's gross margin rose 20 basis points to 57.7% due to leaner inventory and full-price selling. Lululemon also announced a $1 billion increase to its stock repurchase program, with shares rising over 12% in extended trading. Despite a slowdown in the US market, the company's China demand helped offset the decline.

images.alt_text: The move comes at a time when Lululemon is seeing slowing demand for its premium athleisure in North America.
Lululemon’s performance has slowed in recent quarters following a stellar post-pandemic run.

site_title: AFP journalists to strike over expat jobs
summary: Journalists at Agence France-Presse (AFP) will hold a 24-hour strike starting June 6 to protest against potential changes in the status of journalists working outside France. The strike is over the shift from "headquarters" to "local" contracts, which carry less generous housing and social benefits. The union demands the maintenance of 151 expatriate positions with headquarters status. The move is seen as part of a broader effort to curb the number of headquarters-status posts, with AFP operating in 150 countries.

images.alt_text: Google chief executive Sundar Pichai speaks during the tech titan’s annual I/O developers conference on May 14, 2024, in Mountain View, California. Google on Tuesday said it would introduce AI-generated answers to online queries made by users in the United States, in one of the biggest updates to its search engine in 25 years.
The US newspaper said its decision to move its Asia headquarters to Singapore comes after other foreign firms have reconsidered their operations in Chinese financial hub Hong Kong.
The agreement will enhance OpenAI’s generative AI chatbot ChatGPT with attributed FT content, and the firms will collaborate on developing new AI products and features for FT readers.

site_title: Yellen to warn of 'significant risks' from use of AI in finance
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen warns that the use of artificial intelligence in finance poses "significant risks" due to complexity, opacity, and inadequate risk management frameworks. However, she also recognizes the benefits of AI in automating customer support services, improving efficiency, and combating illicit finance. The Treasury Department is working to monitor AI's impact on financial stability and promote dialogue among financial regulators. Yellen notes that concentration among AI vendors and data providers may amplify existing risks, and insufficient data could introduce biases in financial decision-making.

images.alt_text: Janet Yellen, US Treasury secretary, speaks following a tour of Suniva solar cell manufacturing plant in Norcross, Georgia, US, on Wednesday, March 27, 2024. Yellen is visiting Norcross to showcase the reopening of a US solar-cell manufacturing facility that shut in 2017 under the pressure of "cheap imports flooding the market." Photographer: Alyssa Pointer/Bloomberg

site_title: US private payroll growth slows to 4-month low; small firms cut jobs
summary: US private payrolls increased by 152,000 jobs in May, the fewest since January, with small firms cutting staff. This marked a four-month low in hiring, adding to signs the job market is cooling. Wage gains for job changers moderated for a second month, with gains led by large employers and mid-sized companies. Economists had forecast private employment increasing by 175,000 last month.

images.alt_text: Job openings, a measure of labour demand, were down 296,000 to 8.059 million on the last day of April, the lowest level since February 2021.
Four in 10 Americans said having a four-year degree is not too or not at all important to getting a well-paying job.

SAN RAFAEL, CALIFORNIA - MARCH 08: Home Depot customers walk by a posted now hiring sign on March 08, 2024 in San Rafael, California. According to a report from the Bureau of Labor Statistics, the U.S. labor market added 275,000 nonfarm payroll jobs in February, beating analyst expectations of 200,000. The unemployment rate inched up to 3.9% from 3.7% in January.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Monthly data out by Challenger, Gray & Christmas, showed firms announced plans to hire 9,802 workers last month, the lowest figure for the month of April since 2013.
Initial claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted 212,000 for the week ended Apr 13.

site_title: Nvidia tops US$3 trillion in value, leapfrogging past Apple
summary: Nvidia has surpassed Apple to become the world's first computer chip company to reach a market capitalization of over US$3 trillion, driven by a surge in demand for its AI chips. The company's shares have risen 147% this year, adding US$1.8 trillion, and have closed at a record US$1,224.40. CEO Jensen Huang plans to upgrade its AI accelerators annually, positioning Nvidia for a major role in the growing generative AI industry. The company now trails only Microsoft in market value, with analysts predicting it will soon overtake the tech giant.

images.alt_text: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang said that his company was examining the so-called HBM chips that Samsung and Micron Technology offer.
Nvidia sees the rise of generative AI as a new industrial revolution and expects to play a major role as the technology shifts to personal computers, the CEO says.
Many businesses are training AI systems to help their employees with tasks such as answering human resources questions or assisting customer service agents.
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang touted 98 per cent cost savings and 97 per cent less energy required with Nvidia’s technology, saying that constituted “CEO math, which is not accurate, but it is correct”.

site_title: OUE Reit Treasury prices S$250 million green notes due 2027 at 4.1%
summary: OUE Reit Treasury has priced its S$250 million green notes due 2027 at 4.1%, with a rating of BBB- by S&P Global Ratings. The notes, expected to be issued on June 14 and listed on the Singapore Exchange Securities Trading on June 18, will bear an annual coupon of 4.1% and be guaranteed by DBS Trustee. The net proceeds will be used to finance or refinance eligible green projects.

images.alt_text: Tthe notes will be issued at an issue price of 100 per cent their principal amount, and will bear interest at the rate of 4.2 per cent per annum.

site_title: US: Stocks up as Nvidia tops US$3 trillion market capitalisation
summary: US stocks rose solidly on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq hitting fresh highs, as Nvidia topped the US$3 trillion market capitalization mark. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.3% to 38,807.33. Nvidia's shares closed 5.2% up, while tech giants Apple and Meta Platforms also advanced. A cooler labor market and services sector activity also boosted market optimism for a "soft landing" and potential interest rate cuts.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 26, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: US home-purchase applications fall by most since early April
summary: US home-purchase applications declined 4.4% in the week ending May 31, the largest drop since early April, due to high mortgage rates above 7%. The 30-year fixed mortgage rate rose 2 basis points to 7.07%, while the 5-year adjustable mortgage rate fell to a two-month low of 6.37%. This decrease follows a four-year low in contract signings on home resales, as buyers are deterred by high asking prices and borrowing costs.

site_title: Europe: Shares led higher by tech stocks ahead of ECB rate decision
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 rose 0.8% on June 5, led by technology stocks, including ASML's 8.1% gain. The sector's best single-day performance in over four months was driven by a Jefferies analyst report suggesting positive orders from top customer TSMC. Investors now focus on the European Central Bank's (ECB) rate decision on Thursday, expected to ease borrowing costs by 25 basis points. The ECB's forward guidance on further cuts will be key, with inflation on a good path and eurozone business activity expanding at its quickest rate in a year.

images.alt_text: The continent-wide Stoxx 600 closed 0.5 per cent lower, snapping a three-day winning streak.

site_title: Telco M1 struggles to find a fit in Keppel’s transformation plans
summary: Keppel may consider shedding telco M1 from its portfolio as part of its transformation plans. M1's net profit margin of around 6.3% for FY2023 is comparable to StarHub's, while Keppel's data centre and subsea cable businesses have higher margins. Paring M1 from its portfolio could help Keppel focus on more profitable ventures and demonstrate its ability as an asset manager. However, M1's telco revenues in Singapore easily cross into billions, making it a significant contributor to Keppel's earnings.

images.alt_text: From left: Thomas Pang, Keppel's current CEO of data centres and networks, and Manjot Singh Mann, CEO of M1 and Keppel chief digital officer. Their new appointments will be effective from Jun 1.
Since the start of 2024, Keppel has reported the monetisation of about S$170 million in assets.
Analysts believe that the local telecoms industry is due for consolidation, which should help improve margins.

site_title: Boeing’s Starliner capsule is launched from Florida on first crewed space flight
summary: Boeing's Starliner capsule successfully launched from Florida on its first crewed space flight, carrying two NASA astronauts on a mission to the International Space Station. The CST-100 Starliner, launched on an Atlas V rocket, completed a 24-hour journey to reach the ISS, where the crew will spend about a week before returning to Earth. This milestone marks a significant step forward for Boeing's ambitious space program, which has faced delays and budget overruns. The test flight aims to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which has been NASA's primary vehicle for ISS crew missions since 2020.

images.alt_text: United Airlines, a prominent customer of Boeing, has been hit by the planemaker’s safety crisis.
“Aviation needs a strong Boeing,” says Qantas chief executive Vanessa Hudson.
Boeing has also come under fire from regulators, lawmakers and airlines following a January accident in which a fuselage panel blew off a 737 Max mid-flight.

site_title: eBay to stop taking American Express cards after fee dispute
summary: eBay will stop accepting American Express cards due to "unacceptably high fees" charged by Amex for processing credit card transactions. The change, set to take effect August 17, is a result of negotiations over merchant discount rates. eBay claims Amex fees are not comparable to those paid for similar cards on other networks, such as Visa and Mastercard. This decision follows similar moves by competitors like Amazon, which has also dropped certain card options to negotiate lower fees.

images.alt_text: The tie-up with Ebay, which started on May 8 with just seven vendors on Rakuten’s second-hand goods unit Rakuma, aims to capitalise on the currency effect and also a move towards bargain hunting as cost-of-living pressures around the world crimp spending.
EBay defines active buyers as customers who paid for a transaction on eBay within the previous 12-month period.
Ebay has been losing United States market share for years to the likes of Amazon.com and Walmart.

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial enters JV with Alpha Omega Marine to acquire vessel
summary: Yangzijiang Financial's maritime fund has entered into a joint venture with Alpha Omega Marine to acquire a 40,000 deadweight tonne Handymax vessel, scheduled for delivery in July. The move aims to increase assets under management for the maritime fund, despite concerns from shareholders that it may create a conflict of interest with its sister company, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding. The company has stated it has no intention of competing in the shipbuilding segment and will focus on providing maritime services.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Financial said that it “has no intention of competing in the shipbuilding segment”, but will focus mainly on services such as providing secured loans to maritime players.

site_title: StanChart banks on international ties amid demand for cross-border wealth needs: James Lye
summary: Standard Chartered Bank is focusing on its international banking business to cater to growing demand for cross-border wealth management services. The bank's affluent client business saw a 50% rise in net inflows to $29 billion in 2023, with client numbers increasing to 2.3 million. StanChart aims to expand its international affluent clients to over 375,000 by 2026, leveraging its four wealth hubs in Jersey, the UAE, Hong Kong, and Singapore to connect cross-border needs.

images.alt_text: StanChart, which earns most of its revenue in Asia, said pretax profit in the quarter was US$1.91 billion, compared to US$1.81 billion a year earlier.
Wong Kee Joo (left), CEO for HSBC Singapore, and Ashmita Acharya (right), head of wealth and personal banking at HSBC Singapore.
Marisa Drew, chief sustainability officer at StanChart, says that the goal with the guidelines around adaptation finance is that they become “a catalyst for that capital flowing.”
Simon Cooper, who has led the firm’s corporate, commercial and institutional banking division for eight years, will leave Standard Chartered to “pursue other interests”.

site_title: Vietnam unicorn VNLife banks on diversified model to maintain distance from loss-making rivals
summary: Vietnam's fintech unicorn VNLife has maintained profitability by diversifying its revenue streams beyond e-wallet services. The company processes transactions for 60 million users and 400,000 partner merchants, with revenue growth driven by its financial infrastructure and software solutions for enterprise clients. VNLife's approach sets it apart from struggling fintech competitors, including M-Service and VNG, which have reported consistent losses. The company is not actively seeking a new fundraising round, but is considering a strategic trade sale or initial public offering (IPO) as exit options.

images.alt_text: The tech and telco sector represents merely 2 per cent of the total number of listed companies on Vietnam's local bourses
VNG Campus in Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Alphabet names Lilly executive Anat Ashkenazi as CFO
summary: Alphabet has named Anat Ashkenazi, former CFO of Eli Lilly, as its new CFO, succeeding Ruth Porat. The move comes at a crucial time for Alphabet, which is investing billions in AI to compete with Microsoft and drive growth. Ashkenazi, who took over as CFO of Lilly in 2021, helped the company quadruple its stock and become the world's most valuable healthcare firm. Her appointment is seen as a strategic move to invest wisely in the AI mega trend and help Alphabet achieve leadership in the category.

images.alt_text: Google also laid off hundreds of employees in January.
Singapore is one of 11 countries where Google currently operates data centres.

site_title: Bridging the gap in South-east Asia’s capital markets
summary: Singapore's startup investments outpaced the region's IPO markets in 2023, with US$6.1 billion in startup investments compared to US$5.8 billion in IPO proceeds. This gap is concerning, as companies often stay private longer and need access to public markets for more sustainable capital and liquidity. To address this, Granite Asia, a firm that catalyzed 29 companies to US$548 billion in market capitalization, has launched NextGen Tech 30, a public-private initiative to highlight growth companies in the region and attract investments. The initiative aims to accelerate the growth trajectories of innovative startups and tech companies in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Granite Asia's senior managing partners,  Jenny Lee and Foo Jixun, will tap on their years of expertise as the firm ventures into other asset classes.
Granite Asia will be led by senior managing partners Jenny Lee (above) and Foo Jixun.

site_title: OCBC takes HNWI banking to next level as clients grow ‘more cosmopolitan and sophisticated’: Helen Wong
summary: OCBC's CEO, Helen Wong, notes that Asian high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) are shifting their focus from investing to preserving wealth for the next generation, driven by the limited number of generations they have inherited wealth. This trend is reflected in OCBC's 19% year-over-year growth in wealth management income to S$1.3 billion, with a 36% share of the group's total income. To support this, OCBC's private banking arm, Bank of Singapore, is offering services such as succession planning and educational programs for the next generation.

images.alt_text: Helen Wong, group chief executive of OCBC, said
OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
Helen Wong, group chief executive of OCBC, said Greater China has been a key contributor to OCBC’s group profit, growing at a compound annual growth rate of 24 per cent in the last 10 years.

site_title: US dollar gains after stronger-than-expected services sector data
summary: The US dollar rose 0.3% to 104.41 following stronger-than-expected services sector data, with the Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing purchasing managers' index rising to 53.8 in May. This rebounded from a contraction in April, suggesting uncertainty surrounding the Federal Reserve's easing cycle later this year. The dollar's gain contrasts with earlier concerns that the economy is weak, with some analysts downplaying the April data's significance.
