site_title: Clean energy behind 10% of global growth in 2023, and it’s early days: Tharman
summary: President Tharman Shanmugaratnam stated that clean energy investments contributed 10% to global growth in 2023, with the sector's growth benefits being immediate. He emphasized the need for global collaboration to mobilize capital and tackle the climate crisis, moving away from burden-sharing to investing together for a return. Tharman suggested focusing on the benefits of taking climate action early, such as lower pollution in cities, to change minds and develop a political constituency to support climate measures.

site_title: Cash is king: Charles III banknotes enter circulation
summary: King Charles III's banknotes, featuring his portrait, entered circulation on June 5, 2024, two years after he succeeded Queen Elizabeth II. The four new notes, with values of £5, £10, £20, and £50, will be used alongside existing notes bearing Elizabeth's image. The updates come as cash usage decreases, with Britons increasingly relying on physical and online bank cards. Bank of England governor Andrew Bailey hailed the move as a "historic moment," emphasizing the importance of cash for many people.

images.alt_text: epa11390607 A handout photo taken 03 June 2024 made available by the Bank of England shows newly issued banknotes featuring the portrait of King Charles III, in London, Britain, 05 June 2024. Banknotes carrying a portrait of King Charles III will be issued for circulation the first time on 05 June 2024. The portrait of King Charles III will appear on existing designs of all banknotes. Banknotes that feature the portrait of Queen Elizabeth II will remain legal tender, and will co-circulate alongside the new King Charles III notes, according to the Bank of England. site_title: Saudi Arabia’s chip design ambitions take shape with new hub
summary: Saudi Arabia has launched the National Semiconductor Hub to develop fabless chip companies, aiming to draw 50 firms by 2030 and focus on simple, non-politically-sensitive technologies. The initiative, backed by US$100 billion from the sovereign wealth fund, will be led by Alat investment firm, with the goal of establishing the kingdom as a hub for semiconductor design. Manufacturing will be done internationally initially, but the focus is on incentivizing companies to relocate and establish new fabless chip firms, with 10 incentives already offered to potential partners.

images.alt_text: HSBC is a joint global coordinator for the US$12 billion secondary share sale in oil giant Saudi Aramco, which is one of the largest equity offerings in recent years.

site_title: Indonesia president says plan to start working from new capital city in July
summary: Indonesia's President Joko Widodo announced plans to start working from the new capital city of Nusantara in July, despite concerns over the project's future following senior executive resignations. The US$32 billion capital city's first phase development has reached around 80% completion. Preparations for Indonesia's 79th Independence Day celebrations in the new capital in August are underway.

site_title: Young talents wanted for ChildAid’s 20th anniversary show
summary: ChildAid, a charity event organized by BT and ST, is marking its 20th anniversary with a fantasy musical titled "The Dream Emporium." The show will be staged on Nov 29 and 30 at Esplanade Theatre and features a call for young performers aged 6-19 to audition for parts. Submissions must be made by Jul 14, with selected performers going through a three-day workshop and rehearsals starting in Oct. The event aims to raise funds for the BT Budding Artists Fund and ST School Pocket Money Fund, supporting artistically talented youth and low-income children, respectively.

images.alt_text: Wearing costumes inspired by the 1930s, the cast belted a harmonious medley of four songs in four different languages.

site_title: China’s Sinograin to expand wheat stockpiles as global supplies fall
summary: China's Sinograin will expand its wheat stockpiles by increasing purchases from domestic producers amid global supply disruptions. Weather-related damage to crops in Russia and the European Union has raised concerns about lower global supplies in the second half of 2024. Sinograin has already started buying wheat from major regions and plans to increase its purchases, following a sharp expansion of its budget to stockpile grains and edible oils. This move aims to secure supply and achieve "absolute self-sufficiency" in staple grains, as China's biggest grain importer this year sharply expanded its budget.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Agriculture’s Foreign Agricultural Service predicts India wheat imports at 2 million tonnes in the season that began on Apr 1 on steady local demand.
Many Chinese consumers remain concerned about the safety of GM food crops.
The US government has reported the cancellation of more than 500,000 tonnes of US wheat exports to China since last week.

site_title: Bank of Canada cuts rates for first time in four years
summary: The Bank of Canada has cut its key policy rate by 25 basis points to 4.75%, its first rate cut in four years, citing increasingly positive indicators of underlying inflation. Governor Tiff Macklem said more easing is likely if inflation continues to ease, with the bank aiming to reach its 2% target. The move follows similar rate cuts by Sweden's Riksbank and the Swiss National Bank, and is expected to boost economic growth and alleviate burden on households and businesses.

images.alt_text: Bank of Nova Scotia is the next Big Six bank to report results on Tuesday before North American markets open.

site_title: China plans new carbon measurement standards to boost climate efforts
summary: China plans to introduce a new "carbon footprint management system" in 2027, tracking carbon emissions for 100 key products, aiming to boost climate efforts and avoid trade tensions. The system will initially apply to high-emitting products like coal and steel, with plans to expand to 200 products by 2030. Analysts see the move as a step towards reducing emissions associated with product manufacturing and potentially launching China's own low-carbon rules, which could mitigate the impact of the EU's carbon border tax.

images.alt_text: Peaking emissions is a key milestone on the road to net zero, which China has pledged to hit by 2060.
The plan said China would “strictly” control coal consumption, “reasonably” control petroleum consumption and promote use of biofuel and sustainable aviation fuel.

COFCO has a 2025 target for a zero-deforestation soybean supply chain in ecologically sensitive areas in Latin America, including the Amazon, and has plans for sustainable palm oil and coffee supply chains.

site_title: McDonald’s chicken ‘Big Mac’ trademark axed in EU
summary: McDonald's lost EU trademark rights to its "Big Mac" chicken burgers after the General Court in Luxembourg ruled that the fast food giant failed to demonstrate continuous use of the label for five years. The ruling, which protects the traditional beef Big Mac, was sparked by a challenge from Irish rival Supermac's, which claimed McDonald's did not put the trademark into "genuine use" in the EU. The decision can still be appealed, but Supermac's managing director Pat McDonagh called it a "significant victory for small businesses."

images.alt_text: An empty McDonalds outlet in Cairo.

The big restaurant company, which has enjoyed robust revenues as inflation drove customers to the chain, still achieved sales increases, but not as big as inflation has moderated. Global comparable sales grew 3.4 percent in fourth quarter, down from 8.8 percent in the third quarter and below the annual average. McDonald's reported its Q4 US sales growth at 4.3%, under the 4.45% increase Wall Street anticipated. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP)

site_title: Etihad Airways forms joint venture with China Eastern to boost growth
summary: Etihad Airways has formed a joint venture with China Eastern Airlines, allowing the airlines to coordinate flights and share revenues on selected routes without equity investment or cost-sharing. The partnership, set to begin in 2025, aims to boost growth and increase travel options for customers between the Middle East and China. Etihad's CEO, Antonoaldo Neves, sees the joint venture as a way to "leapfrog the development of airlines in the region" and capitalize on the surge in air travel since the pandemic.

site_title: NXP, Vanguard to invest US$7.8 billion in Singapore wafer plant
summary: NXP Semiconductors and Vanguard International Semiconductor Corp have announced a US$7.8 billion joint venture to produce silicon wafers in Singapore, with construction set to begin in 2024. Vanguard will invest US$2.4 billion for a 60% stake, while NXP will invest US$1.6 billion and hold 40%. The plant, expected to start production in 2027, will produce 55,000 300 mm wafers per month and supply proportional capacity to its partners, mainly for legacy chips used in vehicles and consumer electronics.

site_title: ‘Modi premium’ in India’s financial markets set to erode after weak victory
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi secured a third term in government, but without a majority of his own. The outcome has led to a weakened mandate for business-friendly reforms, causing investors to reassess their exposure to the country's markets. The rupee plummeted to a seven-week low, and stocks fell, while bonds weakened due to concerns about increased welfare spending. The election result is seen as a mixed signal for investors, with some viewing it as a buying opportunity while others are cautious due to the uncertainty.

site_title: NBA nears rights deal worth US$76 billion with NBC, ESPN and Amazon: WSJ
summary: The National Basketball Association (NBA) is nearing a $76 billion media rights deal with NBC, ESPN, and Amazon over 11 years. NBC would pay $2.5 billion annually, while Amazon would pay $1.8 billion annually. Disney's package would average $2.6 billion annually, including fewer NBA Finals games. The deal would leave out Warner Bros Discovery's Turner Sports network, which has shown NBA games for decades, due to its heavy debt load. The NBA can still create a new package for Warner Bros Discovery, but options are limited.

site_title: Elliott pushes SoftBank to buy back shares after taking stake
summary: Elliott Management, a US activist investor, has taken a stake in SoftBank Group and is pushing the Japanese investment firm to launch a $15 billion buyback. This is the second time Elliott has targeted SoftBank, following a previous stake in 2020. Elliott believes a large buyback would signal SoftBank's founder Masayoshi Son's confidence in the company. SoftBank's shares rose 4.6% after the news, and analysts say the company may not conduct buybacks due to its growing cash pile and plans for investments in AI and semiconductors.

site_title: Indian voters have finally woken up
summary: India's election results have dealt a significant blow to Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Hindu nationalist agenda, with his BJP party securing a reduced majority. Modi's party won 240 seats, short of a simple majority, and will likely remain in power, but with a diminished mandate. The opposition Indian National Developmental Inclusive Alliance (INDIA) alliance nearly equalled the BJP's tally, indicating a shift in voter sentiment. Modi's government has faced criticism for its handling of economic issues and its treatment of minorities, and his victory may mark a turning point in the country's democratic trajectory.

summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday, with Indian stocks rising 3.1% after a key ally pledged support for Prime Minister Modi. Indonesian rupiah hit a four-year low due to market volatility. The Singapore Stock Index (STI) fell 0.1% at the open. Despite a rise in US jobs data, market fears tempered optimism, leading to mixed reactions across Asia.

site_title: Toronto area home sales fall for fourth consecutive month in May
summary: Toronto area home sales declined 1.8% seasonally in May, marking the fourth consecutive month of decline, according to Toronto Regional Real Estate Board data. Average home prices rose 0.3% to C$1.11 million, while new listings increased 2.6%. Home sales fell 21.7% year-over-year, and the average selling price decreased 2.5%. The decline is attributed to home buyers waiting for the Bank of Canada to lower borrowing costs, with a potential 25 basis point rate cut expected in the upcoming decision.

images.alt_text: Canada currently faces a housing affordability crisis with a growing population that is outpacing the number of available homes, increasing home prices and rents.

site_title: Country Garden’s home sales slump persists as aid fails to help
summary: Country Garden Holdings' home sales plummeted 76% in May, reaching 4.3 billion yuan, compared to the previous year. This follows an 83% slide in April. The sales drought may worsen the company's cash crunch, which has been exacerbated by a missed deadline for reporting annual results and a creditor's petition to wind up the company. Despite China's central government's rescue package, loosening home-buying rules in major cities may not help Country Garden, as it targets smaller cities to avoid onerous property curbs.

site_title: Japan's birth rate 'critical' as it hits record low
summary: Japan's birth rate has hit a record low for the eighth consecutive year, standing at 1.20 children per woman, well below the 2.1 needed to maintain the population. Economic instability and work-life balance issues are cited as major factors. The government has approved revisions to laws to provide financial support for parents, improved childcare services, and expanded parental leave benefits. A new dating app requiring proof of singleness and income will also be launched to encourage marriage.

images.alt_text: Egg freezing typically run from around 300,000 to 600,000 yen but can reach into the millions.

site_title: South-east Asia on the radar as global supply chains make big shift
summary: South-east Asia's six major economies saw a 5.5% surge in foreign direct investment (FDI) to a record US$224 billion in 2022, driven by China+1 diversification strategies amid geopolitical tensions and pandemic-related disruptions. Singapore accounted for over 60% of FDI in the region, while the US, Japan, and China were the top investors, with the US leading with US$37 billion. The region's share of global FDI rose to over 17% in 2022, surpassing China for the second consecutive year.

site_title: Online car portal Motorist’s cross-country rally takes it to Japan next; target is 9 overseas markets by 2026
summary: Motorist, a Singaporean car portal, plans to expand its presence to 10 overseas markets by 2026, doubling its current 4 markets. The company aims to increase revenue from overseas markets to 40% by 2026, with a focus on Japan, Taiwan, South Korea, Australia, and Indonesia. Motorist's core business is car auctions, which generates 60-65% of its revenue, and the company expects 15-50% growth in auction business across markets. With a valuation of US$60 million after a recent funding round, Motorist is also considering a listing or acquisition in the future.

site_title: nTan forms alliance with Indonesia’s AJCapital for corporate restructurings
summary: nTan Corporate Advisory has formed an alliance with Jakarta-based AJCapital Advisory, known as 9 Capital, to specialise in corporate restructurings. The alliance will advise Indonesian garment manufacturer Pan Brothers, which is in technical default on its debt after missing payments, on restructuring its debts and operations. 9 Capital combines the expertise of AJCapital and nTan Corporate Advisory, who have experience in special situation transactions and complex corporate restructurings, including notable cases in the Asean region.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 5)
summary: Singapore's retail sales fell 1.2% year on year in April, missing private-sector economists' estimates of 1.9% growth. This reversal follows a 2.8% growth in the previous month. COE premiums dropped across all categories in June's first round of bidding, with the mainstream car category experiencing the largest drop in 2024. Meanwhile, companies in Greater China are expanding into ASEAN, with OCBC aiming to capture rising investment flows.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher as rate-cut hopes increase
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday as investors increased bets on earlier interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve, driven by economic reports showing a weakening labor market and slowing economic growth. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 63.53 points, or 0.16%, to 38,774.82, while the S&P 500 opened higher by 23.14 points, or 0.44%, at 5,314.48. The Nasdaq Composite also gained 117.43 points, or 0.70%, to 16,974.48.

site_title: Indonesia aims to draw single family offices to holiday island Bali
summary: Indonesia aims to attract single family offices (SFOs) to the holiday island of Bali, seeking to replicate Singapore's wealth management success. Indonesia's chief investment minister, Luhut Pandjaitan, said rich families have approached him to ask if Jakarta can adopt a common law system in Bali, a move seen as a step towards attracting high-net-worth individuals. The goal is to establish a hub for wealth management, following Singapore's model.

“The intention is to provide an incentive to those who lend. If we cut the RRR, it will give liquidity to banks, but they may not channel that towards credit,” Bank Indonesia deputy governor Juda Agung said.

site_title: Dramatic rise in geopolitical risk in focus at HK wealth forum
summary: India's surprise election result, with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's party losing its majority in parliament, has triggered market slumps and heightened geopolitical risks. This is the latest in a series of key elections worldwide, including Mexico, South Africa, and the US. Investors are concerned about the potential impact of these elections on global markets, with many ranking geopolitics as the biggest risk over the next 12 months. Despite this, some businesses are benefiting from geopolitical tensions, with South-east Asia attracting capital diverted from the US or China.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Mexico's presidential candidate for Morena party Claudia Sheinbaum celebrates following the results of the general election in Mexico City, on June 3, 2024. Claudia Sheinbaum was set to be elected Mexico's first woman president, exit polls showed, a milestone in a country with a history of gender-based violence. (Photo by Gerardo Luna / AFP)

FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi looks on after speaking with media inside the parliament premises upon his arrival on the first day of the budget session in New Delhi, India, January 31, 2024. REUTERS/Altaf Hussain//File Photo/File Photo

All 10 Adani Group shares plummeted on Tuesday (Jun 4) after the Modi-led political alliance failed to deliver the landslide electoral victory predicted by exit polls, wiping out almost US$45 billion in group market value.

(FILES) India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi (L), leader of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), holds the party symbol during a road show at an election campaign held ahead of the country's upcoming general elections, in Chennai on April 9, 2024. Once shunned and now eagerly courted by the West, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has steered India away from its secular traditions and towards the muscular Hindu-first politics he championed for decades. He is consistently ranked among the world's most popular leaders, and is roundly expected to coast to a third term after a marathon national election starting April 19. (Photo by R. Satish BABU / AFP)

President of China Xi Jinping and South African President Cyril Ramaphosa at the China-Africa Leaders' Roundtable Dialogue on the last day of the Brics Summit, in Johannesburg, South Africa, Aug  24, 2023.

The warmest weather the earth has experienced was 2023. Addressing global warming is not only a human imperative but also a financial one.

A Ukrainian serviceman of the attack drones battalion of the Achilles, 92nd brigade carries a first-person view (FPV) drone before it flies, near a Russian border in a Kharkiv region, Ukraine May 15, 2024. REUTERS/Inna Varenytsia
