site_title: Doubling down on improving water resilience
summary: The world is facing a growing water crisis due to climate change, with extreme weather events affecting millions of people. To address this, innovators are doubling down on efforts to improve water resilience through technology, local adaptation, and collaboration. Examples include on-demand water supply systems, solar pumps, and real-time data analysis for flood control. A global partnership, such as the 2030 Water Resources Group, is also working to secure funding and improve water governance. By doubling down on innovation, adaptation, and collaboration, it's possible to transform challenges into opportunities for progress and create a more water-secure future.

site_title: Indian carmaker Tata Motors' finance unit to merge with Tata Capital
summary: Tata Motors' finance unit is set to merge with Tata Capital in a share swap deal, aligning with the company's objective of exiting non-core businesses. Shareholders of Tata Motors Finance will receive 37 Tata Capital shares for every 100 shares held. The merged entity will offer vehicle loans, home and education loans, and Tata Motors will hold a 4.7% stake in the company. This move comes as part of Tata Motors' plan to split into two listed companies, separating its commercial and passenger vehicle businesses.

site_title: HSBC bolsters Saudi Arabia investment banking team to tap deals boom
summary: HSBC has bolstered its investment banking team in Saudi Arabia with the appointment of Mehdi Benabdallah as head of mergers and acquisitions and Ramez Halazun as head of equity capital markets. The move comes as Saudi Arabia embarks on a multi-trillion-dollar plan to diversify away from oil, attracting investment banks to pursue deals in the kingdom. HSBC is a joint global coordinator for the US$12 billion secondary share sale in oil giant Aramco, one of the largest equity offerings in recent years.

images.alt_text: Wong Kee Joo (left), CEO for HSBC Singapore, and Ashmita Acharya (right), head of wealth and personal banking at HSBC Singapore.
HSBC is known for its wealth prowess across Asia, but it’s long lagged Swiss rivals such as UBS Group in the Middle East.
The logo of Expobank is seen on a building in Prague, Czech Republic, September 8, 2017.   REUTERS/David W Cerny/Files

site_title: Emerging tech is making green buildings and sustainable construction more viable
summary: Emerging technologies are making green buildings and sustainable construction more economically viable, with developers, landlords, and tenants willing to pay premiums for environmentally friendly features. Advances in construction methods and materials science are reducing construction costs and waste, while digital solutions improve environmental data tracking. Regional governments are pushing for better disclosures and environmental, social, and governance (ESG) reporting, driving demand for sustainable features. Banking solutions, such as UOB's Transition Finance Framework and U-Build program, support companies in decarbonizing their operations. Governments must foster an environment that supports innovation and technology development to maximize efficiency in buildings and materials, while also considering extreme weather resilience and biodiversity impacts.

images.alt_text: Greenery cascading from the facade of the Parkroyal on Pickering hotel located along Upper Pickering Street on 16 October 2020.
Melissa Moi, head of sustainable business at UOB
Jasper Wong, managing director and head of UOB's construction and infrastructure, sector solutions group

site_title: Volvo to issue world’s first EV battery passport ahead of EU rules
summary: Volvo is launching the world's first electric vehicle (EV) battery passport for its flagship EX90 SUV, ahead of EU regulations requiring the use of such passports starting in 2027. The passport tracks raw materials, components, recycled content, and carbon footprint of the battery. Developed in partnership with UK startup Circulor, the system uses blockchain technology to map supply chains. Volvo aims to be transparent with car buyers and is targeting a fully-electric lineup by 2030. The passport will be rolled out to all EVs, with a simplified version available to owners and a more complete version for regulators.

images.alt_text: A sign outside a BYD Co. electric vehicle showroom, operated by Schiller Auto, in Budapest, Hungary, on Monday, May 27, 2024. Chinese EV giant BYD plans to set up its first European car plant in Hungary. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg
Mo Batteries’ withdrawal raises questions about whether swappable batteries are still viable in Singapore in light of other EV charging solutions, which are springing up across the country.

A male worker cleans a Volvo logo as it sits on a sign at the Volvo Cars display stand, ahead of the 85th Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday, March 2, 2015. The International Geneva Motor Show opens to the public on Mar. 5, and will showcase the latest models from the world's top automakers. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg

A male worker cleans a Volvo logo as it sits on a sign at the Volvo Cars display stand, ahead of the 85th Geneva International Motor Show in Geneva, Switzerland, on Monday, March 2, 2015. The International Geneva Motor Show opens to the public on Mar. 5, and will showcase the latest models from the world's top automakers. Photographer: Matthew Lloyd/Bloomberg

site_title: Alibaba considering convertible bond sale, following JD.com
summary: Alibaba is considering selling convertible bonds to raise approximately $5 billion, following JD.com's $1.75 billion offering. The move aims to fund share repurchases and growth, as the company faces market share losses in e-commerce and cloud businesses due to Chinese authorities' crackdown and internal turmoil. This comes as Alibaba's Hong Kong-listed shares dropped 6.6% and the company has expanded its share buyback program to $25 billion.

images.alt_text: The development comes as state-owned Poly has yet to conduct a private placement of shares for which it announced a plan in December 2022.
Alibaba sold US$4.5 billion in debt that can be turned into equity last week, a record for convertibles denominated in dollars by an Asian company.

site_title: United Airlines cuts hiring plans for 2024 due to Boeing delays
summary: United Airlines has cut its hiring plans for 2024 due to Boeing delays, with the airline now expecting to hire around 10,000 new employees instead of 13,000-15,000 previously planned. The company has added 4,000 new team members since January, including 800 pilots and 600 flight attendants, but has been forced to pause pilot hiring and offer unpaid leave to deal with excess staffing. Boeing's safety crisis has resulted in a 25% reduction in aircraft delivery estimates for this year.

images.alt_text: Possible penalties to Boeing may include fines, forfeiture, restitution, and a federally appointed monitor.
Until the Alaska Airlines incident, Boeing appeared poised to exit a period of financial hardship following the MAX crashes and the Covid-19 downturn.
United Airlines was impacted more than rivals by the MAX 9 grounding, which followed a January emergency landing of an Alaska Airlines flight after a panel on the fuselage blew out midair.

site_title: US: Wall Street edges lower as growth worries resurface
summary: US stocks edged lower on Tuesday as concerns about the health of the world's largest economy resurfaced. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 52.17 points, or 0.14%, to 38,518.86, while the S&P 500 dropped 5.16 points, or 0.10%, to 5,278.24. Investors await key economic data this week for clues on growth slowdown.

site_title: India's BJP concedes defeat in Ayodhya, where Modi opened grand Ram temple
summary: The ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) conceded defeat in the Faizabad constituency in Ayodhya, Uttar Pradesh, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi inaugurated the grand Ram temple in January. The BJP's incumbent lawmaker, Lallu Singh, acknowledged the party's shortcomings, while opposition parties, Samajwadi Party and Congress, are ahead in more than half of the state's 80 seats. The results suggest that voters were swayed by issues of unemployment and high inflation, rather than the temple's inauguration, which was seen as a key campaign promise.

images.alt_text: The prime minister strode into the inner sanctuary and performed a series of rituals before a newly minted idol of the Hindu god Ram.

site_title: Microsoft takes its AI push to customer service call centres
summary: Microsoft is introducing AI-powered tools for customer service call centers, leveraging its Copilot technology to improve chatbots and streamline tasks for human agents. The new software aims to reduce "toil and drudgery" by automating tasks and providing natural language navigation. The tools will be available on July 1 and are expected to compete with rivals like Salesforce.com and Zoom, with Microsoft hoping to gain ground in the customer service market. The goal is to improve the customer experience and reduce the workload for human agents.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Microsoft logo is seen at the Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona, Spain February 27, 2024. REUTERS/Bruna Casas/File Photo

site_title: British Airways to hire 350 staff to avoid Heathrow summer chaos
summary: British Airways plans to hire 350 staff at London's Heathrow Airport to minimize disruption in the peak summer season, which is expected to be its busiest since the pandemic. The airline aims to improve its on-time performance and upgrade its technology, but the IT system upgrade won't be fully rolled out by summer. The new staff will fill customer service and ground handling roles to ensure smooth operations. This move comes after the airline laid off thousands of staff during the pandemic and struggled with IT issues in the past.

site_title: HSBC to open 3 wealth centres in Singapore by Q1 2025 as part of pivot to wealth banking
summary: HSBC plans to open three wealth centres in Singapore by Q1 2025, as part of its strategy to pivot its branches into wealth centres to facilitate comprehensive wealth conversations with clients. The bank aims to increase client-facing roles by more than a third by 2028 to sustain growth momentum. The wealth centres will focus on client conversations and events, with a more personalized approach. HSBC also plans to expand its offerings across its whole wealth continuum, including mass market, affluent, high net worth, and ultra high net worth individuals.

images.alt_text: HSBC is known for its wealth prowess across Asia, but it’s long lagged Swiss rivals such as UBS Group in the Middle East.

“Today’s bank may not be identical to tomorrow’s, but banks like HSBC have ridden through multiple different cycles, so there is no reason why we cannot navigate what’s out there,” said Ashmita Acharya, head of wealth and personal banking for Singapore at HSBC.
In his new role at HSBC, Gilbert Ng drives the global banking strategy and franchise growth.

HSBC bank group chairman Mark Tucker’s comments hint at a likely shift in direction for new CEO, as the bank turns its focus away from shrinking its global empire to trying to grow its business in its remaining markets.
HSBC's pretax profit came in at US$12.7 billion for the quarter ended March versus US$12.9 billion a year earlier.

site_title: US job openings fall more than expected in April
summary: US job openings fell 296,000 to 8.059 million in April, the lowest level since February 2021. This drop is a sign of softening labour market conditions, which could aid the Federal Reserve's fight against inflation. Economists had forecast 8.355 million job openings, and the number of people quitting jobs rose 98,000 to 3.507 million. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep its policy rate at 5.25-5.5% until data shows inflation is headed back down to its 2% goal.

images.alt_text: The factory sector has been under pressure for well over a year, with ISM’s measure of output in contraction now for 18 of the past 19 months, as high interest rates curbed demand for goods.

CHICAGO, ILLINOIS - FEBRUARY 13: Customers shop at a grocery store on February 13, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois. Grocery prices are up 0.4% from December and 1.2% over the last year, the slowest annual increase since June 2021.   Scott Olson/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SCOTT OLSON / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The downgrade of first-quarter growth followed recent softness in readings of retail sales and equipment spending.
Across the United States, economic activity remained positive from early April to mid-May but conditions varied across industries and districts, the Fed report said.

site_title: Chinese security firm Nuctech challenges EU raids over alleged subsidies
summary: Chinese security firm Nuctech has challenged European Union raids on its Dutch and Polish offices, alleging no evidence supports claims it received illegal state subsidies. Nuctech, which makes body and luggage scanners, denied EU allegations and appealed to the Luxembourg-based General Court. The European Commission, which launched four investigations against Chinese companies under the FSR, said it respects companies' right to appeal and will defend its decisions in court. A ruling could take several years.

images.alt_text: China has repeatedly rebuked the EU for its probe.
Great Wall Motors reportedly sold about 6,300 cars in Europe in 2023, excluding Russia, accounting for about 2 per cent of its overall exports.
The EU has opened a barrage of trade probes against Beijing on the grounds of anti-dumping and unfair subsidies, especially in the clean-technology sector.
The Commission can impose provisional anti-subsidy duties nine months after the start of the probe.
European firms are feeling the pinch with the number of companies reporting revenue increases also at its lowest on record, the chamber says.

site_title: Global Invacom, Keong Hong, Green Build Technology added to SGX watch list
summary: Three Singapore-listed companies, Global Invacom, Keong Hong, and Green Build Technology, have been added to the watch list by the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) due to consecutive pre-tax losses and failing to maintain a minimum market capitalization of S$40 million. The companies have 36 months to restore their financial health and improve their market valuation.

site_title: US dollar regains footing after sharp drop but yen keeps rallying
summary: The US dollar regained ground after a sharp drop, rising 0.27% to 104.32, its lowest since mid-April. This comes as signs of a softening US economy boost the case for earlier Federal Reserve interest rate cuts. Meanwhile, the yen continued its rally, increasing 0.6% for a second day, as Bank of Japan officials warn of close monitoring and a report suggests bond purchases could be reduced. The euro fell 0.4% to $1.0863, its lowest since March 21.

images.alt_text: Indonesian Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during the 10th ASEAN finance ministers and central bank governors meeting in Jakarta, Indonesia, August 25, 2023. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan
The dollar index, which measures the US currency against six others, was up 0.1 per cent at 104.67.
As the influence of Eid al-Fitr gradually diminishes, economists foresee Indonesia’s inflationary pressures continuing their downward trajectory in the months ahead.
Canadian one hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Qatar sovereign fund agrees to buy 10% stake in China asset manager: sources
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund, the Qatar Investment Authority (QIA), has agreed to buy a 10% stake in China Asset Management Co (ChinaAMC), China's second-largest mutual fund company, from investment firm Primavera Capital. The deal, valued at at least $490 million, is part of Qatar's efforts to deepen ties with China amid rising tensions with the West. The QIA's purchase would give it access to China's fast-growing mutual fund industry and underscores the country's increasing financial sector push.

images.alt_text: Firms including Mubadala Investment, Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) and China Investment Corp (CIC) are in talks to jointly invest in McDonald’s China operations as minority shareholders.
Qatar's sale of 361.7 million shares in Barclays is expected to raise £510 million.
The Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) purchase translates into a stake of 0.99 per cent in Reliance Retail Ventures “on a fully-diluted basis,” the Mumbai-based firm says.

site_title: SIA to establish commercial partnership with Riyadh Air
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Riyadh Air, a new airline set to operate in 2025. The partnership aims to boost passenger travel between Saudi Arabia and Singapore, offering more options, enhanced connectivity, and greater benefits to customers. SIA and Riyadh Air will explore interline connectivity, codeshare arrangements, and reciprocal benefits for frequent flyers, cargo services, and customer experience. The collaboration is seen as a precursor to a deeper, long-term strategic partnership.

images.alt_text: With SIA's new in-flight service protocol, cabin crew will have to be seated and strapped in whenever the seat-belt sign comes on.
SIA flexed its muscles when it overcame the pandemic challenges and became the first off the blocks to capture pent-up travel demand after borders reopened and rewarded shareholders and staff alike.
Turbulence can occur when a plane hits a strong air current that pushes or pulls the airframe.
The incident on Flight SQ321 is SIA’s first fatal aviation accident since 2000.

The interior of Singapore Airlines flight SQ321 is pictured after an emergency landing at Bangkok's Suvarnabhumi International Airport, Thailand, May 21, 2024. REUTERS/Stringer REFILE – CORRECTING FLIGHT NUMBER FROM "SG321" TO "SQ321".

site_title: Singapore stocks end lower with Asia markets mixed; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) retreated 0.3% to 3,338.94, with the broader market seeing 281 losers and 272 gainers. Most Asian indices closed lower, except for Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index, which gained 0.2%. ST Engineering led the decline, dropping 2.4%, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also fell. However, airport services provider SATS rose 2.1% after posting a second-half profit.

images.alt_text: The broader Nifty index ended up 3.25 per cent at 23,263.90 points after touching a record high of 23,338.70 in opening deals. The BSE index closed up 3.39 per cent at 76,468.78 points, just off its lifetime peak of 76,738.89 hit earlier.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 4)
summary: A survey by NUS found that nearly 2 in 3 property executives see traditional office space as relevant, with co-working spaces playing a complementary role rather than replacing it. The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS) and IATA plan to launch a sustainable aviation fuel registry in 2025. Singapore Airlines (SIA) will establish a commercial partnership with Riyadh Air, exploring interline connectivity and potential co-operation. The Economic Development Authority (EMA) launched a request for proposal for new generation capacity, inviting private sector companies to build and operate hydrogen-ready power plants.

site_title: World falling short on 2030 renewables goal: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warns that nations are falling short of the goal to triple renewable energy capacity by 2030, which is crucial to transitioning away from fossil fuels and limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. The IEA estimates that countries could reach 8,000 gigawatts of renewable power capacity in six years, short of the 11,000 GW pledged at the COP28 climate talks in Dubai. This shortfall is a concern for meeting the global warming goal and transitioning to cleaner energy sources.

images.alt_text: Poor industrial activity and another mild winter have sapped gasoil consumption this year, particularly in Europe where a declining share of diesel cars were already undercutting consumption, the IEA said.
IEA says that demand growth in 2025 will edge down to 1.1 million bpd, with global GDP growth forecast to remain steady and electric vehicle expansion expected to gather pace.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, June 4, 2024 (Ep 74)
summary: Asian stocks fell after weak US manufacturing data, with Indian stocks and the rupee also declining after early election results suggested a narrow victory for Modi. Bank Indonesia lowered reserve requirements for key sectors to raise liquidity, providing some relief.

images.alt_text: Singapore equities began trading in negative territory on Tuesday.
Asia stumbled, with Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Wellington all in negative territory.

The broader Nifty index ended up 3.25 per cent at 23,263.90 points after touching a record high of 23,338.70 in opening deals. The BSE index closed up 3.39 per cent at 76,468.78 points, just off its lifetime peak of 76,738.89 hit earlier.

site_title: Investors take a golden backstop
summary: China, Russia, and India are rapidly stockpiling gold to increase control over assets and reduce currency vulnerability, raising concerns about a potential crisis. Since 2020, gold prices have traded in a sideways band between US$1,700 and US$2,130, with the Reserve Bank of India purchasing 24 tonnes of gold in four months, exceeding its 2023 total. The rapid accumulation of gold suggests geopolitical fears, particularly for assets in previously safe havens, and investors are establishing fortified lines of defense.

images.alt_text: While gold is often considered a safeguard against inflation, higher rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.
A smaller working-age labour force and geopolitical tensions support the case for structurally higher inflation, and for interest rates to remain higher for longer.

site_title: Germany to sell 2.5 billion euros in Deutsche Telekom shares
summary: Germany sold a 2.5 billion euros stake in Deutsche Telekom, the country's largest telecommunications company, to strengthen Deutsche Bahn's equity and build out its rail infrastructure. The sale, facilitated by state-owned bank KfW, brings the government's combined holding to 27.8%. The net proceeds will be used to bolster Deutsche Bahn's equity and upgrade Germany's rail network. The move is part of the government's "responsible privatisation policy" to raise cash for budget negotiations and modernize the economy.

images.alt_text: Telekom’s MagentaTV, which will be streaming all Euro 2024 soccer games as its official partner, increased its customer base by 73,000 to 4.4 million, supporting revenues in the company’s German operating segment.

site_title: Myanmar’s shadow government flags deepening economic turmoil
summary: Myanmar's military regime is facing deepening economic turmoil, with the kyat plummeting 70% against the dollar since 2021, foreign-currency reserves at $3.8 billion or lower, and inflation at double digits. The regime has resorted to printing money to finance defense operations, spurring inflation. Remittances from nationals working overseas have declined by 50% and a possible full sanction by the Financial Action Task Force may further pressure the junta's finances. The economic crisis is partly driving the collapse in the exchange rate and inflation rates, with 70% of the budget deficit financed by money printing.

images.alt_text: Soldiers from 8th Battalion of the Karenni Nationalities Defence Force, an armed insurgent group, during their graduation ceremony, in Karenni State, Myanmar, Feb 1, 2024. Myanmar's junta has suspended the issuing of permits for men to work abroad.
Myanmar is in the throes of an insurgency on multiple fronts, with allied anti-junta groups backed by a pro-democracy parallel government seizing control of several military posts and towns.

site_title: Thailand plans Bill to legalise casinos
summary: Thailand plans to legalize casinos as part of large entertainment zones, aiming to generate 12 billion baht (S$442.2 million) in tax revenue in the first year. The move follows a study by lawmakers that favored setting up legal casinos to attract high-spending tourists. This comes after Thailand's recent liberalization of laws, including decriminalizing cannabis and allowing same-sex marriages. The country is not the first to consider competing in the global casino industry, with the UAE also setting up a framework for legalized gaming.

images.alt_text: casino theme, poker game, aces

site_title: Thaksin will defend his case, won’t flee this time, Thai PM says
summary: Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra will defend himself against a royal defamation charge, despite the risk of a lengthy jail term. The charges stem from an interview Thaksin gave in Seoul in 2015 that prosecutors deemed breached Thailand's lèse-majesté law. Thaksin, currently on parole, has stated he will not flee the country this time, saying he is "ready to fight" and will stay in Thailand to face the indictment on June 18.

site_title: The case for structurally higher inflation – and its impact on rates and portfolios
summary: The global economy is shifting away from globalization, leading to a decline in cross-border capital flows and a flattening in global trade to production. This shift, combined with a smaller working-age labor force and geopolitical tensions, supports the case for structurally higher inflation and potentially higher interest rates for longer. Policymakers are more willing to tolerate inflation overshoots due to crushing public-sector debt burdens, and the temptation to inflate away excessive debt levels will always be present. Investors must focus on catching long-term structural shifts in economic trends to shape strategic asset allocation and portfolio returns.

images.alt_text: By embarking on a new cycle of interest-rate cuts now, the ECB appears to be relying too heavily on flawed forecasts and ignoring economic and geopolitical realities.
Mark Haefele, CIO of UBS Global Wealth Management, said bond yields are now at attractive levels after central banks hiked rates to tame inflation.

site_title: Tesla’s China-made EV sales extend decline in May amid output cut
summary: Tesla's China-made EV sales declined 6.6% in May to 72,573 units, extending a year-on-year decline for a second month. This follows an 18% drop in April and a production cut at the Shanghai plant since March. Deliveries of Model 3 and Model Y vehicles rose 16.7% from April. Chinese rival BYD saw a 38.2% year-on-year increase in sales. Tesla aims to address weakening demand for its Model Y in China with the output cut.

site_title: German unemployment up more than expected, damping rebound hopes
summary: Germany's unemployment rose 25,000 in May, exceeding economists' expectations of a 7,000 gain. The unemployment rate remained at 5.9%, as the country recovers from an economic contraction at the end of 2023. Analysts expect growth to continue, driven by consumption rebounds and industry growth, but warn that the labour market's resilience means firms will prioritize existing employees over new hires. The strength of the labour market is seen as limiting potential recovery, with real wages expected to continue rising.

images.alt_text: The HCOB final Purchasing Managers’ Index (PMI) for German manufacturing rose to 45.4 in May from 42.5 in April, confirming a preliminary flash estimate and still below the 50 level that marks growth in activity.
FILE PHOTO: People carry their shopping bags in downtown Hamburg, Germany, January 25, 2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo
In Germany, cooling energy and food prices have had an easing effect on inflation this year – but core inflation, which excludes those more volatile elements, has remained high.
FILE PHOTO: People carry their shopping bags in downtown Hamburg, Germany, January 25, 2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: Meme stocks are back – but you shouldn’t chase them
summary: GameStop's stock price surged 74.4% after Keith Gill's return to social media, boosting other meme stocks like AMC and BlackBerry. However, the companies' weak fundamentals and high price-earnings ratios suggest the rally is irrational. Meme stocks, which gain hype through social media, often have strong disconnects between share prices and earnings. The GME token, a crypto meme token, plummeted 87.5% from its peak after the hype faded, highlighting the extreme volatility of these assets. Investors are advised to steer clear of momentum-chasing and focus on research and due diligence to avoid losses.

images.alt_text: GameStop shares are trading almost 68 per cent below their January 2021 peak.
GameStop says that its preliminary first-quarter net sales were between US$872 million and US$892 million.
FILE PHOTO: GameStop logo is seen in front of displayed Reddit logo in this illustration taken February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Intel battles AMD with new data centre chips
summary: Intel has launched its sixth-generation Xeon server processors, aiming to regain data centre market share from rival AMD. The new chips offer improved performance at lower power consumption, with the "efficiency" model requiring 67% fewer server racks. Intel's Gaudi 3 AI accelerator chips are priced at around $125,000, significantly lower than rivals AMD and Nvidia. This move is seen as a response to Intel's declining market share, now at 76.4%, down 5.6 percentage points from the past year.

images.alt_text: For decades, Intel made chips only for itself but over the past few years has poured billions into its foundry business as it seeks to bolster its manufacturing capabilities and produce more semiconductors as a contract manufacturer.
The chipmaker is reporting earnings for the first time under a new business structure that shows the financial performance of its manufacturing operations.
The chipmaker is reporting earnings for the first time under a new business structure that shows the financial performance of its manufacturing operations.

site_title: Dubai’s iconic mall expands to boost city’s allure for wealthy visitors
summary: Dubai's iconic Dubai Mall is set to expand with a 1.5 billion dirham (S$551 million) project, adding 240 new luxury retail and dining outlets. The expansion aims to boost the city's allure for wealthy visitors, following a 19% increase in visitor numbers to 105 million in 2023. The mall, which already boasts over 1,200 stores and 200 food outlets, will further solidify its position as the world's second-largest shopping mall. The expansion ties in with Dubai's efforts to attract more repeat visitors through new visa rules and increased airline capacity.

images.alt_text: Office towers in the Dubai International Financial Centre Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg
Ali Sajwani and his sister Amira plan to build 24 mansions, a beach club and two helipads along with dedicated berths for boats on a 1.2 million square feet island.

Nakheel was at the center of Dubai's debt crisis in 2009 that pushed the emirate to the brink of a default. After receiving support from the government, it now has billions of dirhams of projects and infrastructure development underway.
Built on the city’s outskirts, Al Maktoum airport has received a relatively small share of the Gulf financial hub’s air traffic since 2010.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees rupiah strengthening in 2025
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Perry Warjiyo, expects the rupiah to strengthen in 2025 due to a potential US Federal Reserve rate cut and returning capital inflow. The rupiah is forecast to trade between 15,300 and 15,700 per dollar this year, with a range of 15,700 to 16,100 per dollar expected in 2025. The central bank maintains its economic growth forecast of 4.8% to 5.6% for 2025 and keeps its inflation target at 1.5% to 3.5%.

images.alt_text: “The intention is to provide an incentive to those who lend. If we cut the RRR, it will give liquidity to banks, but they may not channel that towards credit,” Bank Indonesia deputy governor Juda Agung said.
As the influence of Eid al-Fitr gradually diminishes, economists foresee Indonesia’s inflationary pressures continuing their downward trajectory in the months ahead.

site_title: Australia’s Qantas back Boeing to bounce back from crisis
summary: Qantas has expressed support for Boeing's recovery, stating "aviation needs a strong Boeing," according to CEO Vanessa Hudson. Boeing is undergoing an overhaul after a crisis led to the departure of CEO Dave Calhoun by the end of the year. The airline is looking to a new CEO to address the issues, including a loose door plug on a Boeing plane in January. Qantas' backing comes amid scrutiny and criticism from major customers. The airline believes a strong Boeing is essential for the aviation industry.

images.alt_text: Boeing has also come under fire from regulators, lawmakers and airlines following a January accident in which a fuselage panel blew off a 737 Max mid-flight.
Qatar Airways currently has 74 outstanding orders for the Boeing 777X and 18 of the larger A350-1000s.
Possible penalties to Boeing may include fines, forfeiture, restitution, and a federally appointed monitor.
The two parties have long been at commercial loggerheads, including a years-long court battle over fees and capital costs under Qantas’ former CEO, Alan Joyce.
Qantas aircraft on the Shanghai route will be redirected to fly other destinations across Asia experiencing higher demand or where there are new tourism opportunities, the company said.

Demand for seats in the airline’s first, business and premium-economy class cabins is “stronger than ever,” Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson said at an investment conference hosted by Macquarie Group in Sydney on Wednesday.

site_title: Rio Tinto to develop US$143 million facility to test low-carbon iron-making process
summary: Rio Tinto plans to invest $143 million in a research and development facility in Western Australia to test its low-carbon iron-making process, BioIron. The process uses raw biomass and microwave energy to convert iron ore to metallic iron, reducing carbon emissions by up to 95% compared to traditional methods. The facility will include a pilot plant and is expected to be commissioned in 2026. This project demonstrates Rio Tinto's commitment to supporting the decarbonization of the steel industry.

site_title: Swiss financial regulator wants to be able to name and shame banks
summary: Switzerland's financial regulator Finma is seeking increased powers to name and shame banks that breach its rules, following criticism over its handling of Credit Suisse's collapse last year. Finma Chief Executive Stefan Walter stated that the publication of enforcement proceedings should be the norm, not the exception. This move aims to enhance transparency and accountability in the financial sector, with Finma seeking more authority to enforce its regulations.

images.alt_text: After the near-collapse of Credit Suisse over a year ago and its takeover by UBS Group, Switzerland is grappling with how to handle an outsized financial sector dominated by a behemoth bank.
The FSB is set to review its ranking of UBS among the list of global systemically important banks after the Credit Suisse takeover, which is due to close later this year.

site_title: Uncertainty looms over the future of Indonesia’s new capital after chief resigns
summary: Indonesia's new capital city project, Nusantara, has faced uncertainty after the sudden resignation of its head, Bambang Susantono. The project, aiming to complete its initial phase by August, has raised concerns among investors and observers, with some speculating that unattainable targets may have been set. President Joko Widodo has appointed a new acting head and deputy to maintain momentum, but the project's future remains uncertain, with economists warning that revoking its legal standing would be highly challenging. The project's completion is slated for 2045 and is estimated to cost 466 trillion rupiah.

images.alt_text: The project involves building and developing a large-scale integrated project involving 50 megawatts of solar capabilities and 14 megawatt-hour of battery energy storage in Nusantara, the future capital city of Indonesia.
Bambang Susantono, chairman of Indonesia Nusantara Capital Authority shows Indonesia's future capital Nusantara layout in a presentation.

site_title: Airbus in talks to sell more than 100 widebody jets to China
summary: Airbus is in talks to sell more than 100 A330neo aircraft to China's largest airlines, according to people familiar with the matter. The negotiations, which gained momentum after President Xi Jinping's visit to France, are confidential and the terms are still being discussed. This sale highlights the stark contrast between Airbus and Boeing in the Chinese aviation market, where geopolitical tensions between China and the US are high. The timing of the sale remains uncertain.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of Airbus is pictured outside the Airbus facility in Saint-Nazaire, France, November 7, 2023. REUTERS/Stephane Mahe/File Photo
Badr Mohammed al-Meer, CEO of Qatar Airways, speaks during a debate at the Qatar Economic Forum in Doha on May 15, 2024. (Photo by KARIM JAAFAR / AFP)

site_title: TSMC’s new chairman affirms hopes of AI-fuelled 2024 recovery
summary: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) Chairman C C Wei reaffirmed projections for a 10% chip market growth in 2024, driven by AI development. Wei's ascension signifies a changing of the guard at the company, which remains critical to the global AI boom and holds key partnerships with tech giants like Apple and Nvidia. TSMC is expanding production overseas, particularly in Arizona, but will prioritize adopting advanced technology in Taiwan before considering its adoption elsewhere.

images.alt_text: TSMC is the world’s biggest contract chipmaker and the centrality of the island to the semiconductor supply chain is seen as an essential element of its international security.
TSMC has estimated second-quarter sales may rise as much as 30 per cent as it rides a wave of demand for semiconductors used in AI applications.
ASML’s new machine can imprint semiconductors with lines that are just eight nanometres thick – 1.7 times smaller than the previous generation.

site_title: German construction industry outlook worsens: study
summary: Germany's construction industry is expected to shrink by 4% this year due to weakness in residential and public construction, leading to around 10,000 job losses. The only growth area is commercial construction, with a 1.5% increase in sales. Rising interest rates, inflation, and economic stagnation are contributing factors. The German Construction Industry Federation (HDB) is calling for increased construction activity to mitigate the decline.

site_title: Blind wagers on a bank risk transfer trade have never been so popular
summary: Synthetic risk transfers (SRTs) are gaining popularity as lenders seek capital relief, with demand reaching record highs. Banks are selling blind pools of loans, including to consumers and small businesses, to investors who collect quarterly payments. Despite the risks, buyers of blind pools are getting negligible premiums for the extra risk, with spreads tightening by at least 1.5 percentage points since 2022. Fund managers, such as PGGM, are using loss-based assumptions and ratings to manage risk, and some are excluding certain industries and borrowers from their portfolios. The trend is expected to continue, driven by the need for capital relief and the growth of the global economy.

images.alt_text: SRTs – also known as significant risk transfers – allow banks to buy protection on their loan portfolios in order to release regulatory capital or manage risk.
JPMorgan is in early discussions with investors for two SRTs that could total about US$2 billion in bonds combined.

site_title: Learn how to invest smartly from the experts at Mark to Market ‘Live’ 2024
summary: Veteran economist Song Seng Wun and other industry experts will discuss navigating the volatile global investment landscape at Mark to Market 'Live' 2024, a sold-out event on July 13. The forum, titled Smart Investing in Dynamic Times, will focus on strategies for protecting capital and discovering hidden gems during turbulent times. Panelists include Krishna Guha, Gerald Wong, and Ben Paul, who will provide expert guidance on how to diversify portfolios and thrive in today's dynamic market.

images.alt_text: (From left) Aaron Chwee, head of wealth advisory, OCBC Bank; Vijay Natarajan, vice-president, real estate and reits, RHB Bank Singapore; Terence Wong, chief executive officer, Azure Capital;  Ben Paul, senior correspondent, Business Times. Panellists discussed how investors should reposition their portfolios amid high inflation and aggressive interest rate hikes.

site_title: Modi celebrates victory in India vote, but falls short of landslide
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) secured a parliamentary majority, but fell short of a landslide victory, with a vote share of 36.7% compared to 2019. The BJP needs to rely on its alliance partners due to failing to secure an overall majority on its own for the first time in a decade. The opposition Congress party nearly doubled its parliamentary seats, with Rahul Gandhi claiming "voters have punished the BJP." Modi vowed to continue fulfilling the aspirations of people, while Congress hailed it as a "moral defeat" for the ruling party.

images.alt_text: The broader Nifty index ended up 3.25 per cent at 23,263.90 points after touching a record high of 23,338.70 in opening deals. The BSE index closed up 3.39 per cent at 76,468.78 points, just off its lifetime peak of 76,738.89 hit earlier.

site_title: ECB rate-cut expectations start to unravel before first move
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to lower interest rates this week, but economists and traders are scaling back expectations for consecutive rate cuts due to sticky inflation, rapid wage growth, and robust eurozone output. The ECB's cautious approach aims to avoid a policy mistake, as policymakers fear that lowering borrowing costs too aggressively could prompt markets to take a more aggressive pace. Despite the initial rate cut, economists predict fewer moves this year, with some foreseeing only two cuts by year-end, and markets have largely ruled out a July cut.

images.alt_text: The pan-European Stoxx 600 ended 0.3 per cent higher on the first session of June.
The costs of construction has risen; and to cover the increase, investors are demanding rents in excess of 20 euros (S$29.30) per square metre.

site_title: Malaysia to reform pension system to ensure ‘no one is left behind’: PM Anwar
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim announced plans to reform the country's pension system to ensure "no one is left behind." One in four Employees Provident Fund (EPF) members exhaust their savings within five years after retirement. To address this, expanding the EPF's coverage to include more working-age individuals could help accumulate adequate retirement savings. The reform aims to provide a dignified retirement for all citizens, regardless of their socio-economic background.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund CEO Ahmad Zulqarnain Onn said the latest dividend payout of 5.5 per cent for the conventional savings account in 2023 was higher than 5.35 per cent in previous year.
Economists said extending the retirement age may be an inevitable option for low income groups in Malaysia to rebuild their retirement savings.
Over the past five decades, Malaysia’s fertility rate has markedly decreased from 4.9 children per woman in 1970 to 1.6 children in 2022.

site_title: TikTok fails ‘disinformation test’ before EU vote, study shows
summary: TikTok failed to detect and prevent the approval of ads containing false information about the European Union elections, according to a study by Global Witness. The platform approved all 16 ads created by the group, despite violating its own guidelines. The ads included false information about voting age, poll violence, and contagious diseases. TikTok acknowledged the mistake, citing "human error," but insisted it has the systems in place to prevent such incidents in the future.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is in a close race with Democratic incumbent Joe Biden ahead of the Nov 5 presidential election.
TikTok declined to comment on the paused rollout plans and said the company is “guided by demand.”
TikTok has previously said it had no plans to sell the US assets and such a move would be impossible.

site_title: Thailand needs to fix credit access problems, central bank says
summary: Thailand's central bank has urged the government to address credit access problems for small and medium-sized businesses, citing structural issues that hinder the economy. SMEs account for over a third of the economy and 70% of jobs, yet only 50% of 3.2 million SMEs have access to loans. The government plans to provide 50 billion baht in credit guarantees, while the central bank favors structural reforms to increase productivity over rate cuts and fiscal stimulus. The central bank's deputy governor stated that the problems are urgent and require immediate attention.

images.alt_text: The Philippines recorded growth of 5.7 per cent in the first quarter of 2024 to occupy top spot in Asean.
Growth in the April-June quarter should be higher than the first quarter’s 1.5 per cent, which beat the BOT’s forecast.
Small modular reactors are advanced nuclear reactors with the capacity to generate around one-third of the electricity produced by traditional nuclear power reactors, according to the IAEA.
The BOT has said that easing monetary policy at this juncture may aggravate near-record household debt levels.

site_title: Behind bars: Belfast jail reborn as whiskey distillery
summary: A former Belfast prison, Crumlin Road Gaol, has been repurposed as a whiskey distillery after a £30 million investment. The 1846 prison, notorious for holding paramilitary prisoners during the Troubles, now produces McConnell's Whiskey, bringing distillation skills back to Belfast after a 1930s decline. The distillery, which provides jobs for over 30 people, complements the prison's history and attracts tourists to the area, drawing parallels between the prison's past and present.

images.alt_text: FILE — Visitors make their way through the Tower of Faces at the United States Holocaust Memorial in Washington, D.C., April 22, 2013. Students who visit Holocaust museums are bringing up antisemitic tropes and asking survivors and docents: What is Palestine? Is there a genocide in Gaza? (Drew Angerer/The New York Times)

site_title: Holocaust museums debate what to say about the Israel-Hamas war
summary: The US Holocaust museum community is grappling with how to discuss the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as the war has raised concerns about antisemitism and Holocaust comparisons. Many museums have historically focused on the Holocaust, but some now feel compelled to address the Nakba, or Palestinian displacement, and the complexities of Israel's founding. The debate centers on how to distinguish between legitimate criticism of Israel and antisemitism, with some museums walking a fine line between acknowledging the humanitarian crisis and avoiding accusations of bias.

images.alt_text: Gaza City's 17th century Qasr al-Basha or the Pasha's Palace, also known as Radwan dynasty castle, which houses a museum and a girls'school, damaged in Israeli bombardment during the ongoing battles between Israel and the Palestinian Hamas movement.

The display presents “the Gazan artistic scene in a new way”, which helps “to face the challenges and difficulties which artists and culture are confronting in Gaza amid the destruction and siege”, says board member Ehab Bessaiso.
The manuscript, which is believed to be more than 1,000 years old, is set to be sold at auction in New York for up to an estimated US$50 million.

site_title: Singapore hotel rates, other indicators fall in April from Taylor Swift-driven highs in March
summary: Singapore hotels experienced a decline in room rates and revenue in April, following the Taylor Swift concert-driven high in March. Average room rates fell 6.6% to S$279.44, while overall room revenue dropped 17.5% to S$404.9 million, the lowest year-to-date. Revenue per available room and average occupancy rates also declined, marking a year-to-date low.

images.alt_text: Indonesia, China, India, Malaysia and Australia are the top five sources of tourists to Singapore in April.
China remained as the top source of visitors, with Indonesia and Malaysia rounding up the top three.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CapitaLand Ascott Trust, iFast, Sabana Reit
summary: iFast Corporation is set to issue S$100 million of fixed-rate notes on June 11. The digital banking and wealth management platform priced its inaugural issue under its S$300 million multi-currency debt issuance programme. Meanwhile, CapitaLand Ascott Trust acquired a 10% stake in a South Carolina student accommodation property, expected to generate a 7% Ebitda yield. The stapled group's securities ended flat at S$0.895 on Monday.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation cools further as policy stays tight
summary: South Korea's inflation eased to 2.7% in May, beating expectations, as the Bank of Korea maintains its policy of keeping interest rates at 3.5%. The central bank expects inflation to reach its 2% target by the end of the year, despite economic growth picking up due to an export rally. Weakening oil prices and declining food prices contributed to the slowdown in inflation, while household debt remains a concern for the bank's decision-making.

images.alt_text: South Korea's president-elect Yoon Suk-yeol speaks during a news conference at the National Assembly in Seoul, South Korea, March 10, 2022.  REUTERS/Kim Hong-Ji/Pool
South Korea’s exports have been growing since October and provided the biggest boost to the trade-reliant economy’s first-quarter growth.

South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol speaks as Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (3rd left) and Chinese Premier Li Qiang (right) listen during a business summit at Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Seoul, South Korea, May 27, 2024.

site_title: Philippine central bank rejects rate-cut call that weakened peso
summary: The Philippine central bank, Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas, rejected a rate-cut call made by Finance Secretary Ralph Recto, describing it as "too aggressive." Recto had suggested a 150 basis point rate reduction to 2025, but Governor Eli Remolona said this would only be applicable if the economy hits a hard landing. The central bank cited the Philippine economy's growth trajectory, which remains among the region's fastest-growing, as a reason for its stance.

images.alt_text: Philippines Finance Minister Ralph Recto said it was possible for the central bank to start cutting rates this year, likely followed by more rate reductions in 2025.
The central bank is facing potential vacancies in its seven-member Monetary Board as the inquiry into the presence of the ghost employees nears completion.
A weak currency spells trouble for local consumers and businesses in the Philippines, especially since the country is a net importer.

site_title: Key features of China’s affordable housing policy
summary: Chinese policymakers have introduced a support package for the property sector, including local governments buying unsold apartments to create affordable housing. Cities with over 3 million people are expected to lead in developing affordable housing. The policy aims to reduce excess construction and boost domestic consumption by lowering household savings. Authorities hope the measures will improve access to affordable housing and mitigate the property market downturn.

images.alt_text: Outstanding PSL loans stood at 2.95 trillion yuan at the end of May, compared with 3.03 trillion yuan at end-April, says the People’s Bank of China.
In Shanghai, second-hand sales last weekend were 50 per cent higher than the daily average for the month.
Commercial and residential buildings stand in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 6, 2014. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The Chinese government's renewed housing policy focuses on building affordable homes and renovating run-down inner-city districts.

site_title: EMA launches second request for proposal for new generation capacity
summary: The Energy Market Authority (EMA) launched a second request for proposal for new generation capacity to meet growing electricity demand in Singapore. The two new hydrogen-ready combined cycle gas turbine generating units, expected to be ready in 2029 and 2030, will have a minimum generation capacity of 600 megawatts each. This move aims to ensure power system security and reliability, and align with EMA's goal of developing a "greener and more resilient power system" through a centralized process. The statutory board projects Singapore's peak demand to grow at least 3.7% over the next six years.

images.alt_text: The hydrogen-ready power plant is expected to be commissioned by end-2027.

site_title: China courts Spain to push EU on EV probe
summary: China has urged Spain to support the European Union in its probe into the country's electric vehicles sector, emphasizing the need for a fair and predictable development environment to combat climate change. China's commerce minister, Wang Wentao, stated that the EU's investigation is protectionist and has repeatedly rebuked the EU for its probe. The EU has postponed its decision on imposing tariffs until after the European Parliament election. China hopes Spain will encourage the EU to maintain an open attitude towards green and new energy cooperation.

images.alt_text: Great Wall Motors reportedly sold about 6,300 cars in Europe in 2023, excluding Russia, accounting for about 2 per cent of its overall exports.
The EU has opened a barrage of trade probes against Beijing on the grounds of anti-dumping and unfair subsidies, especially in the clean-technology sector.
This photograph taken on April 23, 2024, shows the European flag flying in front of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg eastern France. (Photo by FREDERICK FLORIN / AFP)
The Commission can impose provisional anti-subsidy duties nine months after the start of the probe.

site_title: CAAS, Iata to develop sustainable aviation fuel registry
summary: CAAS and Iata are developing a globally recognized sustainable aviation fuel registry, set to launch in Q1 2025. The platform will track and account for emission reductions from sustainable aviation fuel use, aligning with internationally recognized sustainability standards. The registry will enable accurate accounting and reporting of sustainable aviation fuel purchases, generation of credits, and allocation to airlines and businesses. This development supports Singapore's national sustainable aviation fuel target in 2026 and is part of a broader global effort to drive sustainable aviation fuel adoption.

images.alt_text: Iata director-general Willie Walsh says: "Our assessment is that it’s not getting worse but it’s not getting better either."
The steel industry in China accounts for 5% of GDP and 15% of emissions. Transition bonds could be a way for the country to raise funds to decarbonise the industry.
The plan said China would “strictly” control coal consumption, “reasonably” control petroleum consumption and promote use of biofuel and sustainable aviation fuel.
Global demand for biofuels is expected to grow 3 to 5 per cent per annum through 2050, with sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) and hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) projected to see the largest growth.

site_title: Fretful Chempaka residents and deals galore
summary: Singapore residents seeking a private home for life may need to pay more for a property with a long remaining land lease due to rising life expectancy. In Jalan Chempaka Puteh, 144 landed homes with 3,500 sq ft of land are available for under $1 million, but owners worry about lease extensions. Experts argue that extending land leases will be challenging due to differing opinions among multiple owners, making it essential for buyers to consider lease length and costs when making a purchase.

images.alt_text: The latest ABSD hikes have hammered the market in prime areas, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
It’s no secret that suburban malls are strongholds for retail landlords, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Perhaps transparency and efficiency in HDB resale flat sales will improve with the launch of the HDB Flat Portal.

With the government signalling it will release increasingly more supply into the housing market to curb rising prices and market measures eroding demand, developers are showing little appetite for big-ticket buys, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.
Current prices of Sentosa properties, which are located in the Core Central Region, lag behind those of homes in prime areas on the mainland, writes BT deputy news editor Michelle Low.

site_title: China sees property silver lining but can’t shake Japan comparisons
summary: China's new home construction fell 63% from its peak to 634 million square meters in the 12 months through April, fueling hopes the battered property sector is stabilizing. Analysts expect home-building activity to stabilize within a year, removing some weight on economic growth. However, a clean-up of bad assets remains elusive, keeping Japan-like stagnation fears alive, with prices still to fully adjust and negative financial spillovers continuing. China's pace in addressing the crisis is similar to Japan's, with analysts warning of a prolonged adjustment and potential for a cyclical rebound.

images.alt_text: Cities with more than three million people are expected to take the lead in developing affordable housing.
The pickup in sales has not been strong enough to ease a cash crunch at Vanke, which has been raising funds to calm investors’ concerns over its liquidity strains.

site_title: Brokers’ take: Analysts raise Sats price targets after strong earnings performance
summary: DBS and OCBC have raised their target prices for Sats, the in-flight caterer and ground handler, after the company reported a 10-fold jump in profit for the half-year ended March 31. DBS raised its price target to S$3.60 from S$3.40, citing an "attractive" risk-to-reward setup. Analysts expect Sats to benefit from strong global air travel demand, but also note that higher finance costs and tax expenses may offset near-term revenue growth. Both research houses continue to rate the stock at "buy".

images.alt_text: Post WFS acquisition, Sats has gained opportunities it wouldn't be able to seize says Kerry Mok, chief executive of Sats
Sats reports impressive earnings for both H2 and full year.
Tan says he is looking forward to Sats continuing its ESG efforts.

site_title: China Vanke’s sales slump eases as housing market picks up
summary: China Vanke's home sales value increased 11.5% in May, reaching 23.3 billion yuan, as the housing market sentiment improved. The company's sales dropped 29.3% from last year, narrowing for the third consecutive month. Despite this, Vanke's cash crunch persists, with the company raising funds and in talks with major banks for a 50 billion yuan loan. Analysts believe a fundamental recovery in sales is needed to improve Vanke's liquidity by 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sign of Vanke is seen outside of a construction site in Shanghai, China, March 21, 2017. Picture taken March 21, 2017. REUTERS/Aly Song/File Photo
China Vanke is working to raise funds after saying last month it is facing short-term liquidity pressure.
Vanke had been negotiating with insurers after it deferred payments twice since December 2023, when the lenders first asked for early payment.
The Shenzhen-based company is also applying for a one billion yuan loan from banks, to be guaranteed by real estate assets held by a fully owned subsidiary in the city,.

site_title: Star Wars show The Acolyte merges murder mystery with family drama
summary: The Star Wars series "The Acolyte" begins streaming on Disney+ on June 5, combining murder mystery with family drama. The eight-episode series stars Amandla Stenberg as Mae, a character with complicated family problems and a connection to the Force. The show takes place 100 years before "Star Wars: Episode 1 – The Phantom Menace" and follows Mae's investigation into her own murder, aided by a Jedi master and a former smuggler. The series explores themes of trauma, corruption, and the power of the Force, offering a unique take on the Star Wars universe.

images.alt_text: The Mandalorian & Grogu will be directed by Jon Favreau, who created the hit Disney+ streaming show The Mandalorian, in which Grogu was first introduced.

site_title: New York City gets 150,000 applications in 12 hours for affordable housing
summary: New York City received over 150,000 applications in 12 hours for its affordable housing program, surpassing its goal of adding 200,000 households to the waiting list. The city's Section 8 voucher program has been at maximum capacity since 2009, and the waiting list has been locked. The portal for new applications will close on June 9, with a lottery in August selecting 1,000 households per month for the program. The surge in applications comes as the city faces a severe housing affordability crisis, with an apartment vacancy rate of 1.4% in 2023.

site_title: Hedge fund Dymon expands central Hong Kong office, bucking trend
summary: Hedge fund Dymon Asia Capital is expanding its central Hong Kong office, despite the city's record premium office vacancies and declining rental rates. The 7,000 sq ft office in Edinburgh Tower will seat over 70 employees, doubling the current space. This move comes as Hong Kong struggles to lure back talent and firms, with stringent Covid-era restrictions and geopolitical concerns contributing to an exodus. The expansion reflects Dymon's commitment to the city, where it has more than 30 employees, and its growth plans in the region.

images.alt_text: The offerer has received valid acceptances amounting to about 71.73 per cent of the total shares in Amara, as at 6pm on Jan 2.

site_title: China lunar probe module takes off from moon carrying samples
summary: China's Chang'e-6 lunar probe successfully launched a module carrying samples from the far side of the moon, marking a world first and a significant leap for Beijing's decades-old space programme. The module lifted off on June 4 and entered a preset orbit around the moon after landing in the South Pole-Aitken Basin on June 2. The mission, which began on May 3, features two sample collection methods and aims to shed light on the moon's formation. China plans to send a crewed mission to the moon by 2030 and build a lunar base.

images.alt_text: China in 2019 became the first and so far only country to land on the moon’s far side.
China in 2019 became the first and so far only country to land on the moon’s far side.

site_title: Asia: Markets in reverse as US data spark economy worries
summary: Asian markets fell on June 4, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and other major cities experiencing losses, as traders reacted to weak US economic data, including a manufacturing index showing contraction for the second consecutive month. The US Federal Reserve's potential delay in cutting interest rates due to stubborn inflation has raised concerns about the economy, with investors now focusing on Friday's non-farm payrolls figures. Oil prices also declined after OPEC announced plans to lift output in 2025, following an extended period of cuts.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong up more than two per cent thanks to a surge in Chinese tech firms, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, Taipei and Jakarta were also well up.

site_title: Indian stocks lose US$386 billion as polls tighter than forecast
summary: India's stock market plummeted, erasing $386 billion in market value, after exit polls showed Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party did not win a majority of seats in national elections. The BJP's vote share at 36.7% was marginally lower than in the last polls in 2019. The NSE Nifty 50 Index tumbled 5.9%, its worst day in over four years, as Modi's alliance was leading in more than 290 seats, short of the 272 needed for a majority in parliament. The outcome raises questions about the new government's ability to push through reforms and affects investor confidence.

images.alt_text: The broader Nifty index ended up 3.25 per cent at 23,263.90 points after touching a record high of 23,338.70 in opening deals. The BSE index closed up 3.39 per cent at 76,468.78 points, just off its lifetime peak of 76,738.89 hit earlier.

site_title: How different senior housing types impact quality of life to be studied in S$2.9 million NUS project
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) is launching a S$2.9 million study to investigate how different senior housing types impact the quality of life for seniors in Singapore. The study aims to design future homes that cater to diverse needs and evolving preferences of elders, particularly those living alone or with family. The research will develop a framework and tool to compare seniors' quality of living across various housing typologies, and establish minimum standards for senior housing from a quality of living perspective.

images.alt_text: The development will comprise 200 units of assisted-living apartments, a nursing home with 100 beds, a wellness clubhouse and a geriatric care centre.

site_title: Nearly 2 in 3 property execs see continued relevance of traditional office space: NUS survey
summary: A survey by the National University of Singapore found that nearly 2 in 3 senior executives in the real estate industry believe traditional office space remains relevant, with co-working spaces playing a complementary role instead of replacing it. The survey also noted that office demand from family offices and wealth management sectors is expected to drive demand for traditional office space, despite a slowdown in demand from the technology sector. Additionally, respondents predicted a slowdown in demand for office space across various sectors, with two-thirds expecting deintensification and decentralization of office space in the CBD.

images.alt_text: WeWork said its restructuring cuts its future rent obligations in half, or about US$12 billion overall.
