site_title: Japanese authorities inspect Toyota HQ over certification irregularities
summary: Japanese authorities conducted an on-site inspection at Toyota Motor's headquarters over certification irregularities found in its applications to certify certain models. Toyota, Mazda, Honda, Suzuki, and Yamaha Motor were previously found to have submitted flawed or manipulated data, leading to a widening fallout in the industry. Toyota chairman Akio Toyoda apologized to shareholders and stakeholders, stating that the company needs to strengthen its governance. The inspection comes after a safety test scandal at Toyota's Daihatsu unit, with Toyota's shares falling 1.1% on the day of the inspection.

images.alt_text: epa11261494 A view of a Toyota dealership logo in Round Rock, Texas, USA, 05 April 2024. In the initial quarter, Toyota Motor North America (TMNA) disclosed sales figures of 565,098 vehicles, marking a 20.3 percent increase in volume and a 17.2 percent rise in DSR compared to March 2023. Electrified vehicle sales for the same period amounted to 206,850 units, constituting 36.6 percent of the total sales volume.  EPA-EFE/ADAM DAVIS
Automakers have been locked in a fierce price war in China’s huge but crowded auto market
Toyota hopes a more compact engine will help revamp vehicle design by saving space under the hood.

site_title: Gold flat as spotlight shifts to US data
summary: Gold prices remained flat at $2,347.48 per ounce in early Asian trading on Tuesday, June 4, after a 1% gain on Monday. The shift in focus to US economic data later in the week could provide more insight into the Federal Reserve's interest rate path. A 0.1% decrease in the US dollar index against a basket of currencies made bullion more attractive for foreign currency holders.

images.alt_text: Bullion is known as an inflation hedge, but higher rates increase the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding gold.

site_title: Singapore shares down at Tuesday’s open; STI falls 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.1% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) opening 4.34 points lower at 3,344.53. The mixed performance followed weaker-than-expected US economic data, with Wall Street stocks posting a 0.1% gain, 0.3% loss for the Dow Jones, and a 0.6% gain for the Nasdaq. Local banking stocks had mixed performances, with DBS edging up 0.1%, OCBC falling 1%, and UOB declining 0.1%.

images.alt_text: Gainers outnumbered losers 345 to 237, after 1.4 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands.

site_title: Vietnam expands massive bank rescue effort on deposit exodus, document shows
summary: Vietnam's central bank has lent a total of $24.5 billion to SCB, a lender engulfed in financial fraud, as part of its efforts to rescue depositors. The bailout has cost the central bank 6% of Vietnam's 2023 GDP in special loans. The bank has provided $1.2 billion in funding over the last two months, bringing the total to $1.2 billion. The move aims to stabilize the financial system, but has contributed to inflation and a weakening currency.

images.alt_text: The Philippines recorded growth of 5.7 per cent in the first quarter of 2024 to occupy top spot in Asean.
The move is a change in the State Bank of Vietnam (SBV)‘s efforts to manage gold prices.
Inflation has stayed above the 4 per cent mark for a second straight month.

site_title: Microsoft to lay off hundreds at Azure cloud unit, Business Insider reports
summary: Microsoft is laying off hundreds of jobs at its Azure cloud unit, impacting teams including Azure for Operators and Mission Engineering, according to a Business Insider report. The layoffs, potentially affecting up to 1,500 employees, come after the company cut 1,900 jobs at Activision Blizzard and Xbox in January. The cuts are part of Microsoft's efforts to prioritize strategic growth areas, despite witnessing sharp growth in Azure's AI-driven business.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A view shows a Microsoft logo at Microsoft offices in Issy-les-Moulineaux near Paris, France, February 9, 2024. REUTERS/Gonzalo Fuentes/File Photo/File Photo
The Microsoft-G42 deal is an agreement between the two companies that requires each to give security assurances to their respective home governments.

At a developer conference in Seattle, chief executive Satya Nadella promotes new application programming interfaces, or APIs, that make it easier for developers to tap in to AI technology offered by Microsoft.

site_title: Last S$3 billion money laundering accused to plead guilty handed four more charges, including faking job titles
summary: Cypriot national Wang Dehai, 35, has been handed four additional charges related to the Singapore money laundering case, including faking job titles and hiring a housekeeper without a valid work pass. This brings the total charges against him to eight. Wang Dehai is the last person scheduled to plead guilty in the case, which is Singapore's largest money laundering case.

images.alt_text: (From left) Su Baolin, Su Haijin and Vang Shuiming were deported from Singapore on May 25, May 28 and June 1 respectively.
Lin Baoying, one of the 10 foreigners arrested in the S$3 billion money laundering case.
Su Jianfeng now faces 14 charges in total in Singapore’s biggest money laundering case involving more than S$3 billion in assets.
Su Jianfeng faces 12 charges for forgery and fraud. Four cars, including a red Porsche 911 Targa, were towed away by the authorities from a GCB he resided in before his arrest.

Over S$200 million of Lin Baoying's (right) assets have been seized, BT reported previously. This includes cash, properties and vehicles, including some that were held collectively with Zhang Ruijin (left).

site_title: Asia’s new flying geese
summary: Asia is shifting its economic growth pattern, with the "wild-geese-flying pattern" of development seen in post-war Japan now spreading to other countries. The original geese, Japan, Hong Kong, South Korea, and Taiwan, have been joined by new geese, including the Asean-4 and China. The China-plus-one strategy, led by India, Vietnam, and Malaysia, is benefiting from foreign direct investment and export growth. The shift is driven by US-China tensions and the pandemic, with China becoming a lead goose and supplier of intermediate goods. Weaning off China will be difficult, and the process of becoming integrated into global value chains is still in its infancy, with government policies playing a crucial role in determining the future of Asia's new flying geese.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians in Tokyo's Ginza district, April 2023. Japan’s economy is finally breaking out of its decades-long deflationary mindset.
China has become an electric vehicle (EV) behemoth as a result of a concerted effort to go all-in on EVs more than a decade ago.

site_title: Arm aims to capture 50% of PC market in five years, CEO says
summary: ARM Holdings aims to capture over 50% of the Windows PC market in five years, according to CEO Rene Haas. The move is driven by Microsoft's plans to launch AI-powered PCs using Arm's technology, which could disrupt the traditional PC industry dominated by Intel and AMD. Microsoft has committed to developing software tools to support Arm-based chips, and hardware vendors like Asus and Dell are already signed on to sell Arm-based machines. This could reorder the market and challenge Intel's x86 technology.

images.alt_text: Arm will pay for initial development costs, which may go up hundreds of billions of yen, with SoftBank also contributing, the report says.
Masayoshi Son has moved on to new obsessions, inspired in part by the success of Arm.
Arm’s chip designs and licensed standards already serve as a critical technology for most smartphones.

site_title: Google cuts at least 100 jobs across its cloud unit, CNBC reports
summary: Google has cut at least 100 jobs from its cloud unit, primarily from sales, operations, and engineering teams. This move follows previous job cuts in January and April as the company aims to meet customer priorities and reduce costs amid economic uncertainty. A spokesperson for Google stated that the company will continue to invest in critical areas to ensure long-term success. The layoffs are part of Google's efforts to evolve its business and adapt to changing market conditions.

site_title: Roaring Kitty’s Reddit post on GameStop signals a US$289 million paper fortune
summary: Keith Gill, known as Roaring Kitty, posted a screenshot of his GameStop portfolio on Reddit, potentially worth $289 million. The image showed a significant increase in shares, with a 21% surge in the stock price, netting $79 million in a single day. This move has raised concerns about potential stock manipulation, with E*Trade considering kicking Gill off its platform. Gill's actions have sparked a renewed rally in GameStop shares, but the stock remains nearly 68% below its January 2021 peak.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: GameStop logo is seen in front of displayed Reddit logo in this illustration taken February 2, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
GameStop says that its preliminary first-quarter net sales were between US$872 million and US$892 million.
GameStop‘s shares hit an 18-month high at US$38.20 and were halted multiple times for volatility. They posted their sharpest one-day percentage gain since January 2021.
Gamestop contracts that expire on Friday had the largest volume, with the most active contract — a Dec 1 US$30 call — changing hands 54,100 times.

site_title: CapitaLand Ascott Trust fully acquires US student accommodation property
summary: CapitaLand Ascott Trust has fully acquired a 678-bed student accommodation property in South Carolina, increasing its total portfolio value in longer-stay assets to 17%. The property had a 99% pre-leasing occupancy rate as of end-May 2024, with expected earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) yield of about 7% on total development costs.

images.alt_text: Citadines City Centre Frankfurt, one of CapitaLand Ascott Trust’s properties. The stapled group's managers say revenue per available room for the quarter has reached pre-Covid levels on a pro-forma basis.

site_title: Oil hits four-month low as Opec+ decision fails to allay demand worries
summary: Oil prices plummeted to a four-month low on Monday, falling $3 a barrel, amid concerns that Opec+ output cuts will be unwound later in the year, potentially leading to higher supplies. The agreement to extend most cuts into 2025 was seen as bearish for oil prices, with analysts citing high interest rates, rising US output, and disappointing economic indicators in the US and China. The US is also buying more oil for its Strategic Petroleum Reserve, but the market remains well-supplied, with US petrol futures hitting a three-month low.

images.alt_text: Opec and allies led by Russia are currently cutting output by a total of 5.86 million barrels per day, which is about 5.7 per cent of global demand.

site_title: Shaping robust governance of AI
summary: Singapore emphasizes the importance of governance in artificial intelligence, alongside innovation, to ensure AI serves the public good. The country has developed a Model AI Governance Framework and introduced laws and regulations to address AI-related harms, such as data protection and cyber risks. However, Singapore is not introducing an overarching AI law, instead focusing on risk mitigation through research, testing, and design measures. The government is also promoting international cooperation and developing a playbook to help small states adopt AI responsibly.

images.alt_text: Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo (centre) at a demonstration by small business owners on the use of chatbot Bard at the launch of the AI Trailblazers initiative on July 24, 2023.
The challenges of good governance are no less acute in the digital age. There are very few tried and tested formulas of good digital governance; no ready playbooks to adapt.
The private sector also has a role to play to realise the potential of artificial intelligence for public good, said Minister Josephine Teo.

site_title: Ex-Pakistan PM Imran Khan acquitted in state secrets case, but to stay in jail
summary: Pakistan's former Prime Minister Imran Khan has been acquitted in a state secrets case by a high court, overturning a 10-year prison sentence. However, he will remain in prison due to a conviction in another case, where he faces a 7-year sentence over his marriage to his third wife. Khan's acquittal is seen as a major victory for his party, with his lawyers predicting acquittals in other cases. Despite this, Khan's imprisonment is expected to continue.

images.alt_text: The election took place in the shadow of a month’s long military campaign to gut the party of former Prime Minister Imran Khan, a former international cricket star and populist leader who was ousted by parliament in 2022 after falling out with the generals.

site_title: Bill Ackman’s wealth hits US$8 billion on vision of supersized Pershing
summary: Bill Ackman's wealth has reached US$8 billion after a group of investors invested US$1.05 billion in his hedge fund, Pershing Square Capital Management. The investment values Ackman's stake at over US$3.5 billion, making Pershing Square one of the most expensive asset managers globally. Ackman, 58, now ranks 333rd on Bloomberg's list of the world's 500 wealthiest individuals, surpassing notable financiers such as Jon Gray, George Soros, and Todd Boehly. Investors are betting Pershing Square's assets will increase to around US$45 billion.

images.alt_text: A pool of potential capital could come from billionaire hedge fund manager William Ackman’s 1.2 million followers on the social media platform X.

site_title: Maersk faces significant port congestion in Asia, Mediterranean
summary: Maersk, the world's second-largest container shipping company, faces significant terminal congestion in Mediterranean and Asian ports, causing delays in its vessel schedule. The company will skip two sailings from China and South Korea due to congestion in Singapore, Dubai, China, and the US. Global supply chains are suffering from cascading delays and higher costs due to Yemen's Houthi militant attacks on the Suez Canal. This congestion is driven by surge in cargo demand and disruptions caused by ships diverting around Africa.

site_title: Nvidia and AMD square off in fight to take control of AI
summary: Nvidia and AMD are engaging in a rivalry to dominate the artificial intelligence (AI) market, with Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang predicting a major role for his company as AI shifts to personal computers. AMD's CEO Lisa Su showcased new AI-powered chips, while Huang unveiled a chip dubbed Rubin, set to succeed Nvidia's Blackwell family, which will sustain the company's leadership in accelerators used by OpenAI and Microsoft for generative AI services like ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: The chip will feature more memory and faster data throughput, the company said. MI350 will follow in 2025 and the MI400 model a year after that.
Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang touted 98 per cent cost savings and 97 per cent less energy required with Nvidia’s technology, saying that constituted “CEO math, which is not accurate, but it is correct”.
AI accelerators – a category pioneered by Nvidia – help data centres process the flood of information needed to develop artificial intelligence chatbots and other tools.

site_title: Singapore’s PMI rises further in May, mirroring improvements in regionwide factory activity
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector saw a 0.1 point gain in its purchasing managers' index (PMI) in May, reaching 50.6, marking the ninth straight month of expansion. The electronics sector also expanded at a slightly faster pace, with a 0.2 point gain to 51.1. Despite geopolitical tensions and potential supply chain disruptions, economists expect the manufacturing and electronics sector to remain supportive in the second half of 2024.

images.alt_text: UOB associate economist Jester Koh remains optimistic on the recovery prospects in the electronics sector, which he believes will be driven by the boost from generative artificial intelligence-related applications.

site_title: Sustainable financing needs rise in Asean as regulations evolve: corporate and investment banking expert
summary: Governments in Southeast Asia are seeking blended financing solutions to scale up investments amid evolving environmental regulations. According to Sunil Kaushal, co-head for corporate and investment banking at Standard Chartered, the need for supply chain resilience has brought benefits to the region. As a fast-growing trade bloc, Singapore serves as a strategic node for businesses to access the whole region. The demand for sustainable finance is expected to surge, with governments and businesses working together to channel capital to areas with the greatest impact.

images.alt_text: Generic photos for Budget 2024
Scepticism regarding the performance of ESG investments has also been on the rise since 2021.
SIT's Campus Court site is certified Green Mark Platinum, with two buildings being certified as Super Low Energy (SLE) buildings.

site_title: Boeing 737 deliveries to China still halted amid restart reports
summary: Boeing's 737 deliveries to China remain halted amid regulatory scrutiny of a new cockpit voice recorder design. The US planemaker has resumed deliveries to China in January but halted them again in late May due to regulatory concerns. Boeing is working with the Chinese Civil Aviation Administration to complete its review of the 25-hour cockpit voice recorder assembly unit. The US Federal Aviation Administration and Europe's main aviation regulator have certified the system, but Boeing is deferring further comments. The halt in deliveries is a significant blow to Boeing's financials and its efforts to clear its 737 Max inventory.

site_title: Maersk raises 2024 guidance on strong demand, Red Sea disruptions
summary: Maersk has raised its 2024 profit guidance to $7 billion to $9 billion, citing strong demand and disruptions in the Red Sea. The company expects a free cash flow of at least $1 billion and upgraded its earnings before interest and tax to $1 billion to $3 billion. Signs of further port congestions, especially in Asia and the Middle East, and increased container freight rates are expected to contribute to a stronger financial performance in the second half of 2024.

site_title: Singapore unlikely to draw large-scale data-centre investment despite added capacity: report
summary: Singapore's plan to increase its data centre capacity to 500MW may not attract large-scale foreign investments due to insufficient allocated capacity to meet South-east Asia's growing demand. Neighboring markets like Johor and Batam in Malaysia and Indonesia are attracting data centre investments due to lower costs and proximity to Singapore. The BMI report estimates that Singapore's total data centre capacity will reach 1,400MW, but still falls short of the region's needs, with emerging markets requiring over 2,500MW of capacity in the near term.

images.alt_text: Singapore is a regional data centre hub, with over 70 data centres.
The pledge marks Google’s largest planned investment in the South-east Asian nation, according to Alphabet chief financial officer Ruth Porat in a statement.
IFC has invested in three projects in Malaysia since it set up an office in the country last year.
More than 50 per cent of data centre development activity in the region are found in China, Japan and India, says Colliers.

site_title: Why energy will power this bull market higher
summary: Energy stocks are expected to continue their upward momentum in 2024, driven by rising oil prices and strong demand. Despite a disappointing 2023, energy firms have deeper fundamentals underpinning their strength, including near-term incentives and increased production capacity. Global oil demand is expected to hit record highs, and natural gas demand is expected to rise 2.5% in 2024. Big integrated oil firms are poised to benefit, and investors should diversify their exposure by shopping globally, particularly in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Real risks must be big, economically significant events few fathom – stealth torpedoes unpriced by markets, says Ken Fisher.
Singapore’s venture capital funding per capital is the highest in the world at US$1,060 per person – more than three times second-place America.
There are hard and easy ways to gauge sentiment; both now reveal more bulls in the market ahead.

site_title: US construction spending slips again in April
summary: US construction spending fell 0.1% in April, marking a second consecutive decline, after a 0.2% drop in March. Non-residential activity declined, while single-family home building spending reached its highest level since August 2022, increasing 10% year-over-year. Economists had forecast a 0.2% gain, and spending on private projects fell 0.1% due to declines in commercial projects, while public projects also fell 0.2%.

site_title: Choose bonds over stocks as central banks cut rates, says UBS Wealth Management
summary: UBS Wealth Management's CIO, Mark Haefele, recommends bonds over stocks due to attractive yields and low risk. Despite stocks rising 8% this year, Haefele favors bonds, citing a preference for high-grade corporate credit and five-year US Treasury bonds. Central banks' interest rate cuts are expected to boost bond prices, making them an attractive investment option, particularly as equity volatility may increase in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: business, stock, finance
Investing without making mistakes is like trying to surf the ocean waves without getting wet –it’s just not realistic.
India's economic growth remains robust. Expected earnings growth for FY24 is among the strongest in the region and not deendent on the technology sector.
Too much cash may partially explain strong bond inflows and the sharp rally in higher-risk fixed income assets.

site_title: Shareholders should question the rationale for share buybacks
summary: US President Joe Biden proposed quadrupling the tax on corporate share buybacks to 4% to encourage long-term investments. However, US investor Warren Buffett defended share buybacks, calling critics "economic illiterates" or "silver-tongued demagogues." A study found no relationship between the amount spent on buybacks and shareholder returns, and some studies suggest that buybacks may actually decrease operating income. Shareholders should scrutinize repurchase proposals due to the lack of rigorous justifications for the activity.

images.alt_text: China-listed firms announced record cash dividends totalling 2.2 trillion yuan (S$405.8 billion) for 2023 despite a fall in combined profit, official data shows. Over 100 listed companies returned money to investors for the first time.
OUE said the share buyback is to commemorate its 60th anniversary and enhance shareholder value.
Excessive share buybacks, sometimes funded by debt, have been blamed for recent scandals or bankruptcies in companies such as Boeing and Bed Bath & Beyond.

site_title: Indonesia law giving religious groups mining permits sparks outrage
summary: Indonesia's outgoing President Joko Widodo signed a decree allowing religious groups to manage mining concessions to "improve social welfare". The move has sparked outrage from environmentalists, who claim the government is attempting to control natural resources for the benefit of elites. The regulation is part of Indonesia, the world's leading nickel producer, which has vast mining resources spread across its thousands of islands. Critics, including the Mining Advocacy Network, warn that the new law could lead to environmental degradation and exploitation of resources.

images.alt_text: A coal mine in Kalimantan, Indonesia. The country's coal reliance is partly driven by a need for energy self-sufficiency.

site_title: Products with high levels of toxic chemicals removed from website: Shein, Singapore consumer safety body
summary: Shein, an online retailer, has removed from its website products found to contain toxic substances, including phthalates, by South Korean authorities. The Singapore Consumer Product Safety Office (CPSO) has also confirmed that the tainted products have been removed from its online catalogue. The CPSO is working with Shein to follow up on the investigations and remove non-compliant products from sale in Singapore. The company has stated it will take "appropriate follow-up action" against the supplier if products are found to have flouted safety standards.

site_title: The many-sided crisis in consulting
summary: The management consulting industry is experiencing a slowdown, with revenue growth halving to 5% last year, according to the Kennedy Consulting Industry Monitor. Firms such as Bain and McKinsey are shedding workers and cutting costs, while politicians and academics are increasingly critical of the profession. Critics argue that consulting firms prioritize short-term gains over long-term value, and that the industry's problems date back to the 1980s. As technology replaces lower-end consulting work, the industry will need to adapt to remain relevant, with some experts suggesting that a recession could bring new life to the profession.

images.alt_text: Not long ago, the consulting industry looked indestructible. Now, however, growth has been soggy for this “Great Eight”, slowing to around 5 per cent in 2023.
Budget tightening at companies in Singapore may dampen demand for consulting services, watchers agree.
Besides consulting, the Big Four also help multinational corporations minimise tax while simultaneously acting as "gatekeepers" in auditing the same big companies.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as markets try to shake off economic concerns
summary: US stocks experienced a mixed showing on Monday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average retreating 0.3% to 38,571.03. The S&P 500 edged up 0.1% to 5,283.40, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.6% to 16,828.67. Weaker-than-expected economic data, including a manufacturing index of 48.7% for May, suggested the economy is slowing. Despite this, investors appeared to be optimistic about a "soft landing" for the economy, with some companies like Nvidia and GameStop experiencing gains.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., April 26, 2024.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: iFast prices S$100 million notes due 2029 at 4.328%
summary: iFast Corporation priced its S$100 million fixed-rate notes at 4.328% annual coupon rate, to be issued under its S$300 million multi-currency debt issuance programme. The notes will be issued on June 11, with semi-annual coupon payments made on June 11 and December 11.

images.alt_text: iFast's debt issuance programme has received in-principle approval from the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: US risks a ‘forever’ trade war with China, economist Stephen Roach says
summary: Economist Stephen Roach warns that the US' protectionist measures against China risk creating an "endless economic conflict" and a "forever war" between the two nations. Roach calls the US' stance a "blunder" that could hinder China's sales of key products like electric vehicles, as Beijing views the US measures as an act of protectionism. The US is erecting new trade barriers, accusing China of building excess capacity using state subsidies and flooding global markets with cheap products. Roach's comments echo Beijing's view and highlight the fragile state of China's economic recovery.

images.alt_text: Middle Eastern governments are ploughing in billions of US dollars to upgrade their infrastructure, offering Chinese companies and financial institutions new avenues for growth.
Those wishing to export items including aerospace structural components as well as equipment and software used in engine manufacturing, among other things, will need to apply for an export licence.
Chinese companies are bracing for even tougher times ahead as Joe Biden and Donald Trump gear up for a rematch in the November presidential election.

Malaysia’s Top Glove, the world’s largest medical glove maker, expects the US tariffs to boost the prices of domestically produced gloves that have dropped below production costs due to competition from China.
The latest investment vehicle, known as Big Fund III, showcases the renewed push from Beijing to build its own semiconductor supply chain.

site_title: US factory activity slips for a second month in May, ISM says
summary: US factory activity declined for a second consecutive month in May, with the Institute for Supply Management's manufacturing purchasing managers index falling to 48.7 from 49.2 in April. New goods orders dropped by the most in nearly two years, but input inflation fell back from its highest level since mid-2022. The factory sector has been in contraction for 18 of the past 19 months due to high interest rates. Economists expect interest rates to remain high until at least September.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Car bodies are lifted at "Factory 56", one of the world's most modern electric and conventional car assembly halls of German carmaker Mercedes-Benz, in Sindelfingen near Stuttgart, Germany, March 4, 2024. REUTERS/Wolfgang Rattay/File Photo

site_title: Christie’s extortion deadline ends without hackers posting data
summary: Christie's auction house missed its deadline to release client data compromised in a cyberattack, after a group known as RansomHub threatened to post names, passport details, and other information on the dark web. The group initially posted a countdown clock and message, but later changed tactics and offered the data for auction. Christie's sent a notice to affected clients stating that passport information was compromised, but contact details, financial data, and transaction-related information were not exposed. The hackers' true intentions remain unclear.

images.alt_text: The attackers also did not obtain ID photographs, signatures, email addresses or phone numbers, according to the Christie’s memo sent to customers.
The attack came days before Christie’s began its all-important 20th and 21st century May auctions in New York.
Amidst a tepid global art market, down by 4 per cent last year, both Christie’s and its rival Sotheby’s have suffered from a dearth of major collections coming to auction.

site_title: NYSE resolves glitch that led to volatility pause for dozens of stocks
summary: The New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) has resolved a technical issue that led to volatility pauses for dozens of stocks, including Berkshire Hathaway and Chipotle Mexican Grill. The Limit Up-Limit Down (LULD) mechanism, which prevents extraordinary market volatility, was affected, causing stocks to be halted. The issue has been resolved, and the impacted stocks have reopened or are in the process of reopening. The NYSE attributed the issue to an error in trade reports and said it was a "glitch." The incident has raised concerns about the reliability of exchanges and market makers.

images.alt_text: Rising US Treasury yields have dented investor confidence and led to market weakness.

site_title: Google’s latest data centre raises its investment in Singapore to S$6.7 billion
summary: Google has increased its investment in Singapore's data centres to S$6.7 billion, up from US$850 million in 2022. The fourth data centre in Singapore will power the company's popular digital services, such as search engine and Google Maps. The new facility, located in Jurong West, will employ over 500 people. Google has committed to making its data centres more sustainable, with plans to reduce energy consumption and carbon emissions. The company's Asia-Pacific head of public affairs said innovations in facility design and hardware have enabled the creation of supercomputers that require less energy for cooling.

images.alt_text: The pledge marks Google’s largest planned investment in the South-east Asian nation, according to Alphabet chief financial officer Ruth Porat in a statement.

site_title: Europe: Shares kick-off June on a high note in anticipation of ECB rate cut
summary: Europe's pan-European Stoxx 600 index rose 0.3% on the first session of June, driven by gains in bond-proxy sectors ahead of a near-certain interest rate cut from the European Central Bank. Global factory activity showed signs of recovery, while soft US inflation data fueled hopes of interest rate cuts this year. Spanish and Italian stocks led gains with 0.7% and 0.5% rises, respectively, amidst upbeat sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index is still in its second week of declines despite being up for the month.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher on chip and megacaps boost
summary: Wall Street opened higher on Monday, driven by gains in semiconductor and megacap growth stocks ahead of a data-packed week. The Dow Jones rose 23.67 points, or 0.06%, to 38,709.99, while the S&P 500 gained 19.64 points, or 0.37%, to 5,297.15, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 130.69 points, or 0.78%, to 16,865.70.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Jun 3)
summary: DBS launches an internationalisation programme to support 1,000 businesses in expanding overseas. The Bridging Business Horizons programme, supported by the Singapore Business Federation and Enterprise Singapore, aims to engage businesses in Singapore and the region in entering new markets. Meanwhile, Indonesia's inflation rate dropped to 2.84% in May, lower than expected. Singapore's real estate players have turned more pessimistic on the prime residential, office, and business park sectors in Q1, despite an overall improvement in the real estate trade. The Straits Times Index rose 0.4% on Monday, tracking regional gains.

site_title: China’s Great Wall Motor closes European HQ and lays off workers
summary: China's Great Wall Motor is closing its European headquarters in Munich and laying off about 100 workers due to the challenging electric vehicle market in Europe. The company cited uncertainties in the region as the reason for pulling back, with higher import tariffs from the EU expected to reduce competitiveness. Great Wall Motors sold about 6,300 cars in Europe in 2023, accounting for 2% of its overall exports. The company's base operations in China will assume responsibility for supporting European distributors and exploring new markets.

images.alt_text: BYD intensified the price war by cutting the prices of many popular models in February which led others to follow.
The company's cumulative deliveries since inception has hit 515,811 cars in May.
The Commission can impose provisional anti-subsidy duties nine months after the start of the probe.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, June 3, 2024 (Ep 73)
summary: Asian markets rallied on Monday, following Wall Street gains, with India stocks reaching a record high as polls showed Modi's election win. Skywaters Residences set a record for 99-year leasehold properties with a sale of S$6,100 per square foot.

images.alt_text: The Straits Times Index (STI) edged up 0.3 per cent at the opening bell on Monday.
Hong Kong up more than two per cent thanks to a surge in Chinese tech firms, while Tokyo, Shanghai, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Manila, Taipei and Jakarta were also well up.
The luxury unit sold at Skywaters Residences in May is the fourth-highest in terms of psf pricing.

site_title: Sheinbaum makes history as first woman elected to lead Mexico
summary: Claudia Sheinbaum, a 61-year-old climate scientist and former mayor of Mexico City, has made history by becoming the first woman and the first Jewish person elected president of Mexico in a landslide victory. Sheinbaum, a leftist, won with at least 58% of the vote, surpassing her closest competitor, Xóchitl Gálvez, by 31.4 percentage points. Sheinbaum's victory marks a significant milestone for women's representation in politics and follows the legacy of her mentor, President Andrés Manuel López Obrador. She vows to work on behalf of all Mexicans, reaffirming her party's commitment to democracy, and faces significant challenges in addressing cartel violence, economic issues, and public finances.

site_title: India markets rejoice exit poll prediction for a Modi landslide
summary: India's stock market surged after exit polls predicted a decisive mandate for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's Bharatiya Janata Party, with the Nifty index closing up 3.25% at 23,263.90 points and the BSE index up 3.39% at 76,468.78 points. The rupee gained 0.4% against the US dollar, and bond yields dropped to their lowest level since April 2022. Analysts expect sustained economic growth and a potential third term for Modi, which could lead to a surge in equity markets.

images.alt_text: FILE — An electric scooter factory in Tamil Nadu, India, on Aug. 24, 2022. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has kept India on its swift upward path among the world’s largest economies. Many Indians are better off, though wealth gaps have widened. (Atul Loke/The New York Times)

site_title: Sabana Reit EGM will not proceed: manager
summary: Sabana Industrial Real Estate Investment Trust (Sabana Reit) will not proceed with its postponed extraordinary general meeting (EGM) as proposed by unitholders led by Quarz Capital Asia. The manager cited the requisitionists' "proposing entirely new and different resolutions" as the reason for the decision, effectively withdrawing the notice. The manager is considering the new resolutions and seeking legal advice. The decision comes after a court ruling requiring the manager to issue a notice for the postponed meeting by Thursday.

images.alt_text: New Tech Park, at 151 Lorong Chuan, is an asset in Sabana Reit's portfolio.
Among other proposed changes, the requisitionists have withdrawn the resolution deemed unnecessary to effect internalisation as per the court ruling.

site_title: Global factory activity shows signs of recovery in May
summary: Global factory activity showed signs of recovery in May, with the eurozone's manufacturing sector potentially turning a corner after a long downturn. The eurozone's manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) rose to 47.3, indicating a slight acceleration of growth. Other major economies, including Asia's largest economies, also reported improved manufacturing activity, defying slowdown expectations. The positive trend suggests a more solid expansion in the global economy, which may lead to a cautious approach by central banks to cutting interest rates.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has been squeezed by a protracted property crisis, which has weighed on business and consumer confidence.
South Korea’s exports have been growing since October and provided the biggest boost to the trade-reliant economy’s first-quarter growth.
The inflation strains prompted manufacturers to raise their selling prices at the fastest pace in a year last month.

site_title: South Korea's Yoon approves exploration of vast oil, gas prospects
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol approved the exploration of vast oil and gas prospects off the east coast, estimating 14 billion barrels of potential reserves. The project, costing over 500 billion won, will begin near the end of the year and aims to find energy reserves by 2025. If successful, the prospects could fuel the country for 29 years and provide enough oil for four years of consumption. Energy stocks in Seoul surged following the announcement, with shares of oil refiner SK Innovation and gas corporation Korea Gas Corporation jumping significantly.

images.alt_text: South Korea’s exports have been growing since October and provided the biggest boost to the trade-reliant economy’s first-quarter growth.

site_title: China's PSL loans fall but housing support seen in place
summary: China's outstanding PSL loans fell to 2.95 trillion yuan in May, down 75 billion yuan from the previous month, but analysts say this decline does not signal a policy shift from supporting the housing market. The drop is attributed to maturing loans used for a shantytown renovation program. The People's Bank of China has maintained its support for the property sector through various measures, including a 300 billion yuan relending facility unveiled in May. This suggests the central bank remains committed to stabilizing the housing market.

images.alt_text: In Shanghai, second-hand sales last weekend were 50 per cent higher than the daily average for the month.
Commercial and residential buildings stand in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 6, 2014. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
Economists expect the PBOC to cut the RRR for banks by 25 basis before the end of June, a move that would release cash for loans and investment.

site_title: GSK plunges as drugmaker must face Zantac cases in Delaware
summary: GSK's shares plummeted 10% as a Delaware court ruled the UK drugmaker must face trials over Zantac's alleged cancer-causing effects. The ruling exposes GSK to over 70,000 cases and estimates total settlement costs at $3 billion. GSK faces more cases than Sanofi, which has about 25,000 cases pending. The decision allows consumers' experts to testify and GSK plans to appeal. This is the worst drop since August 2022 and wipes out roughly half the stock's gain this year.

images.alt_text:
GSK's profit after tax dropped to £1.1 billion, 
despite sales of its drugs sales rising 10% to £7.4 billion.

site_title:
Risk is not volatility. Understand the difference 
for better investment results
summary: China stocks have weathered significant 40% drawdowns three times in the last 23 years, highlighting the tradeoff between returns and risk. The "science of wealth" emphasizes knowledge over cash, with historical data and behavioral finance studies providing valuable insights for investors. Understanding risk and volatility is crucial, with volatility being an observable market phenomenon and risk being a personal comfort level with potential losses. Investors must balance returns with risk tolerance, investment horizon, and financial goals, and consider alternative asset classes and private markets to diversify their portfolios.

images.alt_text: Ten-year US Treasury yields remain elevating despite having slipped back after touching 5 per cent last year.
Funds that claim to offer a hedge for geopolitical uncertainty strip out companies the managers say threaten national security or are vulnerable to state takeover or US sanctions.

site_title: Downturn in German manufacturing may be bottoming out, PMI shows
summary: Germany's manufacturing sector, accounting for 20% of its economy, may be bottoming out after a downturn, according to the HCOB final Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) for May. The PMI rose to 45.4 from 42.5 in April, below the 50 level that marks growth. New orders declined at a slower pace, while output fell at its slowest rate in over a year. Chief economist Cyrus de la Rubia notes signs of a turnaround, citing an accelerated decline in inventory levels and optimism about growth prospects, with firms expecting a rebound in investment and demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People carry their shopping bags in downtown Hamburg, Germany, January 25, 2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo
In Germany, cooling energy and food prices have had an easing effect on inflation this year – but core inflation, which excludes those more volatile elements, has remained high.
FILE PHOTO: People carry their shopping bags in downtown Hamburg, Germany, January 25, 2018. REUTERS/Fabian Bimmer/File Photo

site_title: Qualcomm says laptop users will leave power bricks behind
summary: Qualcomm has announced that its new Snapdragon X Elite systems will power Windows laptops, offering up to twice the battery life of traditional laptops and significantly improved power efficiency for AI features. The technology is being used in Microsoft's Copilot+ PCs, which will also be faster and more efficient than Apple's MacBook Air. Qualcomm's CEO, Cristiano Amon, described the partnership as "significant" and comparable to the impact of Windows 95, aiming to diversify the company's revenue streams and capture market share in new areas such as automotive and computing.

images.alt_text: Chief product officer Jeff Wittich said that Ampere is working on standards that allow the combination of different companies’ chips on single pieces of silicon.
The move comes after the release last month of Huawei’s first AI-enabled laptop, the MateBook X Pro powered by Intel’s new Core Ultra 9 processor.
Qualcomm said its sales to Chinese smartphone makers have grown 40 per cent in the first half of its fiscal year, a sign of recovery in that market.

site_title: Spotify raises US prices of its premium plans in margin push
summary: Spotify has raised prices for its premium plans in the US, increasing monthly fees for individual, duo, and family plans. The price hikes follow the company's efforts to boost margins by reducing marketing spending and layoffs. The individual plan now costs $11.99, up from $10.99, while the duo and family plans cost $16.99 and $19.99, respectively. The move is part of Spotify's strategy to invest in product offerings and features. Shares rose 3.3% in premarket trading.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit alleges that Spotify on March 1, without advance notice, reclassified its paid subscription services, resulting in a nearly 50 per cent reduction in royalty payments to MLC.

Spotify submitted a new version of its app to Apple with basic pricing and website information, which is a minimum requirement under the European Commission’s ruling in its music streaming case, it said in a post on X on Wednesday.
Premium subscribers, who account for most of Spotify’s revenue, rose by 14 per cent to 239 million, in line with estimates.

site_title: More investors turn to private-market assets in 2024
summary: Professional investors are shifting towards private-market assets in 2024 to generate yield and diversify portfolios amid high interest rates and recessionary fears. 65% of institutional investors plan to allocate 60/20/20, enriched with alternative investments, to outpace traditional mixes. Private equity dominates alternative allocations, with 83% of institutional portfolios invested in private assets. Investors are drawn to private equity's potential for outsized returns, while also exploring sustainable investments, with 87% of institutions investing in green bonds planning to maintain or increase their investments.

images.alt_text: KKR sees Japanese companies as increasingly willing to sell non-core businesses that can do better as individual entities.
China stocks have weathered a significant 40 per cent drawdown three times in the last 23 years. There is a tradeoff between the allure of returns and the possibility of drawdowns.

site_title: Airline body Iata calls for airline taxation to remain in carriers’ headquartered country
summary: The International Air Transport Association (IATA) has recommended that the United Nations maintain the current system of taxing airlines in the country where they are headquartered, rather than taxing them in the countries where they generate revenue. IATA director-general Willie Walsh stated that this change would add complexity and cost, and potentially cause routes to be scrapped. The proposed "source-based" taxation system aims to address concerns that developing countries do not benefit sufficiently from air travel revenue, but IATA argues it would create a "reporting mess" for accountants.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Willie Walsh, Director General of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) speaks during an interview with Reuters in Istanbul, Turkey June 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dilara Senkaya/File Photo
According to the global industry body, Middle East passenger traffic will double in the next 20 years, climbing to 530 million passengers by 2043.
Airlines demand virus-busting seats to ease Covid deep-cleaning

site_title: Fast fashion retailer Shein to launch resale platform in Europe, UK
summary: Shein, a fast fashion retailer, plans to launch a resale platform in Europe and the UK, following studies showing 50% of respondents in the UK, France, Germany, and Brazil prioritize sustainability when buying second-hand clothes online. The platform, launched in the US two years ago, will initially be available in France, with the UK and Germany to follow. This move comes as the company prepares to file for a London float and has seen significant growth on its existing exchange platform, with over 4.2 million new users and 115,000 pre-owned items listed for sale in 2023.

site_title: India stocks hit record, rupee gains as polls predict Modi win
summary: India's stocks surged to a record high, with the NSE Nifty 50 Index rallying 3.6% after exit polls predicted a landslide victory for Prime Minister Narendra Modi's ruling party. The rupee also gained, while sovereign bonds climbed. A landslide win would enable Modi's party to push through policies boosting economic growth. The rally was driven by short-covering by foreign investors and optimism over macro, political, and credit positives.

images.alt_text: FILE — An electric scooter factory in Tamil Nadu, India, on Aug. 24, 2022. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has kept India on its swift upward path among the world’s largest economies. Many Indians are better off, though wealth gaps have widened. (Atul Loke/The New York Times)

TOPSHOT - India's Prime Minister and leader of the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) Narendra Modi (C) with chief minister of Maharashtra state Eknath Shinde (L) and their deputy chief Minister Devendra Fadnavis (R) waves to the crowd during his roadshow in Mumbai on May 15, 2024, ahead of the fifth phase of voting of India's general election. (Photo by Punit PARANJPE / AFP)

site_title: Australia raises minimum wage 3.75%, aiding inflation fight
summary: Australia's Fair Work Commission raised the national minimum wage by 3.75%, effective July 1, to A$915.90 (S$823) a week or A$24.10 an hour. The increase aims to combat inflation, which has been above the 2-3% target, and is in line with economists' expectations. The move is expected to support the Reserve Bank of Australia's efforts to return inflation to target by 2025. The decision affects approximately 2.6 million workers, or 20.7% of the labor force, and is seen as a step to restrain consumer prices.

images.alt_text: The RBA has held its cash rate at 4.35 per cent since a surprise hike in November, pointing out that aggregate demand still exceeds the economy’s supply capacity.
April’s retail sales of A$35.7 billion (S$32 billion) were up a sluggish 1.3 per cent from a year earlier.

site_title: GameStop shares double as Keith Gill’s post shows US$116 million bet
summary: GameStop shares more than doubled after a Reddit account run by Keith Gill, who bought 5 million shares at $21.27 apiece, posted a screenshot showing a potential $116 million bet. The account, which hadn't posted in three years, also included 120,000 call options worth $65.7 million. The post sparked a surge in GameStop shares, with the stock price more than doubling. The screenshot's authenticity couldn't be verified, but the move reignited the meme-stock mania of 2021.

images.alt_text: Social media and investing: what influencers may not tell you

site_title: US dollar stands tall as traders mull Fed outlook
summary: The US dollar held steady against other currencies, rising 0.1% to 104.67, as investors anticipate potential interest rate cuts from the Federal Reserve in 2024. The euro, however, fell 0.12% to $1.0834 ahead of an expected European Central Bank rate cut. Emerging market currencies, such as the Indian rupee and Mexican peso, strengthened following general election results. The dollar's monthly decline in May was attributed to shifting expectations on US rate cuts, with markets pricing in 37 basis points of cuts this year from the Fed.

images.alt_text: Canadian one hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The dollar index was last down 0.39 per cent at 104.36.
The record spending on intervention shows the commitment of Japan’s government to push back against speculators betting against the yen.

site_title: Microsoft makes US$3.2 billion AI bet on Swedish data centres
summary: Microsoft invests $3.2 billion in AI and cloud facilities in Sweden, its largest-ever infrastructure bet in the Nordic country. The company will add 20,000 GPUs at its three data centers, committing to train 250,000 in "essential AI skills." Microsoft vice chair Brad Smith praises Sweden as a leader in innovation, citing the nation's abundant green energy, and notes the company's investments are coupled with bets on renewable energy. The move aims to cement Microsoft's footprint in Sweden and capitalize on the region's low-cost electricity.

images.alt_text: The Microsoft-G42 deal is an agreement between the two companies that requires each to give security assurances to their respective home governments.

site_title: Indonesia central bank says no outright RRR cut as it expands loan incentive scheme
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, is not planning to cut the reserve requirement ratio (RRR) for banks, despite expanding a loan incentive scheme to support economic growth. The scheme allows banks to reduce their required reserve levels by up to 4%, releasing up to $9.6 billion in liquidity. Deputy Governor Juda Agung stated that the intention is to incentivize lending, but the bank will monitor liquidity levels and credit growth to ensure the policy mix does not harm domestic growth.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia will continue to sell rupiah and dollar securities to help bring in more inflows, governor Perry Warjiyo says.
Bank Indonesia governor Perry Warjiyo says total capital inflows into Indonesia had reached more than 20 trillion rupiah (S$1.7 billion) so far in May.
Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during a press conference at the Bank Indonesia's headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 17, 2024. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan

site_title: Chinese developer Poly mulls US$1.7 billion convertible bond sale
summary: Chinese property developer Poly Developments and Holdings is considering a US$1.7 billion convertible bond sale, according to people familiar with the matter. This comes as the company has yet to conduct a private placement of shares, a plan announced in December 2022. The move follows a recent rebound in Chinese equities, with Asian borrowers increasingly turning to convertibles, a practice common in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: Outstanding PSL loans stood at 2.95 trillion yuan at the end of May, compared with 3.03 trillion yuan at end-April, says the People’s Bank of China.
In Shanghai, second-hand sales last weekend were 50 per cent higher than the daily average for the month.
Commercial and residential buildings stand in the Nanshan district of Shenzhen, China, on Wednesday, Aug. 6, 2014. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

site_title: Singapore updates framework on liveability to take in changing aspirations and needs
summary: Singapore has updated its Liveability Framework to reflect changing aspirations and needs, acknowledging the city-state's rapid urbanization and population growth are manifesting in public concerns. The framework now incorporates emerging perceptions of liveability from experts and the public, focusing on factors like mental well-being, socio-economic diversity, and sustainable development. The updated framework aims to balance contesting needs and respond to changing demographics and social diversity, while also addressing the challenges of redevelopment and the diminishing availability of greenfield sites.

images.alt_text: Singapore needs land that can be easily converted to other uses: Desmond Lee

site_title: Tencent, Tencent Music to pick up 10% stake in Thailand's GMM Music for US$70 million
summary: Tencent Music Entertainment Group and its controlled entity, Tencent, have agreed to acquire a 10% stake in Thailand's GMM Music for US$70 million, valuing the company at US$700 million. This deal, part of GMM Music's spin-off plan, aims to expand its business and fund innovation. GMM Music's CEO, Phawit Chitrakorn, stated that the partnership will lead to cooperative efforts in expanding into new markets, particularly in China. The acquisition will provide GMM Music with additional resources to drive growth and innovation.

site_title: Industry observers launch non-profit to encourage better performance among SGX listcos
summary: Industry observers launched a non-profit organization, Corporate Monitor, to encourage better performance among Singapore Exchange-listed companies through research and engagement. The group, led by former KPMG partner Tan Yee Peng, aims to publish regular research reports offering "actionable intelligence" for stakeholders. Its first report analyzed transport operator ComfortDelGro, highlighting the need for the company to focus on profitability and returns rather than growing revenue. The non-profit plans to hire more analysts and secure funding to continue its research, with the goal of improving corporate governance and management in the local public market.

images.alt_text: Mak Yuen Teen says that capital market regulation and enforcement in Singapore tends to be tilted towards business interests.
Picking the right CEO, who is ethical, is crucial.

site_title: Saudi sovereign wealth fund plans sterling-denominated notes offering
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) plans to sell senior unsecured sterling-denominated dual-tranche notes with 5-year and 15-year maturities. The 5-year notes will be priced at 250bp above mid-swaps, while the 15-year notes will be priced at 325bp above mid-swaps. The offering is under the GACI First Investment Company's Euro Medium Term Note program. This move is part of Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy, driven by Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

site_title: New airports, aircraft: wealthy Gulf prepares for aviation boom
summary: The Gulf region is investing heavily in aviation infrastructure and aircraft, driven by a forecasted doubling of Middle East passenger traffic to 530 million by 2043. Dubai is building a new, world-largest airport, while Abu Dhabi and Qatar have expanded their existing airports. Saudi Arabia is also investing in new airports and airlines, including Riyadh Air and a deal for 105 Airbus aircraft. The region's unique geography and strong brands are expected to benefit from growth in Asia and the Indian subcontinent, with global airlines raising their profit outlook due to soaring travel demand.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Willie Walsh, Director General of the International Air Transport Association (IATA) speaks during an interview with Reuters in Istanbul, Turkey June 3, 2023. REUTERS/Dilara Senkaya/File Photo

site_title: Australia orders Chinese investors to sell down stake in rare earths miner
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers has ordered Chinese investors Yuxiao Fund and four associates to sell down their stakes in rare earths miner Northern Minerals within 60 days. The move aims to protect Australia's national interest and ensure compliance with its foreign investment framework. The divestment order, issued on Sunday, involves 80 million shares, which is approximately 10.4% of Northern Minerals' issued share capital. The decision follows concerns over China's growing influence in the sector, particularly for its uses in green energy and defense.

images.alt_text: Prices of rare earths surged to their highest in a decade in 2022 only to plunge last year on increased production in China and slower-than-expected demand growth crippled by the country’s patchy post-pandemic economic recovery.

site_title: US, Indo-Pacific partners holding talks in Singapore on clean energy
summary: The US-led Indo-Pacific Economic Framework (IPEF) is holding a ministerial meeting in Singapore, including a "Clean Economy" investor forum with 22 major US companies, to boost infrastructure and climate investments in the region. US Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo hopes to finalize agreements and attract multibillion-dollar investments in countries like Thailand and Malaysia, with the goal of supporting climate-related infrastructure development and achieving countries' climate goals.

images.alt_text: The investments will span areas like AI, digital upskilling, solar, nuclear projects and a new airline route to Cebu province, US Secretary of Commerce Gina Raimondo says.

site_title: UK factories return to growth, prices rise by most in a year, PMI shows
summary: UK factories reported a return to growth in May, with the S&P Global UK Manufacturing Purchasing Managers' Index rising to 51.2, its highest since July 2022. However, factory prices rose by the most in a year, with a fifth consecutive monthly acceleration in increases. The UK economy's growth is seen as a positive sign, but higher prices may prompt the Bank of England to delay cutting interest rates. The UK's economic outlook remains cautious due to political uncertainty ahead of the national election on July 4.

images.alt_text: Rapid restaurant and hotel price rises and high mortgage rates mean the richest are now suffering more from persistent inflationary pressures.
Confidence about the broader economy was at its highest since September 2021.
Supermarkets are competing to keep prices low as more shoppers opt for value, which is helping to tame grocery inflation.
Even though inflation is easing, prices are still 23 per cent higher than before the pandemic and GDP per capita is below last year’s levels.

site_title: Global airlines raise 2024 profit outlook as travel soars
summary: Global airlines have raised their 2024 profit outlook to $30.5 billion, higher than the previous upwardly revised $27.4 billion in 2023, as travel demand soars. The International Air Transport Association (IATA) attributed the improvement to a better-than-expected environment, particularly in Asia. However, the industry faces challenges, including disruption to global supply chains and high fixed costs, which may limit its ability to serve a strong rebound in travel demand.

images.alt_text: Iata director-general Willie Walsh says: "Our assessment is that it’s not getting worse but it’s not getting better either."
people queuing up at the airport with their luggage

FILE PHOTO: Delta Airlines passenger jets are pictured outside the newly completed 1.3 million-square foot $4 billion Delta Airlines Terminal C at LaGuardia Airport in the Queens borough of New York City, New York, U.S., June 1, 2022. REUTERS/Mike Segar/File Photo

site_title: AMD announces future AI chips, will speed rollout of new models
summary: AMD announces plans to release new AI chips, including the MI325X, MI350, and MI400 models, with faster data throughput and increased memory. The company aims to speed up its rollout of new AI processors, matching Nvidia's annual release cycle. AMD's new models will be compared favorably to rival offerings, and the company is targeting $4 billion in AI accelerator sales this year. Additionally, AMD's Ryzen AI processors, dubbed Strix Point, will be released in July for laptops, featuring improved performance for AI tasks.

images.alt_text: AI accelerators – a category pioneered by Nvidia – help data centres process the flood of information needed to develop artificial intelligence chatbots and other tools.
Microsoft’s clusters of AMD’s flagship MI300X AI chips will be sold through its Azure cloud computing service.
AMD is seen as a leading contender to challenge Nvidia in the market for accelerators.
AMD said the new chips are expected to be available in platforms from HP and Lenovo starting in the second quarter of 2024.

site_title: Chinese courier giant SF Holding gets regulatory nod for Hong Kong listing
summary: China's SF Holding, the country's largest express delivery company, has received regulatory approval for a second Hong Kong listing, planning to issue 625.5 million shares. This approval follows the China Security Regulatory Commission's recent easing of approval processes for listings outside the mainland. The move is seen as part of the company's expansion plans and is expected to be completed within the next year.

images.alt_text: The Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing Ltd. (HKEX) logo is displayed atop a gong at the HKEX Connect Hall in Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Most Hong Kong people were caught off-guard by Beijing's proposal of the national security bill. Executive Council Member and the Chairman of HKEX Laura Cha said she was also surprised but was convinced the bill would ensure clarity and stability of the city. Photographer: Billy H.C. Kwok/Bloomberg

site_title: Trump raises US$34.8 million in less than a day after guilty verdict
summary: Donald Trump's campaign raised $34.8 million in less than 24 hours after a Manhattan jury delivered a guilty verdict in his hush-money trial, with nearly 30% of donors being first-time contributors. This massive fundraising haul is roughly half the amount he raised in April, surpassing President Joe Biden's total. Trump has called himself a "political prisoner" and marked his conviction as the "darkest day in US history," using his legal woes to rally supporters.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump is in a close race with Democratic incumbent Joe Biden ahead of the Nov 5 presidential election.

site_title: Barrenjoey opens Abu Dhabi office as Australian bank expands
summary: Barrenjoey, an Australian investment bank, has opened its first overseas office in Abu Dhabi, allowing for extended coverage during European and US trading hours. The move marks an expansion of the firm, which now has over 350 staff across Sydney, Melbourne, and Perth. The office in Abu Dhabi enables the bank to tap into the thriving global city and its growing financial centre, which has seen a surge in assets under management. This follows other global investment banks, such as Rothschild and Morgan Stanley, opening offices in Abu Dhabi in recent years.

images.alt_text: From left: Koh Kar Siong, group head of corporate and SME banking, DBS; Cindy Khoo, managing director, EnterpriseSG; Han Kwee Juan, group executive and Singapore country head, DBS; Kok Ping Soon, CEO, SBF; and Sharon Tan, chief operating officer, DBS Singapore.

site_title: China’s biggest cities see housing market pick up after easing
summary: China's largest cities, Shanghai and Shenzhen, saw a pick-up in housing market activity after the central government eased property restrictions. In Shanghai, over 90% of new homes were sold, while in Shenzhen, existing-home sales surged 8% over the past weekend, the highest level in over three years. The improvement in market sentiment is attributed to the government's recent policy support package, with over 200 cities easing purchase restrictions and downpayment ratios. Experts expect sales to continue improving this month.

site_title: Digital bank Monzo reports first annual profit in run-up to IPO
summary: Digital bank Monzo reported its first annual profit of £15.4 million for the year to March 2024, up from a £116.3 million loss the previous year, as it expands into lending and savings products. The company has amassed 9.7 million customers since its launch in 2015 and secured £340 million in new funding, valuing the company at £4 billion. Monzo aims to become a publicly-listed company and is also exploring expansion into the US market and other European markets.

images.alt_text: Revolut offers an array of financial services through its app, including payments, foreign exchange, loans and crypto trading, with the exact mix varying market by market.

site_title: German homeowners, housebuilders pin hopes on ECB rates cut
summary: Germany's housing sector is pinning hopes on the European Central Bank (ECB) to cut interest rates, which are currently at an all-time high of 4% due to soaring inflation. Homeowners and housebuilders are struggling due to rising construction costs and stagnant demand, with investors demanding rents exceeding €20 per square meter. Analysts predict a potential rate cut could ease the housing crisis, but a sharp slowdown in sales and approvals, combined with rising prices, make the outlook uncertain.

images.alt_text: Foreign buyers accounted for 35 per cent of purchases of commercial real estate in the first quarter, data from BNP Paribas Real Estate shows.

site_title: Hong Kong home prices drop to erase gains after property tax cut
summary: Hong Kong's used home prices dropped 1.4% in the week ended May 19, erasing gains after the government removed property curbs in February. This marks the fourth consecutive week of decline, with home prices now lower than they were before the curbs were scrapped. The drop is attributed to new home projects with low prices, which have attracted demand and led to developers offering discounts to clear inventory.

site_title: DBS launches internationalisation programme to help 1,000 businesses expand overseas
summary: DBS launches the Bridging Business Horizons programme to support 1,000 Singapore businesses in expanding overseas over the next 12 months. The programme, supported by the Singapore Business Federation and Enterprise Singapore, will engage businesses in discovering new market opportunities, developing entry strategies, and deepening onshore networks. The bank will also provide financing solutions and resources from the federation and federation to help companies scale their operations. This initiative aims to help Singapore businesses overcome challenges in expanding overseas, with 57% of businesses keen on overseas expansion to capture opportunities in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: OCBC has always emphasised the importance of Great Eastern as one of its strategic pillars.
On the back of a robust first quarter, the lenders raised their forecasts for their 2024 performance.

site_title: Airlines eye ‘new frontier’ of AI ahead of global summit
summary: Airlines are embracing AI to boost productivity and gain a competitive edge, with companies like Air France-KLM investing in over 40 AI projects, including a tool that responds to customers in 85 languages. AI is being used to improve customer service, reduce wait times, and streamline airport operations. While AI is not replacing human pilots, it is being used to assist with decision-making and provide real-time data. Industry experts see AI as a key area for growth, with modern aircraft capable of generating vast amounts of data that can be leveraged with AI.

images.alt_text: Iata director-general Willie Walsh says: "Our assessment is that it’s not getting worse but it’s not getting better either."
Sale-and-leaseback transactions have long been a way for airlines globally to generate liquidity and ease the strain on their balance sheets.
The reality, statistics show, remains that getting on a Boeing or Airbus jetliner is still exponentially safer than the drive to the airport.

site_title: Toyota, other Japan automakers under fire for new lapses as safety scandal deepens
summary: Toyota and other Japanese automakers, including Mazda, Honda, and Suzuki, are under fire for new safety test scandal lapses. The Japanese transport ministry found irregularities in applications to certify models from the companies, leading to temporary halts in shipments and sales of affected vehicles. Mazda fabricated test results and tampered with units for collision testing in five models, while Honda found wrongdoing in noise and output tests on over two dozen models. Toyota has temporarily halted sales of three car models made in Japan and is investigating issues related to fuel efficiency and emissions.

images.alt_text: Automakers have been locked in a fierce price war in China’s huge but crowded auto market

site_title: Indonesia inflation drops to 2.84% in May, lower than expected
summary: Indonesia's inflation rate dropped to 2.84% in May, lower than expected. This decline is attributed to decreasing food and energy prices. Economists anticipate inflationary pressures to continue their downward trajectory as the influence of Eid al-Fitr diminishes. The lower-than-forecast rate may pose challenges for Bank Indonesia in reducing its benchmark interest rate, which could impact the country's economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Philippines recorded growth of 5.7 per cent in the first quarter of 2024 to occupy top spot in Asean.

site_title: Chinese firms jostle with US peers for sliver of Gulf oil riches
summary: Chinese firms are expanding their presence in the Middle East, competing with US peers for a share of the region's oil wealth. Chinese banks, asset managers, and hedge funds are investing billions of dollars in infrastructure upgrades, while Chinese companies are setting up branches and offices to deepen their presence. This expansion is driven by China's slowing economy and rising competition, as well as Middle Eastern governments' efforts to upgrade their infrastructure. Analysts predict that annual foreign direct investment flows between Asia and the Middle East will reach $36 billion by 2035, with Chinese firms poised to play a significant role.

images.alt_text: China’s economy has been squeezed by a protracted property crisis, which has weighed on business and consumer confidence.
The Chinese government's renewed housing policy focuses on building affordable homes and renovating run-down inner-city districts.
The EU is expected to announce EV tariffs in the coming weeks and is investigating Chinese subsidies in other areas.

site_title: Stuck in a starter home
summary: The US housing market is experiencing a "rate-lock effect," where buyers are stuck in their starter homes due to high borrowing rates and a shortage of inventory. With interest rates nearly two decades high, trading up would mean doubling or tripling monthly interest payments. As a result, families hoping to buy their first homes are locked out. The median home price has reached a record US$434,000, making it difficult for buyers to upgrade. The Federal Housing Finance Agency reports that 900,000 fewer homes changed hands last year, restricting mobility and worsening affordability.

images.alt_text: Sellers are grappling with the fact that higher-for-longer rates are choking off demand during what’s typically the key season for the market.

site_title: Donald Trump joins TikTok and rapidly wins two million followers
summary: Donald Trump has joined TikTok, attracting over 2 million followers within hours of joining the platform. The move is seen as a strategy to reach younger voters ahead of the Nov 5 presidential election, where he is in a close race with Democratic incumbent Joe Biden. Trump's campaign has vowed to "leave no front undefended" in its efforts to engage with younger voters, while TikTok has argued it will not share US user data with the Chinese government.

images.alt_text: Donald Trump owned 64.9 per cent of Trump Media & Technology Group as of Apr 26, which is worth US$5.7 billion.
No American is above the law, a jury reminded the former president emphatically as they delivered the verdict on his criminal trial in New York City, on May 30.
Donald Trump also faces federal and state charges of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election won by Biden.

site_title: Asia’s factories sustain momentum as Japan halts 11-month slump
summary: Asia's factory activity continued its expansion in May, driven by a recovery in new orders. South Korea and Japan's Manufacturing Purchasing Managers Index (PMI) returned to growth, halting months of slump. Taiwan's PMI improved to 50.9, while Vietnam's sustained its momentum above the 50 level. This growth contrasts with China's rebound, which struggled to gain traction. The expansion supports Asia's factory activity, despite ongoing global economic challenges.

site_title: All the tools the PBOC has to support China’s property sector
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has introduced a new tool to support the country's struggling property sector. The 300 billion yuan (S$55.9 billion) relending program provides cheap credit for banks to fund local-government purchases of unsold homes, aiming to chip away at excess housing stock and ease cash flow strains for developers. The program is part of a series of facilities set up by the PBOC to fight the slump, with economists predicting it could double in size before the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Housing in Ningbo, China Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The oversupply is dragging down prices at the fastest rate in a decade, giving people less reason to buy a home.
Developers have defaulted on more than US$100 billion of onshore and offshore bonds since the real estate crisis began in 2021.

site_title: KKR weighs entering private credit in Japan to challenge banks
summary: KKR is considering entering Japan's private credit market to provide an alternative to bank loans, following the firm's success in the US and Europe. Japanese companies are increasingly willing to sell non-core businesses, which can provide higher returns. KKR plans to increase offerings for institutional investors and high-net-worth individuals, and is in discussions with domestic securities companies to offer products for individual investors. The firm's head, Hiro Hirano, believes it's essential for KKR to do things itself in Japan, and the move could help the firm capitalize on the country's growing investment potential.

images.alt_text: The KKR-SingTel consortium is competing with New York-headquartered alternative investment firm Stonepeak for the stake of up to 20 per cent in STT Telemedia Global Data Centres.
PropertyGuru’s shares have now gained 38 per cent this year.

This general view shows the Sony Group Corporation company name outside the company's headquarters in Tokyo on May 2, 2024. The Japanese entertainment and electronics conglomerate will release full year earnings on May 14. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)
KKR plans to convert its newly acquired hotels in Japan into properties under Marriott International’s midscale brand, Four Points Express by Sheraton.

site_title: Sustainable Kids Market to exceed S$100,000 fundraising target for underprivileged children
summary: The inaugural Sustainable Kids Market, organized by Peace of Art, has exceeded its S$100,000 fundraising target for underprivileged children. As of June 3, the event has raised S$96,900, with the online donation drive still ongoing. The funds will support the Singapore Red Cross Society's Young Hearts programme, providing educational opportunities, mentorship, and personal development workshops to children in public rental housing. The market, held from May 25-26, featured "KidsforKids-preneurs" booths, sustainability workshops, and an art auction, with the online drive expected to raise over S$120,000 in total.

images.alt_text: Alvin Tan, Minister of State for Trade and Industry, as well as Minister of State for Culture, Community and Youth, visits Market for Good's booth. The event aims to raise funds for underprivileged children from Singapore Red Cross' Young Hearts programme.

site_title: 'Garfield' tops North American box office, 'Furiosa' fades
