summary: Garfield's animated reboot topped the North American box office in its second week of release, earning $14 million in ticket sales. This surpasses expectations. Furiosa: A Mad Max Saga, which had previously held the top spot, fell to third place. The victory marks a comeback for the animated film, which initially battled with the prequel for the top spot during the Memorial Day weekend.

site_title: South Korea factory activity expands at fastest pace in two years
summary: South Korea's factory activity expanded in May at the fastest pace in two years, driven by stronger growth in output and orders due to broadening global demand. The purchasing managers index (PMI) for manufacturers rose to 51.6 from 49.4 in April, marking the highest reading since May 2022. This growth is attributed to South Korea's exports, which have been growing since October, providing a significant boost to the trade-reliant economy's first-quarter growth.

images.alt_text: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol speaks as Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida (3rd left) and Chinese Premier Li Qiang (right) listen during a business summit at Korea Chamber of Commerce and Industry in Seoul, South Korea, May 27, 2024.
South Korea has long preferred private conglomerates such as Samsung and SK to lead investment efforts.
The Bank of Korea held its key rate at 3.50 per cent at a policy review in Seoul, as expected by all 43 analysts polled by Reuters.

site_title: A political wild card – will a felon be elected president?
summary: US presidential hopeful Donald Trump has become a convicted felon after being found guilty on all 34 counts in his hush-money case. Despite this, Trump's campaign remains strong, with many Republicans rallying to his defense. Trump's lawyers and prosecutors will meet on July 11 to argue for an appropriate sentence, but he is expected to be formally made the Republican nominee for president at the upcoming convention. A few thousand voters switching sides could make a significant difference in the outcome, with polls showing that a guilty verdict would have little impact on Trump's supporters.

images.alt_text: No American is above the law, a jury reminded the former president emphatically as they delivered the verdict on his criminal trial in New York City, on May 30.
Donald Trump also faces federal and state charges of conspiring to overturn the results of the 2020 election won by Biden.

site_title: China steps up warning to EU just days before tariff decision
summary: China has warned the European Union of potential consequences if it imposes tariffs on Chinese electric vehicles, amid ongoing trade probes into Beijing's clean-technology sector. Commerce Minister Wang Wentao stated that China will take necessary measures to safeguard its interests if the EU continues to "suppress" Chinese companies. The EU must inform Chinese EV exporters of potential tariffs by early June, which could take effect a month later. China has already launched an anti-dumping probe into European brandy and may retaliate against European cars and pork.

images.alt_text: This photograph taken on April 23, 2024, shows the European flag flying in front of the European Parliament, in Strasbourg eastern France. (Photo by FREDERICK FLORIN / AFP)
The Commission can impose provisional anti-subsidy duties nine months after the start of the probe.
China imported a total of 1.55 million tonnes of pork in 2023 with the EU accounting for more than half of the total.

site_title: Hoping to extend the land lease on your private home? Don’t count on it
summary: Residents of the Chempaka housing estate in Bedok, Singapore, are facing uncertainty as their land leases expire in 10 years. Homeowners may struggle to secure lease extensions, as the underlying landowner may not be willing to extend leases for varying periods. The government's policy of selling private housing sites on 99-year land leases allows for the land to be taken back when the lease matures, potentially limiting options for homeowners. To mitigate this risk, buyers may need to opt for units with longer remaining land lease periods, but securing extensions may be challenging due to the need for collective agreement among owners and the potential for limited financing options.

images.alt_text: Leslie Yee
Home owners said they hope to get more clarity on the fate of the land after the lease runs out.

site_title: Asia: Markets rally on renewed US rate cut hopes
summary: Asian markets surged on June 3 as a US inflation gauge dipped in April, reviving hopes of a rate cut. Hong Kong rose over 2% thanks to a surge in Chinese tech firms, while Tokyo, Shanghai, and other cities also saw significant gains. The US dollar weakened, and analysts say the Federal Reserve is unlikely to make a decision based on this single data point, despite a cautious approach to cutting interest rates too early. The rally was seen as a much-needed boost to investor sentiment after a recent pull-back.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong rose more than one per cent, while there were also gains in Shanghai, Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei, Wellington, Manila and Jakarta.

site_title: ECB to start rate cuts but sticky inflation clouds path ahead
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to cut eurozone interest rates by a quarter percentage point, starting from 3.75% on June 6, in an effort to alleviate pressure on the eurozone economy. However, sticky inflation remains a concern, with recent data showing inflation rose to 2.6% in May, exceeding expectations. The ECB's decision may not mark the start of a rapid rate-cutting cycle, with officials signaling a cautious approach to future rate reductions. ECB president Christine Lagarde's post-meeting press conference will provide guidance on the pace of future cuts.

images.alt_text: The unexpected inflation rise likely will not prevent the ECB from cutting record-high borrowing costs next week but may lead to a pause in July and slower future rate reductions.
Communicating the ECB’s intentions without locking in a specific scenario may – once again – be the biggest challenge for Lagarde.
A sentiment indicator published on Thursday (May 30) by the European Commission rose to 96 in May from 95.6 the previous month.
The imposition of fines still marks an unusually harsh step towards forcing banks to comply with the ECB’s views on how they should manage climate risks.

site_title: Gold holds steady as investors await US data for more Fed clues
summary: Gold prices remained steady on Monday at $2,326.86 per ounce as investors awaited US economic data for potential clues on the Federal Reserve's monetary policy easing this year. The personal consumption expenditures price index increased 0.3% last month, and traders now expect a 54% chance of a rate cut by September. This comes after retailers cut prices and data showed a slowdown in consumer spending, boosting the Fed's confidence in falling inflation.

images.alt_text: While gold is often considered a safeguard against inflation, higher rates increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding asset.

site_title: Japan’s May factory activity expands for first time in a year, PMI shows
summary: Japan's factory activity expanded for the first time in a year in May, with the manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 50.4 from 49.6 in April. Output and new orders remained in contraction but showed encouraging trends, with manufacturers optimistic about the year ahead. The weak yen raised input price pressures, with cost increases attributed to labor, materials, and transportation. Overall growth was modest, and demand remained subdued, prompting concerns about the impact on profit margins and the Bank of Japan's interest rate hikes.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker walks near a factory at the Keihin industrial zone in Kawasaki, Japan, March 8, 2017. REUTERS/Toru Hanai

site_title: Tens of thousands paint Madrid white after Real’s Champions League win
summary: Real Madrid fans celebrated the team's 15th European Cup title with tens of thousands painting the city of Madrid white after their 2-0 win over Borussia Dortmund in the Champions League final. The team's open-top bus was escorted through the city, and players celebrated with fans at landmarks such as the Cibeles fountain. The celebrations included a light show at the Santiago Bernabeu Stadium, with midfielder Luka Modric confirming he would stay with the club. The team's president, Florentino Perez, thanked key players, including Toni Kroos, who will retire after Euro 2024.

images.alt_text: Kylian Mbappe, the captain of the French national team, who will be available on Jun 30 when his contract with Paris Saint-Germain expires, has decided to sign for Real after seven seasons in Paris.

site_title: Trend Micro taps Nvidia software tools for AI cybersecurity offering
summary: Trend Micro is partnering with Nvidia to develop AI-powered cybersecurity tools for data centers, designed to detect intruders and protect sensitive data. The tools will utilize Nvidia's chips and aim to prevent hackers from accessing data by identifying specific AI prompts that contain sensitive information. This move follows the increasing use of AI systems in businesses to assist employees with tasks, making them a target for hackers.

site_title: China’s factory activity growth hits two-year high, Caixin PMI shows
summary: China's manufacturing activity surged in May, with the Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI reaching 51.7, its fastest pace in about two years. The sector remains robust despite a protracted property crisis, with output and new orders growing at strong paces. However, employment remained weak, and input prices rose due to rising metals and energy costs. The improvement contrasts with a surprise fall in manufacturing activity in an official survey, highlighting a mixed picture of the industry.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government's renewed housing policy focuses on building affordable homes and renovating run-down inner-city districts.
The EU is expected to announce EV tariffs in the coming weeks and is investigating Chinese subsidies in other areas.
China’s economic growth has been battered in recent years by a long-running debt crisis in the property market, which accounts for a quarter of gross domestic product.

site_title: SGX reprimands former executive chairman and CEO of Raffles Infrastructure for breaching mainboard rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reprimanded former Raffles Infrastructure Holdings executive chairman and CEO Wu Xinhua for breaching mainboard rules through misleading announcements on SGXNet between 2015 and 2018. The breaches included inflated cash balances in financial statements, considered deliberate market fraud. The Listings Disciplinary Committee (LDC) imposed a three-year ban on Wu from holding director or executive officer positions, starting from May 31.

images.alt_text: CMG20240429-HengYY02 / 王彦燕  / SGX Centre 新加坡交易所 [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.受限股票（restricted stock unit）

site_title: Japan’s firms trim spending, reflecting headwinds to growth
summary: Japanese companies reduced capital investment in the first quarter, with capital expenditures on goods excluding software falling 0.5% from the previous quarter. This decline likely signals that the economy contracted in the period, according to economists. Despite strong corporate earnings, with profits rising 15.1% and sales advancing 2.3%, the cautious stance on investment suggests concerns about persistent inflation and global uncertainties. The Bank of Japan is monitoring this shift and may consider raising interest rates again in the coming months to address the economy's challenges.

images.alt_text: The inflation strains prompted manufacturers to raise their selling prices at the fastest pace in a year last month.
Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida will instruct the government to discuss details of the new plan when he makes the announcement.
The central bank expects rising wages to push up service inflation and keep inflation durably around 2 per cent.
Low wages in Japan have long been a stumbling block to fostering sustainable consumption and broader economic growth.

site_title: Brokers’ take: KGI initiates ‘outperform’ on OUE Reit with S$0.309 target price
summary: KGI Securities has initiated an "outperform" recommendation on OUE Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit) with a 12-month target price of S$0.309, representing a 17% upside. Analyst Alyssa Tee attributes the positive recommendation to the trust's strategic initiatives, strong tenant mix, diversified portfolio, and proactive management, positioning it well for future growth and stability in the competitive real estate market. The trust's expected completion of a 255-room hotel at Changi Airport Terminal 2 by 2028 and a potential interest rate reduction also support the recommendation.

images.alt_text: OUE Reit Management said the S$75 million structured derivative transaction enables the Reit to hedge against interest rate risk.

site_title: Australia home prices continue to climb, Sydney back at record high
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.8% in May, the 16th consecutive month of growth, with prices up 8.3% from a year earlier. The national housing supply remains low, with prices climbing in major cities like Perth, Adelaide, Brisbane, and Sydney, which reached a record high of 0.6% growth, equivalent to a $12,000 monthly increase. Experts attribute the resilience to low supply and high demand, despite high interest rates and cost of living pressures.

images.alt_text: The RBA has held its cash rate at 4.35 per cent since a surprise hike in November, pointing out that aggregate demand still exceeds the economy’s supply capacity.

site_title: Rolex hikes watch prices in UK as gold costs soar to new highs
summary: Rolex has increased prices for some of its precious metal watches in the UK by 4% due to the surge in gold prices, which have reached record highs. The price of the Rolex Daytona chronograph in white gold has risen to £38,700, while the yellow gold GMT Master II has jumped to £35,400. This price hike follows previous increases in 2022, driven by major currency swings. The price of gold has surged 14% this year, and Rolex typically raises prices once a year in January.

images.alt_text: The Rolex Split-Seconds Chronograph 4113.
The timepieces include a unique FP Journe Vagabondage one Model from 2004 that commemorates each of Schumacher’s F1 championship wins.

site_title: Real estate players markedly more pessimistic on prime residential, office, business park sectors in Q1
summary: Singapore's real estate industry remains cautiously optimistic, with overall sentiment improving in Q1 2024, but pessimism grows in prime residential, office, and business park sectors. A slowdown in the global economy is the top risk, cited by 73.5% of respondents. Despite this, 27.8% expect a higher number of units to be launched in the next six months, and 72.2% expect prices to remain the same. The sentiment index reached 5.1, above the neutral score of five, for the first time in five consecutive months.

images.alt_text: The combined effects of rebounding travel activities, relaxed pandemic related restrictions, and pent-up consumer demand catalysed the revenue growth during the period, said Shangri-La Asia.
The Zion Road land parcel, which includes long-stay serviced apartments, closed with just a single bid in April.
The city fringe and suburban regions continue to see healthy resale demand.

site_title: Seatrium inks MOU with M1 to explore 5G connectivity in yards
summary: Seatrium, an offshore and marine group, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with M1 to explore 5G connectivity in its yards in Singapore. This collaboration aims to enhance yard operations with "future-proof ultra-high-speed connectivity" and may extend into other M1 services, including IoT applications and cyber security. CEO Chris Ong views this partnership as a milestone in Seatrium's digital transformation journey, aiming to foster innovation and efficiency in operations and business processes.

images.alt_text: Fortescue Green Pioneer, an ammonia-powered vessel, off Marina South Pier, April 8, 2024.
Seatrium’s current net order book stands at S$25.8 billion, comprising 31 projects with deliveries until 2030,  excluding repair and upgrade projects.
A floating production storage and offloading vessel delivered by Seatrium to Modec Offshore Production Systems (Singapore) in 2023. Seatrium has secured contracts to supply FPSO vessels to Petrobra.
Seatrium logo at their office’s lobby, Oct 19, 2023.

site_title: Chinese EV makers defy industry slump as price cuts boost sales
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers, including BYD and Nio, continued to grow sales in May despite a declining overall passenger car market. Seres Group led the pack with a 234% increase in units sold, followed by Zeekr Intelligent Technology Holding with 115% growth. BYD, the country's best-selling brand, saw a 25% increase in sales, driven by price cuts and new models. Despite challenges at home and abroad, including trade actions and tariff hikes, Chinese EV sales are expected to grow 33% to 770,000 vehicles in May, outpacing overall deliveries.

site_title: Shangri-La Dialogue’s success comes from candid discussion of thorny issues: Ng Eng Hen
summary: Singapore Defence Minister Ng Eng Hen says the Shangri-La Dialogue's success lies in frank discussions of contentious issues such as the South China Sea and Taiwan's independence. The 2024 event was a success, with high-level discussions and clear stances from countries like China and the Philippines. Ng notes that while the dialogue is not a forum for concrete outcomes, it provides a platform for defence and security professionals to engage with thorny issues and gain a deeper understanding. The event's increasing popularity has led to more speaking opportunities, but also more complex logistics.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says: "We are convinced that our world wants to be united and be capable of acting in complete harmony."

site_title: Freeport Indonesia says yet to receive copper concentrate export permit extension
summary: Freeport Indonesia, a copper miner, has not received an extension of its copper concentrate export permit until December 31, despite the government's agreement to extend it. The permit, initially set to expire on May 31, is required for companies to build domestic smelters to boost export value. Freeport is building copper smelters expected to start operation in June, which could disrupt mining activities if production is disrupted. The company warned that the export ban could result in lost revenue of up to US$2 billion for Indonesia.

images.alt_text: The logo of the state-owned oil company Pertamina is seen beside the track ahead of the MotoGP Indonesian Grand Prix at the Mandalika International Circuit in Kuta Mandalika, Central Lombok, on October 12, 2023. (Photo by Yasuyoshi CHIBA / AFP)
Freeport Indonesia, controlled by mining giant Freeport McMoran has called for the ban to be relaxed as its Gresik smelter would not be operating at full capacity by June.

site_title: RBA seen as the only other major central bank at risk of hiking
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is seen as a potential outlier in a global trend of interest rate hikes, with money markets pricing a one-in-five chance of a rate increase by the August 6 meeting. The RBA has kept the policy rate steady for six months, despite a hotter-than-expected inflation rate of 3.6% in April, and is forecast to return to its 2-3% target next year. Economists warn that a failure to slow inflation could force the RBA to hike rates, despite a slowing economy and weak consumer spending.

images.alt_text: The RBA has held its cash rate at 4.35 per cent since a surprise hike in November, pointing out that aggregate demand still exceeds the economy’s supply capacity.
The Australian dollar drifted off 0.2 per cent to US$0.6654 on Tuesday, having repeatedly failed to re-take its recent four-month top of US$0.6714.
Financial markets are now back to betting the next policy move would be down after wages and jobs data disappointed last week.
Australia's house prices rose about 9 per cent in capital cities in 2023 and priced many new buyers out of the market.
Australia's overall increase in annual wages was still just enough to take it above inflation of 3.6 per cent, a welcome return to real pay growth after years of negative outcomes.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday’s open; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.3% or 9.7 points to 3,346.29 at 9:01 am on Monday, following gains from US indexes. The most actively traded counters were Mapletree Logistics Trust and Seatrium, both up 2.3%. Local banking stocks had mixed performances, with UOB and DBS increasing, while OCBC remained flat. The gains come after US indexes rose on Friday due to month-end repositioning, and softer US inflation data encouraging interest rate cut hopes.

images.alt_text: DBS shares rose 1 per cent on Friday to end at S$35.99 – closing in on its 52-week intra-day high of S$36 touched on May 2.

site_title: Qatar Airways closes in on major Boeing, Airbus widebody order
summary: Qatar Airways is nearing a decision on a major widebody order split between Boeing and Airbus, with sources indicating the airline is considering ordering around 200 jets. The airline is looking at a mix of Airbus A350s and Boeing 777X models, with a possible decision as soon as the Farnborough Air Show in the UK late next month. The split has not been finalized, and the transaction's timing is uncertain, with no guarantee a deal will be reached. Qatar Airways currently has 74 outstanding orders for the Boeing 777X and 18 for the A350-1000.

images.alt_text: Qatar Airways says that those injured on the Boeing 787 aircraft are receiving medical attention and the incident is the subject of an internal investigation.
Badr Mohammed al-Meer, CEO of Qatar Airways, speaks during a debate at the Qatar Economic Forum in Doha on May 15, 2024. (Photo by KARIM JAAFAR / AFP)

This photograph taken on June 7, 2023, shows an Qatar Airways Airbus A320 aircraft landing at the newly opened runway of Belgrade Nikola Tesla airport. The opening of Belgrade airport's new runway marked the completion of one of the major infrastructure projects undertaken by French operator Vinci, since taking over the concession in late 2018. (Photo by Andrej ISAKOVIC / AFP)
Qatar Airways is leveraging its position as a connecting airline with its hub in Doha.

site_title:
Shein plans to file for London IPO 
as soon as this week
summary: Shein, an online fashion retailer, plans to file for a London initial public offering (IPO) as soon as this week, potentially valuing the company at £50 billion (S$86 billion). The move comes after the company's attempt to list in New York faced regulatory hurdles and pushback from US lawmakers. Shein's IPO could become one of the UK's biggest ever, following the trend of companies shifting their primary listings to London to avoid US regulatory issues. Approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission is still needed for the listing.

images.alt_text: In the latest round, eight products sold by Shein in South Korea, including children’s shoes, leather bags and a belt and found several to contain high amounts of phthalates – chemicals used to soften plastics.
Shein confidentially files for an IPO with the US Securities and Exchange Commission in November.
Shein’s platforms have attracted many third-party retailers.

site_title: Cathay Pacific looking to add more Belt and Road destinations, CEO says
summary: Cathay Pacific, Hong Kong's flagship airline, plans to add more destinations on China's Belt and Road project, with CEO Ronald Lam stating that around a quarter of its current 80 routes are Belt and Road destinations. The airline aims to reach 100% of its pre-pandemic passenger flights by the first quarter of 2025, having already reached 80% capacity in the second quarter. Cathay also plans to expand its workforce by 20% this year, following the restoration of capacity after the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Cathay’s mitigation measures include increasing the number of pilots in reserve by almost 40 per cent to up to 110 pilots a day.
FILE PHOTO: Cathay Pacific employees work at Hong Kong International Airport, in Hong Kong, China March 8, 2023. REUTERS/Lam Yik/File Photo
Cathay Pacific Flight CX739 arriving at Changi Airport Terminal 4 on September 13, 2022.
The offer is just the latest in a growing list of incentives Cathay has rolled out to tackle a chronic shortage of aircrew.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Nio, Sembcorp, Paragon Reit, Oiltek
summary: Nio delivered a record high monthly delivery of 20,544 cars in May 2024, a 233.8% year-on-year increase, with cumulative deliveries reaching 515,811 cars since inception. Sembcorp Industries added three industrial parks in Vietnam, while Paragon Reit is in negotiations to sell The Rail Mall for slightly higher than S$80 million. Oiltek secured new contracts worth RM94.8 million from Malaysia, Indonesia, and Kenya, bringing its order book to a record high of RM400.5 million.

site_title: Oil prices slip despite Opec+ production cut extension
summary: Oil prices slipped on Monday, June 3, despite Opec+ agreeing to extend deep output cuts until the end of 2025. Brent futures fell 0.3% to $80.87 a barrel, while US WTI crude futures declined 0.25% to $76.80 a barrel. The 5.86 million barrel-per-day production cut, led by Russia, accounts for 5.7% of global demand. Analysts from Goldman Sachs view the extension as bearish, citing plans to unwind extra cuts and bring back production.

images.alt_text: The so-called “voluntary” cuts from key members including Saudi Arabia and Russia, which total roughly two million barrels a day and were set to expire at the end of June, will continue until the end of 2024, the delegates say.

site_title: China’s tourists to spend nearly 6.8 trillion yuan on holidays at home
summary: China's tourists are forecast to spend a record 6.8 trillion yuan on domestic holidays this year, surpassing pre-pandemic levels for the first time. Domestic holidaymakers are expected to spend 11% higher than 2019, with Chinese visitors driving the global tourism industry. Despite international visitors to China still not rebounding, domestic travel is a strong consumption category, supporting 80 million tourism and travel jobs. China has loosened visa restrictions for visitors from Thailand, Malaysia, and Singapore to boost tourism and investment.

images.alt_text: The Chinese government's renewed housing policy focuses on building affordable homes and renovating run-down inner-city districts.
The small increase of quotas under the QDII programme – totalling just US$2.27 billion – reflects regulators’ caution that additional money outflows could further pressure a weakening yuan.
The EU is expected to announce EV tariffs in the coming weeks and is investigating Chinese subsidies in other areas.
The survey-based jobless rate for 16-to-24 year-olds, excluding college students, was 14.7 per cent in April, down from 15.3 per cent in March.

site_title: Green fuel transition presents retrofitting opportunity for shipyards, with some caveats
summary: Shipyards are exploring opportunities to retrofit older vessels to use near-zero-carbon fuels such as methanol and ammonia, as the shipping industry transitions to cleaner energy by 2050. Despite growing interest, the market may be constrained by cost and design challenges, with only 63% of existing vessels expected to adopt alternative fuels. Shipowners may be hesitant to retrofit vessels older than 10 years, and the industry is likely to prioritize interim decarbonization solutions such as drop-in fuels and onboard carbon capture technologies.

images.alt_text: X-Press Feeders' cargo vessel Eco Maestro (middle) simultaneously taking on cargo at Tuas Port and being refuelled with methanol by bunker ship MT Kara  (right).
Generic photos of ports and martime in Singapore
Teo Eng Dih, the chief executive of the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, outlined some of Singapore's latest efforts in moving toward cleaner marine fuels at Singapore Maritime Week 2024.
Transport Minister Chee Hong Tat announces a new facility which will allow global maritime personnel to gain competency in the use of cleaner marine fuels.

site_title: S&P 500 losing steam going into June
summary: The S&P 500 index is losing steam heading into June, driven by rising US Treasury yields and concerns about large-cap tech's performance. Despite a strong year-to-date gain of 10%, the equal-weighted index has only gained 3%. Investors remain optimistic, with short-term inflation data potentially leading to short-term volatility but allowing the uptrend to remain intact. A bearish scenario suggests the index may correct further if it fails to hold above the 100-day SMA level, potentially retesting the 5,000 psychological level.

images.alt_text: Almost all of the major S&P 500 sectors are higher, with the energy sector up 2.5 per cent.

site_title: Nio delivers record 20,544 vehicles in May, up 233.8% year on year
summary: Nio delivered a record 20,544 vehicles in May 2024, a 233.8% year-over-year increase, with 12,164 premium smart electric sports utility vehicles and 8,380 premium smart electric sedans. The company's cumulative deliveries since inception reached 515,811 cars by the end of May. This marks a 51% year-over-year increase in deliveries for the January to May period. Nio's shares rose 8.1% ahead of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Nio is primarily listed on the New York Stock Exchange, with secondary listings in Hong Kong and Singapore.
FSD sales in China would open a new source of revenue for Tesla, which has seen its sales volumes there fall by 7.6 per cent in the first four months of the year.
“Electric vehicles are very important for positive development of the environment, they should never be used as a political target,” Nio founder William Li said.

site_title: Philippines and Vietnam’s robust Q1 growth leaves Thailand in the dust
summary: The Philippines and Vietnam have maintained their economic momentum, recording growth of 5.7% and 5.66% respectively in the first quarter of 2024, outperforming Thailand with 1.5% growth. Despite missing economists' expectations, both countries are expected to continue growing, with the Philippines' growth forecasted to reach 5.9% and Vietnam's to pick up in the second half of the year. However, inflation and currency depreciation pressures loom, with the Philippines facing high food inflation and the Philippine peso reaching an 18-month low.

images.alt_text: Thailand beat its tourism target in 2022 with 11.15 million foreign visitors. Pre-pandemic 2019 saw a record of nearly 40 million foreign tourists, who spent 1.91 trillion baht (S$75 billion).
Indonesia, once a major exporter of natural resources, is now facing slowing demand due to weakening prices of mainstay commodities such as palm oil.
Trade-reliant Vietnam's exports in March surge by 14.2 per cent from a year ago to roughly US$34.01 billion.

site_title: China lands spacecraft on far side of the moon
summary: China successfully landed the Chang'e-6 lunar lander on the far side of the moon on June 2, marking the country's second mission to the far side, following the Chang'e-4 mission in 2019. The lander touched down in the South Pole-Aitken basin, a massive impact crater about 2575 kilometers wide. The mission aims to collect samples and provide insights into the moon's history, including the differences between the far and near sides of the moon. The probe will gather rocks, soil, and subsurface samples for about two days.

images.alt_text: moon, sky, luna
The JPL-built robotic rover Perseverance has been collecting mineral samples since 2021 from the floor of an ancient Martian lake bed called Jezero Crater.
China in 2019 became the first and so far only country to land on the moon’s far side.

site_title: Global banks start targeting a new breed of real estate risk
summary: Global banks are introducing new lending criteria to assess the carbon emissions of commercial real estate (CRE) properties, with some targeting reductions of up to 41% by 2030. The EU's Energy Performance of Buildings Directive aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in the building sector by 60% by 2030, and banks are adapting their lending practices to meet this goal. Some banks, such as BNP Paribas, are exploring synthetic securitisations to shield themselves from potential higher capital costs associated with emissions. The move is expected to shape the sector's access to financing and may lead to private markets being used to offload risk.

images.alt_text: Fortescue Green Pioneer, an ammonia-powered vessel, off Marina South Pier, April 8, 2024.

site_title: Women directorships highest on record across three sectors in 2023
summary: Women now hold 23.7% of directorships across top 100 SGX-listed companies, IPCs, and statutory boards, a threefold increase from 2013. This surpasses the global average of 23.3%. Women's participation on boards has also increased in IPCs and statutory boards, reaching 20% and 15% respectively. The top 100 issuers are closer to achieving the voluntary target of 25% women on boards by 2025, with half the group exceeding this target by the end of 2023. Regulatory frameworks have improved, with issuers required to set a board diversity policy since January 2022.

images.alt_text: President Halimah Yacob, who is a patron of the Council for Board Diversity, said at its fifth anniversary event on Thursday (Aug 31) that the work to improve gender board diversity is not complete.

site_title: Hong Kong says 11 crypto exchanges are closer to getting permits
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has deemed 11 cryptocurrency exchanges, including Crypto.com and Bullish, as licensed to operate in the city. The move comes as part of efforts to expand the roster of permitted exchanges and foster a digital-asset hub, with a focus on investor protection and anti-money laundering measures. The city aims to compete with Dubai and Singapore as a digital-asset center, despite strict rules that have deterred some prominent exchanges, including Binance and Coinbase.

images.alt_text: The agreement marks a major step forward for Tether in its plan to become a major Bitcoin miner.

site_title: Cheong Soo Pieng work doubles estimates at Christie’s auction; Sotheby’s shows Georgette Chen orchids
summary: Cheong Soo Pieng's artwork "Mother And Child" (1973) sold for HK$655,200 (S$113,230) at Christie's Hong Kong auction, more than doubling its pre-sale estimate. Other notable sales include Georgette Chen's "Still Life With Star Fruit" (c. 1946-50) for HK$6.6 million and Jane Lee's "It Is As It Is, Wall Series #1" (2019) for HK$189,000. The sales reflect increasing appreciation for South-east Asian art, with collectors from Asia and worldwide showing interest in regional artists.

images.alt_text: The Russian billionaire Dmitry Rybolovlev, seen here in 2018, at his penthouse in Monte Carlo. He is accusing Sotheby's of helping an art dealer trick him into wildly overspending for artworks.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Untapped potential in Islamic investing (Ep 171)
summary: Islamic investing is gaining popularity, with competitive returns available to everyone, regardless of faith. Sukuks, a type of Islamic bond, are the most popular investment product, offering attractive returns. Singapore is emerging as a key Islamic finance hub, with a potential to become an offshore Islamic wealth hub in the next five years. Investors should look out for trends such as Shariah-compliant investing, Sukuk-based investments, and the growth of Islamic financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Family reasons coupled with a matured ecosystem are the key reasons that attract global investors to Singapore when comes to choosing their offshore investment destination in Islamic finance.

site_title: Asia’s sleeping giant India ‘especially appealing’ as reforms drive growth resurgence
summary: India is poised to become the world's third-largest economy by 2027, driven by reforms and expected to surpass China. The country's growth rate reached 8% in the last quarter of 2023, outperforming emerging markets. India's equity market has also outperformed peers, with the MSCI India index returning 21% last year. Experts warn that the market may be overvalued, advising investors to adopt a sector-based approach. The Narendra Modi administration is expected to secure a third term, bolstering confidence in India's reform-led growth.

images.alt_text: The US Department of Agriculture’s Foreign Agricultural Service predicts India wheat imports at 2 million tonnes in the season that began on Apr 1 on steady local demand.

FILE — An electric scooter factory in Tamil Nadu, India, on Aug. 24, 2022. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has kept India on its swift upward path among the world’s largest economies. Many Indians are better off, though wealth gaps have widened. (Atul Loke/The New York Times)
A listing date for Jio Financial Services is widely expected to be announced at Reliance’s forthcoming annual general meeting.
The Adani Group headquarters in Ahmedabad, India. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg
FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A Reserve Bank of India (RBI) logo is seen inside its headquarters in Mumbai, India, April 6, 2023. REUTERS/Francis Mascarenhas/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo/File Photo
Modi’s political opponents and international rights campaigners have long sounded the alarm on India’s shrinking democratic space.
Indian stocks have trailed their Asian peers this month amid concerns that Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s party may not secure a landslide victory it aims for in the polls.

site_title: Jet supply chain headaches may still be here in 2026: Iata
summary: Iata director-general Willie Walsh says supply chain issues for new aircraft deliveries may persist into 2026, with wait times stretching several months and in some cases, years. Airlines are frustrated with the delays, which are delaying growth plans and opportunities. Despite supply chain headaches, sustainability remains a focus, particularly the inadequate supply of sustainable aviation fuel. Walsh notes that stick-like approaches to meeting fuel demands are having a negative economic impact. The issues are expected to continue through 2025 and into 2026, with no clear improvement in sight.

images.alt_text: Sale-and-leaseback transactions have long been a way for airlines globally to generate liquidity and ease the strain on their balance sheets.

site_title: Can Sats make good on its global promise?
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based air cargo and ground handler, reported a return to profitability with earnings of S$56.4 million for FY2024, driven by the incorporation of global air cargo logistics provider WFS, which Sats acquired in 2023. WFS contributed S$2.91 billion in revenue and S$187.2 million in operating profit. Despite the integration, Sats' shares have not yet reflected the value of the acquisition, with shareholders being roughly 17% poorer. To prove the acquisition's worth, Sats' management must improve profitability metrics and demonstrate continued growth.

images.alt_text: Post WFS acquisition, Sats has gained opportunities it wouldn't be able to seize says Kerry Mok, chief executive of Sats

Revenue for the period more than doubled to S$2.7 billion, from S$963.8 million the year earlier, primarily driven by the consolidation of WFS, which has given the group increased market share and generated network synergies.
The Big Money newsletter aims to pull together highlights of the past week in financial markets – helping readers make money, or avoid losing it.

site_title: Inchcape eyes deals with big Chinese automakers to drive Apac ‘growth engine’
summary: Inchcape, a global automotive distribution company, is focusing on expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region through major acquisitions made in 2023, which are already driving revenue growth. The company aims to maintain its growth by partnering with major Chinese automakers and riding the electric vehicle (EV) wave. Regional CEO Ruslan Kinebas described Apac as the "growth engine of the world" and a key area for Inchcape's expansion.

images.alt_text: China has become an electric vehicle (EV) behemoth as a result of a concerted effort to go all-in on EVs more than a decade ago.
Category B Certificate of Entitlement premiums have increased 2.9 per cent to S$105,002.
The BYD logo is displayed on a car during the media day of the 91st Geneva Auto Show, in Geneva, Switzerland, February 26, 2024. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse
The Porsche Studio, located at Guoco Midtown on Beach Road, will be the German luxury carmaker's sole retail outlet in Singapore.
The MG Cyberster was displayed at the Singapore Motorshow 2024, and could be the first electric sports coupe from a mainstream brand here if it goes on sale.

site_title: Ships diverted from Red Sea send ripple effects across the globe
summary: A global shipping crisis is unfolding due to attacks in the Red Sea, causing ships to divert around Africa's Cape of Good Hope. This has led to increased delivery times, congestion in ports, and higher freight rates. The ripple effect is felt across the globe, particularly in Europe and the US East Coast, where goods are traveling from China. The crisis is exacerbated by strong demand in the US and Asia, and analysts predict it could worsen before peak shipping season. Spot shipping rates have surged, and air cargo rates are also rising, as the interconnected system struggles to return to balance.

images.alt_text: OAKLAND, CALIFORNIA - MAY 21: In an aerial view, a container ship sits docked at the Port of Oakland on May 21, 2024 in Oakland, California. Container shipping rates have surged nearly 30 percent as ships continue to be diverted from the Red Sea due to attacks by Iran-backed Houthi rebels.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Opec+ agrees to extend oil output cuts in bid to support prices
summary: Opec+ has agreed to extend its oil supply cuts until the end of 2024, totaling roughly two million barrels a day, to support prices and avoid a global surplus. The "voluntary" cuts, which were set to expire at the end of June, will continue until the end of 2024, with a separate agreement to cap crude output until the end of 2025. The United Arab Emirates will receive a 300,000 barrel-a-day production boost for next year.

images.alt_text: The government is selling 1.545 billion Aramco shares, representing a 0.64 per cent stake, at a price range of 26.70 to 29 riyals apiece.

site_title: New sponsors of Ara H-Trust, Cromwell E-Reit unlikely to quickly lift their depressed valuations
summary: New sponsors of Ara H-Trust and Cromwell E-Reit have acquired control of the property trusts, marking the beginning of a new phase of growth and development. However, the change in control comes after a protracted period of underperformance, and investors may have mixed feelings about the sale. If the new sponsors fail to quickly generate better returns, minority investors may face a backlash, potentially eroding confidence in the external-manager model and fueling calls for manager internalisation initiatives. The new sponsors aim to focus on their core competencies and enhance their business profiles, but it remains unclear if they can unlock value for minority investors.

images.alt_text: ESR received a non-binding and conditional proposal, which may lead to its privatisation and its delisting from the Hong Kong Stock Exchange.
Cromwell E-Reit holds more than 110 properties worth EUR2.3 billion scattered across Europe
The ARA Private Funds business primarily comprises finite-life funds that own assets in traditional real estate sectors, including office, retail, and hospitality.
Cromwell E-Reit to pivot to logistics for growth
Stoneweg Group will become the Reit’s new sponsor following the transaction.
Acrophyte Asset Management intends to acquire all 1.5 million shares in the capital of Ara Trust Management and all 50,000 shares in the capital of Ara Business Trust Management (USH).

site_title:
Canadian dollar gains despite GDP miss 
as US bond yields ease
summary: The Canadian dollar rose 0.3% to 1.3640 to the US dollar on Friday, despite a weaker-than-expected GDP report, as US bond yields eased following weaker-than-expected US personal spending data. The loonie's gain was attributed to a softer US dollar and lower Treasury yields. The Bank of Canada is expected to cut interest rates, with 80% chance of a rate cut on June 5, according to swaps market data, and a dovish outlook for Canadian rates reinforced a bearish stance on the CAD.

images.alt_text: Canadian one hundred dollar banknotes are arranged for a photograph in Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg
The dollar index was last down 0.39 per cent at 104.36.

site_title: US homebuyers are starting to revolt over steep prices
summary: US homebuyers are increasingly revolting against steep prices, with demand stifled by higher mortgage rates. Listings are rising, but buyers are staying away, causing sellers to cut asking prices. The average 30-year mortgage rate has hovered near 7% since April, and prices continue to climb. Sales of new homes and existing contracts have fallen, leading to stagnant listings and a buyer's market. Experts predict price growth could slow, but pent-up demand from millennials may keep the market buoyed.

images.alt_text: The pending sales report tends to be a leading indicator of sales of previously owned homes because houses typically go under contract a month or two before they are sold.

site_title: Three more men in S$3 billion money laundering case deported to Cambodia, Japan
summary: Three men convicted in Singapore's largest money laundering case have been deported. Su Baolin and Su Haijin, both from Fujian, China, were deported to Cambodia, while Vang Shuiming, also from Fujian, was deported to Japan. The three men were sentenced to 14 months to 13 months and six weeks' jail and barred from re-entering Singapore. This marks the fifth deportation of the eight convicted money launderers in the case.

images.alt_text: Su Jianfeng now faces 14 charges in total in Singapore’s biggest money laundering case involving more than S$3 billion in assets.

site_title: Where the iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index sits within the Reit sector
summary: The iEdge S-Reit Leaders Index, the most liquid representation of Singapore's Reit market, has declined 12.3% for the year to May 29, with a total return of -9.5%. The index's 22 constituents have generated varying returns, ranging from 1.3% for Aims Apac Reit to -25.2% for CapitaLand China Trust. Despite this decline, the index still has a trailing-12-month distribution yield of 6.5%.

images.alt_text: Retail investors spent over $760 million in net buy activities in the first four months of this year.

site_title: London ‘doing well and thriving’ in post-Brexit era: Lord Mayor
summary: The City of London is "doing well and thriving" in the post-Brexit era, according to Lord Mayor Michael Mainelli. Despite the UK's general election on July 4, Mainelli expects little disruption to policies. The City has grown to 615,000 workers and now manages around 14% of global assets, a slight increase from 12%. Mainelli emphasized the importance of building global collaboration in fintech, AI, and green finance, particularly with Singapore, a trusted partner for the City of London. A change of government is expected, but Mainelli believes it will not affect the work of his office.

images.alt_text: The Lord Mayor of the City of London Michael Mainelli delivers a speech next to Britain's Foreign Secretary David Cameron during the annual Lord Mayor's Easter Banquet at Mansion House in London, Britain, May 9, 2024. REUTERS/Peter Cziborra

site_title: More awareness needed for transition bonds issued by coal miners, oil producers
summary: China's steel industry, accounting for 15% of its total carbon emissions, may benefit from transition bonds to decarbonize. Transition bonds, unlike green bonds, target sectors that are hard to abate, such as steel and cement. Despite having a poor reputation, transition bonds could gain traction with proper incentives and standards. Three main drivers for transition bonds are issuer incentives, push for domestic issuances, and continued demand for fossil fuels. The growth in renewable energy is unlikely to be the main driver for a successful energy transition, and transition bonds could provide an avenue for companies to change their ways.

images.alt_text: Leaves.

The Illawarra metallurgical coal project owned by Australian mining and metals company South32 is in the process of being sold as the company focuses on commodities critical in the transition to a low-carbon future.
Transition finance is crucial for South-east Asia as it has yet to wean itself off fossil fuels

site_title: Bursts of free power raise red flags for green tech investors
summary: Negative wholesale prices in Europe's power markets have surged, with a 12-fold increase in occurrences last year, raising concerns among green tech investors about the viability of renewable power investments. The phenomenon, where supply exceeds demand and producers must do something with excess energy, has led to a record share of clean electricity being generated. To mitigate this, producers and investors are exploring ways to store excess energy, such as building more batteries, with the goal of creating a more stable market. The growth of negative prices is expected to continue, with some predicting a sevenfold increase in energy storage capacity by decade's end.

images.alt_text: The danger is that the storms can inject direct current into alternating current transmission lines, as well as sending low pulses of electricity through things like railroad tracks and pipelines.

site_title: Ukraine’s Zelensky dominates Asia security conference as China, Taiwan trade barbs
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky dominated the Asia security conference in Singapore, calling for international unity and support for a peace summit in Switzerland aimed at ending the war in Ukraine. China's Defence Minister Dong Jun warned that Taiwan's prospects for independence were being eroded, and promised to ensure the island would never gain independence. The two leaders held talks, with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin reaffirming the US commitment to supporting Ukraine. The Shangri-La Dialogue, Asia's biggest security conference, highlighted tensions between China, Taiwan, and Ukraine, with China and Russia working to disrupt peace efforts.

images.alt_text: During the meeting with his Chinese counterpart, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin expressed concern about Chinese military activity near Taiwan, including after the island’s presidential election and the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te this month.

site_title: Wall Street lands on India, looking for profits it can’t find in China
summary: India's stock market has surged, with global investors seeking profits in the country, which has become a promising destination for growth. The Mumbai market has attracted big global investors, including North American pension managers, sovereign wealth funds, and Japanese banks, drawn by India's reliable growth, stable currency, and fiscal discipline. Despite uncertainties, India's economy is among the fastest-growing in the world, with a large population and growing middle class. Foreign investors are optimistic about India's potential, with some experts predicting a new cycle of investment activity in healthcare technology, clean energy, and artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: FILE — An electric scooter factory in Tamil Nadu, India, on Aug. 24, 2022. Prime Minister Narendra Modi has kept India on its swift upward path among the world’s largest economies. Many Indians are better off, though wealth gaps have widened. (Atul Loke/The New York Times)

site_title: Thailand probes cybercrime ring’s assets of over one billion baht
summary: Thai authorities, in cooperation with US authorities, are investigating assets worth over 1 billion baht (S$37 million) linked to a Chinese superhacker, Wang Yunhe, who allegedly channelled his cybercrime profits into the country. Assets seized include cash, luxury watches, a car, and land deeds, totaling 88 million baht. Wang was arrested in Singapore on May 24 and charged with deploying malware and operating a residential proxy service. Thai authorities will seek a court order to temporarily seize assets once US officials submit a formal request.

site_title: Ex-Chelsea coach Jose Mourinho to manage Turkey’s Fenerbahce
summary: Jose Mourinho, a former Chelsea coach and two-time Champions League winner, has signed a deal to manage Turkey's Fenerbahce Futbol AS. The announcement was teased by the team, and Mourinho addressed the fans in a video, stating "Let's start our journey together." This marks Mourinho's return to coaching after a brief retirement.

images.alt_text: Kylian Mbappe, the captain of the French national team, who will be available on Jun 30 when his contract with Paris Saint-Germain expires, has decided to sign for Real after seven seasons in Paris.

site_title: Nvidia announces next-generation Rubin AI platform for 2026
summary: Nvidia announces its next-generation Rubin AI platform for 2026, promising 98% cost savings and 97% less energy required compared to traditional computing methods. The company's CEO, Jensen Huang, emphasizes the importance of accelerated computing in addressing "computation inflation" and notes that those without AI capabilities will be left behind. Nvidia plans to upgrade its AI accelerators every year, with a Blackwell Ultra chip set for 2025, and will offer tools and pretrained AI models to help software makers bring more capabilities to PCs. The Rubin platform is expected to play a major role in the shift towards generative AI in personal computers.

images.alt_text: Nvidia is heavily weighted on the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq and has been pivotal in driving US stocks to record highs.

site_title: ‘It’s about supporting the very end of war’: Ukraine’s Zelensky seeks Asia’s backing for its peace plan
summary: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky made a call for international support for Kyiv's peace plan at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore, citing the international community's respect for the rules-based order and human life. He urged leaders to help his people end the war with Russia, which is into its third year, and emphasized that diplomacy works when it aims to protect lives. Zelensky's speech came amid fresh Russian offensives, a fortnight before the Ukraine-backed peace summit on June 15 and 16 in Switzerland.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky says: "We are convinced that our world wants to be united and be capable of acting in complete harmony."

site_title: Saudi Aramco’s US$12 billion stock offer sells out in hours
summary: Saudi Aramco's US$12 billion stock offer sold out in hours after the government opened the deal, with all 1.545 billion shares being snapped up at a price range of 26.70 to 29 riyals apiece. The sale valued Aramco at approximately US$1.8 trillion, with the stock falling 2.9% to 28.30 riyals. The sale is a boon to the government, which aims to use the funds for a massive economic transformation plan.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of the Organization of the Petroleoum Exporting Countries (OPEC) is seen outside of OPEC's headquarters in Vienna, Austria April 9, 2020.  REUTERS/Leonhard Foeger//File Photo

site_title: Untested ETFs pitched to investors as hedge against global chaos
summary: A group of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) claims to offer a hedge against global chaos by excluding companies that threaten national security or are vulnerable to state takeover or US sanctions. These funds, with assets ranging from $8 million to $800 million, track emerging markets and have outperformed other funds in certain periods. The logic behind these ETFs remains untested, and their effectiveness as a hedge against geopolitical uncertainty is unclear.

images.alt_text: The German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, May 27, 2024.     REUTERS/Staff

site_title: The Tang group ventures into the S-Reit sector
summary: The Tang group, led by Gordon Tang, is acquiring the managers of ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) and increasing its stake to 28.3%. This marks Acrophyte Pte Ltd's first venture into Reit management. The deal is valued at US$34,162,198 and is expected to be completed by Q2-Q3 2024.

images.alt_text: CMG20240408-HengYY03 / ÍõÑåÑà / SGX Centre ÐÂ¼ÓÆÂ½»Ò×Ëù [Shenton Way] SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.ÊÜÏÞ¹ÉÆ±£¨restricted stock unit£©

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for May 31, 2024, indicates a mixed market performance across various segments. The Capesize market experienced a positive week, with the C5 index rising $1.15 to $11.135, driven by increased coal cargoes from Indonesia and East Coast Australia. In contrast, the Panamax market declined, with rates easing across the board, while the Ultramax/Supramax market remained lackluster. The Suezmax market saw an upward turn, with the 130,000 mt Nigeria/UK Continent trip rate increasing 4 points to WS114.89. Aframax rates also improved, with the 80,000 mt Cross-UK Continent rate dipping 3 points to a fraction above WS150.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (May 24, 2024).

site_title: How to thrive at work if your older boss expects hustle culture
summary: Millennials are known for their devotion to hustle culture, characterized by multiple jobs and side hustles. However, Gen Z and some younger Millennials are seeking a better work-life balance, prioritizing mental health and well-being over financial stability. To thrive in the modern workplace, younger professionals can take steps such as setting clear boundaries, prioritizing tasks, and recognizing that not every workplace is ideal. By being conscious of mental well-being and seeking out workplaces that value employee well-being, Gen Z can navigate the challenges of hustle culture and find success on their own terms.

site_title: Gold posts fourth monthly rise on Fed rate cut hopes
summary: Gold prices eased 0.7% on Friday as investors digested the US inflation report, which was largely in line with estimates. Despite the mixed news, gold remains on track for its fourth straight monthly gain, with prices up 1.8% for the month. Traders expect a possible rate cut by the Federal Reserve in September, which could support gold prices.

images.alt_text: Gold prices have gained 2.7 per cent so far this month after hitting a record high of US$2,449.89 on May 20.

site_title: Ukraine is running short of people
summary: Ukraine is facing a significant manpower shortage due to migration, conscription, and the war with Russia. The country's workforce has shrunk by 27% from pre-war levels, with millions fleeing the war, joining the army, or falling in battle. This has led to labor shortages in various sectors, including factories, construction sites, and restaurants. As a result, wages are expected to exceed pre-war levels, and businesses are struggling to hire workers. The government is trying to replenish military ranks, but the shortage poses a challenge to the economy, which has already lost a quarter of its output since the invasion began.

images.alt_text: The Biden administration is stepping up warnings about China’s backing for Moscow.

site_title: Moderna’s RSV shot wins FDA approval for use in older adults
summary: Moderna's RSV vaccine, mRESVIA, has received FDA approval for use in older adults, marking the company's second approved product after Covid-19 shots. The vaccine targets respiratory syncytial virus, a flu-like illness that affects elderly adults and babies most severely. The approval comes after a delayed decision due to "administrative constraints" at the FDA. The move is seen as a step for Moderna to diversify its portfolio and move beyond Covid-19 reliance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A sign marks the headquarters of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19) vaccine maker Moderna in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., April 28, 2022.   REUTERS/Brian Snyder/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A sign marks the headquarters of Moderna Inc in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., May 18, 2020.   REUTERS/Brian Snyder//File Photo
Metagenomi will aim to list on the Nasdaq under the symbol “MGX”.

site_title: World crop trade eyes India as new government may relax curbs
summary: India, the world's fifth-largest economy, is expected to relax its trade policies after a new government assumes office, potentially easing global food prices. The country has kept key crops like sugar and rice off the global market for over a year, and Prime Minister Narendra Modi's administration has been criticized for not cutting taxes on wheat imports. A shift in restrictions could ease Asian benchmark rice prices and add to a downturn in sugar, while a rally in Chicago wheat could be further stoked if import levies are cut.

images.alt_text: The US$1.3 billion industry produces popular Ceylon Tea and employs about 615,000 workers.

Women stand in a line to cast their votes at a polling station during the fourth phase of India's general election, in Rangareddy district in the southern state of Telangana, India, May 13, 2024. REUTERS/Almaas Masood
New Delhi has imposed a 20 per cent export duty on parboiled rice exports in August 2023 to control domestic rice prices.

site_title: Hunting for edible plants with London's urban foragers
summary: In east London, a tour guide and park ranger, Kenneth Greenway, leads foraging courses at Tower Hamlets Cemetery Park, teaching people how to identify edible plants. The cemetery's unique environment, with over 100 years of undisturbed growth, allows for a diverse range of wild herbs and plants to thrive. Participants, including a 59-year-old mother and daughter, learn about 10+ edible plants, including wild rocket, nettle, and lemon balm, and gain confidence in foraging for food. The courses are in high demand, with Greenway saying the recent surge in interest is likely due to the pandemic.

images.alt_text: Grow your own : If the right infrastructure is in place, one can grow a surprising amount of produce, reducing reliance on shop-bought. Zero preservatives, zero packaging, zero food miles.

site_title: Boeing executives unlikely to be charged for 737 Max crashes
summary: US Justice Department officials told families of 737 Max crash victims that current or former Boeing executives are unlikely to be prosecuted due to the five-year deadline for bringing criminal charges. The department has not made a decision on whether to charge Boeing itself. Possible penalties for Boeing may include fines, forfeiture, restitution, and a federally appointed monitor. This decision comes two weeks after the company was informed that it had violated a deferred-prosecution agreement signed in 2021.

images.alt_text: Until the Alaska Airlines incident, Boeing appeared poised to exit a period of financial hardship following the MAX crashes and the Covid-19 downturn.

Boeing’s jet production has slowed dramatically in the face of increased scrutiny from regulators, airlines and lawmakers following a January incident when a door plug blew off an Alaska Airlines jetliner while in mid-air.
Boeing has faced mounting questions after a door panel detached during a Jan 5 flight on a new Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9.

site_title: China’s housing crash could set back millions of promising careers
summary: China's housing market crash has severely impacted millions of young professionals, forcing many to abandon their careers in the property sector. The sector's economic weight is expected to shrink to 16% of China's GDP by 2026, threatening 5 million jobs. Unemployment and reduced incomes are on the rise, with the youth unemployment rate reaching 15.3%. Former workers describe the industry as "abandoned" and "no future." While some local governments have relaxed measures to cool speculation, the situation remains severe, with protesters taking to the streets to voice discontent over construction worker pay and delayed projects.

images.alt_text: Housing in Ningbo, China Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg
The oversupply is dragging down prices at the fastest rate in a decade, giving people less reason to buy a home.
Developers have defaulted on more than US$100 billion of onshore and offshore bonds since the real estate crisis began in 2021.

site_title: Here’s how to prepare for flexible work arrangements if you are an employer
summary: Employers in Singapore should prepare for the Tripartite Guidelines on Flexible Work Arrangement Requests, which require them to consider employees' formal requests for flexible work arrangements from December 1, 2024. Employers must have clear policies in place and can only reject requests with reasonable business grounds. To be prepared, employers should review their policies, systems, and processes ahead of the effective date, and be ready to consider various types of flexible work arrangements, including flexible place of work, hours, and workloads.

images.alt_text: Women are stereotyped as better-equipped to take on care-giving duties, while men feel the pressure to be breadwinners.
Employers are not obliged to accede to all FWA requests “due to practical reasons and constraints,” said SNEF.

Co-chairs of the tripartite workgroup – (from left) SNEF honorary secretary, Edwin Ng; Minister of State for Manpower, Gan Siow Huang; and NTUC assistant secretary-general and director of U SME and U Women and Family, Yeo Wan Ling – at McDonald's Ridout Tea Garden, where they launched new guidelines for flexi-work arrangements.

site_title: Europe: Shares post quarterly loss as markets await French elections
summary: European shares closed 0.2% lower, extending losses to the fourth straight session, amid French political uncertainties following President Macron's call for a snap election. The Stoxx 600 recorded its first quarterly loss in three, with the CAC 40 index losing 0.7% and the risk premium on French government bonds hitting its highest since 2012. Technology stocks rose 0.4% as a softer inflation reading firmed bets of a September rate cut from the Federal Reserve.

images.alt_text: US President Joe Biden’s performance in a debate with predecessor Donald Trump was widely criticised by observers, who said it raised concerns the president is too old to run again.

site_title: ‘Inconceivable’ that topic of climate change will somehow go away: MSCI president
summary: MSCI President Baer Pettit says the company's ESG and climate business is likely to be "material" in the future, following a 16% increase in revenue from the segment in the first quarter of 2024. Pettit believes climate change will continue to be a major issue, with governments and companies making commitments to address it. He notes that the ESG ratings provided by MSCI are intended to help investors understand portfolio risks and returns, and that they have outperformed over a longer time horizon. Pettit is optimistic about the demand for MSCI's ESG and climate offerings, which he believes will continue to grow despite some backlash.

images.alt_text: Newly created funds will need to comply immediately, while existing ESG funds will be subject to a nine-month window to either prove compliance or abandon the label.
City Developments stock slipped 2.2 per cent after MSCI said it would be dropped from the Singapore index.
There is evidence of a positive relationship between a company’s greenhouse emissions and the perceived risk associated with that company.
Henry Fernandez, chief executive officer of index provider MSCI, said that climate risk is going to lead to the biggest repricing of assets and reallocation of capital in the history of the world.

site_title: Crunch some crickets: Insects on the menu at some bars and restaurants in Singapore
summary: Singaporean restaurants and bars are preparing to offer insect-based dishes, with some already serving items like pan-fried mealworms and cricket-topped sushi. The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) is expected to release a regulatory framework for insect sales in July, which is now expected to be released later than initially planned. Ahead of this, several establishments, including House of Seafood and Tung Lok Group, have created insect-infused dishes, indicating keen interest from customers. Once approved, these restaurants plan to expand their offerings to include 30 and 8 dishes, respectively.

images.alt_text: Cricket chips by CricketOne's sister brand Rec Rec. The Vietnamese startup has already seen interest from over 30 Singapore-based companies.

site_title: Modi’s third term can still be lucky for Indian stocks
summary: India's newly re-elected Prime Minister Narendra Modi's third term may still be lucky for Indian stocks, despite a volatile market reaction to the election results. The country's growth fundamentals remain intact, with a projected 6.8% growth rate for 2024 and a decade of economic growth that has lifted millions into the middle class. However, job creation is a potential speed bump, with India struggling to create sufficient new jobs for its growing population. Investors will need to tread carefully and focus on key reforms and individual stocks to uncover differentiated opportunities for earnings growth.

images.alt_text: Narendra Modi's ruling party secured a narrow victory in India's elections; Modi now has to rely on allies for a coalition government.
Indian stocks have been scaling new peaks since the ruling party secured sufficient support from key allies to form a coalition government.
India’s stocks suffered their worst day in more than four years after Modi’s Bharatiya Janata Party garnered fewer seats than expected in the election.
The Reserve Bank of India said the economy will grow at 7.2 per cent this year, against the earlier forecast of 7 per cent.

site_title: Pentagon chief touts China talks and efforts to box Beijing in
summary: US Secretary of Defense Lloyd Austin stated that the US will continue to prioritize the Indo-Pacific region, despite recent conflicts in Europe and the Middle East. He emphasized the importance of partnerships and alliances in the region, highlighting strengthened ties with Japan, South Korea, and Indonesia, as well as military exercises with the Philippines. Austin also noted improved military-to-military communication with China, but refrained from criticizing Beijing directly. He warned that China's actions, such as recent military exercises around Taiwan, will continue to erode regional stability.

images.alt_text: Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr (second from left) meeting Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong at the Istana on May 31. Marcos Jr is in Singapore till Saturday,

During the meeting with his Chinese counterpart, US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin expressed concern about Chinese military activity near Taiwan, including after the island’s presidential election and the inauguration of President Lai Ching-te this month.
Dong Jun’s (above) meeting with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin on Friday will be scrutinised for signs that ties between the superpowers have stabilised.

site_title: US says it could act against China firms, banks over Russian war support
summary: The US has warned China that it could take punitive measures against Chinese firms and financial institutions for supporting Russia's war in Ukraine. US Deputy Secretary of State Kurt Campbell stated that the US and its allies, including Japan and South Korea, will take collective action to signal their displeasure. The allies reaffirmed their commitment to strengthening security and maintaining peace and stability in the Indo-Pacific region. A trilateral leaders' summit is planned later this year, and the US is seeking a collective message from European and NATO countries to express concern over China's actions.

images.alt_text: Dong Jun’s (above) meeting with US Defence Secretary Lloyd Austin on Friday will be scrutinised for signs that ties between the superpowers have stabilised.

site_title: DBS mobile app customers face intermittent access on Saturday
summary: DBS mobile app customers experienced intermittent access issues on Saturday, with over 500 reports of mobile banking problems since 7am on Downdetector. The issue primarily affected Digibank app users, who were unable to log in or faced short-term logouts. However, DBS stated that it has since resolved the issue, allowing all iOS users to access their Digibank mobile services normally. Affected customers could still use other services, such as PayLah and credit cards, to make payments.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of the DBS logo pictured on March 5, 2024.
MAS said that while DBS has made substantive progress to address shortcomings that led to service disruptions, the bank’s remediation plan has not been completed and implementation is still ongoing.
More than 3,000 reports have been made from about 5.45pm about issues relating to mobile banking on outage tracking site Downdetector.

site_title: If AI can do your job, maybe it can also replace your CEO
summary: Artificial intelligence may soon replace CEOs, as the technology becomes more advanced and efficient. Several successful companies have begun experimenting with AI leaders, despite the role's high salary and prestige. A survey of CEOs found that nearly half believe most or all of the CEO role can be automated or replaced by AI. Experts caution that while AI may outsource intelligence, it still requires human leadership for accountability and fiduciary responsibility. Researchers speculate that automation on the executive level could benefit lower-level workers by enhancing worker agency and reducing the need for human bosses.

images.alt_text: Multiple senior leaders had privately shared grave concerns with the former OpenAI board, saying they believed that CEO Sam Altman cultivated “a toxic culture of lying” and engaged in “behaviour (that) can be characterised as psychological abuse”.

site_title: Number of days over 35 deg C surges in world’s scorching capitals
summary: The number of days over 35 degrees Celsius in 20 of the world's largest capitals has surged 52% over the past three decades, with Jakarta experiencing the greatest absolute rise. From 1994 to 2003, Jakarta had 28 days over 35°C, while in the most recent decade it reached 167. This increase is linked to climate change, with cities absorbing and retaining heat due to asphalt and buildings. The rise in extreme heat poses a significant threat to over 300 million people living in these cities, leading to heat-related deaths and school closures.

images.alt_text: The 2021 ruling in the Netherlands against multinational oil giant Shell, which was ordered to reduce its CO2 emissions by 45 per cent by 2030, has become a milestone in climate litigation.
In response to Western tariffs, some Chinese manufacturers have moved to Southeast Asia in recent years.
The global mining industry is facing growing pressure from investors and environmentalists to reduce its carbon footprint.

site_title: Hollywood workers union reaches pay, AI-use deal with top studios
summary: The International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees (IATSE) has reached a tentative three-year deal with major Hollywood studios, including Disney and Netflix, that includes 7%, 4%, and 3.5% pay hikes over the term. The agreement also includes language to prevent AI use from displacing employees and provides protection against AI prompts. This follows a similar deal reached by the SAG-AFTRA actors union, which included pay raises and streaming bonuses amounting to over $1 billion over three years. The deals aim to address the impact of AI on the film and TV industry.

site_title: Meta tops Singapore Michelin Guide with two stars; four restaurants bag one star
summary: Meta, a Korean restaurant in Singapore, has been awarded two Michelin stars, becoming the only Singapore restaurant to achieve this honor in the 2024 Michelin Guide. Four other restaurants, including Araya, Chaleur, Matera, and Pangium, have also received one Michelin star. Meanwhile, two-starred Waku Ghin has been demoted to one star, and modern Malay restaurant Fiz has received a green Michelin star for its sustainability practices. The awards reflect the evolving culinary scene in Singapore, with a focus on heritage cuisine and innovative flavors.

images.alt_text: Meta's new minimalist interiors.

site_title: Traditional edomae at Sushi Oono by former Sushi Mieda chef
summary: Keisuke Ohno, a former Sushi Mieda chef, has opened his new restaurant, Sushi Oono, in Singapore, offering traditional edomae-style sushi with a focus on high-quality fish and unique dishes like deep-fried monkfish in dashi broth. The restaurant, helmed by Ohno and his wife Hiromi, is located at #01-01, 14 Mohamed Sultan Road, Singapore 238963, and is open for lunch and dinner from Monday to Saturday.

images.alt_text: Kotuwa's semi-dark interiors feature a rich colour scheme.

site_title: Asia’s data centre rush is making some unique skills highly desirable
summary: Private equity firms are investing heavily in Asia's data centre industry to meet growing demand for AI computing needs. Key players like KKR and Singtel are seeking skilled operators, including reliable power suppliers, to build and manage data centres. The region's data centre market is expected to continue growing, with Asia-Pacific data centre deals reaching $7.8 billion in 2021, but activity has slowed in recent years. Experts say successful players need a mix of financial heft and operational capability, with specialist infrastructure operators having an advantage due to industry understanding and expertise.

images.alt_text: Digital Realty's data centre facility in Loyang on May 13, 2024. ST PHOTO: KEVIN LIM ocdc13
Singapore is a regional data centre hub, with over 70 data centres.
More than 50 per cent of data centre development activity in the region are found in China, Japan and India, says Colliers.

site_title: Indulge in Queensland’s wellness retreats
summary: The Gold Coast in Queensland, Australia, is home to several luxury wellness retreats, including Eden Health Retreat and SOL Elements. Eden, located in Currumbin Valley, offers comprehensive wellness programs, tranquil accommodations, and digital detox opportunities. SOL Elements, set to open in December 2024, focuses on the regenerative power of earth, air, fire, and water, featuring mineral-rich thermal baths, cold plunge pools, and a Himalayan salt cave. Meanwhile, Chuan Spa at The Langham and Spa by JW at JW Marriott offer upscale spa treatments, including the Couples Retreat package and the Chuan Harmony Massage.
